column2: It is safe to assume that the 468 out of 787 delegates to the Ohio Democratic State Convention who voted for the free-silver-coinage resolution adopted on Wednesday would prefer to see their party remain in control of the National Government. They could have done nothing that would make that more difficult than this resolution makes it.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- The cadet football team spends twenty minutes every day training under direction of Coach Graves. The fourth class promises to supply some fine material. An old football enthusiast who has watched the progress of every team for the last four years says that West Point will have a better team this year than ever before.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Sept. 20. -- The new Science Building, at Bowdoin College, was dedicated and formally presented to the college this afternoon. It is the gift of Edward F. Searles of New-York. As its name indicates, it will be used by the college entirely for scientific work.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 20. -- R.P. Searles, the bicyclist who is riding from Chicago to NewYork in quest of a record, reached this city at 1:15 this afternoon. The rider was badly covered with mud, but said he was feeling in first-rate condition after a hard ride from Batavia. He left Batavia at 10 o'clock this morning, and kept up a pace of fifteen miles an hour to this city.
ALBANY, Sept. 20. -- The Democratic Phalanx, of which Anthony N. Brady is the President, held a meeting to-night and adopted the following:

In a few days, it is said, three suits will be brought against the big railroad company of Brooklyn, and millions of dollars are involved in the proceedings. The first suit will be for an injunction restraining the issuance of $2,500,000 collateral trust notes by the Traction Company and the Brooklyn Heights Railroad.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 21. -- Ex-Secretary of State Cook of this city was asked to-day if he was a candidate for the nomination of Governor at the coming Democratic State Convention.

The anti-Tammany Democracy of the City and County of New-York held primaries in all of the thirty Assembly districts in the city last evening, to elect delegates to the County Convention, the Congressional District Conventions, the Assembly District Conventions, and the Aldermanio Conventions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- One who takes the trouble to sound Democratic sentiment finds that the mention of the name of William C. Whitney in connection with the Democratic nomination for Governor of New-York State meets with general approval. The leading men of the party now in Washington say that his name at the head of the ticket would unquestionably be a tower of strength.

Few people can now be found to dispute what only a few weeks ago very many people disputed, that the advantage of numbers and resources possessed by China over Japan is not decisive either in a short war or a long war. In fact, it is the advantage of Japan over China in knowledge, enterprise, and patriotism that has been very nearly decisive already.

The action recently taken by certain recipients of sugar-bounty money in Louisiana has caused Congressman Robertson of the Sixth District in that State to publish a long statement in which some plain truths are told to these men. "The sugar bounty," he says, " is dead forever. No party will have the temerity to reinstitute it.
The annual convention of the Society of Electro-Therapeutists came to an end yesterday in the Berkeley Lyceum. It was decided to hold the next convention at Boston.

Mme. Emma Fursch-Madi, the well-known opera singer died late on Thursday night at her Summer home in Warrenville, Somerset County, N.J. She had been suffering for three months from cancer of the stomach.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- The proceedings in police court to-day against the five Brooklyn Constitutional Convention delegates for bribery culminated in the formal application for warrants made by counsel for Andrew W. Ford, managing editor of The Albany Argus.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 21. -- The commission appointed to revise the legal and equitable jurisprudence of New-Jersey met at the State House to-day, and about completed its labors.
A large number of up-town property owners attended the meeting of the Board of Street Opening in the Mayor's office yesterday.

It is not creditable to the Republicans of Brooklyn that they should seriously consider the nomination of a candidate from their own party against Judge Edgar M. Cullen of the Supreme Court, who will be renominated by the Democrats. Judge Cullen is upright, able, and sound. He has the qualities of a good Judge.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The statement is made at the Treasury Department that it will be a month or six weeks before Secretary Carlisle fills the vacancy caused by the enforced resignation of Supervising Architect O'Rourke, and that when he does make the appointment, the new Architect will go into a thoroughly-reorganized office, with the scientific and technical branches of the work segregated from the purely administrative branches.
The delegates and alternates elected by the Shepard branch of the Kings County Democracy have made arrangements to go to Saratoga on Monday.
LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The Central News has received the following dispatch from Tokio regarding the recent naval battle. The dispatch is dated Sept. 22, 8:45 A.M.:

The matches preparatory to the interclass matches in the Crescent Athletic Club's tennis handicap tournament have been decided on the Bay Ridge courts, the first class being the last to finish. Carroll J. Post, Jr., defeated A.E. Merlan, after a battle of three sets. The winners of each of the classes have still to play before the final victor is decided.

We hope that Mr. Platt will lose no time in carrying out his plan to set his lieutenants at work "pushing national issues" in this State. He has done all that he could to make State issues, of any logical sort, subordinate to the question of Plattism. That question there is no danger that he can eliminate from the canvass.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- It was a decidedly uninteresting stock market to-day. Orders were few and far between, and brokers were not irclined to speculate. Most of the business was in Diamond Match. The support of insiders, and reports belittling the proposed competition, gave strength to the stock.

Early in the day the railway list was strong. There was very free covering of shorts during the morning, particularly in Rock Island, on the supposition that the Directors of that company would declare the quarterly dividend at the usual rate of 1 per cent. It was argued in favor of this assumption that, although the company might not have earned the full dividend, its position was such that it could pay it with safety.
According to his statements in answer to questions in supplementary proceedings in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday, Prof. Herrmann, the sleight-of-hand expert, has not much property of his own.

Although Mrs. Bishop's "Six. Months Among the Palm Groves, Coral Reefs, and Volcanoes of the Sandwich Islands" was written some years ago, matters in the Hawaiian archipelago have been of such interest of late that the volume under notice is most opportune. In a certain direction, the Hawaiians are a very conservative people, and there are no changes in manners, customs, or habits.

SETAUKET, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Nothing has created so much excitement in this village since the British fired on the old Presbyterian Church as the war between the Handites and the Bayviewites over the naming of a certain street.

The gunboat Machias, whose commander has received orders to prepare the vessel for service in China waters as expeditiously as possible, will be reported ready for sea in two or three weeks. The Machias was commissioned Tuesday for the second time within a year.
Important changes in the fittings of the ammunition hoists of the cruiser New-York have been authorized, and the alterations will be begun at once.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 21 -- The members of the Mercury Wheel Club are very much pleased to-night over the outlook for the race meet at the Driving Club Park to-morrow afternoon. The weather promises to be fair, and the track will be in the best possible condition. No meet held in this vicinity has aroused the interest that this has.

ALBANY, Sept. 21. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners held an adjourned hearing to-day on the application of the Amsterdam, Johnstown and Gloversville Railroad Company for permission to construct its road.

The most interesting point about Tammany's primaries last night to elect delegates to the Democratic State Convention to be held in Saratoga next Tuesday was the re-entry into active participation in political work of Congressman W. Bourke Cockran.
The sentiment among Democrats in favor of the nomination of ex-Secretary William C. Whitney for Governor is so great that it forms a remarkable tribute to Mr. Whitney's popularity and ability.

PITTSBURG, Penn. Sept. 21 -- The game to-day between the Giants and the Pirates was not only the best of the series, but the best game witnessed on the Pittsburg grounds this year. It was exciting from beginning to end. Meekin pitched good ball, and would have won but for the costly errors at firt and behind the bat.

CARMEL, N.Y., Sept, 21. -- If the disposition of the Democrats of the State at large is the same as that exhibited in the County Convention of Putnam County, held here to-day, the party will fight with one purpose in view, and that purpose is victory The fractions that divided the party last Fall have united, and will present a strong front to the enemy in Putnam County at least.
A special meeting of the Council of the Confederation of Good Government Clubs was held at the offices of the President of the Council, J. Augustus Johnson, 58 William Street, yesterday afternoon.

Superintendent Byrnes filed his report with the Police Commissioners yesterday regarding the charges that there were irregularities and fraudulent transactions in connection with the examination of candidates for the force.

Two new and fast steamers, which will ply from Bremen to Asia and Australia, have been, added to the fleet of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company of Bremen. They are named, respectively, Prinz Regent Luitpold and Prinz Heinrich, and are sister ships. They were built by F. Schichau in Danzig, Germany.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 21 -- The intense personal bitterness engendered during the Breckinridge-Owens campaign culminated here to-day in an attack with a knife by Desha Breckinridge, son of W.C.P. Breckinridge, upon James Duane Livingstone, formerly of New-York, where he was a member of Tammany Hall, but now the financial manager here for J. Kennedy Tod, owner of the Kentucky Union Railroad.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21 -- An attorney brought suit in the District Court to-day against Mrs. Paran Stevens for $65. The plaintiff is Edward T. Burge, who early in the season was engaged by Mrs. Stevens as butler, and was discharged after a few days' service.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The Rev. Dr. Burtsell has made public a statement regarding his connection with the Universal Association for the Dissemination of Encyclical Rerum Novarum, in answer to the statement of Cardinal Parocchi, Vicar General of his Holiness the Pope.

The tenement at 388 East Forty-seventh Street was raided yesterday by the Secret Service detectives, and all the members of an Italian family, named Franko, were arrested on a charge of manufacturing and passing counterfeit money.
The Committee of Seventy formally entered yesterday upon the conference phase of its campaign against Tammany Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- The local market started off as if it would work higher, but the Rock Island 1/2 per cent, dividend chilled New-York prices and Philadelphia suffered sympathetically. The members of the Philadelphia Exchange are making every effort to prevent their customers from dealing in New-York stocks, and they have met with wonderful success.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The Constitutional Convention finished its work to-night rather unexpectedly by passing the two amendments which the House of Lords had decided should be selected from the forty odd yet remaining, namely, the militia and the anti-gambling.

Thomas F. Oakes, Henry C. Payne, and Henry C. Rouse, receivers of the Northern Pacific Road, have had several important conferences with representatives of large interests in the property within the past few days, and some important changes are the result of the said conferences.

An Eighth Avenue horse car was stopped by a gang of white and colored men at Bank and Hudson Streets late Thursday night, and at least one passenger was robbed. The stopping of the street car was the last of a series of lawless acts committed in the streets of the Ninth Ward the same night.

AMITYVILLE, Sept. 21 -- The second day of the Fall fair under the auspices of the Agricultural and Driving Park Association drew the largest attendance ever seen on the ground, fully 2,500 persons being present at the harness races in the afternoon. Interest centred in the harness races. Summary:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 21. -- At noon to-day the arguments on the demurrer to the petition of the Central Trust Company of New-York against Stephenson Burke and others were closed by Judge Burke for the defendants, and the demurrer, which really carries the whole case with it, is now in the hands of Judge David F. Pugh of the Common Pleas Court of this county.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The Westminster Gazette and The Star of to-day print articles congratulating the Central News on the excellence of its news service in the East, and thanking it for its "most vivid and lucid war dispatches."
The hearing in the investigation of charges against the management of the city insane asylums was continued yesterday by the State Lunacy Commission at the Park Avenue Hotel.
Business in the executive offices of the Adams Express Company moved along yesterday as smoothly as if a new President had not just taken charge.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Treasury's statement was issued to-day for the twenty days of September. It shows a decided improvement in custom receipts in New-York. The figures are:

The first professional football game of the season at the Polo Grounds will be played this afternoon, between the New-Yorks and Longfellow Club, of Brooklyn. The same will begin at 3:30 P.M., with Thomas Bright as referee. There are several good players in the Longfellow Club, and two or three of them believe that they are strong enough to entitle them to positions on New-York's representative team.

The peculiar spectacle of Federal officers soliciting private contributions of money to enable them to enforce the provisions of the law under which they are commissioned is now afforded by the Inter-State Commerce Commission. That body, through the negligence of Congress, is absolutely without funds, and therefore unable to employ the necessary legal talent to get proper judicial rulings on its orders.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 21 -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Queens County held its fifth annual convention in the Methodist Church here yesterday. There was present thirty-three delegates, representing five of the seven unions in the county.
The money market continued easy. Can loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The bellicose tendencies of Desha Brickinridge are not of recent development. Ever since he came into public notice last March as one of the counsel for his father in the notorious breach of promise trial he has gained his greatest prominence from his disposition to resent by physical means everything that reflected on the Breckinridge side of the case.

OGDENSBURG, Sept. 21 -- Sentaor Higgins of Delaware spoke at the fair to-day on the relations of this country with Canada. He urged a union of the two countries. Canada, he argued -- taking a Republican view of the case -- had secured a benefit in the recent change in the American tariff, but the benefit would be short-lived, a return to higher rates of duty being, in his judgment, absolutely certain.

The builders and building contractors of this city have organized an Employers' League of the Building Trades of New-York City for the purpose of meeting the labor unions on an equal footing and defending themselves against strikes.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee met at the Brooklyn Athenaeum, corner of Clinton and Atlantic Streets, last evening. There was a large attendance of delegates. All the arrangements were perfected for the Assembly District Conventions to be held to-night.

The funeral of William Ellingwood Donnell, late financial editor of The New-York Tribune, took place yesterday afternoon from his residence, 330 West Fifty-sixth Street. There was a large gathering of his former associates and friends.
There was some excitement in the lobby of Daly's Theatre last evening while the audience was entering.
AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- The ecclesiastical trial of Presiding Elder Queal was concluded this afternoon, and resulted in the complete vindication of the accused.

Chairman William Brookfield of the Republican County Committee and John E. Milholland did not shake hands over the bloody chasm last night at the ratification meeting of Oliver Sumner Teall's Second Assembly District Republican Club, which was held at 1 Chambers Street, and thus Oliver Sumner Teall's programme was spoiled.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- Bay State Gas still continues to be the feature of the Boston market; the stock advanced 1, to 14, and the second bonds 1 5/8, to 59 3/4. No news is heard on it, and the rise is believed to be the result of pure manipulation. The telephones were strong, Bell at 203 1/2, 1 1/2 above recent sales, and Erie at 50; a small lot selling at 51.

"Perhaps it is owing to my oversensitiveness, or from reading Ingersoll's suicidal theories, I don't know which. But I know that I have done nothing evil or nothing to merit the reproaches of honest people, (except drink.) May God forgive me."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- Lord Hawke started his second American game here today with the gentlemen of Philadelphia, and so far as the game has gone, a close and interesting match is promised. The wicket to-day was altogether in favor of the bowlers, and the scoring consequently low, but the game was left in a very even state when stumps were drawn for the day.

Everything is in readiness for the Fall games of the New-York Athletic Club, which are expected to result in the breaking of several records at Travers Island to-day. The recent heavy rains caused much anxiety as to the condition of the track, but if the weather to-day is as bright as that of yesterday the track will be thoroughly dried out and in perfect condition for record breaking.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- At the afternoon session of the Constitutional Convention to-day Col. William P. Burr of New-York made his final attempt to bring in his anti-trust amendment. Judge Chester B. McLaughlin of Essex offered a resolution that only two more propositions be considered, that on militia and that on anti-gambling.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 21 -- The steamer Ululanda arrived from Liverpool last night. She called at St. John's and brought from there two members of the Peary auxiliary expedition -- Prof. J. Chamberlain of the University of Chicago and Mr. Bridgman of Brooklyn -- the rest of both the original and auxiliary parties having gone direct to Philadelphia from St. John's in the steamer Falcon.

When the Republican State Committee meets at the Fifth Avenue Hotel next Wednesday it is probable that another exhibition of the "bossism" of ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt will be given. Having nominated his candidate and outlined a campaign on "national issues," the Tioga statesman is expected to select the men who will manage the campaign.

RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 21 -- The licensed maple sugar producers in Vermont will unite to institute a suit against the United States Government for the earned bounties on the crops of 1894, the payment of which has been refused by the Secretary of the Treasury. The suit will be brought before the United States Court of Claims.

READING, Penn., Sept. 21 -- Success was scored by the Perm Wheelmen of Reading with its National Circuit meet to-day. The day was perfect for racing and the track good. A bad hill on the back stretch in this track makes fast time impossible, but grand finishes possible. There were several to-day, and over 4,000 people saw the sport.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn returned from Tennessee yesterday. He is more than ever in favor of the extension of Flatbush Avenue to the bridge entrance. President Harkness of the Department of Assessment and the Mayor went over the map of the proposed extension and figured out the cost of construction.
LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- Thomas Cullen, nineteen years old, a prisoner in the Queens County Jail, in this city, made a desperate attempt to escape from custody this morning.

Vitro Romano, an Italian murdered his wife, Annie, yesterday morning in their rooms on the fourth floor of the large tenement, 299 Mott Street. After shooting her in the neck he quietly went down stairs, observed by most of the other occupants of the building, who knew that he had fired the fatal shot, and, unmolested, walked away.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 21 -- Mr. E.C. Benedict's refusal to be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Governorship of this State is generally regretted by Democrats here and in other sections of the State, where the belief that he would be a candidate strengthened the hope of Democratic success.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 21 -- The fact that the approaching Congressional elections in this State will be held under the operation of the new Australian ballot law is one of the most interesting features of the contest. The point in the new law on which the Republicans and other opponents of the Democrats say they may lose is that it gives the dominant party absolute control of the special constables.

The third attempt to finish the doubles match between Canfleld and Coiling and Fischer and Bostwick, which has been a standing attraction for the last three days in the West Side Tennis Club's tournament, was a success, although play was again prolonged past the time for early candle lighting. Canfield and Collins had the snug handicap of thirty and forty from their opponents.
The strike of the laborers employed on the scows of the Barney Dumping Company against a reduction of wages resulted yesterday in a serious crippling of the Street-Cleaning Department.
The committee of the State Board of Health met in the trial room at Police Headquarters yesterday forenoon to continue its investigation of the Newtown Creek nuisance.
"Beware of blondes!" said Mme. El De Louie, in mysterious tones. "You were born in October, and you are liable to have a great deal of trouble in love. Now, take my advice, and marry your opposite."

Arrangements for Tammany's trip to Saratoga have been completed by the committee which has the matter in charge and which is made up of John F. Carroll, George W. Plunkitt, and James W. Boyle. The schedule for the Tammany Hall trains which will leave the Grand Central Station to-morrow follows:

WEST POINT, Sept. 22. -- The cadet football team is in active training under the supervision of Coacher Graves, who trained Lehigh last year. After the Annapolis game, when the athletic association held its annual meeting for the election of baseball and football managers and Captains, it was decided to ask Graves to coach the '94 team. A correspondence was opened, and matters were arranged satisfactory to both sides.

From The Scranton Truth of Sept. 20. The list of New-York papers claimed by The Scranton Times for the so-called Associated Press makes a beggarly showing as compared with that taking the United Press news service.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The political woods of the Twenty-sixth Senatorial District are just now full of ambitious and designing Republicans after the seat of Senator Saxton, the Republican nominee for Lieutenant Governor, who, it is believed, will soon resign.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Police Justice Adler to-day issued warrants for the arrest of Charles J. Kurth and William Deterling, charged by the city editor of The Albany Argus with bribery, in connection with the payment to them of a per diem compensation for services as delegates to the Constitutional Convention for a period during which they did not serve.
BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- The sixty-first annual report of the Boston and Maine Railroad Company, covering operations and results of the fiscal year ended June 10, 1894, was issued to-day.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 22. -- Large delegations arrived this morning from each of the counties in this Congressional district, to be present at the counting of the returns of the primary in the race between Col. W.C.P. Breckinridge and W.C. Owens. Col. Breckinridge and Desha Breckinridge did not come down, and John Shelby.

LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 22. -- The inauguration of George C. Chase as President of Bates College took place to-day in the college chapel. The exercises were opened with prayer by the Rev. Dr. C.F. Penney, followed by an address by the retiring President, the Rev. O.B. Cheney, who gave an interesting sketch of the history of the institution.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Sept. 22. -- The steam yacht Talisman ran on the beach on the east shore of Willet's Point during a dense fog shortly before 7 o'clock this morning, and was floated off at flood tide this afternoon. The Talisman has been under charter to S. A. Maxwell, Vice President of the National Wall Paper Company, all Summer Her owner is J.B. Thomas of Boston.
OSAGE, Iowa, Sept. 22. -- Five persons were killed by a cyclone which passed five miles north of here at 10 o'clock last night. Many others were hurt and will probably die.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 22. -- Major J.Q. Pangborn of Baltimore, President of the Field Columbian Museum Commission, will sail with his party from New-York on the American liner Paris next Wednesday for a trip around the world in the interests of the museum.
LONG ISLAND CITY, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The Gleason Democracy of Long Island City to-night elected the following delegates to the Democratic State Convention:

A five-chambered revolver, a brutal husband, and a resentful wife were linked a tragedy yesterday shortly after midnight. George Joseph Young, the husband, is dead, and Mrs. Young and her mother, Mrs. Catherine Foster, are locked up in the West Thirty-seventh Street Station.

ALBANY, Sept. 22. -- The Republicans adjourned the Constitutional Convention today until next Thursday evening at 8 o'clock without having determined how the amendments shall be submitted to the people; whether each one shall be presented separately, or in pairs, or on a blanket ballot.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Judge William J. Gaynor left here on the 4 o'clock train for New-York, to take the Long Island Railroad to-morrow morning for Riverhead, L. I., where he has to open a term of court early Monday morning.

As my stepfather continued hidden I did not choose to remain alone with the piratic company who lounged in the gangway or loafed, pipe in mouth, about the galley. I thought to find the stewardess in the saloon, till on descending I recollected I had noticed her face among the emigrants in the boat. I cannot express the extraordinary deep sense of solitude inspired by this interior.

HAVANA, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- At the Schuyler County Democratic Convention at Watkins to-day, Osborn Smith of Reynoldsville was nominated for member of Assembly, Clark M. Smith for Sheriff, A.A. Cowing for County Treasurer, Waldorf Bishop for Judge, Dr. J.M. Quick and D.D.W. Scutt for Coroners.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Motorman Martin of the Plainfield Electric Street Railway, by his presence of mind, saved a child from death to-day. As Martin's car was passing through Grant Avenue, and nearing Second Street, he heard a shutter open in the building at that corner. He looked up, and saw a child standing in the third-story window, balancing itself on the ledge.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 22. -- Pittsburg and New-York had two hard-fought games to-day, and the outcome was a game a piece. Rusie won the first game, but Ehret, in the second, was unconquerable. He only gave New-York four scattering hits.

Through a mistake, Alexander Judge, the truckman who was arrested early Friday morning for obstructing the sidewalk, in front of Lexow Witness George Allison's store, 296 Washington Street, was dlscharged by Justice Ryan, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Applications for the new Democratic campaign book are pouring in upon the Democratic Congressional Committee, and the first issue of 5,000 volumes is already exhausted. It is probable that the presses will be kept running until all demands are met. The general opinion of politicians from different parts of the country is that the book is unusually effective, and they look for good results from its publication.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 22. -- Francis M. Logan, thirty years old, was sentenced to the State Penitentiary to-day for five years for setting fire to the yards of the Kansas City Lumber Company.

HELGOLAND, July 30, 1894. -- July 23, at 1 o'clock, was reached the picturesquely-situated town of Tromso. It is dependent on fishing and the sale of furs. Its commerce with Southern Europe and Russia is wholly in dried fish and skins. No guide, book need tell travelers of the omniprescence in the town of codfish and of cod liver oil.

Mr. F.H. Green, bond clerk in the U.S. Custom House, New-York City, says: "When I went to Prof. Munyon's office I was suffering greatly from catarrh and deafness. There was always an uncomfortable, stuffy feeling in the nose, and the mucus dropping into the throat was a source of constant annoyance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 22. -- United States District Judge Morrow rendered his decision in the case of the Salvadorean refugees to-day. The court, after reciting the demand of the Salvadorean Government for the refugees, went into a history of the Ezeta Administration, which began in March, 1891, and the revolution of this year.

PARIS, Sept. 22. -- To-day being the date fixed for the issue of the new Panama Canal shares to the amount of 30,000,000f., a representative of the United Press called upon M. Gautron, the liquidator of the old Panama Canal Company, and inquired as to the probable amount of the subscriptions.
SARATOGA SPRINGS. N.Y. Sept. 22. -- Congress Hall on Thursday morning closed its doors for the season.

The announcement made by The NewYork Times last Sunday or Father Hyacinthe's conversion to Archbishop Ireland's methods of Catholic reform has deeply interested the friends whom he has retained in this country.

SETAUKET, L.I., Sept. 22. -- Scudder Jayne, Captain by virtue of prowess on land and sea, and by grace of the taxpayers of Setauket Overseer of Town Roads, vowed yesterday that there would be no "Hand Avenue" in this village to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- The conservative element in the Philadelphia Stock Exchange has been again at what seems to them to be an electrical craze. It was first the Trolley, then Wellsbach, and now the Electric Storage Battery Company. On July 3,500 shares of Electric Storage Battery stock sold at auction in Philadelphia at 50 cents per share.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Sept. 22. -- This place is soon to have a commodious Town Hall, which will provide ample accommodations for all the varied departments of the Municipal Government. Plans have already been accepted, and the work of construction will be begun at once. The building is to be situated in Springfield Avenue, next to the Reformed Church.

HIGHLAND, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- A new religious fad has been taken up by the church people here. The people of the Presbyterian and Methodist Episcopal Churches are engaged in a mild scramble for money to swell the treasuries of their respective societies, and the fad is to secure this money by practicing unusual occupations, economizing in personal and household expenditures, and begging.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Only a knot of Democrats are here to-night, but they are all leaders. The United States Hotel, which in the past has been the abiding place of the politicians, is now given up to 800 Unitarians, and De Lancey Nicoll, the only delegate to the convention who is registered there, looks solitary and alone as he pushes his way through the crowds of strangers.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The little locality known as "Harmony Park," in the upper part of this city, bounded on one side by North Broadway and on the other by Warburton Avenue, has of late been a little out of harmony, owing to an annoyance Frederick Blake was put to in his endeavor to keep miscellaneous picnickers and tramps from making a thoroughfare through his premises.

THURSDAY, Sept. 27. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale. S.L.H. Ward, referee, 75 West Ninety-first Street, north side, 125 feet east of Columbus Avenue, 18 by 100.8 1/2 Three -- story brownstone dwelling. Due on judgment, $15,890.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 22. -- The Democratic Convention for the First Assembly District of Queens County to elect three delegates to the State Convention, eight delegates to the First Congressional District Convention, and one delegate to the Judiciary Convention, met in the Queens County Court House, in this city, at noon to-day.

An excellent idea of the Autumn styles may be obtained by visiting the store of Stern Brothers, 38 West Twenty-third Street. The show windows are so beautiful that a crowd lingers in front of them all the time.

The last seven weeks show a very decided improvement in building operations in Brooklyn. During the period, plans have been filed for 436 buildings, to cost $1,697,119. During the corresponding period last year there were filed 182 plans for buildings to cost $804,230, or less than one-half as many. The average cost last year was about $4,420, as against $3,900 this year.

The committee to notify ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton that he has been nominated for Governor by the Republicans was made public yesterday. The sedate ex-Senator Warner Miller named the gentlemen yesterday, and from the personnel of the committee it looks as if there would be a very entertaining spectacle when the time comes for the committee to perform its functions.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 22. -- The best cycle meet ever held in this part of Long Island was managed to-day at the Driving Club Park by the Mercury Wheel Club. It had been twice postponed, but this only served to make it additionally attractive. Fully 2,000 people were present. All of the events were interesting, only pure amateurs being eligible to compete.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 22. -- The Sugar Planters' Convention of the First Congressional District met to-day at noon at Poydras, in St. Bernard Parish, and selected Henry P. Kernochan as the sugar candidate for Congress in that district. His name will be submitted to the regular Republican committee Monday for ratification.

The yachting season is lasting this year longer than usual. Last year it kept on until the middle of October, owing to the international races, but usually it closes about the middle of September. Several races were sailed last week, and yesterday seemed more like a Saturday in the middle of Summer rather than one at the close of the season.

We do not recall, in the literature of war and statesmanship, any correspondence like unto this. Indeed, if there be any such, the resemblance probably is not closer than the fact that two brothers engaged in it. Gen. Sherman and his brother, Senator Sherman, are both men whose eminence has been peculiar.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 22. -- The Secretary of the Navy has received two cablegrams from Admiral Carpenter, commanding the Asiatic station, both dated Tien-Tsin, Sept. 21. The first says: "Chinese routed, PingYang, 15th. Sixteen thousand killed and wounded. Viceroy lost feather and jacket under edict prior to recent defeat."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- News comes from Texas that the Populists are strong in several of the Congressional districts, and that they entertain the hope of being able to elect Representatives to Congress. Mr. L.P. Harris of Texas, who is in the city this week, has given an interesting account of the situation in the Lone Star State.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- Among the many public works in course of construction in Westchester County there are two of more importance than the others, perhaps, on account of their magnitude and the object in view.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The traveling, men, not only of the State of NewYork, but of nearly every State in the Union, are making elaborate preparations for the laying of the cornerstone of their proposed home, which will take place on Oct. 9. Without doubt the people of this city will witness the largest concourse of strangers and distinguished personages it has ever been their good fortune to see.

What Should be the exact duty of savings banks to their patrons is a question that is solved differently by different institutions. The locking up of a large amount of capital in a building from which no rents accrue is regarded by some conservative Directors as a risky proceeding, and therefore a wrong to depositors, because the rate of interest that is decreed upon deposits varies with the income of the bank.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22. -- It is a remarkably quiet September in Newport. Mrs. George B. De Forest, Mrs. H.M. Brooks, and Mrs. N. Devereaux Clapp are the only ones that are now pretending to entertain at all.

ALBANY, Sept. 22. -- Senator David B. Hill and Congressman Charles Tracey were today selected as delegates by the Albany Democracy to the State Convention. Mr. Hill said that he was undecided whether he would sit in the convention, but it is likely that he will, for he is being urged to do so by both factions of the party here.

Summer outings so fully come up to that expression nowadays that women of all tastes and inclinations are coming home from their boating and bathing, bicycling and walking, and general outdoor life looking healthy, brown, and vigorous, ready to take up their Winter work and club life.

From London Truth. Men whose religious or political sentiments move them to stand bareheaded whenever the national anthem is performed in the open air have, of course, every right to do so, more especially as they appear to be in the majority. They often need reminding, however, that they have not the slightest right to interfere with those who see no reason for such demonstrations.

From The Montreal (Ontario) Herald. The beauty of the law of supply and demand was never better exemplified than in the matter of Gen. Wolfe's sword. No one for many years heard anything about the sword of the gallant young soldier, but now that the Minister of the Militia has purchased one, the supply has become so great as to glut the market.

The fair dealing and persistent energy which are Mr. William Easton's characteristics are shown in the announcement which appears in this issue of The New-York Times. It has been known for some time that the ratio of expenses to which horse dealers were put in disposing of large consignments in the New-York market have not followed the decrease of value which has existed in the horse trade, as in every other business.

Herbert M. Kinsley, one of the proprietors of the Holland House, died yesterday morning from the effects of a surgical operation which he underwent last Thursday. He was in his room at the hotel, surrounded by his family, consisting of his wife and three daughters. He was sixty-three years old, genial in disposition, of wide acquaintance with men from all over the country, and popular as the typical boniface.

The Staten Island Ferry controversy assumed a new aspect yesterday morning, when the Corporation Counsel was served with a temporary injunction granted by County Judge Clute of Albany restraining the sale of the ferry franchise, which was advertised to take place at 11 o'clock.

The principal theatrical event of this week in this city will, be the appearance to-morrow night, at the Star Theatre, of William H. Crane as Sir John Falstaff, in a production of "The Merry Wives of Windsor," which has been in contemplation by the comedian for the last three years. "The Merry Wives" has never been among the most popular of Shakespeare's plays, either in England or America.

LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The Times's Shanghai correspondent telegraphs that advices have been received from Chemulpo, under date of Sept. 16, stating that a fleet of thirty-two Japanese transports, convoyed by a number of war ships, has arrived there. The transports had on board 7,000 soldiers, 3,000 coolies, and 2,000 pack horses.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- The troubles of Anthony W. Dimock, once one of the most prominent financiers of New-York City, who for some time has been living at the Peakamoose Clubhouse, in the town of Denning, Ulster County, and J.Q.A. Ward, the sculptor, reached a very sensational climax a few days ago, when Mr. Ward and an officer, armed with a warrant of dispossession, forced Mr. Dimock and his family to vacate the premises.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 22. -- ExSenator John C. Jacobs of Brooklyn died at his cottage here at 8:05 o'clock this evening, of Bright's disease of the kidneys, from which he had long been a sufferer.

With inspiration and fresh enthusiasm gathered from the highways and byways of Summer travel, the members of Sorosis have come back to town full of plans and purposes for a Winter of unusual activity in club work and pleasure. The "social day," on the first Monday in October, will mark the Autumn awakening.

FRIDAY, Sept. 28. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale. Edward Jacobs, referee, lot on St. Nicholas Avenue, east side, 60 feet south of One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, 35.2 3/8 by 58.7 bv 30 by 40.2. Due on judgment, $4,340.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: It may be remembered by your readers that some three or four years ago frequent allusion was made to the fact that College Place, a wellknown down-town street, containing many valuable improvements in the way of warehouses, , had, at the request of the authorities of the City of New-York, been allowed by the Legislature to be widened and improved.

Those who are brought much in contact with the defective and delinquent classes must often doubt the lasting utility of much of the work that is done for them. It sometimes seems as if in a certain number of cases the principal result attained is a provision for the survival of the unfit. If such an opinion occasionally finds voice it cannot apply to children.

Travers Islana, the pretty Summer home of the New-York Athletic Club, was comfortably crowded yesterday afternoon by lovers of outdoor sport, who journeyed thither to witness the fifty-third games of the well-known organization. Admission was by invitation only, and the assemblage was far better than is usually seen at athletic games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Evidences continue to multiply that the contest in the district of Representative Wilson of West Virginia will be the hottest the State has ever known. The enemies of Mr. Wilson in the Democratic Party have combined with the Republicans to bring about his defeat, if possible, and every wire is being pulled to that end.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 22. -- Senator Voorhees read closely from printed slips his keynote speech for the Indiana Democracy to-night. No unusual effort was made to get out a crowd, as it seemed to be understood that Mr. Voorhees's speech was more for national interest than local effect.

STAPLETON, S.I., Sept. 22. -- The County Convention of the regular Democartic organization of Richmond County, was held in the German Clubroom, at this place this afternoon, and delegates were chosen to the State Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22. -- There was another fashionable and large attendance at the cricket game here to-day between Lord Hawke's team and the Gentlemen of Philadelphia, but the crowd was doubled, and there were fully 10,000 spectators present in the afternoon. The warm weather enabled the ladies to don their prettiest gowns.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 22. -- Henry Gruber, one of the leaders of the Labor Party in this city, holds a clerkship in the Street and Water Department. He is also an aspirant for an Assembly nomination on the Republican ticket. Mayor Wanser sent for him yesterday, he says, and told him that if he proposed to become an Assembly candidate he would have to resign his clerkship under the City Government.

There are 4,000 children in Brooklyn who want to go to school, but who are unable to do so, because there are no seats for them in the public schools. They are of the legal school age, and they are entitled to free tuition, but owing to the lack of accommodations, they cannot get into the public schools.

From The Electrical Review. An Englishman discovered electricity; a Prussian, in the land of amber, invented the first electrical machine. Otto Guericke of Magdenburg, who also invented the air pump, formed the instrument by which electricity could be most readily produced. He placed a globe of sulphur on an axle, to be turned by the hand of the operator, while with the other he applied a cloth to the sulphur to produce the necessary friction.

BOSTON, Sept. 22. -- State Senator John P. Fitzgerald will be the Democratic nominee for Congress in the Ninth District, and Congressman McEttrick will not be the regular nominee in the Tenth. These are the two features of the Boston caucuses held last night by the Democratic Party.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 22. -- The petition that has been sent to Mr. J.K. Cowen is one of the most unusual things of the kind in Maryland politics. It begins as follows: "The Democratic Party of Maryland is about to lose the services of the Hon. Isidor Rayner, who has so ably and conscientiously represented the Fourth District in Congress for three terms," and it goes on to say: "We recognize in you the qualities necessary.

Postmaster Charles W. Dayton returned on the Paris of the American Line from his vacation yesterday. He was met at the dock by a number of his friends, who warmly congratulated him on the success of his trip, as indicated by his appearance. He is well browned, and has added to his weight as well as to his store of knowledge la things postal, by his trip and experience in England.

From The Westminster Gazette. President Lincoln used to tell this story: A friend of his came to him one day, saying, "Me and wife have quarreled." "Indeed, how so?" asked Lincoln. "She wants the house painted red, I want it white." They parted, to meet a fortnight later. "How's your quarrel?" asked Lincoln.

Copyright, 1894. LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The tide of gold has at last turned outward for the first time this year. A good amount has been taken from the Bank of England for Germany, but the movement is probably but temporary, and has had no effect on rates, and the attempt of the banks to lift them has proved abortive.

-- The temple of Jupiter Anxur, on Mount St. Angelo at Terracina, which was a centre of worship for the people of Monte Ciceo, has been excavated. The orientation is from north to south. Outside the eastern wall of the temple a square subterranean cavity, containing votive objects, was found. This was probably the "favissae," or treasury cellar.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 22. -- Exceptional racing was seen to-day at the annual race meet of the Associated Cycling Clubs of Philadelphia. The attendance was the largest ever seen in this city at a bicycle race, fully 10,000 people swarming around the entire outside of the track.

ALGONA, Iowa, Sept. 22. -- Twenty-six persons are reported killed in Kossuth County, and thirty-nine injured, some fatally, while the greater part of the town of Cyclinder, twenty miles west, was badly damaged by the storm which swept over this section of the country last night.

TOLLAND, Conn., Sept. 22. -- Tolland County, of which this is the shire town, is one of the closest counties of the State on a matter of elections, though in normal years it is more than apt to return Democratic county officers and a delegation of town representatives to the Assembly Democratic in the majority.

Collis P. Huntington, President of the Southern Pacific Railroad, speaking of the general improvement in railroad business, said yesterday: "As I view the situation, matters are improving all the time. The improvement is slow, but quite steady. Things are working just about as I thought they would and as I explained during the worst period of the financial depression.

From The Washington Post. An example of the cynical philosophy and agnosticism of the early days of the Republic, when it is popularly supposed that these outcroppings of thought were unknown, is given in the will of an eccentric Virginian which reposes in the will vault of the City of Richmond. It was drawn by Alexander Campbell Nov. 27, 1795, and admitted to probate March 3, 1812, in the Probate Court for that county.

Many signs of the decline and fall of the British Empire have been from time to time set forth by the French press and by the leading organs of Oshkoshian and Sheboyganese opinion. Curiously enough, not a single editor has, however, mentioned the respirator in enumerating the dangers which threaten England.

ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 22. -- A Whitney delegation to the State Convention was elected by the Democratic Convention of the Second Assembly District of Queens County, which was held in Pearsall's Hotel, in this village, to-day.

From The Boston Journal. The phase man was dilating on the value of politeness everywhere, but especially in stores, and remarked that he would discharge a clerk for impoliteness or inattention quicker than he would for petty theft. Impolite or inattentive clerks rob their employer of more money in the course of the year than do the thieves.

William T. Meredith of 11 West Twelfth Street was assaulted and robbed last Tuesday night, at 9:30, while standing in Fifth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets. His face was badly cut, his eyes were blackened, and his watch was stolen. At the request of the police, he refrained from making the fact known until yesterday, to aid them in arresting his assailants.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Mr. O'Rourke, the retiring Supervising Architect of the Treasury, left here to-day for Newark, N. J., to resume his private business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The stories which are being circulated relative to the alleged poverty of the Democratic Congressional Committee are not causing the Democratic leaders any annoyance. Senator Faulkner, Chairman of the committee, said to-night that, while the committee did not possess a large bank account, it was receiving subscriptions right along, which were being used to defray the expenses of preparing materials for use in the campaign.

KNOXVILLE, Iowa, Sept. 22. -- A terrific hail and rain storm visited this city and vicinity at 5 o'clock last evening. The damage by hail is very great. In the Home for the Adult Blind. 160 window panes were broken, and in the Court House a large Slumber were broken and the damage to private houses was general.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 22. -- The first society dance of the season was held at the Casino of the Union County Country Club Tuesday night. It was a german, and was arranged by Miss Maude Van Boskerck and Miss Grace Cooley. The figures were unique and pretty. The german was led by Clifford McGee, with Miss Grace Cooley.

PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The past month has been dull to a most uncommon degree. Even the political world seems inclined each year to take a holiday, which is certainly comfortable for everybody else. Ambassadors the Ministers, all the Deputies and representative working people of international emotions, are resting with more or less enjoyment.

Sugar Justified the common expectation that when it should be quoted ex dividend it would slide down below par; and Rock Island surprised some people, and did not surprise others, by reducing its dividend from 1 to 1/2 per cent., which thus puts the stock on a 2 per cent, basis. This was really the event of the week.
ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. William H. Rockfellow of Arlington Avenue gave a card party on Friday evening.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 22. -- The Democrats of Suffolk County had a harmonious convention here to-day, and its action is representative of the feeling that prevails among the Democrats of this county.

Writer's cramp is sufficiently well known, but it is only in countries in which the use of the cigarette displaces all other forms of enjoying the "weed" that smoker's cramp is heard of. This affection is common enough in Spain, notwithstanding that the Spaniard is so expert that he can roll a cigarette with a single movement of the hand.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. Sept. 22. -- Ground has been broken on Cannon Street for the new Masonic Temple which the several Masonic organizations in Poughkeepsie propose to erect at a total cost of about $35,000. When completed, it will be the only Masonic Temple in any city except Troy between New-York and Syracuse.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 22. -- Advices by mail to Percival Lowell from his observatory at Flagstaff confirm the observations of the satellites of Mars, which have been seen on several evenings. Sept. 10, at midnight, they were observed near elongation, their positions according closely with those given for them in the Nautical Almanac, but to Mr. Douglass, the observer, it seemed that Phobos, the inner moon, had a motion in the wrong direction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Don M. Dickinson of Michigan reached Washington on Thursday, and in the afternoon argued a case in the District court. In the evening Mr. Dickinson called at the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Committee and discussed Michigan politics with Senator Faulkner and several other gentlemen who were present.

The good-natured looking ticket puncher at one of the gates in a Grand Central Station waiting room was temporarily idle the other afternoon, when a questioner accosted him: "Will it be this door or the other for the 3:45 train?" "Both," replied the man, and then, with a reminiscent smile that detained his questioner, he added: "I suppose I should say eyther.
The sales referred to in the accompanying list will be held at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated.

Brooklyn has had a great deal of experience in Mayors since the first days when she could hardly call herself grown up. That was sixty years ago, and she long ago developed into ample proportions and assumed matronly airs, and her Mayor now is a great man.

What kind of an art is this comic opera, so-called, which so cheerfully dispenses with ability to act? Here is a form of amusement capable of reaching an admirable level, yet content to dance gayly along the border line of what Mr. Hoyt calls farcecomedy, with occasional excursions into Miss Margaret Cline's notable province of "vaudeville." There are several actors on the operetta stage, but they are all men.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 22. -- The Lenox cottagers have had an exceedingly busy week. There are more well-known people here than for a number of years. The Diplomatic Corps is particularly well represented.

There are some Republican lawyers in Brooklyn who believe that it is their duty to place in nomination a member of their party for the office of Justice of the Supreme Court, to succeed Justice Edgar M. Cullen, whose term of office expires Dec. 31, but these Republican lawyers are very few.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- 8 P.M. -- Forecast for Monday: NEW-ENGLAND and EASTERN NEW-YORK, showers in the early morning, followed by fair, cooler, winds becoming nortnwest. WESTERN NEW-YORK, generally fair, cooler, northwest winds.
Julius Harburger, Grand Master of the Independent Order of Free Sons of Israel, addressed the members of Zion Lodge, No. 38, yesterday afternoon at Odd Fellows' Hall touching the A.P.A. He said:

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 23. -- Congress has taken up the investigation of the famous Romero-Verastegui duel, in which the latter, who was practically a member of the Cabinet, by reason of his position as chief of the Government stamp department, lost his life. The Chamber of Deputies yesterday occupied itself with the duel. The proceedings were secret.

Railroad men are smiling at what they imagine to be a huge joke on General Passenger Agent Charles E. Lambert of the West Shore Railroad, played by Emil Porges, or Blum, as he calls himself, who was until recently connected with Eldorado, in Weehawken.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 23. -- Manager Barnie of the Louisville Baseball Club announced tonight that Brooklyn has accepted his terms for the transfer of Pfeffer and Grim to that club for next season.

In referring the other day to the folly of the Ohio Democrats in adopting a resolution in favor of free silver in their State Convention, we remarked that it would be easy to exaggerate the significance of such action as an indication of party feeling, while it would be impossible to exaggerate its stupidity.

The Tombs Police Court and the Court of Special Sessions, which were to have been transferred to the new Criminal Court Building on Oct. 1, will probably remain in the Tombs Building for two months longer.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Under the most favorable circumstances, the Westchester Cycling League held its second semi-annual century run to-day. The roads were exceptionally good, save for several short stretches, and at the outset there were 110 enthusiasts in line. This number included three of the gentler sex. The run was to Hicksvllle, L.I., and return, over a route that delighted the cyclers.

If it were known that William C. Whitney would accept a nomination for Governor we think the Saratoga Convention would nominate him by acclamation. If he were here and accessible, we think his party's need and the urgency of its appeal would overcome his disinclination and constrain his acceptance.
The police report that there were 157 arrests yesterday for violations of the excise law.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23. -- The opening of the present college year at Princeton marks many important advancas in the curriculum. The number of the elective studies has been largely increased and subjects of the higher classes have been brought down to the lower ones. The freshmen and sophomores are giver, a slight range at choice, while members of the two upper classes have almost unlimited freedom in arranging their schedules.

VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 23. -- The steamship Victoria, which arrived from the Orient last evening, brought among her passengers Capt. Galsworthy, commander of the famous Kow-Shing, who is returning to England, and also the very latest mail advices of the war in the far East. These confirm the plans of the Japanese forces in Corea. outlined in the cable advices.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- After the conspicuous failure made by the Cornell team on the football field a year ago there seems some disposition among the players here to go at the game with renewed vigor this season. From a team which in the season of 1892 ranked with the first four or five among the great colleges, Cornell in 1893 fell to the rank of a third or fourth class team.
AURORA, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Wells College opened Tuesday with a large incoming class and favorable prospects for a successful year.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 23. -- The positive refusal of Mr. Benedict of Greenwich and New-York to accept the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination makes possible the nomination of Morris B. Beardsley of this city. Leading Democratic newspapers in the State indorse him, and the delegates from this city, New-Haven, and Hartford have indorsed him. Judge Beardsley said to-night that he was in the hands of his friends, and would accept the nomination if it came to him.

The fourth annual penathalon contest of the Young Men's Christian Associations of New-York State for the championship was held Saturday at the association's grounds, One Hundred and Fiftieth Street and Walton Avenue. The programme was made up of a hundred-yard dash, throwing twelve-pound hammer, running high jump, pole vault, and one-mile run.
ALBANY, Sept. 23. -- Gov. Flower was asked to-night who he thought would be nominated by the Democratic Convention on Tuesday.

While on the surface, as indicated by the sales on the Stock Exchange, the bond market to a casual observer appeared dull the past week, in reality it has been far from being so, that is in the high grade bonds. A large demand has existed, and nearly all the floating bonds have been exhausted. Higher prices have obtained than for many months.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- A bold attempt was made last night to wreck a passenger train on the Central-Hudson Railroad between here and Bergen. The train is known as No. 46, the fast mail which leaves Buffalo at 7:30 P.M., and is due here at 9:15. Last night it was late and was trying to make up time, going at about the rate of fifty-five miles an hour.

From The New-York Recorder of Sept. 20. It is becoming more and more apparent that the so-called "Associated Press" is not attempting to gather the news these days, or, if it is, it certainly fails, for that energetic institution known the world over as the United Press is scoring a "scoop " against it almost daily.

With the approach of October, the uptown avenues and the drives in Central Park are beginning to take on an appearance of life and activity which has been lacking ever since the Summer season set in. The warm, yet clear, and perfect weather yesterday afternoon served to bring out a larger array of stylish equipages than has been seen on Seventh Avenue at anytime this season.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- There is a thread of romance in the mystery surrounding the case of William D. Stevens, who lies in the Massachusetts General Hospital hovering between life and the death which he evidently sought. Stevens is a man fifty years old, although he looks fully fifteen years younger.

The Democrats at Saratoga should speak out in a frank and manly fashion about the new Tariff act and its tax reductions. It is a Democratic act, it is a reform act, and it will benefit the people of the country. It is not all that was expected, it is imperfect, it was maimed toy un-Democratic hands after it left the House.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Yesterday was an eventful day with Democrats in the three Assembly districts of this county. Five conventions were held, all factional ones, the party not uitting in any instance.

GREENVILLE, N.H., Sept. 23. -- The mills of the Columbian Manufacturing -- Company will start on full time to-morrow. They furnish the principal industry of the town, and have been running only four days a week for the last ten months.

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- The demonstration at Narzin to-day was marred by the heavy rain, which fell throughout most of the day. The roads were hardly passable, but this did not deter the people from the vicinity from gathering about the railway station at Hammersmuhie to await the arrival of the special trains.

Some person threw a potato that came near striking Archbishop Corrigan yesterday during the ceremonies attending the cornerstone laying of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, in East Eighty-seventh Street.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 23. -- The Brooklyns took advantage of the Reds' bad fielding and won the first game. The second was taken by the Reds, on account of Daub's bases on balls. Attendance, 6,484. Score:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, has returned from visits to Michigan and Ohio, where he made addresses before the Bank Associations of the two States. To the correspondent of The New-York Times, who inquired as to the general condition of business affairs in the States mentioned, Mr. Eckels said to-day:

BERLIN, Sept. 23. -- Apparently with a desire to associate the opening of the Reichstag in the new and splendid Parliament building in Leipzigerstrasse with the imperial house, the Kaiser has ordered that the session shall begin on Nov. 21, the anniversary of the birth of his mother, the ex-Empress Frederick.
LYONS, Sept. 23. -- In the bicycle races to-day Zimmerman won the Grand Prix de la Ville, a five-kilometer race. Wheeler was second.

It is difficult for those who patronize the harness races in the East to realize fully the speed development of the past decade. Since Jay-Eye-See turned the course at Narragansett Park, Providence, in 2:10 during the season of 1884, not one of the Eastern tracks has been the scene of a world'srecord-breaking performance.

COLLEGE POINT, Sept. 23. -- Fair women, a splendid day, and plenty of wind characterized the ladies' day regatta or the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, which was sailed yesterday over the club's triangular course from the clubhouse at College Point to a stakeboat off Barretto's Point, thence to the stakeboat off Clausen's Point, thence to the clubhouse, twice over.
The Rev. Dr. J.A.B. Wiison preached two sermons, with the pollce for texts, at the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Carl Von Lengerke, the winner of the Irvingrton-Millburn race a year ago, won the Atalanta Wheelmen's ten-mile road race for members yesterday, but finished more dead than alive, from exhaustion. Von Lengerke rode in his characteristic plucky style. He left the three one-minute men from the start, overhauled man after man, and then punctured his tire near the turning point at Springfield.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- The Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company has filed protests at revenue offices, both in Chicago and Peoria, against the new tariff law's provision for increased bonds which the distillers are compelled to give to secure the payment of the tax on the spirits bonded before the new law went into effect. Distillers were under bonds to the full amount of the whisky in the warehouses at 90 cents per gallon.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 22. -- Pittsburg has very little to boast of to-day in the way of gains, whether in general business or securities. Trade was not above the average in any quarter, while in some instances the volume of trade was lower, Local securities still rule dull, and there are no important changes in quotations beyond a slight gain in Air Brake and softer prices for street railways.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Sept. 23. -- Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle arrived here at 12:30 o'clock this afternoon on the lighthouse tender John D. Rodgers, having left New-York late yesterday afternoon. The President and Mrs. Cleveland welcomed him cordially at Gray Gables. Capt. Schley of the Rodgers accompanied him ashore. After lunch the party enjoyed an informal chat on the veranda, as the day was pleasant and warm.

TONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The Yonkers Canoe Club held a very successful regatta yesterday afternoon over the club course on the Hudson in front of the clubhouse at Glenwood. The races were well contested, and there were some good finishes.

The sun shone through a window of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon and fell upon something which glowed and glistened like a living coal. It was the neatly-groomed head of "Johnnie" Simpson, Republican leader in the Fifth Assembly District, and sponsor for the Gubernatorial boom that belonged to Gen. Daniel Butterfield.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- A dispatch from Vienna to The Daily News says that, according to a Cracow newspaper, the Czar was recently stricken with an apoplectic fit, and arrived at Spala in so weak a condition that he had to be carried out of the railway car.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Sept. 23. -- The injustice of the present Constitution, which makes the town the basis of legislative apportionment, is keenly felt in this city, which suffers by reason of it. Democrats and Republicans alike recognize the inequalities and injustice of it, although for partisan reasons Republicans are disposed to crowd the issue out of sight.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 23. -- With very desirable prizes and a track pronounced by the racing men to be one of the best ever constructed for cycling purposes, the fourth meet of the Crescent Wheelmen on Saturday next should easily prove the most successful ever held by this popular and influential club.

If John H. Seitz of Detroit can find Willlam D. Trombley, formerly a waiter at the St. Denis Hotel, he thinks he can establish his claim to an interest in a large tract of land, worth $150,000, and situated near Detroit.
LONDON, Sept. 23. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Shanghai, dated this afternoon, says the missing Chinese transports have arrived safely at Ta-Ku, in the Gulf of Pe-Chee-Lee.

The London Economist prints an interesting review of some of the features of the Baring liquidation and the relations to it of the Bank of England, as shown by a comparison of the statement of Sept. 1, 1893, and that of Sept. 1, 1894. A year ago the liabilities were $23,210,000, with an apparent surplus, at the then valuation of securities, of $2,095,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 23. -- Reports of the destruction wrought by Friday night's cyclone indicate that the loss of life will be in the neighborhood of seventy-five, while the injured will number several times as many. Some of those hurt are expected to die, and it is not unlikely that fully 100 persons will be numbered in the list of the cyclone's fury.

SARATOGA, Sept. 23. -- Those representatives of the contesting delegations from New-York City and Kings County who are already here passed Sunday very quietly and held nothing in the nature of formal conferences.

Mme. Fursch-Madi, the famous opera singer, died in poverty. Her last days were spent in a small, lonely cottage at Plainfield, N.J. So great was her poverty that her body will rest in an unmarked grave unless her former friends and pupils come forward and assist her little daughter, who has temporarily been taken in charge by one of Fursch-Madi's former pupils, Mrs. Keyne, nee Attila Claire.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23. -- Gen. Antonio Ezeta, ex-President of Salvador, in an interview as to his future intentions, said to-day:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The question of the water supply in the State of New-Jersey now comes up for consideration under two phases. One is presented by the legislation now proposed to have the State take control of the water supply or of the watersheds in the State of New-Jersey.

SARATOGA, Sept. 23. -- It has been a number of years since the advance body of Democrats who gather at a State Convention has assembled in any such frame of mind as that in which the prominent members of the party here to-day find themselves. There are fifty or more of these Democrats here representing the Shepard organization of Kings, Tammany, the State Democracy, and the Democracy of the interior of the State.

Superintendent Thomas Byrnes did not go to church yesterday morning. Instead, he went to Police Headquarters, in Mulberry Street, and while there gave out a brief statement, denying positively that he had ascribed the bold highway robberies and other acts of lawlessness last week to the demoralization of the police by the Lexow and police investigations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Capt. Henry W. Plummer, the colored Chaplain of the Ninth Cavalry will be dismissed from the service of the United States if the President approves the sentence imposed by a court-martial.

STAPLETON, S.I., Sept. 24. -- The organization of Richmond County Democrats which was formed two years ago to oppose the domination of Nicholas Muller in the party and in the county held a County Convention at this place this afternoon and elected a delegation, which started at once for Saratoga to contest the right of the delegates selected last Saturday to a seat in the convention as the representatives of the praty in Richmond County.

C. W. Kellogg's fast colt Azmon yesterday won The hard-fought seven-heat trotting race postponed from lest Saturday's matinee at Fleetwood Park, when darkness came on after three of the contending trotters had won two heats apiece. There was a good deal of jockeying for the advantage in the deciding heat yesterday, the horses being kept at the post fifty minutes before they could be gotten away on even terms.

READING, Penn., Sept. 24. -- A special meeting of the Grand Trustees of the Grand Lodge of Elks of the United States was held here this afternoon to consider the disagreements and dissensions in the order. When the order was founded, it consisted mostly of theatrical men and those who found it convenient to meet on Sunday.

Whatever may be the truth about the reported and denied invasion last week of a street car by a band of highway-men, there is no controversy about the assaults upon two respectable and inoffensive men by gangs of rowdy criminals, on two successive evenings, in the heart of New-York.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 24. -- Some important political conferences are likely to be held in Indianapolis to-morrow. Gov. McKinley left this afternoon for the Hoosier capital, accompanied by his confidential appointees, Librarian Joseph P. Smith, Private Secretary Boyle, State Chairman Dick, and others. They will reach Indianapolis by midnight to-night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24. -- The steamer City of Rio de Janeiro arrived from the Orient shortly before 9 o'clock this mornins. She brings Chinese advices up to Aug. 29 and Japanese advices up to Sept. 9.

SARATOGA, Sept. 24. -- The first delegation to arrive this morning was from Erie County. It embraced Daniel Lockwood, member of Congress; Norman E. Mack, editor of The Buffalo Times, and Augustus Scheu, former Police Commissioner. None of the other delegates had arisen when the Buffalo contingent came to town.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Secretary Herbert decided to-day to add the-Yorktown to the Asiatic squadron. On reaching this decision he promptly telegraphed orders to the Mare Island Navy Yard to have her docked at once, and issued directions to have all necessary repairs made as soon as possible, preparatory to starting the trim little ship across the Pacific.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- The Paris Journal publishes an interview with M. Flourens with reference to affairs in Madagascar, in which the ex-Foreign Minister says that, in his opinion, Great Britain is exciting the Hova Government to resist the demands made by France, and that in order to thwart Great Britain it will be necessary for France to expedite such military action as will crush the Hovas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Senator John R. McPherson, fresh from Europe, arrived in town to-day, and went immediately to the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Committee, where he spent some time in making inquiries as to the amount and quality of campaign matter being sent to New-Jersey, and in securing other information bearing upon the campaign in his State.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 24. -- The candidates for the Wesleyan football team began practice last week. There will be several changes in the management of the team this year. Since Wesleyan has dropped out of the "big" league most of the games with the larger colleges will be omitted from the schedule, and Wesleyan will give most of her attention to colleges somewhere near her size.
LONDON, Sept. 24. --A dispatch from Shanghai to the Central News says that the British steamer Irene has arrived at TaKu, where she has landed her cargo of munitions of war.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The seat of war among the Democrats of Monroe County has been transferred from here to Saratoga. The three Assembly districts of the county, entitled to three delegates each, or a total representation of nine, will be represented in Saratoga by eighteen delegates, or two sets from each district, one delegation from the Slocum or Spellman faction, and the other from the Raines-Decker faction.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24. -- J.W. Reinhart, ex-President of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, returned to his home from Hot Springs, Va., unexpectedly last night. Mr. Reinhart and his family went to their cottage at Hot Springs ten days ago, with the intention of remaining there until October.

SARATOGA, Sept. 24. -- The action taken to-night by the State Committee in granting the request of the New-York State Democracy's contesting delegation for seats on the floor of the convention simply carries with it the right for the contestants to present their claims from the floor at the preliminary organization of the convention. It does not clear up the situation further than that.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The fifteenth biennial meeting of the National Conference of the Unitarian and other Christian Churches was begun in the village hall this evening. The Scripture lesson was read by the Rev. Dr. George L. Chaney of Richmond, Va., and prayer was offered by the Rev. Joseph H. Crooker of Helena, Mon.
Concentrated thought, continued in, robs the stomach of necessary blood, and this is also true of hard physical labor.

Four special convention trains left the Grand Central Station for Saratoga yesterday. One carried the delegates of the State Democracy, the others those of the regular Democracy, and it was estimated that each train had about 500 persons aboard.
RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- After leaving the bench at 6 o'clock this evening, Judge Gaynor sent the following telegram to M. L. Towns at Saratoga:

The armored cruiser Maine, which is scheduled to leave the New-York Navy Yard this morning on an initial trial trip, may also have an opportunity of showing what manner of sea boat she is. To give an illustration of that sort certain meteorological conditions are necessary, and these the Weather Bureau has promised to furnish.

STURGIS, Ky., Sept. 24. -- Throughout this section of Kentucky the people have been greatly perturbed to-day over the threat attributed to Capt. Blackwell, Tax Collector, to begin operations with an armed posse to collect the tax on the bonds levied some years ago for a railroad. The property owners, dissatisfied with the methods employed in the railroad scheme have long resisted the payment of the bond tax.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- After a very dull opening, West Chicago stock became quite active, presumably on covering by shorts. It opened strong at 132 3/4. Buyers were averse to paying the advance, and there was a slow decline to 132 1/2. A recovery followed, and the close was at 133 1/4. North Chicago was quiet at 246 1/4.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The Inter-State Fair opened to-day with an attendance of about 5,000. Since the last fair $100,000 has been spent on improvements, and the result is increased space for all classes of exhibits needing shelter and protection from the weather. The exhibition is especially strong this year in fancy cattle, and farming machinery.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Joseph Field, the veteran farmer of Middletown Township, who is probably the oldest person in New-Jersey, will be 102 years old on Wednesday. There will be no formal celebration of his birthday, but he expects a number of callers.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 24. -- Louisville gave NewYork a sharp contest for to-day's game. The Giants won on the home team's errors in the seventh inning.
