Both Knell and Meekin were in splendid form, and the game was the best all-round that has been seen her for some time. Darkness ended it after eight innings. Attendance -- 150. Score:
SARATOGA, Sept. 24. -- The situation at midnight to-night gives more encouragement to the friends of Mr. Whitney than at any time since the canvass for the Gubernatorial nomination began.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The report of the Bureau of Statistics for July shows that 706,023,895 pounds of sugar were imported free of duty in July last, against 279,082,642 pounds in July, 1893. The large import in July of this year was due to uncertainty as to what duty would be placed on sugar by the new tariff law.

The Granger situation continued to absorb the attention of Wall Street yesterday. Burlington and Rock Island were under the hammer most of the day, and they yielded rather easily. Burlington sold down to 73 1/8, and closed at 73 3/8, a net loss of 2 points. Rock island touched 60 3/8, and closed at 60 3/4, a decline of a point.

A plan for Reading reorganization, devised by the Olcott committee, was completed yesterday. As reported by the receivers, the amount of receivers' certificates with interest is $3,676,824, the company's floating debt is $3,900,645, and car trusts outstanding reach $7,533,988. Annual fixed charges are placed at $10,477,560.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24. -- To-day's market has been rather a disappointment. A good many people came down town expecting to see it open up and advance. It opened lower and sold off, with one or two feeble rallies. The people engaged in bulling the several tractions displayed more than the usual caution.

PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 24. -- The gold and silver chalice, valued at $250, of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, was stolen from the altar by a tramp this morning. The theft was soon discovered by Under Sexton Murray, who chased the thief for several blocks and then lost sight of him.

A meeting of the contractors and builders of the city was held last night in Renwick Hall, Third Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, and there was formed an organization which will be known as the Employers' and Builders' League of the Building Trades of the City of New-York.
The City Vigilance League and property owners met last night in the Second Reformed Presbyterian Church, in Thirty-ninth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- A tropical hurricane, that is suposed by the Weather Bureau experts to have devastated the Island of Cuba, is now attacking the southern coast of Florida and lashing the waters of the Gulf, uncertain whether to pursue its northwestern course or cariom off the land and follow up the Atlantic in the track of coastwise trading vessels.

Sixty representatives of various professions and workingmen's organizations of New-York called on C.C. Shayne, the fur manufacturer and dealer, last night, at his place of business, 124 West Forty-second Street, and requested him to allow them to work for his nomination as the Republican candidate for the Mayoralty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The indignation which is said to be felt in Virginia over the change in the name of the Post Office at Appomattox Court House from Appomattox to Surrender has not manifested itself in the form of communications to the Post Office Department, and the officials there are inclined to think that there is nothing substantial in it.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 24. -- Great interest is being shown in the coming race meet of the Crescent Wheelmen. They entry list closed on Saturday, and the character of the riders booked is highly gratifying to the gentlemen having the arrangements in charge. It has been decided not to make public the entires until the handicaps are allotted, so the list will not be announced for a day or two.

Only three of last year's football team have returned to the City College this year. Those interested in the sport at the college have realized the importance of getting immediately to work. Candidates for the team were called for last week, and over thirty men responded. Two teams will be formed. The college has always in the past preferred team work to individual practice, and will pursue the same course this season.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 24. -- The football men, those who are to uphold Yale's supremacy on the gridiron this year, are very nearly all in town. Fifteen of the candidates started to practice last week, and are moderately at work either in the gymnasuim on the Yale field, or in running through the streets of New-Haven. Walter Camp watched the men practice for a while during the week.

SARATOGA, Sept. 24. -- The delegates from Kings County, representing the organization of which Edward M. Shepard is Chairman, held a long meeting at the Windsor Hotel to-night, and discussed a programme for tomorrow. Speeches were made by Messrss J.G. Sherman, Richard S. Ramsay, JacobS. Van Wyck, J. Warrea Green, and others.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 24. -- What seems to be a murder by poison, and a murder without adequate motive, is a mystery which Chief Murphy has to-day been trying to solve. The victim, George Moore, thirty-two years old, died shortly before 12 o'clock last night at the United States Express stables, where he was employed as night foreman.
The striking shirtmakers have their headquarters at Walhalla Hall, 50 and 52 Orchard Street.

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Dr. William Everett, Representative from the Seventh Massachusetts District, has withdrawn his name from the Democratic Convention for renomination. Dr. Everett says that his Congressional career has convinced him that he cannot act according to his convictions and satisfy his constituents at the same time.

The Committee of Thirty Republicans held Assembly District Conventions last night to elect 220 delegates to the Republican County Convention, which is to be held Thursday night at Lyric Hall, in Sixth Avenue.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- As usual, the New-York City men who are here are attracting more attention than the delegations from other sections. The village is swarming with them to-night.

It would be going too far to say that Mr. Crane's production of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" is a disappointment. A large assemblage at the Star Theatre last night admired the scenery representing Windsor Castle and Windsor Forest in the time of Henry IV. very much, and applauded the play, too, after they had recovered from the shock of seeing Mr. Crane dressed as Falstaff.

GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- To-morrow will probably be the biggest day ever known in the history of the Marble City, as it is generally called, by reason of the fame of the St. Lawrence marble. The dedication of the new Masonic Temple is to be the great event, not only to the local members, but to Masons from all over Northern and Central New-York, who are expected in large numbers.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The Congressional fight here among the Republicans is becoming more and more intense. The contest being waged by ex-Consul O.F. Williams against Henry C. Brewster is more bitter every day. The course pursued by Brewster has caused much comment and criticism, even among his main supporters, while those opposed to him have had many bitter things to say.

Dr. Theodore B. Shelton, whose body was taken yesterday from Newburg, N.Y., where he died suddenly last Thursday, to Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Tarrytown, for burial, was one of the most prominent men in the early days of stock speculation in Wall Street. He had been graduated as a physician, but ventures in stocks decided him to try his fortune in that line.

In the course of an editorial article designed to assist the Democratic opponents of the proposed removal of the duty on iron ore, The New-York Tribune recently made the following remarks about the imports of iron ore and the companies which have brought ore from Cuba:

The consensus of opinion among prominent Democrats in New-York is that William C. Whitney's nomination for Governor by the Democratic Convention would insure the Democracy's success at the coming election.

SARATOGA, Sept. 24. -- Ten carloads of Tammany men reached this village at 6:30 o'clock to-night with an enthusiasm for William C. Whitney which caused his name to sound through the corridors more often even than it had before. The ten cars were the first section of the special train which brought the braves to the convention city.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- The Democratic State Committee held a meeting tonight, and, by its action toward several contesting delegations, save evidence that it proposes to give everybody a fair and full opportunity to be heard on the merits of their cases. Requests for this from the contestants from New-York and Kings Counties were granted with a readiness that could hardly fail to be satisfactory to the applicants.

BOSTON, Sept. 24. -- Ada Rehan, so long identified with Augustin Daly's company as leading woman, made her first appearance as a star at the Hollis Street Theatre here to-night, under the direction of Mr. Daly. She appeared as the Baroness Vera in "The Last Word," a character in which she has been seen here before, and which she invests with a charm that is all her own.

No one who was familiar with the history of the new Panama Canal Company could have been Surprised by the announcement that subscriptions for only $1,600,000 of the $6,000,000 of stock offered to the public were received. There was nothing in the scheme to attract intelligent investors, while there was much in the history and character of the new organization to repel them.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24. -- Otis Skinner made his debut as a star at the Grand Opera House to-night in Clyde Fitch's new play, "His Grace De Grammont." A large audience greeted him, and the pleasure the performance gave was never in doubt. The stronger portions of the play were received with positive enthusiasm, while the comedy excited much laughter.

Copyrighted 1894, by The New-York Times. WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 24. -- Some Connecticut Republicans have given visible evidence of that spirit of partisanship to which is attributed the unwillingness of the party to bring about a change in the Constitution which shall give justice to the people.

Some six weeks ago The Times began to preach the doctrine of harmony for the edification, but particularly for the unification, of the Democratic Party in the State of New-York. There seemed to be no good reason for keeping up a party organization if along with it party quarrels and divisions were also to be kept up.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24. -- Four thousand spectators saw the finish in the first of the big cricket games between Lord Hawke's team and the Gentlemen of Philadelphia at Haverford to-day, and 4,000 Philadelphians were sorely disappointed at the result, which gave the Englishmen a victory by 131 runs.
It is now possible to ascertain how much raw sugar in excess of the normal supply was imported in the two or three months immediately preceding the enactment of the new tariff.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Shanghai says that in an imperial edict issued on Sept. 23, the Emperor of China expresses great personal regret at the death of Gen. Tso-Fung, who was killed in the recent battle at Ping-Yang, and orders that his remains be given all the military honors due a Provincial Commander in Chief and that his sons be treated with especial favor.

SARATOGA, Sept. 25. -- In one corner of Convention Hall, in this village, a band had seats at the opening session of the Democratic State Convention here to-day. The musicians came in late. The sturdy body of Democrats that filled the convention floor and the seats that rise in terraces up from the floor was in its most serious mood.

A large block of Richmond Terminal securities was sold at public auction at 111 Broadway yesterday, and was bought by C.H. Coster of the General Reorganization Committee. These securities formed part of the collateral behind the floating debt, and the sale was a technical proceeding necessary to enable the Reorganization Committee to perfect title to the securities.
The American Electro-Therapeutic Association began its fourth annual meeting in the hall of the New-York Academy of Medicine yesterday morning.

SARATOGA, Sept. 25. -- Probably the most interesting contest had before a Committee on Credentials of the Democratic State Convention in many years was the contest in Kings County, which was fought out this evening.
Gen. Thomas Seir Cummings, the miniature painter and Dean of the Foundersc of the National Academy of Design, died in his home, at Hackensaok, N.J., quietly, Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The President to-day appointed Gen. William Ward Duffield of Detroit, Mich., Superintendent of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, to succeed Prof. T.C. Mendenhall, resigned. The place is worth $6,000 per annum.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- There was prolonged applauding and cheering when George H. Morrison arose in the Nineteenth District Congressional Convention, held by the Republicans of Rensselaer and Columbia Counties in this city this afternoon, for it was previously known that he was to present the name of his friend, Frank S. Black, for the nomination.

The new armored cruiser Maine started on her preliminary trial run yesterday morning. She gave a satisfactory exhibition of her powers, and returned to her berth in the New-York Navy Yard in the afternoon.

We have held from the moment of the passage of the reform tariff that the only logical ground for the Republicans to take was in favor of its repeal. The reform tariff replaces the McKinley act, which was passed by the Republicans without opposition or serious criticism from any quarter in the party.

The young ladies of Central Park have abandoned their singles tennis tournament, and are holding mixed doubles in its place. Some of the players, especially Miss Aline Hart, are quite skillful in the use of the racket, and on better courts might become recognized among experts. Miss A. Risch and Charles Trier have won both their matches, and will meet Miss Blatt and H. Freund in the finals.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 25. -- Two prospective candidates for the Republican nomination to the highest office in the gift of the American people sat side by side on the platform of Tomlinson Hall this afternoon and vied with each other for the plaudits of one of the most notable assemblages in the history of the Hoosier State.

RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 25. -- In accordance with a general order recently issued by the War Department, the new military post in Vermont, Fort Ethan Allen, is to be garrisoned by Troops C, E, F, and G. Third United States Cavalry, transferred from Fort Riley, Kansas, who will arrive at the new post about Oct. 1.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 25. -- Statistics to-day from the different sections of the cotton belt of this State all report the staple in first-class condition. Picking has become general all over the districts, and gins are making double time. Cotton on the uplands has suffered very little from the boll worm, and even the bottom lands are suffering very little from these pests, now that hot weather is prevailing.
The general tendency of yesterday's stock market was toward lower prices. A few stocks showed some strength, but the majority of the list closed lower than on Monday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- A special election took place in the Twelfth Ward of this city to-day, to elect an Alderman to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Joseph Bierbrauer. Two candidates and three tickets were in the field, Richard Decker running on the straight Democratic ticket and Augustus May on both the Republican and independent Republican.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Judge W. J. Gaynor did not leave the bench till S o'clock this evening. Among the telegrams he then opened was a long one from several delegates at Saratoga, asking him to run for Governor. Judge Gaynor sent the following answer:

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- About fifty stockholders were present at the Old Colony Railroad Company's annual meeting to-day. The Board of Directors was re-elected, 10,770 shares being voted on by 43 voters. It was unanimously voted to give the Directors authority to issue $2,000,000 new bonds, interest not to exceed 6 per cent, and bonds payable not exceeding fifty years from date, interest to be paid by the lessee.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- Preparations for the wheel races at the fair grounds tomorrow afternoon are completed and fine sport is assured. The first event will be called at 2 o'clock, after which hour the cyclists will have the track to themselves. The Westchester Cycling League, under whose auspices the sport will be conducted, has been particularly fortunate in securing entries.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 25. -- Amos Rusie was the pitcher who faced the Louisville batters at the park this afternoon, and the Colonels failed to make any sort of showing against the Giants. They supported Rusie in perfect form, except in one instance, when stupidity gave Grim a two-bagger, but the break was not costly. Louisville was never in the game.

Gustave Amedee Humbert, French Sena- ' tor, died in Paris yesterday. He was born at Metz, June 28, 1822. He was the son of a volunteer of 1792 whose exploits have been enthusiastically described. He studied law in Paris, receiving in 1845 the first premium at the University Concourse.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Second account trading commenced to-day, and, as Friday is delivery day, the time for making turns is quite short. To-day's business was very largely in West Chicago Street Railway stock. Yesterday it became apparent that one of the heaviest longs on the market would require deliveries on all maturing contracts in West Chicago.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 25. -- Residents of this place fear that a gang of burglars has settled near this city. Three houses and a store were entered last night, and in every instance the thief escaped.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 25. -- Ernest Cady of this city, who was nominated for Governor at New-Haven to-day, was elected Lieutenant Governor two years ago on the ticket with Luzon B. Morris. He polled a very large vote, receiving the heartiest support throughout the State. He presided in the State Senate during the session of 1893 with dignity and success, winning the admiration and esteem of both parties to the General Assembly.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- The market for local stocks was insufferably dull, although prices generally held firm. Bay State Gas was the only active stock, and was boosted to-day to the highest price it has reached recently. It opened at 14, the same as last night's close, rose to 15, and closed at 14 1/4. The second bonds rose 2, to 60.

Mary Reynolds, nineteen years old; a domestic in the employ of Augustus C. Dexter, was fatally burned yesterday afternoon in the fashionable apartment house, the Santa Marguerita, 1,125 Madison Avenue. It is supposed that her clothes caught fire either from an explosion of gas or from a match which she had thrown on the floor.

The racing at Jerome Park yesterday was a vast improvement over that of Monday, and still the sport was decidedly stupid. In the only race that promised anything of merit, the Bedford Stakes for three-yearolds, all of the starters except Rubicon were scratched, although there was $200 for the second horse and $100 for the third.
SARATOGA, Sept. 25. -- The other preliminary business of the session was quickly disposed of.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- The case of the Government against Eugene V. Debs and the other officers and Directors of the American Railway Union for contempt of court in violating the Woods-Grosscup injunction, postponed from Sept. 14, in order to allow counsel to prepare arguments, the evidence being all in, was resumed this morning before Judge Woods.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept: 25. -- The fine list of entries for the Crescent Wheelmen's fourth race meet at the Oval here on Saturday next should prove a strong attraction among the devotees of cycling. Star riders of the first magnitude will glitter in the contests in both classes, and, on such a superior track as the Crescents boast of, some capital time ought to result in the scratch contests.

George Scrafford went to Police Head-Quarters yesterday to find the present whereabouts of his father, Jacob, whom he has not seen and of whom he has heard nothing for fourteen years. Scrafford says he lived at 2,331 Second Avenue in 1882. His father was a car driver.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 25. -- It was a cold and chilly crowd that greeted the circuit chasers in this city. The Maryland Bicycle Club had made elaborate preparations for this meet, which was to crown a successful season in this city. But Baltimore has a champion baseball team and is baseball crazy. Only 600 persons turned out to-day, and, with six finely-contested finals and twice as many heats, hardly a cheer could be brought forth.

It is for Mr. Whitney himself to say whether he will be the next Governor of New-York. The convention awaits his arrival and his answer. Before the delegates reassemble at noon to-day he will have been apprised of his party's demand upon him, and of the circumstances in which that demand has been made.

SARATOGA, Sept. 25. -- The second case taken up by the Committee on Credentials was the contest from New-York. The Hon. Charles S. Fairchild, Frederic R. Coudert, Francis M. Scott, J. Walton Green, Wheeler H. Peckham, John Henneberry, Henry R. Beekman, and Hugh R. Garden appeared as a committee representing the contestants.
FIRE ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 26, 2:10 A. M. -- The White Star Line steamship Majestic has just been sighted.

Columbia College students now have the brightest prospect of soon occupying their new home on Morningside Heights, for it was announced yesterday that the college authorities took complete possession of the Bloomingdale Asylum grounds last Saturday. The asylum people have been for the last few months transferring the hundreds of patients to their new home in White Plains, and Thursday the last of them were removed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The announcement is made that the work connected with the eleventh census is nearly completed, and that by Oct. 15 most of the force now employed will be discharged. The only work not completed is that of population and vital statistics.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 25. -- A terrific gale is raging along the east and west coasts of Florida and also at interior points. Reports are meagre, as the wires south of Jacksonville are either down or are working badly.

Judge McAdam, in the Superior Court, held an examination yesterday afternoon in the case of Pietro Fannessi, alias Angelo Damiano, and Charles Sullivan, charged with attempting to commit fraud in obtaining naturalization papers. Judge McAdam decided that the case was not in the jurisdiction of the Superior Court, but of the United States District Court.
SARATOGA, Sept. 25. -- It was some time before Mr. Hill was allowed to speak, but when the enthusiasm of the delegates had calmed down he made his address, as follows:...

The project of dispensing gradually with the services of Indian scouts, which Secretary Lament has sanctioned, will furnish another source of strength to the army. The 150 Indian scouts are very useful in certain emergencies, but as the law requires that they must be reckoned in the total of 25,000 enlisted men allowed to the army, they take the places of just that number of soldiers who would be available in the regular regimental organizations.

In an interview with a reporter of The Herald, as printed yesterday morning, Mr. G.K. Ackerman, late Secretary and Chief Examiner of the City Civil Service Board, made the following statement: "I know that it was the unwritten law that no man was appointed on the police force whose application was filed originally with the Civil Service Board.

BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- The Cologne Gazette's St. Petersburg correspondent telegraphs that dispatches have been received there from Vladivostock confirming the report that a Chinese mob had attacked and plundered a Siberian railway station in the Province of Ussuri, and that eight Russians, who attempted to defend the station, were killed by the mob.

The Municipal Organization of the City of New-York, a new anti-Tammany association, was organized last night in the Manhattan Athletic Club Theatre. Business men, representing the real estate, building, engineering, electrical, and other interests of this city, were present. William J. Fryer was Chairman, and Warren A. Conover Secretary.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- The New-York Times's correspondent to-day met Mr. Frank B. Sanborn of Concord, the famous prison reformer and social scientist, and plumply asked him: "Have you followed the course of the long persecution of Mr. Brockway and the managers of the Elmira Reformatory. If so, what do you think of it?"

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- The market was irregular and feverish; active when it was strong and dull when it became weak. Philadelphia Traction, which was dormant for a good while pending the return of some of its principal owners, became fairly active, and was strong. The electric people keep rather quiet, but the stock is steadily recording material advances.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The Westchester Horse Show opened to-day here under rather unfavorable conditions, the weather being cold and raw and a high wind sweeping down through the valley in which the fair grounds are situated. Nevertheless, the attendance for an opening day was very gratifying to the management, fully 5,000 persons being present.
James A. Brown, Auditor of the NewYork Life Insurance Company, died last night at his home, 357 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, of organic troubles.

SARATOGA, Sept. 25. -- When the Richmond County contest was called, Mr. J.D. Van Hovenberg and Howard R. Bayne presented the claims of the contestants, claiming they were not recognized by the regular organization.

SARATOGA, Sept. 25. -- The Democratic State Convention has come to a dead standstill. It wants William C. Whitney as its nominee for Governor. It will nominate him unanimously, and no other name will be mentioned in the convention, if he will accept the nomination. It waits anxiously to learn his decision.

Part pf the programme of the Republican State Committee, when it meets to-day at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, will be, if the arrangements that were made last night are not reconsidered, to elect as Chairman Charles W. Hackett of the Twenty-fifth District, in place of William Brookfield of the Thirteenth District, who is Chairman of the County Committee.
The convention of Good Government Clubs met yesterday at Hardman Hall, in West Nineteenth Street, but adjourned without making nominations for municipal offices.

SARATOGA, Sept. 25. -- It was a sturdy, fine-looking body of men that faced Chairman Murphy as he rose and took the gavel. As he did so, the applause which had been heard when he entered was renewed. It was precisely 1:10 o'clock when the gavel fell.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 25. -- A fashionable wedding was celebrated this evening in Trinity Episcopal Church, the contracting parties being Miss Anna Grant Hubbard, youngest daughter of James Hubbard, a retired farmer of Middletown Township, and Riviere Hetzel Sneden, a prominent young business man and an officer of the New-Jersey State Democratic Society.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25. -- The barkentine Tropic Bird, from Tahiti, brings news of the reported death of an Austrian noble-man. Count Festetics, son-in-law of J.B. Haggin. His death is said to have occurred in one of the small islands of the Penryn group, where he and the Countess have been living.

The Democrats of Connecticut have made a good beginning in a canvass of more than usual importance. Both National and State issues will engage the interest of the people of that State this year. On both the Democrats are definite and candid, and their candidates are worthy representatives of the people.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 25. -- The United Press reporter here interviewed C. Ben Johnson, District Deputy of the Elks for Easton, Penn., this evening relative to the meeting of the alleged Trustees at Reading on Monday, and their action in suspending the lodges at New-York, Philadelphia Boston, Baltimore, Washington, and other lage cities for meeting on Sundays.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 25. -- At the annual convention of the State Liquor Dealers Association to-day President August Koehler of Orange urged the delegates to combat the temperance fanatics, who, he said, were waging war against an honest industry. C. Berry Paterson of Monmouth County said the temperance agitators were exercising the same spirit of bigotry which burned the witches in Massachusetts two centuries ago.

The Board of Rapid-Transit Commissioners held a meeting yesterday afternoon and adopted a resolution to place the question of municipal construction of a railway or railways before the people at the coming election, in conformity with the law.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 25. -- Jordan, a local pitcher, was in the box for the home team to-day and put up a creditable game. His work, however was only secondary to other incidents of the game.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The Upitarian National Biennial Conference was opened at 9 o'clock with a communion service, conducted by the Rev. Dr. Edward Everett Hale, assisted by the Rev. Drs. Camp of Brooklyn and Bolcheletin of Lowell. At its conclusion Senator George F. Hoar, the new President of the conference, delivered the annual address.

Ellen Carr, the young colored woman who was arrested Monday night, charged with setting fire to the house at 148 Seventh Avenue, in which she lived, was yesterday held for trial in the Jefferson Market Police Court.

Dr. Parkhurst has been giving to Superintendent Byrnes the same counsel that this journal offered him when his promotion to the Superintendency was announced. The Times then said: "Although the new Superintendent is not a politician, he has four official superiors who are politicians and nothing else, and whose influence will therefore be exerted to prevent too vigorous an enforcement of the law.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 26. -- The storm which has raged here all day has given rise to the gravest fears for the Sea Islanders. The wind kept increasing in violence from early morning until nightfall, and the barometer fell steadily. Every one believed the storm would equal in destructiveness the terrific cyclone of August, 1893.

Mr. Harrison thinks it would be good politics this year Just to "arraign" Democracy and Democrats and Democratic measures. He said as much down at Mr. Elkins's home in West Virginia, and took pains to have it spread over the country that what the country wanted was peace from tariff agitation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- It hardly can be said that the result of the Democratic Convention at Saratoga was a surprise to observant politicians here. The enthusiasm for Hill displayed by the convention from the moment it came together, the Senator's speech upon assuming the Chairmanship, and, finally, the dispatch received here early to-day announcing Mr. Whitney's final refusal, prepared the politicians for the subsequent news of Mr. Hill's nomination.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- At the Unitarian Conference to-day the principal controversy was over an amendment to Article VIII. of the constitution. The liberals finally accepted, as all they could expect from the conservatives this year, an article which, after recognizing that the constituency of the Unitarian Church is congregational in tradition and policy, declares:

Superintendent Byrnes has determined to ignore the resolution adopted by the Police Commissioners over three years ago, which practically rendered futile all efforts on the part of the force properly to carry out the excise law.

BOSTON, Sept. 26. -- Bay State Gas took the downward plunge in the "see-saw " of speculation to-day, opening 3/8 off at 14, and declining to 10 3/4, closing at 10 7/8. The second bonds dropped 1, to 59. The telephone stocks were strong, Bell advancing without a break to 207. Erie Telephone advanced to 52 1/4 and closed at 51 3/4.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 26. -- The second concert in the Worcester County Musical Festival, given this afternoon, called out a larger audience than last evening's performance. Miss Caroline Clark, soprano, who sang last evening in "Elijah," was the only soloist, and most of the afternoon was given up to the orchestra, an arrangement which resulted in what perhaps may be the best concert of the series, to those who are not ultra-musical, at least.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 26. -- The second day of the Queens County Agricultural Society's Fall exhibition was even an improvement on the first. The managers estimated the attendance at 10,000. A team of young horses owned by Alfred Sawkins of Westbury collided with a phaeton occupied toy Valentine Willis and hts brother of East Williston.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- A Central News dispatch from Tokio says the report recently put into circulation that an armistice between China and Japan had been proposed by England and Russia is absolutely untrue.

SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- The story of to-day's convention will form as interesting a chapter in the history of State politics as any other. With all its long delay, after the hour for reconvening in the Casino had come, and the remarkable business of the convention's second and last session, it did not occupy quite four hours.

The local Weather Bureau yesterday sent out notices to the various steamship lines whose vessels were scheduled to sail for Southern ports, warning them of the near approach of the "West Indian cyclone, which is now making its way up the coast.

ALBANY, Sept. 26. -- When the Phalanx returned to Albany this evening, the streets about the railroad station were choked with people. They had assembled because the news had got abroad that Senator Hill was a passenger on the same train.

LONDON, Sept. 26. -- The Admiralty is considering the scheme of manning subsidized merchant cruisers with officers and seamen of the Royal Naval Reserve. The scheme has already been referred to the Board of Trade and will be submitted to the various mercantile and marine boards.

WEST BRIGHTON, S.I., Sept. 26. -- The gang of incendiaries which has been spreading destruction in this vicinity fired the grand stand at the grounds of the Staten Island Athletic Club this morning, and the structure was entirely destroyed.
SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- Senator Hill insisted that the roll call be proceeded with James J. Martin wanted to know if he meant on the nomination for Lieutenant Governor. Hill rapped for order.

At a meeting of the Directors of the New-York Central Railroad yesterday, the usual quarterly dividend of 1 1/4 per cent. was declared, without any discussion. The financial statement for the quarter ending Sept. 30 showed gross earnings, $10,922,000; operating expenses, $7,184,000; net earnings, $3,738,000, and profit, $1,103,000.

Great dullness was the feature of the stock market yesterday, until the day was well advanced. Then there was a very apparent effort to manipulate the market to enable shorts to cover, particularly in the Granger group. The short interest has become so large as to be unwieldy, and the active stocks command a premium in the loan crowd.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The Japanese Legation is in receipt to-day of the first correct official report of the battle of Yalu River which has yet been made, and it corroborates the graphic story of this engagement cabled to the United Press from Tokio. The dispatch containing the official intelligence is as follows:

Among the passengers on board thesteamship Spree of the North German Lloyd Line, which arrived from Bremen and Southampton last night, were the followig members of the arctic expedition once reported lost and which left New-York last March, bound for the North Pole via Norway:

SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- Liuet. Gov. Sheehan, Chairman of the Committee on Platform, submitted the platform, and said that when it was read he would move its adoption and on that move the previous question. Mr. Sheehan explained that he had a cold, and asked the indulgence of the convention while Secretary De Freest read the platform, which, when read, was unanimously adopted as follows:

SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- As soon as Senator Hill had taken hold of the gavel, he quickly secured such order as he could, but Lieut. Gov. Sheehan called his attention to the very patent fact that all of the delegates could not find seats.

The resolutions of the Democratic Convention which relate to national issues are well conceived, candid, and strong. They well define the lines of the campaign in the Congressional districts, where logically, and by the stress of current events, the fight on such issues will be made. The tariff question is fairly handled.

David Bennett Hill, the nominee for Governor of the New-York State Democratic Convention, will be fifty-one years old next Saturday. The village of Havana, Schuyler County, then Chemung County, was his birthplace.

Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times. NEW-BRITAIN, Conn., Sept. 26. -- Republicans, as well as Democrats, here are fully aware of the growing sentiment in the State in favor of constitutional reform. After twenty years of agitation, the oldtime politicians who have withstood attempts to change the organic law of the State, so that a show of justice may be given to the majority of the population, are beginning to come into camp.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26. -- The local traction stocks and the industrials have cut loose from the general market, and are either strong at about yesterday's prices or higher. Electric Traction advanced to 110, and did not lose it. The friends of Philadelphia moved that stock up to 105 3/4, but it receded slightly from the top quotations.

SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- When the State Democracy delegates from New-York and those from Kings County, led by Edward M. Shepard, heard the official declaration that they were not to be given any votes in the convention, they left the hall.

SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- As quickly as New-York was reached, Senator Charies L. Guy jumped on his chair and demanded Hill's nomination. He made an impassioned speech and then there was another wild wave of enthusiasm. The convention became a scene of frenzy, It was the second section of the stirring stampede.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 26. -- Frederick W. Purington, lighthouse keeper at Gull Rock, was cruelly beaten to-night. Gull Rock is about 300 yards off the west shore of Newport. Mrs. Purington was up stairs in the lighthouse, when she heard her husband's cries. She ran down stairs to find him insensible and bleeding on the floor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- The Treasury officials, after having discussed thoroughly the alcohol paragraph of the new Tariff bill, have about reached the conclusion that they have no means at hand to enforce it, and that, therefore, the rebate clause must remain inoperative until Congress, at its next session, either provides the appropriation necessary to carry the law into effect or repeals it.
Ex-Sheriff Charles B. Farley died at his home, 379 Van Buren Street, Brooklyn, shortly before noon yesterday of blood poisoning, following the amputation of the great toe on his right foot.

Charles H. Voges pleaded guilty to grand larceny before Recorder Smyth yesterday. He admitted that he had by false entries covered up thefts amounting to over $20,000 form Naylor Co. of 45 "Wall Street, where he was employed as cashier.
Prince Emanuel Ruspoll, Mayor of Rome, Italy, and Princess Ruspoll, were among the passengers who arrived yesterday, with ex-Secretary Whitney, by the steamer Majestic.
A special feature in the Fall millinery opening at Lord Taylor's. Broadway and Twentieth Street, is the beautiful display of picture hats.

The most objectionably partisan performance of the Constitutional Conven- tion has undoubtedly been the article relating to reapportionment. Mr. Hill's praise, in his speech before the Democratic Convention, of the fairness of the Democratic apportionment in comparison with the Republican apportionment that preceded it was deserved, and the evidence he adduced of its fairness was decisive.

SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- Mr. Thacher's name was received with cheers and handclapping, but as Mr. Hitt descended from the platform it became evident that something else was on the tapis. The band played merrily. No one appeared to be ready with the secondary speech.

The Church of the Holy Trinity, at Madison Avenue and Forty-secpnd Street, was filled yesterday with clerical and lay delegates to the one hundred and eleventh annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The Democratic State Convention has come, and nominated its ticket, and gone. The result of the convention was a surprise, and to some extent bewildering to the spectators who gathered in the old skating rink at 12:30 to-day.

When the Saratoga Convention reassembled at noon yesterday it had greater need of sagacious leadership than at any other stage of its proceedings. It was known that Mr. Whitney declined to allow the use of his name as a candidate. Some of the candidacies much talked of in the earlier discussions had been definitely abandoned.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 26. -- Bulietins have been received here all day long from the Weather Department at Washington asking that the information be distributed to the effect that a tropical hurricane is moving this way from Florida.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Sept. 26. -- A representative of the United Press was the first to notify the President of the result of the Democratic State Convention in Saratoga early this evening. Mr. Cleveland appeared quite anxious to hear, and during a conversation on the veranda was asked if he had anything to say as to the nomination of David B. Hill for Governor.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26. -- The second day's meet of the Maryland Wheel Club was witnessed by not over 300 persons. The air was cold and a sharp wind cut like a knife. Both Class A events were captured by W.F. Sims, the Washington man and intercollegiate champion, who displays splendid head work in all his races. Sims has been engaged for a prominent team next season.
SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- Immediately after the adoption of the resolutions, Norman E. Mack of Buffalo handed up the resolution that the convention should proceed to nominate a candidate for Governor.

Several thousand people went up to Jerome Park yesterday to try and get some of the money that fifty-four bookmakers took to the track for the crowd to bet against. The bookmakers probably had the best of the game. They usually have. The racing was far from exciting, for the fields were very small and the class of horses decidedly commonplace.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- Now there was some quick politics played. Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan consulted with the New-Yorkers, rushed quickly back to the Buffalo delegation, and in a very brief speech placed Congressman Daniel N. Lockwood in nomination for Lieutenant Governor. Mr. Sheehan said:

SARATOGA, Sept. 26. -- The consideration of resolutions to be embodied in the platform occupied several hours of the time not only of the sub-committee, of which Lieut. Gov. Sheehan was Chairman, but of the entire Committee on Resolutions. The full committee had a meeting this forenoon.
Hon. J.W. Hinckley, Saratoga: I find on my arrival this morning that my name is the subject of some consideration by delegates to the convention, and I have received many friendly messages.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 26. -- The horses at the Westchester County Show attracted a big crowd to-day, and, although the weather was raw and cold, every one seemed to have a good time. The judging was got through promptly, and no accident marred to-day's sport.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- People living along the Atlantic coast, from Georgia to Massachusetts, will to-morrow have a taste of a pretty lively gale, while the men who go out to sea in ships in defiance of the warning that is now two days old will do so at the peril of their lives.

While the official trial of the Maine to determine her horse power is yet to be made, her preliminary run has shown her to be successful in speed, steadiness, and handiness of steering. The act of 1886, under which she was built, called for at least 16 knots under forced draught, and there is good reason to believe that she will exceed 17.
William Brookfield received his chastisement yesterday for his temerity in opposing the great "Boss" Platt.

It is gratifying and encouraging to note that the Superintendent of Police took in good part the advice that Dr. Parkhurst publicly gave him two days ago. Night before last he arrested the keepers of a large number of barrooms that were unlawfully open after hours, and in every case he had his evidence ready yesterday morning when the case was brought Up before the police magistrate.

The intercollegiate tennis tournament, the last of the big tournaments of the year, will be held on the grounds of the New-Haven Lawn Club, beginning Tuesday, Oct. 2, at 10 A.M. There are thirteen colleges belonging to the association -- Amherst, Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Princeton, Stevens Institute of Technology, Trinity, University of Pennsylvania, Wesleyan, Williams, and Yale.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 27. -- The ministers of Hudson County are about to form a permanent moral reform league, based upon the Idea of the Parkhurst society of New-York.

BOSTON, Sept. 27. -- In the United States Circuit Court this forenoon. Judge Colt ordered a verdict for the defendant in the case of Leon Bernard of Belgium against Lee, Higginson Co., bankers, for the conversion of securities deposited by Bernard in the State Street safe-deposit vaults in 1883.

Mr. William J. Tate has sold, for William Gubbins, the four-story stone-front dwelling 55 Montgomery Place, near Ninth Avenue. 21 by 45 by 85. at $21,00O. He has also sold the three-storyand-basement brownstone dwelling 155 Prospect Place, Near Carlton Avenue, 21 by 45 by 10O, at $11,000.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 27. -- The State Executive Committee of the Democratic Party has just adjourned, after making preliminary arrangements for conducting the Congressional campaign. Col. Henry C. Tompkins, who conducted the recent State campaign so successfully, was retained as Chairman, which insures a wise, active, and aggressive contest.

The recent diplomatic doctrine of "zones of influence" is undergoing an enlargement beyond the dreams of its authors. It was invented for the adjustment of the various claims of European nations in Africa. It assumes, of course, the actual inhabitants of the "zone" are "natives," who have no rights that Europeans are bound to respect, and whose lands are to be partitioned among European claimants without any regard to the owners' wishes.

In two respects Gov. Hill was wiser than the convention over which he presided at Saratoga. He did not approve the exclusion of the delegates of the State Democracy of New-York and the Shepard Democracy of Brooklyn, and he disapproved and sought to prevent the convention's nomination of himself for Governor.
The Executive Committee of the Committee of Seventy appointed a special conference committee yesterday afternoon, composed of the following members:

A dispatch from Shanghai, the other day, announced in a commonplace way that the British steamer Irene had landed a cargo of war supplies at Ta-Ku. It Is generally understood that American rifles and cartridges have gone to Tokio by way of the Canadian Pacific Railroad and Vancouver, and it is even said that negotiations are pending for a supply of rapid-fire guns to Japan.

Bishop Potter differs from many members of his order in that his charges to his clergy are of interest to others than to those to whom they are directly addressed. This is especially the case with the address which he delivered to the Diocesan Convention on Wednesday, in which he took occasion to admonish the clergy against letting their sympathies run away with their judgment in the consideration of economic problems.

RIVERHEAD, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Some persons who have talked with William J. Gaynor have drawn the inference that he does not intend to accept the nomination for Judge of the Court of Appeals tendered him by the Democratic Convention at Saratoga yesterday. Judge Gaynor declined to-day to make a direct statement concerning the matter, but he did say that he did not think he should accept the nomination.

"Where are you from?" a merchant asked. "Whar am I from? I'm from Kaintucky, of course, five miles from Mount Stirling, whar they shoot a man every court day, and stab a feller or two whenever the Grand Jury hold a session. Ever down there? Fine country. Grass and hoases and all sorts of things. Feller come in thar some time ago and got into a row with the County Jedge and killed him.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Congressman Daniel N. Lockwood, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, arrived home from Saratoga to-night. He was accompanied by Lieut. Gov. Sheehan.
Policeman Taylor of the West Sixtyeighth. Street Station appeared before Police Justice Meade in the Yorkville Court yesterday, and said: "This boy is charged with stealing a horse and wagon."

Funeral services over the body of ex-Senator John C. Jacobs, who died at Atlantic City, N.J., last Saturday, were held at 2 P.M. yesterday, in St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, Clinton and Livingston Streets, Brooklyn.

The cars on the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge are to be lighted by electricity. This was decided by the Bridge Trustees at a special meeting yesterday afternoon. Trustees Howell, Henriques, and Keeney, and Mayor Schieren voted in favor of the adoption of electricity in place of the present system, while Trustee Skinner voted for a gas system.
Elections of State officers are to be held in October in Florida and Georgia.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The trotting horse had an innings at the Westchester County Horse Show and Fair today. Two classes of trotters were judged. Belini, by Artillery, a handsome black, won the prize for stallions, and Rentes, another black, won the prize for mares. The roadster class brought several good animals in the ring, and W.H. Tailer won with his b.g. Stanford.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27. -- The receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad applied today, through counsel, to Judge Jenkins of the United States Court for permission to issue $5,000,000 additional certificates. The new certificates are wanted to take up certificates due next Monday, amounting to $2,135,985 and to pay preferential claims.

Masters of steamships bound for West Indian and coast-line ports are unsettled as to the advisability of facing the storm that is making its way north, and, as a result, many of the ships have sought berths in the upper and lower bays. The Mallory Line steamship Lampasas, which cleared for Galveston Wednesday, got as far as the lower bay, and there anchored until yesterday afternoon.

After the passage of the law declaring that no United States official shall hold two offices either of which pays annually $2,500 or more, John A Shields decided to act no longer as United States Commissioner, but to retain his position as Clerk of the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York, which pays considerably more than $2,500 a year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Through the Department of State to-day, President Cleveland made a proclamation of amnesty and pardon to all persons who have been convicted of polygamy under the teachings of the Mormon Church. It is as follows: BY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA.

ROME, Sept. 27. -- It is semi-officially stated that representatives of the Governments of Italy and the United States of Colombia have signed a protocol submitting to President Cleveland, as arbiter, Italy's claim for reparation for the treatment of the Italian subject Cerruti, who, it is alleged, was illegally arrested and imprisoned in Colombia.

BOSTON, Sept. 27. -- In the alleged breach-of-contract case of Manager Rice against the cantatrice Miss D'Arville to-day, Ernest Driscoll of New-York, an old theatregoer, said that he considered "Little Christopher Columbus" a burlesque; that it was advertised and criticised as such.

The bad blood generated at the Clan-naGael Convention held in Philadelphia Sept. 4-8 and the dissatisfaction caused among the members through the country by the expulsion of Camps 10 and 93 of Brooklyn has caused much discussion among persons interested. The trouble may ultimately cause the disbandment of the Clan-naGael Society.

"If the women would only fight for this reform with the energy with which they fought each other last Spring, I think It would be a very good thing," said the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 27. -- The Wan Department has in hand plans for the extraordinary fortification of Newport Harbor, and it is understood that the visit here Monday of Secretary Lamont was to look over the ground casually.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 27. -- The Crescent Wheelmen's fourth race meet at the handsome oval on Saturday continues to grow in interest. Cyclists throughout the State are talking about it, and if only Jupiter Pluvius will kindly absent himself from this section on the day of the races, many persons will be highly pleased.

ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- When President Choate called the Constitutional Convention to order to-night there were 59 Republican and 18 Democratic delegates present. Enough came in during the first call of the roll to determine the presence of a quorum and to swell the attendance to 124.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- There is a conflict between two atmospheric forces that has operated to retard somewhat the advance of the West India hurricane, and the conflict between the elements and the telegraph companies has resulted so disastrously to the latter that it is difficult for the Weather Bureau to get accurate information from the vicinity of the storm centre.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 27. -- Harvard University formally opened its doors to begin its two hundred and fifty-ninth year this morning. Most of the morning was spent in registering the students. The freshman class of the college alone promises to be at least 430. This does not include specials or scientific students.

Troy, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Post Griswold, G.A.R., of this city, has decided to inaugurate a movement to enlist the interest of the entire Grand Army in erecting a lasting memorial over the grave of Francis Scott Key, author of "The Star-Spangled Banner." Key lies buried at Frederick, Md., where his grave is neglected. Major Gen. Joseph B. Carr and Brig. Gen. Alonzo Alden have been appointed on the committee to consider the matter.

"Ed" McLaughlin won the billiard game last night, making 338 points to "Tom" Gallagher's 250. McLaughlin's highest run was 95 and his average 19 15-17. Gallagher's highest run was 70 and his average 13 16-18. The total for the week is: Gallagher, 1,000; McLaughlin, 837; so that Gallagher still leads by 163 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Commissioner Miller has prepared a statement showing In detail the collections of internal revenue taxes for the last two months. The aggregate Is $51,924,878, against $25,092,304 for the corresponding period of 1893. The statement is as follows:

Very nearly half of yesterday's transactions in the stock market were in Sugar, and the stock was weak all day. It opened at 94 3/4, which was the highest price, and closed at 90 1/4, its lowest. Compared with Wednesday's closing its loss was 4 1/2 points. The manipulators evidently were satisfied to see lower prices, for they offered no support whatever.

ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- Senator Hill, when asked to-day why he had not announced his acceptance of the Democratic nomination for Governor, replied: "I have not yet been officially notified of my nomination."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Bigotry and Know-Nothingism have been introduced into the campaign by the Republicans, and from now until November these un-American agencies will be invoked to secure votes for Republican candidates. This will be a matter of surprise to many who have listened to the assurances of the Republican leaders that the ideas advanced by the American Protective Association would not be adopted by the party in the present contest.

Mrs. Sarah Porter, colored, of 804 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, informed Coroner Kene yesterday that her brother, Reilly Bailey, aged thirty-seven years, who bad been an Inmate at the asylum at St. Johnland, had been killed, as she believed, by one of the attendants.

There Is considerable uneasiness In the camp of the Class A riders these windy Autumn days. Rumors that a large number of the "pures" were slated for transfer to the growing army of the B's are the cause of it all. Somebody has said that Chairman Raymond carries a big type-written list of "amateurs" in his inside pocket, and is only waiting for a little more testimony before announcing the names to an unsympathetic public.

A mass meeting in favor of the "Greater New-York" was held last night at Loeffier's Hall, Willis Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street, in the annexed district. The Chairman of the meeting was John H. Knoeppel, head of the joint committee of the Taxpayers' Association. The principal speaker was Matthew P. Breen.

NYACK, Sept. 27. -- Nicholas Murphy, late Chairman of the Democratic County Committee of Rockland County, is at present in a perturbed state of mind over his action at the County Convention last Saturday in ignoring the Supreme Court mandamus served upon him by Sheriff Dickey at the opening of the convention.

The Australian system of balloting was adopted yesterday morning by the convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York, in session in the Church of the Holy Trinity, but not until the annual election had been held under the old methods, so that it will not be put in operation until next year.

Benjamin D. Stevens, the oldest manager of comic opera in the American field, since he was John A. McCaull's trusted assistant long before that pioneer in the work was forced by illness to retire, was allowed yesterday to arise from the bed in which he had been confined for two weeks in the Presbyterian Hospital.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- What appeared to be a natural recovery to wheat took place to-day, but right at the close the bull courage and enthusiasm oozed out and most of the gain was lost, prices resting exactly where they did at the end of yesterday's session. Outside orders were not notably large or numerous, and local trade was insignificant.
"Is it not time to make a change?" The speaker was connected with the Board of Health of one of the leading American cities.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- The calling of the Congressional, County, and Assembly Conventions by the Republican committees this week has stirred up the members of that party, who are now engaged in spirited contests and fights over the various nominations. The first convention in order is that in the Third Assembly District, which will be held at Spencerport to-morrow morning.
A birthday reception was tendered to the Rev. Dr. McGlynn by many of his friends and former parishioners at the Murray Hill Lyceum last night. He was fifty-seven years old yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J. Sept. 27. -- Governor's Day at the Inter-State Fair brought the largest number of people ever seen on the grounds, notwithstanding the leaden sky and sharp winds that prevailed during the morning. A larger number of visitors were on the grounds before 10 o'clock than had ever passed through the turnstiles before.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 27. -- A Lake Erie and Western freight train going East broke in two on a heavy grade three miles from town at 1:30 A.M. The detached cars, heavily loaded, came rushing tack into the city over the Big Pour tracks, which are used by the Lake Erie Road for several miles out of town.

A widow in destitute circumstances was found yesterday on the third floor of a tenement at 215 East One Hundred and Second Street. Her case is one of real distress, and she probably owes her life and the lives of her three little children -- two boys and a girl -- to the kindness of her neighbors, who themselves are poor.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 27. -- This was politicians' day at the Fall Exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society. County officials and those willing to be such, were out In force, making new acquaintances and renewing or strengthening old ones.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The Star to-day prints a dispatch from Shanghai, received through a news agency of this city, stating that native officials claim to have received news on the 25th inst. that Japanese troops had made an attack at the same time upon the Chinese at Anchow (probably Ai-Chow or Yi-Chow) and Wi-Ju.

The rigid enforcement of the excise law, begun under the personal orders of Superintendent Byrnes Tuesday morning, was continued yesterday morning, and, as a result, about sixty violators of the law, chiefly bartenders, were arrested by policemen sent out in the precincts in plain clothes.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27. -- Fully 10,000 people went to the Driving Park to-day to see the several attempts that were to be made to lower the world's turf records, and though the only record they saw broken was that of double team racing by Roseleaf and Sallie Simmons, going against Azote and Answer, they were well satisfied with the exhibitions given by the famous horses, including Alix, Directly, and Flying Jib.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27. -- The first week of football practice at Cambridge promises well for the future success of the Harvard team. The training began on the Soldiers' Field a week ago, under the supervision of Capt. Emmons, and will be continued without cessation up to the time of the Yale game at Springfield, which comes on Nov. 24.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Admiral Gherardi reports to the Naval Department that the Maine will not be ready for her official trial until next week. While there was no derangement of her engines on her recent contractors' preliminary run, several adjustments are required which cannot be made before Monday next.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., Sept. 27. -- A man giving his name and address as L. Abderhalden, 709 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y., committed suicide this morning at the hotel at Glen Onoko, shooting himself through the head.

Christian Peterson, thirty-eight years old, was brought before Justice Hogan, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday afternoon, by a Central Office detective, who said that his prisoner had walked into Police Headquarters, and announced that he had committed a forgery in Wisconsin, and that he had come to give himself up.

About six weeks ago The New-York Times announced that the National Academy of Design building, at the northwest corner of Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, was for sale, and that it would probably be acquired by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which had theretofore bought other property on the block adjoining its new building.

Owing to the illness of Chairman Howard B. Raymond of the Racing Board, the weekly crop of additions to Class B were not made known yesterday. Mr. Raymond has been a very sick man since Tuesday. He caught a bad cold at the Springfield meet, which resulted in an abscess in the stomach. An operation was found to be necessary, and on Wednesday he submitted to one.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 27. -- The large Western distributors of spirits and whisky met in this city to-day. Among the delegates were the following: Henry Schwabacker and Frank Corning of Peoria, John Ross of St. Louis, A.W. Weller of Louisville, P.B. Her of Omaha, George Meyer of Terre Haute, P.J. Burganthal of Milwaukee, and about twenty-five representatives of the local trade.

The most striking thing about the racing at Jerome Park yesterday was the wonderful change of form shown by Flirt. On Tuesday this mare of Mr. Croker's could hardly run fast enough to keep warm with the stable boy, Shaw, in the saddle. She was not only badly beaten by Beldemere and Stonenellie, but also by such "crabs" as Florinda and White Wings.

The American people have been deeply touched by the calamity that overtook the Constantinople sufferers, who lost all they possessed by the recent earthquakes there, and are now compelled to live In tents and subsist on charity.

Henry W. Howgate, formerly a Captain in the United States Army, afterward Disbursing Officer of the United States Signal Service, and since April 13, 1882, a fugitive from justice, was a prisoner in United States Commissioner Alexander's office yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The Government cases against American Railway Union were continued to-day, Moritz Rosenthal resuming the argument for the prosecution. He branded the Pullman boycott as a eonspiracy in restraint of trade under the Sherman anti-trust law.

The Democrats of the State of Washington, of whom better things had been expected, have adopted a free-coinage resolution. It is not a matter of serious consequence, as the State is in the zone most exposed to this financial microbe, but there are the beginnings of a great business future there, which will suffer from such attacks.

The Second General Conference District of the Epworth League held its annual meeting and election of officers yesterday afternoon in the Sands Street Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church, Clark and Henry Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon and evening.
Isaac P. Martin, the senior partner in the law firm of Martin Smith, died suddenly yesterday morning at his home, at Fort Washington, this city.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- After an absence of five years from his home in Hurley, Ulster County, John Dearman returned Sunday only to learn that his wife was now the wife of another and that she was living near Albany with his children.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Assistant Secretary Hamlin of the Treasury Department talked entertainingly this morning of his official trip to Alaska, whence he had just returned. He said the Territory was one of vast resources, so far, largely undeveloped, with a great future before it. It should, he thought, be brought into closer touch with civilization and the Government.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)
The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst spoke before an east side audience last night for the first time, and the dwellers in the crowded tenement houses showed a great desire to see and hear him.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- The London Chamber of Commerce gave a complimentary dinner in the Whitehall Rooms this evening to William L. Wilson, Representative in the United States Congress from West Virginia. Sir Albert Kaye Rollit presided, and 100 British and American guests were present, among them being J. Sterling Morton.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 27. -- The one hundred and ninety-fourth year of Yale University was begun this morning. The academic department was the first to open, its members being called together for chapel at 8 o'clock, and the usual exercises being held by President Dwight. The morning was devoted to the work of organization of the various classes, and recitations will begin to-morrow, according to the schedule.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The Republican Congressional Convention of the Thirtieth District, in session at the Genesee County Court House to-day, renominated James W. Wadsworth of Genesen for Congressman.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- The closing arguments in the American Railway Union contempt cases were made to-day, and the cases are now in the hands of the court. Judge Woods set no date for announcing his decision, declaring that he had not yet had time thoroughly to review the evidence and the law cited. It will probably be several weeks before he is heard from.
The three French vessels of war Which yesterday arrived in port form a part of the French Naval Division of Instruction.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 28. -- Word received from the Northwest Colliery, near Carbondale, at 8 o'clock this evening, states that one or the four men buried in the colliery yesterday by a great mass of coal hat been found to be alive on the other side of the mass of coal, and the workmen have been able to talk with him.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 28. -- There is a possibility of a settlement of the labor troubles in the mills in this city. Secretary Howard of the Spinners' Union has written to the Manufacturers' Association, asking for a conference, and Secretary Rouseville has sent a letter in return, saying that the members of the Manufacturers' Association will meet the spinners' representatives at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning.

For the fourth time in recent days, the Cunard Line has scored the triumph of landing passengers in New-York on Friday night. The Lucania achieved that distinction last night, when she reached her dock shortly after 6 o'clock, and had all of her saloon and second-cabin passengers disembarked before 7:30 o'clock.
ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The following is the address to the people by the Republican delegates to the Constitutional Convention on the work of the convention:

CHICAGO, III., Sept. 28. -- The Chautauqua Fountain, presented to the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union by Chautauqua County, N.Y., to commemorate the birth of the union there in August, 1874, was unveiled in the corridor of Willard's Hall at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The exercises were opened with short addresses by Mrs. Mattie McClellan Brown and Mrs. Emily Huntington Miller, the original organizers of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union at Chautauqua.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. George Shepard of West Haven were arrested to-day in that place, charged with bigamy. Mr. Shepard is the son of Dr. Shepard, a well-known physician. The pair eloped last Wednesday, and were married by a Portchester (N.Y.) Justice of the Peace.

The reappearance of Mr. Charles W. Hackett at the head of the Republican State Committee argues a great reliance on the part of Mr. Platt upon Mr. Hackett's capabilities as the manager of a certain kind of campaign, and also upon the shortness of memory of the voters of the State of New-York.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 28. -- The race meet of the Keystone Bicycle Club to-day at Schenley Park was a success, both as regards racing and attendance. No charge was made for admission. About 5,000 persons occupied the grand stand, and a big crowd lined the track. E.C. Johnson won the greatest quarter-mile win of the season, by a bare six inches.
The Republican County Convention's representatives and the Committee of Seventy's sub-committee of seven did not bring about a coalition at the meeting held last night.
Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt arrived in New-York last evening on the Cunard Line steamer Lucania.

ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- The Constitutional Convention, which convened on May 8, probably will adjourn sine die to-morrow. Its work will be submitted to the people on Nov. 6 for final adoption or rejection.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- For some | time past there has been a battle royal In the Republican ranks between Congressman Van Voorhis, ex-Congressman Charles S. Baker, Senator Cornelius R. Parson, O. F. Williams, and Henry C. Brewster for the nomination to Congress from this district.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 28. -- Mayor Wanser to-day formally approved the water specifications in compliance with which bids for a new supply will be received by the Street and Water Commissioners Oct. 22.
BELLPORT, L.I., Sept. 28. -- Justice William J. Gaynor went fishing to-day, and afterward took a drive with James D. Bell, Chairman of the General Committee of the regular Democracy of Kings County.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28. -- Recitations in the Scientific and Divinity Departments of Tale were begun this morning. There are still many students to be heard from, but approximate figures in each department are now available.

ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- Senator Hill's callers to-day included persons from all sections of the State. Telegrams congratulating him on his nomination came to-day in large numbers. Among those received were the following:

The vacation taken by the Lexow committee in order that Its members might attend the Democratic and Republican Conventions will end to-day, and on Monday the committee will continue its investigation of the Police Department.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Sept. 28. -- In the Queens County Court here to-day, County Judge Garretson sentenced Rudolph Leis, twenty-four years old; Theodore Anderson, nineteen years; William P. Bennett, sixteen years, and Joseph Horlak, sixteen years old, to the Elmira Reformatory. After imposing the sentences, Judge Garretson said:

The redistribution of the army now in progress is by far the most important that has been known for many years. Every year there are some changes of this character, based upon the advisability of dividing desirable and undesirable stations fairly and giving variety of experience.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- It is said that Detective Drummond, who effected the capture, in New-York, yesterday of Capt. W.H. Howgate, will be called upon by the Treasury officials to explain why no record was left in the files of the Secret Service office in connection with the Howgate case.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28. -- Cold, dull, cheerless weather, with expectation of rain, helped to keep the attendance at the cricket match here to-day very low. Notwithstanding this, some 4,000 people journeyed to Manheim to see the opening play in the big match between the Gentlemen of Philadelphia and Lord Hawke's team.

BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- After another long programme the meeting of the New-England Breeders' Association ended at Mystic Park to-day. The 2:24 trot looked like a one-two-three affair, till Margaret L., the favorite, slipped up in the third heat. She continued to make breaks till the sixth heat, when the filly surprised everybody by dropping her head and stepping a mile without a skip that landed her a winner after all.

Heaviness in the early part of the day, followed by a sharp recovery in Sugar and Chicago Gas, which to an extent influenced the remainder of the list, was the feature of yesterday's stock market. Sugar was still a pronounced leader in point of activity. The transactions in the first hour were exceedingly heavy, but the price was weak, the lowest point touched being 88 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The retirement to-morrow of Brig. Gen. John P. Hawkins, Commissary General of Subsistence of the army, is a matter attracting unusual Interest, not so much on account of the selection of his immediate successor, who will undoubtedly be Col. Michael R. Morgan, the next ranking officer of the corps, but because of the vacancy, due to promotions, among the Commissaries of Subsistence ranking as Captains.

The address of the people issued by the Republicans of the Constitutional Convention is a mere party plea in defense of an unfair transaction. Unexpectedly and by accident being put in a majority in the Constitutional Convention, the Republicans have taken the advantage of their position to prepare a series of amendments in which, along with some good and useful changes in the organic law, they propose others neither good nor useful, but distinctly partisan.
The Brooklyn police say that Superintendent Byrnes has driven the highwaymen out of New-York, and that they have taken refuge across the river, where they have already commenced to ply their trade.

Henry B. Howgate, alias "Henry Williams," the old-book and print dealer at 80 Fourth Avenue, who is accused of having stolen $370,000 from the United States Government a dozen years ago while he was Chief of the Signal Service, slept with as much apparent contentment yesterday morning at the Ludlow Street Jail as though he were drowsing the hours away in his little basement shop, amid piles of second-hand volumes and engravings.

Ex-Secretary Charles S. Fairchild, exTreasury Controller A.B. Hepburn, and George Coppell, the Reorganization Committee of the Equitable Mortgage Company, which suspended in August, 1893, have completed their work. The successor company was organized yesterday, and Charles M. Preston, Superintendent of the State Banking Department, was elected as its President.

Unquestionably both parties in this State will make a very strong effort to secure a majority in the next Assembly. If the Republicans elect their Governor, the Senate will be theirs by a hold-over majority and the Assembly will be necessary to the complete control of the Government.

WATERTOWN. Sept. 28. -- The Jeffersonian Club of this city ratified the Democratic nominations to-night. Old opponents of Senator Hill joined with his old friends in ratifying his nomination. A telegram from Gov. Flower expressed pleasure at Jefferson County's quick response, and urged every Democrat to active support.
GENERAL LEE. By Fitzhugh Lee. Great Commanders Series. 12mo. New-York: D Appleton Co. $1.50.
LONDON, Sept. 28. -- A dispatch of this date from Shanghai says reports are in circulation that the Province of Manchuria has been entered by the Japanese, who are advancing on Moukden.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 28. -- Communication with South Florida is being restored, and special dispatches are pouring in relative to the damage done by the West Indian cyclone which raged in this State Tuesday and Wednesday.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 28. -- The boarding house of Evan Kavan, at Miner's Mills, was broken into last night by four masked burglars. Kavan was aroused by the noise, and jumped out of bed to defend his home, whereupon he was shot dead. The murderers escaped.

The official oracles of the Weather Bureau are a little disappointed at the failure of that much-talked-of cyclone to arrive here on schedule time. Disappointment is not felt by any one else hereabout, however.

The baleful eminence of Jersey City as typhoid centre is being discussed at great Length in the scientific weeklies. According to Fire and Water, the death rate due to this fearful fever in the chief city of New-Jersey is only exceeded by those, from the same cause, in Pittsburg, Chicago, Louisville, and Washington.

WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 28. -- At the Waltham bicycle track to-day Johnson made a mile in 1:50 3-5, flying start. Until this afternoon the world's record was 1:52 3-5, made by J.P. Bliss at Springfield. The fastest mile ever ridden in the world on a bicycle had been 1:51, by Mike Dirnberger of Buffalo, but this record was not accepted as official, as he was paced by horses.

The well known wholesale grocery firm of Aspell Co. of 314 and 316 Greenwich Street has established a department from which will be supplied groceries to families at wholesale prices. The goods will be delivered, free of charge. In New-York City and Its vicinity.

ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- Unless the Constitutional Convention changes its mind, the final adjournment will take place about noon to-morrow.
