The Steering Committee of the Republicans, better known as the House of Lords, made this decision to-day, but no one can rely upon what will be done to-morrow, owing to the well-established reputation of the convention to change its mind.

Miss Nettie Lee, the youngest daughter of Henry W. Lee, a millionaire, died last night at her home, 65 West Seventy-third Street, from burns received early in the afternoon, When she upset a pan of brandy on a stove.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- There Is another dead-lock between Mayor Oren Wilson and the Common Council. Mr. Wilson was elected last Spring by a combination Of Republicans and Hill Democrats "to reform" the city's administration. His first slate of appointments was rejected three times by the Common Council. About a month ago it wept through with some slight amendments.
Delegates to County, Congressional, Assembly, and Aldermanic District Conventions were elected last night by the New-York State Democracy in this city.
Ex-Mayor William R. Grace, one of the leaders of the State Democracy, was among the passengers who came from Europe yesterday on the Cunard steamship Lucania on her record-breaking passage.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 28. -- At the meeting of the Western distributors of whisky and spirits yesterday, a committee was appointed to prepare a set of resolutions to the trust favoring an advance and a change In the rebate system, and the result of Its work was adopted. The meeting then adjourned, to meet in Peorla next Thursday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept., 28. -- The Democratic Society of New-Jersey, of which W.S. McKean of Asbury Park is Secretary, purposes taking an active part in the State campaign this Fall, its principal work being in the direction of arousing the Democratic voters of the State to the importance of making the fight on national issues.
There is some talk among the Democrats who were refused representation at the Saratoga Convention of putting an independent State ticket in the Field.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- Daniel B. Hubbard is in jail here for attempting last night to kill his wife and Frank Garsuch, a young man with whom she was walking on the street. Hubbard and his wife live in Dorchester, Mass., and she came here to visit her parents, who live at 568 Evanston Avenue.

Not all these letters are published here for the first time. In Emerson's small volume of 1865 was printed a selection from Thoreau's correspondence, but it shed little light on his personality and illustrated only one side of his character. Mr. Sanborn has aimed to show us his domestic side, (which had real attractions.) and his practical side, (which really had an existence.)

The Prison Sunday Committee of the Prison Association of New-York met yesterday at 135 East Fifteenth Street and designated Oct. 28 as Prison Sunday for this year. The Chairman of the committee, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Brooks, presided, and among those present were the Rev. Dr. J. M. Buckley of The Christian Advocate, the Rev. Dr. W.R. Huntington of Grace Church, and Prof. Charlton T. Lewis, President of the association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- In its desperate search for campaign material, the Republican Congressional Committee has put in circulation a statement that the Pension Bureau, under Democratic control, has more than doubled its issue of pension certificates in the last month; that this issue has been in the doubtful districts, and that the whole intent and purpose is to aid the election of Democratic candidates for Congress by capturing the soldier vote.

Police Commissioners Martin and Sheehan took occasion, at the meeting of the Board of Police yesterday, to reply to Superintendent Byrnes, in answer to his action in breaking away from the board, because, as he asserted, the Commissioners had hampered him in the performance of his duty.

The officers and members of the Twenty-third Regiment, as well as the veteran association connected with, that organization, are working hard to make their fair in the new armory in Bedford and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn, a success. There was a mass meeting In the old armory, in Clermont Avenue, last night, in which the matter was discussed at length.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The question, Who shall be the next State Committeeman from this district? is now agitating the Democrats here. It is now stated that a choice has been made, and that the name of the man is known to three or four leaders who have the ear of the powers that be at Albany.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- This was Hackney Day at the horse show at the Westchester County Fair, and the high-steppers were greatly admired as they were put through their paces in the ring. Old Fashion, a great favorite with admirers of this breed of horse, was applauded as he made his appearance, and the judges thought him good enough to win the prize for stallions with three of their get.

There was another day of decidedly tame racing at Jerome Park yesterday, the natural result of conditions for races being made for certain horses or certain stables. Yet the last three races were omre like contests than any that have been had at the track this season.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 28. -- There was no abatement to-day in the interest taken in the fifty-third annual exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society. It was the fourth day of the fair, and fully 20,000 persons passed through the gates.

On Thursday two speeches were made on the tariff policy of the United States by the most eminent and most authoritative leaders of their respective parties. One was delivered by Gov. McKinley of Ohio in the town of Findlay in his own State, the other by Chairman Wilson at a banquet in his honor by the Chamber of Commerce of London.

Copyright. 1894. by The New-York Times. NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 28. -- David A. Wells pointed out to a reporter for The New-Tork Times that under the existing basis of representation in Connecticut a very small proportion of population elects the men who represent the State in the United States Senate.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 28. -- Mr. Andrew D. White, ex-United States Minister to Russia, and his wite were granted an audience by King Christian to-day and later dined with his Majesty. Mr. John E. Risley, United States Minister to Denmark, was also a guest.

Several private sales of real estate of some magnitude were about completed yesterday, but they are not yet in shape for publication. There were rumors, also, of several more which have been mooted for a month past, including a parcel on Fifth Avenue. In the latter instance the parties concerned denied that any contract had been made.
The independent county organization held a convention at the Cooper Institute last night. The hall was crowded and the band began to play about 8 o'clock.

The Lexow committee witness George Appo, of "green-goods" fame, who testified as to the manner in which "greengoods men" treat their victims, and told a story about the police force protecting the members of the fraternity, yesterday cut his throat while in a state of drunken delirium.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The members of the Asbury Park Wheelmen participated In a ten-mile road race this afternoon, and there were twenty-two participants. The course was from Asbury Park to Oceanvllle and return, the finish being on Asbury Avenue.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The nominating committees appointed by the People's Party Conventions on Thursday made public their action to-day. John S. Queens of Perth, Fulton County, is their choice for Congress in the Twenty-second Congressional District, and John W. Shurter of Gansevoort, member of Assembly for Saratoga County.

Supreme Court Justice Edgar M. Cullan of the Second Judiciary District was yesterday renominated by the Republican Judiciary Convention, which met in the Kings County Court House, Brooklyn, for the term of fourteen years. As Justice Cullen is a Democrat and will undoubtedly be the Democrtaic candidate to succeed himself, his election is practically certain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- "On to Pekin!" is the slogan of the victorious Japanese. The army of 30,000 men which has entered the Chinese Province of Manchooria is supposed to be advancing rapidly upon the capital, Moukden. Another army of 40,000 men is being conveyed across the Gulf of Pe-Chee-Lee, and these troops, it is believed by Japanese officers here, will soon land in the Chinese province of that name.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., Sept. 29. -- The first expert practice of the season was held here to-day. The weather was fair, but a strong "2 o'clock" wind was blowing, making good shooting difficult. Only those who have made 45 or over in the sharp shooters' class are allowed to compete for the "expert" decoration, and they must make eight or more hits out of ten shots at 700 and 800 yards, five shots at each distance.

ALBANY, Sept. 29. -- During recess to-day the delegates crowded into the Assembly parlor and organized, with Mr. Peck as Chairman. Mr. Peck said that he hoped the gathering would be the first of a series of meetings of the Association of the Delegates to the Constitutional Convention of 1894.

When the gentlemen who take charge of the "business end" of what used to be the game and is now the business of baseball come to foot up their accounts for the season that closed yesterday, some of them may find that they have had more profitable seasons than that of 1894.

The children of Jay Gould, as individuals and as executors and trustees under their father's will, procured an order from Justice Lawrence yesterday, requiring the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessment to show cause on Oct. 4 why the assessments upon their personal property in this city should not be canceled.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The Democrats of the Second Assembly District of Westchester County held their convention here this afternoon to nominate a candidate for member of Assembly.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- If you were turning out of Bond Street toward Regent Street Into London tailor land this week, you would understand why it is said that we are now in the height of our American Summer. From Paris, Rome, the Engadine, and all Baedeker land, in fact, homeward-bound Boston and New-York people are lingering here a while, bent on serious calls on West End tailors.

To the average person a bunch of flowers in a vase must be harmonious and beautiful under all circumstances. The artistic and educated taste knows that it is quite as easy for the combination to be most unpleasing.

There is no use in denying that the Constitutional Convention has been a distinct diappointment to the people of the State of New-York. That may be their own fault for having entertained high hopes of it, as they undoubtedly did. That it had a Republican majority was allowed for by the entertainers of the hopes.

The sound practice of continuing upon the bench Judges who have proved themselves just and capable has been followed by the Republicans of the Second Judicial District, who yesterday nominated Judge Edgar M. Cullen of Brooklyn to be his own successor as a Justice of the Supreme Court.

Why should the French word employe be so much used when we have at hand the English form of the same word, which seems at once to suggest itself and answers every purpose? Employee is surely the English correlative of employer. When we want the correlative of examiner we say at once examinee, and so in other analogous cases, e. g., licensee, assignee, addressee, consignee, mortagee.

Copyrlght, 1894. LONDON, Sept. 29. -- A considerable amount of gold has gone out from the Bank of England this week, and, with the heavy payments required for displacing funds, loan rates have hardened, in some cases 1 per cent, being paid for the balance of the month. Attempts have been made to lift the rates of discount, but paper is in short supply, and the efforts have met with but very little success.
BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- The agitation for a revival of the Polish kingdom continues to be the foremost topic of discussion throughout Germany, and particularly in Berlin.

During the next two weeks or so the Congressional nominations will be made. For the Democratic Party their character is of the gravest importance. Happily, in the great majority of cases, the Democrats now in the House have done their duty well, and have made an excellent record, not only on the essential question of tariff reform, but on all other questions of interest.
There have been many burglaries within the past two months in the annexed district and the police think they now have three men who can throw some light on the robberies.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Among the many gratifying letters received to-day by Secretary W.S. McKean of the State Democratic Society was one from Assistant Secretary McAdoo of the,Navy Department, in which he says of the proposed conference of the Executive Committee of the society at Trenton on Tuesday:

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Superintendent of State Banks Preston to-day said concerning his election to the Presidency of the Equitable Mortgage Company of NewYork City that he had accepted the post, but that it would be some considerable time, probably, before he would take charge. He had not contemplated the matter of resigning as Superintendent of State Banks.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- Daniel B. Hubbard of Dorchester, Mass., Consul at Annaberg, Germany, under the Harriaon Administration, who shot his young wife and Frank Gorsuch last Wednesday evening, because he saw them talking together earnestly on the street, is still in jail here. He passed last night In oweeping and asking for news of his wife.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 20. -- The Reds won today's same after the Giants had it well in hand. Meekin was substituted for Rusie as pitcher, and the Reds got in their work on him. The game was full of exciting plays, and the crowd applauded in old-time style. Attendance, 1.162.

Mrs. Masters, 130 West Washington Place, says "I had inflammatory rheumatism so badly I could scarcely move; my joints were frightfully swollen and stiff and so tender I could not bear to be touched. Munyon's Rheumatism Cure acted like magic, relieving the pain and soreness at once and effecting a complete cure in a remarkably short time.

From Truth, London. The story told by Mr. Jonathan Pinchbeck at North London Police Court last week is so remarkable as fully to deserve the prominence that has been given to it in the press. Mr. Pinchbeck, among other striking statements, asserts that from January, 1876, to January, 1893, he picked up on his way to and from his work in the neighborhood of Clapton 600,000 cigar ends, which he valued at u1,800.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Advices from Shanghai to the Central News say the Emperor attributes the recent defeats suffered by the Chinese forces to incompetency and corruption, and this fact has caused almost a panic in the palace and has rendered the position of affairs in China extremely serious.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 29. -- In a blissful state of intoxication, Thomas Murray of 37 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn, sat down on the railroad track near Penny Bridge, about 9 o'clock to-night, to think. He was still there when the west-bound Jamaica Express came along. The pilot of the locomotive hurled him from his seat over an embankment thirty feet from the track.

Of all months of the year, September is the one selected by the angler in which to fish for the muskallonge, the largest, and by may considered the gamiest, of all the inland fishes of American waters. Certainly its enormous size and distinctive habit of leaping into the air when hooked entitles this fish to the reputation given it by fishermen, comparatively few of whom have trawled for this mammoth of its tribe.

Poor LI Hung Chang has lost his threeeyed peacock feather. The conferring of the latter is a special mark of royal favor and corresponds with a medal voted by Congress or a decoration such as the Order of the Garter or the cross of the Legion of Honor, and its loss is a disgrace that will be keenly felt.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Perfect weather, good attendance, and an attractive programme, made the last day of the combined horse show and county fair on the grounds of the Agricultural Society a great success.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The politicians of Westchester County are full of activity these days, and, as nearly all the conventions for making nominations have been called, the availability of this or that candidate for the party's support is being canvassed with great care.

From The Cincinnati Tribune. James Miller of Des Moines Iowa, is the most wonderful living example of the power of indomitable will and pluck. He was running on the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and had been in the service twenty years. The accident through which he came so near losing his life occurred in the Fall of 1880 at Tyrone, Iowa, and was caused by a head-end collision between two passenger trains.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Miss Emma Berg, daughter of Frederick Berg of Hillside Avenue, and William I. Nixon of Palouse, Washington, were married at the home of the bride on Thursday evening by the Rev. Stanley White of the Hillside Presbyterian Church.

A large number of the members of the Sixth Election District Association of the Ninth Ward, Brooklyn, met last evening at 266 Flatbush Avenue to express their dissatisfaction with the nomination of David B. Hill.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- There were offered at the wool sales to-day 9,278 bales. The bidding was spirited, especially for greasy merinos. The purchases for America were on a par with previous takings, but there was a keener demand by German operators. All good parcels sold readily at full rates, but the lower sorts were somewhat, irregular. Fallowing are the pales in detail and the prices obtained:

The bicycle is steadily growing in favor with the British, volunteer. At the recent annual review the cycle corps attracted a great deal of attention, and undoubtedly deserved it, for the number of riders that fell from their machines convinced the spectators that a battle in which a corps of cyclists should take part would be extremely amusing to both the contending forces.

MECHANICSVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- A person registered on Monday last at the Hotel Leland as "Howard Burton, Troy, N.Y." The individual wore blue goggles and was dressed in man's attire. It was ascertained that the supposed young man was a woman.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 29. -- Ten good races were run at the national race meet of the Wheeling Athletic Wheelmen. The island track was in excellent shape. Sanger won both of the the open events, being required to win twice the so-called international contest. The limit of 2:25 was not met by a dozen seconds in the first attempt.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29. -- A wonderful surgical experiment has just been performed on Edward Kerwin of this city, whose back was broken by a fall Thursday. Dr. W.W. Hawkes of the local hospital found the vertebrae separated by an inch, also the cartilage lacerated and a profuse hemorrhage.

The doors of the Irving Place Theatre were opened again last evening, and the German end of the dramatic season started off on what should be, if beginnings count for anything, a most prosperous career. They don't, always, as more or less mournful experience has proved, not once or twice, in the past.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- It looks as if Nicholas Murphy of Haverstraw, late Chairman of the Democratic County Committee, had really got into trouble over his refusal to notice a mandamus served upon him at the Democratic County Convention two weeks ago. He was ordered to appear before Judge Dykman, at White Plains, today, and was acompanied by his attorney, Irving Brown of Haverstraw.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 29. -- Standing room was at a premium In the grand stand at the Mineola Fair Grounds to-day. It was the last day of the Fall exhibition of the Queens bounty Agricultural Society. The bright sunshine and a good racing card combined to bring out a crowd. The attendance was estimated at 12,000.

MONTREAL, Sept. 29. -- The annual championship games of the Canadian Amateur Athletic Association were held here this afternoon, and were participated in by a large number of the leading cracks of the United States, as well as the best men in Canada. The attendance was very large, and the weather all that could be desired. The results follow:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Apathy among Democratic voters la Virginia is the only thing the Democrats of that State have to fear, according to Chairman Ellyson of the State Democratic Committee. Mr. Ellyson was in Washington to-day and spent some time at the headquarters of the National Campaign Committee.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The firm of John C. Wilson Co., dealers in hats at 208 Greene Street, New-York City, have begun an action against Charles Crossley, a hat manufacturer of this city, to recover $15,000, alleged to have been obtained by fraud.
DUBLIN, Sept. 29. -- A manifesto has been issued by the Parnellite section of the Irish Party in which, the other factions of the party are violently attacked. The document says:

A few more noteworthy features than have been common recently have marked the transactions in real estate during the past week. The sales have just begun to be more numerous, although the volume of transactions is not nearly what an active season should show, and some of them are quite significant.

Members of the committee appointed by the Republican County Convention to confer with the Seventy over the formation of a local ticket held informal conferences yesterday and discussed the situation as it appears after the first meeting, which was held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Friday night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29. -- Prince and Princess Ruspoli dined with Baron and Baroness Seilliere to-night, who entertained in their honor with a charming floral display and a dozen guests, including Prince John del Drago, the Marquise de Talleyrand-Perigord, and Mr. and Mrs. William Post. The Prince and Princess were out driving nearly all day, as they are delighted with Newport scenery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- One effect of the nomination of Mr. Hill for-Governor of New-York has been to arouse the Democrats now engaged in the campaign in the various Congressional districts. "I am not particularly fond of Mr. Hill," said a prominent Democrat to-day, "but his nomination has undoubtedly done more to excite enthusiasm in the Congressional districts throughout the country than anything that has happened since the campaign opened.

PORT RICHMOND. S.I., Sept. 29. -- The citizens of this place, who for three weeks have been in a constant state of alarm over the operations of a firebug who has Started a dozen fires in the most thickly populated districts, can now rest peacefully. The firebug is in the custody of the police and evidence has been secured which connects him with nearly all of the fires that have occurred.

One practical result of Secretary Lamont's recent orders abolishing the three recruiting depots at Columbus Barracks, Davids Island, and Jefferson Barracks is already seen. In a single day more than 600 recruits at those points were assigned for distribution to companies and light batteries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- West Virginia Democrats who come to Washington agree that the campaign in the district of Representative William A. Wilson is the hottest they have ever known. Editor Thompson of Martinsburg, who called at the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee to-day, said the Republicans were working night and day to obtain votes, and were being aided by the big coal syndicates of the State.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- Nine voters were disfranchised by the Election Inspectors of the Fifth Deer Park District at the last election, the Inspectors refusing to receive the votes because the voters had not returned from the booths when the hour fixed by law for closing the pools arrived. The Attorney General has just rendered the following opinion on the case:

From The Edinburgh Scotsman. Jingo, says Prof. Skeat, has nothing to do with the Basque word for delty, or anybody else, and never had. If we wish to find the true derivation we must look in quite another direction. In the first place, ProfSkeat will allow nothing to the Basque; in the second, he will not permit students to speak of "corruption."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- Lord Hawke has another victory to add to his record, and an easy one, for his English team gave the Gentlemen of Pliiladelplila players the worst beating they have sustained at the hands of a foreign eleven in years, the victory going to the Englishmen by no less than an inning and 40 runs.

BELMAR, N.J., Sept. 29 -- The inlet to Shark River has been reopened, and the fish, oysters, and crabs again enjoy the luxury of their native salt water. So menacing had become the danger to the fishing industry that the interested ones became greatly alarmed, and a call for assistance to aid in opening the inlet was made.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Miss Nellie Garrett of 273 West Twenty-first Street, New-York City, has bought the Russell Hulick property on Deal Lake. The price paid for the cottage and grounds was $13,000. Miss Garrett will remodel the house, increasing its size, and make other extensive improvements.

The challenge that is expected this Fall from Lord Dunraven for a race next year for the America's Cup is already being freely discussed by yachtsmen, and it looks as though there will be some lively discussions in the New-York Yacht Clubhouse on the conditions of the race that will be suggested by Lord Dunraven.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- Summer weather seems to induce Summer dullness, and even Bay State Gas forgot to fluctuate, being quieter than for days past. The stock opened up 1/4, at 11 1/4, and closed 11 3/4. The 1st bonds were steady, at 81. Bell Telephone sold, ex dividend, at 203. This is 1/2 off from the last sale of 208.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 29. -- A grand camp social was held in the gymnasium of the Young Men's Christian Association this evening by the younger members of the organization.

As to the local Democratic situation in this city, it can be said with certainty that the leaders of Tammany Hall have not yet decided, even in a preliminary way, whom they will name for Mayor. The same is true in regard to candidates for President of the Board of Aldermen and Sheriff. Several have been considered -- and are still under consideration -- for Mayor.
BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- An important decision against the United States Government was rendered to-day by Judge Colt, in the United States Circuit Court.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29. -- The authorities of the Agricultural Experiment Station in this State are greatly interested in the appearance of a new and very annoying weed within the borders of Ohio. It is the Russian thistle, which has already been such a nuisance in the West and within the last few months has shown itself in Ohio for the first time.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. H.V. Randall of Third Place have returned from Claremont, N.H.

Ex-Police Inspector Henry V. Steers, now on the retired list, made a statement yesterday in which he asserted that two years ago President Martin said the resolution adopted by the Board of Police in September, 1891, was intended to prohibit the employment of policemen in citizens' dress for the purpose of procuring evidence against saloon keepers.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- The Tompkins County Democratic Convention met in this city to-day to make county nominations. The body was called to order by F.M. Leary, with about fifty delegates, slightly above one-half of the full convention, present. Before proceeding, to nominations, Civil Service Commissioner D.F. Van Vleet made his report of the Saratoga Convention eulogizing Senator Hill.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 29. -- A reception was given last evening by Mr. and Mrs. Willlam H. King at their home, in Springfield Avenue, in honor of their niece, Miss Helen Wright, and their son, Parker King, whose birthdays fall on the same date.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 29. -- The Lenox cottagers have had one of the busiest weeks of the season. The fine weather has made driving especially attractive, the golf club has been well patronized, and the young women have been trying their sailboats on the lake. The largest entertainment was a dancing party given by John Sloane.

The new order of the Community of the Brothers of the Church was instituted yesterday, in St. Chrysostom's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, when Russell Whitcomb took the vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience, and became the first member of the brotherhood, under the name of Brother Hugh.

The congregation of St. Luke's German Evangelical Lutheran Church hopes to worship early next Spring in a handsome and substantial church which is being built for it in Washington Avenue, near De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 29. -- The inquest to determine the cause of the death of Charles B. Chauvin, the Grosse Pointe recluse, who was found dead in his squalid two-room house, on Jefferson Avenue, on the afternoon of Sunday, Sept. 9, was commenced this morning at the office of Coroner Trombley, at Grosse Pointe.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 29. -- A fair town is this, sitting by the sea, and as tranquil as the sunshine on the waters of its harbor. There is one yearly occurrence that wakes it, and that is the Harvard-Yale boat race. Immediately it is over, the town becomes normal once more.

The Mansion House, in Hicks Street, between Pierrepont and Clark Streets, Brooklyn, is one of the best-known select family and transient hotels in that city. Its location on the Heights is ninety feet above the East River, thus insuring pure air. It commands one of the finest views in Brooklyn.

The opening session of the eleventh annual convocation of the Christian and Missionary Alliance was held last evening at the Gospel Tabernacle, at Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. There was a large attendance. The Rev. A.B. Simpson, pastor of the Tabernacle, presided.

"A reason," says a physician, "why I often prescribe one of the mineral waters for my patients and have them take it daily in considerable quantities is simply to give them sufficient water. It is an error committed by many otherwise sensible and intelligent persons that drinking much water interferes with digestion.

PATERSON, N.J, Sept. 29. -- It is not often that a road race arouses such enthusiasm as the race between Louis Laffray and Thomas Hughes did to-day. The interest in the contest had been gradually worked up. until the friends of the two men were in a fever heat of excitement, and, to crown all, the race was only won by half a wheel after riding twenty-five miles.

Some interesting phases in Northern Pacific affairs developed yesterday. About $2,135,000 of receivers' certificates fall due on Monday, and the receivers were naturally anxious to raise the money to take them up.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29. -- One hundred and sixteen delegates to the Second Republican Congressional District Convention met at Veru Hall this morning to select a candidate against the present Democratic member and nominee, J.J. Pigott of this city.

Ex-Sheriff Charles B. Farley, who was one of the best-known firemen in Brooklyn, and who died from blood poisoning at his home on Van Buren Street, near Stuyvesant Avenue, Wednesday, was buried in the Holy Cross Cemetery, in the Twenty-ninth Ward, with honors yesterday.
It was not determined yesterday if the wound in the throat of George Appo, the "green-goods" expert witness of the Lexow committee, was self-inflicted or otherwise.

The century run jointly promoted by the Gramercy and Lexington Wheelmen, which takes place to-day, will probably be the largest affair of Its kind ever held in the State. Over 800 entries have been made, including 52 ladles and probably the youngest rider that was ever booked for a century. The latter is a lad of twelve years, but a remarkable cyclist for his age.

A great deal more is expected of Miss Olga Nethersole, who is now on her way across the Atlantic Ocean, than of any other foreign actor about to visit us -- of Mr. Beerbohm Tree, for instance, who is a London actor-manager, and a man of an odd and eccentric personality, and whom, we know beforehand, we must grow to like by slow degrees.

Last week, at the theatres, we were taught how to win a woman -- those among us, that is to say, who are still in the field and taking our chances. But this is the lesson the theatre generally teaches. Its curriculum is commonly believed to be broad, but most popular plays are love stories, and nothing else.
CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 29. -- Judge Brentano of the Superior Court and his family have apparently been marked out for assassination, although the facts have been kept quiet.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The Crescent Wheelmen held their fourth tournament here this, afternoon, under conditions particularly favorable. The weather was perfect, the track as smooth as a billlard table, the races very interesting, and the attendance large.

In October the calm mornings of sunshine will visit us occasionally and appear like glimpses of departed Spring amid the wilderness of wet and windy days that lead to Winter. We now are beginning to see the difference between having the sun on our side the line and seeing him hurrying away to the southward.

When one's train enters the big Indian Valley, and when from the summit, as the cars round a graceful curve not unlike the more famous Horseshoe near Altoona, the eyes feast upon the noble view, the words of Byron come back to memory: "High mountains are a feeling." He wrote them in the days when his heart throbbed before the beauty of the Alps.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 29. -- Democratic sluggishness has disappeared in this State. United States Senator McPherson has returned from Washington, and announces that he will lead the Democratic Party this Fail in the interests of good government and tariff reform, and that this leadership is not conditioned on being a candidate for the United States Senate.

Candidates for the football teams are at practice getting their muscles hardened for the rough campaign that they are to go through. Capt. Hinkey, the silent man of Yale, was at the pretty Summer home of the New-York Athletic Club, up at Travers Island, with the men who are to represent Old Eli this year.

There was a great deal of activity yesterday among the Democrats who are considering the advisability of putting an independent State ticket in the field. The arrival of William R. Grace from Europe served to stimulate the movement, which, even before he reached port, had been active enough under the leadership of Edward M. Shepard.

The Kings County Grand Jury for September, which was discharged yesterday, handed down a presentment which treats of several questions which they believe the people of Brooklyn should know.

Miss Wormeley's peril in translating the works of Moliere came only slightly from her attempt to give an English guise to a form essentially French. Miss Wormeley has proved by her translation of the works of Balzac that her technical skill in the art is exact, and she might not easily have failed in applying it to the clearer French text of the seventeenth century.
The celebration of Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, will be begun by the Hebrew people throughout the world this evening with the solemn rites which have characterized the day for centuries.

Six races and a walk-over for the only stake event on the card made up the programme offered to a good crowd of holiday seekers at Jerome Park yesterday. As usuual, the class of horses contending was of the most commonplace, and three of the races were one-sided affairs, though the other four produced sharp contests and some considerable interest in the struggle for the money.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- Both private appeals and public warnings by the leaders of the Irish Party have failed to disturb the reticence of the Ministers with regard to the policy they intend to pursue during the coming session of Parliament, and the position of affairs political verges on a great crisis.

APPLETON, Wis., Sept. 29. -- The greatest syndicate deal since the purchase of the American breweries by English capitalists has just been concluded, and, unless something unforeseen happens, all the paper and pulp mills on Fox River will pass into the hands of an English syndicate April a next.

The movement of the Democratic Society of New-Jersey in the direction of making the next six weeks an active and aggressive agitation of tariff reform is sound. That is what should be done in every State and in every Congressional district. The reform of the tariff is the central object of the Democratic Party.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 29. -- Michael Delehanty of 819 Second Avenue, Henry Imhoff of 837 First Avenue, and John Reddy of 314 East Forty-fifth Street, NewYork City, were run clown in the East River, opposite Thirty-fourth Street, about 11 o'clock to-night, by the Thirty-fourth Street ferryboat Long Beach, while on its way from New-York to Hunter's Point.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30 -- The nominees of the democratic Party for State offices give general stisfaction to the Democratic masses and to the leaders. Not a Republican paper in the State has said a word of unfavorable criticism about the candidates.

The Rev. Dr. G. Arbuthnot, rector of Holy Trinity Church, Stratford-on-Avon, England, and custodian of the tomb of William Shakespeare, is at the Holland House. He intends making an extensive tour of the United States.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 30. -- A bill providing for a Constitutional Convention for Connecticut was Submitted, considered at considerable length, and finally killed after a hard fight in the celebrated "dead-lock" Legislature two years ago. The bill at that time had the support of all Democrats in the Senate, with a Single exception.

The Hon. Murat Halstead was the speaker at the Republican meeting on Saturday evening selected to present the Republican view of national questions. He is an able man, of positive convictions and large ideas, and probably fairly represents the sentiment of earnest and sincere Republicans as well as any of the leaders of this part of the country.
Mr. Brayton Ives authorizes the following statement concerning the payment of the receivers' certificates of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company:

Probably the greatest trade convention New-York has ever seen will open this evening at Delmonico's when President Frank A. Faxon of Kansas City will call the twelfth annual meeting of the National Wholesale Druggists' Association to order. With the possible exception of the National Bankers' Association, there is not another business organization in the country that represents as much wealth in the aggregate as the druggists.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 30. -- Alvin Carnahan and Winslow Breedy, two athletic students in the Edinborough State Normal School, had a wrestling bout Saturday. Carnahan caught Breedy and was about to drop his head and shoulders forward, and throw him over his head.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 30. -- Rescued from what was believed certain death on Thursday, when a portion of the workings of the Northwest Colliery, at Simpson, near Carbondale, caved in, "William Mitchell, George Arney, John Fanning, and Andrew Klappowsky have been to-day the objects of demonstrative rejoicing in the village.

The Rev. Dr. John Hail, who has just returned from his vacation, was welcomed to his pulpit in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday morning by a large congregation. He seemed in perfect health, and said he had been, greatly benefited by his trip abroad.

The banner century run of the season in the Empire State took place yesterday in a gale of wind. Four hundred and thirty-two riders passed over checks at the start, and as nearly as could be estimated last night about 300 completed the century.

Hubert Gardiner,a Member of the firm of Gardiner Estes, shoe manufacturers, 675 Hudson Street, was found in an unconscious condition Saturday night at Thirtieth Street and madison Avenue. The effort of three policemen were repuired to remove Gardiner to the sation house.

The games of Saturday brought the championship series of the Metropolitan Cricket League to a conclusion, although there is still one game -- between Paterson and Staten Island -- unplayed. The New-Jersey Athletic Club easily won the championship, while its second team takes the pennant in the second-eleven section. The NewYorks came out ahead in the second section, with the Harlems a very good second.

LONDON, Sept. 30. --- The Shanghai correspondent of the Central News announces that the British steamer Pathan, which was recently seized off Formosa by a Chinese war ship, has been released by order of the Tsung-li-Yamen, the Chinese Foreign Board: The Pathan will proceed to Shanghai under bond.

The Rev. Dr. John A. B. Wilson of the Eighteenth Street Methddist Episcopal Church, in the prelude to his sermon yesterday morning, read lo his congregation parts of an affidavit made by jared Flagg, in which an attack is made on Police Captain Donohue of the West Twentieth Street Police Station.

BERLIN, Sept 30. -- The correspondent of the United Press had an interview to-day with a nigh military officer in Berlin concerning the arrest of 183 non-commissioned officers in the training school in the Invaliden Strasse last night. The correspondent learned that the arrested officers, contrary to the rules, bad maintained regular students' unions and had edited a beer gazette, in which various officers and institutions were lampooned.

The past week has seen a very large demand for the gilt-edged securities, and there is every reason to believe that it will continue for some time to come. The prices of bonds creep higher and higher, but still purchasers are willing to buy. There is much money being held back, which will have to be invested before a great while by institutions whose daily receipts are increasing rapidly.

CONEY ISLAND, Sept. 30. -- Damage that will mount up to many thousands of dollars was done by the storm late last night and early this morning at Brighton and Manhattan Beach. Sea Breeze Avenue, just in front of the Ocean Hotel, was so badly washed out that the Slocum electric railroad tracks caved in at the point where they turn in back of the Brighton Hotel.

"wait until to-morrow; the situation has not arrived at a point of development. Nothing has been decided on yet, even as to preliminaries," was the reply yesterday to inquiry in regard to the intention of the State and Shepard Democrats as to putting an independent State ticket in the field.

BUFFALO, Sept. 30. -- Franklin D. Locke, the best all-around fighter among the opponents of the State organization, said today that, while he would not vote for Senator Hill, and would be glad to support Charles S. Fairchild for Governor, he could not think of accepting any nomination on the proposed independent ticket.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- The University of Rochester has opened for its forty-fifth year with a freshman class of 83, within two of the number registered last year, which was the largest in the history of the college. Over fifty of this year's freshmen are from Rochester, a much greater proportion than usual.

With the advent of really cold weather it is expected that many of the crack cyclists will journey to the sunny South, and there continue the onslaught against Father Time. W.W. Taxis of Philadelphia is expected to be among the first to go, and if he continues to ride as he has during the past month there is reason to believe he will place a number of important records to his credit.
The postponement of the competitive tests of magazine rifles at Newport to the present week has given an opportunity for some tardy inventors of breech mechanisms to complete their preparations.

John E. Milholland, the President of the Republican organization of the City and County of New-York, sat in his room in the State Club yesterday pondering on the resignation of Police Commissioner Michael Kerwin and others from his organization. Gen. Kerwin was Chairman of Milholland's Executive Committee.

A smaller entry list than usual for a Central Park championship tennis tournament was posted Saturday afternoon on the lower courts in the park. Champion Fischer seems to have so tight a grip on the cup that the younger players failed to enter, as usual, and only sixteen or seventeen of the old timers presented themselves to do battle.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 30. -- A week ago Moses H. Katzenberger, one of the leading representatives of the Hebrew race in the South, and President of the Mechanics' Savings Bank of Memphis, died in this city. Yesterday his will, covering many hundred thousand dollars' worth of property, was filed for probate, and it proved a remarkable document.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The Opposition press never was more active than now in inventing stories representing a rupture between the Emperor and Chancellor von Caprivi. This time it is alleged that the Kaiser has had a difference with the Chancellor over the measures of repression which it is proposed by his Majesty to have introduced in the Reichstag during the coming session of that body.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- The new Caucus act passed by the Legislature of 1894 has been tested by both parties, and it may be pronounced a success. The system of choosing delegates under its provisions is somewhat elaborate and cumbrous, but when the voters get more familiar with it they will forget its apparent defects on account of its numerous advantages.

William J. Bok, who manages a newspaper syndicate at 23 Park Row and who is a brother of Edward W. Bok, editor of The Ladies' Home Journal of Philadelphia, has caused the following advertisement to be printed:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30. -- The political leaders of both parties are awaiting with much interest the outcome of the town elections in Connecticut to-morrow. Every town in the State, except New-Haven and Bridgeport, has an election for town officers and for license or no license.

The residents of Fort Greene Place, between Hanson Place and Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, have been greatly perturbed of late, as it was whispered among the neighbors that a colored man had purchased a house in that very select block.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 30. -- The Republican County Convention, held here yesterday, which was controlled entirely by the Hendricks faction, resulted in the nomination, of about as weak a ticket as could be put together. At the head was placed the name of William M. Ross, for County Judge, as unpopular a lawyer as is connected with the Onondaga County bar.

Columbia College will begin the one hundred and forty-first year of existence this morning. Judging from the registration, many of the schools will be taxed to their utmost capacity. This may especially be said of the School of Medicine, where, notwithstanding that the new four years' course has just been inaugurated, during the last week many applicants were turned away, owing to the lack of accommodations. Everything points to year of great prosperity.
Jeremiah J. Sullivan, a brother of State Senator Timothy D. Sullivan, died at his home, 303 Broome Street, on Saturday, and will be buried to-day in Calvary Cemetery.
FROSTBURG, Md., Sept. 30. -- Cardinal Gibbons preached on "Labor" to a large congregation in St. Michael's Church to-day. In the course of his remarks he said:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 30. -- The political leaders of Monmouth County are putting in their spare moments figuring on the probable result of the approaching election for Congressman and Assemblymen. The Congressional and Assembly Conventions will both be held next week, the former at New-Brunswick and the latter at Freehold.
LONDON, Sept. 30. -- The Standard's correspondent in Berlin is authority for the statement that Prof. Leyden diagnosed the Czar's allment as Bright's disease in an advanced stage.

It is doubtful if there is a single racegoer who will regret the ending of the Jerome Park meeting on Thursday next, and the removal of the scene of racing from the old saddlebags track to the great stretches and the hills and dales of Morris Park. John A. Morris is back from Europe, and he will probably order that the tracks at Morris Park be properly put in condition for racing.

A most important epoch in the history of the University of the City of New-York will be marked by to-day, for then the undergraduate college, which for the last sixty years occupied the old Gothic structure which stood until recently oh Washington Square, will take possession of its hew home at University Heights, on the banks of the Harlem River.
The Rev. Dr. R. S. MacArthur preached last night in Calvary Church, Fifty-seventh Street, near Sixth Avenue, on "The Corean War in Relation to Civilization and Christianity." He said:

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Sept. 30. -- The fagged-out cyclone from the tropics reached the Jersey coast to-day, The wind blew with terrific force and drove the Waves shoreward mountain, high. At high tide this evening the breakers engulfed the pavilions along the beach front, and the waves inundated the board walk, and surged over into Ocean Avenue.

HOLLY SPRINGS, Miss., Sept. 30. -- The death of Gen. A.M. West, candidate for Vice President on the National Labor ticket in 1884, occurred this morning. He was seventy-six years of age at the time of his death.

If heredity is worth anything, Robert Edward Lee, the fourth son of Gen. Henry Lee, came of prime stock. The immigrant ancestor of the Lees was an English cavalier gentleman -- Col. Richard Lee, who first came from Shropshire to Virginia in 1641. He was loyal to Charles I. Returning to England more than once, he, in the time of Charles II., finally took up land in Northern Neck, between the Potomac and Rappahannock Rivers.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $817,150. The banks now hold $60,791,825 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $358,400, an increase in species of 5148.100, an increase in legal tenders of $345,400, a decrease in deposits of $1,294,600, and an increase in circulation of $363,300.

Acting under the stringent orders of Superintendent Thomas Byrnes, the police of New-York were extraordinarily active yesterday in their efforts to suppress Sunday saloon traffic. They made the most earnest attempt in many years.

With the opening of the public schools in Brooklyn, Mayor Schieren's Advisory Committee will have an opportunity to study in actual practice the evils of the present system, for which they are called upon to suggest a remedy. We believe that the main source of most of these evils will be found in what may be called crowding.

WINSTED, Conn., Oct. 1. -- In Litchfield County, Winsted is heavily Republican, the majority ranging from 300 to 400. License was carried by 53 majority. Norfolk went Republican by 53 majority; Torrington Republican by 250 majority, and license by 141 majority; New-Hartford, Republican by 85 majority, and license by 18 majority; Riverton, Republican by a majority, and no license, by 131 majority; Hartland, Republican by 20 majority; Colebrook and Canaan both voted for license.

The Lexow committee's investigation was resumed yesterday in Part III. of the old Court of General Sessions. Nothing startling was presented, although, in the afternoon, Capt. Cortright of the Eldridge Street command was "named" in an indirect fashion as the recipient of tribute money.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- The market opened slightly off, and seemed inclined to work to a lower level. In most stocks there was no particular pressure to sell, but the buying demand seemed somewhat abated. The tractions were moderately active. Philadelphia is being well bought and well supported, and, considering the large amount of long stock that has been marketed lately, the price has been maintained remarkably well.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 1. -- The purchase of the Staten Island ferry franchise by Howard Carroll, son-in-law of John H. Starin, who outbid Frank S. Gannon. Superintendent of the Rapid Transit Railroad Company, which has held the lease for the past ten years, has created great interest and discussion on Staten Island.
It will probably be decided to-night whether or not an independent Democratic State ticket will be placed in the field.

Unless bad weather or the proverbial slowness of tournament committees prevents, this will be the last week of the local tennis season as far as tournament play is concerned, except on the Fifth Avenue Tennis Club's courts. The Fifth Avenue Club has tournaments scheduled for Election and Thanksgiving Days, and the club will as usual, have the honor of closing the outdoor season.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The police this afternoon raided the quarters of a bogus lottery, at 100 Hudson Street, on the top floor. It was conducted by the Hamilton Engraving and Printing Company, managed by Joseph W. Hamilton of Van Pelt Manor, L.I., and Samuel Hamilton of 420 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn Joseph W. Hamilton, Elizabeth Fitzpatrick, who was employed to fold circulars, and B.J. Flood and Daniel McNamara, printers, were arrested.

The firm of Journeay Burnham of 28 to 36 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, is holding a Fall opening of high-class novelties in Winter cloaks. The stock includes a complete line of cloth, plush, and fur garments of foreign and domestic manufacture.

The Executive Committee of the Committee of Seventy held conferences with the representatives of the O'Brien Democratic Association and the Independent Democratic County Organization at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. An hour was devoted to each organization, and then the Executive Committee devoted a half hour to a discussion of conferences with other antiTammany organizations.

The foreign exchange market was dull and firm. The posted rates for sterling were $4.86 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.85 1/2 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 1/2 for demand, $4.86 3/4 for cable transfers, and $4.84 3/4 for commercial.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

At the Second Presbyterian Church, corner of Remsen and Clinton Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday, the Brooklyn Presbytery held its semi-annual meeting. In the evening a bronze tablet, in memory of the Rev. Dr. Henry J. Van Dyke, who for forty years was pastor of the church, was unveiled.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The Thirty-fourth District Democratic Congressional Convention, comprising Allegany, Cattaraugus, and Chautauqua Counties, met at Salamanca this afternoon and appointed a committee of three with power to select a candidate for Congress. Its members are Fred C. Mulkins, Allegany; S.H. Terrence, Cattaraugus, and George C. Vandusen, Chautauqua.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 1. -- The Hon. George E. Foster, Minister of Finance, will sail on Saturday for London, England. The departure of Mr. Foster is kept quiet, and the reason that takes him away at this season is not to be had. This cannot long be kept secret. Meantime, it may be said that the Finance Minister leaves for the purpose of trying to replenish a depleted Treasury.
The twelfth annual convention of the rational Wholesale Druggists' Association organized last evening, shortly after 8 o'clock, at Delmonico's.
Joy beamed on the faces of the Republicans as they walked about the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The members of the Nereid Boat Club held their annual regatta Saturday on the Passaic River, opposite their boathause, on Main Street, Belleville. The course was half a mile in length, between Belleville Bridge and the clubhouse. There were eight races, and the results were as follows:

The reassembling of the Lexow committee yesterday opens what is probably the last act in the present investigation of the police force. It is to be hoped that the investigation will be made as thorough as possible, so that there will be as little as possible left for the ordinary agencies of justice to do in the way of collecting evidence.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- For some time past a horse thief, supposed to be Bert Wells of this village, an ex-convict and a fugitive from the Albany Penitentiary, has been operating among the farmers in the neighboring towns, and several of them have lost good horses, notwithstanding the fact that many of them had formed a vigilance committee.
Wheat closed firm at an advance of 3/8@1/2c on better cables, light contract deliveries, decrease on passage, and local covering, with a fair business, chiefly scalping and switching.

The bears had pretty much everything their way in yesterday's stock market. The Jewish holiday, perhaps, had something to do with the contraction in the volume of business, but still the total was not far below the usual average of late. The railway list, although heavy, was not so weak as the industrials.
Clearing House affairs will occupy the attention of bankers a good part of to-day. The annual election will be held, and the cornerstone of the association's building in Cedar Street will be laid.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1. -- From the returns received in this city to-night from the town elections, in every town in the State, except New-Haven and Bridgeport, the indications point to a slight Republican gain in the vote. This gain is attributed to local issues entirely.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- All the winds that blow from Georgia indicate a superabundance of political activity in that State. Practically every man who can talk is on the stump, and the gospels of the different political parties are being everywhere proclaimed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Second Assistant Postmaster General Neilson, who has charge of the mail transportation service of the country, has under consideration a plan for utilizing the cable railway system of New-York City in the distribution of the mails to districts convenient to those systems.

Miss Olga Nethersole, whose first appearance on the stage in this country is to be made at Palmer's on Oct. 15, and whose fame reached here some time ago owing to her many successes in London, arrived in New-York on the steamer Berlin from Southampton yesterday. Miss Nethersole was accompanied by her brother, Louis Nethersole, a maid, and a friend to whom she is much attached.

Tammany's Congressional District Conventions are to be held on Thursday night. While there may be some adjournments, it is probable that most of the nominations will be made then. For the past few days, yesterday especially, there has been a great amount of hard work done by the politicians in certain of the Congressional districts.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1. -- To-morrow the thirteenth annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Tennis Association will begin in this city. There are thirteen colleges in the association. It will be the last big tournament this season in which the famous tennis players will contest. Among Yale men it is expected she will win in this battle, notwithstanding that Brown University is put down as the probable winner by those outside of the Yale contingent.

It was positively funereal at Jerome Park yesterday, where an alleged race meeting is in progress. The crowd was a little larger than those which have assembled to see the baseball games in Louisville recently, but, except in the race in which Halton was permitted to make such a display of himself, it was hardly more enthusiastic.

What the late Charles Sumner was in the habit of denouncing as the "accursed spirit of caste" has not been destroyed by his denunciations. Indeed, the particular phase of it which he deprecated is as strong now as it was before the war, as strong at the North as at the South, and as strong among Republicans as among Democrats.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 1. -- Capt. Halsey and his crew and the passengers of the steamship "Knickerbocker had a thrilling experience in the big storm of last week. The vessel arrived this morning at her pier very much battered, and with two of her crew missing.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- It is reported here that the case of Dr. Burtsell against Archbishop Corrigan has been referred to Mgr. Satolli for final settlement. The Pope has decided that on account of Mgr. Satolli"s acquaintance with all the phases of the case his decision will be absolutely fair to all parties concerned.

GRAFTON, West Va., Oct. 1. -- The Democrats of this district purpose giving Congressman W.L. Wilson a triumphal reception upon his return from Europe. The details of the affair are now being arranged by Mr. Lawrence Gardener, the Secretary of the Democratic National Congressional Committee, and Mr. McGraw, the Chairman of the District Committee.

Columbia College began the one hundred and forty-first year of its history yesterday. In every department of the university an increase is shown, and all indications point to a year of greatest prosperity. President Seth Low made a short address of welcome to the students in the chapel at the morning exercises.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 1. -- A tornado struck the northern part of the city about 6 o'clock this evening, and tore property in all directions. Several people were injured, but so far as known, no fatalities occurred. The wind came from the southwest, accompanied by a fierce rain, and at Tenth Street it took off the roof and one side of a street car barn.

Mr. Moses H. Katzenberger, deceased, of Memphis, in the State of Tennessee, being presumably of sound and disposing mind, prepared some time ago his last will and testament, in which was the following somewhat unusual provision:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- If William E. Werner, the candidate on both the Republican and Democratic tickets for Supreme Court Judge, resigns the position of County Judge in time for his successor to be chosen at the November election, he must do so, under the law, before Oct. 10. In order to let the Republican County Convention nominate a candidate, he must resign this week, as the convention is called for Saturday morning.

WEST POINT, Oct. 1. -- Cadet William Stanley Valentine, a member of the third class, was tried by court-martial several months ago for hazing. He had been a Corporal in camp, and was relieved from the duties of a non-commissioned officer at the time of his arrest. He was also confined to the limits of camp and barracks pending the approval of his sentence by, the Secretary of War.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The Grand Jury of the Criminal Court of the District of Columbia has returned Indictments against H.O. Havemeyer and John B. Searles of New-York and Alien Louis Seymour of Seymour Brothers Young, brokers, of this city.

PHOENIX, Arizona, Oct. 1. -- The Southern Pacific east-bound express was held up two miles east of Maricopa last night by three men, two of whom were masked. They boarded the train as it was leaving Maricopa and captured the head brakeman. He was compelled to turn on the air brakes and stop the train.

In the furtherance of their work of abolishing improper pictures from the billboards and living pictures from the stage, Mrs. Emilie D. Martin, National Superintendent of the Department for the Promotion of Purity in Literature and Art of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, with her co-worker, Mrs. H.S. Pritchard, called by appointment upon Superintendent Byrnes at Police Headquarters yesterday morning.

On Saturday last, while the Republicans of New-York were listening to the argument and exposition of Mr. Murat Halstead, the Republicans of Boston were applauding a much more elaborate address by ex-Senator George F. Edmunds. No man has a better title to speak for his party.

It is not surprising to find the Japanese Legation in London denying the report that Japan has offered an apology to Great Britain, with money indemnity, for the sinking of the transport Kow-Shing by the cruiser Naniwa. If such an offer were made, it would have to be ascribed to the desire to placate England rather than to any sense that it was due.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- The Gaulois is authority for the statement that the Emperor of Germany recently said to a French gentleman whom he received in Berlin: "I shall meet you again at the Paris Exposition in 1900."

LONDON, Oct. 1. -- The St. James Gazette prints a dispatch from Shanghai to a news agency here stating that the return to power of the Emperor's uncle. Prince Kung, who has been in disgrace many years, includes the privilege of at all times entering the imperial palace.

The large circle of lights in Sherry's big ballroom gleamed like a halo over the heads of a large gathering of fair maids and matrons yesterday. Sorosis began its twenty-seventh year under the most favorable auspices.

It is the annual custom of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad to run a great excursion from the northern counties of this State to New-York City. The ninth annual affair of this description will occur to-day and to-morrow, the excursionists reaching this city this evening and tomorrow morning.

Superintendent Byrnes was feeling happy yesterday over the results obtained in his efforts to compel the liquor sellers to keep within the law and not sell during the prohibitive hours. There were 240 arrests for violation of the excise law on Sunday, as told in The New-York Times yesterday.

The Bell Democratic General Committee, at a meeting last evening in the Brooklyn Athenaeum, by a unanimous vote denounced the selection of ex-Senator P.H. McCarren, ex-Senator John McCarty, Senator Michael J. Coffey, and ex-County Clerk John Delmar as members of the Democratic State Committee.

The close of Summer brings a modification of Nathan Straus's plan for providing the poor of New-York with pure and healthful milk. Now that the season of cool weather is come, milk will keep longer, and there is not so much necessity for Mr. Straus's extensive work as there was in the Summer months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- It was expected when the Tariff bill became a law that the clause providing for the imposition of a duty of one-tenth of a cent a pound on sugar imported from countries which pay a bounty on sugar exported would meet with objection on the part of those countries affected by it.

The modification of the injunction of Judge Jenkins in the railroad strike cases will cause little surprise and less regret. The basis of the injunction as understood at the time was that whatever interfered with and hindered the transportation of the mails, or inter-State commerce, was illegal, and that a strike of railway employes did so interfere, and could therefore be enjoined.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- Army officers at headquarters and officials of the Indian Bureau here declare that the arrest of Capt. P. Henry Ray, Eighth Infantry, Acting Indian Agent at Shoshone Agency, is probably the result of a conspiracy against him, caused by his activity in putting intruders off the reservation.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- Exciting scenes were witnessed at the Republican caucuses in this city to-day for the election of delegates to the Republican County and City Conventions, where full tickets are to be nominated for county and city officers. There were no fights, but a larger vote was polled than for years before.

Who is to be Tammany's candidate for Mayor is still an open question. The discussion of available men still goes on among the leaders, but the point has not yet been reached where even a tentative selection can be made.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net increase in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during September of $8,152,700.84. The interest-bearing debt increased $140, the non-interest-bearing debt increased $824,182.95, and the cash in the Treasury decreased $7,228,337.89.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1. -- The first month's receipts of the Treasury Department -- namely, for the month of September -- under the operation of the new tariff law were made public to-day. The aggregate receipts for the month were $22,621,288, as compared with $24,582,756 for the month of September, 1893.

Mrs. Joseph Medill, wife of the editor of The Chicago Tribune, died at Elmhurst Ill., a suburb of Chicago, yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. Bronchial consumption was the cause of her death. The deceased was the daughter of the late Hon. James Patrick of Ohio, who was educated at Belfast College.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 1. -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt and Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt returned from Boston this morning, and Mr. and Mrs. F.W. Vanderbilt came back tonight. Cornelius Vanderbilt went through from Boston to New-York.
The Presbytery of New-York met yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street. About 100 delegates, clerical and lay, answered the roll call.

ALBANY, Oct. 1. -- Albany is the scene of many conrerences these days, Each or the political parties has its internal differences over local officers, and the leaders have at least one conference a day. This morning a committee of the new, or Hill, Democracy, consisting of Andrew Hamilton, Francis B. Delehanty, and Robert Bryce, was closeted with Senator Hill for some time, asking his advice as to the course its faction should pursue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Sudden death overtook Miss Belle White, a rather comely young woman, while trying, by artificial means, to have herself made more attractive. She was a daughter of Benjamin S. White of the lumber firm of White Leathers, with main offices at Grand Rapids, Mich. Her home was at 3,850 Lake Avenue.

READING, Penn., Oct. 1. -- A victory for the Bowmanites in the long Evangelical Church war was scored to-day by Bishops Esher and Bowman in the Supreme Court. This decision ousts the Dubs faction from not only the Reading church which brought the test case, but from the 210 or more Evangelical churches in Eastern Pennsylvania alone.

The Garbage Commission held a meeting yesterday afternoon at its rooms in the Army and Navy Building. During the session four men were heard in arguments favoring their different schemes to dispose of the city garbage.

Recent demands for bills of small denomination for shipment to move the crops having reduced the supply at the SubTreasury, it was decided yesterday to make exchanges only for gold or gold certificates.

From The Staats-Zeitung of Yesterday. When David B. Hill last year forced the nomination of Maynard, the latter was buried under an adverse majority of over 100,000. Maynard dragged down the entire Democratic ticket into the abyss. Both, branches of the Legislature were made Republican.

Chauncey Olcott, formerly of the minstrel halls, has become, under the able administration of Augustus Pitou, the successor to Emmet and Scanlan in the eye of the public. He is a singing comedian, who is not expected to act very much. He seems to have all the needful qualities of a popular stage hero of this sort.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 1 -- A three-cornered race is in progress in Queens County for the Democratic nomination for Sheriff. The contestants are ex-Sheriff John J. Mitchell of the city, Josiah L. Pearsall of Roslyn, the present Under Sheriff, and Philip T. Cronin of Far Rockaway, who at one time represented the First District of Queens County in the Assembly.

CITY ISLAND, Oct. 1. -- Bound East -- Steam yachts Maspeth, Christopher Meyer: Helvetia, C. O'D. Iselin; Aquilo, George A. Thayer; Formosa, George F. Fabyan; Veto. George Law, and Hustle, Richmond Pease. Schooner yachts Fenella, N.L. McCready; Waterwitch, David Banks, and Viator, W. Gould Brokaw.

CHESTER, Penn., Oct. 2. -- The passengers on board of the New-York and Washington express train on the Pennsylvania Road due in this city at 10:20 this morning had a remarkable escape from serious injury and perhaps death. The train struck one of the Dupont powder wagons near Gordon Heights, killed one of the horses, seriously and perhaps fatally injured the driver, and scattered one-pound cans of powder in various directions without an explosion.

Irving J. Benjamin, business manager of The American Druggist, gave a dinner last evening at his residence, 234 West Seventieth Street, to a number of the visiting delegates to the National Wholesale Druggists' Convention.

It appears to be the general desire of the New-York bar, irrespective of political affiliations, to renominate Judge Charles H. Truax for Justice of the Supreme Court, and it is believed that he will receive the indorsement of the Republican Party, as well as that of the Democracy.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners met at 256 Broadway yesterday and listened to the reading of communications from Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons and Henry R. Beekman and Albert B. Boardman, counsel for the board.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 2. -- Business circles in this vicinity are much more active than they were a month ago. The money market is much easier. The several banks in this city have recovered from their recent diffidence in handling the paper of their patrons, and every one says that a marked change for the better in the financial condition has occurred since the passage of the Tariff bill by Congress.

The statement of ex-Police Inspector Steers to the effect that while he was in office President Martin and the Police Board ordered that the police be not detailed in citizens' clothes to secure evidence of violations of the excise laws is corroborated by ex-Superintendent Murray.

Those Republicans who insist upon a Republican candidate for Mayor of this Democratic city might as well drop the mask of reform. A frank confession of their partisan purposes would be good for their souls, and it would cost them nothing, for they would merely have to confess what everybody already knows.

Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan said yesterday, in a board meeting, that the Detective Bureau was the worst feature of the Police Department. He referred to the use of the merit system in making appointments and promotions.

The owner of Copyright, whoever he may be, J.C. Carr, one of the deposed Big Four at Guttenberg, or "Mike" Daly, attempted a coup at Jerome Park yesterday. He, or they, tried to win both the first and the last races. Copyright succeeded in landing the opening race, which was a dash of a mile, and for which he was an odds-on favorite, Setauket and Miss Dixie being the pair to give him an argument.

The Empire Theatre Dramatic School, which Mr. Nelson Wheatcroft brought into successful recognition last season, commences its second term on Monday, Oct. 15. The report of last year's work contains among its long list of patrons the names of Messrs. Palmer, Frohman, French, Pitou, Aronson, Sanger, Barnabee, John Drew, Alexander Salvini, and N. C. Goodwin.

George F. Sewardi ex-Minister to China, was asked yesterday what may be expected in China from the return of Prince Kung to the Presidency of the Tsung-li-Yamen. He answered that it must be considered an excellent movement of that Government. The Prince is a man of good ability and of large experience in foreign affairs. He Is not at all revolutionary in his ideas.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 2. -- There is a decided chilliness between Mayor Latrobe and Capt. Charles H. Davis of the United States cruiser Montgomery. His Honor claims that the commander has cast all official etiquette to the winds, and openly snubbed him, as well as the people of Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The deal in West Chicago Cable stock is very much mixed and brokers are at sea as to the outcome. At times it is given good support from all sides and then is deserted and allowed to drop off, only to be supported again. It is almost wholly a speculative movement at present.

Hiram S. Thomas, proprietor of the new Lake House, at Saratoga Lake, N.Y., has completed his negotiations for the house at 131 Fort Greene Place, Brooklyn, and his family will move into their new home about the middle of the present month.

In the total of 197,977 shares done on the stock market yesterday, 107,563 shares, or more than 54 per cent., were in Sugar. In only three other stocks did the trading exceed 10,000 shares. These were Chicago Gas, Burlington, and St. Paul. The remainder of the list was very quiet and was without feature.

Dr. O'Sullivan of the law firm of Brooke, O'Sullivan Brooke, who defended Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, now serving a life sentence for poisoning Ludwig Brandt, said yesterday tha if the woman alleged to be Meyer's wife, who is now in prison, charged with conspiracy, should be brought to trial, the prosecution would be laughed out of court.

A spectacle absolutely without parallel, as amazing as it was unique, was presented yesterday to the Lexow committee in the room of the abandoned Criminal Court House, where Carlyle Harris was tried and convicted.

The five-story tenement house at 215 Madison Street was set on fire yesterday by an explosion of an oil stove in the basement, which, was occupied by Philip Krieger, a shoemaker. Krieger's daughter, Libbie, two years old, was burned to death, and many of the tenants had narrow escapes.

In view of the sharp fight now waging for Atchison proxies, to be used at the annual election in Topeka, Kan., on the 25th inst., the recently-reorganized Board of Directors yesterday issued a circular to the stockholders, which contains some significant points.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- Prof. Leyden of Berlin, the celebrated specialist, who was sent for by the Czar, has diagnosticated his ailment as Bright's disease of the kidneys in an advanced stage. -- Press Cable.
The Chairmen of the Assembly district organizations of the State Democracy held a meeting last night in the hall of the Reform Club, in East Twenty-seventh Street, that was long and secret.

Soon after 7 o'clock-last evening a coupe drove up to the Thirty-eighth Street entrance to the Hotel Normandie. Some one who was evidently on the watch for it hurried into the dining room, where Senator David B. Hill was just beginning his dinner.

The Committee of Seventy had planned that its conference committee should meet a like committee from the New-York State Democracy to-morrow, believing that at the County Convention of the State Democracy at the Cooper Union to-night such a conference committee would be appointed.
The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst spoke at a meeting of the City Vigilance League, held last evening in the Annex to Amity Church, 312 West Fifty-fourth Street. He said, in part:

The sumptuous headquarters of the Republican State Committee, T.C. Platt owner, in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, with a rear door attachment, were visited yesterday by a number of the distinguished ones of the party.

The General Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County of which Edward M. Shepard is Chairman met in the Brooklyn Atheneum last night and passed a resolution declaring that it would not indorse or support the nominees of the Democratic State Convention.

LONDON, Oct. 2. --The Daily Graphic to-day says the wreck of the Russian ironclad Rousalka, which was lost in the Baltic Sea last year, was found on Sept. 19 south of the islet of Wastertokan, Finland.
