The wreck lies in twenty fathoms of water. A diver who went down and examined the hull reports that he found a great hole in the stern.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- The general trend of prices to-day was toward a lower plane. A continued selling of long stock helped along the downward movement. The traction stocks were less active. Philadelphia Traction was fairly active and advanced throughout the day. People's was inclined to sell off, and Electric was fairly steady.
Wheat declined 1@1 1/8c, on lower cables, weaker West, increased supplies, and foreign selling, December going 3/3c below previous low record and closing weak, with a fair trade.

The Staten Island public is still in the dark relative to the plans of Howard Carroll, who purchased the Staten Island Ferry franchise last Saturday. It was arranged between Controller Fitch of New-York City and Mr. Carroll that the contract should be executed yesterday, but Mr. Carroll did not appear.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The opening paragraphs of the indictments found against Messrs. Havemeyer, Searles, and company, in connection with the Senate Sugar Investigating Committee, recite the terms of the statute sugar schedule of the McKinley act and conclude with the statement that "the several terms and provisions aforesaid of said act were of great benefit and advantage to the interests of a certain corporation called the American Sugar Refining Company."

Promise and performance have seldom been more at variance than in the case of the Republicans who were the natural and chosen leaders in the Constitutional Convention. They set out for the capital with lofty professions of a patriotic desire to formulate amendments of the fundamental law so just and perfect that every delegate to the convention would sign them and urge their ratification upon the applauding people.

A meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday, attended by Messrs. Howell, Schieren, Henriques, Skinner, and Keeney, was held for the purpose of hearing the report of Chief Engineer Martin in relation to lighting the cars on the bridge with electricity. Mr. Martin's recommendation would have been adopted had it not been for Trustee Skinner, who, as he expressed it, was opposed "to any one picking out something to suit somebody."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Edward B. Whitney, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, to-day filed the answer of John G. Carlisle, Secretary of the Treasury, and Joseph S. Miller, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, to the application of the Miles Planting and Manufacturing Company for an injunction to compel to show cause why the Treasury Department should not pay the bounty on the sugar production provided by the McKinley Tariff bill for the year 1894.

Dr. A. Conan Doyle has arrived, and soon Americans whom big books hava pleased may become well acquainted with his personality, for he has come to give lectures, and there Is something of one's mind in one's voice.

"Dr. Syntax's" Free Show. -- The matinee to be given by De Wolf Hopper and his company at the Broadway Theatre to-morrow afternoon is not to be a professional matinee in the strict acceptance of the word. That is to say, actors not specially invited will have no privileges at this performance not granted them at others of "Dr. Syntax."
Thomas Ludlow Ogden of the law firm of Ogden Beekman, 111 Broadway, died yesterday at Spring Lake, N.J., of organic troubles.

The Ladies' Health Protective Association of New-York held its first meeting of the season at the Charity Organization rooms, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, yesterday morning. The attendance was not large, all the members not having yet returned from their Summer outings, but the enthusiasm of those present made up for the lack of numbers.

Prof. Vincenzo Botta of 25 West Thirtyseventh Street fell from a third-story window at the back of his house about 4 o'clock yesterday morning, breaking four of his ribs and otherwise seriously injuring himself.
The cornerstone of the new Medical Hospital, which is to be a part of the New-York Homeopathic College and Hospital, at Sixtythird Street and the Eastern Boulevard, was laid yesterday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 2. -- Two classes made up the card for the commencement of the Fall meeting at Pimlico Park, and the divided heats among the dozen trotters in the 2:29 class took up most of the afternoon. Charlie H., who started favorite, gathered in two heats, and many thought he finished first in the third one. The judges caught Jacksonian ahead of the other gelding, and gave him a mark just inside 2:20.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 2. -- The reception which the Baltimore Baseball Club, champions of the United States, received on its return home to-night surpassed anything of the kind ever attempted in this city. At Washington a committee from Baltimore took charge of the champions and escorted them to this city. As the special train rolled into Camden Station tonight hundreds of track torpedoes were exploded and thousands of throats emitted yells of welcome.

There is no doubt that both the typewriting machine and the phonograph are very ingenious and useful inventions, but the chief difficulty with them is that they cannot be made to act automatically. It has long been felt that what is wanted is a machine which will compose a story, a speech, or an essay without the intervention of man.
Sheriff Sexton yesterday said, regarding his refusal to deputize men to serve subpoenas for the Lexow committee:
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- The Legislature met to-day and almost immediately adjourned sine die, without doing anything in the way of legislation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry of New-York City, called to order in the City Hall this morning the fifth annual convention of the Societies for the Prevention of Cruelty in New-York State. About twenty-five delegates were present, including a few ladies. Mayor Wilson welcomed the delegates.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- The additional returns received to-day from the town Sections in Connecticut confirm the report in The New-York Times this morning that the Republicans have made slight gains throughout the State, but that this Increase In the Republican vote is due to local causes solely, and has no bearing on the State election next month.

Lemuel Ely Quigg, the young Napoleon and the young James G. Blaine of the Republican Party, as he was designated by his supporters, was renominated last night by Congress by the Fourteenth District Conventlon, which was held at the rooms of he West Side Republican Club, 102 West Eighty-second Street.

There was a daring robbery in Myrtie Avenue, Brooklyn, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and the thief, with two associates, escaped with a tray of diamonds, which had been stolen from the jewelry store of Henry Healy, at 331 Myrtle Avenue.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 2. -- A terrible cyclone swept over the business portion of this city at 7:30 o'clock to-night, carrying death and destruction in its path.

NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 2. -- Prince Ruspoli did not visit Harvard College Monday, as he intended, though the Faculty had made great preparations for his coming. He overslept, and consequently was too late to catch the train. To-night Mrs. F. W. Vanderbilt gave a dinner in honor of the Prince and Princess. Mr. and Mrs. William Post, Baron and Baroness Selliere, Prince John del Drago, and the Marquise Talleyrand-Perigord were among those present.

Imported gowns, coats, wraps, and hats just from Paris form a brilliant display at the Fall opening of Simpson, Crawford Simpson, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street. This firm makes it a point each Autumn to give an exhibition of goods that surpasses any of former years.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- The Hill or "New Democracy" has accepted the inevitable. Its leaders held a conference at 11 o'clock to-day and decided that it would be best to nominate no candidates for county offices, but to indorse all of those placed in nomination by the regular Democracy. At the County Convention, held a little later, the following resolutions were adopted:

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 2. -- The Republican County Convention held here this afternoon to nominate a candiate for State Senator and four Assemblymen was the most turbulent gathering in this city for years. A serious split is threatened. Ex-Sheriff Winfield S. Cox openly avowed his intention of fighting the nominees of "Boss" Joseph H. Quackenbush.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- The address which was prepared by the Democratic delegates to the Constitutional Convention in condemnation of the actions of the Republicans in the handling and the lack of handling of certain measures was issued to-day, a committee consisting of John M. Bowers, Eugene Durnin, and De Lancey Nicoll coming from New-York to promulgate the same and to file it, with the archives of the convention, with the Secretary of State.

Surrogate Abbott of Kings County yesterday rejected the will of Michael Conion, which was dated Jan. 24, 1893. Mr. Conlon died at the Gouverneur Hospital Jan. 25, 1893. He lived at 87 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn.
The Consolidation League of Brooklyn, whose members are working in favor of a Greater New-York, held a meeting yesterday in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. James Matthews presided.

The delegates to the annual convention of the National Wholesale Druggists' Association, at Delmonico's, began work at 9 o'clock yesterday and kept it up all day, winding up with a dance and reception at night.
The property at 22 to 26 North Moore Street, near Varick Street, 71.6 by 88, with three-story old building, renting for about $2,400, is reported sold by the owner, Mrs. Woodhull, at about $70,000.
The shopping women of New-York are finding out, to their entire satisfaction, that the tariff is a tax.

The headquarters of Mrs. Emilie S. Martin, who is prosecuting the work of reform in bill posters, living pictures, and unclean literature, is Room 85, in The Times Building, where she receives a hundred or more letters in relation to her work every few days. She visits the office only occasionally, and in her absence she is represented by Anthony Comstock of the NewYork Society for the Suppression of Vice.

TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 2. -- Seventy determined Democrats, representing every county in the State, met in the rooms of the Democratic League of Trenton to-day and decided that the fight for supremacy in New-Jersey was worth making, and resolved to make it in a way that never had been made before.
LONDON, Oct., 2. -- The Shanghai correspondent of the Central News telegraphs:

Whatever fortune may await Princeton on the football field this Fall, her students have already won one great triumph, since the term opened, in public opinion, and presumably in their own self-respect, by their manly stand against hazing. This contemptible practice is utterly without defense or excuse, except such as is contained in the silly plea that, being handed down from class to class, it has become a time-honored custom which must be perpetuated.

SARATOGA. N.T., Oct. 2. -- The dead-lock in the Twenty-second Congresional District Republican Convention still continues, and there is no intimation that It will be broken for some time to come. The 179th ballot was taken this afternoon, and the result was a continuation of the others, as follows: Gen. N.M. Curtis of St. Lawrence, 15; Gen. W.B. French of Saratoga, 9; Judge A.D. L. Baker of Fulton, 6.

Brooklyn Democrats who are Democrats from principle -- and not for -- what they can get by being in politics -- were jubilant yesterday when they heard of the tremendous denunciation that was heaped upon ex-Senator P.H. McCarren, ex-County Clerk John Delmar, ex-Senator John McCarty, and Senator Michael J. Coffey.

Mr. Goff opened a new and very promising line of inquiry yesterday by producing the official returns of the policemen who within the past few years have been convicted of brutally clubbing citizens, and also by producing the clubbers themselves. The advantage of this line of inquiry is that it puts the responsibility for the condition of the force upon the shoulders of the Commissioners, where it belongs.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- The market for local stocks was uninteresting and with no marked features. Bay State Gas, as usual lately, was the most active of the list, but fluctuations were very narrow. It opened at 12, declined to 11 3/4, moved back to 12, and closed at 11 3/4. Bell Telephone was off 1/2, to 203.

WELLSVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 2. -- At but one previous meet this season has there been as slim an entry list of Class B men as here to-day. There were fourteen entered and only eight appeared, including Sanger, Cabanne, Dr. Brown, the Johnson brothers, and Goetz. Sanger rode probably his last race to-day for the season or 1884, and his ten-thousand-dollar prize list was completed.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The population of Staten Island is over 60,000. The number of people daily using the one ferry to the island is about 20,000. The circumstances of the sale of the franchise makes one doubt whether these 20,000 people are considered to have any rights. It's the case of "the public be -- "again.
Side by side with her triumphs in battle on land and sea, the "coming nation" of the Orient is making peaceful conquests in diplomacy and in her relations with Europe and America.

Oswald Ottendorfer tendered his resignation as President of the German-American Reform Union at the regular meeting of the General Committee at Terrace Garden, Fifty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, last evening.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- A Central News dispatch from Shanghai says the Han-Keoo Province has been depleted of troops.

Yesterday was a day of developments in the plans for the operation of the Staten Island Ferry. Howard Carroll, the purchaser of the franchise, has returned to the city and declares that he bought the franchise in good faith, and purposes to operate the ferry and provide Staten Islanders with as good, if not better, service than they now have.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- At to-day's final session of the Convention of Humane Societies, Dr. Balch of Yonkers offered the following, which was adopted:

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- For the time being interest in local stocks has veered from the favorite West Chicago Cable stock to "L" stocks. Both Alley and Lake Street "L's" are moving freely. The positive character of the trading indicates favorable developments in the near future, as there were evidently quite a number of investment orders.

The Park Commissioners, who have heretofore opposed the appointment of a landscape architect to supervise the construction of the Harlem River Driveway, yielded yesterday to the arguments of those who wish to see that road made a thing of beauty as well as of use, and adopted a resolution to make the desired appointment on next Wednesday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- There was issued from the Democratic State Executive Committee headquarters to-day an address to the voters of Ohio, in which it is declared that the restoration of silver to free coinage is the supreme issue before the people. In the national contest two years ago, the address states, the fight was made by the Democracy for tariff reform and silver restoration.

An instance of the low rate prevailing for mortgage loans was given by a broker yesterday. It was the placing of $10,000 at 4 per cect. on an Allen Street tenement appraised at $23,000. He said he believed it was the only loan at so low a rate ever placed in the neighborhood.

Papers were filed in the United States Circuit Court in this city yesterday in a case of uncommon scope and peculiar interest. The Prescott and Arizona Central Railroad Company sues each road in the Atchison system, and the Directors of each separate corporation individually, to recover $8,250,000 damages.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- At the beginning of every quarter of the year it has heretofore been the custom of the Post Office Department to extend the free-delivery service to those towns whose receipts had so increased as to warrant such an extension. For months, in many small towns where this system had been in use, the Government has been steadily losing money on account of the receipts running behind the expenses.

Ex-Postmaster General Thomas L. James was to have presented before the Garbage Commission yesterday some facts additional to those he has already given concerning his observations of the different modes of disposing of refuse in cities in England, but he was unable to be present, and no meeting of the commission was held.

In one of Wagner's letters from Paris, (1841,) which are being repainted in The Meister, is a joke which he takes from The Charivari of the day. At the wedding (then recent) of Jules Janin, M. Chateaubriand was among the guests. The bridegroom begged him for his blessing, which he refused, however, with the words, "All that I have blessed has fallen."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- Philadelphia Traction continued strong. It is reported that there will be another allotment of stock some time this Winter. If the new stock is put out at or near par Philadelphia Traction Should go higher. The par is $50, and the stock is full paid in cash. People's was Inclined to sag in the early trading, but later was strong on good buying.

The business done at Ellerslie yesterday was perfectly decorous and conventional. Mr. Morton was informed that he was running for Governor. He knew that already, but etiquette and campaign finance required that the fact should be borne in upon his understanding. Gen. Collis did the job in a speech of fearful stiffness and formality.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct., 3 -- During the last six weeks there have been several instances of the sinking of small areas of land in the Arkansas and the Walnut River, in Southern Kansas. The most northern of these was in Harvey County, and this was perhaps the largest, the area being about a fourth of an acre of the highest prairie in that vicinity.
"John W. Goff for Mayor" was a "preference" that set the temporary State Democracy County Convention, at the Cooper Union, last night, wild with enthusiasm.

The current number of The Forum contains an instructive exposition, by Mr. Michitaro Husa, of the Eastern war from the Japanese point of view. Such expositions are very timely, because the view of which we hear most in this country is the British view, and the British press at the outset of the war pretty generally took the Chinese side.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- The dullness of the market for local stocks amounted almost to stagnation, and the depressing influence showed itself in a slight lowering of prices generally. Bell Telephone fell 1, to 202, though Erie Telephone held its advance of yesterday and gained 1/4 more, to 53 1/4, on supporting orders.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Advices from Port Louis, Mauritius, announce that a blockade of the ports of Madagascar has been proclaimed. The French Resident has gone to Tamatav. He has received instructions to protect the French inhabitants in the event of hostilities occurring.

RHINECLIFF, Oct. 3 -- The three gentlemen who were nominated for office by Mr. Platt's State Convention were notified of their nominations to-day, all three having gathered at Mr. Morton's country seat, Ellerslie, which is near this place, to meet the Notification Committee.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- Ohio liquor dealers are concerned over the course of State Dairy and Food Commissioner F.B. McNeal, who has begun a vigorous crusade against all liquor adulterations. About thirty retail dealers in Sandusky, Cleveland, and Dayton have already been caught selling wines and whisky that had been badly adulterated and have been compelled to pay fines.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 3 -- A story was printed here yesterday to the effect that Capt. Howgate, the Government embezzler, spent much of his time as a fugitive in Nebraska, at the home of a prominent Beatrice attorney, who also acted as his agent in investing part of his stolen money. The attorney involved denies the story.

The perpetration of election frauds will be a risky business this Fall. The deterrent influence of the convictions secured last Winter will restrain some who pursue that calling, and others will be made cautious by the preparations now making for the detection and punishment of violations of the election laws.

Low stocks in the mills in the city and vicinity, and depression in prices, led to the purchase yesterday at the Produce Exchange of 1,396,000 bushels of spot wheat. It was virtually a cash transaction, for the money will be due on the delivery of the grain.

The proceedings of the Lexow committee were interrupted yesterday morning by a loud and excitedly-expressed threat of murder, uttered by a policeman in full uniform against an employe of the committee.

Upon the request of a large number of holders of the general mortgage 6 per cent, bonds of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad Company, Simon Borg, J. Kennedy Tod, and Albert S. Rea have agreed to act as a committee to protect the interests of the bondholders. The company made a default in the payment of interest on these bonds, due Jan. 1, 1893, and on subsequent coupons.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Drs. Vandeveer and Hun of Albany to-day were in consultation with Dr. D.C. Moriarata, the attending physician, and decided that it would be advisable to remove State Controller James A. Roberts to his home at Buffalo as soon as possible. A special drawing-room car has been secured, and it is hoped to be able to take him to Buffalo on Friday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 3 -- At the Police Board meeting this afternoon President Abernethy offered a resolution instructing Chief Murphy to investigate the charge made by Charles Applegate before the Lexow committee to the effect that Detectives William Dalton and Peter F. Morris were in the pay of the "green-goods" men.

The difficulties of France, under the third Republic, about Madagascar began twelve years ago, when Duclerc was the French Premier. This was in the Fall of 1882. In 1840, by virtue of treaties with the Sakalav chiefs, France possessed well-defined rights of sovereignty and of protectorate on the northwest coast of the island, in the territories contained between the Bay of Antongil and Majunga.
Dora Kaplin, fifteen years old, who lived at 242 Cherry Street, attempted suicide last evening by swallowing carbolic acid, because she had been detected in stealing money.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 3 -- The harness racers drew a large crowd to Pimlico this afternoon, and the very warm weather made the conditions favorable for fast miles. Honors were easy between the two gaits, as Ryland T. trotted a heat in 2:13 1/4 and Robert C. paced in the same time.
PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 3 -- At the Whisky Trust headquarters this afternoon the following circular was given to the public:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- 8 P.M. -- Forecast for Thursday: MAINE, NEW-HAMPSHIRE, and VERMONT, local showers, followed by fair in southern portions, southwest winds, slight changes in temperature. MASSACHUSETTS, generally fair during the day, but possibly local showers in the early morning, southwest winds, cooler in western portions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Secretary Herbert's attention was called to-day to the conversation stated to have taken place in Baltimore yesterday between Mayor Latrobe and Capt, Charles H. Davis of the United States cruiser Montgomery, in which the Mayor is represented as using very sharp language reflecting on Capt. Davis and the Navy Department.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 3 -- There was a large attendance on the second day of the Suffolk County Fair. The trotting was close and exciting. The summaries are as follows:
A reporter for The New-York Times interviewed the delegates to the Druggists Convention during the day on the business outlook in their sections of the country. The responses were as follows:
The Honest Government Club of the Real Estate Exchange met yesterday at the Ex-change and adopted these resolutions:

Many arguments in favor of the Metropolitan Traction Company's application for a franchise to extend its lines along St. Nicholas Avenue to the upper end of Manhattan Island and the district beyond the Harlem River were presented on Tuesday by property owners and others to the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen.
READING, Penn., Oct. 3 -- During a cloudburst this evening, the station at Rickenbach, five miles north of this city, on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, was blown on the tracks.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 3 -- The State election occurred in Georgia to-day, to elect a Governor and State officers, and full Legislature, which will elect a Senator in November. Two years ago the State went Democratic for Governor by 71,000 majority for W.J. Northen over W.L. Peck, the Populist nominee.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Oct. 3 -- Joseph H. Titus, fifty-eight years old, and Mrs. Wallace, his sister-in-law, aged fifty-five, wealthy residents of the shore, were rescued from drowning this afternoon by Henry C. Steffens, also a resident of this place.
The Executive Committee of the Committee of Seventy was busy yesterday afternoon with the full conference committee of the German-American Reform Union. The proceedings were in secret session.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3 -- To-day's matches in the intercollegiate tournament developed little in the way of good tennis. The only exception was possibly the match between Wrenn and Pier of Harvard and Budlong and Jones of Brown, which proved a close fight and resulted finally in favor of the Harvard team. The score was 6 -- 4, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 1.
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction yesterday at 111 Broadway:

The Law School of the University of the City of New-York was formally opened for the present term yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in the temporary quarters on the basement floor of the new ten-story structure that is rising on the site of the famous old university building, in Washington Square.

Oscar Henzel, a waiter, was sent to Blackwell's Island yesterday by Justice Voorhis from the Jefferson Market Police Court for six months for having kidnapped Charles Kroener, three years old, of 150 South Fifth Avenue, on Tuesday afternoon.

Significant moves were made in plenty by the Democratic politicians and their advisers in this city yesterday. Senator Hill spent most of the day at the Hotel Normandie, but in the morning he went to the Murray Hill Hotel and met ex-Secretary of the Navy William C. Whitney.

If Brooklyn needs any assistance from outside sources in her efforts to do away with living pictures and indecent show posters and literature, she is going to receive in from Philadelphia, where, it seems, a successful warfare has been carried on.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The final fight for the Republican Congressional nomination in the Thirty-first District is now being made, and it is a fight to the death. Henry C. Brewster has been the leading candidate, with ex-Consul O.F. Williams a poor second, the others having some time since withdrawn, among them ex-Congressman Charles S. Baker.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- No one knew the Comte de Paris here. No one has even a remote connection with the exile, and it is to the credit of the French people that only kind words have been spoken of him. The young Duke, who signs already in big letters the name of "Phllippe," is expected to "do something."
Edward M. Shepard had his attention called yesterday to the words, "We need, no message wrom Washington," in his speech at the Brooklyn Athenaeum Tuesday night.

Prof. David Swing died in Chicago last evening. He was born in Cincinnati in 1830, but was reared on a farm about thirty miles from the city. His father died when David was two years old. He worked hard in the Spring, Summer, and Fall, and went to school in the Winter only until he was eighteen years old, when he began to fit himself for college.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 3 -- The scene of last night's cyclone here is being viewed by thousands of people to-day.

The speculation in Sugar again dominated the market. In the early trading it sold at 82 3/4, but by noon was up to 86 3/8. After that it was again heavy, and closed at 83 1/8, a net advance of 3/4. The strength in the morning was due to the covering of shorts, who were impressed with the belief that the insiders were once more acquiring stock.
The Executive Committee of the State League of Municipal Clubs held an informal meeting yesterday afternoon at the office of J. Augustus Johnson, Chairman, 58 William Street.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3 -- Yale defeated the Brown University football eleven by the score of 28 to 0 to-day. Walter Camp and other well-known football authorities watched the game, and the public had its first opportunity to pass judgment on the new football rules.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 3 -- This village was gay to-night with fireworks and illuminations, the occasion being the annual parade of the volunteer firemen of Jamaica and neighboring villages. Twenty-six companies, numbering nearly 1,000 men, participated. The last of the companies did not arrive until after 8 o'clock this evening, and it was nearly 9 before the procession began to move.

The National Wholesale Druggists' Association will close its business meetings at Delmonico's to-day. The association will have its banquet in the evening, when Chauncey M. Depew, ex-Secretary of the Treasury Fairchild, and other well-known orators are to speak.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 3 -- The Orange Athletic Club easily defeated the New-Jersey Athletic Club at football this afternoon on the Orange Oval before a few hundred spectators. The Orange team outweighed the visitors considerably, and the New-Jersey team had to take one of the Orange players to complete its eleven. The centre work of the visitors beat that of Orange.

Now that the Supreme Court of Massachusetts has refused to order Camille D'Arville to fulfill her contract with Manager E.E. Rice, that prima donna is making arrangements for a starring tour under the management of Harry Askin and Mr. Shea, Treasurer of the Tremont Theatre, in Boston.

Important action was taken at yesterday's meeting of the Committee of Sixty or Executive Committee of Tammany Hall. Upon Mayor Gilroy's own motion the management of the campaign, the discussion of candidates, and the business of attending to the vast detail of the organization's management were turned over to a committee of eight, which represents in its membership all sections of the city.
ANANTARIVO, Madagascar, Oct. 3 -- A blockade of the ports of the Island of Madagascar has been proclaimed by France.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 3 -- A pretty house of worship will be the new Central Presbyterian Church, which is building here, at Clinton and Belmor Avenues, and the cornerstone of which was laid recently with impressive ceremonies by the Rev. Dr. Hopwood. It is to be a handsome brownstone structure, facing on Clinton Avenue.

Burglars visited the house or David S. Wells, 1,273 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, during Tuesday night, and, after regaling themselves with cold beer and luncheon, carried off silverware, jewelry, and money to the value of $500.

LYONS PLAINS, Conn., Oct. 3 -- A number of New-York society people were here to-day to attend the marriage of Miss Annie Adele Walton Hamilton to Gilvia Burr Kellogg, which took place in Emanuel Church. The Bishop of Connecticut performed the ceremony, assisted by the bride's father, the Rev. Alexander Hamilton, rector of Emanuel Church, and the Rev. Dr. Willlam Tatlock.

A point of interest to naval circles, and, indeed, to all the people of the country, will be the contemplated ascertaining of how many foreign-born sailors who have served on our war ships have profited by the new provisions for their naturalization.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Bergen and Passaic County Democrats met in convention to-day to nominate a candidate for Congress for the Fifth New-Jersey District. Prior to the convention the names of Samuel Taylor and A.D. Campbell, County Clerk and Prosecutor, of Bergen; Freeholder W.W. Green of Englewood, ex-Senator J.W. Bogert, and E.V. Bell were freely mentioned.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 3 -- Wesleyan lined up for its first football game of the season to-day against the Middletown Athletics, and defeated them by a score of 12 to 0. Wesleyan had remarkably fine interference and made long runs. Alexander and Capt. Pomeroy and "Kent" Hubbard did star work. The line up:

HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The tri-county convention, composed of the Counties of Columbia, Ulster, and Greene, held in this city to-day, was the largest gathering of firemen ever seen in this State in an inland city. The procession moved at 12 o'clock, and was composed of fifty-eight companies and forty-eight bands and drum corps. The city was beautifully decorated, and in the line of march were 3,000 uniformed men.

De Wolf Hopper and his company gave an invitation matinee to the members of the theatrical profession, at the Broadway Theatre, yesterday afternoon, appearing in the best role which he has yet created -- "Dr. Syntax." The performance was not a "professional matinee" in the usual sense of that phrase.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 4. -- The BriceThomas people, through John Greenough of New-York, caught the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton faction napping at yesterday's annual meeting of the Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company's stockholders, and, despite the fact that the former represent the minority holders of the Cincinnati extension bonds, they were able to prevent the election of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Directory.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 4. -- A pretty wedding took place at the residence of Mrs. J.L. Roberts, on Mountain Road, South Orange, at noon yesterday. Mrs. Roberts's daughter. Miss Eleanor A., became the wife of the Rev. William McNair of Atlantic Highlands. The father of the groom, the Rev. J.L. McNair of Accord, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

The new cruiser Cincinnati, now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, has no ammunition on board for the use of her big guns. All the ammunition that she has is such as may be used in firing her one and six pound guns.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 4. -- The boom in the wool hatting trade, which began as soon as the Tariff bill was passed, still continues. Both the Monhagen and Wallkill hat shops are very busy, considering the season of the year. The daily shipments from the Wallkill works are about 250 dozen. The trade is principally on jockeys.
James McLean, who died at his home, 138 Lexington Avenue, Wednesday, was one of the best-known men in his day in the dry goods trade.
A resolution calling for a new police system was offered yesterday at the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, by G. Waldo Smith.

E.C. McKay brought suit yesterday for $45,000 against Vermilye Co., the bankers, before Judge Ingraham, in the Supreme Court. He alleges that in 1869 he deposited Government bonds with the firm as collateral in certain transactions, and that this amount remained to his credit when he finished his business. He demanded the bonds last year.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 4. -- John C.H. Ruggles, son of William W. Ruggles, Chief Engineer of the Street and Water Department, and Miss May Praet went to NewYork Sunday and were married at the Central Methodist Church, Seventh Avenue, by the Rev. Gilbert H. Gregory.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Druggist Angelo Von Dessau of 379 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, was fined $30 by Judge Tighe yesterday for sprinkling three siphons of mineral water on Ray Kofsky, niece of Michael Levison. The druggist told the magistrate that there was a large crowd in front of his store, and he only used the siphons to disperse it.

The Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee met at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, and was in secret session for several hours. During that time the committee, as so many State organizations have done, refused to go on record opposing the A.P.A.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- A Carnegie Harveyized nickel-steel plate, four inches thick, representing the barbettes of the cruisers Brooklyn and Iowa, was tested at the naval proving grounds at Indian Head to-day. Three four-inch Carpenter shells were fired at the plate.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct 4. -- The Republicans of Westchester County held their County Convention here to-day to nominate candidates for Surrogate, Sheriff, Coroner, and Justice of Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Republican prophecy that the new tariff would increase the price of sugar is effectually disproved in a pamphlet issued this evening by the Democratic Congressional Committee.

The Chamber of Commerce has adopted a resolution approving of the construction of a rapid-transit railway for the city at the public expense, "under the conditions and limitations prescribed by the act providing for the same," and inviting all citizens having the best interests of the city at heart to unite in an effort to secure a favorable vote of the people upon the question.

Members of the Racquet Club, the Academy of Medicine, and the Century Club, and the residents of West Forty-third Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues were amazed yesterday when they learned that in all likelihood a fire-engine house would soon be put up on the lot at No. 33.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 4. -- Frank Dupre, a Rochester commercial traveler, was sandbagged and robbed of over $1,200 on Spadina Avenue last night. Dupre is in a critical condition and may die from his injuries. He was found lying unconscious on the pavement, just in front of Broadway Place, on the west side of the avenue.
The following additional interviews with delegates to the Druggists' Convention were obtained yesterday by reporters for The New-York Times on the business situation of the country:

The trading in Sugar yesterday fell off to 46,579 shares, against 141,000 on Wednesday and 306,000 on Tuesday. These figures would indicate that the movement has about run its course, but Sugar is under such close manipulation that it is unsafe to apply the usual rules to it in making deductions.
The State Commission in Lunacy resumed its inquiry into alleged abuses in the city asylums for the insane at the Park Avenue Hotel yesterday.

The Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railway -- the Messrs. Anderson, Doane, Lee, and Paddock-have agreed upon a plan which they think will solve the double problem of satisfactorily adjusting the indebtedness of that company to the United States and of reorganizing the now insolvent corporation upon a stable basis.
The New-York woman suffragists have learned the cause of their recent defeat. Mrs. Ella Dietz Clymer told them last evening.

For Mayor -- William L. Strong. For Recorder -- John W. Goff. If there is to be a union anti-Tammany ticket to elect which the city Republicans will zealously strive, this appeared last night at Assembly Hall, in East Twentysecond Street, to be the way some of the officers to be voted on will be apportioned.
Senator David B. Hill, the Democratic candidate for Governor, had breakfast at an early hour yesterday morning, and then applied himself to his correspondence for an hour or so.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The council of Ministers for which a call was issued two days ago met in Downing Street at noon. When the meeting opened, Sir William Harcourt, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the Right Hon. Henry Campbell -- Bannerrnan, Secretary of State for War, had not arrived. The Right Hon. Henry Fowler, Secretary of State for India, was also absent. The council closed at 1:40 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Capt. H.W. Howgate, the defaulting disbursing officer of the Weather Bureau, who was arrested in New-York last week, arrived in Washington this afternoon at 4:30 o'clock. He was in the custody of ex-Chief Drummond of the United States Secret Service and Deputy Bostwick of the United States Marshal's Office, at New-York.

Surrogate Abbott, in the Kings County Surrogate's Court, yesterday heard argument in the proceedings for the appointment of a guardian of the person and estate of Constance Winsor, eight years old, daughter of William T. Winsor, who committed suicide recently in the Astor House.

BALTIMORE. Md., Oct. 4. -- No deeper nor more intense feeling or rivalry ever characterized, a game of baseball in Baltimore than was felt and displayed in to-day's contest. Trouble was averted at different stages of the game by the few coolerheaded players and a riot at the conclusion of the game was prevented only by the large police force which escorted Umpire Emslie off the field.

A significant statement was made by James J. Martin, who is Chairman of the Executive Committee, or Committee of Sixty, of Tammany Hall, and who is a member of Tammany's Campaign Committee of Eight, when the Congressional Convention of the Thirteenth Congressional District was in session last night.

Walter E. Parfitt, a taxpayer, has begun a suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to set aside, under the Tilden act, a contract for supplying the town of New-Utrecht with gas. The defendants are Supervisor Cornelius Furgueson, D.B. Wardell, William Keegan, and J. Lott Nostrand, formerly the Board of Improvement of the town, and the Kings County Gas and Illuminating Company.
The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst addressed a meeting in the Adams Memorial Church, in East Thirtieth Street, last evening. His remarks were addressed particularly to the many women present.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 4. -- Rain again materially interfered with the game here to-day between Lord Hawke's cricket team and the Gentlemen of Canada. There was no play until the afternoon, and then the wicket was so soft that the home team was disposed of for the poor total of 55. It made a, much better showing in the second innings, and when stumps were drawn for the day.

In a recent speech on foreign affairs, Count Kalnoky said that while the armed peace of to-day is not ideal, the Governments themselves are not wholly responsible for the continuation of armaments. He declared that the nerves of the newspaper-reading public are played upon by the press, which magnifies unimportant incidents, and he thinks that it is desirable that the peace congresses should turn their attention to this circumstance.
The National Wholesale Druggists Association had its annual banquet last night it Delmonico's. It was a banquet that will always be memorable in the annals of Delnonico's.

The incident that attracted most attention in the morning proceedings of the Lexow committee yesterday in Part III, of the old Criminal Court Building was a verbal passage at arms between John W. Goff, the chief counsel for the committee, and Commodore Eldridge T. Gerry, the President of the New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 4. -- The smart set turned out in full force at high noon to-day at the marriage of Miss Charlotte Bronson Winthrop Hunnewell of Boston to Victor Sorchan of New-York.
The jury in the case of William P. Wentworth returned a verdict of guilty of forgery in the third degree, with a recommendation to mercy, last night in the Court of General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- With trade reviving throughout the country and manufacturers laying plans for future profitable undertakings, it would seem that the information contained in the October number of Consular Reports, issued under the direction of the State Department, is especially timely. This information is furnished by American Consuls in foreign ports, and calls attention to opportunities for American enterprise.
The present trouble between France and the Malagasy Government may fairly be described as only a particularly acute outbreak of a chronic source of disturbance.

Copyrighted, 1894, by The New-York Times. BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 4. -- It is only natural that Bridgeport, which has to an extent broken away from the old-fashioned system of government prevailing in the other parts of Connecticut, should stand heartily for changes in the State Constitution, which will do away with the antiquated methods of carrying on the State Government.

Justice Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday heard argument upon the application made in the interest of George J., Howard, Edwin, and Helen M. Gould, in their individual capacity and also as executors of the estate of their father, Jay Gould, for the cancellation of the assessments and taxes that have been made upon their personal property in this county by the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments.
Frank Armitage Wilcox, a lawyer, twenty-five years old, of 933 Madison Avenue, was found by Policeman Ryer lying dead on the bank of the reservoir in Central Park early yesterday morning.

At the meeting of the Board of Electric Control, in the Mayor's office, yesterday, there were presented seven strands of skeleton wire of various thicknesses as an evidence of the means employed by persons to keep their telegraph wires out of the conduits.

Oscar Hammerstein yesterday carried out his threat to proceed against his partners in the firm of Koster, Bial Co., and, with Lawyer Steinhardt of Howe Hummel, he went to Albany to present his case before the Attorney General on an application for permission to apply for a receiver.

BERLIN, Oct. 4. -- The Kreuz-Zeitung, which usually obtains accurate news of the Russian Court, learns that the Czar is in a far worse state of health than has been officially admitted, and that his death may be expected within a few weeks. The Czarina, according to this information, has been made fully aware of her husband's condition.

The reform professions of the County Committee Republicans were put to the test last night, and they collapsed in an instant. The State Democracy had proposed Mr. Goff for Mayor, the GermanAmerican Union had proposed Mr. Goff, and in an admirable speech Mr. Reaman put forward Mr. Goff as the candidate of the Committee of Seventy.
Some of the wheels in the Platt machine went around again at the Republican State Headquarters yesterday, and when they had ceased, another anti-Plate man's official head was in the basket.

The tugboat W.J. McCaldin, owned by McCaldln Brothers, Sullivan and Ferris Streets, Brooklyn, was, by the carelessness of her fireman, sunk at her dock, in the Atlantic Dock Basin, at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. There was no one aboard at the time.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 4. -- Special reports to The Manufacturers' Record from all parts of the South show that the general improvement in business previously noted continues, and that the situation, as a whole, is almost universally reported as very promising. There is a decided increase in industrial matters, and in railroad interests quite a number of important commissions are forming which are calculated to have a material influence upon the development of the South.

There was considerable excitement in the Chief Clerk's office at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon, because of the disappearance of an official report made by Superintendent Byrnes to the Board of Police.

The Committee of Seventy met yesterday afternoon in the Chamber of Commerce as a Committee of the Whole. It went into secret session at 3 o'clock, and it was past 6 o'clock when the meeting was adjourned to the United Charities Building.

E. Ellery Anderson, J.W. Doane, Fitzhugh Lee, and Joseph W. Paddock, Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad, have submitted their annual report to the Secretary of the Interior. They declare that they have given the subject of the adjustment of the debt of the Union Pacific Company to the United States special and careful consideration, since the appointment of the receivers.

Special and regular sanctions granted by the Racing Board this week show no diminution in the number of speed trials and country race meets. The list of special sanctions is an interesting one. A.A. Hanson has been granted permission to try for records up to 100 miles, between now and Oct. 15. W. Scott of Lafayette, Ind., has asked for permission to attack the 100mile track record on Oct. 7, and it has been granted.

ATLANTA, Ga. Oct. 4. -- Returns from all of the thirteen counties in Georgia, made from unofficial estimates, compiled by correspondents in every county, and most of them received after midnight last night, indicate that the Slate has gone Democratic by 30,000 majority, but the official county consolidations which took place at 12 o'clock to-day reduce this figure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Now that the campaign in the Congressional districts is fairly on the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Committee are visited daily by members of the party who are anxious to know the exact situation in the different States. Every prominent Democrat with experience on the stump who could be secured has been impressed into service, and in every State the Democratic position is now being thoroughly developed.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 4. -- An examination as to the lunacy of E.M. Byers, a wealthy iron manufacturer, was held to-day. The verdict was that he had been insane since the 1st day of August, 1894, the day he was taken to the Kirkbride Asylum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- The Columbus relies loaned to this Government for display at the Chicago Fair by the Pope, the King of Spain, and the Duke of Talleyrand, commenced their homeward journey this morning, when they were taken from the basement of the State Department and placed on board the Norfolk steamer under the supervision of Horace L. Washington, who represents the Government, and a strong guard of naval marines.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst has not changed his attitude against woman suffrage, nor has he changed his opinion that women can do a vast amount of good toward municipal reform. How they shall do it he leaves to the women.

LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The Star to-day prints a dispatch received by a London news agency to the effect that the married foreign customs officials resident in Pekin are hastily leaving the city with their families.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 4. -- The Directors of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company concluded their deliberations late this afternoon and adjourned sine die. The utmost secrecy has been observed regarding the work done by the Directors, and outside of the fact that the rebate system has been abolished, little can be learned of what the Directors have done during the past few days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Controller Eckels to-day called for the condition of national banks at the close of business on Tuesday, Oct. 2.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 4. -- The failure of this city to take title to certain lands set aside in 1871 by a commission appointed through an act of the State Legislature to select sites for two public parks and a parade ground is likely to cost the city $100,000.

At every stage of the police investigation and at every new revelation of evil practices and is failure to repress them, the conviction is confirmed that the whole monstrous brood of abuses had its origin in the destruction of responsibility at the head of the department by the bipartisan constitution of the commission.

There was a trifle more of life at Jerome Park yesterday than there has been at any previous day of the meeting. The finish in the American Jockey Club Handicap between Banquet and Sir Excess, in which the latter just missed taking the "famous Woodlawn Vase" from M.F. Dwyer, served to enliven matters a bit and make the day's sport bearable.

ALBANY, Oct. 4. -- The Republicans of Albany comprising the Twentieth Congressional District nominated to-day a high protectionist. George N. Southwick, for Congress. Mr. Southwick is an editorial writer on The Evening Journal, State Committeeman Barnes's paper, and is but thirty years old.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Alley L was well supported. Buying orders were numerous. Much of the trading is speculative, but the amount of stock going into strong boxes is heavy. Shorts found it difficult to cover. The stock sold at 12 early in the day, but advanced to 14 during the last session.

An attempt was made early yesterday morning to burn the four-story brick building at 377 Sixth Avenue. Fires were started in two separate portions of the building, and had they not been discovered in time, several lives might have been lost. As it was, considerable damage was done.
Affairs of Government and of commerce that had developed through the Summer awaited the attention of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, when that body met for the first time since June.
Messrs. J.W. A.A. Teets have sold the three-story brownstone dwelling 346 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, 15 by 100, at about $16,000, to Edward S. Simon.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 4. -- The arrangements for a century run from Asbury Park to Newark, under the management of the Asbury Park Wheelmen, have been completed, and the promoters expect to have over 100 entries for the long journey. The run will take place on Thursday. Oct. 18, and each survivor will receive a silver medal.

A circular was issued yesterday by the Atchison Protective Committee in which an earnest plea for proxies is made. The committee is working for the election of an entirely new Board of Directors, and says: "A condition of affairs which has caused a depreciation of the value of the stock from $120 to $3 per share within a few years, inflicting serious loss upon thousands of innocent investors, certainly demands a rigid investigation.
This is the ticket which was formally and finally put forward yesterday by the Committee of Seventy for the indorsement of the Republican and other anti-Tammany organizations of New-York.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- The Republican Party in Dutchess County is in an unhappy condition. At the County Convention, yesterday, ex-Congressman John H. Ketcham, who has been called a back number by the Vail wing, succeeded in controlling two of the nominations -- Theodore Hoffman of Red Hook for County Clerk and Major Willam Hanbennestel of Poughkeepsie for County Treasurer.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 5. -- Capt. Hinkey and Manager Cable of the Yale football eleven left here to-night to attend a meeting of the Intercollegiate Football Association in New-York City to-morrow. This is the meeting at which the applications for admission are to be considered, and it is expected that Lehigh and Cornell, and possibly the University of Michigan and the University of Chicago, will apply.
"I am not in any way related to Mr. T. C. Platt."

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The Morning Post insists that it is impossible to allow Japan to dictate terms with China without consulting the European powers. The Post discusses America's interests in the question, and concludes that these are purely commercial, while Europe's are also political. For the sake of the world's peace, it says, Russia, Germany, France, and Great Britain must interfere.

The feature of yesterday's stock market was its general strength. While the industrials were fairly active, the trading in them did not overshadow the rest of the market, and they moved within unusually narrow limits. Both Sugar and Gas closed unchanged, while Whisky advanced 1/8. The other industrials were very quiet.

The cycling events scheduled for to-day in the metropolitan district are three in number, and each promises good sport. The meet of the Middlesex Athletic Club of Spotswood, N.J., at the half-mile trotting track near New-Brunswick, will be the largest affair in point of competition, 142 entries having been made in the seven events which form the programme.

There was something more of sport in the racing at the Morris Park track yesterday than in any that New-Yorkers have had a chance to see in some time. The change from Jerome Park and its circuses was most grateful. It would have been even more grateful had the Morrises had music at the track, as they have had in years past, and as the Coney Island Jockey Club always has.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 5. -- The furniture store of Kennan Johns, at 215 Woodward Avenue, was destroyed by fire this morning. The front wall fell into the street, killing five firemen and a spectator, and injuring ten persons, most of whom were firemen.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 5. -- The price of whisky was lowered 10 cents to-day, as foreshadowed in these dispatches, as a result of the abolishment of the rebate tax. The quotation is now made on a basis of $1.23.
The Republican City and County Convention last night, by acclamation, nominated Col. William L. Strong for Mayor of New-York and John W. Goff for Recorder, to succeed Recorder Smyth.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6. -- A part of the freight on the steamship Rio de Janeiro, which has just sailed for Yokohama and Hongkong, was 200 tons of pig lead, consigned to Japan. It is supposed that this lead is to be used in manufacturing cartridges. It is the largest shipment of lead ever made to the East from this port.

-- An imposing, exhaustive, and authoritative work is "The United States of America," edited by Prof. N.S. Shaler and issued by the Messrs. Appleton. There are two octavo volumes of more than 600 pages each, fully illustrated and written by men who are authorities in their respective fields.

The delegates to the Milholland County Convention, which met last Monday night at Scottish Rite Hall and adjourned after appointing a conference committee to confer with other anti-Tammany organizations, held another meeting last evening at Nilsson Hall, 125 East Fifteenth Street, to act upon the report of that committee.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- The Republican Congressional Convention for the Thirty-first District was held in this city to-day. Henry C. Brewster was nominated, receiving 168 votes out of the 195 of the district. The only other candidate who received any votes was ex-Congressman Charles S. Baker, who received 27.

A story was started in Wall Street yesterday that the Chicago and Northern Pacific bondholders' committee had decided to bring suit against certain persons, unnamed, to recover upward of $6,000,000, alleged to have been wrongfully diverted from that company's assets. J. Edward Simmons, Chairman of the committee, promptly remarked that he knew nothing of any such proceeding.

Whether the late cyclone that visited the coast of the Southern States and then, luckily for New-York and the seaboard cities of the Middle and Eastern States, put out to sea has as yet entirely spent its force is a question that the incoming mariners differ about.

Col. Strong is the regular Republican candidate for Mayor and nothing more. His status, as a straight party candidate is not changed in the slightest degree by the Seventy's acceptance of his name. That hapless body was forced by the County Committee Republicans to abandon the candidate it had first announced as its own and take up Col. Strong.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 5. -- There is another postponement in the J. Coleman Drayton divorce proceedings, the first announcement of which was made exclusively by The New-York Times. The answer by Mrs. Drayton to her husband's petition for divorce has not been filed, nor will it befiled to-morrow, which day, until this afternoon, was supposed to be the last day for the filing of the same.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Rew, a freshman, from Buffalo, mysteriously disappeared from this place last Tuesday. That day he had a lunch prepared at his boarding house, and started out about 1 o'clock for a walk, saying that he might not return in time for supper. When he did not appear at his boarding house the next day it was thought that he might have left for home, on account of homesickness.

The latest interpretations of the hurried Cabinet meeting the other day in London are not exactly creditable to the British Government. In fact, they go to make out an immemorial Continental contention that Albion, if not altogether "perfide," is extremely greedy -- a contention that the best friend of Albion cannot reasonably controvert.

Dun's Review will say to-day: "The lowest prices ever known for wheat and cotton necessarily imply somewhat restricted consumption of other products. With the chief money crops of the West and South sinking in value, it is not strange that purchases of manufactured products are smaller than was expected.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 5. -- The seagull Dick, christened more than a score of years ago, whose return last Wednesday to the Brenton's Reef Lightship was briefly mentioned in The New-York Times, is doubtless here to spend the Winter, as is his custom. The hardy sailorman in charge of the lightship hardly expected the bird, for when he left the boat last Spring he was thought to be pretty well used up.
The friends of Frank A. Wilcox, who committed suicide in Central Park on Thursday morning by shooting himself in the head, deny that he killed himself because of a woman.

There are those to whom time ambles withal, and they must find rare enjoyment in a Norris novel. Here is one as placid as the water of a mill pond, and as clear, and almost as deep, too, for there's quiet satire underlying this long, finely-spun, almost motionless tale of the quiet, unimpassioned tribulations of a girl who had too much money.

Judge Gaynor's silly letter comes some days too late for decency. If the reasons that led him to refuse the use of his name as a candidate for Governor preclude him from accepting a nomination to the Court of Appeals bench they must have been in full force and operating on his consciousness the morning after the nomination.

Col. William L. Strong, the candidate for Mayor, was born in Mansfield, Ohio, in 1827, and was educated in the common schools there. He came East in 1853 and obtained employment with the firm of L. O. Wilson Co. in this city. He remained with them until 1858 and then took a clerk's position with Farnham, Dale Co., dry goods merchants.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5. -- Malcolm Chace of Yale and C.R. Budlong of Brown were the winners in the semi-finals of the intercollegiate tournament this afternoon. Chace was drawn to meet Talmage of Yale and Budlong to meet Herrick of Princeton. In both contests the results were foregone conclusions, and so one-sided that they lacked interest.
Dr. Vincenzo Botta died yesterday of injuries sustained from falling from a window of the third story of his house, 25 West Thirty-seventh Street, during an attack of vertigo, last Tuesday morning.

The explanations made before the Lexow committee the other day by Mr. Goff and Col. Fellows are interesting, and, so far as they go, are creditable to both parties. They amount to this, that the District Attorney has agreed not to interrupt or embarrass the work of the committee by finding any indictments against the witnesses before it upon their testimony or upon testimony given about them.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 5. -- Mrs. Henry W. Bishop of Chicago gave a dance tonight for Miss Mary Pomeroy Cutting, whose marriage to Arthur Cumnock will take place to-morrow at St. Stephen's Church. The dance was a very large one, and all the society people who came from New-York and Boston to attend the wedding were present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Representative John T. Dunn of the Eighth New-Jersey District was at the Democratic Headquarters to-day in quest of campaign documents. Mr. Dunn is about to take the stump, and desires to have a full supply of the excellent material which the committee has caused to be prepared in anticipation of the demands of campaign orators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The report of the Commissioner of the General Land Office to the Secretary of the Interior was made public to-day. Speaking of the great forest fires in Michigan, Minnesota, and Wisconsin, the Commissioner says a great portion of the lands devastated were held by settlers who were in process of perfecting title, but who had not resided long enough thereon to permit them to acquire complete title thereto.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The news received here from Louisiana leads the Democratic managers of the campaign to believe that the "bolt" of the sugar producers, and their support of the Republican candidates for Congress, will prove futile to defeat the regular Democratic candidates. The motive of the bolters is purely a selfish one.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 5. -- Notwithstanding the Temple Cup baseball some in progress at Union Park, the third day of the Fall Trotting Meeting at Pimlico was fairly-well attended, and the sport seemed the best of the season. The day was one of complete surprises, and it will take the talent quite a time to recover from the setback given the favorites.

The State of New-York may soon embark in the concert, living picture, wine and cigar business at Koster Bial's Music Hall, in West Thirty-fourth Street, if Oscar Hammerstein's application for a receiver for Koster, Bial Co. is granted.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 5. -- Hundreds of Baltimore enthusiasts who had arranged to go to New-York to-night to see the Orioles and Giants play ball to-morrow have canceled their engagements. Many of them discarded their orange and black neckties, and other Oriole decorations, and donned plain black as better representing their state of mind.

The tennis tournament in Central Park was continued yesterday afternoon on the lower tennis courts. Of the aspirants for championship honors only two are left, Paret and Cragin. These players will contest to-day in the final round, the winner becoming the challenger for the championship, now held by Edwin P. Fischer of the West Side Club. The doubles tournament was also continued.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 5. -- When the story in last Monday's New-York Times about the Louisiana Lottery being operated in Florida was shown to Senator George F. Hoar to-day, he said there was no doubt in his mind that the next Congress would take up the question, and the lottery business would be stopped in the United States.

The conference of which the Committee of Seventy was the product set out with a declaration that municipal government should be divorced from party politics, and with an appeal to citizens to rise above party affiliations in dealing with city affairs and support candidates for municipal offices without regard to their politics.

Copyrighted, 1894, by The New-York Times. NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 5. -- "The people of Connecticut demand a change from the present inequalities and injustice of the oldfashioned Constitution," said ex-Congressman Levi Warner to a reporter for The New-York Times.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The Hamburg-American steamer Normannia, which arrived at Southampton to-day, reports having experienced a violent hurricane and tremendous seas on Oct. 1 and 2. The boatswain's legs were broken and seven of the crew were injured. The hatches were battened, and the passengers were compelled to stay below for three days.

With an excursion on one of the fastest steamboats in American waters, to the strains of one of the finest military bands in existence, and cheered by a ten-course luncheon, served on board by Delmonico in his best style, the delegates to the convention of the National Wholesale Druggists' Association wound up their week of business and pleasure in this city yesterday.

The delegates of the State Democracy to the anti-Tammany Convention held a secret conference yesterday afternoon at Cooper Union, before going to the convention. Ex-Mayor Grace presided, and there was a full attendance of the delegates.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 5. -- Gov. McKinley reached Council Bluffs, from Omaha, this morning. He found several friends, who had been attending the reunion of the Army of the Tennessee, awaiting him. Among them were Gen. O.O. Howard, Col. Fred Grant, Tecumseh Sherman, Major Hoyt Sherman, and Gen. G.M. Dodge.

Several notable sales of city realty were reported yesterday. Among these is that of the four-story brownstone dwelling 589 Fifth Avenue, east side, adjoining Mr. Hobert Goelet's mansion, at the corner of Forty-eighth Street. The property sold is 20 by 125 feet, and was owned by Mr. Camille Weidenfeld, the banker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Judge Advocate General Lemly of the navy will go to NewOrleans to-morrow to purchase the necessary land for the establishment of the Gulf Navy Yard at Algiers, La. In 1848 Secretary John Y. Mason purchased about twenty-five acres at Algiers for use as a naval station.
David Alexander Williams, who was well and favorably known by the many patrons of Tiffany Co., died on Wednesday evening, after a brief illness.

The closing event of the baseball season, though it does not strictly belong to the season, is of more interest as a study of pure baseball than the season itself. There cannot be much question that, on the showing of the last three months of the season, the New-York club plays much better ball than any other club belonging to the League.
Coffin Stanton, a firm of bankers and brokers at 72 Broadway, passed into the hands of a receiver yesterday, with liabilities at $3,600,000 and assets undetermined.

Police Justice McMahon, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, after hearing charges preferred against Mrs. Ellen Henry by her husband, through the Gerry society, said to James L. Henry, the woman's husband, who is a member of the Steamboat Police Squad:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 5. -- This morning, in Common Pleas Court No. 1. statements were filed in suits brought by Waring Brothers, against the Pennsylvania Railroad, for amounts aggregating $2,300,000. The suits were brought in 1879 and 1880, and have not been pushed since that time. The first suit is for $800,000.

Some of the Republican politicians and Republican newspapers have been endeavoring to make capital out of a claim that the National Administration would be hostile to the Democratic State ticket. Democrats, as a rule, have taken little stock in this report.
Leading members of the Republican Party in Kings County are anxious to form a combination with the Shepard organization regarding the nominations for city and county officers.

Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn has investigated the charges made by Charles M. Patterson against Detective Sergeant George V. Zundt before the Lexow committee regarding the recovery of a diamond stud in a New-York pawnshop, which resulted in the reduction of Detective Sergeants McManus and Lang.

BERLIN, Oct. 5. -- The Lokalanzeiger publishes a dispatch from St. Petersburg which says that the Czar suffered a renewed attack of apoplexy last evening. The Russian Embassy in Berlin has heard nothing to confirm this statement.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. William Cole sold to John Kipp, at $4,500, the threestory brick building 18 Bergen Street, southwest side, 175.1 feet northwest of Boerum Place, if extended, 19,11 by 100.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- A letter received to-day at the Democratic Congressional Committee headquarters from Representative Heard of Missouri contains the information that the Democrats are getting in better shape every day in Missouri, and that the chances are that ten, and perhaps eleven, Democratic Representatives outside of St. Louis will be elected.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- A reply to the criticisms on the apportionment adopted by the Constitutional Convention, as contained in the Democratic minority address, has been prepared by Elon R. Brown of this city, who was the author of the apportionment measure as introduced in the convention and only slightly amended.

The return of a considerable part of the naval vessels included in the Bering Sea patrol fleet has been a sufficient token that the Summer's police work is substantially ended. The revenue cutters and also the Mohican, the Ranger, and the Albatross remained after the others had departed for Mare Island or the Asiatic station, but it seems likely that most or all of these are by this time homeward bound.

This afternoon the race of the year, that which will decide the championship of the aged division among thoroughbreds, will be run at Morris Park. Preparations have been made by the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company to handle an enormous crowd of people, and something like 20,000 persons are expected to go and see Domino, Henry of Navarre, and Clifford try conclusions at even weights, over the mile and an eighth course.

The secretary of Judge William J. Gaynor handed out last night for publication typewritten copies of a letter addressed to J.W. Hinckley, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, declining the Democratic nomination for Judge of the Court of Appeals. The secretary said Judge Gaynor would not consent to be interviewed concerning the letter.

Lieut, Gov. Sheehan, it is said, was in Brooklyn Thursday afternoon, and he was the bearer of a message from Senator Hill to Mr. McLaughlin. This is the story The Brooklyn Citizen published yesterday. It also said that Mr. Sheehan and Mr. McLaughlin were in consultation for a long time, and that Mr. Sheehan then drove back to the Hotel Normandie, in New-York, where Senator Hill awaited his return.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The Military information Division, Adjutant General's Office, of the War Department, has issued an illustrated publication on the organization, armaments, and military progress of foreign nations, which is fully up to the standard of excellence shown in the earlier publications of that office concerning Hawaii, the German Army, and the militia of the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The Globe, in an article referring to yesterday's Ministerial council, ridicules the idea that it was summoned merely for the purpose of sending war ships to protect the lives and property of British residents in China, and expresses the opinion that The Manchester Guardian's article of to-day gives the real reason for the meeting of the Ministers.

It contains a fine portrait of a lady by Rembrandt, dated 1639; two excellent portraits by Paulus Moreels, two by Wybrand de Geest, three by Cornelis Janssens, one of Admiral de Ruyter, by K. du Jardin, and others by these and other artists which have elicited much surprised admiration.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 6. -- Hundreds of financiers who belong to the American Bankers' Association are coming to Baltimore next week to hold their twentieth annual convention. The National Bank Examiners will also gather here at the same time to discuss some of the technicalities of their occupation.
Election day in this State falls this year upon Nov. 6. The polls will be open in New-York City from 6 o'clock A.M. to 4 o'clock P.M., and in Brooklyn from sunrise to sunset.

The twenty-five-mile road race over the Elizabeth-Rahway course was run off yesterday afternoon. The promoters of the race were after records and they got them. The world's record for the distance, held by Callahan of Buffalo, of 1:10:37, was lowered by Thomas Hughes of the East Side Wheelmen to 1:09:27.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- One year ago to-day Carroll D. Wright, Commissioner of Labor, assumed charge of the Census Bureau. At that time he expressed to the Secretary the belief that the work of preparing all the copy and getting it into the hands of the printer could be completed within the calendar year of 1894, and at this time he sees no reason to change the opinion he then gave.

Our sources of information regarding the Anglo-Saxon parish priests are not so meagre as is generally assumed by those who have not given their attention to the subject. They may be said to begin with those documents which belong to the days of Archbishop Theodore, who came among us in 668, and who continued to preside over the Church of England till 690.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Copyright, 1894. -- The loss of gold on the part of the Bank of England continues, and the reserve has declined this week to the extent of u2,000,000. The disbursements on account of Government dividends, however, have released a sufficient amount of money to make supplies as plentiful as ever.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- The two hours and a half of trading in wheat dragged through in the most desultory manner to-day. There was scarcely any gossip worthy of consideration, and scalpers were the only people doing anything. They managed either to eke out a few eighths or drop an equal amount, according to views they held or the side they worked on.

Members of the National Guard of the State of New-York will be pleased to learn that Adjt. Gen. Porter has given an order to Messrs. Tiffany Co. to at once proceed with the manufacture of the medal for long service, which is to be presented by the State to members of the guard now serving, who have performed 80 per cent. of duty, for ten, fifteen, twenty, and twenty-five years.

Steenie Calthorp was the young woman of a horse ranch in California. Old Sutro Vives, the Spaniard, had been her riding master and her most devoted servant. What amazing performances on a horse Steenie could accomplish! She could dash off a full speed on Tito, and with a knife in her hand pin a handkerchief on the turf and carry off the kerchief.

The stockholders of the Ohio Southern Railway, at a meeting in this city yesterday, confirmed the lease of the Columbus, Lima and Milwaukee Railway, which extends from L ma, the present northern terminus of the Ohio Southern, in a northerly direction to Defiance. This will connect the Ohio Southern with the Baltimore and Ohio, the Wabash, the Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City, and the New-York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroads.

Yale, 10; Crescent Athletic Club, 0. That was the score the New-Haven men made against their Brooklyn opponents yesterday afternoon at Eastern Park, Brooklyn. The Yale men expected to roll up a larger score, even with a team composed almost entirely of substitutes.

The Brooklyn Young Men's Democratic Club, at a meeting held at 44 Court Street last evening, with Frederick W. Bailey in the chair, after a long discussion, decided, by a vote of 22 to 20, to repudiate the Democratic State ticket. It indorsed the platform, however.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- Excitement enough to make a half year interesting has been concentrated upon this single week just ended. A vivid war scare, a wholesale financial panic, and distinct statements that the Chinese Empire was broken up and that the Russian Emperor was dying -- all worked together to set things rocking and swaying as if they were under an earthquake shock.

Rodolphe Rosinsky, theatrical agent, of 11 Rue Caumartin, Paris, has arrived in NewYork to give advice and assistance to Rudolph Aronson in the work of establishing the Casino as a first-class music hall and vaudeville theatre. Mr. Rosinsky is one of the leading "agents" of Europe, where the agency business is carried on much more extensively than in this country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- visitors to Washington always want to know something when they reach here.
