OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 6. -- The Methodists of this village are an energetic body of workers. They no sooner decided to build a new church than the project was under way. They met with many obstacles, but overcame them all, and are now looking forward to the early dedication of their new home.

Galileo in his "Sidereal Messenger" made a map of eighty new stars which he had discovered in the constellations of Orion's Belt and the "Sword"; and since then astronomer after astronomer, as is well known, has added various groups and galaxies to the 2,000 or 3,000 conspicuous stars of the first six magnitudes which can be always seen with the naked eye.

The appearance of the second volume of Mr. Conway's edition of Paine's writings recalls the pleasure and interest awakened by the appearance of the first, an event now distant from us by many months. The work he has undertaken for Paine was a work which should have been undertaken long ago, but, having waited for Mr. Conway to perform it, the public is fortunate in having it done so well.
Creditors of J.M. White Co., cotton brokers, met yesterday at the firm's office, 49 Beaver Street, to hear the statement of Assignee Johnson. There were about forty persons present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The Department of State has received advices dated Sept. 12 from Consul General James H. Mulligan, who recently arrived at his post at Apia, Samoa, announcing the death of High Chief Mamea of Lefagu, which uccrred after a brief illness Sept. 9, in Apia, where he had resided during the recent troubles.

The sales of real estate at auction in Brooklyn during the past week amounted to $216,333. In the corresponding week last year they were $162,776. During the past week there were recorded 287 mortgages, for $731,633, of which 150, for $322,101, were at more than 5 per cent., and 137, for $409,532, were at 5 per cent, or less. In the corresponding week or 1893 284 mortgages, for $820,248, were recorded.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- When the Federal Supreme Court meets on Monday for its October term, it will be with the encouraging knowledge that the congestion in the docket, which left cases hanging for periods of time inconsistent with justice, no longer exists, and that the court in the near future will catch up with the very last case filed.

Only one more victory is necessary in order to bring about this result.

Thus it happens now that most of the bib liners have cricket and football teams, and the better the boat the better are the men at their favorite sports.

ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- The regular Democrats completed their nominations for Assembly to-day. Conventions were held in three districts, the third having a week ago placed Jacob L. Ten Eyek in the field. In each instance the nominees of a year ago were retired.

ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- The Onteoria Club was incorporated to-day for promoting social intercourse among and for the mutual benefit of cottage owners at Onteoria, in the Catskill Mountains. The incorporators are Francis B. Thurber, D.D. Williamson, Robert F. Wilkinson, Washington E. Connor, Charles H. Russell, Tunis G. Bergen, Walter Romeyn Banjamin, Lewis A. Coffin, Ripley Hitchcock, John E. Borne, Mary Mapes Dodge, Lucia Gilbert Runkle, Adelaide Hazlehurst, Catherine E. Turnbull, and Maria Brace Kimball.

Indications yesterday were that the receivership for Coffin Stanton, bankers and brokers at 72 Broadway, will disclose a much worse condition of the firm's affairs than was at first supposed. Debts of the firm seem to be definitely fixed at $3,600,000. but no one is bold enough to guess at the assets.

BERLIN, Oct. 6. -- Immediately after the adjournment of the Council of the Prussian Ministry on Wednesday Count von Eulenburg, President of the Ministerial Council, proceeded to Rominton, presumably to confer with the Kaiser upon the arrangement of business for the coming session of the Landtag.

Chicago Gas was the only stock in which the trading exceeded 10,000 shares yesterday. It was firm all through the session, and closed within 1/4 of the top at 75 3/8, a net gain of 1 1/2 points. The strength was due to the operations of the pool. It was said that a trader short of 10,000 was being squeezed.

BUTTE, Mon., Oct. 6. -- Reports of ravages by great packs of gray wolves come from Eastern Montana. Stockmen report wolves more numerous and bold than at any time in the history of Montana stock raisins. Hundreds of head of grown stock have been killed, and the number of calves slaughtered is unknown.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Queen Victoria receives frequent reports on the condition of the Czar, and imparts the news freely to the Court. A special courier arrived at Balmoral on Wednesday with autograph letters from the Czar and Czarina. The sum of the authentic news is that the Czar is suffering from granular contracted kidney, with functional disorder of the heart, occasional oppression of breathing, and insomnia.

Hoyt's Theatre, formerly known as the Madison Square, will be opened to-morrow night, with Charles H. Hoyfs "A Milk-White Flag." The interior of the theatre has been completely overhauled. New seats have beer provided, with plenty of space between them to insure comfort, and the house has been newly decorated.

The diminutive British gunboat Partridge, Commander McAllister, arrived here yesterday from Halifax, from which port she sailed on Oct. 2. She mounts six guns, and has a crew of sixty-eight men. She lies at anchor in the North River.

It is none too soon for girls and boys to be making plane for Christmas. Pocket money is scare, as a rule, with young folks, and they need to begin early to put it aside and make it go as far as possible. A good idea is to have a little blank book, and put down in it a list of all the persons to whom you will give presents.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 6. -- The test of the Daudetean rifle, submitted by the Hotchkiss Ordnance Company, was resumed this forenoon before the Rifle Board at the torpedo station.

Veranda Place, in Brooklyn, calls up many interesting meditations. It is a very little place, extending only from Clinton Street through one block to Henry Street -- quite too small and insignificant, apparently, to be worthy of much thought. But to the philosopher of the present day Veranda Place is a mystery deeply interesting.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 6. -- The marriage of Miss Mary Pomeroy Cutting to Arthur James Cumnock of New-York took place this evening in St. Stephen's Church. The bride is the daughter of Col. and Mrs. Walter Cutting, and the groom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. A.G. Cumnock of Lowell, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- There is just enough uncertainty as to the outcome of the political campaign in Kansas to attract the attention of every person who delights in a struggle, the result of which is shrouded in doubt. A letter received to-day from one who is well posted on political matters in the State gives a pretty good idea of the mixed condition of affairs there.

Washington, Oct. 6. -- Hamilton Black has been arrested at Bay City, Mich., for counterfeiting notes of four different national banks with the Garfield head. The notes are dangerous photographic counterfeits. Another new five-dollar United States note has turned up. It is of the series of 1880, bearing the portrait of Jackson.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- The plays at the Odeon may not be called good. It is a pity, for the Odeon is the only theatre taking the trouble to present something new, and certainly anything from the pen of Mme. Judith Gautier promised interest at least.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Miss Mamie Whiting, daughter of William M. Whiting, and Joseph Wooley of New-York, were married at the home of the bride, in Ashland Avenue, East Orange, on Wednesday evening, by the Rev. Dr. Henry M. Storrs of the First Presbyterian Church.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 6. -- Four Connecticut regiments will dedicate monuments on the battlefield at Antietam Oct. 8, with ceremonies befitting the event. Not less than 400 members and friends of the commands will be present and take part in the exercises. Three of the regiments, the Eishth, the Eleventh, and the Sixteenth, were under Gen. Burnside on the left of the Union forces.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- The market for local stocks was generally firm and dull, with no special feature of interest. Erie Telephone sold off 1/4, to 52. New-England Telephone was steady at 67 1/2, and Bell Telephone gained 1/2, to 201. West End Street Railway was steady at 54.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The political situation in Westchester County becomes very interesting as election day approaches. Thus far only two conventions have been held, and there are eight yet to take place before all the nominations will have been made. Those that have been held are the Republican County Convention and the Democratic Second Assembly District Convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Secretary Carlisle to-day made public the official correspondence relating to the conclusion, unofficially announced three weeks ago as having been reached by the officials of the Treasury Department, that the alcohol paragraph of the new tariff law is impracticable of enforcement.

Congressman William L. Wilson, author of the original Wilson bill, and Isidor Straus of this city yesterday arrived home from England, after a tempestuous voyage in the steamer New-York of the American Line.

His keenness of observation and his readiness to embrace opportunities which other men, less alert, would let pass unheeded, have placed Lieut. H.C. Duval fairly upon the road to business success. Although known far and wide as the sagacious private secretary to Chauncey M. Depew, his identification with important business enterprises promises to speedily amplify his reputation.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- The Twenty-second Congressional District Republican Convention is no nearer to a nomination than when it first assembled, on Sept. 14. The three hundred and thirtieth ballot today was a weary repetition of the vast majority of others, and was as follows: Gen. N.M. Curtis of St. Lawrence, 15: Gen. W.B. French of Saratoga, 9, and Judge A.D.L. Baker of Fulton, 6.
LENOX, Mass., Oct. 6. -- Among the recent distinguished arrivals are Prince and Princess Poggio, suasa Ruspoli, who have just come on here from Newport.
There is an American girl whose belief in the German Emperor's kindliness can hardly be shaken, and one memory which she holds of him shows him to be both courteous and self-controlled.

The views upon the European situation of a clever observer are expressed in Mr. Frederick Greenwood's article in the current Contemporary Review on "The New Drift in Foreign Affairs." The article asserts that there is no life left in the Triple Alliance. England, of course, does not acknowledge this.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- First Assistant Secretary of State Edward F. Uhl will leave Washington next week to enter actively into the Michigan campaign, and beginning at Detroit, Oct. 20, he will speak at various points in the State every day until the polls close.

The Iman of Muscat possesses a pearl weighing twelve and a half carats, through which you can see the daylight; it is worth about u33,000. The one owned by Princess Yousoupoff is unique for beauty. It was sold by Georgibus of Calais, in 1620, to Philip IV, of Spain for 80,000 ducats; its present value is about u36,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- Chief Naval Constructor Hichborn made an official inspection yesterday of the new war ships under construction at Philadelphia, and found everything progressing satisfactorily. He says he found the crack cruiser Minneapolis in condition to go into commission next week.
The enduring popularity of "Dixie" is not confined to any one section of the country. It is as well known in New-England and the Northwest as it is in "Dixie's Land."
O.L. Hummell, a bright-looking man of twenty-two years, was sent back to Cleveland, Ohio, yesterday. He is accused there of a number of forgeries.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The Montclair Orchestral Society held its first rehearsal of the season to-night.

Whatever did the late Lord Tennyson mean when he wrote, "Oh, you chorus of indolent reviewers; irresponsible, indolent reviewers"? It may be that critics are irresponsible, but certainly they, cannot be indolent, for by all accounts they are continually engaged in the most pernicious activity.

Upon an unhappy male scribe fell the burden of describing the first wedding in Coolgardie, Western Australia. With a noble desire to rise to the importance of the occasion, but with a limited and technical vocabulary, he plunged in. The bride, he tells us, wore "a creamy, quartz-colored silk, with orange blossom outcrops."
From The New-Yorker Staats-Zeitung, Oct. 6. The anti-Tammany conference has come to naught. The proposition made yesterday by the Committee of Seventy has practically ended the negotiations.

The New-York and Norwalk Steamboat Company's steamer City of Albany caught fire at 6:30 o'clock last night while tied up at Sturgess's dock, on the Harlem River, between One Hundred and Forty-ninth and One Hundred and Fiftieth Streets.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union here has moved into its new building, next to the Baptist Church, in Washington Avenue. Interesting dedicatory exercises were held recently, when Mrs. Emma Bourne, the President of the State Woman's Christian Temperance Union, made an address in which she outlined the work accomplished in the State.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The indications for a big season at Lakewood, which were manifest early in the Autumn, have been well borne out by the six days since the opening. The new register at the Laurel House shows the names of many visitors of past seasons who are booked for several weeks.

With several new and really interesting features, the Hagenbeck trained animals ought to draw crowds even larger than hitherto during the coming week. The menagerie all along has been exceptionally popular. None can visit the Hagenbeck animals in their sleeping quarters without comparing them more than favorably with their fellow captives in the Central Park zoo.

If we were to catch a musical performance, even of a first-rate instrumentalist, by means of a phonograph, and then slowly reproduce and analyze it, we should very likely be astonished to see how incorrectly he played. And yet his performance was good enough for the general impression, and even the most attentive hearer might not have been annoyed by its inaccuracies.

A telegram was received at the Admiralty on Saturday last from the commanding officer of the Dart, dated at Noumea, Sept. 15, reporting that the Ringarooma was afloat, and had arrived at Port Sandwich, in the New-Hebrides, on Sept. 12. She was got off the reef with the assistance of the French cruiser Duchaffault. Contrary to the apprehensions at first entertained, the Ringarooma was found to be only slightly damaged.

Mr. Geo. Meyers, 1,831 Third Avenue, says: "For over a year I suffered from stomach and liver troubles. I could not eat. My suffering was intense, and I grew so weak I had to lie down nearly all day. At least a dozen old-school physicians, treated me; but, instead of deriving benefit, I found that their strong drug's made me worse.

The Cunard Line steamer Etruria, Capt. McKay, arrived last evening after a very stormy passage. She experienced a succession of heavy gales from west to north-northwest and southwest, with violent squalls and high seas, nearly the entire passage.

Richard O. Davis, who was arrested on suspicion of passing a forged check for $1,200 on the National Lafayette Bank of Cincinnati, was before Justice Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on habeas corpus proceedings.

PARIS, Sept. 24. -- The yellow carpet of golden, ruddy leaves grows too fast. After the escapades of a freaky Summer, we seem likely to be able to growl at a twin Fall, and to berate the speedy frosts of an early Winter. Wine growers are in despair. Ten days or one week of hot sunshine would have brought a fortune; but the twenty-four hours so greedily offered were quite insufficient.
The Fall and Winter opening at B. Altman Co.'s store, at Sixth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, will begin to-morrow. The display of imported gowns, cloaks, and bonnets is strikingly beautiful.

Managers Charles H. Hoyt and Frank McKee yesterday afternoon welcomed a few invited guests to an inspection of the auditorium of Hoyt's Theatre, as the old Madison Square is hereafter to be called, which is to open its season to-night with the production of "A Milk-White Flag." Except the four walls, nothing of the old house remains.

The Stewards of the Jockey Club; having investigated the recent running of the horse Halton, particularly as to the race in which he was ridden by Jockey Reiff at Jerome Park when Governor Sheehan beat him, have suspended Reiff for the remainder of the year. He can hereafter ride only for his regular employers, with whom he has a contract, McCafferty Wishard.

The earliest records indicate that one William Hamilton was the first person who killed whales on the New-England coast. He was born in Scotland in 1043, and, com ing to this country in the early part of his life, took up his residence at Cape Cod, where he was persecuted by the inhabitants for killing whales, as one who dealt with evil spirits.

The German-American Reform Union of the Twenty-sixth Assembly District, at a meeting held at Steeg's Hall, 1,997 Third Avenue, Friday evening, nominated F.O. Dettmann for the Assembly. The nomination, which was accepted by the candidate, was received with the greatest enthusiasm. The district organization is one of the strongest of the union, comprising more than 1,000 members.

Since their appointment, a little more than one year ago, the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad have been treading a thorny path. All of their efforts to disentangle the snarl in which they found the company's finances, and their efforts to restore the company's credit and get its business upon a stable basis, have been hampered by a variety of circumstances and obstructed by antagonistic litigation.

The clear, crisp Autumn air of yesterday in duced many a man to take a spin behind his favorite trotter, and the clubhouse at Fleetwood Park harbored a larger gathering of member and road riders than on any Sunday morning since the Grand Circuit meeting of a month ago.

Lawyer Frank Moss, counsel for the Parkhurst Society, and assistant to John W. Goff in the Lexow investigation, is of the opinion that George Appo, formerly a green goods swindler, has been converted to religion, or at least is trying to lead a moral life. Mr. Moss, yesterday afternoon, addressed the Yorkville Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, at Eighty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

From Chicago to this city on a bicycle in 6 days 8 hours and 30 minutes, with but eleven and one-half hours of sleep, is the new record between the two cities, and to George W. Wolfe of Chicago belongs the credit of the great performance. The distance pedaled was about 1,038 miles, nearly 100 of which was toilsome work through a continuous stretch of sand.

Prominent members of the State Democracy said yesterday that, unless something unforeseen transpired within twenty-four hours, their organization would go into County Convention to-morrow night standing on the ground taken by Francis M. Scott at the meeting of the general conference under the auspices of the Committee of Seventy last Friday.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 7 -- A cave, supposed to have been used by burglars, was found a week ago by two men searching for walnuts north of Richmond Hill. It was in a lonely hollow. Leaves carefully concealed a trap-door entrance. The men ran away without examining it.

The industrials were the feature of the stock market last week, the trading in them being about half of all the business done. The downward movement in Sugar culminated, after several days of very heavy trading, on Wednesday, when it sold as low as 82 3/4. Subsequently it was firm, and closed on Saturday at 85 7/8, a loss for the week of 3 1/4 points.

Many of the vessels that came in yesterday reported having encountered the cyclone that put out to sea after making its way up the coast. The steamer P. Caland, from Amsterdam, experienced a severe storm from the northwest on Oct. 1. There were very heavy seas, and one of the lifeboats was broken. There was a strong gale from the northeast last Friday, and some of the sails were lost.

At this season, when the harness racers develop their highest form, they leave the populous centres of the North and East, finding greater profit in what is known as the Western-Southern Circuit. This series has, during the tew years of its existence, furnished more sensations than the betterknown Grand Circuit.

The English Post Office has always been supposed to be the best in the world. Now, however, it appears that, so far as carrying wedding cake safely is concerned, the English Post Office is eminently untrustworthy. Complaints have recently been made that when wedding cake is sent by mail it rarely reaches its destination, and it is generally supposed that it is appropriated and eaten by the Post Office clerks.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- Local securities hold firm. Hudson River Telephone and Albany Railway stocks were the favorites, and there is a good inquiry for both securities. Among local bonds, Troy Gas consolidated 5s and Troy Gas debenture 6s are each 1/4 per cent. lower, sales having been made at 106 and 114, respectively.
Individual communion cups will be used by the members of the Bedford Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 7 -- Presbyterians are preparing to celebrate the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Presbyterianism in this country with a three days' service in Christ's First Presbyterian Church, in Hempstead, L.I., which was the first Presbyterian society organized in America.

At a railway station after an accident. A Man -- I desire to have -- The Clerk -- Have what? I haven't the time. Come back at 4 or at 6. Have what? The Man (intimidated) -- To have some information, if possible, on the accident which has had the honor to occur on your line. My entire family was on the train; so --

The Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Rosary, Chauncey Street, near Reid Avenue, Brooklyn, was dedicated, with the usual impressive service, yesterday, by Bishop McDonnell, who was assisted by the Rev. Father D. Monteverde, rector of the church.

A suit brought by the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, as executors, to have the will of Charles Bathgate Beck declared valid, the probate having been passed upon last week, will soon be tried in the Supreme Court. The estate, which is valued at from $1,500,000 to $5,000,000, consists of tracts of land in the annexed district and Westchester County. It was originally owned by James and Alexander Bathgate and Mrs. Janet Beck.

James Bartel, a stone cutter, lately of 220 East One Hundred and Eighth Street, but now of "the Island," climbed a latticed elevated-railroad pillar on the Bowery, late Saturday night, fell from the top down the interior to the bottom, went to sleep, and, after several hours' slumber, was rescued with a block and tackle.

Four trotting stallions have secured records during the present season of better than 2:10, as follows: Strader H., 2:09 1/4 Raiph Wilkes, 2:09 1/2 Ellard, 2:09 3/4, and Trevilian, 2:09 3/4. Ever since Mambrino Gift set the mark for entire horses at 2:20, twenty years ago, a peculiar interest in the stallion champions has prevailed, and their blood lines have been carefully analyzed.

Progress in the Republican programme of making up the municipal ticket was blocked yesterday because the Committee of Seventy neither held a session nor informally through its members made known what it proposes to do with the State Democracy men who are on the list of candidates submitted at the general conference last Friday afternoon.

Hubert F. Allan, who was arrested at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Saturday morning on the strengrth of advices from Des Moines. Iowa, charging him with the theft of $1,500 from D.B. Lyons, a banker of that city, was held for further examination in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning.

Although the bill for a new site and building for the college was vetoed by Gov. Flower last year after having passed both houses of the Legislature, yet the alumni, who were mainly instrumental in pushing the measure, are not disheartened, and from present prospects will again present the bill at the next session.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 -- Bloody Monday dies hard. The first annual reception to the freshmen, two years ago, was held on the Monday evening, for the avowed purpose of checking the rushes and disturbances which had for so many years disgraced the first week of the college year. The institution had been gradually dying a natural death with the advance of civilization, but this move of the Faculty only increased the disturbances.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7 -- The football season at Princeton has now advanced far enough to render possible an intelligent opinion on the make-up of the eleven. The daily practice is gradually sifting out the chaff from the new crop of players, and, although forty-six men are still at the training table, and a large number of these will be kept through the whole season, many will never make 'Varsity material.

Lewis L. Troy of Chicago is Superintendent of the Sixth Division of the Railway Mail Service, which territory takes in everything from Chicago, Ill., to Ogden, Utah, on the Union Pacific line and its branches. Mr. Troy is one of the oldest men in the service, so far as service goes.

There is every reason why Democrats in this city should unite heartily in support of candidates for Congress and for the State Assembly, and there should be no thought of rival candidates of the party in any of the districts. Such differences as have existed have no relation to the national policy of the party or to the control of the Legislature.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The Daily Graphic will print to-morrow a dispatch from Shanghai saying that Japanese transports have landed a large force at Talien-Wah, on the Chinese coast northeast of Port Arthur.
In the prelude of his sermon last evening the Rev. John A.B. Wilson of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church talked on the work of the Lexow committee. He had this to say:

HYDE PARK, Vt., Oct. 7 -- The Republican editors and spellbinders are telling the people of other States that Vermont's Republican majority this year is the measure of her indignation "against the party which is not willing to give protection to American industries." There is an intimation of patriotism and disinterestedness in this allegation with which the Vermonters are not entitled to be credited.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- The Democratic State Convention will meet in Music Hall promptly at 11 A.M. to-morrow. Ex-Judge John W. Corcoran, Chairman of the State Committee, will call the delegates to order, and will introduce ex-Gov. William E. Russell as permanent Chairman. Mr. Russell will deliver one of his most able addresses in defense of the Democratic Administration and Democratic policy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The order of the War Department which has resulted in a general transfer of United States troops and the abandonment of many posts in different parts of the country has brought, as might have been expected, many protests from persons whose interests have been affected by the withdrawal of the troops.

It was easier to get a drink in New-York yesterday than on Sunday a week ago. More saloons were open and a smaller degree of vigilance was exercised. This was shown by the decreased number of arrests for violation of the excise law, not only in the small hours after midnight of Saturday, but all through the day of rest.

The overshadowing importance of other measures at the last session of Congress obscured somewhat from public attention the enactment of a statute of no little consequence concerning the disposition of arid lands. It gives to each State or Territory that may desire it 1,000,000 acres of such lands within its own limits, in order that it may reclaim them by irrigation.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Oct. 7 -- The auditorium at Prohibition Park was filled this afternoon with 3,500 people, Protestants and Catholics, from New-York, Brooklyn, New-Jersey, and Staten Island. They came to hear the Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn speak on "The A.P.A.; Its Causes and Its Cures, the Relations of Protestants and Catholics in America."

The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst preached to a large congregation in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church yesterday. His sermon dealt with the qualities of Christ as exemplified by His great sacrifice far the world.
The Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton, rector of the Church of the Transfiguration, the "Little Church Around the Corner," celebrated the forty-sixth anniversary of his pastorate of that parish yesterday.

MADRID, Oct. 7 -- The King of Portugal gave offense to his naval officers by his speech to the Cortes on Oct. 1. Many of the officers drafted a protest, which, in the form of a manifesto addressed to the Portuguese people, was widely circulated. The man who printed the manifesto was arrested. None of those who prepared the paper signed his name to it.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Hobart College has begun its seventieth year with the largest freshman class in its history, numbering over thirtyfive. President Potter has returned from his European trip, which lasted four months. He visited many foreign universities. Prof. Rose, the head of the department of modern languages, is still in Germany.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7 -- The official records of Yale University last year show that there were 2.202 students in all the departments. The figures for this year have not yet been made up, but it is assumed from the returns thus far received that about 2,400 will be Yale's family for the coming year. The Medical School will number over 100, which is an increase of about 25 per cent.

BRISTOL, Tenn., Oct. 7. -- Afternoon train No. 5, from New-York, on the Southern Railway, jumped the track about three miles south of Bristol. The engine fell across the track, and the express and mail cars jumped over it, and, falling on their sides, were soon burned up, with the exception of the last car, a Pullman sleeper, which was cut loose and backed from the train. Among the injured are:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The West Indiana hurriance, previously reported in the Gulf, and of which timely warning has been given, is now approaching the Central Gulf coast, the wind having reached a velocity of sixty miles at the mouth of the Mississippi. The indications are that this storm will recurve, and move to the northeastward, causing dangerous gales on the South Atlantic coast Monday night.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 7 -- Passenger train No. 35, of the Atlanta and West Point Road, which left Atlanta at 5:25 o'clock this morning, tumbled from the high trestle over Osanappa Creek, a few miles beyond West Point, and seven persons were badly injured.

When the subject of politics came up before the Central Labor Union yesterday, a circular from the State branch of the American Federation of Labor was read. This stated that none of the organizations which the federation had asked whether it was advisable for labor to go into independent political action had voted in the negative.

The history of Venice has three periods. The first comprises the dawn of the ducal power from the close of the seventh century to the middle of the twelfth; the second, the years from 1172 to 1457, when Venice was at the height of her glory, and the third, the 350 years coming down to the French Revolution, when Venice became only a name.

Col. Strong's nomination evokes only a reluctant and disheartened approval from the sincerely non-partisan friends of good government. In the bosoms of Democrats it arouses a desire to get at him with a candidate of their own. The Seventy have succeeded in pleasing only the Republican machine.

In view of the controversies that have arisen in Northern Pacific Railroad affairs and the embarrassments that have beset the receivers since their appointment something more than a year ago, a representative of this paper called upon Henry C. Payne, one of the receivers, a day or two ago and requested that he make a statement for publication, defining the situation and narrating some of the peculiar difficulties which the receivers have encountered.

Foreign exchange was generally firm. The posted rates for sterling were advanced to $4.87 for sixty-day bils and $4.88 for demand. Actual business was done on Saturday at 84.85 3/4 @ $4.86 for sixty-day bills, $4,86 3/4 @ $4.87 for demand, $4.87 @ $4.87 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.84 3/4 @ $4.85 for commercial.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Oct. 7 -- Andrew Gregg Curtin, War Governor of Pennsylvania, died at his home here at 5 o'clock this morning. He had been near death's door for several days, and had been in feeble health for a long time.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 -- Capt. Emmons is still unable to play football, but is on the field with the aid of his crutches every afternoon. The time for practice each day is still very short, but during that time the men are kept at work constantly. No list of the Varsity can be given, for the men are changed constantly back and forth.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The total number of students at Vassar this year is 477. The freshman class numbers 131, only one more than the class that entered last year. Many applicants withdrew altogether or for the present year, because they could not secure rooms in the college buildings. Several students have passed examinations for admittance to higher classes.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 6 -- The past week in the local stock market has been exceedingly dull, no sales of importance having taken place. Offerings of stocks still continue light, and the wide margin between the bid and asking prices permits of but few opportunities to trade. Paper is more plentiful and rates remain unchanged, being quoted at 4 @ 4 1/2 per cent.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- The Chancellor's conference with the Emperor at Hubertus-stock was finished on Friday evening. The Emperor assented to the Ministerial draft of the Parliamentary programme, and the Ministerial Council will act finally on the Chancellor's proposals next week.
BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Oliver Wendell Holmes is dead. He passed away without the semblance of a struggle or a pain.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- Judge Acheson of the United States Circuit Court heard argument yesterday on demurrer to the bill of complaint of H. Rider Haggard and the publishing firm of Longmans, Green Co. of New-York, against the Waverly Company of New-York, for an alleged infringement by the latter of the copyright of one of Haggard's novels.

A combination signal station and lighthouse is to be made of the tapering tower on the Manhattan Life Insurance Building, at 66 Broadway, for Local Forecaster E.B. Dunn and his assistants. The Weather Bureau will be removed from the Equitable Building to the new quarters about Jan. 1 next.

The committee of the Chamber of Commerce on Internal Trade, in its report to the Chamber on its efforts to secure improvement of the canals, after citing the proposed amendment to the Constitution which is to be voted on at the coming election, says:

Golf, says The Hospital, is the game for the exhausted brainworker at any stage of his life. No junior is too young, no senior is to old, to learn it; to learn it and to enioy it. The proof of the pudding is in the eating. On the golf links at St. Andrew's the man of seventy looks fifty, and the man of fifty has the appearance of thirty-five.

Arthur E. Fowler of Lynn pleaded guilty on Friday in the United States District Court to the charge of using the United States mails in a scheme to defraud. He was arrested some time ago for advertising in the newspapers stating that he would send a lady, on receipt of 10 cents, a new improvement as a substitute for the obnoxious hat pin.

Brooklyn voters will this year have four days of registration, the first being to-morrow, when the books will be open from 7 A.M. until 10 P.M. The other days will be Wednesday, Oct. 17; Friday, Oct. 26, and Saturday, Oct. 27.

Services at the Grace Presbyterian Church, Stuyvesant Avenue, near Jefferson, Brooklyn, were dispensed with last evening on account of the fact that the body of the Rev. Dr. Asbury O. Clarke, late pastor of the church, who died on Wednesday last, was resting in a casket in the church, while five of the members of the Board of Trustees served as a guard of honor.

By the way a provincial paper, which has turned its attention to this weighty topic, has fallen foul of the unfortunate lexicographer whose authority invoked last week for the use of "antiquarian" as a substantive. Webster is ruled out of court as an American, who "speaks only for his own country, and "antiquarian" as a substantive is said to be an Americanism.

Albert Harris of Harris Brothers, kidglove manufacturers, at 865 Broadway, committed suicide at 7 o'clock on Saturday morning by shooting himself in the right temple in the parlor of his house, 103 East Seventy-second Street. He had been depressed for some time, owing to business troubles.
No decision has yet been publicly announced by the Attorney General of the State in regard to the action which he will take in the case of the Commercial Alliance Life Insurance Company of this city.

When Major James W. Hinckley, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, began to make up his list of the Campaign or Executive Committee, he requested exSecretary of the Navy William C. Whitney to accept the Chairmanship of it or at least become a member.

John E. Russell, whom native distinction and an exact knowledge of many lands and varieties of men and of works have formed into one of America's most attractive personages, was born at Greenfield, Franklin County, Mass., in 1834.
The office of the receiver of the insolvent firm of Coffin Stanton was visited by a large number of persons yesterday, but no new disclosures relating to the affairs of the firm were made.

Antonio Canidani of 109 Cherry Street and George Sands of 374 Water Street, Greek sailors, were robbed yesterday in Henry Von Glahn's saloon, 152 South Street, of $130 by four men whom they invited to drink with them.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 8 -- The biggest strike that New-Bedford ever had is practically ended. The strike has lasted eight weeks, and during that time much more suffering has been endured by the idle operatives than will be ever known. The mills will start their machinery on Thursday morning, and the operatives will flock into the gates in a happy frame of mind.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Secretary Hoke Smith, who has just returned from Georgia, says he sees nothing discouraging to the Democracy in the result of the recent election in that State. He thinks the idea that there was a "slump" in Georgia has grown out of a total misapprehension of the facts. In speaking of the matter to-day he said:

A dozen or more students of the senior class of the Columbia College School of Mines surrounded City Hall yesterday, and, while some began taking measurements with tapes, others went around the building and wrote figures on large cards.

About 400 enrolled Republicans of the Fourteenth Assembly District had a lively mass meeting last evening in the Lexington Avenue Opera House. They met in response to a call issued in circular form by Howard C. Rees, candidate for the nomination as Assemblyman.

The conference committee or the State Democracy was in session for twenty minutes in the large meeting room of the Cooper Union yesterday afternoon. The session was private, and when the meeting adjourned it was arranged that the delegates should meet at 3 P.M. to-day at the same place.

The courage of the "men of Massachusetts" when they are convinced that there is a duty to perform is one of the traditions of American history, and American history would be much less interesting if it were not for that characteristic. The Democratic Party in Massachusetts is made up and led largely by men of conviction.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Did the Committee of Seventy know when they named Col. Strong for Mayor that he had never manifested any interest in union tickets for municipal reform? Did they know that in 1884 they refused to join in the Citizens' movement of that year, which was backed up by nearly all the leading men of the city.

Boston, Mass., Oct. 8 -- By a decision of Judge Colt of the United States Circuit Court to-day, the estate of the late Henry A. Hallett, for many years United States Commissioner here, will receive $6,385 as the result of a suit brought by Mr. Hallett before his death to recover fees disallowed by the Controller at Washington. The full amount claimed by Mr. Hallett was about $9,500.

The Madison Square Theatre has disappeared, and playgoers whose memories go back as far as the early eighties will regret its loss, for there was good promise in that unique little theatre, and good performance, too. Mr. Hoyt has renamed it Hoyt's Theatre, and nobody who sees the newly-decorated interior will regret the change of name.
Gustav H. Schwab was a very angry man yesterday, and he made no efforts to conceal his wrath.
PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 8 -- On application of J.B. Greenhut, President of the Whisky Trust, the Peoria Steel and Iron Company went into the hands of a receiver to-day, Ben J. Greenhut being appointed.

Secretary Hoke Smith, in an interview published in our Washington dispatches this morning, gives an explanation of the recent election in Georgia. He points out that the Democratic majority was between 20,000 and 35,000, and within 5,000 as large as that for Cleveland in 1892. It is only about one-half the majority for Gov. Northen, but there was no Republican candidate against the Governor, who was indorsed by the colored teachers' convention.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- West Chicago opened at 139, advanced to 139 1/2, repeded to 139, and then in quick order passed the 140 mark to 141 for a few shares, but closed lower, at 139 1/4. North Chicago sold at 262@263, then to 265, and then to 260 1/2. Elevated stocks were strong, Alley L and Lake Street leading.

The Shepardites of Brooklyn decided, at a secret meeting held in the rooms of the Brooklyn Democratic Club, 201 Montague Street, last night, to place a third ticket in the field. When the vote was announced in favor of this action there was great enthusiasm.

Richard Worthington, head of the Worthington Publishing Company of this city, died suddenly Sunday night at his home, in Sea Cliff, L.I. Mr. Worthington attended church service in the evening and appeared to be in his usual health. Shortly after retiring he was taken with a fit of suffocation.

There was an excellent attendance at Tattersails sale of saddle and harness horses yesterday afternoon, and bidding was good when good horses were offered. The bay mare Indian Girl is an exceptionally handsome animal, and her manners and fine action will attract attention anywhere. About fifty head were sold. Those which fetched $200 and over were:

Messrs. Bennett Graft have sold, for Builders Gunn Grant the four fourstory brownstone dwellings 152 to 158 West Eightieth Street, the first being 20 feet front, the second 19, and the other two 18 each. The houses are 57 feet deep.

SARATOGA, Oct. 8 -- There was a midday rumor that when the Twenty-second Congressional District Republican Convention reassembled this afternoon, Judge R.D.L. Baker of Fulton would, on the second ballot, be nominated for Congress. The deal fell through. Seven more formal ballots were taken.

The Lexow committee will continue its inquisition to-day, but its sessions will in future be held in Part III. of the Superior Court, it having been found impossible to meet in the old General Sessions Building because of its unsanitary condition.

The Committee of Seventy will try to remodel its municipal ticket, and put upon it such names as will be supported by the independent organizations. The remodeling will consist chiefly in striking off in a lump the State Democracy candidates below the name of John W. Goff, and substituting Republicans, O'Brienites, Stecklerites, and others who may be acceptable to some of the German Reform Union.
The burning lumber-laden bark that El Sud of the Morgan Line passed on her way to New-York, and reported when she arrived at port on Sunday, was heard from by the Ward Line people yesterday.

A lively, and to some extent amusing, time was enjoyed by the stockholders of the Comstock Tunnel Company who attended the annual meeting at 115 Broadway yesterday afternoon. About thirty persons were present, and they represented a majority of the $4,000,000 of capital stock. Theodore Sutro, as President of the company, submitted his annual report, which dealt chiefly with the litigation against the company.

C. P. Huntington, President of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, said yesterday that nearly all of the floating debt of the company had been paid off. When he took hold of the property the floating debt amounted to $1,200,000. That amount has been whittled down to $290,000 and the compayments on the floating debt have been payment on the floating debt have been made out of the earnings of the company. Mr. Huntington said:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- The local market was fairly active during the opening and closing hours, but dull in between. The tractions were inclined to sag. There was no effort made to depress them, but a few selling orders, with no organized support, caused a moderate decline. Electric sold this morning at 115, later at 113.

The franchise of the Bay Ridge Ferry, running from the foot of Whitehall Street to the foot of Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, was sold yesterday by Controller Fitch to Alrick H. Man, President of the New-York and Sea Beach Railroad, whose bid of 21 1-10 per cent, of the gross receipts of the ferry was the highest.

Capt. Cory of the schooner Hastings, which arrived here yesterday from NewBedford, Mass., reported having picked up on Saturday an oyster sloop which was floating bottom upward about five miles east of Middle Ground, Conn.
In speaking of the newly-appointed members of the Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee, Major Hinckley, Chairman of the State Committee, said yesterday:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- the action of Stephen E. Wilkinson of Galesburg, III, Grand Master of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, and Thomas McDermott and George H. Ruppel, brakemen on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, to restrain the receivers of that corporation from discharging eleven employes, including McDermott and Ruppel, because of their connection with the above brotherhood, came up before Judge Dallas in the United States Circuit Court this morning.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent throughout the day.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 8 -- The Official Gazette shows that $10,500,000 has been added to the public debt of Canada during the year ending Sept. 30. The liabilities payable in England increased nearly $6,000,000, while in the money the Government has been borrowing from the banks by way of temporary loans there has been a large increase.

After the race for the All-Aged Serial Handicap at Morris Park yesterday, which was won in a canter by Sir Walter, the Stewards had Griffin, the rider of Roche, who was the favorite in the betting, up before them. Roche ran an atrociously bad race-as poor a race as ever was seen by a horse of his class.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The news from New-York, received here daily by prominent Democrats, conveys to them that in a week at the most the campaign in the Stats will be well under way, with Democrats of all shades of opinion supporting the nominees of the Democratic State Convention and indications pointing to the election of the ticket by a handsome plurality.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Funeral services over the body of Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes are to be held in King's Chapel at noon, Wednesday, and the Rev. Edward Everett Hale, D.D., is to officiate. The services are to be of a semi-public nature, but all the details have not been completed by Dr. John Dixwell, who has the arrangements in charge.
William S. Thorn, Jr., thirty years old, committed suicide at the home of his father, 136 East Seventieth Street, Sunday afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 8 -- A storm of great violence has been raging over the South Lousiana and Mississippi county. At Mississippi city a Methodist church and several outbuildings were blown down. At Horn and Ship Islands everything is reported as blown ashore. The Norwegian bark Tristal, the American bark Caria Capon, the British bark Orlovie, and a number of lumber lighters were washed ashore on Ship Island.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Chief Clerk D. MacQuaig of the Agricultural Department this evening gave out over his own signature an answer to the charges made in the Republican campaign book against the administration of that department by Secretary Morton. The letter in full will make about 2,000 words.

Oscar Hammerstein struck Lawyer Issaac Fromme in the face at 8:23 o'clock last night in the lobby of Koster Bial's Music Hall. Immediately thereafter Mr. Hammerstein was arrested, taken to the Thirtieth Street Police Station, and held in $500 bail on Mr. Fromme's charges.
BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 8 -- The Democrats of this place have organized a campaign club, and purpose to make an active campaign. Mass meetings will be held. The club has adopted these resolutions:

Baltimore can have the League pennant, but the Giants are the proud possessors of the Temple Cup, emblematic of the champion of champions. They won the fourth and decisive game yesterday in a manner that surprised their Baltimore friends, and sent the poor Orioles home without a single victory to their credit.

The local political situation, so far as the plans and purposes of Tammany Hall are concerned, did not clear up very much yesterday, and even some of the most conspicuous leaders in the organization declared that everything was as yet in the air. There were indications that this was so.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 8 -- Two sensational races occurred at the last big race meeting of the season at Waltham to-day. These were the mile open contests, one in Class A, the other in Class B. Harvey Davidson of Toronto won the Class A and John S. Johnson the Class B. Davidson had been warned that if he staid here longer he would have to go into Class B.

Among the witnesses examined before the Lexow committee last Wednesday was Mrs. Anna Treibusch of 242 Tillary Street, Brooklyn, the keeper of a small news stand at the corner of East Broadway and Rutgers Street, who charged Patrolman Lynch of the Madison Street Station with arresting her because she refused to give him $5. Her husband, Samuel Treibusch, who keeps a news stand at Park Row and Mulberry Street, also testified before the committee.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Local shares showed somewhat more activity than they have recently, though the market Is not by any means very lively. Bell Telephone was steady at 201 and Erie Telephone at 52. Boston and Albany was firm at 206, and Boston and Maine at 153 1/8. Boston and Providence was strong at 206, 3 points higher than the last sale.

George W. Cram, a carpenter, sixty-four years old, while crazed by drink, shot his wife twice yesterday morning, at their home, 248 West Nineteenth Street. The woman, is believed to be mortally wounded.

The funeral of Prof. Vincenzo Botta was held at his home, 25 West Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday morning. In accordance with the wishes of the professor, the services were conducted by Chancellor MacCracken of the University of the City of New-York, and were extremely simple.

Dr. Holmes was not only the only survivor of the only "school" of American literature that was recognized abroad, or a subject of national pride at home, fifty years ago. His survivorship was the more marked because he survived not only his own contemporaries, but members of the Boston literary group decidely his juniors.
The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen held a short session yesterday and adopted this resolution:

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The Pullman quo warranto proceedings were brought up again before Judge Gibbons this morning, Attorney General Moloney being on hand early to see what procedure the attorneys for the company would adopt.

Unquestionably the most attractive programme of indoor cycling racing ever arranged on this side of the Atlantic has just been devised by Manager Sanger of the Madison Square Garden Company. Thanksgiving week is the time selected, and the bright, particular star among the champions to appear will be the mighty Zimmerman, the king of the racing path.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 8 -- Like most or the contests for the Transylvania Stake, the one today had an unexpected termination. From the first pool sold on Saturday. Ralph Wilkes was persistently backed against a formidable lot of cracks he had nerer met before, and to-night the Boston trotter's speed is as much at a mystery as ever for he did not show any of it this afternoon.

CHARLESTOWN, West Va., Oct. 8 -- William L. Wilson was welcomed to West Virginia with an enthusiasm unequalled in the memory of the oldest citizen of this quaint town. A committee of 150 citizens, headed by Col. Anderson, and accompanied by the Charlestown Cornet Brass Band, met the train conveying Mr. Wilson and the Washington party at Harper's Ferry.

IRONWOOD, Mich., Oct. 8 -- John Ravell, a miner, this evening put a half box of dynamite in the kitchen stove to thaw it out for use in the morning. The family of seven persons were gathered about the stove, chatting over the events of the day and conversing with a neighbor, Mrs. Peterson.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Senator Hill said to-day that he would open the campaign at Syracuse Thursday night.

"Col." William L. Strong, the Republican candidate for Mayor of New-York, sat in his office, at Broadway and Pearl Street, yesterday, and declared himself in a way that added to the confusion in which his party is laboring in its efforts to complete the ticket.
With enthusiasm and oratory in abundance the Democratic Club of the City of New-York ratified and indorsed the Democratic State ticket at a mass meeting in the Cooper Institute last night.

Registration for the November election will begin to-day in this city and Brooklyn. In this city the places of registry will be open from 8 o'clock A.M. to 9 o'clock P.M., and in Brooklyn from 7 o'clock A.M. to 10 o'clock P.M. The other days for registration are Oct. 17, 26, and 27.
BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Sutton Vane's melodrama, "The Cotton King," which had such, a long run at the Adelphi Theatre in London, had its first American production tonight at the Bowdoln Square Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Now that William L. Wilson has returned to West Virginia, the campaign in that State is considered to be fairly opened, and every politician who delights in a hot contest will watch its progress with the greatest interest. The information thus far received is calculated to give Democrats great encouragement.

W. Bourfce Cockran, who represents the Twelfth Congressional District of this city in the National House of Representatives, has determined not to accept a renomination and to close his Congressional career with his present term of office.

The stock market yesterday was almost wholly professional. The covering movement, which was the feature of last week, was apparently completed, and traders were ready to put out new lines on the bear side. Trading, however, was not active.

Some of the men who seceded from John E. Milholland's Republican organization have formed a new organization, and declared, in a manifesto, against Milholland and in favor of the State ticket. They call themselves "The Independent Republican County Oraginzation." As soon as convenient after organizing, they hurried to Chairman Hackett, at State Headquarters, and insisted on having a conference with him.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- A dispatch from CheFoo to The Pall Mall Gazette says that seven Japanese war ships were sighted off Wei-Hai-Wei steaming westward.

ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- The Republicans nominated candidates for the Assembly in three districts to-day. In the Second and Fourth the conventions were held at noon, and in the Third District to-night. In each district there was a lively contest. In the Second District James Keenholtz of Altamont was chosen, in the Third the choice fell to Patrick H. McCormick of Albany, and in the Fourth to Amos J. Ablett of Cohoes.

It is time interest was awakened in this city on the question of consolidating New-York, Brooklyn, Long Island City, and the adjacent territory into one great municipality. Provision has been made by the Legislature for submitting this question to a vote of the people concerned at the coming election, and ballots for and against the proposition are to be provided at all the polling places.

LISBON, Oct. 9 -- A dispatch from Lourenzo Marquez, on Delagoa Bay, Southeast Africa, says that Chief Mahazula's Kafir tribesmen, massacred several whites and a large number of Kafir allies in the outskirts of the town to-day. There is continual raiding and looting in the vicinity. At a meeting of the European residents the incapacity of the Government was denounced, and immediate action was demanded.

The registration in New-York yesterday -- the first day of this year -- was surprisingly heavy, 102,906 voters having qualified, as compared with 68,994 in 1893, 92,644 in 1892, and 70,147 the year previous.

Frank L. Woodward, President of the Dime Savings Bank of Norwich, Conn., and George D. Coit of the Chelsea Savings Bank, have asked Controller Corwin of Brooklyn to have registered $19,000 worth of the one-hundred-and-forty-seven-thousand-dollar bond issue for the improvement of Gravesend.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 9 -- Two long contests for small purses and a short one for the biggest prize ever offered for trotters were decided at the breeders' meeting here to-day. Some 5,000 persons were present to-day, the magnet being the Kentucky Futurity, for three-year-olds. The amount of the stake, after the nine starters had paid $250 each last evening, was $20,430, and of this all but $4,000 went to the winner, Benzetta.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided a case which will have an important bearing upon the construction of the bridges over the East River between New-York and Brooklyn by the East River Bridge Company. The object of the construction of the bridges, it has been stated, is to provide for continuous elevated-railway service between the cities of New-York and Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The little torpedo boats of the Texas will be an improvement on the Cushing in the method of discharging the torpedo. Hitherto the tube through which the projectile is fired has usually been placed in the bow, so that the torpedo could only be discharged when the boat was head on.

BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- A representative of the United Press has had an interview with a number of the leading dealers in the great sugar centre of Magdeburg. Among them, the senior partner in the house of Neubauer Co. says, in regard to the sugar schedule of the Tariff bill recently passed by the United States Congress:

PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 9 -- The tropical hurricane that had been central in the Gulf for several days struck this city Sunday night. The wind blew from the northeast, and was accompanied by rain. The hurricane increased in fury as morning approached, and raged all day yesterday.

Irregularity was the feature of the stock market yesterday. The speculation in Sugar was active, the transactions in it comprising more than 43 per cent. of the business done in the market. It was strong at the opening, but subsequently became irregular, selling down to 80 1/4 in the afternoon. Late in the afternoon the price rallied to 82 1/2, and the final sale was made at that figure.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 9 -- The fastest trip ever made through Long Island Sound was that of the Norwich Line's new steamer City of Lowell. She covered the distance of 122 miles, from New-York to New-London, in 5 hours and 34 minutes. The average hourly speed was 21 3/4 miles. Better time would have been made but for the port engine, which gave trouble several times, necessitating stopping.
The policemen employed on the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge combined last Winter in order to get their wages increased. They had a bill drawn which was passed at the last session of the Legislature.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- The Democrats of Westchester County held their County Convention here to-day to nominate candidates for Surrogate, Sheriff, Coroner, and Justice of Sessions. The convention was called to order by Francis Larkin, Jr., as Chairman of the Democratic County Committee.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- The entire militia of the State, 6,000 strong, was mobilized in this city to-day with very satisfactory results. The main object was the concentrating of masses into prescribed alignment from deployment in irregular formation; or, in other words, the bringing of a disciplined force to the relief of Boston, the performance of work in military fashion, and the retirement of the forces as rapidly as they came.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The Westminster Gazette publishes a dispatch from Yokohama which says that it is reported there that the Japanese have captured Che-Foo. The Government, however, has received no information confirming this report.

The American Horse Exchange began a three days' sale of full-registered hackneys and highclass saddle horses yesterday. Last evening's catalogue was made up exclusively of the Bloodgood hackneys. The three celebrated stallions, Star of Mepal, Blue Peter, and The General II., are well known to New-Yorkers, who have seen them in Madison Square Garden more than once.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Oct. 9 -- A mass meeting was held in the auditorium at Prohibition Park to-night for the purpose of arousing interest in the Greater New-York plan. It was attended by about 800 citizens, from every part of the island. The audience was practically unanimous for consolidation, and showed disapproval of the single speaker who opposed it.
This ticket, substantially that of the Committee of Seventy, was adopted last night at the County Convention of the New-York State Democracy held in Cooper Union.
There was a great deal of talk yesterday about the possible nomination by Tammany of Nathan Straus for Mayor. Following are some of the views on the subject expressed by prominent citizens:

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 9 -- In college circles here the topic of conversation is in regard to the probable make-up of the football eleven. There is plenty of talent in training, and on that account some of the wellwishers of the team are fearful lest Capt. Hinkey will make a mistake and set aside some first-class man when he makes the final selection for the eleven.

The recent decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, modifying the injunction of last December, which restrained the employes of the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad from performing various acts, including the abandonment of the service of the road, puts in a clearer light than has before been done the law as it affects strikes.

Williamstown, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Fire to-day destroyed the wooden buildings occupied by Brown's bakery, McCann's harness shop, Hopkins's furniture shop, Hosford's carpenter shop, and a barn and feed store. Judge Danforth owned the buildings. Loss on buildings, $8,000; insurance, $5,000. Loss on Brown's stock and furniture, $3,000; insurance, $500.

William F. Buckley, a stockholder of the Anglo-American Dry Dock and Warehouse Company of Brooklyn, which owns an extensive plant at Erie Basin, applied to Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for the appointment of receivers for the company.
Earl Grey, third of the title, died at his seat, Howick House, Elton, Northumberland, yesterday. He was born in 1802. His father was Prime Minister from 1830 to 1834.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 9 -- As the late Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes undoubtedly would have wished it, his relatives have decided to make the funeral services to-morrow as private as possible, without giving offense to the dead poet's many friends. Simple services in King's Chapel, to be conducted by the Rev. Edward Everett Hale, will be followed by the burial in Mount Auburn, only the relatives and immediate friends escorting the body to the grave.
We are very apt to forget the significance of the word "nobleman," although a moment's consideration brings it clearly before our minds.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Cornerstone Day, for which Binghamton and the Commercial Travelers of America have so long been preparing, dawned cool and cloudy, with some indications of rain. The state of the weather, however, failed to damp the enthusiasm of the great army of traveling men, who came from all parts of the country to participate in the celebration.

Every Democrat who desires the reform of the tariff, which is the main object of the Democratic Party and which has drawn to it the voters who have put it in power, regards with anxious care any attempt by the party leaders to coax the free-silver vote. If the party could now seriously be entangled with the free-silver men, the peril would be very great.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- The Twenty-second Congressional District Republican Convention has been anything but a political lovefeast to-day. Three sessions were held, and the one to-night was not of a friendly character. In all, 453 ballots have been taken, and the convention seems further from a nomination than when it was called to order on Sept. 14 at Sacandaga Park.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 9 -- Bank Presidents from Maine to California and from Canada to the Gulf of Mexico are in Baltimore to-night. They have come to attend the twentieth annual convention of the National Bankers' Association, which will meet at Ford's Opera House to-morrow. There are 2,000 banks connected with the association, but they are not all represented at the convention.

Oscar Hammerstein, the Harlem theatrical manager, yesterday morning was held for Special Sessions under $300 bonds by Justice Voorhis, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, on a charge of assaulting Lawyer Isaac Fromme. The trouble occurred in the lobby of Koster Bial's, on the evening previous.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 -- The United States steamer Mohican and the revenue cutter Corwin, which arrived here from Bering Sea, experienced heavy gales off the Northern California coast, during which the Corwin's starboard davits were carried away and two of her boats smashed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- The market opened dull, with prices barely steady, at yesterday afternoon's decline. The reaction is but natural after the big advance of the last few days. Operators with good profits in their trades were taking them, and others, figuring on the reaction, ranged themselves with the bears.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Oct. 9 -- The President left early this forenoon on Commodore Forbes's steam yacht Wild Duck for Naushon Island, where he was the guest of J. Malcolm Forbes. At Naushon the party was joined by ex-Gov. Russell, who came from Buzzard's Bay this noon, and Richard Watson Gilder of The Century.

BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- Prof. Leyden, the distinguished specialist who recently professionally attended the Czar at Spala, said to-day in regard to the reports that his Majesty's condition had changed for the worse:
SHAMOKIN, Penn., Oct. 9 -- The most disastrous mine fire in the history of the anthracite regions of Pennsylvania started at the Luke Fidler Colliery last night from the naked lamp of a workman.-

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 9 -- The usual "pointer" on the Government report was out to-day, and found many adherents, who sold wheat on it. There was also a controversy touching the Pacific coast stocks, as well as those of Europe, Bradstreet's figures, it was contended, did not show as fully as they should, the official figures being far in excess.

Christian Volteur, twenty-four years old, a grocer at 788 Eighth Avenue, was held by Justice McMahon yesterday on a charge of attempted suicide. Two months ago Volteur's wife died, leaving to him the care of a two-year-old boy. Volteur grieved greatly over the loss of his wife. He kept house alone over his store, and took care of the child.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 9 -- There was a sharp encounter between a small force of the Newark police and nearly 500 Italian strikers near the East Orange sewer excavation above Roseville Avenue this morning. The strikers came down Springfield Avenue in a compact body to assault the men employed in the big ditch.

If locomotive engines are capable of any emotion at all, it must have been a locomotive engine that fairly tingled with pride which stood on the Erie freight track at the entrance of the Jersey City tunnel about 8 o'clock last night. It was a big engine, with a big boiler and a big whistle. It blew off hilarious clouds of steam in a truly gigantic manner.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners met yesterday and received from William B. Parsons, the board's Chief Engineer, a preliminary report on his observations of the rapid-transit systems in London, Glasgow, Liverpool, Paris, and Berlin.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- The highest dignitaries of the Catholic Church in the United States will assemble in this city to-morrow to hold their annual conference, in conformity with a provision of one of the Church councils.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9 -- It is now definitely decided that the Princeton-Pennsylvania football game will not be played in New-York. A meeting of the Graduate Advisory Committee was held to-night at the Princeton Inn. at the conclusion of which a prominent member said that the State Fair Grounds at Trenton would, in all probability, be chosen as the location, and Nov. 10 as the date of the game.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 9 -- Lord Hawke's team broke up here to-day, and many of the men separated, not to meet again until they encounter one another playing for their verious teams in England. G.J. Mordaunt, L.C.V. Bathurst, G.R. Bardswell, G.W. Hillyard, J.S. Robinson, W.F. Whitwell, and K. McAlpine so to New-York on their way to England, and these are the only men who will go home now.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- To the great surprise of many, the Sharpe-Coykendall slate for county officers on the Republican ticket, that has been the talk throughout Ulster towns for several weeks, was broken to-day. The convention was captured by G.D.B. Hasbrouck, the Second Assistant Attorney General of the State, his brother, Dr. Josiah Hasbrouck, being Chairman
This is the State ticket nominated yesterday by the Democratic Party Reform Organization of Brooklyn.

Oswald Ottendorfer, editor of The Staats-Zeitung, read with much interest the interview with Gustav H. Schwab, published in yesterday's issue of The New-York Times. Mr. Ottendorfer himself is authority for this statement, and last evening Mr. Ottendorfer made a reply to Mr. Schwab's assertions, giving vent to his opinions in a manner that will prove very interesting reading to Mr. Schwab, as well as to that gentleman's friends and enemies.

The lease or sale by the heirs of Peter Cooper to the American Lithographic Company, announced several months ago, has fallen through. The property involved is the block front on the east side of Fourth Avenue, between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets, now occupied by small buildings, and some dwellings adjoining on the side streets.

James T. Powers took the place of Willis Searle as Archibald Rennick in "The New Boy" at the Standard Theatre last night, and the result was a big hit, the first semblance of great success that Arthur Law's very clever farcical comedy has had in New-York. In London the success of this play has been due to the comic personality of Weedon Grossmith.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- Local stocks were dull and the market was uniformly uninteresting, with the usual exception of Bay State Gas, which opened at last night's close of 12, dropped to 11, and then advanced to 13. The second bonds were quiet at 60. Boston and Albany was off 1/4, to 205 3/4, for one share, and Boston and Maine was 1/8 off, to 153.

A golf tournament will be played to-morrow, Friday, and Saturday on the links of the St. Andrew's Golf Club, at Gray Oaks, Yonkers. Great pains have been taken to make this tournament a notable one in every respect, and, judging from the number of entries, both amateur and professional, the contests ought to be well played.

A meeting of the Directors of the new Casino company, which is to take possession of the Casino Nov. 20, was held yesterday in the office of Guggenheimer, Untermeyer Marshall, 46 Wall Street, for the purpose of organizing by the election of officers. Rudolph Aronson was elected President of the board, William Frank Hall Vice President, S. Webber Parker Treasurer, and Joseph A. Arnold Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Nicholas Fredericksen, the American who escaped from the Russian naval guardhouse last July and whose case attracted so much attention at the time, appeared at the State Department to-day in the hope of enlisting the assistance of this Government in securing reparation from Russia for the treatment accorded him.

Policeman Louis De Gann yesterday swore before the Lexow committee that Capt. Schmittberger while in command of the steamboat squad, compelled him to pay him half of his weekly salary of $10 earned by extra work and special services aside from his police duties on the French Line pier, 42 North River, and that Capt. Schmittberger afterward demanded the whole amount and transferred him because he declined to pay it.

The annual report of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad for the year ending June 30 has been issued. It shows gross earnings of $13,034,049, a decrease of $1,635,000; operating expenses, $9,750,500, a decrease of $1,214,283, and net earnings, $3,283,545, a decrease of $420,724.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Democrats who call at the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Committee attest to the growth of enthusiasm among Democrats generally in the various Congressional districts. Representative Pendleton of the Wheeling (West Va.) district said to-day that he had been on the stump in West Virginia for several weeks and had become thoroughly impressed with the growth of Democratic sentiment.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Secretary Carlisle sent the following telegram to the Collector of Customs at New-York to-day:

The marriage of Miss Flora Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Gould of 635 West One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street, to Edward W. Rockafellow of Brooklyn took place last evening at St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street and St. Ann's Avenue.

Max Gombossy, a saloon keeper at 58 East Fourth Street, was arraigned in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday morning, charged with selling liquor without a license. Gombossy was recently a witness before the Lexow committee, but was induced to say nothing against the police.

The Executive Committee of the Amalgamated Cloakmakers and Cutters, in its meeting yesterday afternoon, at 412 Grand Street, after listening for three hours to suggestions from the cutters, decided upon the following demands to be made on the manufacturers:

The provisions for separating municipal from general elections, which were made by the Constitutional Convention, are mostly contained in the revised body of the Constitution which is to be submitted to a vote as a whole. No change was made in the term of office of members of the Assembly, and they would continue to be elected every year.

According to Le Figaro, Signor Crispi is about to be expelled from the fraternity of Freemasons, of which he has long been a member. For some time past his political attitude has excited a good deal of hostility in the lodges. His recent speech at Naples especially is held by many to constitute direct advances to the Vatican, which is the last Masonic apostasy.

Tammany's leaders professed to be in as much doubt as ever yesterday over the men they propose to nominate. They were waiting, they said, for the situation to arrange itself so that they could see the outlook. They were probably waiting for what took place last night -- definite action on the part of the State Democracy.

The proposition to defer the election of Directors of the Comstock Tunnel Company for thirty days, on which a stock vote was taken at the company's office, 115 Broadway, Monday, was found to have been defeated when the votes were counted yesterday. The election therefore proceeded, and the result was made known early last evening.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 9 -- William A. Slater's handsome new steam yacht Eleanor has arrived here from Bath, Me. It is understood that the Eleanor will go to New-York soon to haul out and then return to New-London, from which port she will leave for a long foreign cruise, Mr. Slater desiring to spend the Winter on the other side of the Atlantic.

James Kine, thirty years old, and variously described as a laborer and a pianomaker, shortly after 6 o'clock yesterday morning became suddenly insane at his home, 63 Avenue B. True, his outbreak had been preceded by a rapid decay of his mind, due, among other things, first, to a habit of drinking, and then to a complete stoppage of the habit because of an inability, through loss of work, to pay for liquor any longer.

The Committee of Seventy's Executive Committee was in session morning and afternoon at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday -- waiting. They discussed the possibilities of making a ticket which would receive the support of independent Democratic organizations, but, beyond listening to some remarks from a Republican or two, took no action.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 9 -- A meeting of the senior class was held Monday, at which appointments for class day honors were elected. The places were filled, with the best of good feeling, as follows:

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- At the joint meeting of the Executive Committee and Committee on Law Reform of the New-York State Bar Association held to-night, there was presented by J. Newton Fiero, Chairman of the Committee on Law Reform, an elaborate paper entitled. "The Code of Civil Procedure, the Necessity for Condensation and Revision."

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- This city celebrated to-day the memory of the famous Chicago Day at the World's Fair and also the anniversary of the "big fire" twenty-three years ago. Two parades, a grand military club ball, and two club banquets were the features of the jubilation.

The City Vigilance League held a meeting last night in the Fourteenth Street Presbyterian Church, and Dr. Parkhurst was the magnet that filled the church to overflowing. The doctor began by saying that he felt encouraged. He spoke as follows:

O.A. Sjostrom has done a business in money transfers to Sweden, at 27 State Street, for several years. Immigrants deposited with him their savings, on which he made the profit of exchange, promising to send the money home for the owners. He had an arrangement with the Bank of Copenhagen, as a distributing agent.
