New-York people who have conceived the idea that in the matter of the union with Brooklyn all the courting is being done by that city are mistaken, and still more so those that imagine that it is only a question of taxes. A distinguished citizen of Brooklyn in private life, but keenly interested in public affairs, recently remarked: "I am suspending judgment on the question of Greater New-York.

The Campaign, or Executive, Committee of the Democratic State Committee, which was appointed by Chairman James W. Hinckley, met yesterday for the first time in Major Hinckley's room at the Democratic State headquarters, in the Park Avenue Hotel. John Boyd Thacher of Albany, who was named as Chairman when the Campaign Committee was appointed, presided.

Republicans found yesterday that their hands had been tied by the State Democracy's action Tuesday night. There was but one thing for them to do, according to the leaders, and that was to join with the State Democracy on the entire ticket.

Another nice point of law has been injected into the controversy over the Staten Island Ferry franchise, in the shape of a license which has been granted to the Rapid-Transit Railroad Company by the Richmond County Court to operate a ferry between Staten Island and New-York.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- One of the most important cases to be argued in the Court of Appeals this session was argued to-day. It is in regard to the application of the City of Brooklyn to acquire the property and franchises of the Long Island Water Supply Company.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 10 -- Record breaking was out of the question here to-day, for the gale that blew across the track retarded the speed of the harness racers at least three seconds. As Alix was down for an attempt to lower her record, the attendance was well up in the thousands, but the best that the queen of trotters could do wag 2:08 1/2.

The German sugar dealers, who are not unnaturally indignant over the provision in the new tariff that imposes an added tax on sugar that has already received a bounty, are unreasonable. The principle is a well-established one in any country not guided by free-trade ideas. It is true that England has never adopted it, preferring to let her consumers have the benefit of the bounty, as they were sure to do in her own markets.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 10 -- The Democratic Convention for the First Congressional District, composed of Queens and Suffolk Counties, met in the Town Hall in this village this afternoon. An effort was made to induce James W. Covert, the present representative of the district, to accept, but he declined.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10 -- The Yale-Williams football game at the Yale field today resulted in Yale's favor by the score of 23 to 4. It was an interesting game, long runs being made by Thorne, Marks, and Beard of Yale and by the Draper brothers of Williams.

Messrs. Matt J. Ward Co. have leased, for the Zborowski estate, the Gedney House, at the northeast corner of Broadway and Fortieth Street, to Jaines H. Coleman, formerly proprietor of the Coleman House, in this city, and the Hotel Castleton, on Staten Island. The hotel will be renamed and improved, and will be opened about Nov. 10.

A scene that might have been dramatic in the extreme occurred in the Superior Court yesterday, when Frank J. Larkin, who had an action for damages against the Long Island Railroad Company before Judge Sedgwick, risked his life to expose his injuries to the jury.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1O -- Pennsylvania's eleven had no trouble in defeating the strong Crescent Athletic Club team to-day by the score of 22 to 0 in two short twenty-minute halves. The play in many respects was an improvement over Pennsylvania's showing last Saturday. The soft field and the slippery grass made quick starting an impossibility, but otherwise did not seem to mar the university eleven's work.

NEW-ROCHELLE, Oct. 10 -- The heavy windstorm which struck this place at an early hour this morning played havoc with the many yachts and sailboats anchored in this harbor. Two yachts were completely wrecked and a dozen others damaged more or less. The sloop yacht Banshee, owned by Henry C. Doscher of this place, dragged her anchor and went on Potter's Beach, but was not badly damaged.
This is the city and county ticket placed in the field by Tammany Hall last night. The convention did its work enthusiastically.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 10 -- The annual meeting of the American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions began its session of three days here this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The Rev. Richard S. Storrs, D.D., presided. The annual report for 1893-4 of the Home Department was presented by the new Secretary, the Rev. Dr. Daniels, who succeeded the Rev. Dr. Alden one year ago. Part of it follows:

The Riverside Wheelmen, one of the influential cycling clubs of this city, is arranging for its annual Fall races on election day. Five events will be decided, and sport of an unusually highclass character can be counted on. The races will be a one-mile novice, a one-mile handicap, a two and a five mile handicap, and a five-mile contest for the club championship.
The gale that passed over New-York early yesterday morning caused death and destruction in Monroe Street.

The Anti-Tammany, or O'Brien, Democracy held its County Convention at Murray Hill Lyceum, 160 East Thirty-fourth Street, last evening, and nominated for Mayer Col. William L. Strong, and for Recorder John W. Goff. The conference committee of the organization was empowered to select the remaining candidates.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was restricted owing to the absence of many operators who were away observing the Hebrew fast of the Atonement. There was the usual active trading in Sugar, and it advanced, on covering by small traders. Late in the afternoon there was a reaction which carried the price down from 84 1/2 to 82 1/2.

E.P. Martin, Chairman of the Forestry Committee of the Board of Trade and Transportation, received the congratulations of his fellow-members at yesterday's meeting of that body over the committee's success with the Constitutional Convention.

The reports of the recent movements of the Japanese, so far as they are intelligible, are by no means what their previous operations had led us to expect Everything indicated a "dash on Pekin," and such a dash, if successful, would have ended the war. It was necessary, however, that it should be made at once, because Winter campaigning in the neighborhood of Pekin is quite out of the question.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 1O -- Harmony and conciliation are unknown quantities in the political bear garden known as the Republican Twenty-second Congressional District Convention, which this afternoon reached its five hundred and seventy-fifth ballot without making a nomination. Any suggestion or recommendation that there should be a break, in order to secure a nomination inside of the legal limit, acts like shaking a red flag in a bull ring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Neither the Chinese nor the Japanese Legation has yet been notified by its Government of the reported capture of Che-Foo. The correctness of the report is doubted at the Chinese Legation. It is said by the Chinese officials that Che-Foo is strongly fortified, and that a very considerable Chinese army is stationed there.

The usual number of callers and the applications for speakers at meetings throughout the State formed the principal feature of business at the headquarters of the Democratic State Committee at the Park Avenue Hotel yesterday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 10 -- The gale played havoc with the telephone and electric-light wires, and several accidents resulted from horses and individuals coming in contact with them. A horse owned by Milk Dealer Henry Truax stepped on one of the charged wires in the roadway and was instantly killed.

BOSTON, Mass. Oct. 10 -- Amid a wealth of flowers, the brightness of which was in strong contrast to the gloomy skies and steady rainfall, the simple black, clothcovered coffin containing the body of Oliver Wendell Holmes, and bearing a plain plate inscribed with his name, was placed at the head of the main aisle in King's Chapel at noon to-day.

The first public step of Mrs. Josephine Shaw Lowell as the leader of the Woman's Auxiliary, which is to assist the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst in his labors for purity in the Municipal Government, has been taken, and a large number of invitations have been sent out for a woman's meeting in the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association, at Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, at 3 o'clock to-morrow afternoon.

The musical season this year, instead of springing upon us full-grown, like the proverbial Minerva from the head of Jupiter, is expanding by degrees. It began with some pleasant, if not remarkable, productions in the field of operetta, and is now proceeding by degrees in the realm of concert. After a time we shall have serious concerts and grand opera in all its glory, and the musical world will rejoice and be exceedingly glad.

Sir John Dugdale Astley. Sir John Dugdale Astley, third Baronet or that name, who died in London yesterday, was born Feb. 19, 1828, and succeeded to the title in 1873. He was formerly a Lieutenant Colonel of the Scots Guards, and served in the Crimean war of 1854. From 1874 to 1880 he sat as member of Parliament for North Lincolnshire.

Edward M. Sheperd said last evening that within a day or two the independent Democrats would have headquarters, and that, although the lists of signatures need not be filed until Oct. 17, they will be sent in next Saturday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Judge Tuthill has appointed Elias Summerfield receiver of the American Debenture Company, the securities of which are involved in the failure of Coffin Stanton. This action was taken on a bill for a receiver, filed by stockholders and Directors of the corporation. W.D. Mahoney, its President, filed an appearance in chancery, consenting to the appointment.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 10 -- A large crowd attended the auction sale of trotting stock here to-day and prices ruled high. The best stock offered was the consignment of R.J.R. Bascomb Son of Sharpsburg, Ky. Valissa brought $1,600, going to W.C. France of New-York. Her full sister, Valeria, brought $1,800, going to W.F. Putnam of Cleveland, Ohio.

The testimony given by John H. Lemmon before the Senate committee that Superintendent Byrnes was at the French ball on Feb. 5 last, at Madison Square Garden, and that he could not have helped seeing what happened there, caused some talk at Police Headquarters yesterday.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 10 -- Wheat was in a narrow rut to-day, no one wishing to take any great chances on the Government report, although it was generally believed that there would be nothing in it calculated to help prices. The opening and first ten or fifteen minutes was the most active period and was made noteworthy by the selling of "long" wheat, with on indifferent support coming from the holders of "puts."

The Democratic General Committee of Kings County met at the Brooklyn Athenaeum, Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, last night, and referred the request of the Brooklyn Democratic Club for a conference regarding the union nomination of Congressional and Assembly candidates to the Executive Committee, where Mr. York, the Chairman of that committee, said it would sleep a sleep that would know no awakening.

Tammany at last takes the field to battle with the entire community in arms against it. It is challenged in its encampment by the leagued forces of all other parties and factions. The decent public sentiment it has defied and the moral sense of the people that it has shocked are aroused and arrayed for its overthrow.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- Gov. Flower to-day refused, after a hearing, to grant the application of the Governor of Iowa for a requisition for Hubert F. Alien of Brighton, England, who was arrested in New-York City Monday, charged with having obtained $1,500 from David B. Lyons of Des Moines, Iowa, under the false representation that by his financial influence in London he could obtain capital for a farm-mortgage enterprise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Major Charlss Bentzoni, First United States Infantry, a well-known officer of the army, will retire to-morrow. Major Bentzoni has been on leave of absence in New-York City, his regiment being stationed in California. He is a Prussian who enlisted in the army as a private in 1857, and was rapidly promoted through non-commissioned grades, being commissioned a Second Lieutenant of the Eleventh Infantry in 1861.

The Executive Committee of the Committee of Seventy held a two hours' session yesterday afternoon, at which it considered the ticket nominated by the State Democracy Tuesday night, and what should be done to secure a union of the other organizations which are opposed to Tammany.

CALDWELL, Oct. 10 -- Anglers are in their element now on the beautiful waters of Lake George and the majestic expanse of Lake Champlain. Trolling is excellent, and the fine weather of the last week has afforded excellent opportunity to fishermen to enjoy the sport which is so dear to them.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday the William P. Rae Company sold to J.P. Ellery, as trustee for the Order of Tonti, plaintiff, at $2.000, the two-story frame dwelling 921 Belmont Avenue, north side, 60 feet east of Logan Street, 20 by 100. To the same, at $2,000 each, the company sold the three similar dwelling 922, 924, and 928 Belmont Avenue.

Mrs. Emllie D. Martin, National Superintendent of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union, and Mrs. H.S. Pritchard, State Superintendent, who are waging war against living pictures and indecent lithographs, called at Police Headquarters yesterday to see Superintendent Byrnes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Treasury receipts for the first ten days of October aggregated $6,500,000, while the ordinary expenditures so far have exceeded the receipts by about $1,500,000. To this must be added interest payments of $5,000,000, which will swell the total expenditures in excess of receipts to $6,500,000 up to date.

Although it had stopped raining before the races were called at Morris Park yesterday afternoon, so that patrons of the track did not have the positive discomfort which attempting to watch the running of races during the progress of a storm brings, yet it was cold enough to make heavy clothing very comfortable.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 10 -- The Passaic County Democratic Convention, held at Whitehead's Opera House, Passaic City, this afternoon, profited by the disastrous experience of the late Republican gathering and passed a resolution recognizing the claim of Passaic City and the various townships to representation on the ticket.

RICHMOND, Va. Oct. 10 -- The social event of the season in Virginia was the marriage to-day at Smithfleld, Isle of Wight County, of United States Senator-elect Thomas S. Martin to Miss Lucy Chambliss Day.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L. I., Oct. 10 -- The storm struck this city with full force and left the imprint of its fury in many places. The inhabitants were aroused from slumber by the rattling of window blinds and the beating of the heavy downpour of rain on the window panes. The storm had been raging for some time and had abated somewhat, when the wind came up again with terrific velocity.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 10 -- The mills will start up Monday. This is the result of the effort of Mayor Coughlin to relieve the suffering of the hands. At the meeting of the manufacturers to-day the following resolution was adopted:

The last trotting meeting of the season about New-York begins to-day at the Parkway halfmile track, in Brooklyn. Three harness races are on the card for this afternoon, and the entries number forty-nine, an average of sixteen horses in each class. If half of them respond to the harnessing bell the capacity of, the half-mile track and the skill of the starting judge will be taxed to the utmost.
The Republican Assembly District Conventions were held last night. In many of them adjournment was taken for the purpose of conferring with other organizations before making nominations.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- It is stated upon high Vatican authority that the Pope said to Mgr. Gravel yesterday that his encyclical letter dealing with the affairs of the Church in the United States was aimed at ending the opposition in America to the Apostolic delegation. During his conversation with Mgr. Gravel, his Holiness exclaimed repeatedly:

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 10 -- This has been a day of labor meetings. Every labor organization in the city connected with the textile industry has held a meeting and voted to accept the compromise agreement and return to work on the basis of 5 per cent, reduction. The mills will all be running in the morning.
BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- It is stated here that China has asked Germany to use her good offices with a view of terminating the war between China and Japan.
Nathan Straus, the Tammany nominee for Mayor, was born in Otterberg, Germany, in 1848, and came to this country with his parents in 1854.
Wheat was dull and irregular, with the close steady at 1/8 @ 1/4c decline and speculators holding off for the Government report.

Levi P. Morton, the Republican candidate for Governor, came down from his home, at Rhinecliff, Dutchess County, yesterday, to the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where he remained all day and last night, receiving the leaders of his party. Last. evening Mr. Morion's letter of acceptance was given out. It follows:

LAWRENCE, Mass., Oct. 10 -- The annual meeting of the Boston and Maine Railroad Company was called to order in the City Hall by President Tuttle this forenoon. The report of the Directors was accepted and placed on file without reading. On motion of J.C. Page of Boston the number of Directors was placed at sixteen for the ensuing year.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 10 -- The Morris County Republicans, in convention here to-day, renominated Charles A. Baker and William C. Bates for the Assembly.

The cause of the difficulty which Police Superintendent Byrnes has encountered in his efforts to break up the policy business in New-York was fully explained yesterday to the Lexow investigating committee by Vincent Majewski, formerly a policy writer in Harlem, who revealed many of the secrets of his calling.

William Clare of Thirty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue, Brooklyn, is in a critical condition, due to injuries received while attending Bridget Murphy's wake, at Thirty-eighth Street and Eighth Avenue, on Tuesday evening.

The questions that were of most interest to the State Democracy, and, incidentally, to the Committee of Seventy, yesterday, were what defections might be expected from their own ranks because Col. Strong had been indorsed at their County Convention, and the effect of such nomination on organizations that had not come to a decision on the Mayoralty candidate.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The Cesarewitch Stakes, for three-year-olds and upward, was won at Newmarket to-day by Sir J. Blundell Maple's Childwick, 4 years. M.A. Abeille's Callistrate, 4 years, was second and Mr. Manton's Shrine, aged, third. Annabile, Quilon, Opera Glass, Fllepa, Comedy, Frandale, Ragimunde, Sir Benjamin, Cypria, New Court, Gleanaway, William, Highland Buck, Insurance, Braemar, Lord Barnard, Syndic, Pennyless, and Sutin also ran.
Another tropical hurricane visited Manhattan and adjacent islands early yesterday morning. The wind howled, the rain drifted in sheets, and it was a bad night to be out.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The Cesarewitch Stakes, for three-year-olds and upward, was won at Newmarket to-day by Sir J. Blundell Maple's Childwick, 4 years. M.A. Abeille's Callistrate, 4 years, was second and Mr. Manton's Shrine, aged, third. Annabile, Quilon, Opera Glass, Fllepa, Comedy, Frandale, Ragimunde, Sir Benjamin, Cypria, New Court, Gleanaway, William, Highland Buck, Insurance, Braemar, Lord Barnard, Syndic, Pennyless, and Sutin also ran.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- A dispatch to the Central News from Tokio says that a detachment of Japanese cavalry and infantry yesterday made an attack upon and routed a force of 2,000 Chinese at Wi-Ju, and that the place remains in the hands of the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- William B. Smith of Elizabeth, N.J., thirty-two years old, an employe of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, was arrested here this afternoon by Andrew McWilliams, Chief Clerk of the Secret Service, for stealing 50,000 two-cent postage stamps from the Bureau.

The Republican County Convention will meet to-night in Adelphi Hall, 201 West Fifty-second Street, and complete its local ticket. Leaders in the party said yesterday that there was nothing to do but indorse the ticket which has the support of the Committee of Seventy and the State Democracy.
SHAMOKIN, Penn., Oct. 11 -- A defective boiler exploded at the Henry Clay Shaft, at 7:30 o'clock this morning, causing twenty-seven other boilers out of a nest of thirty-six to blow up.

Five members of a counterfeiting gang were brought before Commissioner Shields yesterday afternoon and were reinanded until Saturday morning. The names given by the men were Alphense Sperloza, Victor Brusch, "Joe" Goldwater, "Cliff" Abbott, and Leuis Giuseppl. Their arrest brought from Washington Chief William P. Hazen of the United States Secret Service.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 11 -- When the Hudson County Freeholders laid out the route of the Boulevard, to run from Bergen Point to the Bergen County line, they condemned a plot of ground at the corner of Pearsall Avenue, owned and occupied by George Schlund and Barbara, his wife. The Commissioners allowed them $2,250, which they refused to accept, and appealed to the courts.

"The sun has broken forth on our horizon and the clouds that threatened a storm when we last met have disappeared," said Chairman Larocque of the Committee of Seventy, in opening the meeting of that body in the Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon.

Franklin Bartlett, renominated for Congress in the Seventh District, was born in Worcester, Mass., and was graduated at Harvard in 1869. He studied law at the Columbia Law School. He is a member of the Harvard, Union, Knickerbocker, Manhattan, Players, and University Clubs.
The Democratic Party Reform Organization will have Charles S. Fairchild for Chairman of its Campaign Committee, Mr. Fairchild having accepted the office yesterday.

The Grolier Club has accustomed its admirers to the thought that it may not give an exhibition of books or of prints which will not be surprising; and still its exhibition of book plates is surprising. It contains examples, in Leicester Warren's nomenclature of Jacobean, Chippendale, Ribbon and Wreath, Plain Memorial, Crest, Allegorical, Pictorial, Portrait, Military, Literary, and Label book plates.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- Holders of Street's Stable Car stock have not found much satisfaction in the market lately for their security. There was quite a change to-day, and in place of a neglected stock at 12 or thereabout, trading in it was quite active and prices advanced from 14, the opening, to 16.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- At the Democratic Convention of the Eighteenth Congressional District, comprising Ulster, Dutchess, and Putnam Counties, held in this city to-day, William M. Ketcham, Mayor of Poughkeepsle, was nominated for Congress without opposition. His name was proposed by R. E. Connel of Dutchess and seconded by John F. Cloonan of Ulster and William H. Woods of Putnam.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 11 -- A secret and significant circular, sent out by Herbert E. Benton, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, has just been made public, much to the chagrin of Mr. Benton and other Republican leaders. It is an appeal to the Republican League of this city, one of the prominent Republican organizations in Connecticut.

The marriage of Miss Rosa Ringler, daughter of the late George Ringler, to George J. Jetter, took place last evening, a 7:30 o'clock, in Liederkranz Hall, Fiftyeighth Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 11 -- The conditions for speed were more favorable at the Breeders' Meeting to-day than they were earlier in the week, but there was nothing on the card to produce anything like a sensation. Two fiercely-contested events opened and closed the afternoon, the 2:29 trot being the first signal for close finishes and divided heats.

The President has not asked and is not likely to ask officers of the Federal service not to make speeches in the pending campaign. It is peculiarly proper that the chief officers of the Government should present to the people their accounts of what the party in power is doing, has done, or wishes and promises to do.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- This has been another day of dullness for local railroad shares. Boston and Maine sold at 152 1/2, Boston and Lowell at 195, Fitchburg preferred at 76 3/4. Connecticut River at 240, and Worcester, Nashua and Rochester at 118. West End common was fairly-steady at 54, a few shares selling at half a point higher, while the preferred sold at 82 1/2.

The Brooklyn and New-York football clubs played yesterday afternoon at Eastern Park. It was the first game in Brooklyn of the American Professional Football League. The game was a very interesting one. but the attendance was far from being encouraging to the promoters of the league. The New-York club had won two games and the Brooklyns had won one and lost one. This made the meeting between the two clubs interesting.
Strong winds, not carelessness, seem to have caused the collapse of the new building at 74 Monroe Street, and the loss of nine lives, early Wednesday morning.

Sudermann's "Heimath" was revived at the Irving Place Theatre last night for the purpose of introducing the new actress from Vienna, Lucie Freisinger, who played the part of Magda. She is a tall woman, whose ripe and ample beauty suggests a picture by Hans Makart, and she is a forceful, competent actress.
The following plans for new buildings and Alterations have been filed with the Building Department:
Nathan Straus, the Tammany candidate for Mayor, was quoted in a morning newspaper yesterday as saying, concerning the nomination for Mayor:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 11 -- George J. Gould to-day sent to Tax Collector Todd of Lakewood Township his check for $36,200, being the amount of his tax on an assessed valuation of $2,000,000 for personal property at the rate of $1.81 per $100.

Dr. James C. Avary, Secretary of the Board of Health of Atlanta, Ga., visited the officers of the Board of Health of this city yesterday. He is laboring in the interests of a plan for calling a convention of the heads of all the Health Boards of large cities for the purpose of comparing sanitary views and systems.

"One man to fourteen square miles of territory, or one man to 2,800 of population, is surely a very small guard to protect property and prevent violation of law, leaving out of consideration the force necessary to guard the extended sea coast against sudden attack by a foreign enemy."

Favorites in the betting won all six of the races ran at Morris Park yesterday afternoon. This is something that has not happened in many moons, and every racegoer was talking of the wonderful record on his way back to the city. The weather was so cold that there was need of something to cheer up the regulars, and they found it in the success of the favorites.
"It is a Democrat against a Republican for Mayor, there is no clouding that issue," says Mayor Gilroy.

The league against Tammany is now complete and ready to open the fight. The German-American Reform Union ratified last night the nomination of Col. Strong and the other candidates on the combination ticket, with the exception of one of the candidates for Coroner. Since the indorsement of the State Democracy was received there has never been any doubt as to the action of the German-American Union.

The citizens of New-York have now to choose between Strong and Straus, and a very large majority will surely determine in favor of Strong. The revelations of the Lexow committee bring the absolute necessity of downing Tammany from day to day nearer and nearer to every citizen, and this must insure a crushing defeat for the Tammany ticket.
FULTON CHAIN, Oct. 11. -- The daily reports from all parts of the Adirondacks give the same statement, that deer have not been so plentiful in twenty years.
Tammany nominated its candidates for representatives in Congress in all the city Congressional districts last night.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 11 -- The second day's session of the American Bankers' Association Convention opened with several delegates in their seats who are particularly interested in currency reform, and who were not able to be present yesterday.
Messrs. M. L. Hess have sold, for the estate of Euphrosyne Power, the five-story basement and sub-basement marble building 429 Broome Street, southeast corner of Crosby Street, 25 by 100, at $90,000.
Republican Aldermanic Conventions were held last night, and with few exceptions adjourned without making nominations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A "prominent Republican" from New-York, who has been interviewed by a Washington paper, admits that Morton's prospects are not so overwhelmingly favorable as partisan boasts indicate.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 11 -- Capt. Collins of Sayville was adrift all last night in an almost foundering yacht.
A pleasant run for bicyclists is to Amityville. It combines a run across the plains and about twenty-four miles over the finest Telford roads of Long Island.

-- Even Philadelphia Wakes Up -- Ada Rehan has succeeded in awakening enthusiasm even in sleepy Philadelphia. On her first appearance as a star there last Monday night in "The Last Word" she received what was, for a Philadelphia audience, a warm reception on her entrance, but, compared with the enthusiasm she had evoked in Boston, it seemed tame to the sensitive actress.
The Republicans of Brooklyn held their City Convention last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink. Their candidates nominated were:

The Democratic Party in Kings County held its City Convention in Brooklyn last night changed its name, for this campaign at least, to the Democratic Party Reform Organization, and made the following nominations:

Tammany men declared in public yesterday that they were delighted with their ticket, and whispered in private that they wondered how it was all going to come out, anyway. Tammany is not confident, as in the last few campaigns. The braves put on merry faces to cover sad hearts, and they made the best out of the existing state of affairs that they could.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Oct. 11 -- Henry Martin, a private watchman in the village of Maiden Lane, had a desperate struggle with a burglar in this village early this morning. About 3 o'clock Martin met a stranger with a bag upon his shoulder. The stranger seemed to be in a hurry.

E.T. Bedford's fast trotting mare Wanda won a rousing race on the Parkway half-mile track in Brooklyn yesterday, defeating a large field of trotters and pacers in the 2:20 class, which opened the Fall meeting of the Parkway Driving Club. Highland Lassie and Van Cott were the favorites before the start, and the gray mare from Roslyn succeeded in winning two heats, with Wanda close upon her at the finish of each mile.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 11 -- There was plenty of enthusiasm at the Democratic convention of the Eighth Congressional District of New-Jersey, held in Music Hall, this city this afternoon, when John T. Dunn was renominated for Congress, amid great applause and cheering.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Will you grant to me once more your permission to enlist a second time in your Foreign Legion? I fought under your flag and in your colors in your conquering war in Brooklyn last year. May I march with you to the relief of New-York, beleaguered by her own Government?
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Senator David B. Hill opened the Democratic campaign here to-night in the Alhambra Rink. A magnificent reception was accorded him.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- A certificate of incorporation of the Jamestown and Lake Erie Railroad Company was filed with the Secretary of State to-day. The company is a reorganization of the old Chautauqua Lake Railway Company, and will be a steam surface road twenty-five miles in length.

-- ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 11 -- The formal canvass of the election returns of the Legislature and the vote on the Constitutional amendments was accepted to-day in the presence of the Governor and the Secretary of State. It shows that there will be 50 Populists in the next General Assembly out of a total of 219, of which 3 are Republicans.

A cable dispatch to Signor Perugini announces the death at Frimton-on-Sea, Essex, England, Wednesday night of Charles Franklyn Henry De Witt Chatterton, for many years private secretary of Henry E. Abbey and one of the best known and most highly esteemed of the theatrical people of this country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The aluminium alloy is attracting the attention of army officers who are interested in lessening the weight of articles a soldier must carry. Foreign armies are vying with each other in the effort to bring down the burden of the infantryman to the lowest notch. Aluminium in the metal which nearly every one has decided will accomplish this result.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Twelve hundred earnest-looking men, most of them young, compose the delegates to the ninth annual convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, which began to-day at Metzerott Music Hall. The convention will last until Sunday, when a mass meeting will be held. Delegates are present from Scotland, Canada, and nearly every State in the Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Two officers of the Ninth Infantry have been surveying the neighborhood of Madison Barracks, near Sackett's Harbor, N.Y., for a rifle range for United States troops. The site considered is about two miles from the post and is known as the Camp Farm. It will require considerable work to transform the property into a suitable target range.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 11 -- Communication has been re-established with all points on the west coast visited by the storm which raged Monday night and Tuesday morning, and the dispatches tell woeful tales of the destruction caused by the wind and water.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 11 -- The reform Democrats, who obtained control of the party machinery in July through the appointment of a Provisional Committee in place of the old County Committee, last night inaugurated the open primary system, thus doing away with conventions. No Democrat could vote who was not enrolled, but the party accepted the plan in good faith, and, as a result, over 15,000 voters were enrolled throughout the county.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Washington Professional Football League team beat the Philadelphia eleven to-day 2 goals to 1. The contest was exciting and was witnessed by 1,500 persons.

Extreme dullness was the feature of yesterday's stock market. In the early trading, the bears were inclined to hammer prices, but in the afternoon the shorts covered, and the early losses were partly regained. London bought a few shares of St. Paul and Louisville and Nashville, but its operations attracted little attention.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 11 -- Mrs. Elisha Dyer. Jr., gave one of the most charming entertainments of the Fall to-day -- a ladies' luncheon. The table and dining hall were decorated with Autumnal flowers and maiden-hair ferns. The guests were Mrs. J.J. Wysong, Miss Grosvenor, Mrs. Mortimer Brooks, Miss McAllister, Mrs. William H. Osgood, Mrs. Daniel B. Fearing, Mrs. James P. Kernochan, and Mrs. James Hude Beekman.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 11 -- With all sails set, laden with a full general cargo, but with not a soul on board, a schooner ran away to sea during a severe storm yesterday, eluded pursuit by another vessel all day, and disappeared in the gloom at nightfall, still plowing an independent course, under full headway, with no guiding hand at the tiller or any human agency to control her movements.

LISBON, Oct. 11 -- A dispatch from Lourenzo Marquez, on Delagoa, Bay, says the Portuguese there are hemmed in by 30,000 Kafir natives. The town is strongly barricaded. The natives looted the suburbs of the town yesterday and burned many houses.

The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst made the principal speech at a City Vigilance League meeting, held in the Lexington Avenue Baptist Church, corner of One Hundred and Eleventh Street, last night. He was also to have spoken inter at the Church of Our Saviour, at One Hundred and Ninth Street and Madison Avenue, but he found it physically impossible to keep that engagement.

The parade of the striking cloakmakers began with something like a riot last night. In the disturbance the police of the Madison Street Station used their clubs freely and with vigor. They fired their revolvers into the air as a warning, but that was not sufficient. More than one striker was removed to neighboring drug stores and doctors' offices to have wounds from clubs dressed.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 11 -- The marriage of Miss Theodosia Burr Potts, youngest daughter of the late George H. Potts, a prominent banker in New-York, to Dr. Benjamin May Baker of Norfolk, Va., was solemnized at noon to-day in St. John's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harrison B. Wright.

The reorganized Democratic Party of Kings County held its County Convention at the Brooklyn Athenaeum, Atlantic and Clinton Streets, Brooklyn, last night, and placed in nomination Col. Michael J. Cummings of the Sixth Ward for County Register; George E. Glendenning of the Twenty-third Ward for County Clerk; ex-Assemblyman John H. Bonnington of the Seventeenth Ward for County Treasurer, and James F. Kelly of the Twenty-ninth Ward for Justice of the Sessions.

The Committee on Political Reform of the Union League Club submitted a report at a regular meeting of the club last night, in which the work of the Committee of Seventy was indorsed. Resolutions accompanying the report were adopted by the club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The officials of the Democratic Congressional Committee have been busy to-day replying to numerous inquiries concerning the state of the campaign in various parts of the country. Senator Faulkner, the Chairman, who had just returned from New-York, was plied with questions relating to the situation in the Empire State.
Camden C. Dike. Camden C. Dike, father of Supervisor Norman S. Dike of Brooklyn, died at his Summer residence, at Point Pleasant, N.J., yesterday morning, after an illness of six days.

The County Convention of the German-American Reform Union met in Fernando Hall, Fifty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, last night and indorsed all of the Committee of Seventy's candidates for city offices, with the exception of William O'Meagher for Coroner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics reports that the total value of the exports of breadstuffs, provisions, and mineral oils from the United States during September, 1894, and during the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1894, as compared with similar exports during the corresponding periods of the preceding year, was as follows:

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Oct. 11 -- Twenty thousand people saw Robert J. beat Joe Patchen in a magnificent race in three straight heats in 2:06, 2:06, and 2:03 1/2, within a second of the race record. Considering that the weather was chilly and the track new and a little wavy in places, the time was remarkable. The first and second heats were close, Robert J. just winning at the wire.

James McMahon, Henry Batterman, Percy G. Williams, E.J. Granger, and E.G. Blackford have been appointed by the Consolidation League, with headquarters at 189 Montague Street, Brooklyn, to raise a fund for the Greater New-York campaign.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 11 -- An increased attendance marked this morning's session of the great Congregational missionary meeting. The Rev. Judson Smith of Boston gave the central address. It was an urgent plea for the fullest intellectual preparation for missionary work. This address was one of the few authorized by the Prudential Committee of the American Board.
A pretty sight was witnessed at the New-York Foundling Hospital yesterday by many interested visitors.
The following preamble and resolutions were unanimously adopted at the last meeting of the Home and Country Protection Club of Kings County:
John E. Milholland has a grievance against Charles W. Hackett, Chairman of the State Republican Committee, and also against ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt, whose representative Mr. Hackett is.

Some other principle than a respect for proved fitness and capacity governed the Tammany Congressional nominations yesterday, but the new candidates named are all respectable men, we believe, and certainly the old and the new alike are to be preferred to their Republican opponents, who for the most part are no better or wiser.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- The Republican Twenty-second Congressional District Convention held three sessions to-day, and reached its eight hundred and nineteenth dead-lock ballot. The opposing delegations indulged in a monkey-and-parrot wrangle to-night, during which the Saratoga, Fulton, and Hamilton delegates declared that they never would vote for Gen. N.M. Curtis, nor for any other man from St. Lawrence County.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- It will be no walk-over for Yale this year. The Harvard football team is seriously crippled just now, and is certainly in hard luck, but the members of the team are working with a vim that is sure to offset the ill luck very soon.

Ex-Mayor Franklin Edson appeared before the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday to ask for an appropriation of $3,000 to defray the expenses of the members of the Mayor's Advisory Committee on Street Cleaning, which is about to make an examination of the methods of disposing of garbage in the large cities of the United States and Canada.
"It is politics, but it is a very good thing," said William Dean Howells last night, in speaking of the Woman's Auxiliary, which is to aid the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst in his municipal housecleaning.

For the fourth time in his life of fourteen years, Harry Howe, of 16 Mechanic Street, Worcester, Mass., is in the hands of the Gerry Society, after running away from home. Harry says his father is a traveling salesman, and is away most of the time. His mother is dead, and his stepmother, the boy alleges, discriminates against him in favor of her own two children.

Our present election law provides for the manner of nominating candidates whose names are to be printed on official ballots. Nominations, whether by convention or by certificate with a prescribed number of signatures, have to be filed with certain public officers, together with the designation of the party, or the "political or other name" adopted by the signers of certificates expressed in "not more than five words."

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The one hundred and seventeenth anniversary of the burning of Kingston, which occurs Oct. 16, will be celebrated in this city in a very patriotic manner by the members of Wiltwick Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution. Many distinguished visitors will be present from other cities.

Arthur F. Curtis testified Aug. 20, 1888, before the Ford Congressional committee, then sitting in this city, to investigate and inquire into the subject of contract labor and the numerous complaints that had been made that the law was being violated with impurity. He stated that Levi P. Morton had in his employ men that he brought over from England under contract.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 12 -- Heavy skies, with a cold rain that came late in the afternoon, kept the attendance down at the Breeders' meeting to-day, but did not interfere with the sport. The trotters took so lone to settle their disputes that the pacers did not have daylight enough to finish their one engagement. It was a bad day for favorites all through.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Mrs. Lottie Bannister, who is temporarily deranged, escaped from the home of her aunt, Mrs. Maria McInness, 1,155 Summit Avenue, about 3 o'clock this morning, clad in a hat, coat, and trousers belonging to her cousin. A general alarm was sent out.

In utter defiance of the wishes of decent Democrats of Kings County, the "reorganized" Bell-McLaughlin Democracy of Kings County has nominated a county ticket which, it is believed, will insure to the followers of the "Boss" a sounder thrashing than was administered last Fall.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Senator Charles T. Saxton and J. Sloat Fassett tonight opened the campaign for the Repub- licans of Buffalo. They spoke at Music Hall. Among other things, Senator Saxton said:

William F. Cody -- "Buffalo Bill" -- attired in a suit of black broadcloth, and carrying a silk hat in his right hand, from which a magnificent diamond flashed rays of light, appeared before Justice Truax, in Part III, of the Supreme Court, yesterday, as defendant in a suit brought against him by Theatre Manager George W. Keogh, to recover salary and for breach of contract.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Senator Hill spoke here this evening to an audience that was as large as could find room in the Opera House. He was enthusiastically received, and his address was frequently interrupted with applause.

Mr. William M. Newman has sold for G. Bernheimer and the estates of I. H. Bernheimer, to the builders, Messrs. Gauer, Gross Herbener, the old Elm Park Brewery property on Ninetieth and Ninety-first Streets, beginning 100 feet east of Amsterdam Avenue, and comprising thirty-four lots, seventeen on each street.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 12 -- By his great performance here to-day, Monte Scott, the peerless road rider of New-Jersey, broke the world's record for twenty-five miles over public highways for the second time within a week. His ride to-day was a remarkable one, for it places the mark over four minutes below the best previous effort -- a wonderful jump in a race of this description.
NEWPORT, Oct. 12 -- Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt gave a dinner to-night in honor of Miss Pauline Whitney, who is visiting Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt.

Prof. Raleigh's brief, comprehensive, and careful review of a broad field of literary labor has just the qualities such a work ought to possess. It includes the material he has used in his lectures on modern literature at the University College, Liverpool, augmented and elaborated, and is to be regarded as an educational handbook rather than a contribution to belles lettres.

The suit brought by Stephen W. and E.J. McKeever, contractors, against William Kelly and George H. Sterling has been compromised. It is understood that the McKeevers received not less than $52,000 and a number of building lots in Newtown.

Senator David B. Hill, the Democratic candidate for Governor, will arrive in this city early this morning from Binghamton, Where he delivered a speech last evening. He will remain in this city until Monday evening, when he will go to Kingston and make a speech.

Russell Sage yesterday won another victory over William R. Laidlaw on an appeal from a verdict of $25,000 damages for injuries received on Dec. 4, 1891, when Norcross, the Boston crank, exploded a dynamite bomb at Mr. Sage's feet and blew himself to atoms.

Justice Gaynor in the Supreme Court yesterday denied the motion for an injunction to enjoin Jacques Friedberger from accepting a position as piano instructor at Cornell University. Franz Wilczek alleged that Friedberg had entered into a contract to go with the plaintiff through the country, giving piano recitals.

Dr. Parkhurst addressed a meeting of women yesterday afternoon in the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association, Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue. His subject was "The Condition, of Our City and Woman's Relation to It."

Bradstreet's will say to-morrow: "An accentuation of favorable features is revealed in the telegraphed reports to Bradstreet's this week. While advices as to the most marked improvement come from the West and South, there are some encouraging features also reported from the East, and the net result of the week's business has been further progress in the direction of enlarged distribution.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Alley "L" stock was raided to-day with success. The heavy selling carried the price down to 11 1/2. The shorts began covering at the decline, and there was a rally to 12. The report of the minority stockholders' committee is not yet ready. Lake Street "L" was dull, but firm, at 21 1/4 with very little stock offered.
The Republican County Convention met last night at 8 o'clock, nominated a ticket, adopted a report, listened to two speeches, and adjourned at 8:20.

A letter was received at the Department of State, Washington, yesterday, from Consul McGarr at Santiago, Chile, announcing the death of John A. Spooner, an American citizen. Mr. Spooner was a citizen of Massachusetts, and had resided at Santiago for ten years, being engaged in running parlor cars on the Government railway, for which he had an exclusive concession.
The Board of Police Justices will hold a special meeting in the Criminal Courts Building on Monday to consider the question of excise arrests and the disposition of excise prisoners.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Ex-Senator Michael T. Barrett of Newark appeared in the Somerset court this morning in behalf of Felix Cohen, who was under indictment for gambling at the county fair last month, when, Farmer David Crotsly of Pottersville was fleeced out of $240. Cohen was to have been tried to-day.

At the approaching election of the Cincinnati, New-Orleans and Texas Pacific Railway C. S. Brice, Samuel Thomas, Edward Lauterbach Thomas McGhee, and one other man will retire from the Directory, to be succeeded in all probability by M.D. Woodford, Eugene Zimmerman, Henry Taylor, Alfred Sully, and J. Howard Taylor.

John Nichol, LL.D., Professor of English Literature, and only son of the late J.P. Nichol, Professor of Astronomy, died yesterday in London, aged sixty-one years. Prof. Nichol was born in Montrose, Forfarshire, Scotland, Sept. 8, 1833, and was educated in the University of Glasgow, and Balliol College, Oxford, graduating respectively in 1855 and 1859.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Mrs. Agnes Skinner of 125 West One Hundred and Eleventh Street was yesterday arrested, charged with perjury in unlawfully obtaining pension money from the Government. Her former husband was Victor Marr, a private in the civil war. She stated that she had received no pension money since September 1893, when she learned that she could not lawfully receive the money.

"The Democratic Party Reform Organization" is the formal and legal title of those Democrats in Brooklyn who have rejected the rule of McLaughlin, who broke the power of that boss last year, and who are bound to the Democratic Party as a means for good government and for no other purpose.

Among the sweet nosegays of thought which the Hon. Levi P. Morton, the Republican candidate for Governor of New-York, plucked from the flower pots of his mind and showered on Warner Miller and Thomas C. Platt when he accepted the nomination, was the following bud of lovely fragrance:

ANTWERP, Oct. 12 -- The steamer Wilhelmine, having on board Baron Dharils, commander of the Belgian troops in the Congo State, who is returning from a three years' bloody but victorious campaign against the Arab slave traders in that district, arrived off the mouth of the River Scheldt yesterday morning, but was prevented by a dense fog from entering the river.

SARATOGA. N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The Republican Twenty-second District Congressional Convention is still in session at midnight, having failed to make a nomination after having taken 1,135 ballots. This afternoon's session was one of the most exciting of the many held since the convention was called to order on Sept. 14.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Treasury officials have not been as yet officially advised of the arrest of J. James Howard, coachman of ex-Vice President Morton, for coming into this country under contract, but they have been considering the matter for several days.

Otto Slimbach the prize bully and rough of the Eastern District of Brooklyn, was mortally stabbed by an unknown man while engaged in a street fight at Boerum and Leonard Streets on Thursday evening. He was taken to St. Catharine's Hospital, where he died within five hours.

Patrick Kelly of 1,677 Third Avenue, who was a witness before the Lexow committee on Monday, made a complaint at Police Headquarters yesterday of larceny and assault against Policeman Schroeder of the Eighty-eighth Street Police Station.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The schooner Hartford, bound from Detroit to Cape Vincent, with 22,000 bushels of wheat, is a total wreck in Mexico Bay. All on board were drowned, as follows:

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The third and last day of the Indian conference began with the discussion of the problem of Indian education, opened by Dr. Hailman, Superintendent of Indian Schools. Dr. Hailman believed that it would be best for the Superintendent of Indian Schools to be transferred from the Indian Bureau to the Commission of Education.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 12 -- The Naval Small Arms Board busied itself to-day with the testing of a magazine invented by Major W.R. Livermore of the United States Engineers. It was fitted to a Lee speed rifle, which mechanism did not show the work of the magazine to the best advantage.
The Executive Committee of the New-York State Democracy has decided to nominate candidates for Congress in this city in opposition to Tammany Hall.

-- The output of books for the Autumn and for Christmas -- the great season, of the year for the book trade -- has well begun. From the most important houses have already proceeded many volumes which will be the talk of the literary world for the remainder of the year, books of fiction, of travel, and of history.

Edith Hawthorn Crane Simmons, wife of Robert S. Simmons, has begun proceedings in the Surrogate's Court to contest her mother's will and to nave its provisions construed by the court. Her mother was Angeline Crane, a widow, who died recently, leaving an estate valued at about $50,000. She appointed the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company executor of the estate.

It Is not at all surprising that one who fought in honor for the South" should find his sympathy with the character and achievements of Abraham Lincoln deep enough to call for picturesque expression. It was Emerson who said that "The search after great men is the dream of youth and the most serious occupation of manhood."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- At the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Committee there is great activity these days. In the basement a large force of men is employed in folding and addressing campaign documents, and up stairs several clerks are kept busy opening and replying to letters from every corner of the Union.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 12 -- The American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions chiefly occupied this morning in discussing their embarrassing financial condition, but it was finally voted not to devote the Otis Fund of $80,000 to a partial liquidation of the one-hundred-and-sixteen-thousand dollar debt of the board, but to use it as previously determined upon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Senator Faulkner, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, who recently spent several days in conference with the party leaders in New-York, had this to say as to the situation in the Empire State:

The four delegates who represented the Young People's Association of the Warburton Avenue Baptist Church at the fourth international convention of the Baptist Young People's Union of America, held at Toronto, gave their reports of the convention in the lecture room of the church last evening. The programme was interspersed with vocal and instrumental music, followed by a social meeting.

The stock market was a again very narrow yesterday. Speculative interest centred in Sugar, and until late in the day it was strong. It opened at 84 1/4, advanced to 85 7/8, and then developed weakness, closing at 84, a net advance of 1/4 on sales of over 60,000 shares. Chicago Gas was also strong until the afternoon, when it was sold down to 74 1/4, and closed at 74 1/2, a gain of 1/4.

BLUEFIELDS, Nicaragua, Oct. 3, via New-Orleans, Oct. 12. -- Soon after the order for the arrest of C.G. Ausbern of Pittsburg was issued by Cabezas, that gentleman secured a launch and steamed to the Marblehead, laying the facts before Capt. O'Neil and spending the night aboard.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- The feature of the local stock market was the continued strength and activity of Erie Telephone, which opened up 5/8, at 55 7/8. The highest of the day was 56, and the closing 3/8 lower, at 55 5/8. Rumors of improved business and consequent increase of the dividend is the cause of the recent advance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Representative Bellamy Storer of Ohio, who has been studying the political situation in New-York, gave his opinion of it to-day to a Washington reporter. He is a Republican, but he does not believe that there is to be a Republican landslide in the Empire State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The statement has been made since the exposure in these dispatches of the connection of the Republican Congressional Committee with the A. P.A. that Chairman Babcock would authorize a denial of the charges. Mr. Babcock may have once contemplated making such a denial, but nobody with knowledge of the facts believes that he will now do so.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 -- The east-bound overland train, due at Sacramento at 9 o'clock P.M., was held up by two men about six miles below that city last night. The track walker was first robbed and then forced to start to town.
-- Marion Crawford's story, "Casa Braccio," will be Illustrated by Andree Castaigne. Three women of the house of Braccio are among the characters. Each is of a different generation.

All of the city candidates of the Committee of Seventy, except the nominee for Mayor, Col. W.L. Strong, met the Executive Committee of that organization yesterday morning at the Chamber of Commerce and accepted their nominations.

The same rooms in the Union Square Hotel that Hugh J. Grant used for headquarters in his successful campaign for re-election as Mayor in 1890 have been secured by Nathan Straus for headquarters in the present campaign.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 12 -- The Amherst "Aggies" added another defeat to Wesleyan's poor record to-day, by scoring 10 points to Wesleyan's 0. The scoring was all done in the first five minutes, on Wesleyan's fumbles. After that neither side could score, and it was a hard fight, in which both sides had about equal honors. Amherst "Aggies" played a strong interfering game, while Wesleyan had none at all.

The application of Patrolman Henry McArdle fpr a writ of mandamus to compel the Board of Police Commissioners to retire him on a pension was denied yesterday by Judge Giegerich of the Court of Common Pleas.
The Actuarial Society of America yesterday continued its meeting begun Thursday at the Mutual Life Building, in Nassau Street.

Nathan Hirsch of 158 West Sixty-fifth Street, the grandfather of ex-Civil Justice Steckler, was a prisoner in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday. So was Edward Smollbach, a painter, of 330 West Thirty-eighth Street.
Tammany nominated candidates for Assembly and Aldermen in almost all the Assembly districts of the city last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Louisville, Ky., was chosen by the Brotherhood of St. Andrew convention as the place for the next annual meeting. An invitation was extended by a New-York delegate to hold the convention of 1896 in New-York City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Secretary Herbert has made an important order. For the first time in the history of the navy, all the details connected with designing and building vessels are placed in the hands of one officer, who will hereafter be held responsible for errors and faults.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- According to a dispatch to The Westminster Gazette from Shanghai, it is rumored that the Chinese Government has opened negotiations with Japan for a settlement of the war between them.

The adoption by the Bankers' National Association at Baltimore of a definite plan for the issue of bank currency is an extremely encouraging sign for the possible solution at no distant time of the whole vexed problem of the currency. For such a solution the country is in some respects most fortunately situated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Acting Postmaster General Jones has issued a circular of instructions to all Postmasters at freedelivery offices directing that hereafter substitute letter carriers must be nominated from the eligible list. Vacancies in the carrier force must be filled, where practicable, by the promotion of the senior substitutes.

Republicans who visited State headquarters yesterday kept Chairman Hackett busy answering Questions about Candidate Morton's importation of servants from England. Mr. Hackett regarded the fact that the candidate had seen fit to employ one J. James Howard "in dear old Lunnon" and bring him over here to drive his horses as one of the jokes of the campaign.

-- A bicycle race will take place at West CreeK, N.J., to-day, under the management of G.W. Cranmer and F.E. Cox. The prize will be a gold badge, and the entrance fee will be 25 cents. The race will be five half-mile heats. A large number of Toms River wheelmen are expected to enter. Among the towns that will be represented in the contest are West Creek, Tuckerton, Barnegat, Waretown, Toms River, and Lakewood.

The safest way to treat issues that are "entirely disposed of " and powder that is "already burned" is to let them alone. If they are stirred up, there may prove to be life and explosive power in them yet. The plea that justice prevailed, as a defense for violating law, does not work.

Counsel for Mrs. Elizabeth Garnett of Bristol, England, again applied to Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court yesterday for the removal of the receivers of the Jarvis-Conklin Mortgage Trust Company.

The City Convention of the regular Democratic Party of Kings County was held at the Brooklyn Athenaeum last night. It was demonstrated that the nominations made Thursday night did not meet with popular favor, as, before the proceedings were over the he was passed between John A. Quintard and Bernard J. York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The stamp robbery at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing discovered yesterday turns out to be much larger than at first suspected.

Reform Democrats who believe in the overthrow of the remaining remnants of the crippled Brooklyn "ring," and who are disgusted with the nominations made by the "machine" at the Atheneum Thursday night, placed an exceedingly strong county ticket in the field last night.

The suit brought by Louise Burgoyne for a separation from her husband, Stephen Burgoyne, who is connected with the Central Gaslight Company, is on the calendar before Justice Ingraham, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, for trial.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- For the first time in many years appointments were made today to the grade of Ordnance Sergeant in the army. There are 110 positions of this grade under the ordnance officer, but for years none of the vacancies which have been created by death or retirement has been filled.
Seated in a cab on Broadway, yesterday afternoon, returning from a drive through Central Park, Julius Petsche fired a bullet into his brain.

As a spectacle, the best race of the day at Morris Park yesterday was the second on the card. This was a run of a mile for selling-platers, and had a field of seven starters. It was a race that was full of good things, Victorious being the choice in the specuiation, with Adelbert the second choice, and Counter Tenor the third.

The second day's trotting races at Parkway were witnessed by a large crowd of Brooklyn and New-York road riders and horsemen, and, while one of the events proved to be a hollow walk-away for the good four-year-old filly McLaughlin Maid, the other developed a stirring, contest, which remained undecided when darkness came on.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 12 -- There will be only three days of registry in this city, instead of tie four allowed by law, unless the authorities can put such construction upon the statute covering that very important part of election as will permit the Boards of Registry to hold a sitting on Saturday, Oct. 27.

The Charity Organization Society makes the following appeals on behalf of needy and de- serving persons under its care who require aid of a kind or to an extent not procurable from any existing agency:

II. To the Editor of The New-York Time: Yesterday I called attention in your columns to the picture of the New-York policeMan running amuck, "under the influence of medicine," as the Malay, drunk with "bhang," cuts, with his kriss, at the men, the women, and the children who got in his way.

Joseph Borp, who says he came from Providence, R.I., three days ago, was shot yesterday afternoon in front of a saloon at Monroe and Market Streets. He was taken to Gouverneur Hospital, where it was found that he was shot in the abdomen. Laparotomy was performed as a last effort to save his life.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Two men and a woman were seen shortly before midnight yesterday by people residing in the vicinity going toward the exposition grounds. As they neared a pond just outside the gates one of the men was heard to shout: "Throw her in!"

A decision has been given by the General Term of the Supreme Court modifying the judgment which was entered upon the report of William G. Choate, as referee in the proceedings for the settlement of the accounts of the executors of the estate of Paran Stevens.
The series of lectures by Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, given under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction, was resumed yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

Mr. Fawcett, perhaps, started out to draw the picture of a perfect man, morally, physically, intellectually perfect, and entirely uncontaminated by the evil influences of modern society. He has, however, simply pictured a rather amiable, but frequently inconsistent, boor, without much blood in his veins.

L.B. Stoddart of the St. Andrew's Golf Club won the amateur championship of America at golf yesterday on the links of the St. Andrew's Club at Gray Oaks, near Yonkers. The match was not decided until late in the afternoon, and then only after one of the closest games that golfers seldom have the opportunity of watching, even among acknowledged expert players.
There will be no move in the Staten Island Rapid-Transit fight until to-morrow. This decision was reached yesterday. Howard Carroll will not commence to run his boats till Monday night at least.

The situation of the Democratic Congressional canvass in the city districts is deplorable. It is not too much to say that to a Democrat who cares something for national principle as well as for local reform it is maddening.

The last notes of the song died away, the Singer's fingers still holding the chords of the finis. There was a moment's silence, then, "I wish I could paint that," said the Artist, drawing a deep breath.

On March 6, 1893, the Liverpool Overhead Railway was opened for traffic. This line now has a length of 6.4 miles of doubletrack running through the Liverpool Dock property, parallel with the river. In construction it is an elevated railroad, differing from the usual American practice, however, in that it has a solid iron floor, composed of steel troughs.

In high speeds, the United States seems just now to hold the world's record. Neither England nor any other country in the world has any trains as fast, for the distance, as the Empire State Express, which runs 440 miles at 50.7 miles an hour, including four stops, or as fast for the distance as the defunct Exposition Flyer of last Summer, which ran 964 miles at 48.2 miles an hour, including nine stops.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- The parallel between the Czar's last weeks or months on earth and the closing scenes in Emperor Frederick's life is extending itself in a truly remarkable way into all manner of details. We are evidently to have another unpleasant public squabble between two rival schools of medicine, into which is to be imported the added bitterness of hostile nationalities.

The uncertainty of the future of racing was in evidence at the sale of race horses in training held at Morris Park yesterday, before the races were run. Mr. Pierre Lorillard and McCafferty Wishard were the parties offering the racers. The bidding was slow and spiritless, and the prices obtained seemed absurdly low for the best of the offerings.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 13 -- In a pouring rain this afternoon, the Yale football team defeated the Lehigh University eleven at football by a score of 34 to 0. The grounds were wet and soggy, preventing fast running, and the hall was so slippery that accurate kicking was almost an impossibility.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- The market for local stocks was dull, even for dull times, and there were almost too few quotations to make a market. Boston and Albany was steady at 205, and Boston and Maine sold, ex-dividend, at 151. Mexican Central sold off 1/4, to 7 1/2. Erie Telephone was firm at 55 1/2.

Dr. Dana B. Hubbard, resident physician at Riverside Hospital for smallpox patients. North Brother Island, has been relieved of his charge and assigned to a place on the state of Dr. Doty of the Bureau of Contagious Diseases.

There are now in operation in London, says Mr. Parsons, three underground railways -- the Metropolitan, the Metropolitan District, and the City and South London -- while there are under construction the Waterloo and City Railway, and the Blackwall Tunnel. The latter, though not a railway, being for vehicles and pedestrians only, merits consideration on account of its size.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Rain fell here all the morning, and when play was called for the football game between Cornell and Lafayette it was still pouring steadily. The weather soon cleared, however, but the grounds were very slippery and the attendance small. The game began with the ball in Lafayette's possession. Their kick-off was returned by Dyer to Lafayette's thirty-yard line.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Without display or ostentation the Gould Memorial Church, at Roxbury, Delaware County, one of the prettiest villages in the Catskills, erected to the memory of Jay Gould and his wife by their children, was fittingly dedicated to-day. The services began at 11:45 o'clock.

The forms of diversion among the cycling clubs during the Winter period will be many and varied, but undoubtedly the most popular will be the bowling tournaments, which increase in favor of each succeeding year. Last Winter the sport was the topic of general conversation in the local wheeling circles, and the competition was of the most spirited nature.

Eighty-five years ago, on the 29th of last August, the Rev. Dr. Abiel Holmes, pastor of the Congregational Church of Cambridge, Masa., spent a very busy day. It was commencement at Harvard College, to begin with, and, as the good minister was a great student, and his house was almost under the shadow of the college buildings, he was naturally much interested in all the exercises that were going on.

During the Summer there has been an invasion of gnats, or mosquitoes, which the French call moustiques, or, more familiarly, cousins. The plague ceased for a time when colder weather set in, but the tantalizing insects have returned, with the Autumn, which has a tendency to beat. There is no means of escaping from the winged tormentors.

The bowling averages of the Metropolitan District Cricket League have been made up by the Secretary of the league, who had considerable difficulty in getting some of the reports from clubs to agree. The figures show J. West of the Paterson Club in the lead with an average of 5.91 lor thirty-seven wickets, while M.R. Cobb of the New-Jersey Athletic Club is not far behind with forty-seven wickets for 6.74 each.

Mrs. Ida Lieberman was committed to the Tombs yesterday on the charge of arson. The police claim that she is connected with the Gottlieb gang of incendiaries. An indictment has been standing against her since Jan. 26.

The energetic gentlemen who are at the head of operatic affairs in this city are looking forward to a very profitable season. The subscription is already far ahead of the figrures reached at this time last season, and that means that the managers are already assured of a large profit. That the season will be interesting is wholly beyond dispute.
At the time of the Revolution, and during the generation immediately succeeding it, religious indifference was common among the leading men in politics.
The Attorney General began proceedings yesterday against the Commercial Alliance Life Insurance Company of 253 Broadway, looking to the appointment of a receiver.

-- Orrin Hickok, owner of Directum, made a flying trip to New-York from Boston on Friday, arranging for the race between Directum and Alix. The second meeting of this pair of fliers may be in New-York or Baltimore. It is possible that a meeting may be arranged between Robert J. and John R. Gentry, the race to be at Fleetwood Park. There are some horsemen who believe Gentry can trot in 2:00.

The soldiers of the Revolution who lived in and near Tarrytown are to be honored by their descendants and others next Friday by the unveiling of a monument in their memory. This monument, which is already in position, stands in the old Sleepy Hollow Cemetery -- that famous burial place. The remains of Washington Irving are interred there, and his home, Sunnyside, is but a short distance below Tarrytown.

Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn has directed the police, to prevent any knock-outs or brutal exhibitions at the opening entertainment of the Atlantic Athletic Club, of which Justice E. Clarence Murphy is President. The club's first series of fights will take place to-morrow night in the Sea Beach Palace, Coney Island.

BERLIN, Oct. 13 -- The interior of the new Reichstag Building is far from finished, and the balls and corridors are in chaotic confusion. Every effort is making to get the Hall of Deputies in condition for the opening on Nov. 22, and the architects have made such promises as to induce the Ministers, at their meeting to-day, to decide in favor of assembling the members in the new quarters.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 13 -- At last the muchdiscussed new clubhouse and academy of the Orange Riding and Driving Club is fairly under way, and the foundation is now nearly completed, with a prospect that the entire structure will be finished and ready for use in a month or two. The site of the new building is in Halsted Street, East Orange, next to and just north of the Orange Athletic Club.
SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 13 -- An Autumn social entertainment was given at the Springfield Presbyterian Church Tuesday evening, by the Christian Endeavor Society.
The train of the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad which was robbed near Quantico, Va., Friday evening arrived in Jersey City, on the Pennsylvania Railroad, early yesterday morning.

Our English swan has long become a private possession, and one that in old times was highly prized. Great ecelesiastics, the Prior of Spalding or the Abbot of Petersborough, rivaled noble Earls, Huntingdon or Leicester or Essex, in the goodly flocks which they maintained upon the marsy flats of the eastern districts.

Every acre wrested from the desert by the magical mud and water of the Nile will be capable of producing a bale of cotton, superior enough to command a quick market, presumably to the exclusion of a bale of American-grown cotton, for Egypt is already out aggressive competitor in that important fibre.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 13 -- In the little mining village of Wyoming, six miles from here, Michael Paloski, a drunken Slav, last night ran anuck with a shotgun, killing one person, probably fatally wounding two others, and seriously wounding two more. The murderous Slav started a quarrel in a saloon with a man and was ordered out.

It would be easy to exaggerate the importance of the demonstration of friendly feeling between France and Switzerland, of which Macon has been for the last two days the theatre, but undoubtedly these fetes, in which an economic congress was the chief item, are highly interesting and even significant as a sign of the times.
The Woman's Municipal Purity Auxiliary, through its leader, Mrs. Josephine Shaw Lowell, announces that the following committees have been formed to carry on the work:

I beg to propose to-day one more change from the abhorrent class of pictures which, thanks to the industry of the committee of Senator Lexow, now invites the attention of the public of New-York. In its way it is surely one of the most surprising of all of that collection.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 13 -- The Rev. Dr. Minnigerode died here this afternoon. He had been seriously ill for some months, and his dearth had been expected daily.

Republicans who are disposed to vote for the unfair apportionment amendment of the Constitution because it promises a partisan advantage should remember that as a precedent it may sometime be turned against their party. It is like the "bloody instructions" that are apt to "return to plague the inventor."

In Paris the question of intramural rapid transit has been agitated continuously for the last twenty years without producing any tangibie results, so that, with the exception of a belt road running around the city just within the ramparts, travel through the streets is dependent on cabs, omnibuses, and tram cars.
The British steamer Ping Suey, which arrived yesterday morning from China with a cargo of tea, had in tow the dismasted schooner B. R. Woodside, which was disabled during Wednesday night's gale.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 24 -- On the 4th inst., eleven exiles from Bluefields, Mosquito Reserve, and Nicaragua reached Port Limon Costa Rica. They were sent by way of the Pacific and Puntas Arenas. Among them was Mr. E.D. Hatch, for eighteen months past Acting British Consul at Bluefields.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- [Copyright, 1894.] -- No change has taken place here in the condition of the money market. There has been a small export of gold, but supplies are still vastly excessive. Silver has declined on the pressure of sales from America. The fall is not likely to extend, as orders from India are probable.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 -- The two-masted schooner B.W. Bramble of Baltimore was capsized in Chesapeake Bay last night near Poplar Island while bound from Baltimore to the Patuxent River. Capt. P.A. Gatton and the crew of four men were thrown overboard. Seamen William Hooper and Frank Stewart, both colored, were drowned.
Thomas F. Bayard, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived on the Paris from Southampton yesterday. His two daughters and four grandchildren were with him. He looked remarkably well.
A Brooklyn member of the Junior Order of United American Mechanics said yesterday to a reporter for The New-York Times:
