Football on roller skates would have been about as unscientific and unsatisfactory as was the game played in the mud at Eastern Park yesterday by the wildly-enthusiastic elevens of the Crescent Athletic Club and Stevens Institute. The battle was not only fought in the mud, but in a drenching rain, which gave the turf the consistency of custard pie.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 13 -- Postmaster George has read the report made by Inspector Boynton concerning the Providence Post Office. He says that he is not posted in regard to anything which the Inspectors have done. They had free license to go and come when and where they pleased.

Erotic English "literature" is here further enriched by some account of the experiences and opinions of a creature, presumably of the masculine gender, who dresses himself in "the Soft lemon light" and admires himself in a mirror as he stands amid silver toilet articles and ivorywhite bowls filled with masses of gloire de Dijon roses.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 13 -- The season at Lakewood is now well begun, and little trace remains of the Summer's quiet about the village streets, which, with hotel guests and returned cottagers, have again the look of a popular resort. Lakewood air and Lakewood weather have done their share toward opening this season auspiciously.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- For the first time in twenty-eight years the Democrats of the Eighteenth Congressional District, including the Counties of Dutchess, Putnam, and Ulster, stand a reasonable show of electing a Congressman this Fall.

The fact is now dawning on the decent members of the so-called "regular" and "reorganized" Democracy of Kings County that the only way to get rid of James D. Bell and Hugh McLaughlin is to vote against and defeat the Bell-McLaughlin candidates for county and city offices and elect the men nominated by the Shepard Democracy.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 13 -- A concert for the benefit of the Town Improvement Association gathered a large and appreciative audience at the house of T.M. Conradt last evening. The artists were Miss Kathrin Hilke of New-York, soprano; Mrs. Anna Baylis Peck, accompanist; Arthur D. Woodruff, vocalist; Richard Arnold, violinist; Richard Hoffman, pianist; George E. Clander, violoncellist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Mgr. Satolll left the city this afternon tor Montreal, Canada, having been called there to act as arbitrator to settle the misunderstanding which has risen between Cardinal Taschereau, Metropolitan of Canada, and the civil authorities. He will also act in some troubles which have arisen between the Cardinal and his clergy.

An interesting feature of the Melba matinee yesterday was the first appearance of the young women of the new auxiliary chorus. They were disclosed to view when the curtain rose on the second act of Rossini's "Semiramide." They appeared as the handmaidens of the famous Queen, and it was their duty to simulate performance upon the ancient harp, and to weave garlands, while they sang the choral part of "Bel raggio."

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Le Journal to-day published a statement to the effect that the agents of the various powers will shortly hold a conference in Pekin with a view to securing the appointment of a Board of Mediation to arbitrate the China-Japanese trouble.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A curious pistol, of German invention, is exciting the wonder of military men. An army officer, recently in Germany, secured one of the pistols, only a very few of which have been manufactured, and has reported in very complimentary terms of the contrivance, which is known as the Borchardt automatic repeating pistol.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- The delegates to the twentieth annual convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union of Pennsylvania, which began yesterday in the Temple Baptist Church, were to-day addressed by Miss Frances Willard and Lady Somerset. The convention decided to have legislative candidates interviewed as to their standing on the temperance question, and to push the work of the Anti-Cigarette League in the public schools.

There is, I think, some evidence that, in the earliest times, the great centre of native civilization was in the Lebanon, and not in Southern Palestine. The Phoenicians had ports and fleets long before 1600 B.C. in this part. The Amorites lived in the Lebanon Mountains, and the Hittites held all the plains near the Orontes, from Kadesh to Aleppo and to Carchemish.

Among the amusing things in local politics is the talk that Police Justice Patrick Divver is going to resign the Tammany leadership of the Second Assembly District and turn over the management of the district to his old friend and comrade, Alderman Nicholas T. Brown.

An antediluvian spectacle was prepared for me in the stables of the Lord Mayor of London. In a vast courtyard an enormous carriage made of gold, to which was harnessed six magnificent brown horses; harness ornamented with massive copper chiseled by an artist, if not with taste at least with a great deal of care, and a multitude of ribbons and cockades of a cherry color.

The announcement from Paris that a conference of the representatives of the powers is to be held at Pekin is likely enough to be true. But the further announcement that the conference is to be held for the purpose of appointing "a board of arbitrators to settle the war between China and Japan" is not merely very improbable, but upon the face of it quite ridiculous.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Oct. 13 -- The Jeffersonian Democracy held its convention for the First Assembly District of Queens County, which is this city, in the City Hall to-day. Alderman at Large Benjamin Wingrove was Chairman and John F. Crowley Secretary.

Miss Maud Purdy, the twenty-year-old daughter of Dr. Charles D. Purdy of Franklin Avenue and Quincy Street, Brooklyn, and who is well known in society in that city, was seriously injured while riding a bicycle in Prospect Park Friday evening. She was taken home, and was unconscious most of yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- At the Democratic Convention for the Second Assembly District of Dutchess County, held in Poughkeepsie to-day, J. Watts De Peyster Toler of Red Hook was nominated for the Assembly.

You may have traveled over and ever again with the printed page through Hindustan, Burmah, China, Japan, and, in fact, the entire Orient, but never in better or more sprightly company than with Mrs. Miln. This lady is full of joyousness and good spirits; she has all the delightful womanly trails and the nearest ways of recording her adventures.

The twenty-ton armor plate which so successfully passed its official test on Oct. 6 is one of the largest ever tested at the Bethlehem firing ground. The plate was of nickel steel, 12 inches thick at the thickest part, and tapering to 6 inches at the thinnest edge. It was 18 feet 3 inches long and 6 feet 4 inches wide.

It was not a very exciting day at the Republican State Headquarters yesterday, although there were many visitors. Thomas B. Reed of Maine, the star orator at last night's meeting, was expected to call at headquarters, but he failed to do so.
One man loves his fiddle (or, alas! his neighbor's sometimes,) for all the melodies he can wake from it -- it is but a selfish love!

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 13 -- The Republican State Central Committee to-day made public an affidavit by T.L. Dixon and his wife, A.A. Dixon. Superintendent and Matron of the State Asylum for the Deaf and Dumb in Olathe, in which Mrs. Mary Lease, who was President of the State Board of Charities, is accused of advising them to steal from the State and give her a portion of the proceeds.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Mrs. Eugene V. Connett of Scotland Street, South Orange, gave a luncheon Tuesday in honor of the Misses Whittemore, who are to sail for Europe. Wednesday, Mrs. Robert Ward of Raymond Avenue, South Orange, gave a reception in honor of, the same young ladies.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, whose monthly visits to this city are attractive features of each musical season, will give its concerts this year in the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday evenings, Nov. 1, Dec. 6, Jan. 10, Feb. 7, and March 14. It enters upon its fourteenth year with a body of players that can hardly be equaled for individual ability, the result of constant selection and improvement in its membership since 1881.

This, the fourth volume of the Putnam edition of Jefferson, in their familiar and Beautiful series devoted to the Fathers of the Republic, embraces about three and a half years of Jefferson's life. Those year's were spent in France, where he was the diplomatic representative of his country. Among the papers printed the greater number by far are letters to Madison, Monroe, Patrick Henry, Greene, John Adams, Washington, Jay, and others.

Somebody has taken the pains to put together in The Chicago Tribune the places where women have whole or partial suffrage. Taken all in all, it will be seen that they cut quite a figure in the world's politics.
A member of the New-York State Democracy, when asked yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times as to the right of that organiaztion to file certificates of nomination, said:

The Manhattan Bicycle Club will hold a meeting at 1,556 Broadway to-morrow evening. The bowling club meets Tuesday nights at the alleys northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-second Street. Club runs arranged are: To-day -- A new run, riding via Rye, White Plains, Elmsford, and along the Hudson River back to New-York. Leave club at 8:20 A.M.

-- Tony Pastor's -- Fulgora, a lightning change performer of quite a new sort, will make his metropolitan appearance at Tony Pastor's to-morrow night. All Fulgora's changes are made in view of the audience, and his manner of transforming himself is said to be puzzling to people not in his secret. Entering in ordinary attire, he rapidly changes to drum major, policeman, and Irish market woman.

Camden, N.J., Oct. 13 -- Two murderers were sentenced by Judge Garrison this morning. One was Dory Lambert, the burglar who shot and killed Baker Kairer last December. He is to be handed Dec. 13. The other was Thomas Delbridge, an Englishman, who shot and killed Georgiana Spearman, a mulatto, at the Winslow Inn in August.

BELMAR, N. J., Oct. 13. -- Forman Brand of Avon-by-the-Sea, who was formerly a member of the Shark River Life-Saving Station, is the hero of the hour as the result of his rescue of Superintendent F.W. Houghton of the New-York Maratime Exchange and his son and daughter from drowning.

It is to be feared that the county fair throughout New-England and the Middle States is in a condition of progressive degeneration. Time was when the strictest of Deacons in the most settled of rural communities abated in favor of the county fair his general opposition to carnal pleasures.

There was a general air of subdued festivity about the old Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, in Wythe Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday. The church and the Rev. Sylvester Malone, its pastor, are celebrating their golden jubilee together.

HUNTINGBURG, Ind., Oct. 13 -- The train bearing ex-President Benjamin Harrison arrived here at 11 o'clock to-day. The fact that it was the thirteenth day of the month and that the locomotive drawing the special was No. 13 at first caused apprehension, but the sun came out bright and warm, and the bad omen was soon forgotten.
As a day school for boys, Stevens School, at Hoboken, N.J., is gaining a wide reputation. The Rev. Edward Wall is Principal.

Tammany men are still discussing the details of the nomination of Nathan Straus for Mayor. In doing this they do not necessarily go into the question as to whether their candidate will be able to win, but they are interested in the matter because of its probable effects upon the immediate future of the Tammany Hall organization itself.

The audience that heard Representative Thomas B. Reed's speech in Cooper union last night was limited only by the capacity of the hall. There were hundreds who were unable to gain admission to the meeting, held under the auspices of the Republican County Committee and addressed by the Maine statesman.

Pomona's daughter, having grown to be a great girl, goes one Summer to visit her grandmother, and Pomona takes that opportunity to maKe a trip abroad with Jonas. In her Absence she frequently writes to the lady whom we knew in the "Rudder Grange" days, as Euphemia, and her letters, divested of superfluous details, form one of the most delightful books Mr. Stockton has ever written.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 13 -- By another lightning change in the weather the rain-soaked course at the fair grounds dried rapidly this forenoon, and the breeders meeting was finished on time. It was much too cold for fast performances, but about 25,000 persons came to see the last of the harness races and there was plenty of room for speculation.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 13 -- The Govern ment of Quebec has rescinded the order of Aug. 16, fixing the rate of dues on spruce logs for paper pulp out on Crown lands in that Province at 40 cents a cord, but allowing a reduction of 15 cents a cord when the pulp wood is manufactured in the Province. The fifteen-cent rebate has been abolished and a uniform rate of 40 cents a cord imposed.

The resources of the English language were quite inadequate to express the social standing of those who were so fortunate as to attend the ball in honor of the presence of the Princess of Hungary in the city. The newspapers, in describing it, scintillated with italics, and such terms as "elite," "bonton." and "le beau monde" were as prevalent as in a milliner's shop.

Upon the site occupied for so many years by the New-York Hotel, at Broadway, Mercer Street, and Waverley and Washington Places, will be built great structures devoted to business. These are shown in the accompanying illustration, which, however, fails to give the variations in color that will serve to aid the division lines in making the buildings distinct.

In Glasgow there is one underground railway in operation and two more, besides a roadway tunnel beneath the Clyde, under construction, all of which present interesting and instructive features. The Glasgow City and District Railway obtained its Parliamentary powers in 1882, being projected to connect two lines of the North British Railway, so that certain of its trains could be run through the city.

At the beginning of the last century the only church bell at Grosslaswitz, Germany, was so small that its tones were not sufficient to penetrate to the ends of the village. A second bell was badly wanted, but the village was poor, and where was the money to come from?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Princeton football team arrived bore this afternoon, but refused, on account of the wet condition of the grounds, to play the game scheduled with the Columbia Athletic Club, and left immediately for Baltimore.

Cattle aria sheep men are scouring over the country in all directions, looking for Fall and Winter feeding grounds, for their herds. The usual Fall movement has been delayed by the destruction of ranges and crops in Kansas and Nebraska, and it is a serious problem with many stock owners as to what disposition they will make of their property.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The cadets met their first defeat this season on the plains to-day. The Brown University team played havoc with the soldiers, and gave them valuable points on interfering and tackling. Coach Graves was a quiet spectator, and made mental notes of the new and numerous tricks displayed by the visitors.

Among the desirable apartment houses in this city is the Clifford, on the southeast corner of One Hundred and Nineteenth Street and Seventh Avenue Boulevard. The location is of the best. It is on a broad thoroughfare, which is as much frequented by the owners of fine horses and handsome establishments as are the driveways of the Park.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Pennsylvania football cracks downed the Georgetown College eleven hard to-day at football, by a score of 46 to 0, in an interesting game, played throughout with the rain pouring down in torrents. In every department of the play the Quaker lads showed improvement which promises well for the future. The line to-day did much better work than at any time this season.
The often-mentioned bluet is a cornflower blue, which, it must be remembered, is a blue with tones of purple in it.

At Bourne, in Lincolnshire, at a depth of sixty-six feet, water impregnated with iron was encountered, but this chalybeate liquid was excluded as the tubes were carried deeper. Some twelve feet lower the main spring was tapped, and the water rose very slowly up the tube, and it was twenty-four hours before the water overflowed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- A determined effort was made at the opening to hammer the railroad list by offering large lots of West Chicago and Alley L. The attack had no effect upon Alley L, but West Chicago was forced down 3/4. All the offers were taken so readily that a reaction set in directly the offerings ceased.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- Attorney General Hancock, after having heard long and bitter arguments to-day in the case of Oscar Hammerstein against Koster Bial, rendered a decision this evening against Hammerstein, who sought to have the Attorney General bring an action to remove Messrs. Koster and Bial as two of the Directors of the Koster Bial Company of New-York City, Mr. Hammerstein being the only other Director.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- The market has been surprisingly strong for a short day. No stock was active, but the buying orders seemed to predominate. The late decline in the traction stocks seemed to have cleaned up the market, and they all looked much healthier than for some time. The buying has assumed a decidedly less speculative tone.

John W. Goff has not yet conducted the investigation of the Lexow committee by proclamation of his intentions in advance, nor has he inspired any forecast of the plan of campaign against municipal iniquity. Excellent reasons have dictated and will compel a policy of absolute secrecy in these matters.

There is no country in the world which has a more salubrious climate than the coast country of Georgia and South Carolina. Its average temperature is 66, approximating that of Bermuda, Gibraltar, Sicily, and Shanghai. The weather is usually clear. The Summer comprehends more than half the year, a mild Winter embracing the other half, in which there are not a dozen days when an overcoat is necessary.

The annual meeting of the Cosmopolitan Football Club was held at the Cricketers' Club on Friday night, when officers were elected and a general plan of campaign for the ensuing season laid out. The club expects to secure the use of the grounds of the Staten Island Athletic Club at West New-Brighton, and a large schedule will be adopted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Argument was continued to-day before Judge Cole, in Criminal Court, No. 2, on the demurrer to the indictments returned against John J. McCartney and Elverton R. Chapman, the stock brokers who refused to answer questions asked them by the Sugar Trust investigation committee of the Senate.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The Republicans of the Twenty-second Congressional District are likely to see some fun. The dead-locked convention adjourned at 12:25 A.M. to-day. After one faction had left the hall the other nominated Gen. W.B. French.

A dispatch from Boston yesterday said, the new Atchison board has already secured, outside of all promises, proxies for 441,000 shares. The Proxy Committee of the board says the proxies promised to it by parties of the highest business standing amount to close upon 125,000 more. The total number of shares is 1,020,000, and the highest number of votes ever cast at an election was about 750,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 13 -- An old frame house standing on the northwest corner of Clinton Avenue and Monmouth Street, probably the oldest building in that part of the city, is to give place to a handsome structure for the Sherman Avenue Baptist Church. Exactly how old the present wooden building is no one seems to know, but there are documents and incidents to show that it is at least 130 years of age.

PARIS, Ky., Oct. 13 -- The Rev. Charles T. Thompson, pastor of Mount Horeb Presbyterian Church, in Fayette County, read publicly last Sunday the action of the church concerning Col. W.C.P. Breckinridge, who had made to them a confession of his guilt, and asked the prayers and love of his brethren in leading a Christian life.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 13 -- Many of the guests of the cottagers who came up last week especially to attend the Cumnock-Cutting wedding have returned to town. All the cottagers who own places here are still in Lenox. The season will be later than it has ever been before.

Velhdovi is the patron saint. Perhaps tutelary deity would be a better term, for Velhdovi could not have been called, even in these days of broad-minded tolerance, anything of a Christian, and it is more than fifty years since his stern features, wearing the sombre expression of their last repose, were immortalized in bronze.

FOUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Dear to the heart of every Vassar girt is her "Memorabilia," that heterogeneous record of her college existence from beginning to end Every Vassar student keeps one, and each one varies according to the individuality of the owner. If you wish to get the atmosphere of Vassar life, you cannot find a better source that a halt dozen of these memorabilias, with a Vassar girl to explain them.
"If these Eastern people want gold, we will give them gold till they are sick of it."

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 13 -- Amherst beat Troy Technology Institute on Pratt Field to-day 16 to 0. The game was entirely void of good plays and long runs, as it was played in a pouring rain. Amherst scored twice in the first half on daring short dashes through the centre, and long runs around the ends by Converse and Johnston. In the second half Technology braced and allowed Amherst to score but once.

Olga Nethersole begins her American tour at Palmer's Theatre to-morrow night, presenting for the first time in this country a play called "The Transgressor," the work of A.W. Gattie, which had its first production Jan. 27 last at the Court Theatre in London.

REDDING, Conn., Oct. 13 -- Daniel B. Perry of Easton and Mrs. Arthur Sherwood of this place visited the Danbury Fair last week Friday and have not since returned. They were traced to Poughkeepsie, where all clues were lost.
Police Inspector Williams began an investigation yesterday into the alleged clubbing of the striking cloakmakers by the police in Rutgers Place on Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The statement was made to-day at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing that fie reports concerning the recent stamp robbery at the bureau have been largely overdrawn, and that not more than 100,000 stamps were appropriated by William B. Smith and George W. Longstreet, the employes in the stamp department who are now under arrest.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- First Sergt. Edward L. Shuler of Company A. Fifteenth United States Infantry, who was shot at Fort Porter yesterday by Sergt. Thomas Marriott, died early this morning.

Miss Frances Willard will spend the Win- ter attending temperance conventions, making her headquarters in Boston. Her friend, Lady Somerset, has taken apartments in that city to be near her son, Who will attend lectures at Harvard University, and this fact influences Miss Willard's choice of a Winter residence.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 13 -- Col. John M. Chivington, the hero of the famous Sand Creek massacre, is dead. For over nine months the old soldier had been an invalid. Col. Chivington was born in Warren County, Ohio, in 1821. His father was an Irishman, and his mother came from one of the old Virginia families.

The English Statesman's Year Book classifies Madagascar under France. The colony begun to be of commercial importance to Europe about the year 1810, when Radama I. reduced a large part of the island to the sway of the sovereigns of the Hova the most advanced, according to modern ideas, but not the most numerous, of the Madagascar races.

VIENNA. Oct. 13 -- The second evening of the Strauss Jubilee was celebrated at the Imperial Opera with the production of "Round Vienna," a new ballet. The curtain rose first on a magnificent tableau, designed in honor of the composer.

Count out Sugar and Chicago Gas, and the market during the past week would be reduced almost to nothingness. Furthermore, although Gas came second in point of activity, it was far behind its, leader. Transactions in Sugar were so large, comparatively, as to distance every other stock on the list.

Almost every one in Hyderabad is armed to the teeth, and the spcars, sabres, daggers and pistols, which gleam amid the white and crimson robes, or bristle in sash and turban, convert the entire city into a formidable armory. Bazaars filled with deadly weapons brighten dim alley and moldering arcade with the polished steel and burnished brass of a hundred unfamiliar native instruments of attack and defense.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 13 -- The congregation of Christ First Presbyterian Church will commence to-morrow a three days' celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of its organization. It was the first Presbyterian body in this country.

The Hon. Henry L. Pierce of Boston has resigned the Presidency of the New-England Tariff Reform League, and Henry W. Lamb, one of the most active members of the league, has been elected to fill the vacancy. Following is Mr. Pierce's letter:

The most remarkable double-century road race ever run against Old Father Time took place on Friday over the Elizabeth-Rahway course. R.P. Searle beat the old gentleman very handily, taking 38 minutes oft the record, which was made by Steimal of Buffalo. Searle's time for the 200 miles was 12:44:45. In this grand fight Searle also clipped a couple of seconds from the one-hundred-mile mark, his time being 5:33:00.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- This was a notable day in Batavia. Never was such a gathering seen in this village. Nearly all the members of President Cleveland's Cabinet arrived this morning. Other prominent men here were Lieut. Gov. Sheehan and Daniel N. Lockwood, the Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Capt. Montague Martin, late of Her Majesty's Army, came here last night to outdo the alleged feats of "Steve" Brodie, by jumping from the Poughkeepsie Bridge at daylight this morning. This is the story of how he did not do it:

The French yachtsmen have issued the programme for the Cannes carnival, which is to be held next Spring. The carnival last Spring wag a very successful one, but next year's promises to furnish much better sport than when the Britannia won all the big prizes. The programme is as follows:

The coming election will illustrate again the clumsiness of our present method of voting in comparison with the simplicity of the blanket ballot. Every voter will receive in his polling place at least five different ballots, each bearing the names of candidates for all the offices to be filled, and perhaps more than five.

-- Prudent and generous art lovers, who do not wait to accord their admiration to a good artist until after glory has irrevocably consecrated him, may observe the distinctive merit of Mr. W.J. Baer as a painter of miniatures. He is an American, a pupil of the Munich School, and is held in much esteem as a teacher.
At the session of the Executive Committee of the State Democracy, or Empire State Democrats, at the Cooper Union yesterday afternoon, much business relating to campaign details was disposed of.
Any person who doesn't believe that a pot of printer's ink is better than the greatest geld mine ever discovered should have accompanied an inquisitive reporter to Delmonico's last week.
John W. Goff accepts the nomination for the office of Recorder by the anti-Tammany organizations and the Committee of Seventy in this terse and characteristic letter:

It is probable that the majority of the people in Pompell escaped, though some may have been killed afterward from, another catastrophe, for on the banks of the Sarno, not far from the city, many skeletons were exhumed in 1880-81. The Doric temple is the oldest building in Pompell, and it belongs to the sixth century before Christ.
The sales referred to in the accompanying list will be held at 111 Broadway except as otherwise stated:

The English criminal bar is apt to tempt the impecunious and indolent. It is setting rather overstocked. Most students are one or the other, and many both. Weird stories come from the Old Bailey of crowds of "jejuniors" who settle on the soup list like the locusts of the East. Success, undoubtedly, comes quicker, if at all.

-- The Providence and Stonington Steamship Company announces that its passenger service will be reduced for the Winter after Oct. 15 by the withdrawal of the Providence Line. The Stonington Line, the inside and best Winter route to Boston and points east, will run throughout the year with the new steel steamers Maine and New-Hampshire in commission, leaving new Pier 36 North River, one block above Canal Street, at 6 P.M., daily, except Sunday.

As far as brigandage is concerned, most of Greece is as safe as Piccadilly and much more respectable. Since the affair at Pikermi, on the road to Marathon, in 1871, Attica has been perfectly secure, and the Peloponnese and the isthmus have completely lost their traditional terrors. But Thessaly and the Turkish frontier are still dangerous.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13 -- The Harvard game with the Orange Athletic Association took place to-day in the midst of a heavy rainstorm. The halves were each twenty minutes long. The game was called at 2:45 with Orange in possession of the ball. The kick-off resulted in a fumble by Charlie Brewer, with a quick recovery, a run of 83 yards, and a touch-down, from which goal was kicked.

The Naval and Military Record (British) of Sept. 27 publishes interesting interviews with Capt. Mahan of the United States war ship Chicago and Capt. Lord Charles Beresford, in command of the Chatham Dockyard Reserve, on the lessons to be learned from the naval battle between the Chinese and Japanese squadrons in the Yalu River.

Mr. John Sherman began a series of campaign speeches in Ohio last Friday evening, and we suspect that Mr. McKinley will not find much to comfort and encourage him in the Senator's remarks about the tariff. "I am not now and never was," said Mr. Sherman, "an extreme protectionist."
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The Central News correspondent in Shanghai cabled this afternoon:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The first social event of the college year was the reception given by the Young Women's Christian Association to the new-comers. The 500 students were received in the college parlors by the President of the association, Miss Sue Hoagland, '95, of Brooklyn, and by Dr. Taylor, Mrs. Taylor, and Mrs. Kendrick.

The French steamship La Champagne, that arrived yesterday from Havre, had some experience with the storm that raged in this coast Wednesday. After leaving Havre, La Champagne had mild weather and moderate seas until Wednesday, when she was struck by the edge of the gale. This made it generally unpleasant, and most of the passengers had to remain below, but no damage was done to any part of the vessel.

The Executive Committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen took an important step Saturday evening at the regular meeting, held at the Hotel Marlborough, by deciding to enter into an agreement with the Union des Societes Francaises de Sports Athletiques. The agreement makes the members of either association eligible to compete in the sports given under the auspices of the other.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- In the registration Saturday, 6,215 names were enrolled in this city, making a total of 18,163 for the three days, as against 17,041 for the three days last year, an increase this year of 1,122.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14 -- The number of members enrolled in the university is still unde- termined, for new men are admitted every day, especially to the graduate and professional schools. The Secretary of the Lawrence Scientific School has however, made an announcement which shows a promising growth in his depart- meat.

Representatives of sixty-three leading cloak and clothing manufacturing firms met in the parlors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday to formulate a plan of action in opposition to the labor organizations, whose strikes, the manufacturers say, have so seriously affected the business of the clothing trade during the last few weeks that employers have been obliged, for the first time, to take organized action to protect their interests.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- At a meeting of its Directors last night, the Washington Park Club decided to abandon Its racing feature, and in conformity with this resolution the club's resignation from the Turf Congress was prepared and forwarded to the Secretary. The reasons for abandoning this feature are based, it Is said, upon the popular clamor against poolselling and the degeneration of racing from a harmless and high-class sport to a species of gambling.

Some unusual visitors came to the Fifth Avenue Hotel to see ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt last evening. They mingled with the throng of politicians, leaned against a Corinthian pillar, and discussed the political situation in the Seventh Congressional District, whence they came. Like so many others who come to see Mr. Platt, they wanted to enlist the sympathies of the ex-Senator in a political enterprise.

John Rowls, a young colored man who lives at 26 Minetta Lane, was brought before Justice Voorhis, in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday, charged by Policeman John H. Conron of the Fifteenth Precinct with being drunk and disorderly. Conron said he found Rowls on the street at 2 o'clock yesterday morning trying to get into a saloon.
Two sales at auction of real estate are set down for to-day. The first of these given herewith will be had at 111 Broadway, and the other at 59 Liberty Street.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -- Prof. William C. Robinson and Justice Simeon E. Baldwin of the Connecticut Supreme Court to-night discussed "The Mutual Relations of the Roman Catholic and Protestant Churches." The professor's argument was altogether on the lines of his paper, read before the Universalist Convention, at Saratoga, a few weeks ago.

William J. Graynor, aged thirty years, or 297 Elizabeth Street, jumped from a thirdfloor window, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning, taking the glass and part of the sash with him. He was crazed by drink. His skull was broken, and he died at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday afternoon.

The Louisiana, a passenger and freight steamer belonging to the Cromwell Steamship Company, has been in the care of Horace See, Superintendent of the company, and the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company since June 15.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Prof. W.T. Hewett of the German department is engaged on a history of Cornell University from the time when the proposal to found the institution was first made down to the present time.

Next to the apportionment section, the constitutional amendment that will be most stoutly fought is that prohibiting poolselling, bookmaking, and gambling. This prohibition is inserted in Section 9, Article I., of the Constitution. Following other prohibitions of the present Constitution, it is declared that "the sale of lottery tickets, poolselling, bookmaking, or any other kind of gambling" shall not "hereafter be authorized or allowed within this State."
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at an average of 1 per cent. throughout the week. The rate at banks and trust companies was the same.

NEW-HAVEN, Coan., Oct. 14 -- A very important and hovel change in the course of study at the university is the system of debates which Prof. Hadley has adopted in his branch of political economy. The idea is taken partly from Harvard, where Prof. Hadley has made a careful study of the method, but while the Harvard sys- tem is co-operative in character, that at Yale will be competitive.

Most man who have had occasion to utilize libraries for purposes of reference are aware that two books imperatively require concordances. These are the Bible and Shakespeare. Naturally enough, the former led the way in the matter of concordances; for, according to a note in Rock's "Church of Our Fathers," in 1378 Thomas de Farnylaur, Canon of York Cathedral, left a Bible and concordance to be put in the north alsle of St. Nicholas's, Newcastle.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Aisociated Banks, issued on Saturday, snowed-an increase in reserve of $1,396,375. The banks now hold $60,847,325 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $109000, an increase in specie of $675,800, an increase in legal tenders of $1,050,000, an increase in deposits of $1,317,700, and an increase in circulation of $411,700.

We regret that ex-Speaker Reed did not find it convenient to discuss bimetallism in his Cooper Union speech on Saturday evening. The Republican financiers of this city would be glad to have some further exposition of his plan for compelling England by hostile tariff enactments to come into an international bimetallic arrangement.
Neither after closing time Saturday night nor all day yesterday was great difficulty experienced in procuring excise refreshments in any part of this city.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- Richard M. Grlffin, better known as "Governor" Griffin, from the fact that he once ran for Governor on the Greenback ticket, is eighty years old to-day. He is the oldest active newspaper man in Albany, covering Police Headquarters for The Evening Post.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- There is reason to suppose that the leader of the gang which perpetrated the bold train robbery it Acquia Creek, Va., on Friday night, has seen identified. He is thought to be George Carter, a former resident of the neighborhood, an ex-convict of Sing Sing, a railroad engineer, and a man who has been associated with many scenes of robbery and bloodshed.

-- The Messrs, Appleton will soon issue another volume in that charming series of foreign classics in which have appeared "Colette," "Picciola," and "An Attic Philosopher in Paris." It is "Paul and Virginia," illustrated by Maurice Leloir.

All Williamsburg turned out yesterday to honor the Rev. Sylvester Malone and to make the celebration of his golden jubilee as priest and pastor of the Church of St. Peter and St. Paul a gala occasion.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14 -- In spite of the ill-luck which has attended the Harvard football team, the men have not lost courage, and propose to keep steadily at work with an eye upon the long-desired victory over Yale. The scoring of four points by Brown in the game of last Thursday was a disaster almost equal to defeat, but has resulted in what may work victory for the team.

Georgia Cayvan, the leading woman of the Lyceum Theatre Company, was very busy preparing to start with the organization for Boston when a reporter for The New-York Times saw her yesterday in her pleasant home in West One Hundred and Twenty-second Street. She found time, however, to clear up many points regarding her com- ing starring tour, about which so many misleading stories have been printed.

Because she believed that her acquaintances were spreading evil reports about her. Miss Sarah Trainor, a comely girl twenty-three years old, who lived with her uncle. James Trainor, at 436 East Thirteenth Street, threw herself, at 1 o'clock Sunday morning, from a fourth-floor window, and was picked up in a dying condition.

There is every indication that to-day the Staten Island Ferry war will be formally opened. Controller Fitch and the counsel for Howard Carroll and the syndicate that he represents have declared that the terms of the lease have been satisfactorily adjusted, and the actual execution of the lease is expected to take place this morning.

Mrs. Outen, who lives at 312 West Fourth Street and lets furnished rooms, prefers to have her house filled with sulphur fumes rather than with undesirable tenants. At any rate, she can stand sulphur better than she can some lodgers.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Ninety-five seniors met Tuesday in the old chapel and formally declared in favor of wearing the academic cap and gown. A committee, with L. Fred Pease as Chairman, was appointed to canvass the class and secure the costumes. The whole class will appear each Sunday throughout the year, when the weather permits, and on all formal occasions, attired in the regulation dress.

Politicians of all shades of opinion were not numerous about their headquarters yesterday, but all the rooms were open for a portion of the day, at least. The various organizations which have tickets in the field, and have not yet established the places from which they will manage their campaigns, will locate themselves early this week, and by the middle of the week all will be running at full blast.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The Cabinet party consisting of Secretaries Gresham, Carlisle, Lamont, Smith, and Herbert, First Assistant Postmaster General Jones, Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Maxwell, Mrs. Carlisle, Mrs. Gresham, Mrs. Lamont, Mrs. Smith, Mrs. Thurber, and Mrs. Micon, spent the early part of the day in visiting the various attractive spots about the Falls, under the escort of Superintendent T.V. Welch of the State Reservation.
Oliver Summer Teall has again triumphed over great difficulties. At least, he thinks be has.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 13 -- The local money situation shows no change worth mentioning from that of a week ago. The demand has not bettered to speak of, and rates at discount windows are the same, although the supply has been augmented somewhat.

Stock speculation last week, outside of a few specialties, was narrow and almost wholly professional. The Grangers led the railway list in point of activity, the only other stocks which were at all prominent being Louisville and Nashville, Reading, Richmond Terminal, and Atchison. Of these Reading scored the greatest decline -- 1 7/8 points.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 14 -- A complete story of how the Gibbs murder was committed was told by Bert Snyder, a prisoner at the County Jail, in this city, who, with Robinson and his wife, is suspected of the murder. The story was told to Snyder by Robinson himself, so Snyder says, Snyder's statement is as follows:

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- A Vienna physician, who is said to be in the confidence of the Czar's physicians says that at present their diagnosis wavers between cancer of the kidneys and inflammation of the kidneys. All agree that the Czar's decline will be neither sudden nor rapid.

After a lot of skirmishing, the queen of trotters and Directum are to meet and decide the vexed question of their relative merits. There is not even a remote possibility that either Alix or Directum will approach the records they have made elsewhere, when they settle their dispute at Boston next Saturday.
CONEY ISLAND, Oct. 14 -- A drowning accident, the terrible details of which will probably never be forgotten by those who witnessed it, occurred off Coney Island Point about 1 o'clock this afternoon.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- Whatever may be the outcome of the present disagreement between the Yale and Princeton football managements on the questions of time and place for the annual championship game, there is little doubt but that a game will be played.

The old heads in politics declare that Senator Hill's canvass is making visible progress every day and Mr. Morton's no progress at all. The Republican managers may have a plan of campaign, but if so it is subterranean and as yet shows no fruit. Not a single vote has been gained for Morton by any affirmative act of his or as his managers.

A well-dressed man was found lying unconscious on the sidewalk at the corner of Forty-fourth Street and Third Avenue at 10:45 o'clock last night. From papers found in his pockets he is thought to be Adam Wagner. At the Flower Hospital the doctors discovered that his skull was fractured. The man had not been robbed. His recovery is thought to be doubtful.

-- The American Agriculturist, which for more than half a century has been a valuable monthly publication, has recently entered upon its fifty-fourth volume, and, being changed to a weekly, will henceforth be issued in special editions for the Middle, Central, Western, Eastern, and Southern States.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 14. -- One of the worst railroad wrecks in the history of Louisiana was narrowly averted to-day. As it is, about fifteen persons were more or less injured and $40,000 worth of railroad property was destroyed. The wreck was at the junction of the Louisville and Nashville and the New-Orleans and Northeastern tracks, about two miles from the city, and occurred just before 8:30 o'clock.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Oct. 14 -- The rain of yesterday did not prevent the Rockaway Hunt Club of this place having a run over wet fields and slippery roads. The meet started from Frederick Schenck's farm, midway between Hewletts and East Rockaway. Owing to the rain, the trail was several times lost, but after a little skillful manoeuvring the scent was found and the chase resumed.

The arrangement recently made by Secretary Herbert for the Naval Observatory seems after full consideration to have been a judicious compromise between opposing views and interests. Astronomers and other scientific men in the country have long been earnest in their efforts to place the institution under civilian control, believing that this would insure better results.

The Governor of the State of Alabama, United States, ought to be grateful to the Anti-Lynchlng Committee of London, England, (address, care of Mrs. Clayden, 13 Tavistock Square.) That estimable, but not yet world-famous, body has given him a rare opportunity of vindicating the institutions of Alabama, and the enlightenment of her citizens.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 14 -- Belgium's first Parliamentary election with, universal suffrage was held to-day. The weather has been rainy and raw, and the voting has been slow. As the bulk of the votes was cast late, the returns have come in tardily, although the polls were closed about the middle of the afternoon.

RHINEBECK, Oct. 14 -- It has dawned on some of the inhabitants of this little town that just as certain as the blue waters of the Hudson flow past them and find their outlet in the big ocean somewhere down near Manhattan Island, so does the stream from the Morton "barrel" flow away from them to that place, to them indefinite, called "Platt's headquarters."

The People's Party had a meeting last night at 50 East Tenth Street, at which remarks were made by John Swinton and Thaddeus B. Wakeman. Most of Mr. Swinton's speech was devoted to the police, and of them he said:

Athletes of the Twenty-third Street Young Men's Christian Association are paying more attention to football this season than ever before. Dr. J.H. McCurdy, the physical director, says that the team is in better shape and more men are practicing the game than has been the case in any previous year in the history of the association.

Two leopard cubs, a male and a female, were born yesterday afternoon at the Hagenbeck Trained Animal Menagerie, Madison Square Garden. The mother, the Indian leopardess La Tosca, takes part in the pyramid. She appeared on Saturday afternoon and evening, and will probably be on hand to-day, but yesterday afternoon and last evening she staid quietly in the back part of her cage, watching her offspring.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- There has been a conference of the pottery manufacturers of the United States, and the result shows a marked improvement in the business and a general admission that the new tariff law will not affect the industry so injuriously as was at first supposed.

AURORA, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- A lively interest is being manifested this Fall in the Boat Club. The membership is much larger than usual, and it is the desire of the club to build a new boathouse and to add to the number of boats. To raise money for this purpose an entertainment is now in preparation.

It is only by slow degrees that we are making acquaintance with the manners and customs of microbes. A new and very important discovery has just been made in regard to that eminent microbe the comma bacillus. Hitherto it has been supposed that the comma bacillus has had the sole charge of cholera.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- The local security market this week was fairly active. There were a good many more than the average number of fluctuations in prices, and a majority of them were toward a higher level. Albany Railway was the most active Stock, and it scored a net gain of 1 per cent., to 116 1/2 bid, and 117 1/2 asked.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 14. -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Cincinnati, New-Orleans and Texas Pacific Railway Company, to be held at the general offices here to-morrow, there will be two tickets for Directors in the field.
The oath of the American Protective Association was read last night in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Lyman Abbott, and, in commenting on it, he said:

The Broadway Theatre last evening was the garden spot of that interesting species of population known as the baseball rooter. He was there in all the glory of fine clothes to pay tribute to "Johnny" Ward and his Giants for their success in flooring the proud Baltimores for the Temple Cup. The house was crowded from pit to dome, aud in every way the testimonial benefit was a big success.
-- Johnson Intends to do some skating this Winter. After he get through breaking records at Waltham, he will go to Minneapolis to get into first-class condition.

BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- The programme of the Social Democratic Congress, which will meet in Frankfort one week from to-day, shows that the leaders are wide awake to the political issues of the coming Winter. The last developments of the agrarian movement will occupy much of the delegates' attention.

In the coming election the constitutional amendments will be submitted on five ballots, and the State will provide ten ballots, five for and five against each lot of amendments. There will be separate boxes for each of these ballots.

New enemies of the constitutional amendments spring up every day, and every day they grow more determined and aggressive. If they continue in their present temper, and organize their opposition with reasonable care and skill, they will surely defeat the whole batch.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 15 -- On a very fast track the Circuit harness racers began thier engagements at Cumberland Park this afternoon. The attendance was light, though the weather was mild and clear and the card an attractive one. The slow class for trotters began with New -castle a favorite, but Sally Simmons tripped off In the lead for two heats, reducing her record to 2:13 1/2 in the first mile.

John Connolly, who is the Democratic candidate for Congress in the Fourteenth Congressional District, has received a letter from John D. Crimmins congratulating him on his nomination and assuring him of his heartiest support and assistance in the campaign. The story that Mr. Crimmins himself was a candidate for this nomination has no foundation.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 15 -- The National Administration is with Senator Hill in his candidacy for the Governorship, regardless of the fact that President Cleveland has made no formal declaration in the matter.

The headquarters of the State Campaign Committee which has charge of the canvass of Everett P. Wheeler for Governor was very busy all day yesterday examining and classifying the nomination certificates. One thousand of these were taken to Albany by a representative of the committee on the 8:30 express, and were duly filed at the office of the Secretary of State.

The indications are that Police Captain Max F. Schmittberger of the Tenderloin precinct, who was accused before the Lexow committee of receiving money from the agent of the French Steamship Line, while he was in command of the steamboat squad, will be placed on trial soon before the Police Commissioners.

The beginning of the end of the most spirited election ever known in the New-York Division takes place to-day, when to every member of the League of American Wheelmen in the Empire State will be sent a ballot containing the names of the gentlemen comprising the two tickets in the field.

-- Miss Marguerite ?Moore's Wedding -- St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church will be the scene of an interesting wedding next Saturday afternoon at 4:30 o'clock, when Miss Marguerite Moore, daughter of the late V. Mumlord Moore, will be married to Benjamin Franklin Cross of Livingston, S.I. The Rev. Dr. J.W. Brown, rector of St. Thomas's, will officiate.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 15 -- While being finally groomed for the official trial of her engines, the new battleship Maine, at anchor off the Pequot House, makes a striking central figure in the marine view at the entrance to this harbor. The four hours' horse-power test will probably be made on Wednesday.

There was a meeting of the Greater New-York Commission yesterday afternoon at 214 Broadway. The following Commissioners were present: Andrew H. Green, who is President of the commission: T.W. Devoe, J.J. Greenfield, W.D. Veeder, Edward F. Linton, John L. Hamilton, Calvert Vaux, and Secretary Albert E. Herschel.

VIENNA, Oct. 15 -- The celebration of the Strauss jubilee was continued to-day by a grand reception, at which the composer received a number of deputations and an immense gathering of individual callers. The reception began with a serenade by a chorus of pupils from the Conservatoire, after which the visitors were presented to the "Waltz King."
An ever-changing but always large crowd stood in front of the Morse Building, at Nassau and Beekman Streets, all day yesterday.

"In my opinion, the defeat of all the amendments proposed to the Constitution by the Constitutional Convention would be in the interest of decent politics," said John Boyd Thacher, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee, to a reporter for The New-York Times, at the Park Avenue Hotel, last night.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 15 -- Heffelfinger, one of the big guards of the Yale eleven for several seasons, and at present coach of the Lehigh team, will remain in this city for one week, coaching the Tale eleven.

BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 15 -- What seems to have been a bold attempt to assassinate Special Officer Edwin G. Knight of Randolph, who was employed at the Brockton Fair to detect liquor sellers, occurred in Randolph last evening. Mr. Knight was occupying a seat in an electric car, when a covered carriage was driven up alongside, a gun was thrust out from the carriage, and a heavy charge of shot was fired into the car.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Charles H. Trowbridge, one of the prominent bankers in this city and the cashier of the Mechanics' Bank, was shot this afternoon by his brother Elisha, the ball passing through the fleshy part of his left leg.

Mr. M.H. De Young of San Francisco, Vice Chairman of the Republican National Committee, has been talking to The New-York Tribune about the tariff, and our neighbor publishes a report of his remarks. "The reduction of the duty on lumber," he says, "has hurt us [in California] immensely, and benefited Mexico on one side and Canada on the other."

Judge Jenkins of the United States Circuit Court, sitting in Milwaukee, handed down a decision yesterday denying the petition of Brayton Ives for the removal of Thomas F. Oakes as one of the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- In the Park Theatre here to-night, before an audience that packed every part of the house. Palmer Cox's "Brownies" received its first production on any stage. That there was unusual interest in this new departure in theatricals was made manifest by the curious composition of the audience, which seemed to be drawn from every walk of life.

RONDOUT, Oct. 15 -- All Rondout and Kingston, the twin cities of the Hudson, aid one-half of the voters of Ulster County turned out to-night to honor Senator David B. Hill, who came here to discuss the issues of the campaign in the home district of his Republican competitor for the office of Governor, the lights of whose residence could be distinctly seen from the street where Senator Hill made his address.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Gen. Flagler, the Army Chief of Ordnance, will purchase $11,000 worth of cartridges for the New-York National Guard. The cartridges Will fee of fifty calibre. Bids were opened to-day at the War Department for the material.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Oct. 15. -- President Cleveland and Mrs. Cleveland will not leave Gray Gables until some time next week, reports to the contrary notwithstanding. The exact day has not yet been set. This beautiful, crisp October weather is very much enjoyed by them, and should it continue they will not depart until the close of next week.

Madison Hall, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, was crowded last evening with enthuiastic Republicans. The meeting was held under the auspices of the C.C. Shayne Club, which paraded to the hall from its clubhouse, 2,112 Second Avenue.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 15 -- The starring tour of Sadie Martinet and Max Figman began at Proctor's Opera, House tonight with the production of "The Passport." The piece is a farcial comedy by B. C. Stephenson and William Yardley. It has not been staged before. It is played by special arrangement with Daniel Frohman, who owns the American rights.
SARATOGA, Oct. 15 -- Henry D. Purroy, County Clerk of New-York County, was thrown from a carriage here to-day and was painfully, though not seriously, injured:

To set before the people the saving that will be effected to the consumer of woolen manufactures by the new tariff law, passed under the present Democratic Administration, Jacob Schoenhof, the well-known writer on tariff, wages, and economics generally, was yesterday interviewed by a reporter for The New-York Times.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 -- At 10 o'clock this morning the principals in the fight for the control of the Cincinnati Southern Railroad began to arrive at the general offices of that company. They represented two great railroad systems, both anxious to secure control of the property. The first interest is the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton syndicate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Ordnance officers of the navy are making arrangements for a great competitive test, at Indian Head Proving Grounds, of half-ton explosive projectiles for the thirteen-inch peacemakers of the three battle ships. The hardened armor-piercing shells for these big guns have already been obtained.

A fire in William's Bridge, which was caused by a spark from a locomotive on the Harlem Railroad about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, for a time threatened the whole village with destruction and deprived four families, numbering fifteen persons, of shelter.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Mrs. Thomas Harrigan of Grier Avenue, this city, while, it is supposed, temporarily insane, locked her three children and herself in her husband's barn this morning, set fire to it and all perished in the flames. She had previously attempted to burn the house.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Brokers who, a few weeks ago, could figure without trouble serious impairment in the earnings of the cable roads, especially on the West Chicago line, have experienced a change of sentiment. This morning they talked confidently of increased earnings and the wonderful results to come from the introduction of electricity.

Miss Olga Nethersole made her first appearance in this country at Palmer's Theatre last evening. Preparations for this important event were begun last March, in London, when Mr. Labouchere's lively and veracious newspaper, Truth, suddenly proclaimed Miss Nethersole's artistic greatness in slowing terms, and predicted for her an early visit to America, and a great triumph here.

Dr. C.H. Parkhurst was the principal speaker at a meeting held under the direction of the City Vigilance League, at the Eleventh Street Methodist Episcopal Church, near Avenue B. last night. The Rev. E.L. Fox, pastor of the church, presided.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

The Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association held a stated meeting yesterday afternoon (Monday) at St. Luke's Hospital. O. Egerton Schmidt presided. Charles S. Smith of the Chamber of Commerce was elected to membership. An invitation was extended to the Trustees of the thirty-four hospitals in the association to join the members at the meeting which the association will hold on Monday, Nov. 19.

Advances in rates of foreign exchange gave warning last week that gold might soon be engaged for export. According to the trade conditions usual at this season, this country should now be getting back some of the gold which it shipped abroad in the early part of the year. The threatened reversal of the normal tendency checked buying yesterday morning, and, except in two stocks, affected by special causes, the market waited for developments.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- Local traders were inclined to-day to sell St. Paul, and it was lower here than in New-York throughout the day. Reading was featureless until about 2 o'clock when it declined fractionally. The court has referred the reorganization plan to the Master who is taking testimony, to report in the next two days.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., Oct. 15 -- It is believed here that the $50,000 in gold and several thousand dollars in silver, the booty of the Southern Pacific train robbery last Thursday night, is concealed or buried within a mile of this city, but all the work of the detectives has been unable to locate the spot of discover the whereabouts of the robbers.

Senator Daniel Bradley of the Lexow investigating committee, who has received the Democratic Reform nomination for Congress in the Second District of Kings County, believes it to be his duty to hasten the investigation of Brooklyn affairs, as so much has been obtained from the investigation in New-York.

C.B. Richard Co., bankers at 61 Broadway, caused the arrest of Nicholas Coundouris, a Turk, upon the arrival of the Paris Saturday. Coundouris was a passenger aboard the steamship. He was locked up in Ludlow Street Jail.

Edward W. Chamberlain, candidate of the People's Party for Recorder, has withdrawn from the contest in favor of John W. Goff. He sent a letter to that effect to Dr. James McCullum, Chairman, and to the County Committee of the People's Party, yesterday. He says, among other things:
The nomination of Nathan Straus for Mayor by Tammany Hall is being vigorously discussed by business men. Following are some of their expressions of opinion:

The question presented to the Attorney General of this State by a representative of the labor organizations, as to whether paster ballots can be used upon the official ballots relating to constitutional amendments, gives prominence to a drawback which we have already pointed out in the law regarding this matter.

-- Mr. Joseph F. Loubat has given to the Abbey Church of St. Anselm, on the Aventine Hill, in Rome, a statue in white marble of Leo XIII., by Giuseppe Lucchetti. The same sculptor made the statues of Leo XIII. which Mr. Loubat gave to the Catholic University of Washington, the Collegiate Church of Carpineto, and the Cathedral of Perugia.

BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- Local stocks generally were quiet to-day. The chief feature of the market wag the drop in Bell Telephone, which opened at 199 3/4, the same as the last sale, declined without any recovery to 195 1/2, closing 1/2 higher at 196. There was no apparent reason far the decline. Some one evidently wanted to sell badly enough to sacrifice stock, ana no one wanted to buy except at a bargain.
The Chairman of the Notification Committee appointed by the Republican County Convention notified John W. Goff of his nomination for Recorder in the following letter:

Oliver Sumner Teall, who recently removed from the neighborhood of Fifth Avenue to a Park Bow hotel for the purpose of bringing about a reform in the politics of the Second Assembly District in the interest of the Republican Party, filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday a statement of assets and liabilities under his assignment to Francis Farquhar.

The sale was reported yesterday of the business property 43, 45, and 47 Broad Street, east side, south of Exchange Place. The plot is irregular, measuring 61.9 feet in front by 127.8 to 139.6 feet in depth, with a small square for lighting purposes at one side. Old four-story brick store and office buildings are on the site.

The disappointment and disgust felt among all classes of Democrats in Brooklyn at the nominations of the regular "machine" organization for the different offices to be filled this Fall finds particularly strong expression in regard to the men put up by the old regulars for Congress and the Assembly.

The new building erected by John Daniell Sons, Broadway, between Eighth and Ninth Streets, and its fine Variety of seasonable goods for personal wear, attracted a great deal of attention from shoppers yesterday. The large and handsome building was thronged until the hour for closing, and the crowd seemed unwilling to leave the displays of handsome goods.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 15 -- There is an apparent revival of business in many of the manufacturing concerns in this city. The Pope Manufacturing Company has 725 men employed on full time and several departments working until 10 P.M. The Beach Manufacturing Company, woolens, has 250 hands, and the mills at Beacon Falls are running until 9:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- H.C.C. Astwood, a negro who was nominated by the President to be Consul at Calais and was rejected toy tie Senate, has not only renounced his allegiance to the Democratic Party, but has become the editor of The Afro-American Defender, a paper which is cevoted to adulation of Levi P. Jlorton and the cultivation of the chances of negroes to obtain and bold office.

The festivities in honor of Johann Strauss have been going on in Vienna for some days, with an incessancy that must have been trying, and may be threatening, to a man who is about to enter on his seventieth year. But yesterday was the actual anniversary, the "employment jubilee," and the silver wreath that was sent to the composer by his American admirers was properly given to him on that day.
The New-York State Democracy held its Congressional Conventions last night, and made nominations for Congress in opposition to Tammany Hail.

The United German Democracy of the City of New-York, an organization once much more powerful than it is now, met last night in the Teutonia Assembty Rooms, Third Avenue and Sixteenth Street, and adopted resolutions indorsing the Demooratic State ticket and the Tammany local ticket.
Gen. Anson G. MeCook and Job E. Hedges opened headquarters for the management of Col. William L. Strong's campaign in the Sturtevant House yesterday.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Oct. 15 -- A dispute between the Rev. E.B. Elkins of Metuchen and St. George Kempson of this city has resulted in the arrest of both principals and Mr. Elkins's son, E.B. Elkins, Jr. All are prominent residents of the places where they reside.

The headquarters of Nathan Straus, Tammany's candidate for Mayor, in the Union Square Hotel, were running under full pressure yesterday. On all sides there were signs that a campaign of the greatest activity had been begun, and that Tammany proposes to make one of the greatest struggles in its history to save itself from impending defeat.

The downward movement in the price of wheat continued on the Produce Exchange yesterday. December wheat fell to 55 5/8, which is 1 cent lower than Saturday's price, and 1/2 cent below the previous lowest price.

The harness-racing matinee which was given as a benefit for John W. Driscoll at the Parkway track in Brooklyn drew a rather small crowd yesterday, the wind and the cold weather being too much for all but the most enthusiastic followers of the trotters to brave. The advance sale of tickets had been large, however, and a good sum was realized for the popular reinsman in whose behalf the affair was gotten up.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- The opening gun of the Democratic campaign here boomed to-night at Harmanus Bleecker Hall, when Bourke Cockran addressed the Democrats of Albany in a mass meeting presided over by Gov. Flower.

The fight for Congressional honors in the district which includes St. Lawrence, Saratoga, and Fulton and Hamilton Counties was transferred yesterday to the rooms of the Republican State Committee, in the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

The race meeting at Morris Park and the racing season in this State closed yesterday afternoon. The sport brought out a goodly number of people, for the card was one rather above the average, with two stake races, and a special race.

-- Irving Hose No. 5 and City Hose No. 3 will have an excursion to Nyack to-day, with their apparatus and brass bands, to participate in a Firemen's Parade. They will start at 10 A.M. from Peene's Dock on the steamer William H. Morton, Irving Hose will be the guests of Mazeppa Steamer Company, and City Hose of Jackson Hose Company.

-- Daniel Frohman in Boston -- Manager Daniel Frohman went to Boston with his Lyceum Theatre Company on Sunday. He will read to the company the play with which he will open the regular season at the Lyceum, the name of which has not yet been announced, and take the preliminary steps toward placing it in rehearsal, while the company is on the road.

It should be understood that, if the law is strictly construed and applied, the printing of the names of candidates upon official ballots is not a matter of consent, but of positive legal provision. Candidates can prevent the use of their names upon particular ballots, but they cannot secure their use upon any ticket for which they have not been duly nominated.

When Signer Perugini reached St. Leo's Church, Twenty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning, to be present at the memorial mass which Father Ducey was to say for his brother, Charles F. Chatterton, he found, standing on the steps of the church, a woman. She was hesitating about going inside, but when she saw Perugini her eye brightened.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 -- This was a field day in Reading affairs. The petition of the receivers to the United States Circuit Court, asking for sanction to the EarleOlcott plan for the readjustment of the financial difficulties of the company, had been set down for hearing to-day by the court as long ago as Sept. 25, and numerous counsel, representing various interests, were present at the opening of the court.

Sherry's cozy little pink ballroom was comfortably filled yesterday afternoon with the members of Sorosis, who had gathered to listen to an interesting paper by one of its number, Dr. Harriette C. Keatinge.

LISBON, Oct. 16 -- The Governor at Lourenzo Marquez has issued a proclamation warning the inhabitants that the authorities cannot be responsible for the safety of the people during the attack of the Kafirs unless they remain in the Market Square.

-- Edward Wendler, thirty-five years old, a well-known newsdealer and stationer of Mount Vernon, was found dead in bed yesterday morning. The cause of death is supposed to have been heart disease. He was unmarried.

Frederick W. Hinrichs, Brooklyn's Registrar of Arrears, who was nominated by the Reform Democrats for Register, yesterday declined to be a candidate. The Executive Committee has nominated in his place Henry Hentz, a wealthy and influential man and a member of the New-York Cotton Exchange.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 16 -- In the face of a southerly gale that made all coasting vessels within the reach of this port scurry to an anchorage here under well-shortened sail, the battle ship Maine went out for a warming-up spin this afternoon. The engineer trial board took the data of the performance of the machinery to familiarize the members with the duties of their stations.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- Bell Telephone was again the feature of the day. It registered a still further drop to 193 1/2, recovering later to 194. The cause of the decline is undoubtedly due to selling by investment holders, induced by the fear that the decision to be rendered very shortly by Judge Carpenter on the Berliner patents will be unfavorable to the Bell Company.

VALLEJO, Cal., Oct. 16 -- The greatest naval land drill ever held at Mare Island, and the greatest except two or three in the history of the service, took place this morning. The object was to practice men in the "storming drill" in brigade, end the present opportunity was seized on by Admiral Beardslee as being exceptional, seven ships in commission being in port at one time.
A general survey of the field was taken yesterday by the commanders of the forces which will do battle against Tammany Hall this year.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Henry Powell Ramsdell and Miss Adele Livingston Voorhis were married at the residence of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George H. Sheldon, 50 Dubois Street, at 3 o'clock P.M. The ceremony was performed with two rings by the Rev. J. Marshall Chew of the Church of the Good Shepherd.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 16 -- The sloop Plowboy, Stamford, Conn., Capt. William Codd, which started from the docks of the Northport Fire Sand and Clay Company this afternoon, loaded with sand, was upset in a gale when but a short distance out. All hands were thrown into the water, and the deckload of sand was lost.

If the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge continue to wrangle much longer regarding the lighting of the bridge cars by electricity, there is little probability of the patrons of that institution seeing a modern method of lighting the cars for some time to come.

The Grand Jury, at 1:30 P.M. yesterday, presented a large batch of indictments to Judge Cowing, in Part I. of General Sessions. They are supposed to be in registration cases. District Attorney Fellows promises to make strict inquiry in these cases.

-- That Princeton will meet a light but very active eleven when she faces Cornell at Manhattan Field next Saturday, was shown by Cornell's game against Lafayette last Saturday, in which she rolled up 34 points against 0 for Lafayette. The important change of the week was shifting Beacham from quarter to end and putting in Wyckoff as the regular quarter.

VIENNA, Oct. 16 -- In the Reichsrath today Herr von Plener introduced a bill providing for a monopoly by the State of the refining and sale of spirits. Herr von Plener argued, in support of the measure, that it would prevent the people from being poisoned by poor alcohols and would, besides, augment the revenue of the State.

HOUSTON, Texas, Oct. 16 -- Loss of life attended a fire which started this morning in the San Jacinto Boarding House, at Franklin Avenue and Jacinto Street, spread to and quickly destroyed St. Joseph's Infirmary, in Franklin Avenue, and, after extending to other buildings, caused a property loss of $500,000.

"A member of the Consolidation League of Brooklyn" has prepared a pamphlet in support of the Greater New-York proposition, which deals with it mainly as providing the present city with the means of expansion and of relief from congested population and its attendant evils, but he has seen fit to use the same arguments against the plan of relief by improved means of rapid transit within the present area of the city.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 16 -- The leading city of the Diamond State gave a rousing "welcome home" to-night to Thomas F. Bayard, the United States Ambassador to Great Britain. The city was brilliantly illuminated and decorated, and 10,000 persons turned out to do Mr. Bayard honor.

The late Joseph I. West, the head of the West, Cary Bradley Company, was a familiar figure in the real estate auction rooms of this city. Possessed of large means, he had little need of exercising the extreme caution which marks the smaller operator. He had a way of showing up just as an auctioneer was saying "Going, going, gone," and of interposing a bid that was conclusive.
-- Lieut. A.F. Fechteler has been detached from the Albatross and ordered to assume charge of the branch Hydrographic Office at San Francisco.

-- S.H.H. Clark, managing receiver of the Union Pacific, has returned to Omaha from St. Louis, Speaking of the report of Master in Chancery Cornish, he said it was in accordance with his own views on the Union Pacific question, and added: "I believe that all natural feeders of the Union Pacific should remain in the system, particularly Nebraska and Kansas, even if they are operated at a loss."

Neaarly 50 per cent. of yesterady's business in the stock market was in Sugar. It was strong from the opening and closed at 86 7/8, a net gain of 2 3/4 points. The strength gave rise to a rumor that the insiders were buying the stock to accumulate it, being satisfied with the extent of the decline.

At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday, the following resolutions concerning Capt. Schmittberger were adopted unanimously. He was accused before the Lexow committee of demanding $500 from the agent of the French Line Steamship Company, and also with compelling two of his policemen to share with him a weekly sum of money which they received from the steamship company:

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Business was very dull. The heavy traders of last week were apparently indifferent. A feature of improvement was in the heretofore neglected industries, although the orders were scattering, and not very heavy for any one security. The brewers are reported to have reached an agreement to maintain the old price of beer.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I desire to have it clearly understood that I had nothing whatever to do with the preparation or confirmation of the report which was read at the Stockler Club last night as being a report of a sub-committee of seven from the Independent County Organization. Until this morning, when I read It in the papers, I had no idea that any such report had been prepared or considered.

There has been a growing dissension for the past year or more in the Democratic Club, 617 Fifth Avenue, the culmination of which has come in the resignation from office and from membership of the Treasurer, Capt. J. Rockwell Fay, and the appointment of S.D. Freshman as his successor.

The people of Brooklyn, without regard to creed, thronged the Academy of Music last night and tendered to the Rev. Sylvester Malone, the venerable pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, an imposing civic demonstration of the universal esteem for his life and works.

Ex-Secretary Charles S. Fairchild yesterday made public a letter which he received from J.H. Morton of Syracuse with reference to the "third" ticket, and his own reply to it. Mr. Morton says he was one of the Committee of Fifteen that organized the anti-snapper movement, and he is an admirer of Mr. Fairchild.

The Rapid Transit Commission decided yesterday to get up a public statement, a sort of campaign document, showing the general state of the rapid-transit laws, the purposes of the present commission, and the reasons why the City of New-York should build its own rapid-trasit railroads.
