ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The Republican Convention to nominate an Assemblyman in the First District of Monroe County was held yesterday at Pittsford. The convention was called to order at 11 o'clock in the morning, and did not adjourn until 6 o'clock in the evening. During that time an animated contest was carried on, the candidates to the nomination being numerous and determined.

Lithographs of Whistler are exhibited in the Wunderlich gallery in a series of forty -one numbers, including "The Late Piquet," "La Belle Dame Paresseuse.' "La Jolie New-Yorkaise Louis Quinze," and others, the quaint titles of which captivate curiosity.

Dr. Austin Flint has commenced a contest over the will of his mother, Annie Flint, who died Aug. 19, 1894, at Boston, Mass. The value of her real estate is placed at $75,000, and her personal property is worth about $5,000.
The question as to who shall run the ferry from the foot of Whitehall Street to Staten Island was settled yesterday.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. Jacob Cole sold to A.A. Low, as executor, plaintiff, at $4,900, the three-story frame dwelling, 192 Prospect Street, south side, 48.4 feet east of Gold Street, 25 by 100.
BOSTON. Oct. 16 -- The Herald's correspondent cables as follows from Gourock, Scotland:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The vacancy in the rank of Major General of the army, which occurs Nov. 8 through the retirement of Gen. O. O. Howard, commanding the Department of the East, with headquarters at Governors Island, is exciting intense interest in the military service, on account of the doubts raised as to President Cleveland's choice from among the candidates for the appointment.

John James Howard, late of the stables of Sir Robert Affleck, London, will try to show cause to-day at 3 o'clock before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, why that great friend of the American workingman, Levi P. Morton, should not be deprived of his valuable services.

The "Empire State Democrats" have filed with the Secretary of State a certificate of nominations for State offices and will be entitled to an official ballot bearing the names of the candidates. The "New-York State Democracy" has nominated candidates for city and county offices, and if its convention was an "assemblage of the delegates of a political party" it will be entitled to an official ballot bearing the names of those candidates.

A rousing meeting of east-side Hebrews was held in Harris's Assembly Rooms, in East Broadway, last evening, at which the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst was the principal speaker. The meeting was held under the auspices of Good Government Club X of the Fourth Assembly District and the City Vigilance League.

The explanation made by Mr. Goff yesterday of what may be called his policy of investigation is both interesting and timely. A good many people have been wondering why he should have confined his exposures of the police to the small fry, for even a Captain is small fry, compared with the men who can make him or break him.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 16 -- A report is in circulation here that Port Arthur has been captured by the Japanese. This port is one of the most important of the Chinese strongholds, and was the place of refuge of the Chinese fleet after the battle of Yalu, the disabled ships having been repaired and refitted there.

The Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, formerly rector of the West Presbyterian Church. Forty-second Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has returned to the city and is occupying his house, 51 West Fortysixth Street.
The New-York Tribune publishes some remarks about the Twenty-sixth Congressional District in this State, in the course of which we find the following:

The opinions of men in all walks of life were obtained yesterday by reporters for The New-York Times upon the subject of permitting Tammany any longer to rule this city. Interviews were had with men of vast wealth and large interests, and men who live by their daily labor were also talked with.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The one hundred and seventeenth anniversary of the burning of Kingston was celebrated today at the old Senate House by Wiltwyck Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, and by citizens.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 16. -- Walter Peterson, six years old, of 210 Bloomfield Street, was playing on the sidewalk this afternoon, when he was attacked by two Newfoundland dogs. Before he could be rescued he was badly bitten on both cheeks and his nose was almost torn off. Ten stitches were required to sew up his wounds.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 16 -- There was plenty of speed on tap to-day at Cumberland Park, the splendid track and warm weather enabling the horses to reel off thirteen rapid miles. The most sensational performance was that of the two-year-old filly Impetuous in the Melrose Stakes. Oakland Baron, the favorite, led till just at the finish of the first heat, when Impetuous rushed up and had a nose the best of it in 2:15 3/4.

SULPHUR, Ky., Oct. 16 -- Fire to-day swept away the entire central part of this town, including the Deposit Bank of Sulphur, the Louisville and Nashville Railroad depot, filled with merchandise, and the water tank of the road, two hotels, seven stores, two livery stables, and six residences.
LITTLE FALLS, Oct. 16 -- Senator Hill spoke here this afternoon. He arrived here at noon, accompanied by his private secretary and CoL John S. McEwan.
Senator Lexow and his associates yesterday made complaint to Messrs. Goff and Moss because none of the Police Commissioners had been summoned to the witness stand.

The twenty-fourth meeting of the American Society of Railroad Superintendents was held at the Hotel Brunswick Monday. George W. Beach of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, President of the association, was in the chair. About thirty railroad men were present C.B. Price was elected First Vice President, and C.R. Fitch, Second Vice President.

Bids for bonds and stock of the City of New-York were opened by Controller Fitch Monday afternoon. The New-York Life Insurance Company took all of the securities save $50,000 of schoolhouse bonds, which went to the Irving Savings Institution at 101.52.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Brig. Gen. McCook has had charges preferred against him by Lieut. Col. Henry E. Noyes, Second Cavalry, recently in command at Fort Wingate, New-Mexico.

UTICA Oct. 16 -- The Utica Opera House was not large enough to hold all who wished to hear Senator Hill discuss the campaign issues this evening. It was necessary to have an "overflow" meeting in the City Hall Opera House, and even that large auditorium was crowded with Democrats enthusiastic for the State ticket.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 16 -- For more than a year the press of Kansas has contained references to the fact that in many localities the fanners were feeding their surplus wheat, in lieu of corn, as a stock food.

The disagreement between the General Passenger Agents of the Eastern trunk lines and their Western connections over the Touting of the immigrant passenger traffic out of New-York was amicably settled yesterday. A fairly representative meeting was held in the Trunk Line Association office, Commissioner L.P. Farmer presiding.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The greed of one man for office never before stirred up the Republicans of St. Lawrence County to the extent that they are now stirred up over the candidacy of Gen. N. M. Curtis, who, failing to secure a nomination in the regular way, is circulating petitions to place himself before the people as an independent candidate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The belief is expressed in Treasury circles that the export of gold announced for to-day is not the inauguration of a general gold export movement, but is due largely to local causes in New-York which are influenced by speculative action.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Although during the early part of this Pall campaign the Democrats of Monroe County were divided and engaged in bitter factional disputes, since the State Convention was held there has been a union of the factions and a dropping of the issues in controversy for the purpose of having a united party at election.
All the regular certificates of nomination of candidates to be voted on at the coming election were filed in accordance with the law with the Police Commissioners by midnight last night.

Mayor Gilroy sent to the Police Board yesterday the reports of the Civil Service Commissioners relative to the examination of several policemen who are alleged to have obtained their appointments through fraud.

Do you propose to leave your candidates to their fate? Was your work done when you had procured their nomination and united in their support all the organizations opposed to Tammany? Will you leave it to those organizations, not in political accord, in their varying interests opposed, to bear your candidates to their triumph or to their defeat?

-- Jonathan Grant, a bookkeeper, forty-eight years old, of 107 Madison Avenue, was reported at Police Headquarters yesterday by his wife as having been missing since Sept. 21. He left his father's home at Catskill on that day, boarding a train to return home. No traces of him have been found since.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-Tork Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 16 -- The principal interest in the Ohio campaign this Fall centres in the Congressional districts. The present delegation from Ohio in Congress stands eleven Democrats to ten Republicans. The outlook now is that the Republicans will make some gains in the State. They are claiming extraordinary things.

Senator Charles T. Saxton opened the Republican campaign in Brooklyn in the Clermont Avenue Rink last evening. Abel Blackmar, President of the Union League Club of Brooklyn, presided. The candidate for Lieutenant Governor was received with applause and cheers. He said, in part:

ASBURY PARK. Oct. 16 -- Arrangements for the century run from this place to Newark on Thursday are complete, and success is assured. Over fifty entries had been received up to Monday evening by the Run Committee of the Asbury Park Wheelmen, under whose auspices the century is given, and an additional number is expected before the starting time.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- After quarreling with his sweetheart on the train from Jersey City this afternoon, W.E. Stauffer, aged thirty-three, left her here to go on by herself to their home, at Ashland, Ohio, and, going to Dooner's Hotel, secured a room and shot himself through the breast, inflicting a probably fatal wound.

A sensation was created at Democratic Headquarters yesterday when it became known that certain friends of Nathan Straus, the Tammany Hall candidate for Mayor, had got together to protest against the plan which had been agreed upon for allowing names of the candidates of the State Democracy to be printed upon the tickets of the regular Democracy as represented by Senator David B. Hill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- It would be cause for great regret if the action of the divided Democrats of Kings County in nominating two sets of Democratic Congressional candidates should throw the Fifty-fourth Congress into the hands of the Populists, yet there is just the chance that such a result may follow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Surgeon General Wyman has received a preliminary report from Passed Assistant J.J. Kinyoun, from the Pasteur Institute in Paris, where he is making a special study of the methods of Prof. Roux in the treatment of diphtheria by means of serum injections. Dr. Kinyoun states that he is convinced that Prof. Roux has been too modest in his claims for the efficacy of this treatment.
The members of the John F. Ahearn Association did not bolt the Edward T. Fitzpatrick nominations for the Fourth Assembly District Alderman and Assemblyman yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- The hearing was begun to-day, in the Superior Court, in the suit of Mary E. Bartlett against the executors of the estate of Dr. Henry J. Bigelow to recover $150,000. The plaintiff claims that Dr. Bigelow promised her this in the event that he failed to redeem a promise of marriage, which death prevented.

Bays who have tried to climb a greased pole at a country fair for the prize that was at the top of it have experienced something of the sensation that the Tammany managers are now experiencing in trying to make headway with their campaign.
LITTLE FALLS, N. T., Oct. 16 -- While here Senator Hill received a telegram from Brooklyn telling him that E. Ellery Anderson had consented to speak on the same platform with him Oct. 23.
"Johnny" Simpson, Republican leader in the Fifth Assembly District, took down a large knife last night and started out to use it on such of Chairman Hackett's candidates as may seem to him good.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 16 -- The seventy-second annual meeting of the Synod of New-Jersey began at the Third Presbyterian Church at 11:30 o'clock this morning. About 300 of the enrolled delegates were present before the day ended. The session will continue two days. The Moderator's sermon was by the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Studdiford.
Inspector Williams was challenged to a duel yesterday morning by Lorenz Bayer, a witness before the Lexow committee, for insulting Mr. Bayer's wife and daughter and women customers.

Simon Grumm, a cloak presser, and a member of the Operators and Cloakmakers' Union, made a statement yesterday charging that Detective Sergeant Charles Jacobs of the Central Office was the prime mover of the police plot to break up the union.

The second day's registration carries the total of registered voters up to 202,804, surpassing the total of the first two days in the Presidential year of 1892. which was 202,497. In the last Gubernatorial year, 1891, the two days' total was only 150,168; in 1890 it was 140,308.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The annual Fall handicap games of the Princeton Track Athletic Association were held on the Varsity field to-day. R.C. Kumler, '95, broke the college record in the broad jump, doing 22 feet 5 Inches. This beats the late Walter Dohm's record of 21 feet 7 inches, and all recorded performances of E.S. Ramsdell, '94, the present intercollegiate cham-...

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- The market for local stocks was quiet, with no special feature. Bell Telephone recovered 1, to 195, later selling at l94 1/2 for a small lot. Erie Telephone was steady at 54 1/2 and New-England Telephone at 67 1/2. It was rumored that the recent drop in Bell was on account of the proposed issue of 10,000 shares of new stock in the immediate future.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 17 -- Ten thousand persons, the banner crowd of the year, saw the University of Pennsylvania down Lehigh on the gridiron to-day by the score of thirty points to nothing. The game was played on the Philadelphia League baseball grounds, and its success in point of attendance will probably lead to the other Pennsylvania games being played there also.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 17 -- At to-day's session of the New-Jersey Presbyterian Synod the Woman's Home Missionary Society reported receipts of $35,902.84, and the Foreign Missions Society receipts of $31,175.76.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The volume of business transacted on the local Stock Exchange was comparatively light, but prices, as a rule, were well maintained. Alley "L" and West Chicago attracted most attention. The former opened at 13, and sold about that price throughout. West Chicago was firm at a little higher quotations than yesterday.

Ex-Assemblyman Dennis Burns, who represented the Second Assembly District for five terms in the Legislature, and who was known as the "member from Sligo," was refused registration yesterday because he could not produce his naturalization papers.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 17 -- The first regular ladles' golf tournament that has been held this season was commenced here this afternoon on the pretty links of the Morris County Golf Club. This club, while one of the youngest of similar organizations, has been far more successful than even its must sanguine supporters had expected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- No information has been received at the Japanese Legation confirmatory of the reported capture of Port Arthur. The Shanghai dispatches which contain the report are believed to be as destitute of truth as the rumors sent out from the same place last week that the treaty port of Che-Foo had been captured by the Japanese.

RUTLAND, Vt., Oct. 17 -- The Supreme Court of Vermont, in General Term, has made an important decision in relation to the prohibitory liquor statutes. The respondent, David Sawyer of Middlebury, was convicted in the lower court of a first offense for selling intoxicating liquor, and a fine was imposed.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 17 -- Manager Cable to-night says there is no truth in the report that Tale had insisted on playing the football game with Princeton on Dec. 10. There have been no negotiations between the two colleges since the meeting of the association in New-York.

Messrs. Frederick Southack Co. have sold, for Mr. Koenig of Germany, represented here by Mr. Fritz Achelis, the block front on the south side of Broome Street, extending from Broadway to Mercer Street, 28 by 200. The purchaser is Mr. John T. Williams, who paid $350,000 for the prop- erty.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 17 -- The Sixth District Congressional Republican Convention was held to-night in the Essex Lyceum. Richard Wayne Parker, son of the well-known lawyer Cortland Parker, was unanimously nominated for Congress. The other candidates in the field were John S. Gibson and Frederick T. Frelinghuysen.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- "We have brought about ninety cases, and not one of them has been decided against us. That is the record for the last six months, but it is likely to be eclipsed by the results of the next half year. Our work is only fairly begun."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- The silk mills in this city are running at their full capacity. The new Hartley silk mill has started off with a boom that is surprising. Every loom is in operation on full time. Orders are now on hand that will keep the factory busy until the new year, and new orders are being received. The Hartley mill weaves only broad silks.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 17 -- The track record at Narragansett Park was twice broken to-day. In the second race the 1:43 was lowered to 1:42 3/4 for a mile, and the record was clipped off 1 1/4 seconds for seven furlongs in the third. In only one instance did the talent pick the winner, and the increased number of books enjoyed a good harvest.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17 -- This afternoon, in the presence of about 1,000 persons, the annual Fall races of the class crews of Yale University were rowed on Lake Whitney. It was perfect weather for the contests.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- A dispatch to the Central News from Tien-Tsin says the Emperor has ordered that all the Chinamen who are accused of connection with the recentlyarrested Japanese spy be sent to Pekin for trial.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The Republican Party has so far in the State canvass apparently been very quiet. Does it expect to have a repetition of the tactics employed by it in 1888, when Harrison and Morton had an apparent plurality of 14,373?

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17 -- The twenty-third annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad was held in this city to-day. There was a very large attendance. President Charles P. Clark called the meeting to order, and then began a general protest to the by-laws recently adopted by the Board of Directors.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The Daily News will publish to-morrow this comment on Ambassador Bayard's speech in Wilmington last evening:

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday in the Mayor's office for the purpose of considering the provisional estimates submitted by various city departments for 1895. Mayor Gilroy presided.

ASBURY PARK, Oct. 17 -- Wheelmen from New-York, Philadelphia, Jersey City, Newark, and other Jersey towns arrived here this evening to participate in to-morrow's century run to Newark. The Asbury Park Wheelmen will have charge of the run, and Chairman Wiseman expects to see 100 cyclers participate. The riders will leave Asbury Park to-morrow morning at 5 o'clock.

The Synod of the Presbyterian Church of New-York State held its second day's session yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church, corner of Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street. The Rev. Dr. George C. Yeisley of Hudson was elected Moderator.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- If any further evi- dence is required that the Republican National Committee, through the Republican Congressional Committee, is disseminating A.P.A. doctrines and A.P.A. literature, it is only necessary to visit the State Capitol in this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Argument was heard in the United States Supreme Court to-day on the application of the State of New-York for a writ of error to review the order of the Circuit Court of the Second District, discharging John C. Eno, ex-President of the Second National Bank of NewYork City, from custody, after conviction for forgery and false entry.

CALCUTTA, Oct. 17 -- A Lahore newspaper says that the Ameer of Afghanistan is dead. It describes the death scene, and relates at length how the Ameer exhorted his eldest son and heir, Habib Ullah, to maintain friendship with Great Britain. No confirmation of this story has been obtained.
Ex-Mayor William R. Grace, speaking for the New-York State Democracy, sent the following letter to Chairman Faulkner of the Democratic congressional Committee yesterday:

DETROIT, Mlch., Oct. 17 -- Marie Burroughs, formerly leading woman for E.S. Willard, the English actor, made her debut as a star in the Lyceum Theatre to-night, presenting "The Scapegoat," a comedydrama in four acts by Gertrude Warden and Wilton Jones, for the first time in America.

CHERRY RUN, West Va., Oct. 17 -- The Adams Express Company's detectives think they have captured one of the men who robbed the express car on the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad last Friday night, and are encouraged to believe that they will soon have them all in custody, together with the money they stole.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Amherst was defeated at football by a score of 30 to 0 this afternoon by a team made up mostly of Harvard's second eleven. The game was won more through Amherst's weakness than through any very strong playing on the part of Harvard. The Amhersts were light and weak at every point. They had no interference, and their defensive playing was poor.
Prominent citizens of New-York, without regard to party or business calling, met at the Windsor Hotel last night and indorsed the renomination of Recorder Frederick Smyth.

WASHINGTON COURT HOUSE, Ohio. Oct. 17 -- State troops, sent from Columbus at the request of Sheriff Cook of this (Fayette) County, to protect the person of William Dolby, alias Jasper, a young negro who atrociously maltreated Mrs. Mary C. Boyd a week ago, fired upon a mob which attempted to capture Dolby for the purpose of lynching him, late this afternoon.

Tweed's Tammany had ten times the brains and the "nerve" of the present Tammany. When in 1871 a public clamor arose for the Controller's report on city finances, which had been delayed eight months beyond its usual date of issue, "Slippery Dick" Connolly invited a committee of eminent citizens to visit his office and inspect his books.

The Committee of Seventy proposes to enter the jungle. It pitched its tent yesterday, got into its hunting boots, examined its powder and ball, and at nightfall was nearly ready to start for the Tiger.

The marriage of Miss Julia Carlisle Banks to Clement Guion took place at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, in West Forty-second Street. A nuptial mass was celebrated by the Rev. Dr. Thomas McKee Brown, rector of the church. The Rev. Dr. Henry Mottet, rector of the Church of the Holy Communion performed the ceremony.

In talks with Democratic members of the Produce and Consolidated Exchanges yesterday, reporters for The New-York Times found that the great preponderance of opinion in the present campaign appears to be against Tammany.

Mr. John De Witt Warner has done a practically patriotic thing in declining to stand for Congress at the risk of electing a Republican in his district. Unquestionably he ought to have been nominated by the regular organization. He is an able, upright man, of special knowledge as to the tariff and the currency.

Francis H. Weeks, the lawyer convict who embezzled over a million dollars of moneys that were intrusted to his care as trustee and is now serving a term of imprisonment in Sing Sing, is to be examined as a witness in one of the numerous litigations that have arisen over his misapplication of funds.

If the entire work of the Constitutional Convention shall be defeated at the polls it will be due to the partisan spirit by which the majority of the delegates allowed themselves to be controlled and to their departure from sound principles in framing and submitting for approval the amendments of the Constitution.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Senator Hill arrived at Fonda from Utica this afternoon, and for an hour held an informal reception there. He left on a special train, later for Gloversville, and arrived here a little before 6 o'clock. On the way the train stopped at Johnstown, where a number of people had congregated at the station to see Senator Hill pass through.
The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church of America met yesterday morning, in the new Church Missions House, at the corner of Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street.

"How is my friend Mr. Campbell?" was the way ex-Secretary Benjamin F. Tracy yesterday greeted Timothy J. Campbell, who expects to succeed himself in Congress as the anti-Tammany candidate in the Ninth District.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- At 5 P.M. Adjt. Gen. Howe received a telegram from Col. Coit at Washington Court House saying that he would soon start for the State prison with Dolby. This was evidently just before the attack by and repulse of the mob.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Minister Terrell informed the Department of State by cable from Constantinople this afternoon that the native Armenian teachers in the American Missionary School at Aintab, who were arrested by the Turkish authorities several weeks ago on the charge that they had seditious intentions, had finally been exonerated.

Further weakness in the foreign exchange market yesterday, brought about a marked change for the better in the general sentiment, and notwithstanding renewed firmness in sales during the afternoon, the impression prevailed that further shipments of gold would be averted for the present. There was a brisk covering movement throughout the morning and early afternoon, and it revealed the fact that there was a scarcity of stock.

LOGN ISLAND CITY. L.I., Oct. 17 -- Capt. Parker J. Hall of the schooner Robert P. King of Kingston, Mass., is a free man. After thirty minutes' deliberation to-night; the jury before whom the Captain was tried on a charge of murdering one of his crew -- a Portuguese sailor named Frank Duard -- while the schooner was anchored in Flushing Bay on the night of July 23, brought in a verdict of not guilty.

Comparisons of railroad earnings this month with the earnings in October of last year scarcely form a fair test of relative business conditions, inasmuch as the closing weeks of the World's Fair traffic gave an abnormal impetus to the earnings of a large proportion of the railroads in the North and West.

The brutes and blackmailers in the police force and their backers and accomplices in or out of public office have only one consolation in the exposure of them that is now going on and that has been going on with increasing interest for some months, and that is that it will not go on much longer.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- If the efforts of the big Tammany Hall leaders could prevail, the Grace Democracy would be thrown overboard in New-York City and the names of David B. Hill, Daniel N. Lockwood, and Charles F. Brown would not appear on the Grace ticket.

It is now practically certain that the official ballot of the State Democracy, which includes the name of William L. Strong for Mayor, will be headed by the names of David B. Hill for Governor, Daniel N. Lockwood for Lieutenant Governor, and Charles F. Brown for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals.

CINCINNATI, O., Oct. 17 -- Gov. McKinley arrived here at midnight, and upon learning the full extent of the rioting at Washington Court House left Immediately for Columbus. If on his arrival he is advised that the trouble has quieted down, he will leave on the 10 A. M. train for this city, and, by making close connection, reach Louisville early to-morrow evening.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- The forty-fifth annual meeting of the stockholders of the Illinois Central Railroad Company was held here to-day. Of the 500,000 shares of capital stock, 284,890 were represented. Oliver Harriman, John W. Doane, and Charles M. Beach were re-elected Directors, to serve four years.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- The new Bloomingdale Asylum, just completed in this town, was opened for public inspection this afternoon.
A meeting of the creditors of Coffin Stanton was held in Receiver Erb's office, in Lower Broadway, yesterday, about $1,000,000 of the $3,600,000 of the firm's liabilities being represented.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 17 -- Thomas B. Reed of Maine opened the course in the Students' Lecture Association before an audience that filled the large auditorium of Michigan University to-night. His address was upon "The Relation of Leaders of Progress," and was a characteristic discourse upon the great questions of the day, without any references to politics.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- A dispatch received from St. Petersburg this morning confirms the report that the Czar's trip to Corfu has been abandoned.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 18 -- A man giving his name as Charles A. Morganfield, who the police think knows something about the Acquia Creek train robbery, was arrested this morning and was sent to the City Hospital. Wednesday morning a gardener named Henry Geismann found Morganfied lying unconscious, with one leg broken, in a pit at the foot of an embankment near the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton tracks, about three squares east of Mitchell Avenue.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- To-day's market was dull as far as local stocks were concerned, and absolutely without feature. Bay State Gas, for the present at least, has relapsed into great dullness. Its closing price was 11, 1/4 lower than last night. Bell Telephone improved 2, to 196 for a small lot.

ATTLEBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 18 -- This own began to-day a two days' celebration of the two hundredth anniversary of its incorporation. The Bi-Centennial Committee has worked night and day, and, as a result, the town is elegantly dressed for the exercises. The buildings on both sides of the main street are trimmed in the national and other colors, flags, and fine life-sized pictures.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Walter Cash, '91; Alexander Moffat, '84, and H.H. Janeway, '90, arrived to-day to assist Mr. Fine and "Phil" King in coaching the football team. As a result of their combined coaching, both the first and second elevens played much better football throughout both halves of to-day's practice. The scrub especially distinguished itself by scoring a safety against the 'Varsity.

At a meeting of the Democratic Party Reform Organization, held at 45 William Street yesterday afternoon, Everett P. Wheeler's formal letter accepting the nomilation for Governor was read. It was as follows:
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met at the Mayor's office yesterday morning and continued its work of preparing the provisional estimate of city expenses for 1895.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The denial of the Republican Congressional Committee, through its Chairman, Mr. Babcock, of any connection with the American Protective Association has not deceived nor convinced anybody. The Republicans who are acquainted with the facts marvel at Mr. Babcock's "nerve."

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Oct. 18 -- Apparently happy and light-hearted, Miss Mary Duff, daughter of Peter Duff, a Summer resident here, and Ellett Livingston Titus, her affianced husband, left Miss Duff's home here Tuesday evening for a walk. They did not return that night, and after a search lasting throughout yesterday and part of last night their bodies were found in the Duff family bathhouse on the shore of Hempstead Harbor.

The immediate advantages of uniting into one municipality New-York, Brooklyn, and the contiguous and adjacent territory included within the plan of the Consolidation Commission do not appeal so strongly to the people of New-York as to those of Brooklyn and the other communities concerned.

Stock speculation yesterday was extremely dull, the only features being in Sugar and General Electric. The latter, which was somewhat less active than Sugar, attracted more attention, owing to its weakness. Several leading bear operators were very free sellers of the stock, and it declined under their offerings to 33 3/4.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- Unusual interest attaches to the annual meeting of the Pullman Palace Car Company, held to-day, on account of the part taken by the company in the last big railroad strike. As expected. President George M. Pullman, in his report, referred to the strike at some length, answering the charges of inhumanity which have been made against him from time to time.
HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 18 -- The fate of the runaway schooner Lord Eldon has not yet been cleared up. The owners here have filed three insurance protests.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- A dispatch to The Globe, from Port Arthur, under date of Oct. 16, says that the Japanese have abandoned Thornton Haven and advanced to Ping-Yang Inlet, which they are strongly fortifying.

WASHINGTON, Oct 18 -- Secretary Lamont has under consideration a change in the service which will contribute to economical administration. It is proposed to abolish the subsistence storehouses and the system of commissary sales in large cities, such as New-York, Chicago, Washington, San Francisco, and Omaha.
Mr. John Kehoe has sold to a Mr. Schreiber, at about $25,000, the three-storyand-basement brownstone dwelling 312 West Seventy-first Street, 18 by 55 by 100.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Chief Consul James S. Holmes, Jr., of the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen, has decided not to hold his county wheelmen's convention until after the primaries of both the leading political parties have been held, but he says the wheelmen's campaign for good roads in New-Jersey is not the least bit on the wane.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Miss A. Howland Ford won the silver cup this afternoon at the ladies tournament of the Morris County Golf Club. It was a wellearned victory and a very popular one.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Adjt. Gen. Porter today issued an order providing that there shall be awarded to the officers and enlisted men actually serving Oct. 1, 1894, in the National Guard and the Naval Militia, and to those who may be enlisted subsequently to that date, as recognition for faithful service in these organizations extending over ten, fifteen, twenty, and twenty-five years, a State decoration, subject to certain conditions prescribed.

Several members of the Irish National Federation of America were seated in the offices of the society in Cooper Union last night discussing the disturbance at the reception given to Edward Blake, M.P., in the Lenox Lyceum, the night before.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 18 -- The religious portion of Jamaica's colored population is much worked up over a factional quarrel in the Shiloh Baptist Church Society, which formerly worshipped peaceably in a little frame building in South Street, this village.

Alien Lewis Seymour, a broker of the firm of Seymour Brothers Young of 2 Exchange Place and 92 Leonard Street, was arrested shortly after noon yesterday at 3 Exchange Place on a bench warrant from Washington, the charge against him being that he refused, on July 25, to answer questions put to him by the United States Senate committee investigating the relation of the Sugar Trust with Senators.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- All the nominations of both parties or Representatives from Connecticut in the National House of Representatives have been made, except on the Democratic side in the Fourth district.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 18 -- Under escort of six companies of the Fourteenth Regiment of this city, William Dolby, the negro criminal, in charge of Sheriff Cook of Fayette County, arrived here on a special train at 5:30 A.M., from Washington Court House.

The situation concerning the nomination for Congressmen in the Kings County districts has not changed, but there are many who believe that, in the interests of the Democracy of the Nation, some action should be taken in order not to lose a single Congressman.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 18 -- There is great excitement in the Republican camp over the developments of the last few days, and Chairman Bixby of the State Central Committee has Issued two addresses, the first to all voters and the other to the farmers of the State. Besides this, he yesterday hurriedly summoned the State Central Committee here, and that body held a long conference to-day.
MOUNT MORRIS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Senator Hill spoke here this afternoon before an audience that filled the Seymour Opera House. He touched on all the issues of the campaign.

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 18 -- John P. Williams, a colored coachman, formerly in the employ of Henry W. Baldwin, and Thomas Bass, also colored, who were charged with robbing and then, burning the magnificent house of Mr. Baldwin in this village, Oct. 9, were taken, to-day, to the pawnshops in New-York City and Long Island City.

A few gentlemen organized themselves about two years ago into an informal association for the purpose of establishing a lectureship in this country similar in some respects to the Hibbert Lectureship in England, but for the purpose entirely of the study of the history of religions and the comparison of religions.

BERLIN, Oct. 18. -- At 10 o'clock this morning the color companies of all the regiments of the Garde du Corps formed in line at the Berlin Arsenal and marched to the monument to Frederick the Great, in front of which had been erected an altar, which was decorated with drums, two guns, and masses of flowers.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Congressman Pigott, in his speech at the Democratic mass meeting last Monday night, denounced the A.P.A. organization, and charged N.D. Sperry, Republican nominee for Congress in the Second Connecticut District, with being closely allied to the A.P.A.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 18 -- One of the most successful century club runs ever held in the State terminated here at 5:55 o'clock this evening, when fifty-four members of the Asbury Park Wheelmen descended on the Hotel Continental. These were the survivors of a party of sixty-two which left Founder Bradley's seaside city at 5:10 A.M. on the club's initial one-hundred-mile trip.

The New-York Harbor and Staten Island Ferry Company did not acquire the property of the Staten Island Ferry Company yesterday, because of the following letter and the acquiescence of Howard Carroll of the new ferry company to the requests contained in it:

Rome, Oct. 18 -- Prof. John A. Zahm of the Catholic University of Notre Dame, Indiana, is here. The Moniteur de Rome, in announcing his presence, highly eulogizes the professor's discourses at the recent Catholic Congress in Brussels on the subject of seminary studies.

Police Justice Patrick Divver, the Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District, has frowned with judicial dignity and displeasure on many sadly-battered noses in the police courts, but never did he gaze on a redder or more swollen proboscis than that which confronted him when he peered into a looking glass yesterday morning.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 18 -- Sir Charles Tupper was asked to-day about the report sent some days ago to the effect that serious differences had arisen during the Bering Sea arbitration between the Canadian department and the mother country, and that the Canadian department wished to show its position by bringing down the correspondence.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 18 -- Senator Hill addressed a large and enthusiastic meeting in the Lyceum Opera House this evening. He was welcomed in the heartiest manner possible, and his speech was listened to with close attention and liberally applauded.
Unless the indications of last night fail and Nathan Straus changes his mind, he will withdraw to-day as Tammany's candidate for Mayor.

WASHIGTON, Oct. 18 -- Supervising Inspector General Dumout of the Steamboat Inspection Service, in his annual report, states that of the 600,000,000 or 700,000,000 people carried on steam vessels during the past fiscal year, only ninety-six passengers lost their lives through casualties. During the same period 159 officers or persons employed on steam vessels were lost, an increase in the total over 1893 of 27.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 18. -- All political questions are temporarily in abeyance, even the protection of foreigners in China, inasmuch as the Foreign Office's dispatches to Livadia are not answered. This alone is a sinister omen, indicating that the Czar is incapable of attending to even the most urgent affairs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- At a meeting to-day of the stockholders in The Chicago Times Company, William Preston Harrison and his brother. Carter H. Harrison, who have been in control of the newspaper since the assassination of their father, learned, to their surprise and regret, that the millionaire lawyer, Adolph Kraus, who was Corporation Counsel under the last brief term of the late Mayor Harrison, had obtained control of a majority of the stock.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Attorney General Hancock to-day officially announced his opinion against the use of paster ballots for voting on constitutional amendments this Fall. The opinion is addressed to James E. Roach of this city, President of the New-York State Branch, Iron Molders' Union, and is as follows:
It was learned yesterday that Superintendent Byrnes went before the Grand Jury Wednesday in connection with illegal registration in this city. He was also in consultation with the District Attorney.

Dr. A.C. McKenzie of Owego presented the pastoral letter at the session of the Presbyterian Synod yesterday morning. When the Moderator named a Committee on the Pastoral Letter in the afternoon, it was resolved to dispense with the letter until needs arise for its revival.

The rumors that gained circulation Wednesday night that a message from Pops Leo was on its way to this country to invest with the red hat of a Cardinal Mgr. Satolli, the Papal Delegate, is generally regarded by Roman Catholic clergymen in this city as founded upon fact, and there was general satisfaction over the probability of its truth.

Further evidence that brutes on the police force are not deterred from committing outrageous crimes by the presence in this city of the Senate investigators was given yesterday before the committee by a man who was set upon by Philip Wissig, Jr., and two policemen, who knocked him down and beat him into insensibility while he was walking in the street with his wife last Wednesday morning.

VIENNA, Oct. 18 -- Workingmen agitating for universal suffrage had to-day one of their periodical collisions with the police. After a mass meeting, in which they were addressed by Social Democratic orators, 10,000 of them marched out into the Ring Strasse toward the Reichsrath. Two companies of mounted police, who had been called out the moment the procession started, met the head of the column and ordered the men to disperse.

The local elections in Brooklyn this year are very important -- much more so than might be inferred from the general character of the offices to be filled. The chief of these are five in number, two in the city and three in the county, but since the annexation of last year the city and county are practically one.

Ex-Speaker Reed said in this city a few days ago that it was "useless to discuss the new tariff " because it would be impossible for the Republicans to substitute for it a tariff of their own until after the expiration of Mr. Cleveland's term. In his interview at Ann Arbor he goes further.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- The statement of the September earnings of the North Chicago Railway is very satisfactory, showing about equal to the earnings of last year and $30,000 in excess of the corresponding month in 1892. With electrical extensions and saving by use of electricity, the earnings from this time on will increase in even heavier ratio.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- The Grand Duke Vladimir, the Czar's eldest brother, started this evening for Livadia. He will go by way of Vienna, and throughout his journey will receive dispatches as to the Czar's condition. The Russian Embassy here has heard nothing from Livadia concerning a change for the worse.

The argument in the habeas corpus proceedings in the case of J. James Howard, Levi P. Morton's imported coachman, who is under detention by the immigration authorities for an infraction of the alien contract labor law, was heard before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Naval Inspection Board, of which Commodore Selfridge is President, returned to Washington to-day from Hampton Roads after spending two days in a thorough test of the new Government-built cruiser Raleigh, built in the Norfolk Navy Yard, with results which far exceeded the most sanguine expectations.
The Committee of Seventy sat down yesterday and made computations as to the cost of the campaign which it proposes to make in behalf of a decent City Government.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 18 -- The class of '97 won at the annual handicap athletic meet at Dartmouth, scoring 80 points. Stephen Chase, '96, of Hanover, N.H., who holds at present the world's record for 120-yard high hurdles, was the best individual athlete, taking four firsts and two thirds. Gay Garry, '98, the bicyclist, proved an important addition to Dartmouth athletes.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- The Rev. James A. McFaul, late rector of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church of this city, was to-day consecrated Bishop of Trenton. The consecration took place in St. Mary's Church. Archbishop Corrigan of New-York City acted as consecrator, his assistants being Bishops McQuaid of Rochester, N.Y., and McDonnell of Brooklyn.

The Emma Willard Association held its fourth annual reunion at the Hotel Windsor yesterday. An elaborate banquet was served at 1 o'clock to over 200 members of the association, which is composed of the graduates of the Troy Female Seminary.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- The annual meeting of the Association of Collegiate Alumnae is to be held in this city Thursday, Friday, and Saturday of next week, and Miss Jessie K. Dewell of 200 Orangre Street, Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements, is busy attending to the final details for the meeting.

PHILADELPHIA. Oct. 18 -- There will be another big baseball league bidding for public patronage next Summer. The rumored formation of the new association became a fact to-day, when a meeting of the men interested was held here and the preliminary work of the organization was completed. Delegates from seven cities met at the Colonnade Hotel this morning and held an all-day session.

The National Distributing Company, which was incorporated a few weeks ago, has prepared a surprise for the trade. Last Monday the company organized by electing Lawrence H. Quinn President, Morris H. Woolner Secretary and Treasurer, and Directors Samuel Woolner, Samuel Woolner, Jr., and S.M. Rice.

In its present headless condition Tammany's use of political power is attended by results similar to those which ensue when an active but hapless child seizes upon a loaded revolver. Some of the family are pretty sure to be killed, and the baby, of course, always makes an end of itself.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- There was a big line of "calls" that prevented wheat prices from holding the entire gain they made during to-day's session, the selling against those privileges being most active during the closing fifteen minutes' trading. There was decidedly a better tone to the market to-day than has been felt in some time, and the bulls were inclined to pluck up courage and buy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Secretary Lament will, in the next week, designate to regiments the twelve young men, non-commissioned officers of the army, who have successfully passed an examination for promotion to passed Lieutenant. The successful candidates, in the order of merit, are:

FORT WORTH, Texas, Oct. 19 -- The west-bound Texas and Pacific through express train for California, leaving here at 9:05 this morning, was robbed about noon to-day near Gordon, seventy miles west of here.

A small lot of gold, $500,000, was engaged for shipment early yesterday, but as an outgo of a much larger amount had been expected, the incident had little or no influence on the stock market. Furthermore, the shipment had hardly been announced when foreign exchange rates weakened perceptibly on a liberal offering of cotton and grain bills, and further engagements became impracticable.

The proceedings of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment were enlivened yesterday by a heated argument between Mayor Gilroy and Dr. Charles E. Simmons, one of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction.
Col. Strong's headquarters presented a very lively appearance yesterday.
Miss Sylvia Bogert is a little woman of about twenty years who is determined to cause a Brooklyn tailor much trouble.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- It is reported that the Dowager Duchess of Montrose, who races horses under the name of "Mr. Manton," is dying.

This is a most unfortunate year for Tammany. The Lexow committee has been developing the most damaging testimony about the manner in which "the organization" has run "the force," and has gone near to persuade the public that the organization and the force are two chases of a conspiracy of criminals to rota and bully the decent people of the town.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The cruiser Detroit in sailing from Norfolk for Newport, R.I., a few days ago, is ascertained to have left behind about twenty-five of her crew, who deserted, while she lay at the navy yard. These desertions were caused, in great part, by the overcrowding of men J in small and uncomfortable quarters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Congress of Argentina, following the example of the United States, is now considering a bill looking to a material deduction of customs duties. Such a bill has been already reported from committee. It is designed principally to affect the higher rates on foreign importations.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Oct. 19 -- The body of an unknown man, with his skull crushed and his clothing torn to shreds, was found in Bowery Bay this afternoon by John Zimmer and three other men of Steinway, who were fishing. The body was bleeding from nose and eyes.

ALBANY N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Gov. Flower returned from New-York this morning, and resumed work at his desk in the Executive Chamber. An early caller was ex-State Engineer and Surveyor Schenck, who received from the Governor an appointment as Chief of Engineers on his staff. The position is an honorary one, but calls for the services of a civil engineer, and carries with it the rank of Brigadier General.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- The only feature of to-day's market was its intense dullness. There were neither fluctuations nor gossip of importance, and sluggishness characterized the trading. Bell Telephone advanced 1 1/2 per cent. further, to 197 1/2. Erie Telephone was quiet at 54. Lamson Store Service was steady at 24.

WASHINGTON Oct. 19 -- The annual report of George W. Melville, Engineer in Chief of the Navy, was made public to-day. He declares that the United States has several ships which are far superior in fighting and manoeuvring power, as well as in speed and endurance, to any afloat.
At Tattensalls sale yesterday G.W. Crawford of Newark, Ohio, disposed of twenty head of all 'round horses at prices which were in finer of buyers. The following were the best of the consignment:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- The fourth annual reunion of the Harris Light Cavalry Survivors Association, which is known better in military records as the Second NewYork Volunteer Cavalry, Third Division, First Brigade, was held here to-day.

The Women's Municipal League held a mass meeting in Cooper Union yesterday afternoon to take action against Tammany Hall and to listen to what the Rev. Dr. C.H. Parkhurst had to say about the investigations of the Lexow committee.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 19 --The Governors of the Newport Casino made a report of their finances to-day. July 1, 1886, their liabilities were: First mortgage, $1OO,OOO; second mortgage, $9,000; floating debt, $3,700; total, $112,700. Their liabilities Oct. 17, 1894, were: First mortgage, $49,OOO; second mortgage, $20,000; total, $69,000.

An attempt was made yesterday afternoon to kill H. Pomeroy Davison, the paying teller of the Astor Place Bank. The attempt failed only because of the vigilance of the Police Department and Detective Sergeant Freel, who arrested the would-be murderer.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 19 -- Fifteen fair golfers, played a spirited game around the pretty little links of the Morris County Golf Club this afternoon in a contest for a handsome silver trophy given by Miss Susan De Forest Day. It was the third of the great four-day tournament series held by the club.

STAPLETON, S. I., Oct. 19 -- The Rich- mond County Democratic Convention was held Tuesday night. It was largely attended and enthusiastic. An address was made by ex-Speaker William Sulzer of New-York. The following nominations were unanimously made:
LONDON, Oct. 19. -- The Russian Embassy here has received a dispatch from Livadia, saying that the condition of the Czar is desperate.

The two children of Mrs. Urchittel, who were sent to the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, on the testimony of Ward Men Hussy and Shalvey of the Twelfth Precinct, were restored yesterday to their mother by John W. Goff, in the presence of the Senate Investigating Committee and a crowd in the courtroom where the committee meets.

While in full operation, the "bucket shop" at 38 New Street, which for several months has been conducted under the name of the Stearns Commission Company, was visited by Police Inspector Williams and four other police officers yesterday afternoon. The visit was evidently unexpected, for the policemen found eight clerks at work and were able to seize $3,200 in cash.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The market was fairly active, but for the most part heavy. The exception was Diamond Match, which is now verifying the predictions of its friends, who said it was a good purchase when the stock was selling at 125@130. It sold up to 138 1/2 to-day, and closed at 138 1/4. West Chicago was a disappointment early in the day to the bulls.

Thomas C. Platt will not soon enjoy a repetition of the pleasure he has several times experienced, by being driven from the Rhinecliff railroad station to "Ellerslie" by Levi P. Morton's nobby English coachman. J. James Howard.

The personality of the author of these books, which are in the first line of those that popularity extols, and of which we have here beautiful editions, is not inseparable from his literary work since Thiers has passed into history as a statesman. It would be something of an illumination of the history he wrote to retrace even the physical appearance of the historian.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- A dispatch received here from Livadia, by way of St. Petersburg, says that yesterday the Czar was suddenly attacked with a spasm directly affecting his breast. He was compelled to lie down, and his confessor. Father Yanischew, was summoned immediately. Nevertheless, the dispatch says, Prof. Leyden has hopes of his Majesty's ultimate recovery.
Samuel Booth, the sixteenth Mayor of Brooklyn, died at his home, in that city, 50 South Portland Avenue, at 5 o'clock yesterday morning, in his seventy-seventh year.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- In answer to a question asked by Norton Chase of this city, whether the ballots authorized and provided for by the late Constitutional Convention should be numbered, Attorney General Haricock gave out this non-committal opinion to-night:

The nomination of Hugh J. Grant by Tammany' Hall as its candidate for Mayor of this city recalls the fact that while he was Mayor of the city he and others appeared upon the witness stand in the investigation of the City Departments made by the Fassett Senate committee.

Bradstreet's to-morrow will say: "With few exceptions, the leading features of the business situation this week have been those of continued moderate improvement, although the total volume of business, so far as indicated by bank clearing's throughout the country, will require considerable expansion to compare favorably with corresponding totals two years ago.

Charles H. Luscomb, President of the League of American Wheelmen, has had an interesting correspondence with Levi P. Morton and David B. Hill, the candidates for Governor. It was Mr. Luscomb's purpose to find out for the cyclists of the Empire State just how the candidates stood on the important question of highway improvement.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 -- Satolli is to be made a Cardinal. This much is all that can be stated with certainty. Seven-tenths of what has been printed upon this subject is the vaguest speculation. He will probably be named at the next Consistory which will convene in Rome.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 19 -- The Board of Finance, at a secret session last night, adopted resolutions relative to the water question. The parts of the resolutions bearing particularly on the matter are as follows:

Nathan Straus has left the field in the municipal political struggle, and ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant has taken up the standard of Tammany and is trying to rally the discouraged and disheartened forces of the Wigwam to combat with the overwhelming army of the opposition.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 19 -- Another formidable candidate for the trotting stallion championship appeared here to-day in Ralph Wilkes, who twice improved his record of 2:08 12, made on Wednesday. His second trial, in 2:06 3/4, places him next to Directum, and more than one competent horseman who saw the performance believes that the Boston crack is capable of greater things.
BUFFALO, Oct. 19. -- Senator Hill was enthusiastically received to-night at Music Hall by an audience of 5,000 persons. As many more had been unable to gain admittance to the hall.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Oct. 19 -- The bodies of Miss Mary Duff and her fiance, Ellett Livingston Titus, who were found together dead in the Duff family bathhouse, on the shore front here, Wednesday night, were removed to their homes in Brooklyn to-day.

The football teams of Princeton, Yale, and the University of Pennsylvania will play in this vicinity to-day. Princeton will play Cornell at Manhattan Field, the Pennsylvanians will meet the Crescents at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, and Tale will play the Orange Athletic Club eleven at Orange Oval.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Acting under instructions already given, now that Judge Lacombe has decided that he has no jurisdiction in the case of J. James Howard, imported under contract as under coachman for ex-Vice President Morton, Immigrant Commissioner Senner at New-York will immediately deport Howard, and United States District Attorney Macfarlane will enter civil suit against Mr. Morton for violation of the alien contract labor law.

There is an opportunity this year to take an approximate measure of the Tammany vote, as distinguished from the Democratic vote in this city. It has not been done for many years. The nearest approach to it was in 1888, when Hugh J. Grant was elected Mayor the first time.

The Police Commisioners yesterday considered a communication from the Board of Inspectors of the Thirty-third Election District. Charles Hellerson of 37 East Fifty-fifth Street went before the board. He was born in Belgium, came to this country when fifteen years old, has no naturalization papers, but has voted in this city.

Tammany does not change by changing candidates. Under any Mayor of its own nomination and elected by its own votes it would be the same corrupt, shameless, and greedy organization. Mr. Grant is beyond doubt a fitter candidate for Tammany than Mr. Straus. It would have been more brazen, but also more candid and honest, to put him forward in the first place.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- A dispatch to The Globe from Tien-Tsin says the Chinese fleet at Port Arthur was yesterday ordered to sea.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Oct. 19 -- Isidor Straus of New-York arrived on the noon train to call on the President. He was not expected. The President was enjoying his last sail down the bay on the Ruth when Mr. Straus arrived, and did not return until the middle of the afternoon, when he saw Mr. Straus for a short time.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- The marriage of Dr. Charles Emerson Townsend of Newburg and Miss Lent M. Hinchman of this city occurred at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church last evening. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Darwood, pastor of St. Paul's, in the presence of a large assemblage of invited guests, many of whom were from abroad.

ALBION, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Emma Hunt, sighteen years old, pretty, and of good character, has worked for Joseph Van Camp, at Sawyer, eight miles north of here, since last Spring. William Lake, twenty-six years old and unmarried, also was employed by Mr. Van Camp, and all through the Summer, Lake paid court to Emma Hunt.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- The local market to-day has been moderately active, and St. Paul was in demand by the shorts. Reading was dull until the last-hour, when it advanced fractionally. Small lots of Pennsylvania, Lehigh Valley, and Lehigh Navigation were in demand for investment at ruling quotations.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Senator Hill was shown a United Press dispatch to-night reviewing the local Democratic situation in New-York City which led up to the nomination to-day of Hugh J. Grant for Mayor on the retirement of Nathan Straus.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- The Journal des Debats, in an article on the situation in the East, says: "The European powers cannot interfere in any way with Japan's rapid successes. The condition of affairs in China is certain to jeopardize the safety of foreigners residing in that country. Russia will contest the annexation by Japan of Corea.

William H. Crane will discard the habiliments of Falstaff to-morrow night, and appear at the Star Theatre in "The Pacific Mail," which is a freely-adapted version by Paul M. Potter of Tom Taylor's comedy, "The Overland Route." Many old playgoers will remember this piece as a clever and amusing comedy.
The sales referred to in the accompanying detailed list will be had at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated:

These volumes have a common object. Each author, in his own way, makes a presentation of the condition of the City of New-York and aims to arouse in his fellow-citizens a determination to reform abuses. Observations are made from one and the same point of view and there is a striking similarity in the substance of their criticisms.

The Thirteenth Regiment Armory, in Sumner Avenue, Brooklyn, will be transformed into a great bazaar to-morrow night, when the regimental fair will be opened. The building has been decorated in the most artistic manner. The main drill floor will contain the many booths, at which prominent society women will sell various wares to the people who will be in attendance.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 20 -- Gov. McKinley of Ohio reached here this afternoon and to-night he addressed a large audience of Louisiana Republicans and sugar men. Before he was introduced there was read a long letter from United States Senator Manderson of Nebraska, in which he committed the Republicans to the restoration of the sugar bounty.

Yachtsmen are waiting for Lord Dunraven's challenge for a cup race next year. It may be expected now by any mail, and, judging by the cable reports that have come over about the new boat that Watson is to build, the race will be for first-class boats and under conditions very similar to those which governed last year's races. Watson is designing a cutter for the ninety-foot class.

Mr. Lehmann, 2,264 Seventh Av., says: "I had rheumatism in my arm so badly that it was as useless as though paralyzed. The shooting pains in the arm and shoulder were so terrible that I was almost frantic. I consulted Prof. Munyon and used his Rheumatism Cure. In forty-eight hours my pain was all gone, and in less than a week I was completely cured."

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Union defeated Amherst at football this afternoon by a score of 6 to 0. The game was played on the Ridgefield grounds, in the presence of 1,500 persons. The defense playing of Amherst was weak. Union made most of her gains between her right tackle and end. The first half was won for Union by a touch-down made by Richards, who kicked a goal.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- David B. Hill and Daniel N. Lockwood arrived here from Buffalo to-day just before noon. At 2 o'clock the mass meeting was called in the old Armory Hall by Frank H. Mott, a young Jamestown lawyer, who is President of the Hill Democratic Club. Senator Hill, Mr. Lockwood, and Louis W. Pratt of Albany addressed the meeting.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- James Anthony Froude, LL.D., the celebrated religious writer and historian, died at 6:30 o'clock this morning, aged seventy-six years.

The question has lately been under discussion whether the English thoroughbred is really English. Admiral Rous, perhaps the greatest contemporary authority upon the subject, was of the opinion that the English thoroughbred, from which our American thoroughbreds and trotters are descended, is himself not an English horse at all, but a pure Arabian that has grown large under the influence of the British climate, grass, and nurture.

Michael Burns of 327 East Thirty-second Street jumped from a fifth-floor window of the Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Exchange Building, Spring and Wooster Streets, shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday, and received what are thought to be fatal injuries. He was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- Local stocks were dull and the market, without exception, was uninteresting. Prices generally were strong, though there were hardly sales enough to determine the actual tone. The feeling here is against any great activity, unless business shows something more than the very moderate improvement that it has exhibited in the past few months.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The people of Sing Sing think that, as its fair name has the stigma of prison attached to it, it should have some recognition, and efforts are being made to have President of the Village Abram Hyatt appointed Agent and Warden to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Warden C.F. Durston of Sing Sing Prison.

PARIS, Oct. 12 -- I spoke here several weeks ago of the new discovery of the croup remedy. Since then the glad tidings have been heralded, and, finaily, as in almost everything else, money is required to enable the Pasteur Institute to meet the demand for the vaccine. It seems probable that the subscription known as the "Fondation Carnot," will go to this fund.

Several of the Democratic candidates for Congress in this city and vicinity have been placed in the line of promotion by their party for services performed in local or legislative work. In this city, the gentlemen selected by Tammany for promotion are William Sulzer, in the Eleventh District; Col. George Brinton McClellan, in the Twelfth; John Connelly, in the Fourteenth, and Jacob A. Cantor in the Fifteenth.

The time is close at hand when we shall hear of numerous fires in private dwellings "due to defective flues." If the truth were to be told, many of these cases should be described as "dirty flues," but politeness forbids. Furnace and kitchen flues should be thoroughly cleaned once a year, and that should be just before the Winter fires are lighted. The grate or fireplace will ordinarily secure attention by smoking unbearably.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Mrs. Edith T. Balch of Voorhees, Ill., came to Washington Thursday for the purpose at seeing President Cleveland to secure the settlement of her birthright and $1,500,000, which she claimed was due her by the Government. She was arrested for creating a disturbance at the White House, and will be sent home by the authorities this afternoon.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 20 -- The first flurry of snow came Sunday night, and Monday morning the hills about Lenox reminded the cottagers of Winter. It disappeared, however, as quickly as it had come. Few of the cottagers are going away. They are still enjoying the bright October weather in driving, golf, and evening entertainments.

KINGSTON, Mass., Oct. 20. -- Capt. Parker J. Hall, who was acquitted of the charge of murder at Long Island City Wednesday, has contracted with the Government to use his schooner, the Robert P. King, for a lightship. Capt. Hall will command the King, which will be stationed off Long Island soon.
The bronze statue erected to the memory of Dr. James Marion Sims in Bryant Park was unveiled at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- A dispatch from Shanghai to the Central News says the Chinese report that a battle has been fought on the banks of the Lower Yalu in which the Japanese troops, who made the attack, were repulsed with heavy losses. It is added that neither side claims a decisive victory.

A distinguished and trustworthy railroad statistician, in commenting upon an article recently printed on this page of The Times urging the necessity of uniform railroad accounts for public information, writes as follows: "Uniformity in the keeping of railroad accounts must come if railroad property in the United States is to continue private property.

WEDNESDAY, OCT. 24 -- By Bryan L. Kennelly, auction sale, 311 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, north aide, about 100 feet east of Second Avenue, 25 by 100.11, four-story and basement brick flat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The automatic repeating pistol of new design, made the subject of an interesting report from an army officer at Berlin and referred to in The Times of Sunday last, interests the ordnance officials of this country, who are anxious to obtain one of the weapons, with a view to experimenting with it.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- There were 15,000 disappointed spectators at Mystic Park this afternoon when Alix and Directum came together in the much-talked-of match race, which was expected to settle the question of supremacy as between these two renowned trotters, and to develop one of the fastest and hardest-fought contests on record.

The Tammany candidate for Mayor, Hugh J. Grant, served one term as Sheriff of New-York County. After he had retired from that office, and was Mayor of this city, March 25, 1890, the Grand Jury made a strong presentment against the administrations of Sheriffs Flack and Grant. Eight of the Sheriff's subordinates had been Indicted for bribery and extortion when this presentment was made, and it reads, in part, as follows:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- It was in the Spring of 1720 when a Frenchman named Martclaire decided to settle on some of the unclaimed land far up the Hudson. He was one of a party of Huguenots driven a few years previous from France by religious persecution. A French colony had been established at Esopus, (now Kingston,) about 1660.

Berlin, Conn., Oct. 20 -- The New-Britain Architectural Terra-Cotta Works here were burned this morning, with a loss of $50,000. There is an insurance of $13,000 in the Phoenix and Aetna of this city, the Phoenix, the City, and the Hamburg of New-York, and the American of Boston. Finished stock worth $30,000 was destroyed.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- This new Russian tragedy stirs Europe even more profoundly than did the memorable assassination of March, 1881, for sharp and universal as that shock was, it was, after all, localized and personal, and the excitement spent itself largely, as in the recent case of President Carnot, in mingled pity for the victim and curiosity about the crime and its perpetrators.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 20 -- Conflicting rumors in regard to the condition of the Czar are increasing. Official circles either profess to have no information or positively refuse to furnish any, and several Russian journals, unable to get news otherwise, are sending correspondents to Livadia.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- The Federal Council sat yesterday for the first time since the recess. The official newspapers say that the members communicated to one another and debated the views of their Governments regarding the proposals to limit the rights of assembly and association, so as to enlighten the imperial Chancellor and his colleagues on the attitudes of the Federal States.

UPPER MARLBOROUGH, Md., Oct. 20 -- Stephen Williams, colored, who attacked Mrs. Catherine Ann Hardesty, near Woodmore, Wednesday night, was taken from the jail this morning by fifty masked men and lynched. Williams had admitted his crime before being committed to the jail.

There are so many merchants advertising furs -- so many different kinds of merchants advertising furs -- under so many different names, (names which never appeared in natural history or the encyclopaedia up to date,) that it is no wonder ladies become demoralized and hardly Know whom to believe or where to buy.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Sunshine and frost have brought the glow and color of October to Lakewood foliage, especially to the trees and shrubs near the lake, where the brilliant tints of the maple and sumac, with a touch of flaming yellow in the sassafras, make a gorgeous mass of varying color.

Saulte Ste. Marie, Mich., Oct. 20 -- Grave fears are felt for the safety of Judge J.H. Steers of this city, one of the most prominent men of the Upper Peninsula. He went hunting three weeks ago with John Boucher, an Indian guide, expecting to remain away a week. Nothing has been heard of them since. A party started to-day to search for the missing men.

Chivalry had been left very far behind when Wallhausen wrote on military instruction, in 1616. By his directions the lancer fixes his spear point not in his opponent's cuirass, but in the head of his horse, and harquebuse, pistol, and musket are alike leveled at the hapless beast instead of at the rider.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The annual report of Engineer in Chief Melville of the navy, as given out at the Navy Department, surprises every one familiar with that officer's terseness of comment by being a wonderfully lifeless document. It contains a formal statement of what has been accomplished during the year in the way of machinery for new vessels, and in the designing of engines.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The market was featureless, except for the brewing stocks and Diamond Match. The latter security advanced 3/4 more, to 139, the highest point it has reached for months, and the demand continues. The buying appears to emanate from every quarter, indicating a surprising confidence in the management of the company.

Old Bennett, in his comfortable ranchhouse on the site of old Fort Ross, at the mouth of the Russian River, California, has a trophy of the chase which he delights to show visitors. It consists of a grizzly bear's head so big and heavy that two men can scarcely lift it, also pads nine inches wide and fifteen inches long.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- This week has been productive of a number of incidents which have given much encouragement to the Democratic leaders. The most gratifying sign of Republican concern over the outcome of the campaign is found in their attempt to undermine the Democrats in districts where, up to the present time, there has not been much effort to create enthusiasm because of the belief that the normal Democratic vote could not be weakened.

We are to receive with a certain amount of hesitancy accounts of discoveries made in Guatemala, "not far from the base of the Volcan de Aqua." In a certain locality, Atitlan, the remains of habitations of men, it is said, have been found. A Madrid paper, heralding the discovery, tells "of earthenware chiseled with care and painted with brilliant colors."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The best game of football ever played on the grounds of the Peekskill Military Academy was seen this afternoon between the Academy eleven and College of the City of New-York team. Over 500 spectators witnessed the game. In the first half Sherman, for Peekskill, made a touch-down seven minutes after play began.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 20 -- The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Twelfth District, held here to-day, nominated George E. Lounsbury of Ridgefield, a brother of ex-Gov. Lounsbury for Senator. The Probate Convention nominated Louis J. Curtis for Judge of Probate for this district.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Copyright, 1894. -- The only feature in the money market here is a slight hardening of loan rates. The banks evince a disposition to hold their money in preference to lending it at the prevailing rate of 1/4 per cent. A small efflux has taken place to the Continent, where rates are better.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Oct. 20 -- The new Presbyterian Church in this village, made possible by the generous bequest of the late John Goldsmith Payntar, is almost ready for dedication. The church is an exact copy of the Presbyterian Church at Cherry Valley, N.Y., which was always greatly admired by Mr. Payntar.

THURSDAY, OCT. 25 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Louis B. Hasbrouck, referee, 236 East Ninety-seventh Street, south side, 75 feet west of Second Avenue, 25 by 75, four-story brick tenement, with store. Due on Judgment, $2,980; on prior mortgage, $11,700.

The course of business during the past week among real estate men affords much reason for satisfaction. Results are beginning to show for some of the work that has been done. Sales are being made which indicate that there is no lack of confidence in the future of values, and both speculators and investors are in the market.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Monsignor Francis Satolli, the Papal Delegate to the United States, was grossly insulted this morning at the house of the Rev. Sebastian B. Smith of St. Joseph's Church, by a committee of eleven representatives of the Catholic Club of this city, who forced their way into the house, and demanded an interview with the Pope's representative.
The bronze bust of Beethoven which was won in the singing contest of last Summer in Madison Square Garden by the United Singers of Brooklyn was formally presented to the City of Brooklyn yesteray.

ALBION, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- The shocking murder of pretty Emma Louise Hunt, employed on the farm of Charles Van Camp, near here, which was committed Thursday night, was the work of the farm hand, William Lake, as suspected from the first.

ELKINS, Randolph County, West Va., Oct. 20 -- A week spent with Congressman W.L. Wilson in these mountain wilds of West Virginia has shown that the constituents of the great tariff reformer thoroughly appreciate the importance of his present campaign.
