The zeal of the Democracy is a revelation, even to Mr. Wilson himself, and his meetings, without a single exception, have been phenomenal for their size.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- A unique elopement has just been reported as taking place here. The participants are Miss Rose Dayton of this city and Dr. Hugh Copeland McCord of Bridgeport. Miss Dayton is the daughter of one of the wealthiest oyster dealers in this State.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The question of cheaper bread has attracted much attention this week. The Washington public has just awakened to the fact that while flour costs less by $2.50 a barrel than it did two years ago, the price of bread is still 5 cents a loaf, just is it was when wheat was selling at $1 a bushel and flour was considered cheap at $6 a barrel.

Lawrence D. Galligan, an agent for the Oil Well Supply Company of this city, is an American to the backbone. He has been traveling for the last seven years through Russia in the interest of his firm, and, incidentally, telling every one he met in that despotic country what an Eden his native country was.

But, whether he be elected or not, the State cannot survive without profound and permanent loss a deliberate affirmation by the people at the polls that they prefer to limit our choice in future politics to the things for which David B. Hill stands on the one hand, or for which Thomas C. Platt stands on the other.

Eleven young men from Cornell rather surprised the Princeton champions at football yesterday. The game was played on Manhattan Field, and the Cornell boys not only kept Princeton's score down to 12 points, but made 4 themselves. Last year the Princeton team defeated Cornell by 46 to 0.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 20 -- Gen. Harrison started from Fort Wayne on his return trip to Indianapolis this morning. His route to-day was a triangular one -- northwest from Fort Wayne to Plymouth, southwest to Lafayette, and southeast to this city. His first speech was at Columbia City, where he urged protection on the authority of a letter written by Andrew Jackson and accused the Democrats of being subservient to British influences.

The change from the rush of a through express to the quiet of a remote roadside inn can hardly be classed among the ordinary risks of travel; but then a strike has not yet come to take the place of a stopover ticket. The train in question had stopped and backed and gone ahead, and then stopped, to back again, with all that irritating reiteration which only a train, cut from its schedule, can exhibit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Gen. Howard's attack on the post-exchange system of the army has excited much opposition among brother officers in Washington. Gen. Howard, in the report which has been made public, while acknowledging his extreme views on such matters, puts forth the expressions of an officer stationed at Governors Island who drew a graphic picture of "gouty soldiers" enjoying lives of luxury.

Stumps have been drawn for the cricket year, and the season of 1894 will be long remembered as an eventral one, not alone in New-York, but everywhere else throughout the country, where the game made rapid strides toward popularity.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The Government investigation into the alleged violation of the inter-State commerce law by the Santa Fe Railroad in the payment of rebates to shippers resulted yesterday in the voting of indictments. These indictments, following close upon those of Baltimore and Ohio officials at Pittsburg, have created a decidedly uneasy feeling among the officers of the various roads in the city.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 20 -- The marriage of Miss Caroline Bayard Dod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Bayard Dod, and Sidney Morse Colgate in the Central Presbyterian Church on Tuesday afternoon has been the most notable social event of the week. The ceremony was performed by the father of the bride, assisted by the Rev. John Fulton Patterson, pastor of the church.
Patrick Divver has resigned the leadership of Tammany Hall in the Second Assembly District. Tammany has unloaded him; at least that is the way the organization wants the public to look at it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The future issues of the "Notes and Statistics of the Organization, Armament, and Military Progress in American and European Armies," a volume of which has just been issued by the War Department, will be looked for with pleasure by men interested in military problems.

The State Republican Executive Committee yesterday decided the dead-lock in Gen. Curtis's district by declaring him the Congressional candidate in the Twenty-second District. The decision was on a technicality, and caused hard feeling on the part of the defeated man's friends.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 20 -- The last of the big four-day tournament held on the grounds of the Morris County Golf Club was finished this afternoon. The contest was for the men's silver cup, presented by Mrs. H. McK. Twombley, Vice President of the club, and after a close and exciting fight Mr. William Shippen won, beating Henry P. Phipps, the former champion of the club, by three strokes.

Mr. Anton Seidl is making earnest efforts to push his orchestra into the very vanguard of concert organizations, and with a fair promise of success. It will be known hereafter as the Seidl Orchestra, the old title of Metropolitan being consigned to oblivion. The members of the orchestra are all competent musicians, who occupy leading desks in the Philharmonic Society, and they have had the benefit of long training under Mr. Seidl.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Since the new Tariff act went into effect, providing for free wool, a great boom has occurred in the business of the hat shops of this city. Both the Wallkill and the Monhagen shops are now running at full capacity, and are working overtime at that, running from 7 A.M. until 9 P.M.

Theoretically nobody is in favor of gambling. Practically there are not many people so austere as never, in any circumstances, to make bets. The anti-gambling amendment proposed to be incorporated in the Constitution of this State is a measure the practical aspects of which are in some danger of being overlooked, especially in the farming districts.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- Harvard beat Williams to-day in a game replete with interest. The final score was 32 to 0. There was a crowd of 4,000 persons present. The playing on both sides was far better than any game seen on Soldiers Field this year or any other year. Harvard played better than any enthusiastic supporter had supposed was possible.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The fiasco made by Lord Rosebery in the attempt to intervene for a friendly settlement of the China-Japanese trouble is adversely commented upon, even by the Liberal press. The Economist says the Premier will be required to justify before Parliament his successive diplomatic defeats.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 6 -- Many persons now here -- former residents of Colombia -- believe that upon the expiration of the official mourning, thirty days, for the late President, Dr. Rafael Nunez, the long-threatened revolutionary movement will be initiated in the struggle between the Conservative, or Clerical, Party and the Liberals, who are the progressists in Colombia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Mr. Reed's interview at Ann Arbor, qualifies, but not repudiated at Chicago, continues to be discussed with animation by Democrats and Repubcans of the capital, and it gives increasing dissatisfaction to the Bourbon Republicans, who base their hopes for future victories for the party upon the promising of a return to the McKinley taxes.
Carl Browne, the Coxeyite, tried to make a speech yesterday from the steps of the Sub-Treasury. He succeeded in landing at Police Headquarters, a prisoner.

James Darmesteter, the highly-esteemed Professor of Persian Language and Literature at the College de France and the learned Orientalist whom all serious students admired, died at Maisons-Lafitte, near Paris, last Friday.

NUTLEY, N.J., Oct. 20 -- A number of the leading citizens of Nutley, N.J., claim that a very unjust and unequal system of taxation exists there, and they are determined to bring the matter before the State Board of Revision for the purpose of having the situation thoroughly considered and the unjust methods abated.
The heavy fog that settled down over the bay and rivers yesterday morning caused several collisions of a minor nature, and one wherein a tugboat was sunk and carried with her one of her crew.

Americans should be proud of their trees. Apart from their elements of beauty and utility, they possess, also, a historical interest which patriotic Americans can ill afford to ignore. Such was the famous Charter Oak, which stood in the City of Hartford Until 1854, when it was blown down by a furious storm.

The vote of the State of Georgia on the amendments to the Constitution proves that the people are not disposed to tamper with the organic law. The defeat of the increase of the Supreme Court Justices is probably due to the financial depression at this time and the unwillingness of the people to make new offices and salaries.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- Senator Hill and party arrived here over the Erie Railroad, from Jamestown, shortly after 6 o'clock to-night. At 8 o'clock Senator Hill; Mr. Lockwood, and Mr. Pratt were escorted to the Academy of Music amid the glare of colored fire and the display of rockets, a citizens' cavalry and delegates from various places in the county acting as escort.

It was a typical Saturday half-holiday market. The transactions were 68,819 shares, and the only stock in which 10,000 shares were done was Sugar. The stock was rather heavy, its highest price -- 87 -- being made at the opening, its lowest -- 86 1/4 -- just before the close. On the day's business it lost a point.

To those who are aware of the proficiency and courage shown by French sportsmen in their pursuit of big carnivora, it will be no surprise to learn that the Governor of the Straits Settlements has just selected a citizen of that aspiring nation -- M. de Nancourt by name -- to fill the post of "Tiger-Slayer-in-Chief" at Singapore.
The prospects of the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn are unusually bright this year.
MICHAEL DOHERTY, ex-Captain of the Fourteenth Precinct, dismissed from the police force July 26, 1894, for receiving money from Augusta Thorow for "protection."

ROCHESTER, Oct. 21 -- At a meeting of the University Glee and Mandolin Clubs on Thursday P.A. Blossom, '95, was elected manager for the coming season. He will lay out a trip through Northern Pennsylvania for the Christmas vacation. Prof. La Bonde was elected Director. He gave a recital before the organization on Wednesday evening.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 21 -- Francis Jarvis, forty-one years old, of 148 West Seventeenth Street, New-York, was arrested at his home this morning by Detectives from this city, on a charge of petty larceny. He was brought here and released on $500 bail.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Oct. 21 -- This was A.P.A. day at Prohibition Park, and the members of that and kindred organizations to the number of 2,000 gathered in the park auditorium this afternoon to hear Alfred N. Martin in a reply to the Rev. Dr. McGlynn.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 20 -- There is some activity in the local stock market, and prices are fairly well sustained. The lack of selling orders is still quite noticeable, a fact which in a measure accounts for the few trades which have taken place during the last week. American National Bank stock has been sold at 49 1/2.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- The annual congress of the Social Democrats opened to-day in Frankfort-on-the-Main. The party's finances are, as usual, in good condition, showing at once the economy and sagacity with which they are administered. The usual surplus for the general treasury has been left, after the payment of all expenses of the agitation.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Oct. 21 -- Nothing has yet been heard from the Peary expedition steamer Falcon, which sailed from Philadelphia Oct. 3 for this port. The Allan Liner Corean, which arrived here last night from Philadelphia, saw nothing of the Falcon on her passage, nor any wreckage or indication of what has become of her.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Merton A. Church, who has been for the last two years Superintendent of the Port Chester Electric Light and Gaslight Company's plant, was found dead in bed this morning beside the unconscious body of hs wife. His death had been caused by gas escaping from a stove which was connected with his bedroom by an old-fashioned drum. Mrs. Church may recover.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- A careful investigation of political conditions in Ontario leads to the belief that the county will show a substantial reduction from Palmer's Republican plurality of 1,442 for Secretary of State a year ago. The first reason for this is found in the fact that there was both Democratic defection and indifference in some of the towns last year, especially in Phelps and Geneva.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 21 -- Rochester's registration is 32,018, an increase of 314 over 1892 and 6,523 over that of 1893.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- There was a good investment demand for both local stocks and bonds during the last week. About all the changes made in quotations were toward a higher range. Sales were made of several small lots of Albany Railway, also of a fifty-share lot of Troy Rail-way. There was a demand for Saranac and Lake Placid Railroad, and a bid of 50 was made, which failed to meet any stock.
At a regular meeting of the Tenth Ward Jefferson Society of Democratic Voters, Brooklyn, held Saturday evening in Todd Hall, Wyckoff and Bond Streets, the following resolution was adopted:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 21 -- The Asbury Park Board of Trade is making strenuous efforts to obtain additional facilities for handling the increased business of the local Post Office. The board recently appointed a committee to lay the matter before the Postmaster General, and that official has promised to grant the relief asked for.

The curator of the ethnological department of the United States National Museum at Washington, in this volume throws out many side rays of light respecting ethnology, ethnography, prehistoric archaeology, and culture history. And if this be a sample of the coming anthropological series, the completed collection will give intelligent students a full opportunity to become acquainted with the most interesting of all topics, which is anthropology.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- In an interview last evening, Jules Simon said: "Emperor William will do his utmost, in the event of the Czar's death, to win over Russia and detach her friendship from France, but the task will be difficult, for the Franco-Russian alliance rests upon the hearts of the people rather than on the heads of state."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The college monthly. The Vassar Miscellany, began its twenty-fourth, volume with the October number. The Miscellany is edited by the Misses A.L. Crawford, G.S. Boyton, and B.E. Boyd, 95, and the Misses H.O. Scranton and B. McCloskey, '96. Miss Dorrance, '95, and Miss MacArthur, '96, are business managers.

WARSAW, Oct. 21 -- Dispatches from Yalta say that the Czarina is suffering from nervous collapse and paralysis of the legs. Her illness was caused by overwork in the Czar's sicK room, loss of sleep, and constant anxiety. The Grand Duchess Xenia has been confined to her bed for several days. She is said to be suffering from premature childbirth.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- High mass was said in the Greek Church here to-day and special prayers were said for the Czar.

Ex-Mayor Grant's headquarters in the Union Square Hotel were open all day yesterday, and the ex-Mayor was there much of the time directing his campaign. Enough of the followers of Tammany were there to give the rooms a lively appearance, and the work of reorganizing the campaign was in progress.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 21 -- All the heat winners here yesterday showed better form than they have anywhere else this season. The two-yearold colt Oakland Baron reduced his record to 2:14 1/2, going to the Quarter in 0:32, and the half in 1:04 1/2. If the mile had been more evenly rated, the fleet Kentucky youngster would have scored 2:12, at least.

Society received a severe arraignment from the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst in his sermon in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church yesterday morning. The treatment of outcast women was Dr. Parkhurst's theme, and he used language plain and vigorous. A congregation that nearly filled the church listened to the sermon.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 21 -- The Congressional fight has begun in New-Jersey, and it will be the most important of the contests. The Republicans have changed the district lines so as to obtain, if possible, a majority of the delegation. The Democrats propose to give them a hot fight. The nominations are all made, and the National Congress Committees have both completed plans for a very aggressive campaign.

New-York was enveloped in a dense fog yesterday morning. It interfered seriously with navigation on the bay and in the North and East Rivers, and caused several vessels to run aground. No lives were lost and no one was injured, though many persons were badly frightened.

A hospital in memory of Abiel Augustus Low has just been built in Wu-Chang, China, by his sons, Seth Low, President of Columbia College, and Abbot Augustus Low. Mr. Low senior was for many years a successful merchant in Canton.

Six persons have been indicted by the Federal Grand Jury in Chicago for participating in violations of the inter-State commerce law by paying and receiving rebates for shipments of freight over the Atchison system. Ex-President Reinhart and ex-Traffic Manager Hanley are among those indicted for paying the rebates, and Nelson Morris, the well-known cattle dealer, is the principal one indicted for receiving rebates.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., Oct. 21 -- The last supplementary practice shoot of the season took place on the range here yesterday. It being the last opportunity to qualify as sharpshooters and marksmen the attendance was very large. The weather was perfect, with a 6 to 7 o'clock wind. The distances were at 500 and 600 yards. Those who qualified are as follows:

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 21 -- Fully 1,000 persons crowded into the handsome new Church of the Sacred Heart here this morning to witness the ceremonies attending Its consecration. Mgr. Satolli participated in the ceremonies.

Major Gen. O.O. Howard, "the Christian Hero," must retire from the army Nov. 8 because he will then have reached the age. limit of sixty-four years. His retirement will be followed by many changes in the army.

The McKinley newspapers have recently published very gloomy predictions and depressing assertions concerning the manufacture of tin plate. In The Cincinnati Commercial Gazette of the 18th inst. we find a long article, entitled "War on Tin Plate -- The Avalanche of Free Trade Sweeps Down," in which a manufacturer, writing on the preceding day, declares that the "avalanche" has "swept down," and that "all the plants in America are closed."

ALBION, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- William Lake, the murderer of Emma Hunt, was arrested this afternoon, and is safely lodged in jail. He was found hidden in the hay in the large grain barn of Mrs. Rachel Hoag, near Waterport.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Archbishop Corrigan of New-York, and a large number of prominent Catholic clergymen to-day dedicated the Church of Our Lady of Mercy, in Westchester Avenue, this village.

The programme of events for the big cycling tournament in Madison Square Garden Thanksgiving week has been completed and details of the affair arranged. According to Manager Frank W. Sanger of the Garden. Messrs. J.J. Woods, R.G. Betts, and H.L. Saltonstall, representing the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs, have arranged the Class A and B events.
A.G. Van Schaick, Chief of the A.P.A. in this State, came to the city yesterday for the purpose, it is understood, of consulting with the managers of the Republican State campaign.

PATERSON, N.J. Oct. 21 -- The rooms of the Catholic Club were crowded to the doors to-night with angry members of St. Joseph's Parish, who gathered in response to the call of Chairman Richard Salmon of the committee who forced their demand for the removal of the Rev. Sebastian B. Smith on Archbishop Satolli, the Papal Delegate, and in forcing consideration of their claims grossly insulted the great Churchman.
BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- Emperor William received yesterday a deputation from the East Prussian Agrarian League. In replying to an address, he spoke substantially as follows:

PARSONS, Kan., Oct. 21 -- The Missouri Pacific Passenger Train No. 223, on the Kansas and Arkansas Valley Branch, was stopped by four or five masked men at Coretta Siding, seven miles east of Wagoner, Indian Territory, at 10 o'clock last night.

The Rev. John P. Peters, pastor of St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, Ninety-ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, made "Municipal Corruption and Christian Civic Duty" the subject of his sermon at the morning service yesterday.

The striking cloakmakers of Brownsville, asa part of the Twenty-sixth Ward of Brooklyn is called, expressed with revolvers yesterday afternoon their determination to accept nothing but unconditional surrender by their former employers to their demands.
ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- Chairman John Boyd Thacher of the State Democratic Executive Committee spent Sunday at his home in this city.

The concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening was attended by a large and vociferous audience, bound to get its money's worth and have a good time after its kind. A large part of it was grievously disappointed because Mme. Melba failed to appear, and when Stage Manager Parry appeared to make the customary announcement from tne stage some applauded and many others hissed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Ada Rehan closed her first engagement here as a star, under the management of Augustin Daly, last night, at the Chestnut Street Opera House. Her reception here has been unprecedented in the history of theatricals in this city. During the two weeks of her engagement the record of the Chestnut Street Theatre has been broken and hundreds have been turned from the doors at every performance.

William Chesebrough Noyes. William Chesebrough Noyes, a well-known banker and broker of this city, died suddenly yesterday at his home, 60 West Forty-eighth Street. He leaves a wife and several children. The funeral will be held at the family residence to-morrow afternoon at 5 o'clock, and the burial will be in Greenwood.
Six persons, including a crippled girl, a baby, and a seven-year-old boy, were badly burned in a fire at 60 Orchard Street yesterday noon.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21 -- The work of the 'Varsity football team during the last week has not been what the college had reason to expect. Not a little disappointment is felt at the slowness of the men in getting into 'Varsity form. A fear of overconfidence on the part of the players is freely expressed in college circles.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 20 -- There is not much change in the home business or stock situation from that noted a week ago. Demand for funds at banks is improved, and without an advance in rates. On the Exchange interest centred mainly in Pleasant Valley, Birmingham, and Central Traction shares, all of which are higher than a week ago.

Only a few weeks remain for the barness horses to race on this Bide of the Rockey Mountains. By the end of this month all the regular circuits will be completed. A few desultory meetings through the Southwestern States, extending as far as Texas, continue till well along in November.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21 -- The meeting of the senior class for the purpose at choosing Class Day officers was held in Massachusetts Hall last Wednesday evening. Edward H. Warren presided. The ticket put forward by the Hasty Pudding Club and the Pi Eta Society was, in general, successful. The officers chosen are as follows:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21 -- At the next Yale commencement the old conservative university will drop the ceremonial that has been in vogue for over a century and adopt an entirely new plan more in keeping with its present position among educational institutions. The whole programme is now definitely arranged and will in all probability be approved by the Faculty and the corporation.

Speaking last week at Fort Wayne, Ind., Mr. Harrison undertook to explain the cause of the panic of last year. He made a statement which he had frequently made before, to the effect that "the money in circulation was so largely increased that it [the cause of the panic] could not have been a lack of confidence in the money that was in circulation."
ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 21 -- This official statement, sent from Livadia was given out at 8 o'clock:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The annual report of the Chief of the Naval Bureau of Equipment shows what it costs to keep the new cruisers in fuel. There were purchased last year, at home, 42,190 tons of coal, costing $178,163, of which quantity 9,505 tons were purchased on the Pacific coast, at an average cost of $7 per ton, and 32,685 tons on the Atlantic coast, at an average cost of $3.33 per ton.

Manhattan lost 3 points in yesterday's stock market, opening at 3/4 below Saturday's figures, at 107, and closing at 104 3/4. The downward course of the stock has excited much comment. It was explained at first by fears that the rapid-transit agitation boded ill for the property. Afterward the quotation readers assumed that manipulation was behind the decline, inside holders unloading.

William L. Strong, the candidate of the Committee of Seventy, received another formal notification of his nomination for Mayor, at headquarters, in the Sturtevant House, yesterday afternoon. The occasion was the fourth in which Mr. Strong has participated as the central figure since the Seventy made him their candidate.

-- The annual dinner of the Eleventh Army Corps will be held at Morello's on Dec. 18 at 7 o'clock in the evening. Among those who have promised to respond to toasts are Gen. F. Louis Dl Cesnola, Gen. Carl Schurz, Gen. Franz Sigel, Gen. J.T. Lockman, Gen. J. Stahel, and Gen. Orland Smith. Col. A.C. Hamlin, the historian of the corps, has promised to read an interesting account of the battle of Chancellorsville.

BOSTON. Oct. 22. -- Local stocks were even duller to-day than they were last week, and news or fluctuations of any importance are lacking entirely. Bell Telephone improved 1 further, to 200, for a hundredshare lot, but Erie Telephone dropped 3/4, to 53 1/4, for no apparent reason, except that the offerings were greater than the demand.
ST. PETERSBURG. Oct. 22. -- A bulletin issued at 8 o'clock this evening says:
The following plans for new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

The Republican State Executive Committee, by its action on Saturday in declaring Gen. Curtis the nominee for Congress in the Twenty-second District, did a job which resulted in an indignation meeting Sunday. It was held by some of the friends of Lucius N. Littauer who hail from Gen. Curtis's own county and have become tired of him as their representaive.

Proctor's Theatre. -- The seating capacity of Proctor's was exhausted earlv yesterday, and the new bill proved exceedingly popular. Charming in model and pose were the artistic bits of statuary added to the living pictures. The subjects were: "The Spinning Girl," "The Swallows," "La Seve," "Phryne," and "Salambo." In the vaudeville programme much amusement.

-- Bowling Bowser of Hartford, Conn., who was Consul at Sierra Leone, Africa, under the Harrison Administration, died there Sept 24. Mr. Bowser was born in Ohio and was graduated from Oberlin College. He studied law and taught school there, and after living in Hartford for a while went to Liberia to work in the missionary field.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Col. H. C. Merriam of the Seventh United States Infantry, now stationed at Fort Logan, Col., who was stationed at the State Camp of Instruction at Peekskill during the last season, has made a report to the authorities at Washington. He says, among other things:

-- Joseph Brooks in Command Again. -- Things were bustling at the Star Theatre yesterday. Joseph Brooks, Mr. Crane's manager, who had been i11 for several days, was again on hand, and his energetic spirit seemed to pervade everybody connected with the theatre. His physicians had advised him to remain quiet a few days longer, but Mr. Brooks insisted on returning to his work.

George Walton Green, the candidate of the State Democracy for Congress in the Twelfth District, has written an open letter to Col. George B. McClellan, the Tammany candidate in that district, in which he agrees to withdraw, if Col. McClellan will do so, in favor of W. Bourke Cockran, who now represents that district.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- At the present ratio existing between Treasury receipts and expenditures, the indications point to a deficit for the month of October of $7,000,000 in ordinary expenses and of $5,000,000 in interest, or a total of $12,000,000 for both for the month over and above receipts.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The registration in this city is the largest ever recorded -- 5,192.
NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Fire this morning destroyed the handsome new residence of the Rev. Ross Taylor, at South Nyack, and four of his children perished in the flames.

-- Norbert Goeneutte, whose death is announced in Paris, was one of the most independent and zealous of dry-point engravers. He was born in Paris, July 21, 1854. He was a pupil of the Beaux-Arts School, and had earned several rewards of merit. He had organized the Societe des PeintresGraveurs, with Bracquemond and Guerard, and captivated interest by the constant effort at improvements shown in successive exhibitions of his work.

The indorsement of William L. Strong for Mayor by so many Democratic organizations brings some amusing incidents to sight. There was one yesterday. George Walton Green is the candidate of the State Democracy for Congress in the Twelfth District. Robert A. Chesebrough is the Republican candidate.

WALTHAM, Mass., Oct 22. -- Harry Tyler made another sensation to-day at the Waltham cycle park by riding the fastest mile race ever contested In the world, breaking both the even mile and three-quarter competition records, under extremely unfavorable conditions. On Sept. 13, at Springfield, Mass., "Eddie" Bald of Buffalo leaped into fame by winning a mile race against the fastest men in the world, lowering the world's competition record to 2:05 4-5.
What promises to be in many respects the most remarkable political meeting that has been held in this city for years will take place this evening at the Cooper Union.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

The position which Police Justice Hogran takes with reference to excise arrests is plainly in the interest of violators of the law. He holds, for instance, that police officers have no right to enter saloons at times when they are "supposed to be closed."
"By what fragile threads hang the lives and destinies of men."

Funeral services over the body of exMayor Samuel Booth were held in the Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The church was filled with persons prominent in political, business, and social circles in Brooklyn. There was first a private service in Mr. Booth's home, 50 South Portland Avenue.

The plea has been several times publicly made that Tammany was not responsible for the police corruption and the rank abuses exposed before the Lexow committee, on the ground that they were of long standing and the product of a system which was not of Tammany's making.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The police are trying to find the man who Is suspected ou murdering Gabriel Segui, a priest, who belonged to a rich and Influential family in the Argentine Republic. Segui was found dead in his bed about two weeks ago, in a private hotel at 49 Old Compton Street, Soho.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Josephus Daniels, chief clerk of the Interior Department and President of The Raleigh (N.C.) Daily News and Observer, who has been In North Carolina for a week, returned to the city to-day. Mr. Daniels knows as much about North Carolina politics as any man in the State, and his views are interesting.
The opening of the Thirteenth Regiment fair in Brooklyn, last night, drew a large crowd to the fine new armory, Sumner and Jefferson Avenues.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22. -- The annual Harvard Freshman track athletic games were held on Holmes Field to-day. There was only a small crowd present and the performances were very poor. No records were broken and none was approached. There were three promising men out, however. Bigelow, who won the dashes, was not pushed at all.

The Bell Democracy of Kings County, at a meeting at the Executive Committee last night, in the Thomas Jefferson Building, Brooklyn, decided by a vote of 30 to 20 to refuse all conferences looking toward a united Congressional ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22.-- The officers of the two Congressional Committees are now giving the finishing touches to the work which they began months ago. The distribution of political documents has practically ceased. All the large orders have been filled, and at present the committees are sending out only such literature as is requested by individuals.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- The feature to-day has been the continued weakness of Metropolitan Traction. The opening was at 107 1/2, and, on steady sales, declined to 105 1/4, at which price inside support was given for the first time since it sold at 114, and the price rallied to 106 at the close. The selling to-day has all been good, however.

Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy yesterday prepared a statement concerning the conduct of city affairs for the past two decades In the various departments, with a view of defending Tammany Hall on some of the charges and attacks made against the organization and its management of public trusts.

Timothy J. Campbell and John Simpson, each of whom claims that he was regularly nominated for Congress by the Republicans of the Ninth Congressional District, must seek official recognition in the courts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

ASBURY PARK. N.J., Oct. 28. -- Ground was | broken to-day for the new clubhouse of the As- bury Park Wheelmen. The building will be located on Bangs Avenue, in the business portion of the town, and will be completed by Jan. 1. The clubhouse will contain a first-class gymnasium and modern club fixtures. The wheelmen turned out In large numbers at noon to assist in the "ground breaking" exercises.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 22. -- Rudolph Doran, a contractor and builder, of 251 East Thirty-fifth Street, New-York, is a prisoner in the Hackensack Jail. Doran has been indicted for perjury. He built a house at Bergen Fields for Mrs. S.W. Martens, but in the release several names of those who had lien claims on the building were left out.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Music Hall was packed to the doors, and several hundred enthusiastic Democrats shouted themselves hoarse In the street when Senator David B. Hill arrived, shortly after 8 o'clock this evening.
There were thirty-six excise cases before Justice Hogan yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court. Most of them were adjourned for further hearing.

The week opened with the same conditions which marked recent days in the stock market prevailing. Big operators as well as smaller traders hesitated to take sides, preferring to await some definite development in the situation before undertaking new obligations. While London bought a few hundred shares of stocks its operations were too insignificant to influence prices.

CHICAGO, Oct 22. -- The recent weakness displayed by West Chicago culminated in a pronounced bearish trend to-day. The stock broke readily 1 1/2 points without much exertion on the part of the bears; the latter have no idea that these certificates will react immediately; indeed, they affect to believe that 130 will not be an unreasonable price within the week.

We perform a public service of no small value, we think, in laying before the people of this city an elaborate defense of Tammany administration prepared for publication by Mayor Gilroy. We publish it without change or abridgment. We assume that it is the best defense that Tammany has to offer, that it is a full and matured exposition of the benefits of Tammany rule.

Of all the Doctor's marvelous works, none has proved so widespread a blessing as that great medicine, Dr. Greene's Nervura blood and nerve remedy. Like a spider's web, with its millions of delicate threads, it stretches out its mighty arms in every direction and in every land, driving sickness and suffering before it, and leaving in its path health, happiness, bright homes, and rejoicing hearts.

Capt. Alexander S. Palmer, for a quarter of a century connected with the Merchant Marine, died at his residence, Pine Point, Stonington, Conn., yesterday morning, in the eighty-eighth year of his age.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The Graphie has this dispatch from Chemulpo: "Four hundred Japanese have been quartered in the King's palace in Seoul, in consequence, it is said, of the discovery that the King's father is in league with the Tonghak rebels. The Chinese are mobilizing large forces In Kuren and Pow-TingFu.
At the time Hugh J. Grant was examined before the Fassett committee as to the manner in which he had conducted the office of Sheriff, he was Mayor of this city.

-- Capt. R.L. Smith of the South Brooklyn Wheelmen will this week ride over the course selected for that club's century run on Oct. 28. He will make the usual arrangements for the riders along the route. "Pop" Stillwell of the Kings County Wheelmen will be one of the pacemakers on the run. The silver medals to be given to the survivors are said to be the handsomest of the season.

From The United Service Gazette (British) of Oct. 13. The official trial trip of the screw gunboat Independencia took place last week over the measured mile at Skelmorlie under supervision of the representatives of the President and Government of San Domingo, for whom the vessel has been built.

Lord Basing. The Right Hon. George Sclater-Booth, F.R.S.P.C., son of the late William Lutley Sclater. Esq., of Hoddington House. Hampshire, by Arine Maria; daughter of the late William Bowyer. Esq., died in London yesterday. He was raised to the Peerage oii the occasion of her Majesty's Jubilee in 1887, by the style of Baron Basing of Basing Bytlete and Hoddington, in the County of Hampshire.

The Campaign Committee of the Seventy was in session two hours yesterday. It was practically decided to hold two large mass meetings below Fourteenth Street, on the east side, one on the west side, and one in Harlem.

The soldiers of the Salvation Army, who love so well to proclaim to the world by song and symbals and trumpets and drums and exhortations the fervency of their religious tenets, are holding a high carnival of their unique Christianity in the Church of the Strangers, in Mercer Street. They call it their Great American Jubilee, and Gen. Booth, the father of the Salvation Army, is their honored guest.
Senator David B. Hill arrived In this city from Albany at 5:30 o'clock last evening.
The gentlemen of the Committee of Seventy have left it to Dr. Parkhurst and the newspapers to elect Mr. Strong.

Justice Ingraham and over a dozen lawyers in the Special Term of the Supreme Court attempted, yesterday, to straighten out a complicated mass of litigation that has arisen out of Lawyer Francis H. Weeks's defalcations, the property involved being that of the estate of William Edgar Howland, who died in Paris in February, 1885.
The cornerstone of the German Hospital in Brooklyn was laid yesterday by Mayor Charles A. Schieren. An immense crowd attended the ceremony.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22. -- George J. Gould, President of the Missouri Pacific and Iron Mountain system, and Vice President and Director of numerous other railroads, arrived at the Union Station at 8:35 A.M., over the Wabash. He came in his private car Atalanta, and was accompanied only by an inspection force.

The case brought by Lawyer William R. Wilder against George H. Kendall to recover $1,526 for legal services in behalf of the New-York Bank Note Company, of which Kendall owns the controlling interest, was finished for the time being in the City Court yesterday, before Chief Justice Ehrlich and a jury.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 22 -- There is a good prospect for the election of a Democratic Congressman from this, the Thirty-first District, notwithstanding the fact that the district is naturally Republican by a large majority. The district has a reputation for repudiating Republican Congressional candidates who are unsatisfactory, and this year's candidate, Henry C. Brewster, is decidedly unsatisfactory to hundreds of Republican voters.

A typical Anarchist has been discovered at New-Rochelle in the person of an Irishman named Riley. Having had a quarrel with an Italian, or some Italians, Riley desired to be revenged upon all Italians, and he accordingly planned to blow up with dynamite a building in which nearly a hundred Italians lodged.

JAMAICA, L. I., Oct. 22. -- John J. Mitchell, Democratic candidate for Sheriff of Queens County, filed in the office of the County Clerk to-day a protest against the certificate of nomination filed by the Gleason party. The latter ticket is straight Democratic, with the exception that it names Henry Doht, the Republican candidate for Sheriff, instead of Mitchell.

Emma Schorling, who was arrested on Saturday for stealing a diamond pin in the jewelry store at 332 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, was held for the Grand Jury by Justice Groetting in the Lee Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 22. -- William Nelson Cromwell of New-York reported for the Northern Pacific receivers this afternoon upon proposals received for the purchase of the issue of $5,000,000 in receivers' certificates. He said it had been decided to sell the certificates to the parties offering the best rate of interest for them, not more than 6 per cent. to be paid.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 22. -- The Cunningham torpedo is to have another trial at the torpedo station this week, under the auspices of the Bureau of Ordnance of the navy. It is the invention of Patrick Cunningham of New-Bedford, and is owned by a company of which the inventor is President.

Ex-Police Sergeant George C. Liebers, under indictment for felony and misdemeanor, in receiving bribes from Mrs. Augusta Thorow, and for whom a bench warrant had been issued, surrendered himself to Superintendent Byrnes at Police Headquarters yesterday. He said he was absent from the city when the indictments were found.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 22. -- The Chamber of Commerce met in special session this afternoon for the purpose of taking action on the "syndicates," "discretionary pools," and other concerns like the "Public Grain and Stock Exchange," which was raided last Saturday, and the methods of which, as a bogus scheme for speculation, have been exposed by all the newspapers.

Reports of money offering on Morton at odds of 2 to 1 at the Stock Exchange took Capt. W. B. Smith of Company F. Twentysecond Regiment, down town yesterday, with $2,000 to bet on Hill. He authorized Hermann Cohen to place all or part of the $2,000 for him at those odds.

The City Club, at a special meeting last night, enthusiastically indorsed the union ticket named by the Committee or Seventy. There were over 100 members present. James C. Carter, the President of the club, was in the chair.
There were music, gay decorations, and a big flag at 81 Columbia Street yesterday afternoon, when the Woman's Municipal League held one of its regular meetings in Columbia Hall.

The special board of Inquiry which was convened Saturday by Dr. Joseph H. Senner, Commissioner of Immigration at the Port of New-York, to investigate the case of J. James Howard, the English under coachman and stable boy of Levi P. Morton, the Republican candidate for Governor, concluded its work yesterday.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Suday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of the questions which will be voted upon in November, none is of greater consequence than the amendment to the Constitution which permits the Legislature to spend what money may be needed for the improvement of our canals. "Greater New-York" will doubtless result in advantage to the districts which want to be incorporated with us;

Messrs. M. & L. Hess have sold, for Mr. M. Freedman, to Mr. J. Hirsh, the property at 134 and 136 Spring Street, 50 by 125, and 84, 86, and 88 Wooster Street, 70 by 50, together forming an "L," with old buildings, at $156,750. The purchaser will erect a seven-story semi-fire-proof building on the site.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 22. -- In order to get revenge on some Italians for what he considered wrongs they had done to him. Patrick Riley, twenty-four years old, attempted last night to blow up the Italians' shanty with dynamite. There were seventy-three of the Italians in the house.
PANAMA, Oct. 16. -- Regarding the recent outrage on the Arequipa Observatory, which is an American institution, The Star and Herald to-day said:

Senator Charles J. Faulkner will be in this city to-day to discuss the Congressional question with representatives of Tammany. It is probable that after this meeting he will meet a delegation from the New-York State Democracy.

We shall not say that Mayor Gilroy does not understand the causes of the overwhelming disgust with Tammany Hall. We think that he does. We think that, could he have done so without breaking with the organization, he would gladly have avoided or changed much that has justified this disgust.
A complimentary dinner was given in the Hotel Savoy last evening to the Rev. Merle St. Croix Wright of the Lenox Avenue Unitarian Church by the Men's Club attached to that church.

New-Jersey is a Democratic State. Its plurality of over 7,000 for Cleveland in 1888 was more than doubled in 1892, and Gov. Werts was elected by more than 7,500. The same year six members of Congress out of eight were elected by the Democrats, and the Legislature was made to stand 16 Democrats to 5 Republicans in the Senate and 39 Democrats to 21 Republicans in the House.

Senator Charles J. Faulkner, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, labored all day yesterday to bring about harmony in the Democratic Congressional nominations, without any definite results, being attained. At a late hour last night Senator Faulkner was in conference at the Park Avenue Hotel with Chairman Hinkley, Richard Croker, James J. Martin, and Lieut. Gov. Sheehan.

From The London Dally Telegraph. George Allin provided in the City Summons Court a theme for another song on the joys and sorrows of a coster's life. The joys consisted in having a house full of children, and the sorrows in not being able to make a living without having the police down on him for obstructing the thorough-fare with his barrow of fruit.

Messrs. E.H. Ludlow Co. have sold for William Conyers Herring, to a client, the four-story store and office building at the southeast corner of John and Gold Streets, at about $52,000. They have also sold for Katharine V. Butler, to John S. Huyler, the four-story brownstone dwelling, 128 East Eighteenth Street, 23 by 92, at $21,000.

George H. Kendall, President of the NewYork Banknote Company, made a statement yesterday regarding the conspiracy claim made in his defense in the suit Drought against him by Lawyer William R. Wilder to recover $1,526 for legal services.

Lawyer John M. Bowers, on behalf of Hugh J. Grant, receiver of the St. Nicholas Bank, made application yesterday to Justice Barrett, in the Supreme Court, for permission to insert in the report of Receiver Grant, which was handed up last Saturday, one page that had been by an oversight left out of the report.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28.-- The local market opened moderately active, with a decidedly stronger tone in the traction stocks. The good buying noted in these dispatches yesterday was again apparent at the opening in Metropolitan, and it advanced 3 per cent., without sales, to 109. This rapid recovery from 105 1/4 caused some realizing, and the stock reacted to 108, but support again came in toward the close, and the final figures were the best.

FREDERIKSBURG, Va., Oct. 23. -- Charles J. Searcey, the Aqula Creek train robber, made a confession, before being brought here from Washington, that he and Morganfield were the only ones concerned in the robbery. They had known each other for some time when they met in Washington and agreed to rob a train, but fixed on no particular one.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23. -- It is now practically settled between the managers of the Yale and Princeton football teams that the championship game will be played on Dec. 1, as a compromise date between Thanksgiving Day and Dec. 5. Capt. Trenchard put the football eleven through a strong practice to-day in preparation for the game with Lehigh to-morrow.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 23. -- Ex-President Harrison left for New-York this afternoon on private business. Mr. Harrison said to-day that no New-York speech was on his programme as it stands at present. He will return one week from next Saturday, and will make his last speech of the present campaign at Anderson.
From The London Truth.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 23. -- The Middlesex County Democratic Convention met to-day. For County Clerk, ex-Sheriff Thomas N. Acken was nominated, and Mayor James H. Vancleef of this city was named for Senator. Charles C. Homann of Perth Amboy, William F. Harkins of this city, and John C. Cozzens of Spotswood were nominated for Assembly without opposition,
Senator Hill said yesterday forenoon to a political friend who called on him at the Democratic Headquarters, in the Park Avenue Hotel, that he now expected to win by about 15,000 plurality.

When Hugh J. Grant was examined by the Fassett committee, on March 15, 1890, as to his management of the Sheriff's office during his term therein, he testified that no books had been kept by which the receipts and disbursements of the office could be learned.

The greatest crowd that has ever been gathered on a political occasion in Brooklyn filled the Academy of Music and choked up Montague Street from Court to Clinton Street last evening to see and hear Senator David B. Hill argue for the election of himself and his colleagues on the Democratic State ticket.

A well-known staff correspondent of The New-York Tribune has been making inquiries in Connecticut, and in his letter, dated at New-Haven, our neighbor publishes an interesting allusion to the Republican boss, Thomas C. Platt. The correspondent, "I.H.B.," had some conversation with a prominent Democrat, whose residence is in that city, although his business is carried on here.

Tammany Hall ratified last night. The meeting began at 6 o'clock, and lasted until midnight, and any member of the Committee of Seventy who imagines that the Tammany Tiger is already defeated, might have gained a valuable object lesson if he had spent the evening in the neighborhood of the Tiger's lair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- News which reaches this city from many Congressional districts is pleasing to Democrats, for it reveals an amount of enthusiasm for Democratic candidates which is believed to be the forerunner of a great victory in November. Assistant Controller of the Treasury Charles H. Mansur returned to-day from a week's trip in Representative Wileon's district, in West Virginia.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: Will you permit a suggestion from a resident of the Palisades respecting their preservation from injury by blasting?

Inspector McAvoy has been Instructed by Superintendent Byrnes to Investigate the complaint made by Kirk Matthews of 315 West Thirty-eighth Street, the conductor of a conservatory of music, against Capt. James K. Price of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station.

WAGONER, Indian Territory, Oct. 23. -- "Word reached this city at 8 o'clock tonight that "Bill" Cook and his band of desperadoes were encamped on Verdigris River, eight miles south of Wagoner. A posse of Marshals was hastily sworn in, and, headed by Deputy United States Marshals Lawson and Hockbruner, left about 9:30 o'clock.

TRENTON, Oct. 23 -- Because, through the votes of independent Democrats, the people of New-Jersey last year chose a Republican Legislature, the leaders of the Republican Party in the State now assume that the people have turned over to them the continuous management of affairs here.

The Committee of Seventy started on the Tiger's trail last night. The Tammany beast that has made this city at once his lair and the field where he struck down his prey was sighted -- a cruel, man-and-woman-eating brute -- and, backed by every substantial business interest in the city, the Seventy went for him with a shout.

ST. PETRESBURG, Oct. 23. -- The Czar's physicians issued a bulletin at 7 o'clock this evening saying that in the course of the day the patient had been languid, and had shown slight convulsive symptoms, but his appetite was better.

The prices of structural steel and iron recently quotes by English mills to an English firm of bridge builders are published by The Iron Age, which says: "We are getting down pretty close to the English level." The structural shapes mentioned are angles, tees, steel ship-plates, and checkered plates.

In the year 1787 a certain sculptor named Salerno executed a statue of the Virgin which was so perfect that he exclaimed: "I never could have hoped that my chisel could execute such a beautiful work." The statue was purchased for 60 ducats by a wealthy man and taken to Radicena, in Calabria.

The Atlas Line steamship Alene, that arrived yesterday afternoon from Port Limon, Costa Rica, and Jamaica, had among her passengers a number of shipwrecked seaman of the British ship Otago, 1,200 tons, of Yarmouth, Nova Scotia.

From The Westminster Gazette. The great soap question is at present agitating the mind of the German traveling public. It has now become a matter of common knowledge in the Fatherland that English hotels actually go so far as to provide the travel-stained guest with a cake of soap, and that they very handsomely refrain from charging the luxury in the bill.

MOUNT VERNON, Oct. 23. -- Mrs. Baker, the wife of James Baker of 1 South High Street, this city, vigorously cowhided Frank J. Benson, a well-known man-about-town, who lives at 17 South Bond Street, a few blocks from the Baker residence, before at least 100 persons, at Mount Vernon Avenue and Bond Street, at 8 o'clock last night.
"If I believed the rumor," said Dr. Parkhurst yesterday, "that there was a political dicker which would imperil the candidacy of John W. Goff, I should be silent for the rest of the campaign."

Paris Correspondence London Telegraph. An outery has been raised against the high prices charged for dinners and suppers in the fashionable restaurants of the Boulevards. The time has gone by, according to those who are leading the attack against such establishments, when young Frenchmen of the Gramont-Caderousse kind were ready to pay the long "notes" or "additions" presented to them in the restaurants a la mode.

NEWARK, Oct. 23. -- The past forty-eight hours have been busy ones for the Democrats of Essex County. Within that time primaries to elect delegates to the County Convention, which placed in nomination the ticket for Surrogate and Assemblymen, and a great mass meeting have been held. That the work that has been accomplished has been good work every Democrat in the county is satisfied to-night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 23. -- Dr. William T. Bull of New-York has been presented by his father, Major Henry Bull, one of Newport's richest men, with a country residence. It is known as the Dudley place, in Middletown, just over the Newport line, and is a fine old mansion surrounded by broad, sloping lawns.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 23. -- Judge Augustus J. Ricks, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, Northern Ohio District, this morning, decided the famous suit involving the ownership of millions of stock of the Canadian Copper Company, Anglo-American Iron Company, and Central Ontario Railway Company.

The College of the City of New-York celebrated yesterday the twenty-fifth anniversary of Gen. Webb's Installment as President. The Faculty, Instructors, and other officers commemorated the event by the presentation of a large silver loving cup.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- North Chicago was a surprise. It opened at 257, having closed at 256, 10 points under the high mark touched on the late boom. The odd feature is that a reason given for the boom was that the company was about to obtain control of the North Shore Electric Road through a lease to the North Chicago Electric Company, which is owned by the cable company.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 23. -- Never before did the sulkies prove so popular in this city as when the inaugural meeting of the Louisville Fair and Driving Association began this afternoon. By diligent work, the old running track at Churchill Downs has been put in very good condition for the light-harness racers, and some 4,000 persons patronized the sport to-day.

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- The civil marriage ceremony between Miss Susan Tucker Whittier, daughter of Gen. Whittier of New-York, and Prince Belosselsky Belozersky, son of the Czar's aide de camp, took place at the Mairie of the Eighth Ward this afternoon. The bride's witnesses were Messrs. J.B. Eastis and Burden of New-York.

A.G. Van Schaick, Chief of the A.P.A. in New-York State, left this city very suddenly yesterday, ostensibly to return to his home in Lansingburg, N.Y., where he edits an A.P.A. organ known as The Republic.

The important question is now raised as to whether, if the partisan Constitution adopted by the Republican Constitutional Convention is approved by the people at the coming election there will be any Legislature in this State in 1895. judiciary, which is not to go into effect befor 1896.
Dr. Wolfred Nelson of this city, formerly of Panama, returned from a trip through the West Indies on the Atlas Line steamer Alene, which arrived yesterday from Kingston, Jamaica.

Corporation Counsel Clark sent to the Police Commissioners late yesterday afternoon an opinion In answer to their request to be informed whether or not the law requires the actual production of certificates of naturalization before Boards of Registry upon the application of a person for register who is not native born.

The Westfield, a ferryboat owned by the Staten Island Rapid-Transit Company, and running between Staten Island and the foot of Whitehall Street, was coming up the bay on her midday trip yesterday when she ran into the tug Edwin H. Mead of Albany. The tug was just off Governors Island when the Westfield struck her.

When the Reform Democrats of Kings County heard of the action of the Bell Democracy Monday night in refusing to compromise on Congressional candidates, a committee of three was appointed to make another effort in bringing the Bell people to their senses. This committee sent the following letter to Mr. Bell yesterday:

Alfred R. Conkling explained last night to members of the City Vigilance League, which met in the United Charities Building, the rights and duties of watchers, polling clerks, and ballot clerks on election day. "You must be very careful," said he, "of the districts around Franklin and Prince Streets.

Men want to be strong. They want good health, sound bodies, vigorous constitutions. They were told Just how to obtain all. these last evening, in that great private lecture to men given by the noted specialist. Dr. Greene of 33 West Fourteenth Street, New-York City, in Chiekering Hall.

Rice planters seem determined to force upward the price of that staple. They have succeeded in holding prices above the average at this season, on account of the comparatively light yield per acre. Receipts to date are about 30 per cent, less than last year. This is attributed to the holding back of the crop and the disposition of planters to market with greater deliberation than heretofore.

In regard to the members of the police force who were dismissed through the independent Investigation at Police Headquarters, District Attorney Fellows said yesterday that he expected the Grand Jury would investigate every case.

The Committee of Seventy has made a good beginning. It called a great audience to Cooper Union last night to greet the reform candidates and testify to the breadth and solidity of the revolt against Tammany. There was a hearty welcome for Mr. Strong and Mr. Goff, there was intelligent, appreciative attention for the speeches, and the spirit that possessed the meeting betokened an uncommon awakening of the public mind.
Three excise cases were brought before Police Justice Hogan, in the Jefferson Market Court, yesterday, all by men on Inspector McAvoy's staff.

Commanders of precincts in which frauds on the franchise are likely to be attempted, or where false registration has been detected; were not left in doubt yesterday as to the precise intentions of Superintendent Byrnes.
WASHINGTON. Oct. 23. -- Collector General Maxwell reached Washington this afternoon, after an absence of some days, and will to-morrow appear in the Supreme Court to argue the sugar case.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- Ill luck had a firm grip on John Johnson, the noted bicycle rider, this afternoon, and, after two attempts, the straightaway bicycle record was still unshaken. On the first trial, the front tire on his machine gave out at the quarter pole, and on the second attempt a new tire on the front wheel went to pieces.

The managers of the Republican State campaign are likely to find a choice lot of Presidential "booms" on their hands by to-morrow night. Gov. McKinley of Ohio will begin his campaigning in this State to-morrow afternoon, when he will make a speech at Dunkirk. In the evening he will be at Buffalo.

-- The New-York State Democracy of the Twenty-third Assembly District will hold a ratification meeting at Lion Park Hotel, One Hundred and Eighth Street and Columbus Avenue, on Thursday evening, Oct. 25, at 8 o'clock, with music, fireworks, W. R. Grace, Charles S. Fairchild, John De Witt Warner, Carl Schurz, and many others have been invited to address the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- A report of the recent test of rapid-fire guns has been received at the War Department. The guns will be used in arming the coast defenses of the country, and a large number of them will some time be bought by the Government. The test, which was held at Sandy Hook proving ground, was a competitive one and intended for the information of the ordnance officials.

Mrs. Lottie Miller, aged twenty-two, and Bertha Davis, aged twenty, were arraigned before Justice Meade, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday morning, on a charge of conducting a disorderly house at 171 East Seventy-seventh Street. The building is owned by the Rev. Herman Lustig, formerly rabbi of the Beth Israel Bikor Cholem Synagogue, at Lexington Avenue and Seventy-second Street.

NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 23. -- The first Howell torpedo to be fired from a cruiser was shot from the tube in the bow of the Detroit in the outer harbor this afternoon. The occasion was an interesting one in naval circles here, all the officers in this vicinity being gathered to witness it. The men of the Detroit, Cincinnati, and Constellation lined the bulwarks of their vessels.
ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 23. -- Princess Alix, in response to a telegram of welcome from the municipality of Moscow, received by her on arriving in Russian territory, sent the following by wire:
LONDON, Oct. 23. -- A Central News dispatch from St. Petersburg says:...

LOWELL, Mass. Oct. 23. -- The American Missionary Convention opened this afternoon, with 300 delegates present. Dr. H. A. Hazen was chosen permanent Secretary and the Rev. W.E. Barton of Boston was chosen assistant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The Republicans have begun to count some chickens that are not yet hatched. The Star, which has become a pretty thorough-paced Republican paper, assuming that the Republicans are to have a majority in the Congress that has not yet been elected, has elected Reed Speaker by a vote so enthusiastic as to make him the central figure of national politics.

The proxy for the 80,000 shares of Atchison stock held in Amsterdam was on Monday formally delivered to the Proxy Committee of the Atchison Board of Directors. About the same time a proxy for 33,000 shares held by I. S. Wormser was sent to the Myers-Clews Protective Committee.

Sugar was the only stock which made double figures in the trading in yesterday's stock market. It moved between 86 and 87 1/8, and closed at 86 3/8, a net gain of 1/4. In Chicago Gas and Distilling and Cattle Feeding, about 1O,OOO shares were done, and each closed 1/8 higher. There were only 300 shares of Cordage done, and it closed 3/8 higher.

One of the most remarkable rides in the history of cycling ended yesterday in front of the City Hall at 12:10 P. M. At that time R. P. Searle of the Century Road Club of America dismounted from his wheel, having completed the journey from Chicago to the metropolis in 6 days 7 hours 30 minutes, which is now the record between these points.
The provisional estimates of the District Attorney's office were taken up by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Can anything be plainer to the thinking mind than I set forth in my letter of Oct. 18 to your paper? Is it not plain to those in control of the bankrupt railroads and to those who are now trying to reorganize them that, no matter how much they assess them, no matter how much money they may take in from stock and bond holders.

It is reported that the man who has been arrested on suspicion of being concerned in the train robbery in Virginia has offered to surrender so much as can be found of the plunder, and it la inferred that he is thereupon to be let go. It is to be hoped the inference is mistaken.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 23. -- Four men robbed the railroad station, the Post Office, and the only store in the village of Watova, a station on the Kansas and Arkansas Valley Railroad, 125 miles west of here, last night.

The members of the various committees In charge, and the patronesses, of the loan exhibition of portraits of women which is to be given in November at the National Academy of Design, are as follows: Executive Committee-Henry Marquand, Chairman; Robert Waller, Jr., Secretary; James Speyer. Treasurer; Charles T. Barney. William F. King, H. Walter Webb, and Osgood Welsh.
Silver bullion certificates were not quoted.
About 100 of the women of the Society for Political Study met at 144 Madison Avenue yesterday afternoon, and listened to a paper on "The City Electors," read by Mrs. Florence De G. Shaw.

W.H. Crossman Brother, coffee merchants, have carried their point against the Baltimore dealers who refused to accept coffee bought of this firm. The managers of the Coffee Exchange closed the dispute yesterday by suspending for one year Theodore G. Lurman and H.M. Wagner.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Oct. 23. -- There was a steady throne of visitors to the residence of the family of ex-Gov. Joseph D. Bedle, at Jersey Avenue and Montgomery Street, from 3 o'clock until 5 this afternoon, during which time the remains of the ex-Governor were exposed to public view.

More people than Music Hall could comfortably hold crowded into that auditorium last night to greet Gen. Booth. There was an added attraction -- Chauncey M. Depew was to introduce the Salvation Army leader, and there was much curiosity to see exactly how he would do it.

More people than Music Hall could comfortably hold crowded into that auditorium last night to greet Gen. Booth. There was an added attraction -- Chauncey M. Depew was to introduce the Salvation Army leader, and there was much curiosity to see exactly how he would do it.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 24. -- Just after the death, in October, 1885, of Gen. George B. McClellan a movement was started in Philadelphia to erect a statue to the memory of the "Hero of Antietam." Success did not crown the efforts of the admirers of "Little Mac," but they persevered, and in 1889 an appropriation, of $5,000 was secured from the Pennsylvania Legislature.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Chauncey Mr. Depew opened the Republican campaign in Irvington-on-the-Hudson this evening by speaking to the villagers in C. R. Doremus's carriage house. This place is ordinarily a carriage repairing emporium, but for this event the carriages had been removed, and the walls and supporting posts draped with flags and red, white, and blue bunting.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24. -- Yale played this afternoon's game with the Boston Athletic Association football team in a heavy rainstorm, the score resulting 23 to 0. The visitors put up a strong game against Capt. Hinkey and once sot uncomfortably near Yale's goal.

The second triennial session of the National Council of Women of the United States will be opened formally at Metzerott's Music Hall, Washington, D.C., on Feb. 18, 1895, and will close on March 2, 1895.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 24. -- A Republican caucus for the nomination of a Representative to the Legislature was held in this city last night. The contest was between Russell Frost, Colonel of the Fourth Regiment, C.N.G., and Edmund E. Crowe, editor of The News, member of the Republican State Central Committee, and City Clerk and Tax Collector of South Norwalk.

Ebenezer Berry, Jr. Ebenezer Berry, Jr., the retiring Republican Assemblyman from the First District of Hudson County, N.J., died just before dawn this morning at his home in Bayonne. Death was due to pneumonia, and followed an Illness of less than a week's duration.

A meeting of women under the auspices of the Woman's Municipal League was held yesterday afternoon at Thalia Hall, 236 Broome Street, to encourage the efforts being made toward good city government. The women who conducted the meeting, and who are zealous in their efforts to defeat Tammany, had to hold their session with a counter attraction on the floor above in the shape of a cloakmakers' meeting.

Six of the Greater New-York Commissioners met yesterday afternoon in the Aldermanic Chamber at the City Hall and listened to the remarks of representative men from the different localities that are embraced in the proposed plan of consolidation.

(All communcations for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

The Shinnecock Hills Summer School of Art, the Catskill Summer School or Art, and the Old Lyme Summer School of Art, connected with the Brooklyn Art School, have an Autumn exhibition of paintings, drawings, designs, and sketches at the Art Galleries, 174 Montague Street, Brooklyn, which was opened to the public last Monday and will be closed next Saturday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Frederick Clause of this city, John B. Green of Westfield, and A.B. Cook of Rahway, were unanimously nominated for members of the Assembly at the convention held here to-day, by the Democrats of Union County. The county ticket was completed by the nomination of William M. Oliver for County Clerk and Dr. Thomas Dolan for Coroner.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 24. -- Believing that this village would afford his men protection from the striking cloakmakers of New-York, Wolf Metz removed his plant here. The machinery arrived this morning, and was set up in a small house. His workmen were with him. The plant had hardly reached the house when a band of fifteen strikers surrounded the place.

Arguments are soon to be heard in the Supreme Court in two cases involving the application of the Anti-Trust law of 1890. One of these is the suit of the Government against the Trans-Missouri Freight Association, which was originally tried in Kansas. The defendant association was a combination of about a dozen railroad companies, and the purpose of this combination was to prevent competition in freight charges.

A small consignment of trotters from the Redville Stock Farm, Union City, Mich., together with several other horses owned by different persons, were sold at Tattersalls last night. The rainstorm prevented a large attendance, but the prices paid for the best animals were good. Capt. Kidd was the auctioneer. The following horses were those which fetched $200 and over:

"It is a regular Tammany day, dark, dismal, wet," said Mrs. Virginia Chandler Titcomb, in lugubrious tones, at the meeting yesterday afternoon in Abingdon Square, where one body of Tammany's feminine foes was sounding the war cry in one of the lairs of the tiger.

George Houghton, a bank burglar, on Nov. 16, 1871, plundered the First National Bank of Jamesburg, Middlesex County, N.J., and was sent to prison for ten years. On March, 1891, when convicted of carrying burglars' tools in this city, constituting a second offense, because of the conviction in New-Jersey, he was released from custody by Recorder Smyth, who suspended sentence.

HELENA, Ark., Oct. 24. -- Nearly one-half the rural population of St. Francis County has within the last two days moved into Helena and established camps hereabout to attend the trial, which began to-day, of eleven persons accused of White Cap outrages. The prisoners have been brought here on a change of venue.

President Cleveland came to this city yesterday from Greenwich, Conn., arriving at about 10 o'clock in the morning. He went at once to the residence of his friend, Dr. Joseph Bryant, 54 West Thirty-sixth Street, and remained there all day. In the evening he attended the Broadway Theatre.
The Association of Southern Democrats of New-York gave a reception to Senator Hill at its headquarters, in the St. James Hotel, yesterday afternoon. A large number of members were present.
"What is the use of consolidation? is a question frequently asked by those very well contented with New-York City as it is. Here is an example, one of many:

In spite of the rain the Yale freshman and Polytechnic football teams played at Eastern Park yesterday. Only a few Brooklyn enthusiasts watched the contest, and after a few minutes playing it was hard to distinguish the members of the teams, as both were clothed alike in mud. The teams lined up as follows:

Superintendent Brynes's investigation of fraudulent registration during the two days of registry has brought forth good results. Two hundred and sixty cases were presented to the Grand Jury on Tuesday, and indictments were found in a large number of the cases.

Stagnation, almost unprecedented for this Season of the year, was the feature of the stock market yesterday. The total transactions were less than 65,000 shares, and in no stock did the trading reach 1O,OOO shares. Business was so lifeless that at times the ticker was silent for prolonged intervals.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Ex-Consul O.F. Williams, the independent Republican candidate for Congress, "who has been making such a strenuous fight against the regular candidate, Henry C. Brewster, has withdrawn from the field. It was only last Saturday that his petition, with the necessary number of signers, was filed with the County Clerk, and Mr. Williams's sudden withdrawal is a surprise.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24. -- Another disappointment has followed the second attempt to bring Robert J. and John R. Gentry together. These two pacing stars were to have renewed the battle for supremacy that was interrupted at Nashville last Thursday at the meeting in progress here, and to-morrow was fixed as the time for the match.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- The stock list tended downward, especially the cables. The feature of the day was heavy selling of West Chicago for the account. Prices were forced down from 135 to 133 3/4. North Chicago, on the other hand, had a firmer tone, selling up to 257 1/2. The best demand was for Strawboard, with transfers of numerous blocks at 35.

To say that the Tammany Democrats and the State Democrats have been acting like fools in regard to Congressional nominations would be discourteous. But to say that either the one or the other have acted like wise men would be to lie roundly.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- A fashionable wedding took place at noon to-day in St. John's Episcopal Church. The bride was Miss Anna Phillips Cochran, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cochran, and the bridegroom Thomas Ewing, Jr., second son of Gen. and Mrs. Thomas Ewing.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The Globe this morning prints a dispatch from Yokohama saying that fighting took place near Port Arthur yesterday. It is believed that the Japanese troops engaged were those composing the second army of about 30,000 men, which recently left Hiroshima. Details of the battle are lacking.
NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Daniel N. Lockwood, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, spoke here this evening to a large audience. He was cheered heartily as he stepped upon the platform.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- At the Newmarket Houghton meeting to-day the race for the Cambridgeshire Stakes of 25 sovereigns each, with 500 sovereigns added, winning penalties, one mile and 240 yards, was run. It was won by Mr. E. Hobson's three-year-old bay filly Indian Queen. Sir J. Blundell Maple's four-year-old bay colt Gangway finished in second place, and M.A. Abeille's four-year-old brown colt Callistrate was third.

PARIS, Oct. 24. -- The religious ceremonies of the marriage of Miss Susan Tucker Whittier, daughter of Gen. Whittier of New-York, to Prince Belosselsky Belozersky, son of the Czar's aide de camp, took place to-day. The first, according to the rites of the Greek Church, was performed in the Russian Church in the Rue Daru, and the second in the Church of the Holy Trinity, according to Protestant rites.
The following plans for new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

The Police Commissioners held a Special meeting yesterday to act on certificates of nomination of candidates filed by independent organizations, including the New-York State Democracy, Anti-Machine Republican, Empire State Democracy, and other reform organizations.
ALBANY, Oct. 24. -- The following new companies were incorporated to-day:
Chairman Hackett appears to have changed his plan of campaign. It is reported that he hopes to induce ex-President Harrison and Mr. McKinley to make speeches in New-York.

Discussion continues among the banks regarding the proposition to reduce the rate of interest on deposits of country banks to 1 per cent. Several of the large depositories have decided to accept no new deposits at a higher rate, and gradually to reduce all deposits to that rate should the plethora of money continue.
ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 24. -- At 8 o'clock this evening the following official bulletin was issued:
