Mortimer S. Horton was nominated by the Democrats for Supervisor of the Thirtieth Ward, Brooklyn, but the Board of Elections refused to put his name on the ballot. He then applied to the Supreme Court for a mandamus compelling them to. Justice Gaynor yesterday issued the mandamus. He said in his opinion:

Robert Bauer, who for three years has been cashier and bookkeeper for the India Wharf Brewing Company, 60 Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on a charge of stealing $500 on Sept. 25. He was arraigned before Justice Walsh, in the Adams Street Police Court. The hearing was adjourned until Friday.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 24. -- News was brought here to-day by Deputy United States Marshals that "Bill" Cook's gang of robbers, who have been robbing trains and looting towns in the Indian Territory, raided Gibson Station yesterday.

Ex-President Harrison arrived In this city yesterday afternoon and went to the Fifth Avenue Hotel. After remaining In his rooms about half an hour, he went to the residence of his daughter, Mrs. McKee, returning to the hotel at about 6 o'clock.

Senator Hill made a carefully-prepared personal statement last night before the Democratic Business Men's Association, at Carnegie Hall, which proved to be among the most interesting incidents of his remarkable campaign.

-- The report of the Eighth Avenue Railroad of this city for the quarter ended Sept. 30, filed with the State Railroad Commission in Albany yesterday, shows gross earnings from operations, $204,511; operating expenses, $145,652; net earnings, $58,858; other incomes, $6,907; gross income, $65,766; fixed charges, $23,750; net income, $42,016; cash on hand, $20,131; profit and loss, surplus, $29,000.

John Boyd Thacher, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee's Executive Committee, is constantly adding interesting data to the arguments against the adoption of the constitutional amendments at the coming election.

The entire First Brigade, in command of Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, will proceed to Van Cortlandt Park this morning, if it is not stormy, and there engage in a sham battle, and be reviewed by Gov. Flower.

Judge McAdam of the Superior Court yesterday granted a writ of mandamus directing the Police Commissioners to accept John Simpson's certificate and place his name on the regular Republican ballots of the Ninth Congressional District.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The football teams of West Point and Annapolis will not be allowed to do any more work this season.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Oct. 24. -- John E. Lisk and Robert Brown, the game constables who achieved notoriety two years ago by arresting the Rev. Thomas Dixon of New-York for shooting robins on Staten Island, have resumed their raids on strangers who come here for a day afield with a gun and dog.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- The case of Messrs. Kurth and Deterling, delegates from Brooklyn to the Constitutional Convention, who were charged by Mr. Ford, managing editor of The Albany Argus, with having been bribed to vote for the apportionment amendment, was called in the Police Court this morning.

NOROTON, Conn., Oct. 24. -- Miss Susie Beatrix Crimmins, eldest daughter of John D. Crimmins of New-York, and Albert Gould Jennings of Brooklyn were married at Firwood, the country home of the bride's father, at Collender's Point, Darien, at noon to-day. Miss Lilly Lalor Crimmias, sister of the bride, was maid of honor.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 24. -- By the death of Miss Mundell of Windsor, Garibaldi's sword now becomes the property of M.A. Goudge. Miss Mundell's brother Joseph took an active part in resisting the subjugation of Uruguay by Rosas, Dictator of Buenos Ayres. Garibaldi was at that time Commander in Chief of the Uruguayan Army and Navy,

The statement given out from the Democratic Headquarters with reference to the possible effect of the "new Constitution" in suspending the animation of the Legislature for a year does not make clear the unquestionable fact that all the provisions relating to that matter are contained in the amendment which includes the apportionment, and which is to be submitted to a separate vote.

A rumor gained currency late yesterday afternoon that Police Justice Patrick Divver had forwarded his resignation as Police Justice to Mayor Gilroy, together with a letter asking that the resignation be accepted at once.

Arrangements for the century run off the South Brooklyn Wheelmen to Oakdale, L.I., and return next Sunday are now complete. The pacemakers will be Capt. R. L. Smith, J.J. Vilas, Walter Wyeth, David Louderback, F.G. Broaderman, W.B. Stillwell, C.P. Staubach, and J. F. McElhinny. The itinerary is as follows:

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad will be held in Topeka, Kan., today. There promises to be some friction between the present management and the protective committee. The latter will be represented by Theodore W. Myers, Gen. B.F. Tracy, Simon Sterne, and Newman Erb.
Senator Hill was in a very happy mood yesterday forenoon over the Brooklyn demonstration of Tuesday night and various other evidences of improving prospects.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 24. -- Two of the cases brought against druggists of this city by the Ohio Dairy and Food Commission on charges of vioation of the laws against the adulteration of food and drugs came up in Justice Philip Winkler's Court today.

Another grand lecture by Dr. Greene in Chickering Hall. Out of that immense audience of ladies, there was not one to whom the Doctor's powerful words did not appeal most strongly. Indeed, there were very few who did not feel that he was talking directly to them and describing their own complaints.
Senator Charles J. Faulkner's visit to this City to bring about harmony with reference to the Democratic Congressional nominations has not borne fruit.

The business world was notified yesterday morning that the long-established wholesale firm of Stern Co. of 687 and 689 Broadway had failed, and about the same time Louis S.Stern, one of the partners, was found dead in the reservoir in Central Park, at Eighty-ninth Street.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24. -- A cold rain stopped long enough to allow the Princeton and Lehigh football elevens to strive for the mastery on a wet and slippery gridiron to-day, and the Princeton men succeeded in crossing Lehigh's goal line six times, with a total of four goals. Lehigh failed to score.

Authority by the Secretary of the Treasury to issue rulings on customs administration to govern the Board of General Appraisers was brought in question yesterday by a decision of the board in the appeal of Jacob Booth. Mr. Booth, returning from Europe on the Majestic in April, 1893, brought with him a bicycle which he had used abroad.

Agents said to represent certain police officials in this city, assisted by a New-Jersey State Senator and a squad of Jersey City policemen, yesterday morning made a desperate attempt to prevent Mrs. Matilda Herman, a Lexow witness, from coming to New-York with two of the Senate committee's detectives to testify as to her dealings with Captains, ward men, and others connected with the Fifteenth Precinct.

BOSTON, Oct. 24. -- The market for local stocks remains dull and lifeless. The only feature of Interest to-day was Fitchburg preferred, which advanced 1 1/4 further, to 77 1/2. Improvement in earnings is said to be the cause of the advance. Boston and Albany was strong, at 205. West End Street Railway showed some activity, and advanced sharply at the close to 54 1/8, a rise of 1 1/8.

-- The Century Road Club of America has just allowed the following records: R.P. Searle, Rockford, Ill., 200 miles, 16:39:00, Aug. 5 1894; Illinois State record. J.A. Pallister, Ottumwa, Iowa, 50 miles, 3:31:60, July 22. 1894; Iowa State record. W.S. Furman, Oran, Ohio, 15 miles 42:38, July 4, 1894; Ohio State record. T.S. Jensen.

Edward M. Shepard of the Reform Democratic Party in Kings County had a conference with Senator Faulkner of the Congressional Campaign Committee in this city yesterday with reference to the Congressional situation in Kings County. Senator Faulkner is desirous of bringing about a compromise, solely with the idea of helping the Administration.

The "vigilance of Superintendent Byrnes in ferreting out cases of fraudulent registration, the promptness of the Grand Jury in finding indictments, and the determination of the Superintendent to have arrests made at once, instead of wafting for the offenders to turn up at the polls and offer to vote, will have a deterrent effect upon the "floaters" and those who seek to make voters of them.

There is nothing going on in the poli tics of the United States just now more interesting than the canvass of the Hon. William L. Wilson for re-election to the House. Mr. "Wilson's district is a very large one, covering a territory about as great as the State of Massachusetts. It lies among the mountains of West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The Sugar Trust case was argued to-day before all the Justices of the Supreme Court except Messrs. Field and Jackson. The prayer of the bill was that the contracts by which the American Company became possessed of the capital stock of the E.C. Knight, Franklin, and Spreckels Refining Companies, and the Delaware Sugar House be rescinded, and an injunction issued against further violation of the "anti-trust law."

The Empire City Handicap was the event of the tournament of the Emerald Gun Club at Dexter Park, L. I., yesterday. Among the fifty-seven entries were Capt. "Jack" Brewer, ex-champion of America; J. Morphy, who tied Capt. Money in last year's Great American Handicap, shot at Dexter Park; Ferd Vandyke, Newark's crack shot; D.C. Smith, C. Furgueson of Brooklyn, W. F. Quimby, J.G. Knowlton, and R.A. Welch, Philadelphia, holder of the Rivington Cup.

ALBANY, Oct. 24. -- The Twentieth Congressional District is composed of the County of Albany, which gave Gov. Flower a plurality of 4,227 in 1891. The following year Mr. Cleveland kept the county in the Democratic column by a plurality of 596. Last Spring the City of Albany elected for the first time in a decade a Republican Mayor, Oren E. Wilson,

Delmonico's was the scene of one of the handsomest weddings of the season at 6 o'clock last evening, when Miss. Florette Seligman, the youngest daughter of James Seligman, was married to Benjamin Guggenheim, a son of Meyer Guggenheim of 66 West Seventy-seventh Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Gottheil, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Silverman.

UTICA, Oct. 24. -- Thomas E. Kirnney, exMayor and a Democratic leader, caused to be printed to-day in a morning paper a statement of his position in this campaign. In the course of his letter he says:

-- Jesse C. Hensll of Ellenville. N.J., a pensioner, was again acquitted yesterday in a trial before Judge Benedict and a jury in the United States Circuit Court. There were three separate indictments found against him for procuring false writings in pension proceedings. Two have been disposed of by acquittals, and he was yesterday remanded for trial on the third one, which is similar to the others.
The second Retail Grocers' Convention, under the auspices of the Central Association of Retail Merchants, was held last night at Retail Grocers' Hall, 138 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The deputies attached to the Internal Revenue Office in Brooklyn on Tuesday night succeeded in raiding an illicit distillery. It was found in the old pottery works building on Brush Street, near Hamilton Avenue, in the rear of the Brooklyn City Railroad carhouse. None of the moonshiners was captured.

-- The Anti-Tammany Democracy of the Twenty-third and Twenty-eighth Assembly Districts will have a joint mass meeting and ratification Saturday evening at Richmond Hall, One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Eighth Avenue. William L. Strong, Otto Kempner. John Jeroloman, and Dr. William O'Meagher have agreed to speak.

President Cleveland left this city for Washington yesterday afternoon. Just before he went on board the private car of Vice President Frank Thomson of the Pennsylvania Railroad, which was attached to the Colonial Express train at Jersey City, he sent a complimentary message to newspaper men and informed them that there was nothing in a story that he had written a letter indorsing the candidacy of Senator Hill.

HERKIMER, Oct. 25. -- The Mohawk Valley, from Sehenectady to Utica, is buzzing with prosperity by day and oratory by night. Every mill along the valley is humming with Industry. Last year at this time business was as fiat and as cold as a flagstone. Thousands of unemployed walked the streets, unable, many of them, to find a mere pittance for the sustenance of themselves and those -who -were dependent upon them.

-- Harry Bossa, the champion of New-Canaan, Conn., will start from the Obelisk in Central Park at 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon, and attempt to beat the record of 1 hour and 54 minutes to Stamford, Conn. Paul Grosch, the fast quarter-miler, has charge of the arrangements for the trial. He has secured Elmer Hodgson of Lyndhurst and Thomas Hughes or Paterson to do the pacing.

There was a story about the City Hall yesterday that Patrick Divver had placed his resignation as Police Justice in the hands of a personal friend, who was to make terms with Mayor Gilroy. These terms, it was said, were to provide that Divver was to name his successor, and that he was also to be assured of future power in Tammany Hall.

Mr. Charles W. Hackett, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, repels with indignation the charge that he has once more secured the services of Mr. "Dave" Martin of Philadelphia to win doubtful voters to the Republican side. He goes so far as to declare that he need not take the trouble to deny the charge, and that "for Sheehan, Judge Divver, 'Tim' Sullivan, or any of that ilk to make such statements is humorous."

Army. -- Leaves of Absence. -- Major J.C. Worthington, Surgeon, fifteen days, from Nov. 3; Capt. George E. Bushnell, Assistant Surgeon, ten days' extension; Lieut. J.W. Ruckman, First Artillery, one month; Capt. Egbert B. Savage. Eighth Infantry, six months, from Nov. 15; Lieut.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 25. -- Jacob Rudd Shipherd, the Richmond Hill lawyer against whom suit was brought a short time ago for alienating the affections of Mrs. Charles B. Crowell of New-York, has been forbidden, by resolutions passed by the Trustees, to enter the Union Congregational Church of Richmond Hill, under penalty of bodily ejectment.

Dr. Parkhurst spoke last night to an enthusiastic audience that filled New Irving Hall. Essex and Broome Streets. The meeting was under the auspices of the City Vigilance League. Dr. Parkhurst was introduced by T.B. Reynolds, head worker of the University Settlement, as "the plucktiest man in New-York." Dr. Parkhurst said:

We do not see exactly what Mr. Reed expects to gain for the Republican Party by his continual tirades in the "West against the South in Congress. That section of our united country gave up voting on war questions a good many years ago and has been paying a good deal more attention to the business of the present than to the quarrels of the past.

The Emerald Gun Club's tournament at Dexter Park came to an end yesterday, when the Empire City Handicap, begun on Wednesday, was finished. Of fifty entries, twenty-three got part of the money, the first going to Ferdinand Vandyke. T.W. Wright, and J.G. Knowlton, who killed twenty-five straight each; second money to G. Y. Hudson, H.G. Wheeler, C.E. Morris, R. Woods, "Leroy," A. Wilty, and F. Class, twenty-four killed;

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Senator Faulkner, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, returned to Washington this afternoon from New-York, where he spent several days in an effort to bring about harmony in the Congressional districts where there is more than one Democratic candidate.

The Rev. Merle St. C. Wright of the Lenox Avenue Unitarian Church, Lenox Avenue and Twelfth Street, has arranged to have monthly lectures given before the Men's Club of the church during the Fall and Winter upon subjects pertaining to social reform. The club has over 100 members, and its object is to educate all to become good citizens with a proper idea of their responsibility to the community.

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Miss Lillian May Brown was married at St. Paul's Church at 7:30 o'clock this evening to Joseph Lewis Martin. The bride is the second daughter of Mrs. John Everett Brown and the groom the eldest son of Capt. Joseph W. Martin. The officiating clergyman was the Rev. Roderick R. Cobb, rector of the parish.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment acted yesterday upon the provisional estimates for 1895 for charitable institutions. In the following table the amounts allowed are compared with those allowed for 1894:

-- "Jim" Blake, '94, full back on the '93 championship team, and Jessa Riggs, '92, the veteran guard, assisted in coaching the candidates for Princeton's 'Varsity team yesterday. Blake will give his attention to the candidates for full back. Riggs will devote his time to the men trying for line positions, especially to the guards and to his brother Dudley at centre.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- A colony of a dozen intimate associates of Matilda Herman, the Lexow witness arrested in Jersey City, has been discovered in this city. These persons live in Customs House Place. In one house, at 134 Customs House Place, at present resides Mrs. Louise Tabour, formerly of 137 West Third Street, New-York, who also rented two houses on Macdougal Street.
Senator Hill spoke to f the workingmen of New-York and Brooklyn last night at Cooper Union. He had a magnificent audience -- magnificent not alone in point of numbers but in character as well.

The Woman's Municipal League filled the big hall in Cooper Union with a large and enthusiastic mass meeting in behalf of good government yesterday afternoon. Only one or two seats in the hall were vacant, and many men were standing at the back and sides, of the room.
A mass meeting to ratify the reform ticket nominated by the Committee of Seventy was held last night in the Lenox Lyceum.
The Congressional situation in Kings County has been cleared to a considerable extent by the voluntary withdrawal of Daniel Walsh in the Sixth District, and John L. Nostrand in the Fifth District.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., Oct. 25. -- The largest political gathering ever assembled In Harrison County greeted the Wilson party on Its arrival here at 7:30 to-night from Parkersburg. People came a distance of thirty miles in special railroad trains, carriages, wagons, on horseback, and afoot.
Messrs. Stabler Smith have sold for the Mercantile Building Company, to a Mi Sheldon, the four-story American basemen dwelling, 574 West End Avenue, 20 by 47 by 68, at about $24,000.

Ex-Mayor Grant was at his headquarters all day yesterday trying to pull Tammany's chestnuts out of the fire and conducting the campaign of bluff. His literary bureau was grinding out a variety of matter In the hope of infusing some hope into his followers. He held a conference with Corporation Counsel William H. Clark, Mayor Gilroy, and a few others late yesterday afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 25. -- William R. Hunter was married at noon to-day at All Saints' Chapel, to Miss Edith Norman. The groom is a member of a Newport real estate firm, and the bride is the second daughter of George H. Norman, owner of the Newport Water Works. Bishop Thomas M. Clark and the Rev. Dr. Magill officiated.
SOUTHAMPTON, Oct. 25. -- The steamer Paris, from New-York, which arrived last night, reports having encountered terrific weather, with mountainous seas, which swept over her deck.

BUFFALO, Oct. 25. -- Gov. McKinley of Ohio has begun his campaign work In this State. He has made to-day five addresses, In which he has extolled McKinleyism and denounced the policy of tariff reform. The first two speeches were made in Dunkirk, where the Governor arrived at 6 o'clock this morning.

The Golf Club of Glen Ridge, N. J., has been formally opened. The course is laid out on a plot of ground consisting of about forty acres, adjoining Upper Ridgewood Avenue. The ground is an ideal one for golf, and is pronounced by Mr. Tallack, the professional instruotor and an old-time golfer himself, as one of the best golf links in this vicinity.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25. -- There was a little more activity to-day, but it was in most cases at the expense of values. In the last hour, however, there was a slight rally. Reading during the whole session was weak, declining to 8 5/8. The selling was chiefly from New-York, and the buying was without significance.

At the session of the Fassett committee on March 24, 1890, It was discovered, among other things, that Hugh J. Grant, as Sheriff, divided with his auctioneer, William Topping, gross fees amounting to $42,937. His counsel, W. Bourke Cockran, stated before the committee on March 15 that the law did not allow auctioneers' fees.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Under the will of Alfred Badeau, a wealthy resident of New-Rochelle, who died in June, 1893, leaving a large estate, three legatees, who were entitled jointly to $75,000, applied last month for an order compelling the residuary legatee, John E. Badeau, executor of the will, to pay them not only their legacies one year after the will was proved, but also Interest amounting to about $5,500.

The Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, at their meeting yesterday, awarded a contract for lighting the bridge cars with electricity to the Electrical and Mechanical Engineering and Trading Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- According to the estimates prepared at the Interior Department, $155,805,278.83 will be necessary to carry on the work of that department, including payments for pensions, during the next fiscal year. The appropriation for this fiscal year was $169,559,950.03, and the saying for the next year is estimated at $13,754,671.20.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Wi-Ju says that Count Yamagata, Commander in Chief of the Japanese forces in Corea, has reported to the Government at Tokio that a detachment of 1.6OO Japanese infantry crossed the Yalu River on the morning of Oct. 24, at Sukochin, above Wi-Ju.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25. -- Justice Tyrrell this morning set Saturday afternoon as the time for the hearing of the case of the State Food Commission against Milton Franken, a clerk for Druggist. W.J. Hall, who was arrested on a charge of selling a bottle of Paskola. This case is the second brought against Franken, the first having been thrown out of Justice Winkler's Court on a demurrer.

Decision is expected next week by the General Appraisers on a case involving the foreign market value of beet sugar. Importers are much interested in the matter, because it will dispose of the question whether the internal revenue tax laid by the German Government shall be retained or deducted in computing the market value.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- The second-account trading commenced to-day, but there was none of that activity which characterized the trade a month ago. The general market was rather dull, and most of the trading was confined to the cables. The feeling was more favorable, and, that, too, in face of discouraging. Eastern advices.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

--The United Hebrew Charities of this city will hold their twentieth annual meeting at the Berkeley Lyceum next Monday evening at 8:15. President Seth Low of Columbia College, the Rev. Dr. De Sola Mendes, and Henry Rice will deliver addresses.

Gov. McKinley went down to New-Orleans the other day to tell the people of Louisiana that they ought to support his tariff policy. He was received by a committee the Chairman of which was ex-Gov. Warmoth. Four and a half years ago Mr. Warmoth gave testimony before Mr. McKinley and his Ways and Means Committee in Washington.

The managers of Mr. Strong's campaign, at headquarters in the Sturtevant House, believe they are making a winning fight. The leaders of the several organizations which have indorsed the candidates of the Seventy hold dally conferences, and are dividing the campaign work in such a way that all their energies may be used to the best advantage.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25.-- As an out-come of the claim of The Philadelphia Record (Dem.) that 30,00O names have been fraudently placed on the Assessors' lists In this city "for the, purpose of returning a false and enormous Republican majority at the next election," S. Davls Page,
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The Governors of the Bank of England have Issued circulars announcing an extension of the term of the Baring liquidation until Nov. 15, 1895, In accordance with the powers granted In 1893.

Hard work was put in at the Democratic State Headquarters yesterday. Ex-Secretary William C. Whitney, who recently returned from a Western trip, spent the greater part of the day there, working with the great political ability and foresight for which he is noted. He was there three or tour hours and he had conferences with Senator Hill, Chairman Hinkley, and John Boyd Thacher.

In conjunction with Its groups of works by American painters, the Imperious beauty of which is perpetual, the American Fine Arts Society Will now show, for four weeks at least, the collection of paintings by the old Dutch and Flemish painters formed by Mr. Louts K. Ehrich.

"Women are naturally weaker than men, and more despondent. They suffer and require assistance. Far too often this is not appreciated, but it is, nevertheless, necessary. Men are made to battle with the world and with each other; women possess the gentler traits which entitle them to consideration and kindness.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Henry T. Helmbold, the patent medicine man, whose reckless expenditures of large sums of money gave him a national notoriety, died suddenly yesterday in the State Asylum for the Insane, and his body is at an undertaker's establishment awaiting the orders of the family, who so far have failed to respond to the telegraphic notice.
Ex-Senator J. Sloat Fassett dined at the Oxford Club, in Brooklyn, with Mayor Schleren and others last night, and then went to the Clermont Avenue Rink, where about 5,000 persons greeted him.

The fifth general meeting of the New-York Yacht Club was held last evening at the clubhouse in Madison Avenue, and, despite the inclement weather, about sixty members were present. Vice Commodore Brown presided in the absence of Commodore Morgan, who is in Europe.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Oct. 25. -- Senator Hill spoke this afternoon in the Queens County Court House to an audience that filled the seats, aisles, and galleries, and even the benches in the corridors. It was his first visit to this city.

Vice President Adlai E. Stevenson might have had much better weather to begin his campaign speechmaking in, but he would have to go far to find a more enthusiastic assemblage of Democrats than that which greeted him last night in Tivoli Hall, Fifth Avenue and Second Street, South Brooklyn.
UTICA, N.T., Oct. 25. -- Stewart A. England, seventeen years old, was Instantly killed to-night by a shock of electricity received from the combination knob of Jeweler Bernard Goldsteln's safe.

-- Paintings, sketches, studies, water colors, etchings, and engravings, about 300 in number, and some sculptured and carved works by Charles Jacque, are to be sold by auction at Paris, in the Georges Petit Gallery, Nov. 12, 13, 14, and 15, Messrs. Durand-Ruel have the catalogue, for which Jules Claretle and L. Roger-Miles have written reviews of the amiable characteristics of the man and the excellent qualities of the artist.

The retirement of Gen. O. O. Howard for age, early in the coming month, furnishes a double source of interest and surmise, since not only is his successor to be appointed from among the Brigadier Generals, but a Colonel will then be promoted to the vacancy thus created in this latter grade.

About 10O east side women were in the De Witt Memorial Church, 280 Rivingtan Street, yesterday afternoon -- to listen to anti-Tammany speakers from the Woman's Municipal League in their fight against Tammany. Every tenth woman in the audience toad her baby with her.
ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 25. -- Rooms are being prepared for the Czarowitch In the Winter palace. Work proceeds night and day.
John Simpson will be the "only regular" Republican nominee for Congress In the Ninth District.

-- The trial of Robert F. Kneebs of Nebraska on a charge of fraud in racing horses in Germany under fictitlous names and false pedigrees and records began yesterday at Berlin in the Boabit Criminal Court. The President of the Court decided that the animal entered by Kneebs was the American mare Bethel, though she was entered under the name of Neilie Kneebs.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 25. -- Newport's city election yesterday resulted in the choice of a Republican City Council in both branches. Upon the face of the Wardens' returns, John P. Sandborn (Rep.) had a majority of 36 over John Waters (Dem.) for Mayor, but the Second Ward showed an apparent deficit of about 100 votes for Waters.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 25. -- Within a range of 3/4c there was a quiet trade in wheat to-day. Speculators found no inducement to buy, and the low price deterred them from selling. Neither bulls nor bears were aggressive in their action to-day, the market being permitted to take care of itself pretty much all through the session.

The desire of Senator Lexow and some of his colleagues on the Senate Investigating Committee that John W. Goff "go higher" than policemen and lodging house and disorderly house keepers In the examination into the affairs of the Police Department was gratified yesterday by the counsel, who, at the afternoon session of the committee, called Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan as a witness.

St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square, was the scene of an important and unusually pretty wedding at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when Miss Alice Marshal Westervelt was married to Walter D. Clark. The Rev. Dr. John A. Aspinwall, an uncle of the bride, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. T. S. Shipman, rector of Christ Church.

With Senator Faulkner's departure for Washington yesterday all hope of a compromise in the Congressional situation in this city practically ended. Lieut. Gov. Sheehan. who has co-operated with Chairman Hinkley in the effort to get the Democrats to unite on one candidate in each Congressional district, said that all that could be done had been done and that the negotiations were at an end.

This shows that during the six years prior to 1889 the municipal administrations made expenditures out of the proceeds of bonds which became a part of the funded debt of the city to the extent of $38,233.097, from 1883 to 1889, Inclusive.

The Rapid-Transit Railroad Commissioners, in answer to many inquiries, have issued a statement of their views on rapid-transit questions for the benefit of voters. A summary of these views is given herewith.

MUSKOGEE, I.T., Oct. 25. -- The "Bill" Cook gang of outlaws Is headed for the mountains In the western part of the Nation, with the Indian police, Indian Sheriffs, and United States Marshals in close pursuit.

Dr. Alexander M. Phelps, a well-known surgeon, who lives at 40 West Thirtyfourth Street, appeared as complainant in a robbery case at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, but before the proceedings were over he was a prisoner on a charge of disorderly conduct.

A sharp break in the coal stocks was the feature of yesterday's market. The decline began early in the day, and extended to 3 3/4 in Jersey Central, 3 1/8 in Lackawanna, 5 in Delaware and Hudson, and 1 in Reading. Reading closed at its lowest price, and Jersey Central only 1/4 better, but the others of the group made substantial recoveries, although their net losses were still material at the close.

-- English Plays in French. -- A great many French adaptations of English plays are to be produced in Paris this Winter, and the posters of several theatres furnish some interesting and amusing reading, as a consequence. At the Renaissance "La. Seconde Mrs. Tackeray" is announced, which creates a confusion in some minds between Mr. Pinero and the author of "Vanity Fair."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 25. -- Unless Robert J. improves considerably over his present form, he will be unable to keep up his unbeaten record when he meets John R. Gentry at Buffalo next week. The famous king of the sulky made two attempts at a fast mile here to-day, before the largest crowd of the meeting, and each time his limit was 2:07.

Garrick Mallery. Capt. and Brevet Lieut. Col. Garrick Mallery, United States Army, who died in Wash- ington Wednesday, was born in Pennsylvania April 23, 1831. He was a soil of the President Judge of the Circuit Court of Pennsylvania, and was descended in a direct line from Peter Mallery, who arrived in Boston from England in 1638.

Both the professional and Class B ranks have been swelled this week as the result of the vigilance of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen. Eleven riders, according to the announcement in the board's weekly bulletin, issued yesterday by Chairman Raymond, have been adjudged professionals, while five have been branded as Class B men.
The registration in New-York City yesterday -- the third day of registry this year -- was 63,443. The total for the three days Is 266,247.

Mr. James Duffy has sold to the Jackson Sharp Company the fifteen three-story brownstone dwellings on the south side of One Hundred and First Street, east of Fourth Avenue, each 17 toy 100, for $266,325, or $17,775 each.

There is a little mystery surrounding the marriage of Miss Lillian Townsend of this city to the Count Oliver de la Taille of Tours, France, which took place last Monday in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, and at which the Rev. Dr. Houghton, rector of the church, officiated.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The Republicans of the Genesee, Mohawk, and Onondaga Valleys are happy to-night, for the great inventor of the McKinley bill has told them all about it, and filled them with longing for high tariff, protection, big wages, and the millennium.

The steamship Lucania of the Cunard Line added another to her list of glories by reaching the Sandy Hook Lightship yesterday at 3:57 o'clock P.M., thus completing the voyage from Daunt's Rock, four miles from Queenstown, in 5 days 7 hours and 23 minutes.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

Heretofore Tammany Hall has depended upon two great influences for the election of its candidates to municipal office. The first is its influence, as an organization holding power, to control the conduct of a large mass of voters through self-interest or fear. The second is its influence as a "recognized" party organization, commanding support for its nominations through the sentiment of partisanship.

The recent operations of the Japanese make it clear that Moukden is, after all, their immediate objective; or, rather, that it is one of their objectives, the other being Port Arthur. Since it is very plain that the Japanese Generals know their business, they must be presumed to have good reasons for their choice, though these reasons are quite incomprehensible to strangers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The general feeling is that the North Chicago Railway Company will issue another million of stock for construction purposes and retain its World's Fair surplus. On the strength of this belief and the well-known excellence of the system, the stock opened at 264, against a closing yesterday of 260, and sold up to 266 5/8.

Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan occupied the witness stand before the Lexow committee all day yesterday. He was in a belligerent mood. He refused a number of times to answer questions, but was compelled to do so.

WASHINGTON, Oct 26. -- The employes of the Interior Department are much demoralized by the outbreak of smallpox there. One new case was reported to-day, that of J.J. Parker, one of the attorneys In the office of Judge Rucker, who was stricken Saturday.

Any one who will glance at Mr. Ivins's diagram on the first page of The Times will get a good deal of light on the practical capacity of Mr. Grant and of Tammany in one of the simplest departments of the city business, the cleaning of the streets.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- The statement of the business of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad. Company for the month of September shows gross receipts of $1,785,150.90; expenses, $962,927.35, thus leaving a profit in operating of $822,223.35. Net receipts from other sources were $18,172.72, making a total profit for the month of 5840,396.27.

KNOXVILLE. Tenn., Oct. 26. -- For two years there has existed in Sevier County a large organization of White Caps. They have committed many outrages on defenseless citizens, especially owomen and colored people.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The business in wheat today was of the sort that is usually seen when there is a Scarcity of news and a lack of interest. It was the kind that stamps the trade with the mark of unimportance. Although principally local, there was, nevertheless, some outside interest exhibited, New-York doing a little buying.

ROARING SPRINGS, Penn., Oct. 26. -- The Post Office and Thomas Replogle's jewelry store were robbed last night. The Post Office safe was blown open with dynamite, and 13,000 stamps, money orders, and cash to the amount of $453 were stolen.
Chairman Larocque of the Committee of Seventy has received the following letter from Seth Low, President of Columbia College:

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 26. -- Lashed on by a furious wind, the prairie fires that are now raging in the northwestern part of the State are traveling with almost lightning like rapidity, and are consuming every thing in their track.

Bicycles will be cheaper next year. For some time there have been threatenings of a reduction in prices by big manufacturers, and now one of the leading manufacturers announces that the price of bicycles next year will be $100, instead of $125. This firm has also notified its agents that they may now deliver 1894 wheels, to be billed Jan. 1, 1895, at a price of $100.

UTICA, Oct. 26. -- It was not till Senator Hill's appearance here that this beautiful little city realized that a hot political battle was on. The example then set by the Democrats was speedily followed by the Republicans, and, in the language of that political veteran observer and manipulator, Charles M. Dennison, "the Republicans are workins in this county in a way that I have not seen in a campaign since Garfield's."

The annual bowling tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs will begin on Thursday, Nov. 15, under particularly favorable auspices. Eleven clubs will be represented in the schedule, and, judging by the enthusiastic meeting of the Social Intercourse Committee, at the Columbia, in East Fourteenth Street, last evening, other clubs may come in later.

The Reform Democratic Party of Kings County is becoming more sanguine every day that its county and city ticket will receive a tremendous vote on election day. The men on that ticket are well known as men of ability, integrity, and character, and already many Republicans, as well as the better class of Democrats, have signified their intention of throwing over the party lines this year and supporting good men for local offices.

A wholesale attempt at false registration in the Twelfth Assembly District was exposed by Superintendent Byrnes yesterday, and as a result eight men are now under arrest and will be arraigned before Police Justice Simms in the Essex Market Police Court this morning. The names of the prisoners are:
There were several visitors at Police Headquarters examining certificates of nomination which had been rejected by the Police Board.

Most modern dictionaries of words have appended to them several lists of proper names, of which some stand for actual persons, some for names in biography, some for names of characters in action. It was the original purpose of the editors of the Century Dictionary to include in their work such lists, but the growth of material finally convinced them that the space af their disposal was entirely inadequate for the purpose.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 26. -- No fresh robberies by the Cook gang have been reported. The party is being hotly pursued by the Deputy Marshals. About 150 deputies have been ordered to Gibson by Marshal Crump to participate in the chase after Cook. Gibson is where Cook has hitherto made his headquarters.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The conference of the Federal Ministers is over, and the various members of that body will take their departure to-night. The Ministers were unable to arrive at a state of absolute accord, and Chancellor von Caprivi has handed his resignation to the Emperor. Count zu Eulenburg.

Townsend D. Haight, fifty-three yeara old, stabbed himself in the abdomen with a penknife at his home, 71 Bank Street, at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning. He was removed to St. Vincent's Hospital, where he died of shock two hours later. The wounds in themselves were not necessarily fatal.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 26. -- Surrogate Weller of Queens County will have to determine just what society Mrs. Susanna W. Areson of Flushing referred to when she left in her will a bequest of $400 to "The Society of the Old Woman's Home of Brooklyn." There is no institution of that name in Brooklyn.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- A suit in which 126 prominent citizens of Asbury Park have been named as defendants has been brought by attorneys representing a large fire-works concern in New-York City. The defendants comprise the Citizens' Committee of Asbury Park, selected last Spring to raise money to entertain the members of the National Editorial and the National Educational Associations, which held their conventions here in July.
The Women's Republican Association held a rousing anti-Tammany meeting at Abingdon Square last evening. The Lincoln Union rooms were filled with an apparently united crowd of incongruous elements.

William Nelson Cromwell, counsel of the Northern Pacific receivers, made the following announcement last evening: "The receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, through the Chairman of their Finance Committee, Mr. Rouse, have successfully negotiated the sale of $3,500,000 receivers' certificates to the General Reorganization Committee, represented by Mr. Edward D. Adams, Chairman, upon terms better than any heretofore, offered by anybody, all bids presented at Milwaukee being rejected as less favorable.

The Treasury bids fair to go into the month of November with a very cheering tendency shown in the gold reserve. Yesterday another half million was added to the increase of about the same amount for each of the preceding two days, making a total increase of $1,634,084. This brings the net reserve up to $61,140,550.

SEOUL, Corea, Sept. 10. -- It is now three months since the beginning of that remarkable series of events which have fixed all eyes on the far East, and brought Corea, as never before, prominently into public view. Fated by her geographical position and her potitical condition to be the uncertain factor in Eastern politics, she is at last the cause of a war which many felt was inevitable.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- There was a meeting at the White House to-day between the President and Senator Faulkner, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, but no hint of what passed between them has been given to the public. Mr. Faulkner said, in reply to inquiries on the subject, that only private matters were discussed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- The features of the market to-day have been the strength and advance in United Gas Improvement and Pennsylvania Steel and the weakness in Reading and Lehigh Valley. In United Gas Improvement, the buying of the past few days has been of the very best; it continued to-day and caused the stock to advance 4 per cent., to 72.

William Sinclair lived on Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, fifteen years ago, and was well known in financial circles. He was a stockholder in the Brooklyn Gaslight company, and was wealthy. He moved to Baltimore, Md., where he organized the Baltimore Gaslight Company. He also invested heavily in the Cleveland Gaslight Company.

In our dispatches of yesterday concerning the situation in the Mohawk Valley it was said: "At Amsterdam predictions are already made that the near future will bring the greatest prosperity the town has ever had, in spite of the croakings of the Sanfords, the big carpet manufacturers, who are trying to figure out for campaign orators the disadvantages of the Wilson bill as compared with the McKinley bill."

The Advisory Committee appointed by Mayor Schieren to consider the advisability of extending Flatbush Avenue to the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge entrance, and which has had three meetings, including one public meeting, decided yesterday to recommend to Mayor Schieren the advisability of making the extension by an airline route.

The State Democracy met at Cooper Union last night to ratify the Democratic State ticket. Addresses asking the audience to work earnestly for the success of the ticket nominated at Saratoga were made by William R. Grace, Francis M. Scott, and other well-known speakers.
A pamphlet for voters on "How the NewYork Senators and Tammany Hall supported Tariff Reform was issued yesterday afternoon by the Tariff Reform Committee of the Reform Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The latest information received at the English Embassy from Sir Julian Pauncefote is that he will not reach Washington much, if any, before Dec. 10. It is Sir Julian's intention to sail Dec. 1, but he may remain in New-York a day or so before coming to Washington. The ladies of his family, who preceded him to London early last Summer, will return with him.
The cash which Chairman Hackett of the Republican State Committee is disbursing in this campaign is almost drying the stream which flowed from the Morton "barrel" while it was on tap.

There was no improvement yesterday in the volume of trading on the Stock Exchange. In fact, the transactions footed up about 8,000 shares less than on Thursday. The coal stocks continued weak. Jersey Central broke from 105 1/2 to 102 3/4, but closed at 103 1/2, a net loss of 3/4. Leckawanna closed at its lowest price of the day, 162 1/2, a loss of 1 1/2 points, although only 500 shares changed hands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26.-- The San Francisco is finally to leave Brooklyn. This will be acceptable news to the officers and men of the ship, who have been waiting for weeks to learn of the station they must occupy for two or three years.

The "Hon." Justice Patrick Divver continued in strict seclasion yesterday. His best friends prefess to know nothing of his whereabouts, and the mournful inquiries of his followers in the "bannerdistrict," which he led for years with so much honor and glory to Tammany Hall, remain unanswered.

TRENTON. N.J., Oct. 26. -- The papers for the Incorporation of the Great White Spirit Company were filed to-day in the office of the Secretary of State. They show a paid-up capital of $5,000,000, and that nearly all the stock is oVned by Edward G. Maturin of New-York. The company's business headquarters will be in Boston, and branch offices will be maintained in this State.

BOSTON, Oct. 26. -- Speculation in local stocks was almost nil to-day, Erie Telephone being the only stock which showed any activity. The opening quotation was 1/4 lower than the close last night, and from there it dropped 1 1/4, to 51, recovering at the close to 52 1/2. Bell Telephone lost 2, to 198, recovering to 199.

If favored by the weather to-morrow the South Brooklyn Wheelmen will conduct what should easily turn out to be one of the most enjoyable of the Fall century runs. Cyclists all through the metropolitan district are interested in it, as was plainly shown by their haste to enter, and it will not be surprising if the promoters are forced to break their limit of 200 participants.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Daily News's correspondent in St. Petersburg says that, according to private advices, the Czar is steadily growing worse. Private letters received in Vienna say that the development of the cancerous symptoms has extinguished all hope.
Commissioners Martin and Sheehan, at yesterday's meeting of the Police Board, defeated the following resolution proposed by Commissioner Murray:

Harvard against Cornell is the most important football game in this vicinity to-day, and after the fine showing made by Cornell against Princeton last Saturday, much interest is being taken in to-day's contest. The Cornell men are confident of scoring against the men from Cambridge, and last night were betting even money that they would score, and even money that Harvard would be kept down to 18 points.

The season of artistic musical entertainments was formally opened last night in the chamber-music room at Music Hall. A new string quartet, organized and led by the popular violinist Maud Powell, came forward to appeal for public favor. Of course, the auditorium was full and there was any quantity of applause.
There was a well-attended meeting under the management of the Woman's Municipal League at the Home Industrial School, 34 Willett Street, yesterday afternoon.

UTICA, Oct. 26. -- Senator Hill said a few words to-day at the railway station in this city to a large crowd which called him out of his car. He passed through here on the way to Oswego. Speaking from, the car platform, he said:

OSWEGO, Oct. 26. -- Senator Hill this evening addressed a large and enthusiastic Democratic mass meeting in this city. Three thousand persons were crowded into the hall, and as many were on the outside unable to obtain even standing room within. On the stage were seated over 100 prominent Democrats, including all the leaders of the Administration faction.

Senator Hill's visit to this city has certainly had the effect of bouying up the hopes of the Democrats, and on all sides predictions are freely made that the Senator's New-York City plurality will be much larger than any of his friends here previously had reason to expect.

The Consolidated League of Brooklyn recently asked every candidate for Assembly honors in Kings County to state his position on the question of the Greater New-York. The following candidates have pledged themselves to vote in favor of a consolidation bill:

TRENTONY Oct. 26. -- There are eight Congressional districts in New-Jersey, and they were represented in the last Congress toy six Democrats and two Republicans. Four of the Democrats have been renominated and both the Republicans. The district lines have been changed by the recent Republican Legislature so as to secure, if possible, a larger Republican representation In he delegation that will go to Washington text March.

Every vote cast at the coming election should be a "conscience vote." Every voter should act according to his sense of duty as a citizen, having a conscientious regard for the consequences of his actions. There are Democrats whose votes will be affected by the candidacy of Senator Hill.

RIVERTON. N.J. Oct. 26. -- The Fall tournament of the Riverton Gun Club was commenced to-day on the club grounds here. Dark clouds made the light bad, and the wind was raw. Several sweepstakes were shot, but the main event of the day was the twenty-five-bird contest, $25 entrance fee, for the Fall cup, a beautiful silver trophy.

-- The second volume of the Standard Dictionary is nearly ready from the Funk Wagnalls house. The last page is now in type, and the volume will be ready for delivery in November. It is understood that the sales of this owork have been very large already.

The New-York Harbor and Staten Island Ferry Company now holds the franchise of the ferry between this city and Staten Island. Howard Carroll no longer figures In the transaction, and the matter stands exactly as it did about a month ago, when the lease was bid in at auction.

The City Vigilance League held a rally at the Broadway Tabernacle, Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, last evening. The Rev. Henry A. Stimson presided, and introduced as the first speaker Dr. J.H. Burrell.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Tokio says that Field Marshal Count Yamagata has reported to the Emperor that, at daybreak on Oct. 25, the Japanese Army under his command completed the crossing of the Yalu River, and in the forenoon attacked and defeated the Chinese near Fu-Shang, also capturing a fortress on the right bank of the River Ai.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Gen. Sewell, who was in this city yesterday, was asked what he thought of the action of the Essex County Convention in passing ah antiSewell resolution.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Further evidence was taken to-day before Judge Hudspeth in the contest that is being made against Father Corrigan's will, the contest being based on an allegation of undue influence and insanity.

-- The Crescents of Brooklyn and Rutgers College eleven will line up at 3:30 this afternoon at Eastern Park. A close game is likely, as the Rutgers men have been playing good football this season. On the Crescent team will be Wingate, left end; Quill, left tackle; Sanford, left guard; Baldwin, centre; Hotchkiss, right guard; Walker, right tackle; Wardner, right end; Crowell, quarter back; Whate and Goodwin, half backs, and Pratt, full back.
The Democrats of the First Assembly District held a large and enthusiastic meeting last night at Cortlandt Hall, 22 Cortlandt Street. About 1,500 persons were present.

Col. William L. Strong, the Committee of Seventy's candidate for Mayor, made his first address in public at a reception tendered to him by the West Side Republican Club, 102 West Eighty-second Street, last night. He was greeted with cheers and the waving of hats and handkerchiefs by the men and women present, most of whom are his neighbors.

Mr. Gilroy has insisted upon the fact that expenditures for municipal purposes have not been extravagant and have not increased disproportionately to the increase of population. The statement as made, however, is based upon partial figures and is decidedly inaccurate.

The St. Andrew's Golf Club of Gray Oaks, near Yonkers, will complete its championship tournament this afternoon, which was commenced two weeks ago. The only unfinished event is the final of the foursome match, and in this the contesting teams will be composed of J.B. Upham and L.B. Stoddart against T.C. Ten Eyck and W.E. Hodgman.

There were 37,820 names registered In Brooklyn on the third day of registration this year, and, with the two previous days, makes a total for the three days of 169,099, which is 16,060 more than for the three days in 1893, 7,020 more than in 1892, and 28,675 more than in 1891. In 1893 the registration for the three days was 153,039, in 1892 it was 162,079, and in 1891 it was 140,424.

AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 26 -- There seems to be a great improvement in the industrial situation in Maine. Mills are starting up which have been idle for months. The cotton mills and most of the woolen mills are running on full time. The pulp industry is decidedly prosperous and the profits are large.

Lillian Russell took a sunbath yesterday. She left New-York last July for London. She returned to this city last Friday aftering, on the steamship New-York. From the time she left New-York until she returned she did not catch a glimpse of the sun until it burst into her bedroom window yesterday morning, twelve hours after she had landed.

The most casual visitor to the Murray Hill section of Fifth Avenue cannot have failed of late to be struck by the beautiful facade and imposing masonry of a new building midway between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, whose towering form, so majestically raised aloft, dwarfs its fellows and almost challenges the glistening white spires of its close neighbor, the great Cathedral of St. Patrick.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- On the site at Clinton Avenue and Monmouth Street, where now stands an old homestead, said to be nearly a century and a half old, and in which, it is said, the evangelist, George Whitfield, once preached, the new house of worship of the Sherman Avenue Baptist Church is to be built.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Copyright, 1894 -- The outflow of gold to France is still in progress, but it is small. If it continues, it may soon have a noticeable effect, but at present the rates are unchanged.

Whoever chooses to observe with some attention the performances at the Irving Place Theatre can see in full operation the system whose disappearance from stages where English is the language spoken forms the subject for endless and more or less tiresome lamentation on the part of those for whom "old times" is a phrase incomplete without an accompanying "good."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Now that the army has the extended-order drill, the War Department is confronted by a condition created by that modern manoeuvre. The officers in command of troops report that they have great difficulty in getting through this form of extended order. There is no opportunity for it at most of the army posts, the territory being cramped.

-- A motion was made in the Supreme Court yesterday to continue the injunction obtained by John P. Persch, restraining J.W. Allison from assigning or transferring two notes of $10,000 each, given by Persch to Allison. The papers were given for the transfer of Allison's license to introduce the storage automatic telephone system in Pennsylvania.

Paris, Oct. 27 -- In consequence of the announcement in the Matin yesterday that Anarchists were coining from Poissy, Lille, and Lyons to blow up the Chamber of Deputies, the authorities at Lyons made a search of the apartments of a number of Anarchists last evening.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 27 -- The Board of Governors of the Crescent Wheelmen decided today to have an open century run on Tuesday next. This decision was the result of a popular request from the prominent cyclists of this vicinity. J.A. Haynes, Captain of the Crescents, was given charge of the arrangements, and he has determined upon a route that will delight all who take part in the run.

"You ain't had time to get acquaint much weth Deac'n Wallace, have you now?" the Squire was saying, tentatively, to the new minister, who had stopped by the pasture bars to admire the Squire's milking herd, and had glided from that subject into a discussion of his own spiritual flock. The minister shook his head. " I believe he is a pillar, firm and strong.

A wealthy American has bought for $8,000 a picture the history of which is impressive. This picture, signed Schenek, represents asses deliberating gravely around a cloth-covered table. It was exhibited at the Salon, at the close of the Empire. The Figaro gave to it an apppreciative article, in which it was insinuated that the painter doubtless had the intention of representing the Privy Council of the Emperor.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore delivered his one hundred and seventy-second lecture to the teachers of the City and State of New-York at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday morning. It was the second lecture in a series, of six given under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 27 -- County Treasurer Albert M. Darling of Suffolk County has in his possession five checks whose aggregate face value is exactly 13 cents. He will have them framed.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- I was telling a benevolent French family, who spend the larger portion of a small income, not to speak of time and patience, about our private enterprises in such matters -- King's Daughters, Little Mothers, and many others of similar value. The pater familias drew my attention to the extraordinary intellect, the remarkable energy and fitness of Severine.

Charles H. Swan, Secretary and Treasurer of the Union Bridge Company, the concern which desires to build a cantilever bridge across the Hudson, with a pier in the centre of the river, was shown the above report yesterday by a reporter for The New-York Times. He said he was not surprised that the report favored a suspension bridge.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 27 -- To have made a leisurely tour of the eastern part of this State with an eye single to observation in to have been less in town than in country; to have seen fewer men in coats than in farmer frocks; to have learned something of the condition of farmers in Connecticut now, as compared with past time.

The latest aspirants for a yachting, season are the members of the Pequot colony at New-Londoh, and from the present outlook they will have what they want. L. Vaughan Clark, owner of the sloop Gossoon and part owner of the schooner Alcaea, and one or two of the cottagers have been working hard to get the yachts to race there the week after the Yale-Harvard boat race, at the end of June.

A well-to-do fisherman, who was saturated with the angling craze, built a few years ago on a lake not many miles from this city a palatial mansion with all the appointments that wealth could devise or support. But his hobby of fishing cropped out when building the rear end of his house, which was placed on piles and projected some fifty feet over the lake.

Miss Beatrice Harraden is gaining health slowly but surely out in California, She is staying at a ranch near San Diego, and proposes to take a long draught of Pacificcoast ozone before she leaves there next June. Those who meet the young English-woman find her a very charming personality.

-- Mr. Philip Gilbert Hamerton says, at the conclusion of a highly appreciative article on the work of Louis Deschamps, in Scribner's Magazine, "It may, perhaps, be regretted that so serious an artist as M. Deschamps should be incongruously associated with the wildest freaks in the delirium of the modern French decadence, freaks which are entirely foreign to the sobriety and dignity of his nature."

A New-York woman has just toad an experience the indignity of which, shie says, she will not soon forget. "It emphasizes," says its victim, "two things; one, the extreme caution that every metropolitan housekeeper should employ in engaging a servant, and the other, the extreme difficulty that an American finds to get fair treatment at the hands of a Tammany Justice when his case is against an Irishman."

Referring to the personnel and discipline of the National Guard of New-York, Col. H.C. Merriam, Seventh United States Infantry, one of the most competent and practical officers yet detailed to this State by the War Department, has this to say:

I once had lovely golden hair, Or raven hair -- no matter which -- I was as good and sweet and fair As any angel in a niche. Or, if I did a little wrong, It was to prove me human still; My feelings were extremely strong, But I had disciplined my will.
The Republican Club of the City of New-York had a mass meeting at the Cooper Union last night. The hall was filled, and there was abundant enthusiasm over State and municipal issues.

The Illustrated London News says: "The will of Miss Charlotte Rosa Raine of St. Margaret's Lodge, Woodstock, Oxfordshire, Hayland's Manor House, Ryde, Isle of Wight, and 7 Peter's Place, Brighton, who died on June 19, was proved on Aug. 28, the value of the personal estate in the United Kingdom amounting to upward of L86,000.

One of the first passengers to step off the big record-breaking Lucania Friday night was a prominent English railroad man, who comes here as a representative of the English bondholders of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway system. He is Sligo de Pothonier of London, and is himself a heavy holder of Atchison bonds.

Gov. McKinley's visit to this State in behalf of Levi P. Morton's candidacy for Governor is construed at the Democratic State Headquarters as meaning that the Republicans are depending largely upon the high-tariff issue to carry this campaign.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 27 -- The Naval Cadets played one of the most creditable games, of football to-day that they have ever put up, holding the great University of Pennsylvania team down to 12 points. In the first half the Varsity did not succeed in scoring at all, but in the second half Brooks and Osgood made touch-downs and Brooke kicked both goals.

WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 27 -- Harry Tyler this afternoon rode a mile on the "Waltham cycle track in 1:48 3-5, lowering the world's record by 1 2-5 seconds, the Waltham track record by 2 seconds, and his own best previous time by nearly 5 seconds.

William Dean Howells leaned his cheek upon the two outstretched fingers of his right hand and gazed thoughtfully at the window -- the panes black from the night without, although studded once or twice with little electric stars far up on the west side of the Park. He was looking at something which his memory had just brought to him.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 27. -- The strike of the cotton screwmen paralyzed commerce on the rives front to-day. On only three vessels were men at work, and not a bale of cotton was handled on these.

The flotsam and jetsam of a dinner table is often suggestive. At one recently, at which were included among the men of the company several who are interested in newspapermaking. In one way or another, "shop" talk naturally got started, and the ideal newspaper was freely discussed. One put forward his notion of what it should be, with an enthusiasm and fluency that indicated off thinking on the subject.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 27 -- The annual Fall Yale track athletic games were held this afternoon. The weather conditions were perfect and a large crowd was in attendance. No records were broken, however. Exceptional work was done by Kershaw in the pole vault, Chubb in the 220-yard dash, and Cady in both hurdle races.

Two recent publications, viz., the official guides respectively of The Compagnle Internationale des Wagons-Lits and The Guide Officiel des Voyageurs, possess an especial interest as giving an insight impossible to obtain without the most extensive personal journeying, into the railroad systems of Europe, and suggest comparisons with, our own.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 27 -- J. Allen Francis, defaulting teller of the City Bank, was arraigned in the police court this afternoon, charged with embezzling $23,859 from the bank. He pleaded guilty to the charge. Judge Barbour held him in $5,000 bonds for trial at the next criminal term of the Superior Court, to be held in December.

William L. Strong yesterday made some utterances on the excise question which were loudly applauded by a large delegation from the German Reform Union, which called at his headquarters in the Sturtevant House.

Gen. Amos Beckwith, United States Army, retired, died in his rooms at the Southern Hotel, St. Louis, Mo., Friday night, after an illness of three months. He was born in Vermont in 1825. He entered West Point Military Academy, and was graduated in the class of 1850. He entered the army as Second Lieutenant of Artillery on July 1, 1850.

NEWPORT, Oct. 27 -- Newport has really had a gay week, but the several entertainments that have rendered it so undoubtedly have marked the very close of the season. The Hunter-Norman wedding of Thursday was a charming incident. Another was Mrs. S.F. Barger's young ladies luncheon, given in honor of Miss Louise Baldwin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The field telephone equipment for the array is a great success. Experiments have been held with the contrivance at Fort Clark, Texas, during the recent rifle practice at that post. One operator was stationed behind the firing butts, and operated the telephone from that position.

-- George Stewart was found dead in his bed early yesterday morning. Death was due to heart disease. He had been ill for some time. He was the eighth of nine children of David Stewart. He was born in Perthshire, Scotland, Dec. 11, 1832, and came to this country with his parents in 1836. He had lived in Yonkers since 1841.

At a meeting of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs, at the Columbia, in East Fourteenth Street, Friday night, the alleged slight to the Race Committee, which was laid at the door of the Trustees when they appointed a special committee to arrange for giving the Thanksgiving week races in Madison Square Garden, without consulting anybody on that committee, was satisfactorily explained by President Hildick.
Superintendent Byrnes was very reticent yesterday in relation to the registration frauds he had discovered in the Twelfth Assembly District.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Miss Ada Rehan concluded to-night a season of a week at the National Theatre, with a superb performance of Rosalind, which was seen by an audience as enthusiastic and cordial in its appreciation as it was large and thoroughly representative of the national capital.

The Question as to whether or not the adoption of the Constitution proposed by the partisan Republican Constitutional Convention would result in this State being left without a Legislature next year is one of the most interesting that has been raised in this campaign.

The National Christian League for the Promotion of Social Purity held its regular prayer and business meeting at the house of the President, Mrs. E.B. Grannis, 33 East Twenty-second Street, yesterday afternoon. The league proposed to further its good work by a discussion upon political purity after the transaction of the regular business.

C.J. Maynard of Newton told the members of the Boston Scientific Society that people who believe that the crow cannot sing are in error. The male bird. Mr. Maynard said, sings a beautiful sons during the nesting season,, but he prefers his mate as his only listener. The crow has everything in the way of singing apparatus that any bird has.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The death this week at the Providence Hospital of C.D. Brigham, a veteran journalist well known here and in New-York and Pittsburg, marks the passing of another of the small band of newspaper men who gained fame as war correspondents. Mr. Brigham had been a newspaper man before the war broke out, and was the intimate friend of Charles A. Dana, who was connected with The New-York Tribune as managing editor.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- It would be hard to find a finer or more substantial group of buildings than those of the United States Military Academy at West Point. The new Academic Building, which is now receiving its finishing touches, was begun in 1891. The cost of this structure will be about $450,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- The financial affairs of Mercer and Camden Counties are in desperate straits because of legal complications that have grown out of the organization of two Boards of Chosen Freeholders in each county. The State legislated out of office the old board in certain counties of the second class because they were represented according to the Assembly districts, which lines had been declared unconstitutional by the courts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Secretary Carlisle to-day received the report of the special board of inquiry on the Howard case, together with Commissioner Seimer's remarks transmitting the report and the voluminous evidence in the case.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The Prime Minister, Lord Rosebery, made an attack on the House of Lords in a speech in Bradford this evening.

The new rubber tire which J.B. Brewster Co. of 487 and 489 Fifth Avenue have just perfected is classed among the valuable recent improvements in vehicles, at least so far as concerns the comfort of drivers. This tire is of solid, cone-shaped rubber, fitted into a square steel rim, which in turn takes the place of the ordinary tire.

The Metropolitan Insurance Athletic Associa- tion team lined up against the football team of the Flushing Athletic Club at Flushing yesterday afternoon. The Flushing players won by a score of 18 to 0. In the first half Barnewall and Bell secured touch-downs. Bell, Weed, and Homans played well and made several good gains. In the second half Weed and Peck made touchdowns.

Sherlock Holmes could have communicated wisdom to the reporter if the latter had been young enough to receive it. for he admitted him into the intimacy of his home life, which, in accordance with the dictates of a very moral, though gently cynical, philosopher, one should ardently love.

In London, in the daedalous of small streets in the neighborhood of the colossal temple where the scales of Themis are held, you would seek in vain, for other things than lawyers' offices. Like bees in a hive, solicitors and barristers, in a multitude of cells, buzz. Still, I saw there in the showcase of a shop, under globes, a museum of wigs.

Of course the question of "literary morality" obstinately faces us when we come to consider "The Pacific Mail," by Paul M. Potter. It glares at us and will not down. It must be met some way, and the easiest way to meet it, perhaps, would be to say that Mr. Potter has no "literary morality," and thus get quickly to the horses.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- The re- ports of the various banks of Monmouth County have been published during this week. There are eleven national banks in the county and five State banks. The last statement of both the national and State banks shows that the total amount of money on deposit in all the banks Oct. 1 was $4,196,770.66.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The rifle team of the District National Guard defeated the State team of New-Jersey to-day at Marshall Hall, opposite Mount Vernon, by 31 points. Each team was composed of ten men, and the ranges were 200 and 500 yards, with fifteen shots at each distance. Private Scott, D.C.N.G., made the highest score, 140 out of a possible 150.
Ex-State Senator William Conselvea Traphagen died at his home, in Nyack, late Friday night of Bright's disease. He was in his fifty-seventh year. He leaves a wife and several children.

Gen. John B. Woodward, Gen. Wingate, A. Augustus Low, Silas B. Dutcher, Henry Hentz, and Daniel F. Lewis called on Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn yesterday and presented to him a petition urging the great importance of taking immediate action toward securing a proper park system.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 27 -- Onondaga will not true to her traditions this Fall. The former great pluralities of 4,000 and 4,500 that have been wont to set the Republican Party into spasms of exhilaration will not be forthcoming Tuesday, Nov. 6, unless all signs fall and James J. Belden is persuaded or cajoled into joining the procession and putting his shoulder to the wheel.

That was a brave little girl in Hackensaok, N.J., the other day, who saved a whole roomful of women and children from being burned by her quick thought and action. It was at a church party of some kind, held in the church parlors, and a lighted lamp with a big fancy shade on it blazed up suddenly, and the shade took fire.

WILLETS POINT, L.I., Oct. 27 -- There is a big twelve-inch gun standing on top of the ramparts here. It is an innocent-looking gun, and a big coil of telegraph cable wound around the muzzle end of the piece suggests that it has become fractured and that the Government is experimenting with an economical method of repairing brokendown ordnance.

J.B. Upham and L.B. Stoddart are the champion foursome players of America, by virtue of their victory yesterday afternoon in the final round of the foursome tournament at the St. Andrew's Golf Club, near Yonkers. Both men are members of the St. Andrew's Club, and Stoddart won the amateur championship in singles two weeks ago.

The date and details of the annual Yale Princeton football game are to be settled by a conference of prominent alumni of both Institutions. The managers of the elevens have failed to agree on the conditions of the match, and a graduate committee has taken the matter in hand. Thus far they have agreed on the date, which will undoubtedly be Dec. 1.

Alas for humanity in primitive times! If Mr. Worthington G. Smith is to be credited, the early man of the rough flint period treated the weak and the ailing with little consideration. "If friends grot badly hurt by beasts of prey or by accident, such injured companions were hunted away or killed. Fever patients, consumptives, the blind, the half-blind, and fractious children were driven off and killed."

One of those pleasant affairs which make the sport of cycling all the more popular occurred last evening at the clubhouse of the Riverside Wheelmen, 232 West One Hundred and Fourth Street. It was called a "presentation stag," and very appropri- ate the title proved to be. Nearly all of the prominent members were present, and everybody expressed himself as glad that he came.

The Committee of Seventy has been devoting considerable time to the investigation of the way Tammany has manipulated juries. The subject was first brought up by a letter, of which it is said 4,000 copies have been sent out, in an effort to secure the votes of former jurors for Recorder Smyth. The letter read:

In the interview with Prof. Fennel of Cincinnati, concerning his analysis in the case of the Ohio Food Commission against Vin Mariani, which is now practically "shelved," and a report of the proceedings of which appeared in The Times of Thursday last, the professor is quoted unintelligibly, owing to a typographical error.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Secretary Herbert's order for the cruiser San Francisco to relieve the Chicago as flagship of the European squadron was a great surprise to the navy, as it was expected the Chicago would remain abroad another year, but the Secretary decided that it would be better to put her out of commission pending the construction of her new machinery.

A reunion of the Associate Alumnae of the Normal College was held in the college chapel at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The graduates listened to an interesting address by Thomas Hunter, the President of the college, upon the life and labors of the late William Wood, the practical founder of the college, who died on Dec. 1 at the age of eighty-six years.

The census of 1891 has raised some intersting questions, and has furnished matter for warm debates in the House of Commons and in the country. What is a monoglot Welshman; how many of the species are still to be found in Wales, and on what evidence were the census returns on the subject based?
That jaunty confidence which existed a few days ago at ex-Mayor Grant's headquarters has disappeared.

Our London correspondent in his cable letter makes a very suggestive comment upon the present condition of Italy and Austria as threatening a social revolution, with mob violence on the one hand and organized force on the other. The remark might have been made more general.

The women who originated the idea last Spring of holding an exhibition of the portraits of women in the interest of a worthy charity are feeling that they have reason for self-congratulation, for their plans and work are about to bear fruit in an event which, both artistically and socially, will be one of the most important of the coming season.
