LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 27 -- The new church erected by St. Mary's Roman Catholic congregation of this city to take the place of the edifice destroyed in the big fire of July 21, 1893, will be dedicated tomorrow. The Right Rev. Charles E. McDonnell, Bishop of Brooklyn, will dedicate and bless the new church at the 11 o'clock services, at which he will also celebrate mass and preach a sermon.

The report of the board of engineers officers appointed by Brig. Gen. Thomas L. Casey to investigate the practicability of bridging the Hudson River between this city and New-Jersey was yesterday made public. In effect, the report recommends a suspension rather than a cantilever bridge.

Frederic C.P. Robinson has been a distinguished figure on the American stage for nearly thirty years. He came here with a good artistic reputation, acquired chiefly at the old Sadler's Wells Theatre, in London, under the famous management of Phelps. He has since been continuously before the public, and has acted a great variety of roles, often with brilliant success, always with taste and skill.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- It is an interesting historical coincidence that on the same day that ex-Gov. Joseph D. Bedle was buried, a sister Commonwealth was paying its tribute to the heroic deeds of a distinguished Jerseyman by unveiling an equestrian statue to commemorate the bravery of George B. McClellan, the thirtieth Governor of New-Jersey after the adoption of the Constitution.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Miss Elizabeth Saxer was made the bride of Charles H. Gerdes Wednesday night, although an hour before the wedding her life had almost been despaired of and a physician had been summoned, who administered morphine to her. This so revived her that she was able to leave her bed and go through the marriage ceremony.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The town of Greenburgh appears to be in a financial predicament which promises to give rise, soon, to some expensive litigation. It is all over some 4 per cent, bonds issued by the town, dated April 16, 1894, and maturing April 16, 1904, which are awaiting buyers at 97 1/2, with no takers.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- The present is one of the most quiet political campaigns the State has known for several years. It hardly raises more than a ripple on the surface of affairs in any portion of the Comomnwealth as yet, according to the political pilgrims who meet the leaders in the State during their travels and then bring what gossip they may find to headquarters here.

The state of the public mind in this country and elsewhere in Europe in regard to the present position of affairs in the far East, as reflected or created, by the chief newspapers, may, I think, be briefly stated as follows:

There was plenty of sport yesterday aftnoon at Meadow Brook, L.I., as the first rounds of the ladies' golf match were start- ed at 11 o'clock in the forenoon, and closed just before the afternoon hunt. The handsome silver cup which the ladies of the Meadow Brook Golf Cup are striving for is the gift of Sidney Dillon Ripley.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A Western lawyer has made a violent attack, on the head law officer of the War Department, Col. G. N. Lieber. The lawyer is the attorney of Capt. W.S. Johnson, a retired army officer who has given the Government considerably trouble, and who had previously been the subject of court-martial.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 27 -- A fire which resulted in the death of at least sixteen persons and the injury of three more started in the West Street House, at Columbia and West Streets, at about 1 A.M. At 3 A.M. the fire was under control, and an investigation of the ruins was made.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- The Princeton football eleven to-day lined up against the team of the Volunteer Athletic Club of New-York, and in two twenty-minute halves rolled up a score of 34 to 0. Capt. Trenchard played only five of the first eleven.
At auction in Brooklyn yesterday. Mr. Jose E. Pidgeon, as referee, sold to James C. Brower, plaintiff, a vacant plot at the west corner of Hamburg Avenue and Ralph Street, 90 by 100, at $10,000.

An attachment has been obtained here against John Heerdegen of Greenville, N. J., for $3,055 in favor of George W. Bramhall and others, doing business as the Hydraulic Contracting Company, on a claim for damages.

There are not many men in Massachusetts to-day whose fathers were soldiers in the revolution. The few who still live among us naturally are all advanced in years. They have their homes in various towns throughout the Commonwealth, and nearly all of them long since have given over the active toil for daily bread and await in peace the call of the trumpeter who long ago summoned their fathers to eternal rest.

Elections of Representatives in Congress will be held on Tuesday, Nov. 6, in all the States of the Union except Maine, Oregon, and Vermont, which have already chosen their Representatives -- eight in number, and all, as usual, Republicans. On the same day, the Territories of Arizona, New-Mexico, Oklahoma, and Utah will each elect one Delegate to Congress.

Of all the merchants in Venice Fabio Mutinelli was the most exact in keeping his engagements. He was liberal and magnificent on every occasion, and especially with ladies and people of the Church. The elegant polity of his manners was celebrated throughout the republic, and people admired at San Zanipolo an altar of gold which he had offered to St. Catherine for love of the beautiful Catherine Manini, wife of the Senator, Alesso Conaro.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The United States Treasurer now holds in United States bonds to secure national bank circulation, $199,756,200, as follows: Currency 6s, $14,042,000; 2 per cents., $22,749,900; 4 per cents., $155,982,450;5 per cents., $6,980,850.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- In a game of two twenty-minute halves on the parade grounds to-day. Yale defeated the cadets by a score of 12 to 5. The West Point team showed marvelous strength, and in the first half came near defeating the visitors.

Cornell scored twice in the football game on Manhattan Field yesterday against Harvard, and the students of the college at Ithaca are very much elated. The final score was: Harvard, 22; Cornell, 12. The Harvard team made the 22 points in the first half, while Cornell got the ball over the line only once.
The Very Rev. Dr. S. Reynolds Hole, Dean of Rochester Cathedral, England, who arrived here a day or two ago, was entertained at dinner last night at the Lotos Club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Secretaries of War and of the Navy are deaf to all the appeals that have recently been made to secure a football same between the Naval and Military Academy teams on Thanksgiving Day, and, it is understood, the policy adopted as a result of last year's fame to prevent the two branches of the service from meeting again on the gridiron will be rigidly enforced.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- United States Senator James Smith, Jr., reached his home in this city late last night from his European trip. He is much improved in health, but the rough weather encountered during the homeward passage greatly tired him. The Senator was a passenger on the steamship New-York.

About luncheon time my father sent us down to the pastry cook's shop, where we reveled among cream tarts and petits fours, and then we ordered our dinner, as people did then, from a trattoria near at hand. Then we went out again, still in our raptures, and when dinner time came, just about sunset, excitement had given us good appetites, notwithstanding the tarts.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- A dispatch to The Pall Mall Gazette says that the Japaness and Chinese fleets are off Che-Foo, and a battle may be expected at any hour.

There has recently been published the opinion of Prof. Virchow that the antitoxine treatment "has the effect of protecting the person so treated from diphtheria for weeks, and possibly for months, but that it remains to be demonstrated whether the effect is permanent or really curative."

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 27 -- The prices at which the greater part of to-day's very small trade in wheat was transacted did not vary 1/5 c from the closing quotations, of yesterday. At the close a few liquidating sales depressed the price a little, but it was a distinctly minor character business at all times. Throughout the entire half-holiday session there was scarcely enough trade to fill fifteen minutes on an ordinary day.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Senator David B. Hill arrived here to-night at 6:30 o'clock over the Black River Road. At the Stations along the line large numbers of people had congregated to see the Senator pass through. At several places where the train stopped he went out on the rear car platform and shook hands with many people who surrounded his car.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- Yesterday it seemed a nice problem whether the imperial tragedy that is being enacted at Livadia, or the decision of the London County Council to abolish the glaring Cremorne features of the Empire Music Hall, or the feat of the nine-foot boa constrictor at the Zoo in swallowing entire his eight-foot brother was the topic uppermost in the public mind.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Oct. 27 -- A new complication arose to-day in the extraordinary political situation here, and it is likely to offset the Whiteway success in the Trinity District last Tuesday, when three Whiteway supporters were elected. These three candidates, during the counting of the votes and before the result was known, filed a formal protest, claiming that the election was invalid, owing to the fact that a number of voters were without ballots.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The most interesting social event since the close of the last season will be the marriage of Miss Mattie Thompson to William Davis of New-York, in this city on Wednesday next. Miss Thompson is a daughter of ex-Congressman Philip Thompson of Kentucky. The wedding will take place at the residence of Secretary Carlisle.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27 -- By superior work behind the line and exceptionally strong and aggressive centre play the Orange Athletic Club won at football with the Lehigh University at the Orange Oval this afternoon. Two thousand persons saw the game.

There is a shortage of $78,000 in the Kings County Treasurer's office, at the head of which is Henry H. Adams. The shortage is plainly shown by the books. It stands forth as a fact not to be gainsaid by any plea, of incompetent accounting. It has been known for months.

In 1893 there was imported more than $12,000,000 worth of fine worsted cloth, such as diagonals and other similar goods commonly Known as coatings of the first quality. The duty exceeded $12,000,000 and was almost eaual to the value of the cloth, being equivalent to 99 1/2 per cent. ad valorem.

-- The members of the Central Traffic Association finished their labors in Cleveland Thursday and adjourned. The session was the most important, of the meeting. It resulted in the appointment of an Executive Committee of fourteen men and Passenger and Freight and Traffic Committees of seventeen members each. All matters of difference in either of the last-named committees will be referred to the Executive Committee for arbitration.

There was a fair amount of activity in the stock market yesterday, considering that it was a half holiday and that transactions have been so few in recent days. The sales were 73,134 shares, very nearly the average full day's business during the week. The coal stocks scored sharp declines. Jersey Central sold down to 98 3/4 , Lackawanna to 156, and Delaware and Hudson to 123 1/2.

What was called a "full-dress rehearsal or reading," but seemed, nevertheless, to be a very fair first-night performance of a new five-act play in prose, by Mr. Lorimer Stoddard, son of the venerable poet, entitled, "Napoleon Bonaparte," was given at the Herald Square Theatre last evening by Richard Mansfield, in the presence of an extraordinary audience.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 27 -- A.E. Tower of New-York to-day leased the George Gordon King villa, on Beacon Hill and Har- rison Avenue, for next season. Mr. Tower occupied the place last Summer.

A big fire in the heart of the dry goods district caused excitement yesterday among the business Houses on Broadway, between Leonard and Worth Streets, and brought out all the reserves below Fourteenth Street.

Over 40,000 citizens availed themselves of the last opportunity given to them this year to register, the exact number of names added to the list being 43,654, bringing the grand total registration for the four days up to 308,401, according to the official figures.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Thomas Nevins, the contractor of this city who recently went to Ireland to buy Killeen Castle, arrived home last night on the steamer Lucania. He returned sooner than he had expected, on account of the strike among the laborers on the East Orange outlet sewer.

HAMBURG, Oct. 27 -- A decree promulgated by the Senate was published to-day forbidding the importation of American live cattle. The decree is based upon the ground that in two herds just landed several animals were suffering from Texas fever. Cattle which left the United States prior to Oct. 28 will be permitted to land, but they must be slaughtered immediately upon arrival.

-- The Second Sunday Concert -- The programme arranged for this evening's concert at the New Metropolitan Opera House, with the artists of the grand Italian and French opera company and the Seidl Orchestra, with Mr. Anton Seidl at the conductor's stand, is one calculated to attract much interest. The instrumental numbers are varied and well calculated to please a popular as well as a critical audience.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 27 -- The rapid advancement of the season is manifested not only by the falling leaves and shorter days, but by the arrival of all-Winter guests and the fact that nearly all the cottagers have returned from their Summer outing. With the return of the cottagers comes a revival of social activity, which bids fair to more than equal the enjoyable round of pleasure which made Lakewood life attractive last season.

The much-talked-of suit against the Brooklyn Heights and the Brooklyn City Railroad Companies was begun yesterday by the serving of the papers upon President Daniel F. Lewis. The plaintiff in the action is Patrick H. Flynn, a stockholder in the Brooklyn City Railroad Company and President of the Nassau Electric Railroad Company.

Prince Clodwig Carl victor von Hohenlohe-Schillingsfurst is the chief of the second branch of the princely line of Hohenlohe-Waldenburg. He was born at Rothenburg March 31, 1819. He succeeded, in 1846, to his brother. Philip Ernest, in the titles and Qualities of Prince of Hohenlohe-Sehillingsfurst, by virtue of a contract with his elder brother, Duke Victor of Ratibor.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 27 -- United States Marshal Crump of the Western District of Arkansas has had more than 5,000 posters scattered throughout this section, announcing a reward of $250 each for the bodies of the members of "Bill" Cook's erase of outlaws. The reward is authorized by the Attorney General of the United States, and is payable on approval of the court.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman preached yesterday morning in Temple Emanu-El, Forty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, on the coming election.
Advices from the United States of Colombia indicate that the southern republic is about to enter on another stirring era in her history.

It is doubtful which is the most popular season of the year in wnich to be married -- Spring or Autumn. May and October are evenly-matched rivals with fashionable brides. Last Spring there were more weddings of general interest than in many previous years, and yet it is probable that more marriages are being celebrated this Fail than last Spring.

First elevens of the Majestics and the Sagamores played a lively game at Claremont Park yesterday, the Majesties winning by one goal. Banning and Tait, as guards, did especially good work. Nichols played an excellent game at full back. Meighan secured the touch-down, from which Mitchell kicked a goal.
Four thousand citizens of Brooklyn attended the mass meeting of the reform Democracy in the Clermont Avenue Rink last night, held to ratify the State and local tickets of that organization.

A board of War Department Engineers was set to investigating "the maximum length of span practicable for suspension bridges and consistent with an amount of traffic probably sufficient to warrant the expense of construction" some time before the expert board was appointed to consider the Hudson River Bridge question.

Last night, in one of the least tiresome of the Murray Hill drawing rooms was one of New-York's most exquisite women, Dorothy Dane, who is a widow for the second time, and is not yet thirty years of age. She looks as if a portrait by Beckwith had been animated by some magic and had come out of its frame.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The bulletin issued this evening says that the Czar has eaten well to-day, his heart's action is somewhat better, the oedema has not increased, and his spirits are better.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Ludlow B. Patton gave the fourth of their evenings at home on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- About this time every two years those persons who are entitled to regard themselves as reasonably permanent residents of the capital begin to consider the gloomy lot of the member of The existing Congress who has been doomed by the verdict of his constituents to remain for a time a local "has-been," instead of being chosen to be a powerful M. C.

OGUNQUIT, Me., Oct. 27 -- "Terrible glad t' see, sure's my name's Silas Larrabee. I was sayin' t' my darter only day 'fore yist'day, says I, ' I wisht I could see thet 'ere feller,' says I, 'thet corresponds for The New-York Times.' B'jocks, I ain't sot eyes on you sence you writ them pieces for the pepper 'baout me 'n some more on us wantin' t' hev a tin-plate fac'try daown here."
"Dropped into a letter box by mistake? " the Bureau of Information man in the Post Office repeated; "Room 14, second floor."

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Mrs. Mary Berger of 7 Grand Street Is dying of starvation in St. Mary's Hospital. She is the widow of a soldier who died several years ago, and, being seventy-six years old, was no longer able to support herself.

Five children clinging to a man in no way related to them, and begging, with tears and sobs to be left with him, rather than to be handed over to their grandmother, was the unusual sight witnessed yesterday morning in Judge McAdam's part of the Superior Court.

The ratification meeting of the Anti-Tammany Democracy organization of the Twenty-third Assembly District, held in Richmond Hall. One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, near Eighth Avenue, last night, was attended by about 700 persons. A big brass band and a handsome silk banner, presented by Mrs. Mark M. Pomeroy, added to the attractions of the ball.

The examination into the Tammany methods of governing this city was continued by the Fassett committee during April and May, 1890. Many of the facts that had been brought to light previously were again gone over by other witnesses than those who had already testified.

The registration in Brooklyn yesterday, the last day for this year, amounted to 22,081, which, with the three previous days, brings the registration this year up to 191,613 -- a decrease of 396 compared with last year and an increase of 615 over 1892.

Although it is impossible at the present time to present a complete list of the musical entertainments which are to be offered in this city in the season about to open, a tolerably full summary may be given, and may serve as a guide to those who desire to lay plans for the Winter's musical delight.

Capt. Max F. Schmittberger of the Nineteenth Police Precinct, against whom an indictment for feloniously accepting a bribe from Augustln Forget, the agent of the Compagnie Generate Transatlantique, while be was in command of the steamboat squad, surrendered himself at Police Headquarters yesterday into the custody of Detective Sergeant Reilly, who held the bench warrant issued for his arrest.

-- Thomas Stevens, who made a trip around the world on a bicycle, lectured to a small audience last night at the Fifth Avenue Theatre on "Yogi Magic." The lecture dealt with the alleged magical works of the Yogi Indians. In the course of his remarks Mr. Stevens said he held the secret which, when revealed, would go far toward strengthening the belief of Christians in the miracles related in the Bible.

The members of the National Beagle Club will meet at Hempstead, L.I., to-day to participate in their fifth annual field trials. These trials, as usual, will attract a large number of sportsmen, and dog lovers from all over the country.
The completion of the registration in New-York, Chicago, and Brooklyn shows rather striking contrasts, best brought out in tabular form:

The heraldic fauna is chiefly remarkable for the large number of chimerical animals that it contains. The predilection of heralds for such creatures as dragons, griffins, and unicorns may perhaps be explained by the fact that it is sometimes convenient to be unable to compare portraits with originals.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The Berlin correspondent of The Central News says: "The appointment of Prince Hohenlohe and Baron Koeller will be published in The Reichsanzeiger to-morrow.

The new Gravesend Reformed Church was dedicated yesterday afternoon. The locality is now included within the limits of the City of Brooklyn. The church is situated on the Neck Road, that famous thoroughfare in which Col. A.S. Bacon and his party of watchers were set upon and beaten last election day by "Boss" McKane's gang, and is about half way between the Ocean Parkway and Gravesend Avenue.

EASTON, Md., Oct. 28 -- Senator Gibson did not preside over the Democratic mass meeting in Music Hall yesterday. As United States Senator he naturally would be considered the biggest man in his party at his own home. Yet he did not even have a seat on the platform in front of the people he was sent to Washington to represent.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28 -- So many mistatements have been made about the number of students enrolled in the different departments of the university that the authorities have made an official statement regarding them. This supersedes the figures formed from the directory issued last week, and will be the authoritative account of the membership until the publication of the catalogue in December.

The Students' Aid Society, although but recently organized, yet has already become one of the most active agents for students' welfare of Columbia. Its main object is to assist students who are working their way through college. Through the efforts of the society students have secured positions as lecturers in the evening schools, tenement-house Inspectors, assistants in libraries, clerks, and in a number of other branches.

When the front of Levi Weinberg's clothing store, 178 Canal Street, was blown out by an explosion at 6:40 last evening a policeman was waiting and seized a man and woman who had just come out of the hall door. They gave their names as Louis Rothman, of 12 Avenue B, and Sadie Silvermeister of 219 Second Street.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 28 -- Probably the most interesting feature about the Virginia campaign this year is the apparent fact that it will furnish the issue upon which the legislative contest of next year will be fought.

Valentine Williams, who sleeps over the stable of Thomas Gallen, at 205 East Eighty-fifth street, was awakened at 5 A.M. yesterday by smoke in his room. He rushed down stairs and got out the horses safely, but forgot all about John Kelly, with whom he had shared his bed.

One of the best indications that Tammany does not desire to improve the condition of the city departments is shown by the fact that it did not demand Fire Commissioner Anthony Eickhoff's resignation after his want of qualification was published in the daily papers and became known to the community at large.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 28 -- A complex runaway accident, in which three horses and carriages were involved, one of the vehicles being reduced to kindling wood, occurred on the new boulevard, near Virginia Avenue, shortly before 6 o'clock this evening. Fortunately, no one was seriously hurt, though the occupants of two of the carriages were thrown out.
NEWARK, Oct. 28 -- Herr Most and his cohorts were ignominiously routed by the Newark police last night and fled like a lot of hunted sheep.
The Committee of Seventy yesterday made public a manifesto, in which it arraigns Tammany Hall for its conduct of the City Government. The arraignment is as follows:

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 28 -- The Congressional delegation in this State is not likely to be changed at the election in November. The political forecast is in favor of the Democrats holding the First, Second, and Fourth Districts, while the Third is conceded to the Republicans. The State Democratic ticket would win without difficulty on a plurality vote, which prevails in the Congressional districts.

Foreign exchange was generally firm, although narrow. The posted rates for sterling were $4.87 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.88 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done on Saturday at $4.86 3/4@$4.87 for sixtyday bills, $4.87 3/4@$4.88 for demand, $4.88 for cable transfers, and $4.86 1/2 for commercial.

The Rev. Dr. W.C. Bitting, pastor of Mount Morris Baptist Church, last evening chose as the subject of his sermon Article I., Section 9, of the constitutional amendments relating to gambling, making special reference to racing.
Seven dollars was said to have been in a pocketbook thirteen-year-old Joseph Toohey was accuesed of stealing from a steerage passenger on the Umbria, that sailed Saturday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 28 -- Within the last forty-eight hours new life has been injected into the Democracy of Rhode Island. Before that time a calm, dispassionate study of the political conditions here would have brought the inevitable conclusion that the star of Wetmore Republicanism was in the ascendant, with not a cloud in the skies in which it was rising.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Senor Lazo Arriaga, the Guatemalan Minister, made to-day the following statement in regard to the present difficulties between his country and Mexico:

During the day Prince Krapotkine went about, disguised as a painter, from workshop to workshop, making friends among the men and winning their confidence. Then, in an evening, he held classes for them, led debates, and grave lectures. The Prince has an innate genius for teaching; St. Petersburg was thronged with men eager to learn; his attic, therefore, was crowded night after night, although every one who went risked imprisonment.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 28 -- The morning service in Shiloh Colored Baptist Church here to-day bore a striking resemblance to a scrimmage in a football game, the pastor, the Rev. E.W. Tapley, filling the rather unenviable position of the ball.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 28 -- There are several especially interesting Congressional contests in progress in this State. Thus far the drift has been in favor of the Republicans, and they are certain to recapture several districts now represented by Democrats, but which are usually Republican. Several of the normal Democratic districts are also debatable, and no less than six of the twenty-one districts may fairly be placed on the doubtful list.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- Judge Gaynor held court here Saturday. Afterward he had a conference with Chairman Hinkley of the Democratic State Committee. He expressed himself as anxious to aid in the suppression and punishment of bribery and corruption wherever he could do so.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The Dally Graphic prints this dispatch under a Yokohama date:

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28 -- The policy of lighter training adopted by Capt. Trenchard is becoming more and more apparent as the football season advances. Neither Holly, Brown, nor Morse have been in the game the last week, and several of the other men have been allowed to lay off a day or two at a time and take a rest.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 38 -- The college library has received from a prominent alumnus, whose name is withheld a fine mediaeval manuscript of Terence. This manuscript consists of 166 leaves partly of parchment and partly of paper. The text is written throughout in one hand, in clear minuscule letters, in black ink. The names of the characters in the play are regularly written in red.
The Rev. Madison C. Peters, in the course of his sermon in the Bloomingdale Church, last evening, said:

A large congregation was present at the Madison Avenue People's Church, Madison Avenue and Fifty-third Street, last evening to hear the Rev. Charles L. Thompson speak on "Good Citizenship, or The Duty of the Hour." He said:
Prof. Felix Adler addressed the Society for Ethical Culture in Music Hall yesterday morning on the immoral issues of the election. He spoke as follows:

Gov. McKinley and other advocates of his tariff policy have been telling the people of the northern part of this State that what they need is the restoration of the McKinley duties on agricultural products. But the Republican vote in the northern counties in 1892 appears to have been overlooked.

Ex-Mayor Grant yesterday signed the letter by which he formally accepts the nomination for Mayor on the Tammany ticket. The letter was then given to the newspapers, with this statement from Mr. Grant:

For the purpose of illustrating more in detail what has been done by Tammany in the way of increasing departmental expenditures, we cannot do better than consider one department which most closely touches the well-being and happiness of our citizens, namely, the Department of Public Works.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- The columns of all newspapers teem with surmises as to the final cause of Count von Caprivi's fail. The most trustworthy explanation now at hand was published yesterday by the Hamburgische Correspondent, which is known to have got its information from Dr. Hanrnann of the Foreign Office.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 28 -- A crime was perpetrated at 5 o'clock this morning by which it was premeditated by the scoundrels to sacrifice fifty or sixty fives by means of dynamite. The motive was undoubtedly robbery, and it resulted in the instant death of three Hungarians, while a large number were injured, eight of whom are in a serious condition.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- Each year the editors of The Campus, the college paper, are selected by competition. This year each candidate is required to submit at least one contribution a month during November, December, January, and February, suitable for publication in a college paper, and, if prose, of less than 600 words in length.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 28 -- The Conssional campaign in Alabama is exciting more interest throughout the State generally this year than for many years past. There are opposing candidates in of the districts, which is unusual, and, with the exception of the Sixth District, the opponents of the Democrats are attempting to concentrate their votes upon one candidate.

There were 353 deaths in Brooklyn in the week ending last Saturday, which, according to Dr. West, the Secretary to Health Commissioner Emery, represents an annual death rate of 17 in every 1,000 of the population. Of this number 170 deaths were in tenements and 42 in public institutions.

While the Central Labor Union was holding a quiet session yesterday afternoon the hall was invaded by twenty-five strapping journeyman brewers, led by the President of their union, Daniel McKernig. They had come, as they called it, to enforce their rights, and were getting themselves in a condition for a first-class fight when some one ran out calling "Police! Murder!" The arrival of half a dozen policemen cooled the ardor of the invaders.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Monmouth County Democrats are born political fighters, but the battle now being waged is much too one-sided to please the tariff reformers, for the enemy is troubled with "that tired feeling" to such an extent that it is making an unusually tame fight.

David Weinig, who was arrested in August on a charge made by Fire Marshal Benjamin Lewis of Brooklyn, who alleged that Weinig had attempted to extort money from Jacob Klein, of 74 Johnson Avenue, on the pretense that he was an Assistant Fire Marshal, now proposes to call to account the officials and others who, he claims, conspired against him.
The greatest variety of ballots in the history of the State will confront the citizen of New-York who enters a polling place to vote Tuesday, Nov. 6.
The registration in this city was discussed at all the local political headquarters yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- President Schurman has been one of the prime movers in the formation of the Association of American Educators, which has for its purpose the securing of lectures from the highest authorities in various fields. The lectures will, for some time to come, at least, be restricted to history and the comparison of religions.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Thomas F. Gallagher of 173 Ocean Avenue was found unconscious at Jackson and Kearny Avenues at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. He was taken to the Communipaw Avenue Police Station, where a physician said he had been beaten with a blunt instrument.

A policeman from the West Thirtieth Street Police Station found a well-dressed, respectable-looking man lying unconscious on a stoop at Madison Avenue and Thirtieth Street at 8:30 Saturday night. He tried to arouse the man, but could not. He then took the man in a cab to the station, where he was locked up on a charge of intoxication.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 28 -- Reports from the Minnesota Congressional districts are conflicting, and it is difficult to predict what the outcome of the election of Nov. 6 will be. Democratic confidence has been growing in the last ten days, and the Chairmen of the Congressional Committees assert that Democratic candidates will be returned in the Third, Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Districts.

Francis Farquhar and Henry K. Keenan of the Reform Club have sent a letter to ex-Secretary Charles S. Fairchild, in which they protest against the circular letter issued by Mr. Fairchild, in which he speaks for the club. Mr. Keenan wrote the, letter. He said:

Truck No. 3 of the Fire Department and a mail wagon driven by Patrick Martell of 429 East Sixteenth Street, were in collision at Broadway and Fourteenth Street at 5:30 yesterday afternoon. The accident will probably result in the death of Martell, who was taken to the New-York Hospital in a dangerous condition.

Considering the dullness and depression in the stock market, the business done and strength shown in railroad bonds have been remarkable. The demand for first-class bonds continues exceptionally good, as well as the demand for bonds netting 5 per cent. Chicago and Eastern Illinois 5s and Rock Island 5s have been extremely active at advancing prices.
The auction sales of real estate set down for to-day at 111 Broadway are as follows:

PITTSBURG, Oct. 28 -- Precious little was uncovered locally during the past week to encourage investment demand, and the market, whether for staples or speculative things, was duller than for an extended period. Money is still in plentiful supply in banks, but was not to be had, save where the best possible collateral was offered.

NEW-HAVEN,. Conn., Ocl. 28 -- The academic Faculty of Yale has made an important announcement regarding admissions. The change is in relation to the passing off of entrance examinations. It is regarded as a change that will aid students who enter college without full preparation, but who do good work after entering college.

The House Committee on Foreign Relations of the Forty-seventh Congress investigated the conduct of several Representatives of the United States Government in foreign countries. One of them was Levi P. Morton, then Minister to France.

Many of the finest woods in existence are yet unknown, or only slightly known, to the manufacturers of wood in the civilized world. The woods of Central and South America are perhaps the most remarkable as well as the best known. In the yet untouched forests of those parts of this continent are many woods far finer than any of those now in use.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28 -- The last of the Mutual Driving Association's matinee trots for the season of 1894 was held at Waverly yesterday. A large crowd was present. Five events were on the card and close finishes were me rule. One of the features of the afternoon was the clever style in which President Chandler sent his bay mare, Jenniss, along to beat 2:28 1/2, which she made two weeks ago.

A pneumatic sporting boat article designed for hunting and fishing purposes has recently been exhibited at the New-York Athletic Club. It is circular in shape, made of rubber, and Just large enough to sit in, and has boot legs projecting below. The vessel is propelled with legs as in walking, there being folding paddles or fins on the boot legs which close or feather with the forward motion and open with the backward stroke.

After a search of over a month, high and low, and everywhere in New-York and Brooklyn, Inspector McLaughlin's men have at last caught the pretty and plaussible young woman who has been swindling so many milliners in the two cities.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 -- The interest in local securities this week was mainly confined to the decision of Judge Ingraham against the Union Railway Company of New-York. It is said by those well posted that the importance of that decision had been greatly exaggerated. There was some selling of Westchester bonds during the week, the transactions being larger than for many months past.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 27 -- The local stock market for the week presents few it any interesting features. Offerings of the more desirable stocks were still exceptionally light, with slight changes in prices. The bank stock list was very quiet; some few shares changed hands, however. City National sold at 66 1/2 and a small lot of Manufacturers' National at 136 1/2.

At the Washington Square building a full meeting of the Executive Committee was held last week. Mr. A. D. Juilliard was welcomed back from a four months trip abroad and resumed the Chairmanship of the Washington Square Building Committee.
ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 28 -- An official bulletin issued from Livadia shortly before noon said:

Of thirty-five Western and Southwestern railroads that have reported their earnings for the third week in October, twenty-two are able to show largely-increased incomes. This is certainly a very encouraging showing when taken in connection with the fact of the almost total collapse of east-bound grain shipments.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Mottet of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, Twentieth Street and Sixth Avenue, preached yesterday morning on "The Duties of Citizens in the Approaching Election." He said:

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 28 -- Although the election is soon to occur and the party managers should begin to have very definite ideas of what the results are to be, yet the Democratic, Populist, and Republican leaders differ very widely as to the probable vote each party will cast at the coming State election.
The Rev. John A.B. Wilson, at the Eighteenth Street Methodist Church, in the prelude to his morning sermon yesterday, said:

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Oct. 28 -- L.D. Hampton, nephew of Gov. Lewelling, shot Edward Egan through the heart last evening in an alley in the rear of Egan's residence, 26 North Second Street. Hampton was shot three times by Dennis Byrnes, Egan's father-in-law.

How to dispose of New-York's garbage has not, apparently, been decided on by Charles G. Wilson, President of the Board of Health; ex-Mayor Franklin Edson, William S. Andrews, Commissioner of Street Cleanig, and Lieutenant Commander Daniel Delehanty, United States Navy.

AUBURN, Oct. 28 -- The four counties -- Cayuga, Ontario, Wayne, and Yates -- that go to make up the Twenty-eighth Congressional District are purely agricultural and strongly Republican. Two years ago this district gave Congressman Sereno E. Payne a plurality of 8,123 and Gen. Harrison 5,581.
These existing features move me more than eloquence:

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $1,351,225. The banks now hold $63,884,900 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $1,079,800, a decrease in specie of $11,300, an increase in legal tenders of $1,259,600, a decrease in deposits of $411,700, and a decrease in circulation of $103,300.

The regular meeting of United Council, 1,035, American Legion of Honor, was held in the council rooms, in the Jasper Building, yesterday afternoon. After the routine business, the members were entertained by an excellent programme of vocal and instrumental music, provided by Orator Daniel W. Quinn.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The members of the Rochester University football team are now under the entire control of E. A. Griffith, as coach. He played four years as right guard on the Cornell team and last year was its coach. He gives it as his opinion that Rochester has a good heavy line, but the members need additional practice.
Our zealous and respected contemporary, The Mail and Express, has discovered an entirely novel test for capacity in public affairs. It says:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Candidates for office in Monmouth County have an easy time of it when they visit Asbury Park and Ocean Grove. Both these thriving Summer-resort towns are run on prohibition principles; consequently the seekers for votes are not obliged to meet their coldwater constituents in barrooms and treat them to the "essence of trouble."

-- Future of the Bijou -- When Canary Lederer take possession of the Bijou Theatre, Dec. 3, the policy which Manager Rosenquest has pursued at that house will be completely changed. Farce comedy has not proved successful at the Bijou this season, and Dockstader's Minstrels, who were booked for two weeks, found it advisable to bring their season to a close last night, after but one week's occupancy of the theatre.

The newly-erected north addition to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Central Park will be thrown open to the public next Monday. The inaugural ceremonies will be held at 2 P.M. The addition will be formally turned over by the Park Board to President Henry G. Marquand, representing the Board of Trustees.
Brooklyn politicians who are interested in the coming election were kept busy yesterday going over the registration figures and drawing a comparison with previous years.

We had originally intended to ride through Albania to the capital of Montenegro, and had actually telegraphed in advance for horses to meet us at the little Turkish port of Mendua. But as a telegram takes a week to deliver in Albania, we found no animals awaiting our arrival next day, and so had to go on by sea to Cattaro and drive up from there to Cettinje.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- The Democratic State Central Committee, in carrying on the work of Constitutional reform inaugurated by The New-York Times, has issued a pamphlet entitled "Why Does the Republican Party Oppose Constitutional Reform? Some Arguments by Independent Republicans in Favor of It."

The century run to Oakdale, L.I., yesterday, promoted by the South Brooklyn Wheelmen, was one of the most enjoyable affairs of its kind given this season. Perfect Fall weather favored the cyclists, and the percentage of breakdowns was surprisingly small. Two hundred enthusiasts participated, and there might have been as many more in line had the club not decided to limit the entry list.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Newark is witnessing a lively stirring up along political lines in the agitation led by the Christian Citizenship Union, which is composed of all the Christian Endeavor Societies, Epworth Leagues, Baptist Union, and the Iron Cross Army. No less than fifty pastors are actively promulgating the principles of the union in their respective churches and preaching sermons on topics suggested by the union's declaration of principles and its work.

Harry Smith of 156 India Street and John Sullivan of 149 Huron Street, Brooklyn, each seventeen years old, were arrested at 3 A.M. yesterday by a policeman, who found them in a grocery store at 444 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, trying to open the safe. They had broken the combination lock.

Tammany Hall will find no comfort either in the enormous total of the registration, or in the study of the grains and losses by districts. The up-town districts, where Tammany's hold is feeblest, show the heaviest increase -- an increase not to be altogether accounted for by the growth of population.

In these sketches, originally published in The Century Magazine, we may learn as much of the beauty, grandeur, and wildness of the California mountains as it is possible to get from another person. Mr. Muir not only knows what is in the grand region of the Sierra Nevada Range, but how to write about what he has seen.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

The Democratic Reform Party in Kings County is having considerable trouble in securing copies of the registry lists. Charles J. Patterson, Chairman of the Executive Committee, says that the claim of some of the Democratic Inspectors of Election that they can conceal the registry lists is likely to bring them under the influence of Section 94 of the Penal Code, which reads:

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Arguments were begun to-day in the Court of Appeals in the case of John Y. McKane, who is serving a term of six years in Sing Sing Prison for having induced the Election Inspectors in the First District of Gravesend to violate, in November last, the provisions of the election law which required them to keep the registry lists accessible to the public.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Gov. Flower made a triumphal speechmaking tour from Albany to Syracuse this afternoon. In all he spoke ten times. He was in the best of spirits, the weather was delightful, and the crowds were enthusiastic all along the line. The Governor had something appropriate to every locality to say, and the people appreciated the homely interest he manifested in their affairs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The President to-day appointed Gen. W.F. Duffield a member of the Lighthouse Board in place of Prof. T.C. Mendenhall. Gen. Duffield some time ago succeeded Prof. Mendenhall as Superintendent of the Coast and Geodetic Survey on the latter's resignation, but it was understood at that time that Prof. Mendenhall would continue his connection with the Lighthouse Board.

There was a lively session of the Park Board yesterday, and for a time it looked as if there would be a quarrel. The cause of the disturbance was a resolution offered by Commissioner Tappen to the effect that Frederick L. Olmsted be appointed landscape artist of the Harlem River Speedway.
There was a great deal of comment yesterday in Brooklyn over the article in The New-York Times of Sunday in relation to the shortage in County Treasurer Henry H. Adams's office.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 20 -- Richard de Logerot, the Marquis de Croisic, who has been indicted for perjury by a New-York Grand Jury, is to be extradited. Gov. Brown to-day, upon advice of Attorney General Dubois, who reviewed all the papers in the hands of Detective Reilly of New-York, granted the requisition of Gov. Flower.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- An amazing condition of affairs exists in this county, which forms the Thirty-first Congressional District Charges are openly and publicly made, and have been for days, that the Republican nomination for Congress was simply put up to be knocked down to the highest bidder, in true old-fashioned Republican style, and that the unselected candidates who aspired to the position were subsidized to withdraw from the field.

Prof. T.W. Rhys Davids, Ph.D., LL. D., of London, Secretary of the Asiatic Society and one of the most distinguished scholars of the times, is in this city, the guest of George Haven Putnam, the publisher.

It is not at all clear why anybody should have taken the trouble to invent and promulgate a baseless story to the effect that Gov. Altgeld had pardoned a notorious and habitual criminal, who had not even the claim upon the Executive clemency of Illinois that he called himself an Anarchist.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- John Eno, formerly President of the Second National Bank of New-York City, must answer in the State courts to the indictments found against him for alleged crimes committed while acting as such President before he can invoke the jurisdiction of the Federal courts in his behalf.

George S. Morison, the civil engineer, has written two letters to Albert Stickney explaining his views on the public utility and the practical value as an investment of the proposed viaduct railway of the NewYork Railway Company, on the east and west sides of the city.

The Park Commissioners may be congratulated upon having reached the best possible escape from the curious scrape into which they had got themselves by insisting that a landscape architect was a man who "beautified" the work of contractors, after it was done, by planting shrubs and flowers.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 29 -- In the new whisky combine, the Great White Spirit Company, which filed papers of incorporation in New-Jersey recently, the Whisky Trust has a most formidable foe to fight. While not officially announced, it is learned from reliable authority that the main plant of the concern will be located in East Cambridge, occupying the old plant of the Bay State Distilling Company.

The Democrats of New-Jersey paid the penalty last year for the folly of those who misrepresented them in the racetrack legislation, and there is no likelihood of the repetition of such an offense. The obnoxious laws were set aside by the courts and repealed by the Legislature, with Democratic support.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor. The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan yesterday, before the Lexow committee, tried, in a way, to shift the responsibility for the corruption and demoralization of the Police Department upon the shoulders of Superintendent Byrnes.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 29 -- The big strike of weavers, which was commenced with a four weeks' vacation ten weeks ago, was declared off this morning and the strikers will return to work to-morrow morning. They were defeated by the manufacturers, and they will resume their places under a reduced scale of wages.

Dr. Eugene Crowell, who was at one time the leader of the Know-Nothing Party in California, died early yesterday morning, in his apartments in the Hoffman Arms, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue. Dr. Crowell was seventy-eight years old. He leaves two sons, Frank and Charles E., and a daughter, Mrs. John Halliday of Nyack, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- It is now known definitely that Secretary Carlisle will not make any political speeches this Fall in New-York or elsewhere. Mr. Carlisle this afternoon dictated a message to Major James W. Hinkley, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee of New-York, saying to him that the condition of public business in the Treasury Department would prevent him from taking any part in the campaign.

The business district west of Broadway seems to continue in favor for investment purposes. Two transactions in the neighborhood were made yesterday. The first of these was by brokers M. L. Hess, who sold for Henry Rothschild the southeast corner of Mercer and West Third Streets, 25 by 100, with new six-story, basement, and sub-basement brick business building, at $140,000.

Proctor's Theatre. -- Mazeppa, the talking horse, astonished and delighted large audiences at Proctor's yesterday. The exhibition of almost human intelligence is well worth going to see. One has only to tell the year of his birth and Mazeppa, with his hoof, will quickly strike on the floor the number of years to which one pleads guilty.
William H. Willis was appointed receiver yesterday of the Commercial Alliance Insurance Company by Justice Barrett of the Supreme Court, on the application of Deputy Attorney General Hasbrouck.

It was a large and decidedly well-disposed audience that filled the Herald Square Theatre last night before the curtain rose. When an audience is in the seats early it is an indication of pleasant expectations. There was an air of hopefulness in the house, but there was more than one reason for this.

-- The first "open meeting" of the Monte Relief Society, a mention of whose charitable aims and work was made in The Times a week ago, took place last night at the Terrace Garden. The programme offered and the entire success of the entertainment well evidenced the enthusiasm which the society has aroused in Hebrew circles for the relief of its poor. The garden was crowded and the receipts were encouraging.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 29 -- There is going to be about as lively and pretty a political fight in Union County from this on as one would care to see. The Republicans are very much broken up over the situation, and the leaders begin this, the week for the most effective work, with ranks considerably broken and the chances of success not of the brightest.
The Real Estate Exchange Honest Government Club had an anti-Tammany mass meeting yesterday afternoon at the Exchange on Liberty Street that must have caused the Tiger a great deal of pain.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Daniel Kash of New-York, Capt. Schmittberger's ex-ward man, is in Chicago, with his newly-wedded wife, and is stopping at the Southern Hotel under the name of Daniel Kingsley. Why he is traveling under an alias is not known here.

It is a hard task for the habitual theatregoer of large experience to sit through the English version of "La Dame aux Camelias," called "Camille" in these days. Not only is this remarkably ingenious and powerful play full of the most vicious sentiment, plausibly expressed, but the English translation, or adaptation, seems to so so cheapen the sentiment that much of it becomes, with iteration, unbearable.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Senator David B. Hill was greeted royally here to-night. He addressed an immense audience in Harmanus Bleecker Hall, which was crowded to the doors with over 5,000 persons an hour before the meeting was called to order.
Ex-Mayor William R. Grace addressed an enthusiastic meeting of the New-York State Democracy of the Eighteenth Assmbly District last night in Adelphl Hall, Fifty-second Street and Broadway.
ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 29 -- The official bulletin sent from Livadia at 8 o'clock this evening said:

WHITEPORT, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The pretty new Church of St. Patrick here was dedicated with imposing ceremonies by Archbishop Corrigan yesterday. The Archbishop and other church dignitaries, with a large crowd from Rondout, came on a special train. From the station there was a triumphal procession to the church, headed by a brass band.

NEW-DORP, S.I., Oct. 29 -- Thomas S. Burke, who killed his son-in-law, Frederick Bergmann, Aug. 16, by means of a gun set as a trap in his hut at South Beach, pleaded guilty to-day of manslaughter in the second degree. He was sentenced to ten years in Sing Sing Prison, which term may be commuted to six years and six months for good behavior.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The Central News correspondent in Shanghai says it is rumored in Tien-Tsin that the young Empress is dead, but the fact will not be announced nor mourning be worn by the Court until after the birthday of the Dowager Empress.

During the debate in Congress on the Wilson bill, when it was proposed that agricultural machine implements should be put on the free list, leading Republican journals made a great outcry, saying that the removal of the duties would cause the importation of agricultural machinery from Canada, "flood" the American market with the products of Canadian factories, and bring the domestic manufacturers to ruin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Interior Department was again opened to the public to-day, after a two days' quarantine on account of the Infection of smallpox therein. Every possible precaution has been taken to prevent the spread of the disease, and each room in the department has been thoroughly fumigated.

The Police Board has been ordered to show cause in the Supreme Court this morning why it should not print official ballots for the Empire State Democracy with the full Democratic State ticket at the head.

What was probably one of the largest meetings of the City Vigilance League during the campaign was held last night in the Harlem Presbyterian Church, at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Business was decidedly slow, a waiting market, without the slightest pressure on the part of holders to force sales at the expense of prices. It was the last day of second-account trading, and the inference was that traders were well evened. The market was absolutely devoid of features, unless a fairly sood inquiry for Canal and Dock at 57 is worthy of special mention.
The Board of Engineers which conducted the horse-power trial of the armored cruiser Maine has finished computing the data taken on the trial and made its report to the Navy Department.

The anti-Tammany women workers held a meeting at 333 West Twenty-third Street yesterday afternoon, at which there were speeches by Andrew J. Campbell. Republican candidate for Congress from the Tenth Congressional District; E. Holbrook Cushman and William Halpin, Republican and Good Government Club candidates for Alderman and Assemblyman, respectively, for the Thirteenth Assembly District, and Mrs. Jane Pearce Miss Helen Varick Boswell presided.
The Chamber of Commerce has issued the following address to voters on the question of municipal construction of rapid transit:

PHILADELPHIA. Oct. 29 -- A favorable report having been rendered by Special Master Crawford, upon the application of the receivers of the Reading Railroad, to pay the commissions provided for in the latest plan of reorganization, the report was confirmed by Judge Dallas, in the United States Circuit Court to-day.

The corrected registration for 1894 is given below, with comparative tables, so that it can be seen how this year compares with 1893 and 1892, and just where, in each instance, there was a falling off or an increase in the Assembly districts:

A stylishly-attired, intelligent-looking young woman, about twenty-seven years old, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon, charged with operating in green goods and using the mails for that purpose.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The South Carolina dispensary law, where it comes into conflict with the United States, is inoperative, according to a decision rendered by Attorney General Olney. The opinion is given in answer to a request by the Secretary of the Treasury.

Richard Mansfield, having finished a long and profitable engagement down town, has removed with his company and all his rich theatrical belongings to the Harlem Opera House, where he will remain a week before proceeding on his travels. Last night the familiar "Beau Brummell" was the play, and the bill will be changed frequently.

The decline in the high price of coal stocks yesterday was even more marked than on Friday and Saturday of last week, Jersey Central lost 73-8 Delaware and Hudson 41-2, and Lackawanna 1 1/2 points. The greatest weakness was in Jersey Central, and it was based apparently on the statement of the company for September, and for the nine months of the year, which was given out during the day.

The managers of the Democratic State campaign were all hard at work at the Democratic Headquarters in the Park Avenue Hotel yesterday. It was evident from the tray in which they talked that the information which they have received as to the progress of the campaign was of a most encouraging character.

If the people of the City of New-York had one-half of the civic pride that is known to pertain to the smaller cities throughout this country, the question as to whether there shall be a "Greater New-York," by annexing its surrounding cities and towns, would be unnecessary.

FLINT., Mich., Oct. 30 -- Chauncey W. Church started an altruist community nine months ago, on about 400 acres of land south of here. The colony began with about forty souls, and worked entirely on the co-operative plan, their main dependence for support being a creamery, basket factory, live-stock raising, and farming.

"With a little courage the Democrats will win this fight by a decisive plurality. The contest is ours now at any rate. Let Democrats everywhere stiffen up their political knees, and the result will be an emphatic indorsement of Democratic principles.

Before Frederick A. Ware, who is the Republican candidate for Alderman in the Eleventh Assembly District, was nominated by his organization, he wrote a letter to Preble Tucker, First Vice President of Good Government Club D, which is a potent factor in the district, asking that the club indorse him.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- At a meeting of the shareholders of the Grand Trunk Railway this afternoon Sir Henry Tyler, President of the company, moved to adopt the report and accounts. Mr. Searle, a shareholder, moved an amendment that the report and accounts be received, but that their adoption be postponed until the result of the investigation of the accounts to be made in Canada by an expert shall be announced.

-- The 499 steerage passengers by the steamer Kronprinz Friedrich Wilhelm, from Naples and Palermo, who have been detained since Oct. 16 at Hoffman Island for vaccination and observation, a case of smallpox having developed among them while aboard the steamer, were released yesterday and landed at Hoboken.

The wealth and culture of New-York City is typified in the hotels that have been erected here within the past few years. In this city the word hotel is synonymous with home, for probably in no city in the world does so large a proportion of the wealth and fashion find its home in a place of public resort.
The Garbage Commission held an informal meeting yesterday in Lieut. Delehanty's room in the Army Building.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 30 -- The fifth annual field trials of the National Beagle Club of America were started to-day on the Barnum property, about three and a half miles from this village. While most of the work of the dogs was confined to swamp land thickly covered with underbrush, the day's results were considered very satisfactory.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The Westchester County Historical Society held its annual meeting in the Court House this morning, and there was a large attendance. President Wood presided. The society decided to co-operate with the people of New-Rochelle in erecting a monument to mark the landing place of the Huguenots there, over 200 years ago.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 30 -- Miguel Torruco is the owner of a large timber tract called Egypto, near the Guatemalan frontier. Recently the authroities of Peten, Guatemala, arrested and took away six Mexican subjects who were employed by Turruco.
The speakers at the Republican mass meeting in Carnegie Hall to-night will be ex-President Harrison, Gen. Horace Porter, and John Proctor Clarke.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 30 -- The Crescent Wheelmen held their first century run to-day, the wheelmen leaving the clubhouse on East Second Street at 5:15 A.M., fifteen minutes behind schedule time. The schedule prepared by Capt. Haines was as follows: Leave plainfield, 5 P.M.; Somerville, 6:25; Belle Meade, 7:25; Hopewell, 9; Pennington, 9:30; Trenton, 11; Princeton, 12; New-Brunswick, 2:30; Metuchen, 3:10; Rahway, 4:15; Elizabeth, 4:45; Springfield, 5:45; Plainfield, 6:45.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- Brig. Gen. Robert Shaw Oliver, commanding the Third Brigade of the National Guard, to-day ordered Lieut. Col. William E. Fitch of the Tenth Battalion to make a complete investigation as to the circumstances surrounding the trouble at the Battalion Armory last night at the time of the Hill ratification meeting.

There is wrath in the camp and among the camp followers of McLaughlin and Bell in Brooklyn. It has been reported that a "deal" has been effected between McLaughlin and Bell, parties of the first part, and "Jakey" Worth and Sheriff Buttling, parties of the second wart, in the interest of Senator Hill and Granville W. Harman, mutually and jointly.

RED BANK, N.J., Oct. 30 -- As election day approaches the prospect of Democratic success in Monmouth County grows brighter. There was an inclination among some of the Democrats early in the campaign either to forsake the Assembly nominees altogether or to cast aside one or two of the three candidates.

The persons of the Empire State most deeply interested in the defeat of the anti-pool amendment are very active at the present time. Looking at the issue from their standpoint, and they quote figures to substantiate their arguments, the passage of the amendment will cause a damage to the breeding, trotting, and racing interests of not less than $200,000,000.

The tendency of the time seems to be toward consolidation in municipal affairs. The royal commission recently appointed to consider municipal government in London has reported in favor of a union of the thirteen separate Governments under the head of the Lord Mayor and a City Council, so far as the administration of the general interests are concerned.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Oct. 30 -- Blumenthal Brothers, cloak manufacturers of New-York, leased an old factory building in this village, and about a week ago opened a cloak factory. Twenty non-union cloakmakers were put at work, the firm feeling confident that the men would be safe from interference from the strikers in New-York.
P.D. Armour contributed yesterday to the news of reviving business in a telegram from Chicago, in which he said:

William M. Ivins presented the closing argument for the defense yesterday before the Board of Inquiry in the Elmira Reformatory investigation. Mr. Ivins spoke over six hours, and there was not a moment during all this time that he did not hold the closest attention of every person in the room.
"Now you can go home and get your husbands to try that, but don't try it yourselves."

Justice George C. Barrett decided, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, that it is clearly the duty of a policeman to enter a saloon at any time when he has reason to believe that the law is being violated.
It is a sad spectacle to the non-advertising oftician to see his rival's store crowded.

"Very little short of treasoh to the people," said Carl Schurz, yesterday, speaking of the possibility that voters who believe in honest government might be turned away from the movement against Tammany Hall.
Seven lives were lost early yesterday morning in a tenement-house fire at 216 West Thirty-second Street.

-- Frank Albert, the long-distance professional bicycle rider, will make an attempt to lower the New-York to Chicago road record, now held by H. H. Wylie. On Monday Albert rode from Fiftyninth Street to Yonkers against a heavy wind in 55 minutes. Returning, he rode the distance, being paced by Harry May of the Lafayette Wheelmen, in 48 minutes.
Of course the Twentieth Congressional District will not elect Southwick and leave Gen. Charles Tracey at home. It is preposterous, unthinkable.

A large meeting of the City Vigilance League was held last evening at the German Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, Second Avenue and Ninth Street. The principal speaker was Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst. He said:

MONTREAL, Oct. 30 -- Honore Mercier, ex-Premier of Quebec, died this morning at about 8:45 o'clock. The end had been expected any time during the preceding twenty-four hours, and hope of recovery had been given up weeks ago, almost from tha time he first felt seriously ill, on Aug. 14. He had been suffering from a complication of diseases for years past, diabetes predominating.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 30 -- Senator Hill spoke here to-night to an audience larger than ever before assembled in the Opera House. The Opera House was crowded to the doors an hour before the meeting was called to order.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The Westminster Gazette has a dispatch from Yokohama, which says that the second Japanese army has landed at Talien-Wan Bay, and is now marching upon Port Arthur. The total number of Chinese troops at Port Arthur and Kin-Chow is 13,000, of which 4,000 are raw recruits.

A complimentary dinner was given at the Oxford Club, Brooklyn, last evening to Gen. O.O. Howard, who is to retire from the United States Army Nov. 8, and to Col. Loomis L. Langdon, who retired Oct. 27.

Mr. William J. Tate has sold, for Thomas Adams, Jr., the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn, 25 by 112, to Mrs. C.K. Greenman, who will erect on the lot a brick, stone, and terra-cotta dwelling, to cost $40,000.

The Woman's Municipal League held a meeting in the rooms of Good Government Club Q, 215 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon, and warmly discussed Tammany Hall and misrule, and how women can successfully combat them.

MONTREAL, Oct. 30 -- In the Superior Court this morning, Judge Doherty dismissed, with costs, the action of the proprietors of The Canada Revue (newspaper) against Archbishop Fabre. The case arose out of criticisms by The Canada Revue upon alleged irregularities among clergymen of this diocese.

The newspaper which denounced the management of the most successful and beneficent reformatory in the world upon the strength of statements made by the vilest of mankind seems to have performed a considerable public service. Wherever men are intrusted with arbitrary power there is danger that that power may be abused.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- There are to be two trials by court-martial at Norfolk this week, as a result of an investigation into a naval pay officer's accounts. As stated in these dispatches at the time, an Inspector recently reported to the Navy Department that Paymaster Cann was $1,900 short in his accounts, and the blame was placed on the officer's clerk, a young man named Sayre.
There was a pretty wedding at Delmonico's last night, when Miss Ida Foster was married to Dr. Meyer Katzenberg. The Rev. Mr. Kohler and the Rev. Mr. Grossman officiated.

If the girls could vote in the Fourteenth Congressional District Congressman Lemue Ely Quigg and William Leary, who is managing his campaign, would rest much easier than they do at present. The campaign which they have been making, has boon turned along sentimental lines to an extent that few who know Mr. Leary would suppose possible.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The contract for dredging and improving the Harlem River, New-York, will be awarded to Rittenhouse R. Moore of Mobile, Ala., by the War Department. When proposals for doing the work were opened, the bid of Mr. Moore was found to be considerably lower than those of his competitors, the next lowest being that of a New-York firm.

-- The receivers of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad Company have been authorized by an order filed in the United State court in St. Louis to advance money toward the payment of $428,133, the amount due the Southern Pacific for the use fo its Mojave division by the Atlantic and Pacific, the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe, and the St. Louis and San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Gen. T.L. Casey, Chief of Army Engineers, in his annual report to Congress, asks for $1,500,000 for coast defense, and a much larger sum for river and harbor work in all sections of the country. The coast defense has so far cost $3,021,000, which is a small fraction of the amount estimated, and permits the defense of only a few of the ports indicated in the original plan.

The George J. Kraus Legion of the Eleventh Assembly District turned out 700 strong yesterday, and, after marching through the district, serenaded ex-Mayor Grant at his headquarters in the Union Square Hotel.

It is reported from the City Hospital that the number of cases of diphtheria and scarlet fever that are being received at that institution is exceptionally large. The officials state that those two diseases are at the present time epidemic in certain sections of the city. Recently frequent cases have been reported from Charlestown, Neponset, Dorchester, and Brighton.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The fight of last year in this county wages again. It is not so fierce on the surface, but is just as bitter underneath.

Sheehan probably regrets now that he went so far as to declare that Mr. Taber "lied" when, as foreman of the Grand Jury, he made a statement that the evidence indicated that the total of the blackmail extracted from the people of this city by the police amounted to between seven and ten millions a year.

The plans drawn by Charles F. McKim for the proposed new buildings to be erected for Columbia College, on the site of the old Bloomingdale Asylum, were on exhibition yesterday at 54 East Forty-ninth Street. They were shown to visitors by E. A. Darling, the Superintendent of Buildings and Grounds of the college, who took great pains to explain at length every detail of design.
THE NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, published this morning, consists of TWELVE PAGES. It contains:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- The local market opened with a decline in Lehigh Valley from 34 1/2 to 33 7/8, but the selling seemed to be short stock. After the pressure was removed the price jumped, without a sale, to 34 3/4, and was steady the balance of the session, closing at 1/8 advance. Lehigh Navigation, in sympathy, sold at 51, and Pennsylvania was fractionally lower.

William L. Strong spoke on the east side last night -- in fact, he spoke all over it, beginning on Seventh Street, branching off in a southerly direction toward the East River, and winding up amid a blaze of glory on the Bowery.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- North Chicago Street Railway was the only stock on the local board that was weak. The depression in it was manifestly due to the realizing by a few tailers, who bought directly the deal with the North Shore Line was consummated. Opening at 263 3/4, it declined a point, closing firm there.

The most noteworthy of the sales of real estate announced yesterday was that of the St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church and rectory property, on the north side of West Eighteenth Street, adjoining Chickering Hall, 100 by 92 feet. Messrs. Frederick Southack Co. were the brokers. The price paid was $192,000.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 30 -- An intoxicated man, who gave his name as M.D. Howard, and who said he lived at 17 Hopkins Avenue, amused himself by giving out one-dollar notes in Montgomery Street to-day. Very few persons accepted them, although Howard said that they were samples of a new brand of green goods he intended to put on the market soon.
To the lips of Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan the word "liar" comes readily and without reflection, but once there it sticks with a dogged pertinacity.

All the Democratic candidates for Congress in this city are making a hard fight to keep up the Democratic pluralities in their districts. It is significant that the Tammany managers are doubtful of only two districts, the Fourteenth and Fifteenth, and it is still more significant that they regard the Fifteenth, in which Senator Jacob A. Cantor is the candidate, as the more doubtful of the two.

-- Charles Frohman's Attractions. -- Charles Frohman's companies will occupy live of the city theatres next week. In addition to John Drew at the Empire, "Shenandoah" at the Academy, and "The New Boy" at the Standard," "The Girl I Left Behind Me" will be at the Grand Opera House, and "Charley's Aunt" at the Harlem Opera House, with the original cust, including Etienne Girardot as the amusing old lady from Brazil.

Edwin Wallace, seventy-one years old, the surviving partner of E.G. E. Wallace, shoe manufacturers of Rochester, N. Y., died yesterday. He was born in Berwick, Me., was graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, and taught school in his younger days. Long before the civil war the firm commenced in a small way by tanning hides, afterward manufacturing shoes.

It is a good thing for the champions of municipal reform to carry their contest into the densely-peopled district known as the "east side." It is often assumed that Tammany "owns" the vote of that swarming population, which is largely made up of the poorer part of the "foreign element."

The Democratic Reform Party in Kings County is working enthusiastically for its county ticket, which is headed by Henry Hentz for Register. Half a dozen meetings are held in all sections of Brooklyn every night, and they are largely attended toy men who believe in good government.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- John S. Johnson made an attempt for the world's record for an unpaced mile before leaving Buffalo for Chillicothe to-day, and he succeeded in covering the distance in 1:57 4-5, or nine and two-fifths seconds faster than the record made at Springfield this year by Walter S. Sanger.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Reports received from all parts of old Bergen County bring to the managers of the Democratic campaign assurances that the county will this year again assume its rightful place in the Democratic column and that Bergen will be represented at Trenton by two Democrats instead of by a Democrat and a Republican, as last year, the latter an "accidental" Assemblyman, who was sent to Trenton solely on the race-track issue.
Chairman Charles W. Hackett of the Republican State Committee is between a "barrel" and the deep sea.

Arrangements have been perfected for a mass meeting of the Republicans and the anti-Tammany Democracy to-morrow evening, at the Murray Hill Lyceum, Thirty-fourth Street and Third Avenue. Messrs. Strong, Goff, Tamsen, and several other anti-Tammany candidates have promised to be present, and to address the meeting.

Virtuosity, as it is called, was on exhibition in Music Hall last night. Now, virtuosity is a bad thing in its way; because its way usually is to look upon itself as a means and not an end. Its substantial value in the world of art is measured by the degree to which it humbles itself before interpretation.

Decision was rendered by the General Appraisers yesterday in a case which will stand, unless reversed on appeal, against all claims for the imposition of the former duty of 90 cents a gallon on whisky, no matter when it may have been placed in bond.
The twentieth anniversary of the United Hebrew Charities were celebrated Monday night in the Berkeley Lyceum.
Frederick Law Olmsted will receive by mail, at his home at Brookline, Mass, the following resolution offered by Commissioner A.B. Tappention Monday, at the Park Board meeting, and adopted:

As a result of an investigation made by Superintendent Byrnes of the lists of persons who registered last Friday and Saturday, Capts.
