The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $7,508,245, of which amount $1,562,458 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $57,918, and the exports of specie were $570,386.

GLASGOW, Nov. 10. -- The body of James Kirkwood, the Troy (N.Y.) coal dealer, was found in the canal here last Tuesday morning. Upon the body was the sum of $9 and a visiting card, by which the deceased was identified.
The following plans of new buildings and alterations have been filed with the Building Department:

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- At yesterday's Cabinet Council the Ministry definitely decided to put the resolution for the abolition of the veto power of the House of Lords in the first place on the programme of legislation to be considered at the coming session of Parliament. Following this measure will come in order the Electoral Registration bill; the bill for the disestablishment of the Church of Wales, and Mr. Morley's Irish Land bill.

In our own day it really seems as if we couldn't possibly get on without india rubber and gutta percha. Though both are of comparatively recent introduction, the number of purposes to which they are applied is so immense that our civilization without them would at least be very different from the form in which we actually know it.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Nov. 10.--Patrolman Pharo of Life-Saving Station No. 20 saw a vessel heading dead on the beach at 5 A.M. He gave a danger signal, which was either not seen or not heeded, and in twenty minutes the vessel struck the outer bar half a mile from shore.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 10 -- Thomas Murphy, a gardener employed by Mrs. J.R. Value of 765 North Broad Street, attempted to kill the cook. May Rush, by shooting, this morning. The cook was preparing a breakfast for the family, when Murphy entered the kitchen. He had a revolver. The cook ran into the laundry, followed by Murphy.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 10. -- Early in September, 1863, twenty-three United States men-of-war and transports, with a force of 10,000 men under command of Major Gen. Franklin, appeared off Sabine Pass, Texas. The pass was defended by a small earthwork manned by forty-two men of an Irish company in the Confederate Army, called the Jeff Davis Guards, commanded by Lieut. R.W. Dowling.

If the "three-decker" in novels is of the past, Mr. Ford launches a "five-decker." He is not apologetic as to his prodigality, for he writes "that the American people have anglicized themselves as thoroughly into liking the three-volume stories as they have to other things." We can hardly say "yea" to this, for public taste in America inclines toward the short novel.

On a street-car platform the other day was a little newsboy kicking his toeless shoes once in a while to get warm and putting his hands quite through the pockets of his ragged jacket in his efforts to keep them away from the raw air. He looked jolly and happy, though, and whistled as he jumped about.

The recent competitive examination of enlisted men at Fort Leavenworth for commissions in the line of the army has resulted in securing an unusually large number of Second Lieutenants from this source. No fewer than twelve of the seventeen candidates who had previously passed their preliminary examinations before the respective department boards were successful in this final test.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Ninety-eight Republicans in the present Congress have been re-elected, but it so happens that fifty-two of them are now serving their first terms.
The following is a complete list of the realty to be offered at auction during the present week, the sales to be had at 111 Broadway, except as otherwise stated:
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.

A circular has been issued by the General Reorganization Committee of the Toledo, Ann Arbor and North Michigan Railroad calling the attention of the various classes of bondholders in that company to the fact that its modified plan of reorganization has been indorsed by the representatives of the Mount Pleasant, Cadillac, and Lake Michigan Divisions, and also by holders of the Grand Trunk and North Michigan divisional bonds, as well as by the stockholders' committee.

The Winter gales, especially the hurricanes of Jan. 12 and 13 and Feb. 12, resulted in serious disasters and the loss of several first-class fishing vessels, and swelled the list of disasters for the past year considerably above the average of recent years.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The Pall Mall Gazette's dispatch from Che-Foo says that Port Arthur has been captured. The dispatch also says that five Chinese torpedo boats passed Che-Foo at an early hour yesterday morning, steaming in the direction of Wei-Hai-Wei.

James A. Blanchard was appointed yesterday by Judge Bookstaver of the Court of Common Pleas receiver of the David Jones Company, which does business at First Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. The receiver is required to give a bond of $50,000. The appointment is made in proceeding's taken for the voluntary dissolution of the company.

Evidently the gods had never loved Ephraim Melick, for at threescore and ten he might have earned good wages as a shoemaker -- he was such a laster. Might have, had not his avarice had the saving grace to admit that he was able to live without work in a small way," as if he could live in any other way," his indignant relatives would often remark.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- The local market to-day failed to sympathize either in activity or buying with the New-York market, and, except for the local steam roads, closed fractionally lower. The investment buying noted yesterday in Pennsylvania and Lehigh Valley was again apparent to-day, causing the former to advance to 51 7/8 and the latter to 35 7/8.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The November returns to the Department of Agriculture of the rates of yield by the acre make the average of corn 19.7, which is about 1 1/2 above the yield indicated by the condition figures in October. This is the lowest rate of yield that has occurred since 1881, when it stood at 18.6 bushels an acre.

The Committee of Seventy do well to continue their organization and to declare their purpose to aid in securing to the city "honest, efficient, economical, and non-partisan government"; in compassing the removal and punishment of men in office who have been unfaithful and inefficient in the performance of their duties, and in procuring the enactment of such laws as may be found necessary to the better government of the city.

It is a curious fact that a good many interesting things happen in Europe that do not come flying under the sea to us by way of the busy cable. For instance, about three weeks ago died, at Wurzburg, Johanna Wagner, the niece of the famous Richard.

The East River, which is in reality a strait, begins about opposite antique-looking Fort William, on Governors Island, and ends at the lower end of Lons Island Sound at Sands Point. There enters the Harlem River, the home of many rowing clubs: odorous Newtown Creek, and Bushwick Creek.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 10 -- Richard S. Waring this morning entered an equity suit against George Westinghouse, Jr., asking for an accounting of 10,000 shares of Standard Underground Cable stock; worth $1,000,000.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 10. -- This has been the most interesting, day so far passed in the trial of the Paskola case. There was much less testimony than usual, no witnesses, in fact, being called after the noon recess, but the devoting of the afternoon to experiments in court gave variety from the monotony of evidence by chemists and physicians put on the stand as experts.

The interesting question was raised yesterday, whether, under the provisions of the new Constitution of the State, which takes effect Jan. 1, 1893, the term of office of William L. Strong as Mayor of this city is for three years or one. Until this question was raised it was generally believed that Mr. Strong was elected for three years, and that his term ended Dec. 31, 1897.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Secretary Lamont issued the order this afternoon for the army changes consequent upon the retirement of Gen. O.O. Howard. There are but two transfers and one assignment -- Gen. Miles to New-York, Gen. Rugrer to Chicago, and Gen. Forsythe to California.

Many years ago the author of "The Chemistry of Common Life" indicated the groundnut as a probable or actual substitute for cocoa -- or roasted, ground, and prepared in the same way as chocolate. He mentioned that in Spain the earth chestnut was even then being consumed as a substitute for coffee.

"The history of the Russian Czarina," says the Courrier des Etat-Unis," begins like a fairy tale. There were once upon a time three little girls in jaconet dresses who received 15f. a month for their wardrobes, made, their own skirts and corsages, and filled with their youthful gayety the peaceful old city of Frankfort-on-the-Main. They were all pretty.

The Supreme Court of Michigan has handed down a decision affecting the present method of voting. The case hinges on the question of what constitutes a "distinguishing mark," and was brought in the contesting of the rights to office of two local candidates at Bay City, who were ostensibly elected at a Spring election a year and a half ago.

John D. Barry, City Attorney of Ironwood, Mich., and Otto E. Karste of the Ironwood Common Council and manager of the Ironwood Bank, reached here yesterday to consult with the attorneys regarding the $150,000 of city improvement bonds of Ironwood which were intrusted to Coffin Stanton and hypothecated by that firm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Naval Constructor Fernald, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, has presented a plan for the general improvement of the constructor's department in a report which has been made to Chief Constructor Hichborn. The lack of funds will probably prevent for a time the carrying out of the suggestions, but it is probable his system will eventually be adopted.
A large old-fashioned Colonial mansion is one of the most conspicuous features of that new part of Brooklyn which has not as yet lost enough of its identity to be known as anything but Flatbush.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 10. -- Dartmouth defeated Amherst to-day on Pratt Field, 30 to 0. Amherst was entirely out-classed by Dartmouth's superior weight and team work. The condition of the field aided Dartmouth more than Amherst, which accounts for the large score.

When Edward M. Shepard walked into the Athenaeum, Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, Brooklyn, last evening he was greeted with tumultuous applause. The hall was crowded with the members of the General Committee of the Democratic Party in Kings County. The applause lasted fully two minutes and then broke out afresh when Mr. Shepard appeared upon the stage.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 10. -- The advance guard of a large number of negro emigrants left Birmingham yesterday en route to Monrovia, Liberia, via New-York and Liverpool. The negroes go as a committee to make arrangements for the emigration of several thousand of their countrymen, who have paid the necessary money to the International Migration Society and only await perfected plans to leave.
Admirers of Napoleon and the Napoleonic period are having a treat in the exhibition of furniture, relics; and art treasures at 238 Fifth Avenue.

BARRANQUILLA, Oct. 12. -- I have shaken the hand of a man whose father, so far as lapse of time is concerned, might have shaken the hand of one of the Pilgrim Fathers. "But," says the reader, "'twere to consider too curiously to consider so." And I answer, "No, faith; not a jot." Let us see.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Business on the Stock Exchange to-day was fairly active. Diamond Match was strong, selling up to 142, a gain of about 2 points, as compared with yesterday's close. West Chicago showed some improvement at the opening, being in good demand at 137 7/8, with a few sales at 138, but later it eased off to 137 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Two parties are laying claim, through their representatives in this city, to the credit of having overwhelmed the Democrats last Tuesday. The Poulists say, "We did it." The A.P. A., through The United American, says, "The victory was ours." And neither the Populists nor the A.P.A. will assume for a moment that there was any issue more potent than those urged by them, respectively.
Rear Admiral Henry Erben, who was recently placed upon the retired list, was entertained at a dinner at the City Club last night by a number of his friends.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The transit of Mercury, as witnessed to-day by the scientists at the United States Naval Observatory, was made an occasion of some interest through the presence of a number of distinguished persons.

OGUNQUIT, Nov. 10. -- "They ain't many on us left," said Mr. Silas Larrabee this morning, speaking of the recent elections. "Dimmycrats is sca'cer in hen's teeth this year. I've seen "em sca'ce consider'ble many times sence I throwed my fust vote for President, but b'jocks, this year beats the hull on 'em put together for sca'ceness."

Eliza and George Beck have sued the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company for damages to their property at 369 Broadway, in that city. The plaintiffs claim that the rental value of their property had been damaged $250 a year, and that the building had sustained at least $1,000 damage by the vibration of the passing trains.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 10 -- A new form of entertainment was provided for Park Club members last night in the shape of a congress whist smoker. It was arranged by George T. Rogers and Samuel Townsend, the Whist Committee of the club.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10. -- Harvard defeated the Chicago Athletic Association this afternoon, 36 to 0.

In order that the business of the session might be expedited, the members of the General Missionary Committee of the Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday agreed to limit speeches to five minutes. This was made necessary because of the alarming loquacity of the Bishops and Doctors of Divinity who constitute the committee.

Hooded, padded, and booted until it was impossible to tell what the type or color of the animal was, the members of the Equine Four Hundred were led into the Madison Square Garden last evening, until about one-half of the 400 stalls provided for the animals that are nominally the attraction at the horse show the coming week were filled.

In their last game of football for this season, the Boston Athletic Association eleven defeated the beefy Crescents by 22 to 0, at Eastern Park, yesterday afternoon. The weather was all that could be desired, the cool, light winds from Jamaica Bay invigorating both the players and the spectators.

Among the notable attractions of the first of the series of six concerts to be given by the Seldl Society of Brooklyn in the Brooklyn Academy of Music next Tuesday evening will be the appearance of Mr. Cesar Thomson, the distinguished Belgian violinist. Mr. Thomson is a great artist, and his first performance as a soloist with Anton Seidl's grand orchestra in Brooklyn will doubtless be one of the drawing features of the event.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 10 -- A large reception was given at the home of Mrs. Robert Ward, in South Orange, this afternoon in the interest of the McAll Mission of France.

The New-York Athletic Club gave its thirty-fifth Ladies' Day yesterday, and it was one of the most enjoyable. C.L. Burnham and G.D. Philips, the Entertainment Committee for the occasion, quite distinguished themselves, both as to the programme and the way it was carried out. The big building was crowded from the gymnasium balcony to the ground floor.

Balzac's method in writing the historical novel was most precise. In the introduction to the novel now under notice his method can be followed. It is the philosophy of history, colored, perhaps, by that period of unrest which influenced the writer. France, when this work was composed, had just gone through internal strife, and was on the eve of beginning it over again, and Honors de Balzac was immensely conservative.

A telegram was received at the War Department, in Washington, yesterday, announcing the death of Capt. J.P. Schindel of the Sixth Infantry, from heart disease, at Fort Thomas, Ky. Capt. Schindel was appointed to the regular army from the volunteer service as Second Lieutenant of the Sixth Infantry from Pennsylvania, his native State, in October, 1861.
Modesto Falizano, Consul for Ecuador, who lives at 8 West Twenty-eighth Street, called at Police Headquarters last night and reported that he had been robbed.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10. -- A herald, with trumpeters, in picturesque costumes, proclaimed to the city this morning that the funeral services at the Cathedral of the Archangel would begin at 10 o'clock to-morrow.

Sydney Grundy's "The New Woman," originally produced at the Comedy Theatre, London, Sept. 1 last, will have its first presentation in America at Palmer's Theatre to-morrow night. At the opening of the play Gerald Casenove is engaged, with Mis Sylvester, in writing a work on "The Ethics of Marriage."

Through Col. Juan Cienfuegos, the Salvadorian exile, Gen. Antonio Ezeta purchased yesterday of Capt. E.N. Jennings, the broadsword fighter and trainer, a handsome six-year-old chestnut sorrel horse known as Dictator, Jr. It is the horse that attracted much attention in the society circus given here some time ago.

Timothy Dwyer, a real estate dealer, fifty-nine years old, who lives with his wife and family at 1,181 Third Avenue, was shot in the abdomen about 6 o'clock last night, on the northwest corner of First Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, by James McLaughlin, a stonecutter, forty years old.

SCRANTON, Penn., Nov. 10.--Beginning next Monday the South Mills of the Lackawanna Iron and Steel Company will begin work in every department. The coal mines of the company will also go on better time, and with the old and new rolling mills, converting works, and furnaces of the North Mills now running, fully 5,000 men will have steady employment for an indefinite period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- People who know what a privilege it is to vote and take part in the excitement attending political campaigns might be pardoned for assuming that a disfranchised people like that of the District of Columbia would take little interest in such matters, by reason of the conditions surrounding them.

That there has been some feeling among the members of the German-American Reform Union has been well known for some time. That Gustav H. Schwab and some of his friends would resign from the organization was Indicated in The New-York Times early in the campaign. They disagreed with Oswald Ottendorfer over some of the questions that came up in reference to the campaign.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The most interesting event of the recent reunion of the survivors of the Sixth New-York Volunteer Artillery in this city was the presence there of Brevet Major Gen. William Hopkins Morris, who, as its first Colonel, took this famous fighting regiment into the field in September, 1862.

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- Cabinet politics is as confused as ever. The public uneasiness over the reorganization of the Ministry increases with every day's delay. From one hour to the next, rumors as to more resignations and new appointments change and multiply. This afternoon the alarmists report that the Emperor is not able to obtain the assent of several Ministers to remain in the Cabinet with Prince Hohenlohe and Freiherr von Koeller.

A week broken into by a public holiday is rarely a good one for real estate transactions. When the holiday happens to be for an election, and for so exciting a one as that of last Tuesday, the chances are that business will suffer. Brokers and customers have both been talking more politics than real estate during the past weeK, and the former are rather glad that it is all over.

The Consolidation League of Brooklyn has been able to get returns on the Greater New-York vote from 679 out of 682 election districts. The Police Department of the City of Brooklyn has had reports from the officials of only 670 districts.

Molsey was Miss Martha's protegee. Her small, dark face always shone with good humor and eager interest in life; her bright, black eyes ever rolling in search of new objects of inquiry. This was especially the case when Miss Martha was teaching her and particularly desired her pupil's undivided attention.

determined on an issue of bonds by the Government had an immediate influence on prices for securities both in this country and in Europe. The London market was considerably above New York's local closing of Friday, when business began here, but the discrepancy between the two markets was not permitted to continue long.
Lucasta -- When you advocate Greek dress, you lose sight of another objection, or rather defect, in it for our retirements. It leaves the neck too bare.

The police are investigating a charge of murder made against George W. Page of 342 East Ninety-third Street by his wife, Margaret. The charge was made to the police Friday night, when Mrs. Page accused her husband of having caused the death of Harry Williams of 224 Chrystle Street by giving him morphine.

We have now had three political tidal waves in six years, two in favor of the Democrats and one, the latest, against them. The full extent of the overturn on Tuesday was not fully known until Thursday mornng. That morning's issue of the daily papers presented in compact array the returns from every State in the Union, and then it was seen how wide sweeping had been the victory.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 10. -- The new Republican Governor of Connecticut, O. Vincent Coffin of Middletown, will have a larger amount of public patronage at his disposal than has fallen to the lot of most of his predecessors in a number of years. The dead-lock in 1891, which kept the Republicans in power in all of the State departments, deprived the Democrats of the offices that legitimately belonged to them.

The stories of national adventure in regions outside Europe fell upon the ever-attentive car of our great Shakespeare, and lent wings to his fancy. What things in heaven and earth aid not Shakespeare touch upon. The intrepid "Portingals" who had sailed with Ferdinand Magelhaens had brought back strange tales of Patagonia and the inhabitants of those stormy latitudes -- their vast size, uncouth appearance, their manners, customs, and an account of their god Setebos.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The cotton returns of the Department of Agriculture for the month of November show improvement of the prospects as Compared with the returns of last month. This is due to better weather, and is especially noticeable in the States of Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, and Texas.

Of recent years probably no matter has received more thoughtful consideration from those who have the best welfare of the race at heart than the amelioration of the condition of those unfortunate persons, born deaf, who form a considerable proportion of our population.

" Squire," said Deacon Wallace, as the two prominent men met on the steps of the Post Office and general store of Hop Meadow village, " didn't I see your man workin' a new yoke of oxen yisterday -- red ones, weth leetle white stars in their faces?"

I crossed on one of the big Atlantic liners lately, with 500 other saloon passengers. They were naturally people of intelligence, and presumably of easy circumstances. Yet at least half of those people were planning to rob our Government of money by contriving plans to avoid paying duties truly owed.

Joseph Herzig -- or Hart, as he prefers to call himself -- was arraigned before Justice Ryan, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday morning, on a charge of forgery. He is twenty-four years old, and has been all over the country, because, as his father charges, of his ability to successfully forge.

Theodore P. Gilman, formerly President of the Port Jervis Brewing Company, now connected with the Bingo Brewing Company, was arrested at his home, 50 West Ninety-third Street, yesterday morning, upon an order signed by Judge Bischoff, in the Court of Common Pleas, nearly a year ago, in a suit brought by Mrs. Caroline Kurzeja of 85 Second Avenue, against Gilman and Richard Rinckwitz, who was Secretary of the Port Jervis Brewing Company, to recover $1,000.

The offerings of the muse of Thomas Bailey Aldrich are always welcome. There is a restful finish about his work that must always charm the cultivated reader and the professional writer alike. All of Mr. Aldrich's poetry is notable for its exquisite refinement. There is never a suspicion of a lack of strength in the bit put into the mouth of his Pegasus.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The Highlands of the Hudson, which stretch in an almost unbroken range from a point opposite Peekskill to Newburg, formed in Revolutionary days a section where the most interesting and important events of that period took place. The numerous forts and other defenses now in ruins bear silent testimony to the indomitable perseverance of the men who risked everything for freedom.

-- Mrs. Barnette Woodard has commenced a suit against the Union Electric Railroad Company for $5,000, for being thrown from one of the cars in Mount Vernon. Another suit has been begun by Samuel Thurton for $200 for damages to his horse and wagon, received in a collision with a car.

Nothing new was put forward at the city theatres in election week excepting "Miss Dynamite," which is good enough of its kind, but hardly worth pondering over. The explosive omelette and the unmanageable cuckoo clock are funny, but they are neither edifying nor dramatic. The German theatre in Irving Place, however, was the scene of some theatrical events of interest which are duly reviewed below.

Two of the three survivors of the schooner Coronet, which was wrecked while making passage to Cuba from Halifax, were yesterday brought to this port by the steamship Creole Prince. Three members of the crew of the Coronet were swept overboard and lost, and a fourth was drowned in the cabin by a wave which ingulfed the craft.

The latest excitement in Paris smart society is the pursuit of cooking as an accomplishment. Cooking soirees are frequent, and it goes without saying that the art attains greater excellence among the French belles than it ever has when countenanced by English or American dames of high degree.

The old Newgate Prison at East Granby, Conn., is famed throughout New-England as one of the two distinctly political prisons this country has ever had, the other being the old Capitol Prison at Washington, which was used during the war of the rebellion as a place of safekeeping for rebel suspects and high prisoners of war.

The value of pearls has been in all ages commensurate with their beauty. In the East, especially, they have been greatly admired, and enormous sums of money have been paid for them. Pliny observes that pearls are the most valuable and excellent of all precious stones; and from our Saviour's comparing the kingdom of heaven to a pearl, it is evident they must have been held in very high estimation at that time.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- A dispatch to The Times from Port Louis, Mauritius, says that all diplomatic relations between France and Madagascar have now been broken off.

Now for the Horse Show! The social season opens to-morrow night with its most interesting and all-important event. The few fashionable people who have lingered latest at the Autumn resorts will no longer remain away. To-morrow there will be a general influx of society people from Lenox, Newport, and the mountains.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- [Copyright; 1894] -- There is no abatement in the flow of gold to the Continent, and the stock in the Bank of England shows reduction of u100,000. While as yet no effect has been, produced upon discount, it is admitted that the outward movement of gold cannot continue much longer without causing an increase in rates.

-- George S. Good of Lock Haven, Penn., and the Hon. James Kerr, under the firm name of George S. Good Co., have closed a contract for constructing 120 miles of railroad for the Choctaw, Oklahoma and Gulf Railway Company. Headquarters will be opened at South McAlester Indian Territory, the eastern connection of the line, and at Oklahoma City, the western terminus.

On the contrary, Anthony Hope's personages have none of the characteristics of puppets, unless a few of them are distinguished by that total depravity which belongs to all inanimate objects, and to many human beings as well.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- [Copyright, 1894, by The New-York Times.] -- For the next ten days all reading Europe will follow in imagination that strange and barbarously splendid funeral procession which, slowly through solid avenues of troops, will be wending its way northward across Russia.
The Clyde Line steamer Algonquin, Capt. Platt, which arrived yesterday, had in tow the steamer Croatan, Capt. Hasen, of the same line.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 10. -- The eighteenth annual convention of the Knights of Labor will begin here on Tuesday. General Master Workman James R. Sovereign of Des Moines, Grand Secretary John W. Hayes of Philadelphia, Patrick Murphy of NewYork, T. B. McGuire of Amsterdam, N. Y., and other prominent leaders have arrived in advance of the convention.
Theodore R. Davis, artist and writer, died in Asbury Park, N.J., yesterday morning of Bright's disease, after a lingering illness.

-- The American Horse Exchange of New-York will hold an important sale of thoroughbreds In Lexington, on Nov. 19. The entries are large and some of the sires represented are: Imp. Albert, sire of Pop Gray, Belvidere, Ber- san, Ballard, imp. Cheviot, imp. Deceiver, Hanover, Imp. King Galop, Troubadour, imp. Richmond, Masterpiece, imp. Wagner, Onondaga, Fonso, Fordham, Linden, Lord Clifden, Julien, Powhattan, Heimdel, and The Bard.

The report that Japan is prepared to present a bill of $200,000,00 to China for the cost of the war in addition to a demand for the cession of Formosa, seems to be unauthorized and premature. China has not yet sued for peace to the people whom in his declaration of war the Emperor described as "vermin" and ordered his Generals to destroy.

-- Dr. and Mrs. La Roche of Madison Avenue will give the first of a series of dinners on Saturday evening, Nov. 17. The dinner will be in yellow and blue, the floral decorations consisting of violets and yellow chrysanthemums. The guests for this occasion are Mr. and Mrs. John Jasper, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Esler. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Montgomery, Mr. and Mrs. D.B. Van Houten, and Mr. and Mrs. Gilson S. Whitson.

Cincinnati, Ohio, Nov. 10. -- L.D. Henderson, forty years old, a commercial traveler from New-York, was found dead in his room at the Stag Hotel, this morning, by J.B. Palmer, who ocoupied the same room. Death was due to heart failure, superinduced by alcohol. Henderson had been at the Stag since Oct. 24, most of which time he had been drinking.

HOLLIS, L.I., Nov. 10 -- A skirted-trousered apparition -- so the townspeople call it -- has been seen here twice in the last few days. If anybody doubts this statement, the Rev. Richard Copp, pastor of the Methodist Church, will make affidavit to its truth. He chased the apparition half a mile.

The second volume of the work which Mr. Traill intelligently edits continues to clarify into invincible facts the record of the progress of the people of England in religion, laws, learning, arts, industry, commerce, science, literature, and manners. It is in four chapters, and relates to the consolidation of the Kingdom, in 1274-1348; the Black Death and its effects, in 1348-1399; the close of the Middle Ages, (1399-1485,) and the beginnings of Modern England, (1485-1509.)
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1/2@1 per cent., although the usual rate was 1 per cent.

-- The Frederick A. Stokes Company, which has not been much given heretofore to the publication of novels, brings out in a neat 12mo, with red muslin covers and gilt stamping, a story called, "In the Midst of Alarms," by Robert Barr. It excites one's curiosity immediately, for the novelists of to-day adapt their titles frequently from Shakespeare and Tennyson, but have ignored Cowper.

Society's clans will gather to-day at the Madison Square Garden for their annual parade and exhibition, for which the Horse Show is made an excuse. Philadelphia, Boston, Baltimore, Brooklyn, Buffalo, and other near-by cities Will be largely represented in the small mob which will assemble daily and nightly during the coming week to see and be seen.

The progress made upon the two main buildings on University Heights, namely, the Hall of Languages and the Chemical Laboratory, is a source of congratulation on the part of the Faculty and university authorities. The contractors having the work in charge are more than fulfilling their agreements in respect to time. Language Hall is about ready for occupancy.

The statistics of the Dominion's seal catch for the past season suggest the inquiry whether the rules adopted at Paris are adequate for the purpose they have in view. The pelagic sealers of Canada took, it is said, 95,049 skins, against about 70,000 last year and 54,000 the year before.

Just how Mrs. Annie Hackett, a widow with two children, happened to be tied by neck and wrist to the newel post of the lower stairs in the flat house at 1,152 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning, is a question that is puzzling both the neighbors and the police.

Emma Zimmerman, a four-year-old girl of Bath Beach, which is now a part of the City of Brooklyn, has one of the strangest afflictions on record. The little one cannot eat anything sweet, like a piece of candy, or pie, or fruit, without becoming blind for three days.

The first practical step has been taken toward the establishment of an endowment fund for the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 11 -- First Assistant Postmaster General Frank H. Jones of Illinois, who has supervision of the Divisions of Salaries and Allowances, Free Delivery, Post Office Supplies, Money-Order System, Dead-Letter Office, and Correspondence, has submitted his annual report for the year ended June 30 last to the Postmaster General.
The Rev. Dr. Ferd C. Iglehart preached last evening at the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church on the election results. He said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- No one need be surprised to hear to-morrow that the Treasury Department is about to advertise for bids for a loan of fifty or a hundred millions of dollars -- five per cents -- at a premium that will make them practically 3 per cent. bonds. The New-York Times has already fore-shadowed this event in these dispatches.

This volume contains all of Bishop Brooks's public utterances outside of the pulpit of which records have been preserved that are measurably correct. The essays and orations have been printed from the most authentic sources available. Some have been taken directly or at second hand from manuscripts prepared by the Bishop himself, and some from reports of addresses furnished by stenographers.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- The first week of secret practice by the Yale University football men has been one of the toughest for bad weather that Tale has probably, ever had. A storm set in Monday morning, and it has been raining or snowing or hailing every afternoon since, much to the disgust of Capt.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 11. -- Silas Tuthill, a wealthy farmer at Quogue, owns some fine cows. Farmer George Rogers, also of Quogue, owns a fine orchard of young trees. Farmer Tuthill's fine cows broke into Farmer Rogers's young orchard and injured some of the trees. That is what Farmer Rogers alleged in his complaint when he sued his neighbor for the injury inflicted on the trees.

Philadelphia, Nov. 11 -- The British Naval Court of Inquiry, summoned by the British Consul to inquire into the facts concerning the loss of the British ship Otago, has suspended for three months the British certificate of competency of Capt. Landry, who commanded the vessel when she was abandoned.

The committee of the Marylebone Cricket Club, the governing body for the game in England, has prepared a scheme, at the request of the leading counties, for regulating the county championship. The scheme has met with the approval of the counties concerned, and the contest for the championship will, in future, be regulated by it.

There was a general election in the Australian colony of Victoria on Sept. 20, and the dominant issue was tariff reform. There had been a popular movement for a reduction of duties. The Victorian tariff had been increased three times in the last eight years. In 1887 the ad valorem standard was 25 per cent.; in 1889 it became 35 per cent., and in 1892 it was advanced to 50 per cent.

There are no great bookbinders; there are only great bookbindings. In the Fifth Avenue, in their new white building, under the gracefully-shaped architectural marquise of which it is delightful to pass in, Messrs. Charles Scribner's Sons are to exhibit today, for the first time, great bookbindings, and not merely works that are signed by great bookbinders.

The Boston Writer prints a letter written by Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes to the Rev. Edward Everett Hale in December, 1869, in which he promises to write a requested article at some time, but amusingly adds:
The associate graduates of Grammar School No. 22 held their first banquet at Riccadonna's, 42 Union Square, on Saturday night.

The police of the Twenty-fifth Precinct think they have arrested the two principal members of a gang of thieves which has lately been robbing a number of small shopkeepers in First, Second, and Third Avenues, in the neighborhood of Sixtieth and Seventieth Streets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- An interesting and important letter has been received from Rome by the Apostolic Delegate, Mgr. Satolli, to be forwarded by him to the Archbishops, who are to distribute it to their suffragans.

A triple baptism under peculiar circumstances took place last evening in the presence of about 200 men and women at the home of W.C. Andrews, 18 Orient Avenue, Williamsburg. The spectators were the seceding members of the Old Bushwick Dutch Reformed Church, and the officiating clergyman was the Rev. S. Miller Hageman, the deposed pastor, whose cause so many of the congregation have espoused.

Senator John Sherman has given to the public his opinions as to the causes of the recent defeat of the Democratic Party and the meaning of that defeat with respect to the tariff issue. His remarks are on the whole quite philosophic and conservative. He is not inclined, he says, "to claim that the victory will be permanent," for the people "before many years may administer to the Republicans as crushing a defeat."
When Police Commissioner Sheehan's Pequod Club paraded before election day, it was conspicuously assisted by the Calcium Club, an organization of colored men, at 113 West Thirty-second Street.

Quentin K. McKendrick, a well-known commission merchant of New-York, died at his home, 25 Brevoort Place, Brooklyn, yesterday. He was born in Scotland seventy years ago, and came to America in 1861. He was engaged in business on Bowling Green, New-York, and was a member of the Produce Exchange.
The Rev. J.V. Saunders preached yesterday morning at the Seventh Street Presbyterian Church on the result of the election. His text was "What Next? " He said:

Speaker George R. Malby of St. Lawrence County has rented rooms at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, which were opened by him yesterday as headquarters, from which he will conduct his fight for the Speakership of the next Assembly.

The Anarchists of this city yesterday had a cheerless commemoration of the execution of the Chicago Anarchist murderers on Nov. 11, 1887. The services were hold in the Thalla Theatre in the Bowery. The place had not been warmed up, and, as not more than 300 assembled in this large place, there were not enough of them to warm each other.

George W. Page, who was charged by his wife, Margaret, with administering morphine to Harry Williams on Oct. 25, which caused death twenty minutes later, was brought before Justice Burke, in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning for further examination. The case was adjourned. until Tuesday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Though the football season ends for the Cornell team with the Lehigh game at Ithaca Thanksgiving Day, the most important contest to be played is that with the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia next Saturday. The men who play in this game will really constitute Cornell's 'Varsity team this season, and from the present Indications these men may be picked with reasonable certainty.

Miss Annie Kampf, a pretty, dark-eyed German girl, seventeen years old, who narrowly escaped a sentence of two and a half years in Trenton (N.J.) State prison on a charge of picking pockets, is a prisoner in Jefferson Market prison on a similar charge.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11. -- The imperial party, with the body of Alexander III., arrived here to-day in typical Moscow weather. The sky was dull, the thermometer was two degrees below the freezing point, and a north wind blew fitfully throughout the day.

The proprietors of the New-York barbers shops have started a movement to secure from the Common Council an ordinance forbidding their shops to be open after 1 o'clock Sunday afternoon. A well-attended meeting of employers was held yesterday at Third Avenue and Fiftieth Street, and it was agreed to employ ex-Assemblyman Myer J. Stein to further, legally, the purposes of the barbers.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- The prices for local securities have held steady. Sales of Hudson River Telephone, Commercial Bank, and Troy Gas stocks were reported at current quotations. The most important item of news was the announcement that the Consolidated Transfer Company would be consolidated with the Westcott Express Company, now doing business in the cities of New-York and Brooklyn.

One of the pleasantest of the late Fall centuries was the open run given yesterday under the auspices of the Amphion Wheelmen of Brooklyn. The affair was originally scheduled for election day, but was postponed on account of the condition of the roads. brought about by the heavy rain. The roads yesterday were in fine condition, and over parts of the route very good time was made.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- Freiherr von Hammerstein, the high-tariff Feudal Agrarian, has entered the Ministry of Agriculture amid the fears and reproaches of all liberal Germany. The gazetting of his appointment has stirred bad blood throughout the empire. It provoked so many venomous comments from the unofficial newspapers that the Norddeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung felt moved yesterday to publish a general defense of the Government's course in the present crisis.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $1,534,625. The banks now hold $61,669,659 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $1,107,300, a decrease in specie of $78,500, a decrease in legal tenders of $2,188,300, a decrease in deposits of $2,928,700, and a decrease in circulation of $310,200.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- The Central News correspondent in Tokio says: "A special steamer has arrived at Hwang-Chu with dispatches as to the course of the war in Corea. Kin-Chow was taken by the Japanese on Nov. 4. The garrison consisted of some 1,200 infantry and artillery. The batteries were very badly served during the defense.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- A train containing about 1,500 Anarchists, en route to Waldheim Cemetery, this afternoon, was wrecked at Fortieth Street. The engineer of the train, probably, is hurt fatally. Several passengers were slightly injured. One man had a hand hurt so bad that it was necessary to cut off his fingers.

"Greater New-York's Splendid Opportunity" was the subject of the sermon delivered by the Rev. James P. Carson in the Central Presbyterian Church, Tompkins and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn, last evening. He said:
The Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Twelfth Street and Fifth Avenue, spoke yesterday morning on the results of the election. He said:

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- President Schurman has arranged for a series of lectures on money and banking by distinguished authorities. The first lecture of the series will be delivered on Nov. 16, by Horace White of The Evening Post.

The Rev. A.C. Dixon of Brooklyn, in the absence of the Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., who is in Texas, preached yesterday Inorning in the Twenty-third Street Baptist Church, in the Young Men's Christian Association Building. Referring to last Tuesday's election, the Rev. Mr. Dixon said the result caused him both pleasure and pain.

Richard Croker is out of politics, and dislikes to talk of political matters. A Tribune reporter had a conversation with him yesterday afternoon, however, about Tuesday's great Republican victories and their probable effect in the future. The first question asked of the former Tammany chieftain was: "Mr. Croker, is there any truth in the reports that you were interested with Michael F. Dwyev and won heavily on Morton and Strong?"

WHITESTONE, L.I., Nov. 11 -- The football contest between the teams of the United States Engineers' Battalion and the Fort Adams team for the championship of the Army League, which the former now holds, will take place on the parade ground at Willet's Point next Saturday afternoon instead of Thanksgiving Day, as at first arranged.

-- Two suspicious characters, Harry Louis and Joseph Bird, were arrested by Detectives Dunn and Dowling on West, Street Saturday. For some time Inspector MeLaughlin has been receiving complaints about immigrants being robbed along West Street, and sent Dunn and Dowling to investigate. There is no complainant against the men, but the police hope to secure evidence.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan is expected here next Wednesday from New-York, to prepare for his final departure from this city, to take up his home in the metropolis. On election morning he made the announcement that whatever the result of the election might be, he intended to go to New-York to practice law.
Mrs. Frank Scaffin of 125 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, registered Saturday night at the Ashland House, this city, as Mrs. Lane of Wilmington, Del. She was assigned to a room on the second floor.

PRINCETON, Nov. 11 -- The new catalogue is now finished, and will be distributed in the near future. Those men who have obtained high honors by virtue of their last year's work are shown. The first group men of Junior, sophomore, and freshman classes are as follows:

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 10. -- The local stock market for the week has been somewhat dull. Few shares have changed hands, and prices remain about the same. The American National Bank has declared its usual semi-annual dividend at the rate of 5 per cent., and the First National Bank its usual semi-annual dividend at the rate of 6 per cent.

Charles Muller, a Swiss, who was sixty years old and a watchman, was slain some time Saturday night in the one-story frame office of John Cullen's Empire Stone Works, in. East One Hundred and Seventh Street, near First Avenue.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 11 -- A murderous asault was committed at New-Market, about two miles from this city, last night, and it may yet end in murder. The victims were Maxton Dunham and his wife, who have long lived alone on a farm, on a lonely country road.

Police Justice Patrick Divver had not resigned last evening, nor had he proclaimed his whereabouts or authorized any statement of a definite nature in regard to his hiding place. At his Madison Street home no information about his sequestration was procurable.
Westward the musicians take their way. Saturday witnessed the advent of Mr. Abbey's tuneful company, and yesterday La Champagne brought another contingent of the votaries of melody.

Julius Grau of 701 East Sixth Street was thrown out of a light wagon in which he had been driving alone, about sundown last evening, in a little runaway that took place in the East Drive in Central Park, near the Arsenal. The horse became frightened opposite Sixty-second Street, and Grau was unable to hold him.

A large audience assembled in the Star Theatre last night to hear what Col. Robert G. Ingersoll had to say in his new lecture, which has the Bible for its subject. He said he had read the book from beginning to end, and asked if it was a moral book.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 11 -- Justin H. Smith of Boston of the class of '77 has given to Dartmouth College a, prize yielding $50 a year for extemporaneous speaking. This prize, taken in connection with another which is available for original work, enables the Faculty to establish an exercise in prize speaking in the Winter term, quite distinct in its object from the prize speaking before Commencement.

The members of the Knickerbocker Whist Club, whose headquarters are in the Hotel Wellington Annex, at Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street, are making active preparations for another successful whist season. This club, which was only organized last year, made an excellent record, and the opening of another season finds the club stronger in membership than ever.
The Rev. Dr. Sylvester F. Jones preached last evening at the Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church on "After Victory, Fidelity." He said:

The striking cloakmakers stand firm. They passed resolutions resolving to stick it out at the various shop meetings yesterday, and at their mass meeting at Everett Hall they declared they would, if necessary, stand out all Winter and Spring.

It was evident before the cable line upon Third Avenue was opened to the public that if it was conducted with an intelligent regard for the public convenience it would operate to divert enough traffic from the elevated road that runs over it to relieve the pressure upon that mode of conveyance.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 11. -- Within the last twenty-four hours quite a number of robberies have been reported to the police among the cottages of the Summer residents. This morning at 2 o'clock word was received by telephone from a life-saving station surfman, who was patroling the beach, that a man was breaking into the residence of Prof. Agassiz of Harvard College, situated at Castle Hill.
The Rev. Charles H. Eaton, pastor of the Church of the Divine Paternity, Forty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, preached yesterday morning on "The Wicked in Hiding."

CHARLESTON, West Va., Nov. 11 -- The defeat of the Democratic Party in this State last Tuesday, and the election of a Republican Legislature, has transferred from the Democratic to the Republican Party the contest for the United States Senatorship. The Legislature elected last Tuesday, which will meet Jan. 9, will elect a successor to Senator Camden, whose term will expire March 4 1895.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Secretary Herbert sent the following letter to Admiral Gherardi yesterday:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 12. -- The Montclair Club is arranging to make things interesting at its headquarters this Winter, and tournaments are announced to take place in billiards, pool, bowling, whist, and euchre. The entry-lists are already open, and will hot close until Nov. 24, As there are many experts, among the club members in all these branches of amusement, each of the five tournaments promises to be close and spirited.

Charles J. Clark, the ten-year-old son of James Clark, of 523 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, has been missing from his uncle's home at Bridgeport, Conn., for more than a week. The boy went to Bridgeport last July and visited his uncle. Dr. H. J. Dever of 36 Benham Avenue. He was sent to St. Agnes's Convent School, but refused to attend the school after being there three days.

Joseph L. Sheffield, about fifty years old, died suddenly shortly after 9 P.M. Sunday in the Mount Morris Hotel, 2.370 Third Avenue. His body was found in the small dark room on the third floor of the hotel that he was permitted to occupy from a charitable feeling toward him.

Arthur Zimmerrnan, the crack bicyclist, arrived from Genoa yesterday morning on the steamship Augusta Victoria. The Hamburg-American Line dock at Hoboken was crowded with the famous rider's friends when the steamer arrived, and "Zimmie" was given a royal welcome.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The case of Charles Wilfred Mowbray, the English Anarchist, who arrived in New-York from England last Saturday under an assumed name, is likely to be brought to the attention of the Treasury officers, although up to the present time no effort has been made to trouble Mowbray.

Retail grocers of Brooklyn will meet tonight in the Johnston Building, in Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, to take action on the sale of groceries in dry goods stores, and members of the New-York Retail Grocers' Union will be present to make addresses and give advice.

The contest for the Speakership of the next Assembly is being reduced to close quarters. While there are seven nominal candidates in the field, as a matter of fact the names of not more than three will be presented to the Republican caucus, which will meet on Tuesday evening, Jan. 1, 1895.

BRIDGEPORT, Nov. 12. -- The freighting business on the Consolidated Road was never known to be heavier, and everything that can draw a car is pressed into service. The great difficulty is to get enough freight engines to haul the trains, and oftentimes heavy passenger engines are pressed into service.

The steamship St. Louis, and her sister ship, the St. Paul, are the largest vessels that have ever been built in this country. The determination of the International Navigation Company to build the vessels was in pursuance of the company's promise to construct two steamships in this country of equal tonnage to its steamship's Paris and New-York if Congress would pass a bill admitting the two latter vessels to American registry.

The Greater New-York was the subject discussed for over an hour between James S.T. Stranahan and Mayor Schieren in the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday. The Mayor has been a consolidationist for over thirty years, and Mr. Stranahan is a member of the Consolidation Commission. Speaking of the interview, Mayor Schieren said:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12. -- Christened by Mrs. Cleveland, in the presence of President Cleveland, members of his Cabinet, and a delegation of prominent citizens of St. Louis, Mo., headed by Mayor Walbridge, as guests of honor, the steamship St. Louis, the first of the two great vessels built in this country for the International Navigation Company, (the American Line,) was successfully launched from the Cramps's shipyard this afternoon.

-- Proetor's Theatre -- A girl en deshabille, bidding good-night to her pug dog and white kiten, formed a very pretty domestic tableau called "Retiring" in the living series at Proctor's yesterday. It was loudly applauded, and so was "Comin' Through the Rye," with its accompaniful and melodious, with a liberal seasoning of sensational acrobats.

The Racing Board of the League of American Wheelemn held a special meeting at Chairman Raymond's office, in Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, and transacted much business of importance to cyclists. There were present G.D. Gideon of Philadelphia, Henry Robinson of Boston, L.C. Jaquish of Chicago, E.C. Crowinger of Louisville, and the Chairman.
N.R. Reynolds, twenty-two years old, committed suicide yesterday at 146 East Thirty-fourth Street by taking morphine. No cause for his act is known or suggested.
The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen at yesterday's meeting granted to the State Electric Light and Power Company an extension of six months to build its conduits.

-- The Charity Organization Society appeals to the benevolent people for $300 with which to supplement a fund raised by private persons to pay for the admission of two aged sisters in to a home for the aged. The women are thoroughly respectable, are in feeble health, and entirely unable to do anything for their own support. They have outlived those who have maintained them, and are now in extreme destitution.

The Horse Show, which opened yesterday at the Madison Square Garden, is a success. For nine seasons it has drawn society to the big show place, as the strongest mag- net attracts the smallest needle, and yet never before has it been so generally successful in all its details and taken as a whole as it is this year.

Louis Grunhut and Mary Bullona, son and daughter of Dr. Bernhard Grunhut, who was supposed to have died in Brooklyn Aug. 22, have filed, in the Surrogate's Court of Kings County, objections to the probate of their father's will. They allege that Dr. Grunhut, whose will was offered yesterday for probate, is not dead.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12. -- The local market to-day was dull and showed a pretty firm tone, but in most cases the close shows fractional losses. Citizens' Passenger of Indianapolis was the feature at the opening, advancing to 51, a rise of 7 1/2 points from the close on Saturday. This rapid advance was all made in the first fifteen minutes.

Michael Carney, a young bartender, of 205 Monroe Street, died at 616 East Thirteenth Street yesterday morning from injuries received in a fight the night before after leaving Hickey's saloon, at Thirteenth Street and Avenue B, where he vras employed.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 12. -- Ivy Baldwin, the aeronaut, has joined the arms, under the direction of Capt. Glassford of the War Balloon and Signal Corps. He was admitted yesterday, and will be placed at Fort Logan, where he will have charge of the balloon equipment and the construction of a plant for gas generation.
Mayor-elect William L. Strong returned to this city from Philadelphia yesterday morning. He said he had enjoyed his brief rest and was feeling in good condition.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 12 -- The Post to-day publishes the report of the Labor Commission appointed to investigate the strike of last Summer. It says in part:

Mayor Charles A. Schieren of Brooklyn yesterday expressed himself in favor of the plan of Chauncey M. Depew for taking the saloon out of politics in this State, outlined by Mr. Depew in The New-York Times of Sunday.
ISLIP, L. I., Nov. 12. -- George Smith, thirty years old, of this village, was shot and mortally wounded by his companion, George Raynor, while hunting, deer north of this place to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Mayor-elect Strong of New-York has no reason to fear that if he should select Gen. Anson G. McCook to be his private secretary he would be deprived of the General's services inside of a year.

Joseph Larocque, Chairman of the Committee of Seventy, and W. Travers Jerome, who has been retained by the committee to prosecute persons charged with, election frauds, called on District Attorney Fellows yesterday.

The Methodist Missionary Committee continued its sessions yesterday in the Hanson Place Methodist Church, Brooklyn, with Bishop Foss of Philadelphia in the chair. Consideration of appropriations for foreign missions was continued during the morning, India taking up a large share of the time.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 12. -- In the case of John Hyson et al. vs. the School District of Gallitzin borough et al., better known as the "Gallitzin School case," the Supreme Court to-day affirmed the decision of the lower court. Justice Dean, in delivering the majority opinion, says, in part:

BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- The new Castle Square Theatre was opened to-night with the production, for the first time on any stage, of a drama called "Captain Paul." A large audience was in attendance, and the beauties of the new house were greatly admired.
Ignacio Martinez, a well-known member of the Stock Exchange, committed suicide some time yesterday in his rooms in the fashionable bachelor apartment house at 21 West Thirtieth Street.

Although Secretary Herbert cut down heavily the estimates of his chiefs of bureau for the coming fiscal year, he will have to ask Congress for a sum considerably larger than has been called for by the Navy Department during several years past. The current appropriations are $25,585,820.76; those of the previous year were $22,104,061.38; those of the year before that, $23,548,266.56. Mr. Herbert's estimates are $30,952,020.40.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Postmaster General Bissell, who has been ill for the last ten days, is still unable to do any work, and probably will not go to the Post Office Department before Thursday. Mr. Bissell contracted a severe cold, which for some time. refused to yield to treatment, and finally affected one of his ears so that leeches had to be applied when other remedies failed to relieve his pain.
The Board of Aldermen will meet this morning at 11 o'clock to transact some routine business, and at noon it will be sworn in as a Board of County Canvassers by County Clerk Purroy.
VICTORIA, B.C., Nov. 12. -- The following Honolulu advices up to Nov. 3 have been received here by the steamship Miowera:

An open letter on the affairs of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company has been addressed to the Hartshorne committee of security holders by Mr. Isaac L. Rice. It has been prepared in anticipation of the annual election of the company, an its main purpose is to place before the security holders a resume of the occurrences since the last annual meeting.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- A dispatch from Shanghai to the Central News, under today's date, says it is reported there that Port Arthur was taken by the Japanese yesterday, without resistance. The Japanese, after bombarding the place for a short time, made a land assault upon, the enemy's works, when the Chinese surrendered.

PALERMO, Nov. 12. -- The great Sicilian landowners have met here to organize for the purpose of defeating the Government's plan of agrarian reform on the island. This reform is to be presented to the consideration of Parliament in a bill for the division. of the large holdings. The Government's object is to allay the suffering of the agricultural population and to prevent thus the recurrence of the revolt of last Winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The recent acceptance by President Cleveland of the recommendations of the Civil Service Commissioners to amend the civil service rules so as to bring about a reduction in the number of employes in the classified Postal Service who are not subject to examination will exempt many clerics in the New-York City Post Office from anxiety about being disturbed for political reasons by Postmasters hereafter appointed.

Stephen Little, the expert railroad accountant, has submitted his completed report on the financial condition of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe system to the Reorganization Committee, and yesterday the report was issued in pamphlet form. It shows that the net earnings of the system (not including the Atlantic and Pacific, the Colorado Midland, and the St. Louis end San Francisco) for the year ended June 30, 1894, were $5,956,614.

Developments in the financial district yesterday bore mainly upon the impending Government bond issue. The plan, as foretold in The New-York Times, had been well considered since Saturday, and, knowing for two days what to expect, bankers went to business yesterday with opinions fairly well defined regarding their own action.

The cases of the People against ex-Police Captains John T. Stephenson, formerly of the Leonard Street Station; Michael Doherty, formerly of the Fifth Street Station, and Max F. Schmittberger, formerly of the staemboat squad, now of the Nineteenth Precinct, were called for trial yesterday before Justice Ingraham, sitting in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, in the new Criminal Courts Building.

A jury before Justice Barrett, in the Supreme Court, has decided that if a man asks another man in very warm weather, "Is it hot enough for you?" and the man questioned clubs and then cuts the questioner with a big knife, the man cut and clubbed is entitled to $1,000 damages.
JAMAICA, L. I., Nov. 12. -- The trouble in Shiloh Colored Baptist Church was renewed at the evening service last night, and the factions had a free fight in the darkness.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Nov. 12. -- Dr. Louis Bauman and Mrs. Letitia Bauman, his wife, gave society a shock to-day by revealing to the public a closet full of skeletons. The couple were married April 27, 1886, when Mr. Caldwell, the bride's father, gave to her a handsome house at 61 Wayne Street. They have one child, a daughter, six years old.

The tenth annual Horse Show began promptly at 2 o'clock with the judging of the first class of harness horses, for which there were thirty entries, all but three of which were brought out to answer the call of Bugler Hayes.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Joseph S. Kerngood, who formerly resided in this city, and whose home is now in New-York, has disappeared. He is employed as a traveling salesman by Barnett L. Price, a clothing manufacturer, doing business on Green Street, in New-York.
RHINECLIFFE, N. Y., Nov. 12. -- Ashley Cole, Mr. Mortem's private secretary, said this evening:

What proved to be the roost interesting game that has yet been played in the interscholastic football series took place on Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon. The contesting elevens were the old rivals -- Cutler and Berkeley. The day was precisely what was desired, and this, together with the reputations of both teams, drew out a crowd of over 700 howling enthusiasts.

The Ohio Society of New-York honored Col. William L. Strong, its President and the Mayor-elect, in a signal manner last night by proposing his selection for the Presidency of the United States two years hence. The society met at 236 Fifth Avenue to accept portraits of Col. Strong and of the late Col. Charles W. Moulton.
Patrick Divver is in hiding to escape the subpoena servers of the Lexow committee. This fact came out yesterday, in the district where the eminent Tammany Police Justice was formerly the king.

WINDSOR, Mo., Nov. 12. -- The public school building here was burned this morning. In the building were 500 pupils, many of whom had narrow escapes. The fire started from the furnace, and was well under way before it was discovered. The children lost their wraps and books.

Robert C. Thomas, who was one of the jury that convicted John Y. McKane, died at his home, 202 South First Street, Brooklyn, last week. He was fifty-five years old, and had been under the care of a physician since the trial ended. He was a member of the Volunteer Fire Department, and leaves a wife, two sons, and three daughters.

Jules Overbury, twenty-three years old, of 23 Burnett Street, East Orange, N. J., was probably fatally crushed about the head shortly before 7 o'clock last night by an elevator in the Edison Electric Building, 53 to 59 Duane Street.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 12. -- Although the Czar's funeral is a week off, the hotels are crowded, and strangers are coming to the city by scores with every train. Nearly a thousand wreaths and crosses have been received from Princes and members of their Courts, and fully a thousand more are expected to arrive with the body.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Treasury has quit denying that there is to be an early issue of bonds. The department was just a bit slow in hearing the news, and as it did not know of the intended bond issue until it saw the fact that it was to be made published in The New-York Times, the official disposition to deny it was humored at once.

Carrie Turner, in a rather winsome way, assisted by a good company of players, presented at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night a new-old play bearing the title "The Coming Woman." Although the author, Mervyn Dallas, claims for his piece the merit of novelty, and the management announces it as a first production on any stage, it smacks strongly of translation -- possibly adaptation.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment will take up the final consideration of the city budget for 1895 in about two weeks.

Mrs. Carrie W. Delaney of 1,493 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, has begun a suit for separation from her husband, Michael F. Delaney, of Hill Delaney of 182 Franklin Street, New-York. She alleges that she was married Feb. 2 last, and that her husband deserted her in April.

In the new wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a gallery wherein are to be exhibited, from time to time, examples of the best work of etchers and engravers of all periods. In this room may be seen the entire collection of Sir Francis Seymour Haden's works formed by Mr. Samuel P. Avery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12.-The flagship Chicago arrived at Malaga, Spain, to-day from Tangier. The Chicago has about completed her cruise in European waters, and will start for home in January on being relieved by the San Francisco, which will leave New-York for the Mediterranean about Dec. 15.

Jacob Schaefer, the hero of many a hardfought contest on the billiard table, and the youthful rival for championship honors, Frank Ives, began their six noghts' tournament in Madison Square Garden Concert Hall last night. On even innings Ives led throughout, but Schaefer by one of those finishes for which he is peculiar managed toget the balls together in the seventeenth inning and score 129, finishing the night's play 32 points ahead of his rival.
J. Hood Wright, a member of the firm of Drexel, Morgan Co., died suddenly last evening while on his way home from his office.
The authorities of Brooklyn were very much disturbed yesterday by the reports of Sunday fracases, street brawls, and stabbing affrays which poured into Police Headquarters.

The commission which has been investigating the subject of the disposal of street refuse, ashes, and garbage, met in the Army Building yesterday. There were present Franklin Edson, Thomas L. James, Charles G. Wilson, President of the Health Board; Lieut. Commander Daniel Delehanty, United States Navy, and Commissioner William S. Andrews.
Wheat was active and excited, and closed firm at 3/4@1 1/8c advance, with cables higher, West firmer, local covering, and decreased stocks.

Some of the older men in Tammany Hall are indignant because no effort has yet been made to call the General Committee of the organization together, to ascertain what can be done in aid of the defeated braves.

Irregularity was the feature of yesterday's stock market. In the early trading prices were higher, but London was a free seller and before noon the advance was checked. Sugar, which sold at 96 1/2 in the first hour, declined to 92 3/4 in the late trading, on sales of more than 110,000 shares. The weakness influenced the remainder of the market.
The statement of election expenses filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday by John W. Goff, the successful anti-Tammany candidate for Recorder, is as follows:

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 12. -- The Paskola case has come to an end. The defendant has been acquitted. It was not until this evening that this result was reached. Late this afternoon the case was sent to the jury. According to current talk the first ballot stood 6 to 6, but after two or three hours' debate the jurymen reached an agreement and a verdict.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico, Nov. 12. -- The volcano of Colima is still in a state of active eruption, and the people of that section, are terror-stricken. The crops at the base of the mountain have been destroyed by lava. The flames ascend to a great height, and the scene is a grand one, particularly at night, and is plainly visible for a distance of 200 miles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A general order was issued to-day by Adjt. Gen. Ruggles giving the names of the following officers and enlisted men who, during the past year, have distinguished themselves by specially meritorious acts or conduct in service:

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The floods in various parts of England are still raging. In Buckingham the houses in the lower portion of the town are flooded and the roads are blocked. The Avon has overflowed its banks at Bath, and thousands of persons are, consequently, imprisoned in the upper stories of factories and dwellings.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent throughout the day.

The Tenement-House Committee, Richard Watson Gilder, Chairman, which was appointed by Gov. Flower last Spring by authority of the Legislature to investigate New-York tenement houses and report plans for improving their condition, held its first public hearing yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 13. -- John P. Muller, Postmaster at Warren Point, Bergen County, appeared before United States Commissioner Alfred A. Van Hovenburg to-night and made complaint against Clerk Rowland C. Lane, charging him with forcibly driving him from the office at the point of a shotgun, and also accusing him of appropriating stamps and other property of the Government.

The police of the Fourth Precinct, Brooklyn, and of Police Headquarters are trying to unravel a mysterious stabbing and shooting affray in which a young minister and a young burglar were involved early yesterday morning at 376 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn. The clergyman is the Rev. Frederick C. Seckerson, assistant pastor of the Clinton Avenue Congregational Church, who has charge of the Willoughby Avenue Chapel, Willoughby and Grand Avenues.

Justice Patrick Divver still remained in hiding yesterday. At his house, in Madison. Street, the stereotyped answer was given that he was "not at home." The girl who answered the bell added that her master was out of the city. "Where he might or might not be she said no one in the house knew.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- Dr. P.J. Gibbons of this city to-day sent the following letter to Gov. Flower:

Contrary to expectation, no word was received by the Park Board yesterday from Frederick Law Olmsted as to whether or not he will accept the position of landscape architect of the Harlem River Driveway. Mr. Olmsted will be in the city later in the week, and will then give his answer to the Board.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- The Rev. Eugene Smith, who came from New-York City to Port Ewen, near here, three years ago, and became rector of the Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation, has become insane on religious subjects.
Recorder Smyth filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday a statement showing that his election expenses were $3,500, all of which was paid to Tammany's Treasurer, John McQuade.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 13 -- The preparations for the reception of the body of Alexander III, in this city to-day were hardly equal to those in Moscow, and, in consequence of a thaw, followed by fog and a heavy snowfall, the procession had to march through deep slush and mud. The heralds yesterday announced that the body would arrive at 10 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- There is some danger that the reading public will reach the mistaken conclusion, from reading some of the recent publications concerning the interest of the United States in the conflict between China and Japan, that this Government has made an offer of mediation between the two nations now at war.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Among the prominent persons present at the opening of the Congress of Arbitration and Conciliation to-day were President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor and Josephine Shaw Lowell. An address on the subject of "The History of Industrial Arbitration in England and on the Continent" took up the time of the convention during the morning.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 13. -- The following official statement was made by the committee of the Faculty of Wesleyan University appointed to investigate the recent cases of typhoid fever there:

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 13 -- A.A. Cadwallader, ex-President of the Superior National Bank, under indictment for the embezzlement of about $40,000 of the bank's funds two years ago, and in whose case the jury disagreed at the trial last Spring, pleaded guilty to the charge in the United States court this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- When The New-York Times last Saturday announced that within three days the President would call for bids for proposals for a new issue of Government bonds, the Secretary of the Treasury and some superserviceable purveyors of denials at once declared that the report was untrue, and the Secretary made his denial with unnecessary circumstance and positiveness.

Dr. Paul Gibier, Director of the Pasteur Institute, Ninety-seventh Street and Central Park West, announced yesterday that the first shipment of antitoxine serum for the cure of diphtheria manufactured in this country would be sent from the institute last night to the Board of Health in New-Orleans, where diphtheria has been raging for nearly a month.

The people of this city made a new political will last Tuesday. In it they devised that Tammany should no longer hold possession of the Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty. By a codicil in the shape of constitutional amendments the people also provided that the new trustees of their rights, the reform Government, should also deprive Tammany of all its other political property.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13. -- Gen. Cassius M. Clay was married to pretty Dora Richardson at 10 o'clock this morning, Squire B. Douglass officiating. Only the farm hands and relatives of the girl were present.

It is curious how perfunctory are the objections that have been made to the new bond issue. Some of them are partisan, and were expected. One gentleman very gravely accuses the President of waiting until after the elections, and then trying to appropriate the "glory" of sustaining the national credit, which Republican victories had already made secure.

Hubbard, Ohio, Nov. 13. -- James Mahany, John Richards, and Martin Rosteth were butchering pigs this morning. Mahany and Rosteth quarreled, and Rosteth whipped Mahany. The latter, crazy with rage, went home, obtained a revolver, and, returning, shot Richards twice, mistaking him for Rosteth. Richards is likely to die, but he refuses to make a complaint, saying Mahany did not intend to shoot him.

So numerous have become the classes at the Horse Show and so large are the lists of entries that the work of judging has to be begun early this year. The judges are working rapidly, as a rule, and they keep up with the programme in excellent shape.

Cyclists of many clubs were present last evening at the Central Opera House, where the New-York Wheelmen gave their annual dramatic entertainment and reception. The drama "East Lynne" was presented by a cast including several members of the association, and very entertaining it proved to be. Three professionals assisted the amateurs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Judge Cole this morning, in Criminal Court No. 2, rendered a decision overruling the demurrer filed to the indictments found against E.R. Chapman and J.W. Macartney, stockbrokers, for refusing to tell the Senate committee charged with investigating the Sugar Trust whether any United States Senators had speculated in Sugar stock through their firms.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., Nov. 13. -- About twenty villagers, headed by Charles Dickerson, are patrolling the streets to-night and watching for the burglars who have been working so successfully here for several weeks.
ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- No formal petition asking for the pardon of John Y. McKane has been received by the Governor, despite reports to the contrary.
