BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- The Tageblatt says that Nicholas II, has summoned Miljoutin, ex-Minister of War and a confidential adviser of Alexander III., to aid him in reforming the Russian Ministry. Privy Councilor Durnovo, it says, will retire from the Ministry of the Interior to make way for M. de Plewe; Dr. Witte will retain the finance portfolio, and the Grand Duke Sergius will become Governor General of St. Petersburg.
The Rev. Joseph L. Hoey has been appointed by Archbishop Corrigan pastor of the new parish on the east side.

BERLIN, Nov. 18. -- Chancellor Prince Hohenlohe left Strassburg for Berlin to-day. On his way he will stop in Stuttgart and Dresden to confer with the ministers and sovereigns in these capitals, as he conferred with the Bavarian Cabinet and Prince Regent Luitpold. No definite arrangements have been made for his visit to Bismarck.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Important changes have recently been made in the required part of the curriculum of Vassar College. Hereafter hygiene will be confined to the first semester, and the hour of the second semester formerly given to it will now be given as a fourth hour to the course in mathematics.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Nov. 19 -- There was a temporary suspension in the Maspeth horse-bologna-sausage industry to-day. Deputy Sheriff Louis Walters, armed with an execution, took charge of the factory which is operated by Henry Bosse.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19 -- If Harvard does not win at Springfield on Saturday, it will not be the fault of the management of the football team. Every precaution is being taken to keep the men in condition. The practice is light. After the work on the Soldiers' Field every afternoon, the men take the train for Auburndale in time for dinner.

ALBANY, Nov. 19.--Gov. Flower Issued a proclamation this afternoon ordering a special election to be held Dec. 20 In the Twenty-sixth Senatorial District to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Charles T. Saxton.

The Tourist Cycle Club's bowling team journeyed from Paterson to Brooklyn last evening to meet the Bushwick "Wheelmen's team on the American Alleys, in Greens Avenue. The pins were bowled over right merrily by the Jerseymen in their first game, but in the second the tooting of immense tin horns by their rivals somewhat "rattled" the lads from Paterson, and they lost.

In the financial report submitted by Charles P. Mayer, President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, at the annual meeting of the stockholders in Baltimore yesterday, the following figures were given: Gross earnings, for the year ended June 30, 1894, $22,502,662; operating expenses, $15,560,689; net earnings, $6,941,973; other income, $1,982,857; total available income, $8,719,829.

A respectably-dressed man was seen for some time early last night walking on the Bowery, between Bleecker and Great Jones Streets, but he attracted no particular attention until he threw a brick wrapped in tissue paper through the window of David Marks's jewelry store at 334 Bowery.

SING SING, N. Y., Nov. 19. -- At Croton Dam about noon to-day Miss Maggie Sheehan shot and killed her brother William, thirty years old. They are the children of John Sheehan, who drives a team for Charles H. Lent. They live in a little farmhouse, near the dam.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 19. -- The Chronicle will publish to-morrow the reply of Congressman J C. C. Black to Mr. Tom Watson's proposition to appoint a commission to purge the recent Congressional election, in the Tenth District of illegal votes, and abide by the eliminated count.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- Gen. Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, to-day appointed Omar V. Sage of Catskill Agent and Warden of Sing Sing Prison.

On account of the candidacy of Mr. Joseph Medill, the veteran editor and chief proprietor of The Chicago Tribune, for the Senate, and of The Tribune's partisan use of the tariff issue during the recent campaign, the latest utterance of that prominent journal as to the tariff policy of the Republican Party in the near future is quite interesting.
Members of the Committee of Seventy read the statement of ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt in which he declared against a Police Commission constituted of a single member with varying emotions.
John Garvin, the frowsy tramp who took a nap Saturday night in one of the fine beds in Mrs. William Astor's mansion, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, was released from prison last evening.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 19 -- Ex-President Benjamin Harrison is here to-day in consultation with Chairman J. til. Quigley and the representatives and Trustees of the preferred coupon stock of the Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City Railroad. This road is now in the hands of a receiver under a bill filed by the first mortgage bondholders in the United States Circuit Court in Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois to bring about a foreclosure and sale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Admiral Meade's proposed race of the Columbia with the Majestic or any other liner is not likely to take place immediately. Assistant Secretary McAdoo is not in favor of acting on the Admiral's suggestion at present, nor does he intimate that the race may be arranged by and by.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- It has been ascertained here to-day that the Berliner Tageblatt of Nov. 2 was well advised when it published it as a fact that assurances had been given at Washington that the Administration would recommend to the approaching session of Congress the repeal of the tariff law so far as it imposes a discriminating duty of one-tenth of a cent a pound on all bounty-paid sugars imported into the United States.

A Rector Street train, in charge of Conductor Crosson, ran into a South Ferry train which was standing at the Park Place station at 3:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Nobody was injured, the rolling stock suffered slightly, and the blockade lasted less than fifteen minutes.

Owners and lessees of a number of the worst tenement houses in the city were subpoenaed to appear before the Tenement House Committee yesterday afternoon. Many did not answer to their names when called, and a large part of those on hand were evidently unwilling witnesses.

FARMINGDALE, N.J., Nov. 19 -- An explosion that shook every house in the neighborhood and made the residents believe that an earthquake had visited the place was felt here soon after 1 o'clock to-day. One of the large outhouses of the Phoenix Powder Works in which was stored nearly a ton of rifle powder was blown high in the air, and the two men working therein, were killed outright.
BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Judge Coit of the United States Circuit Court to-day rendered an adverse decision in the case of Emily A. Corliss and others versus certain photographers and publishers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The boom on the local Stock Exchange has, to a great extent, died out, and the market seems to be drifting into the old rut The movement is again largely of a speculative nature, outsiders showing little disposition to do anything in an investment way. Values today were as a rule well maintained, but this, in most cases, was almost entirely due to covering of shorts.

Mayor Gilroy has invited Mayor-elect Strong to attend the meetings of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment at which the final estimate for the budget of 1895, the first year of Mr. Strong's administration, will be decided upon. Mr. Strong has accepted the invitation.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 19 -- The remains of Orville H. Stevens arrived here this evening from Wernersville, Penn., where he died Saturday afternoon. Mr. Stevens was one of the most prominent citizens of Western Connecticut, and his sudden death in connection with his deep family trouble has caused a severe shock to the community.

A priest from St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, in Pacific Street, near Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, and Ambulance Surgeon Schell of the Homeopathic Hospital, in Cumberland Street, had a long argument in a drug store in Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, last night, while James Whelen of 452 De Kalb Avenue, lay on the floor, unconscious, with a fractured skull.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 19 -- The arrest in New-York of a man named Stetson, alias "Bill the Brute," on the charge of breaking into a flower store, awakens much interest here. It is understood in Newport that he has confessed that he was implicated in two big burglaries here -- the robbery of the houses of Commodore Gerry and J.W. Ellis, in August, 1893.

When a four-hundred-pound safe can be stolen and carried through the streets of Brooklyn it begins to look as though the police of that city had lost all knowledge of police duty, and were simply drawing their salaries as walking models.
The Ward Line steamer Seneca, which arrived here yesterday from Progreso, Mexico, had on board A.V. Armour of Chicago.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 19 -- The Niewsdag publishes a dispatch from Lombok stating that the Dutch have stormed and captured the town of Tjakra Negara, the stronghold of the Balinese. The Rajah of Lombok escaped during the fight, taking his treasure with him. The Dutch lost 150 killed and wounded, and the enemy's loss was several hundreds.

Services in memory of the late John Jay, LL. D., will be held to-night, Nov. 20, in the Concert Hall of the Madison Square Garden by the Evangelical Alliance of the United States. President Seth Low of Columbia College will preside over the services. Brief addresses will be made illustrative of the phases of the life and eminent public services of Mr. Jay.

John Raymond of 9 James Street created much excitement in the neighborhood of Chatham Square, about 3 o'clock yesterday; afternoon, by rushing around, thinly clad, with a gash in his neck. He was followed through the streets by large crowds until arrested and taken to the Hudson Street Hospital.
Interesting facts in relation to the recent local campaign, so far as the Tammany end of it was concerned, are coming to light.
Fulton Avenue, west side, 232 feet north of One Hundred and Sixty-eighth Street; no owner recorded; two-story frame workshop; cost $3,500.

RED BANK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The approaching cold weather brings to mind the Winter sports, for which this place has become famous. Red Bank, as has been said truthfully by a wellknown authority, is the "ice yachting centre of America." Added to this reputation is the fact that the world's skating records were made here two Winters ago by Joe Donoghue.

From The Atlanta (Ga.) Journal. The preliminary report of Assistant State Geologist McCallie, just issued by State Geologist Yeates, shows that Georgia is rich in marble deposits, which, when properly developed, will bring a flood of wealth within her borders.

There will be a large gathering of Democrats who are opposed to machine rule in the banquet hall of the Clarendon Hotel, Washington Street, Brooklyn, to-night, when it is expected that a new Democratic club will be organized.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 19. -- The body of the late Czar Alexander III. was placed in the tomb of his fathers, beneath the fortress Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul, to-day, seventeen days after his death.

Following the example of their fellowtradesmen in Brooklyn, the retail grocers of New-York have taken up the question of the sale of groceries, wines, and liquors in the dry-goods department stores. The matter was discussed last night by the members of the New-York Retail Grocers' Union, at a meeting in Grocers' Hall, 140 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Acting Secretary of the Navy McAdoo this morning received a full report from Capt. Henry Glass of the accident to the Cincinnati, as well as a preliminary telegraphic statement from the commandant of the New-York Navy Yard as to the amount and character of the damage to the ship, as shown by inspecting her in the dry dock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Some of the officers and soldiers of the army are anxious to secure abandoned Springfield rifles, now that the new magazine arm is ready and these old weapons are to be turned in. The rifles are good for hunting purposes, and Secretary Lamont has decided that a certain number of them may be laid aside and purchased for the men out of the company fund.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- A dispatch from Tien-Tsin to the Central News says that part of the japanese fleet is cruising between Talien-Wan and Port Arthur and the remainder of the squadron is cruising in the Gulf of Pe-Chi-Li, giving particular attention to Wei-Hai-Wei, which they are watching closely.

There is an evident tone of menace ii the "prediction" Which Mr. Platt "vent ures," that any attempt on the part of "self-constituted committees, or am bitious busy-bodies," to forestall the work of the Lexow committee and "boss the action of the Legislature," will be "resented by Mr. Lexow and his associates and by the people generally."

Society welcomed the opera last night as a pleasing divertissement after the fatigue attendant upon the Horse Show. The opera is a most popular entertainment to which the hearts of social leaders will always remain true.
The Seventy's Committee on Legislation is hard at worn preparing measures to send to Albany.
A meeting of Good Government Club A of Brooklyn was held last evening at 189 Seventh Avenue, in that city. M.E. Moore, the President of the club, presided.

Although the Montauk Wheelmen "rooters" shouted, "Good eye! "until they were red in the face least evening, their united efforts went for naught in their bowling team's games with the Atalanta Wheelmen of Newark. The contests took place on the Acme Alleys, corner of Ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, and every time a Montauk warrior sent a sphere whizzing down the alleys their enthusiastic followers uttered their unearthly yell, "Good eye!"

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 19 -- This was a sort of gamblers' field day in the Court of General Sessions. The first prisoner arraigned was Georsre Storey, who was arrested June 9 for running a poker game at 62 Newark Avenue. The complaint was made by Detective Christie and William Ramsey, who were employed by the Rev. John L. Scudder.

-- Mrs. Ann A. Foley, the widow of Thomas F. Foley, who died on May 16 last from injuries received by falling down the elevator shaft in the Windsor flats, then in course of erection at 1,700 Broadway, has a suit pending in the Supreme Court against Dr. Charles Phelps, one of the physicians in Bellevue Hospital, to recover $10,000 damages for performing an autopsy on the body of her husband against her protest.

Seventy-five graduates of Cornell College met last night at 170 West Thirty-fourth Street. It is proposed that hereafter informal meetings be held on the first and third Mondays of each month at the above address. The object is to bring together as many Cornell men in this city as possible, that they may keep up the friendships of college days and keep in touch with their alma mater.

Some unpleasant and uncomplimentary remarks were addressed yesterday by Miss Rebecca Fream to Justice Feitner in the Essex Market Police Court, where the Justice was sitting on the bench holding court.

The tugboat A. T. Kapella of Jersey City caught fire mysteriously while on Long Island Sound, opposite Caswell's Point, early yesterday morning, and was destroyed. The crew cannot be found, and are supposed to have made their escape in their boat. A policeman of the Morrisania Police Station first discovered the burning tug.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Notwithstanding all that has been said of the intention of the New-York bankers to supply out of bank stocks a large percentage of the gold required for floating the new issue of bonds, the drafts upon the Treasury reserve continue, and most of the gold withdrawn is going into the vaults of NewYork banks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Secretary Herbert has received from Capt. Kempff of the Monterey a report regarding the behavior of his vessel in a storm at one of the most dangerous points on the Pacific coast. During the Monterey's recent voyage from New-Whatcom, Washington, to Astoria, Oregon, very rough weather was encountered, and the ship was compelled, to lie all night in the open Pacific off the mouth of the Columbia River.

The performance of Gounod's "Romeo et Jullette," which was chosen for the opening opera, does not call for any serious or extended comment. The members of the cast have all appeared before in the roles which they assumed last night, and consequently there it not a great deal to say about the merits of their work.
The Gould heirs will have to pay taxes of about $180,000 a year in this city on their personal property of the estate, unless the higher courts help them in the effort to escape.

Police Justice Patrick Divver, after nearly two months' absence from the bench, sat in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning. Justice Welde was in the courthouse also, but with the exception of a few minutes, during which he had a confidential talk with Justice Divver, he remained in the Justice's private room, and left just before 10 o'clock.

VIENNA, Nov. 19 -- A prolonged conference of Austrian Ministers and Deputies was held to-day to discuss the question of a coalition in regard to the proposed electoral reforms. The two sections disagreed upon the proposal of the Government to create a workinsmen's representation in Parliament.

The annual Horse Show sale of hackneys, hunters, saddle, and carriage horses, and ponies, held by W.D. Grand, was opened yesterday at Madison Square Garden. The animals offered were a good lot, and included a number of prize winners at last week's Horse Show, and this fact alone served to bring out visitors, who otherwise would not have attended the sale.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 19 -- Yearlings sold low here to-day. Twenty-four head sold by William Easton of the American Horse Exchange brought nearly $4,000. The beat of the lot were:

Keeh observers say that the practice of hard drinking is growing steadily less among intelligent, self-respecting men, who, while not posing as apostles of reform, see the folly of excess, and govern themselves accordingly. Yet the time when people can get along without an occasional stimulant is as distant as ever.

-- The receivers of the Wisconsin Central Company and the Wisconsin Railroad Company filed their reports for September in Milwaukee yesterday. The report for the former shows that the receipts were $365,835.35 and the expenditures 5350,569.79, leaving a balance of $15,265.53. The balance for August was $44,005.64.

PHILADELHIA, Nov. 19 -- The local market to-day was extremely dull and devoid of feature. The tone, however, was strong, and the final prices were the best of the day. Lehigh Valley was in good demand around 34, as was also Pennsylvania at 51 1/8. In Lehigh Navigation, a few investment orders to buy were executed at 47 7/3@48.

BOSTON, Nov. 19. -- A dispatch was received to-day from Percival Lowell, at the Lowell Observatory, Flagstaff, Arizona, stating that the canals of Mars, as observed last night, had begun to double, and that Phison and Euphrates were seen geminated.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 -- Ada Rehan, supported by Augustin Daly's company, began the closing week of her starring tour at the Olympic Theatre, in this city, to-night. The seats for this evening's performance had been practically all disposed of two weeks ago, as, indeed, had all the choice places for every night this week, and the theatre was packed to overflowing long before the orchestra took its place.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Prices of local stocks changed very little to-day, and there was almost no gossip on the situation. West End Street Railway, was strong, advancing 1/2, to 57 1/2, with the preferred up 1/2, to 84 1/2. There are rumors of an increasing short interest in this stock, but at all events, it has not yet shown itself, as far as influencing the price is concerned.

There was a great crowd of marksmen at the Seventh Regiment Armory last evening to witness the forty-third competition for the Abeel Trophy, and incidentally to assist in opening the indoor rifle shooting season of 1894-5. The Abeel Trophy, which is open to teams of ten men from each company, is one of the principal matches of the indoor season, and the number of teams unlimited.

The first severe cold wave of the season struck New-York last night. The mercury dropped to 20 above zero and the northwest wind howled around the corners at the rate of twenty-eight miles an hour. Down the bay the gale was so severe that it was impossible to board incoming steamers.

According to well-authenticated rumors in the National Guard, Governor-elect Levi P. Morton will come to New-York to-day, and before he returns to Rhinecliff this evening will announce as his staff appointments: Adjutant General -- Edwin A. McAlpin; Inspector General -- Fred C. McLewee.

Gov. Flower has developed a sudden sensitiveness about having his motives "assailed" for refusing to require the Attorney General of the State to relieve District Attorney Fellows of the burden of the prosecution of Tammany malefactors in this city, and he shows an uneasiness under criticism that is strange, considering his experience of three years past.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 19. -- Reuben F. Kolb, the defeated Populist candidate for Governor, to-day issued a lengthy address to the people of Alabama, in which he renews his charge that he was defrauded out of the Governorship in 1892, and again this year, and calls attention to the numerous protests by him and his leaders.
Several politicians met in the Mayor's office late yesterday afternoon. They all denied that their presence had any political significance.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- State Engineer Adams made known to-day a plan which he has had under contemplation for some time for doing away with the troublesome sixteen locks above Cohoes, in the Erie Canal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Miss Kate Field has been decorated by the French Government for her literary services. She has received an official communication from the French Ambassador, Mr. Patenotre, informing her that his Government has conferred upon her the "Academic Palm," instituted to recompense artists and authors.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Burglars entered the saloon of Councilman J.P. Kelly, at 33 Frank Street, early this morning, blew open the safe, and carried off about $800. There were four men in the gang, and they used so much powder that when the charge exploded the entire front of the building was blown out and a portion of the rear was also damaged.

The bears ware aggressive again yesterday, but their success was small. They directed their attack against the Grangers and Chicago Gas, but late in the day they began covering, and, under this operation, prices rallied sharply, so that practically all the early loss was wiped out. At the close the market was firm.

Members of the Musical Mutual Protective Union occupied the visitors' seats in the Common Council Chamber in the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen. Senator Daniel Bradley sat on the platform beside President Wallace.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Gottfried Bailer, forty-four years old, of Watertown, N.Y., gave himself up to the Second Precinct police Saturday, with the request that he should be examined by three competent physicians to prove that he is in his right mind. He said he escaped from an asylum in Ogdensburg, N.Y., and wanted to have his sanity established, so the authorities could not have him recommitted.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 19 -- Gideon Smith Nichols, an eccentric resident of this place, died at his home here yesterday. He was eighty-four years old. Mr. Nichols walked from New-York to Tarry town about a week ago, and caught a cold that developed into pneumonia.

WELLSVILLE, Mo., Nov. 19.--This village was the scene of a triple murder and suicide early this morning, which wiped out all but one member of a family. Thomas Portercheck, with his mother, two sisters, and a brother, occupied a small house half a mile from the business portion of the village. They were Bohemians in humble circumstances.
Josiah F. Sease of 326 East Twenty-ninth Street was committed by Police Justice Meade, in the Yorkville Court yesterday afternoon, in $1,000 bail to answer to a charge of grand larceny.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The wheat bulls had their own troubles to-day and mourned a loss of 1/2c in prices when the day's business was over. Everything started auspiciously for holders, but after that it was but little encouragement they received. Liverpool opening cables recorded an advance in that market of Id, and curb trading at this point was at a gain over Saturday of 1/2c, the regular trade beginning with the appreciation maintained.

Philip Race, sixty years old, acting Captain of the barge Katie Roche, was arrested yesterday on the barge, at the foot of West Thirty-fifth Street, by Secret Service detectives, charged with having counterfeit silver dollars in his possession. It is believed that he is connected with the gang of counterfeiters of which William Walsh, alias "Bill" Spike, is leader, which was arrested last Saturday in Jersey City.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Nov. 19. -- Through the death of Mrs. Arthur Adams the people of Patchogue have been set to figuring out the relationship of the members of her family to each other. Mr. Adams married a widow with one child, a daughter. The widow died, leaving three children by Adams, who were half brothers to the brothers to the widow's daughter.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19. -- The Grand Jury this afternoon returned true bills of indictment against Herman Mudgett, alias M. H. Holmes, who is under arrest at Boston; Jeptha D. Howe, the St. Louis lawyer, and Mrs. Carrie A. Pitzel, alias Cook, for fraudulently obtaining $10,000 insurance from the Fidelity Mutual Life Association of this city upon the death of B. F. Pitzel.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 19 -- Capt. Blake of the schooner P.T. Barnum, hailing from this port, has returned from a trip to Philadelphia with a story about the vessel being struck by a meteor.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Treasury Department will begin business to-morrow with the following classified assets and demand liabilities:

Sovereigns are a very small part o1 wealth. There are only, in Great Britain, 226 of them for every nominal 10,000 While the United Kingdom alone produces L1,300,000,000 a year, the whole world, within the same time, yields gold and silver to the amount of L38,000,000 only. We, for our share, have only one new sovereign for every nominal L325 of new riches.

The club women of New-York State made a first step toward the founding of a State federation of women's clubs at Sherry's yesterday afternoon. As guests of Sorosis, they gathered in large numbers in the big blue ballroom, and talked over women's clubs, collectively and individually.

The leaders of the Democratic machine in Kings County played a shrewd trick on James D. Bell, Chairman of the Democratic General Committee, last night, and Mr. Bell did not discover that fact until long after the meeting of the Executive Committee.

Capt. Enright of the British steamship Etona, which arrived yesterday from South American ports, says his vessel passed the derelict schooner St. John, Nov. 16. The wreck was sighted in latitude 31 degrees 50 minutes north, longitude 69 degrees 20 minutes west. The wreck, which has been reported several times, is said by Capt. Enright to be now directly in the path of vessels trading to South American and West Indian ports.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 19 -- There was a rousing meeting of prominent citizens held here to-night at the Elizabeth Wheelmen's clubhouse to take some action toward compelling the Consolidated Traction Company to live up to its agreement with the city to place a trolley road in operation by July 1, 1894, and properly repair the streets, which has not been done. Charles B. Vaughan presided, and Lawyer Frederick K. Day was Secretary.

-- The Charity Organizaton Society desires to secure employment for a man thirty years old, with excellent references, as cashier and bookkeeper. He has been out of employment twelve months, and has a large family dependent on him. Offers of employment should be addressed to Charles D. Kellogg, General Secretary, United Charities Building, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

David Gideon, the owner of fast horses, who is the partner of John Daly, and whose winnings are estimated to have surpassed those of any other houseman on the track this season, is endeavoring, in legal proceedings in the Supreme Court, to compel Philip J. Dwyer, the Brooklyn horseman, to pay him $50,000 damages for alleged slanderous remarks made on June 30 last on the club house stand of the Sheepshead Bay race course.
The Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers, continued the official count yesterday of the votes cast at the last election, completing twenty-four of the thirty city Assembly Districts.

QUARANTINE, S.I., Nov. 19. -- Eugene Haye, thirty-five years old, a steward on the steamer La Touraine, while suffering from delirium tremens, jumped through one of the port holes Into the sea and was drowned on Nov. 15.

The first "ladies' day" of the season at the Fencers Club, in West Twenty-second Street, was marked yesterday by an exceptionally large attendance. The Executive committee, which was in charge for the time being, consisted of Clarence C. Buel, T. Montgomery Roosevelt, A. Van Z. Post, J. Murray Mitchell, M. Roosevelt Schuyler, Truman Heminway, W. Scott O'Connor, and Charles Tatham.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Charles A. Anderson, an inmate of the Soldiers' Home in Kearney, N.J., claims to be the first of a series of eight husbands whom the woman now known as Mrs. Irene A.V. Redmond of Trenton has taken to herself during her forty-nine years of life. A commission was appointed at Trenton on Saturday to inquire into the woman's sanity, on the application of one of her husbands, Paul K. Redmond.

While the bells tolled and the minute guns boomed their requiem, priests chanted the sonorous Greek liturgy over the body of Czar Alexander III. in the "Fortress Cathedral," St. Petersburg. On a black covered dais, three steps above the floor of the nave, the coffin was placed. Candelabra blazing about it did little to relieve the gloom in the great church.

Roman Catholic Church circles in this city were startled yesterday, when it became rumored that the Rev. Thomas J. Ducey, pastor of St. Leo's Church, had been censured by Archbishop Corrigan for having given so much of his time to the hearings before the Lexow committee, and that he had been forbidden by the Archbishop to again attend the meetings of the committee, which are to be resumed Dec. 1.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 19. -- The Naval Small Arms Board reconvened at the torpedo station this forenoon. After listening to George Luger of Berlin, who explained his piece by the assistance of Emil B. Zathrum of Boston, acting as Interpreter, the board repaired to the range at the station, the Rose Island range being too exposed for further use this Winter.

The return of the Bostonians to New-York was cordially welcomed by a large audience at the Broadway Theatre last night. Although it is indisputable that the company is no longer the remarkably brilliant assemblage of operetta lights that it was a few seasons ago, it is still the only high-class company engaged in the production of works not built around a "star."

John Garvin, the tramp who walked into Mrs. William Astor's house, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, on Saturday night and took a nap in the room of the laundress, was rearrested yesterday afternoon on a warrant issued by Police Justice Hogan, at the request of John Jacob Astor.

A resolution was passed yesterday by the United Garment Workers of America, who are in convention in this city, to recommend to the Executive Committee that each member of the union be assessed 50 cents in behalf of the striking cloakmakers. If this suggestion is adopted, between $7,000 and $8,000 will be raised.

The Rev. Alexander Shiras. The Rev. Alexander Shiras, a retired Episcopal clergyman and a cousin of Justice Shiras of the United States Supreme Court, and of the late Gen. Shiras of the regular army, died yesterday at Clifton, Penn., after a long illness.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 20. -- The announcement in Scotland, by Sir Charles Tupper, High Commissioner, in London, that the Dominion of Canada was prepared to put the Royal Canadian Regiment of Infantry at the service of the British Government, owing to the alarming state of affairs in the East, has created considerable surprise here.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 20. -- The session of the National Convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union this morning was devoted to the hearing of reports of national organizers, at the conclusion of which the convention, contrary to expectations, proceeded to the election of officers.

One of the most remarkable trials ever held in the County Court House began yesterday. It was unusual because the plaintiff, a woman, conducted her own case, while there was araryed against her a combination of legal talent that might have tested the nerve of the most experienced lawyer at the bar.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20. -- Ex-Postmaster James S. McKean was selected to-day as receiver for the Irwin Discretionary Pool. It is believed by some that Irwin will be back this week and settle all legal claims. It is said that Irwin once made $1,000,000 with an investment of $30,000, and those for whom he made it now desire to help him out.

W. Travers Jerome, who is one of John W. Goff's associates as counsel to the Lexow committee, is wondering why it is that people of a certain class will still continue to become the dupes of "green goods" men, after all the exposures made before the committee and in the newspapers.

WOODSBURG, L. I., Nov. 20. -- Frederick Hartwell, a well-known electrician, son of Dr. John B. Hartwell of this village, had a shoulder dislocated and was badly cut in a runaway accident this afternoon. He was on his way home from Far Rockaway when his horse became frightened, jumped to one side of the road, and upset the carriage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- A claim for over $60,000 against the Government of the United States for the use of the Schillinger patent pavement in the Capitol grounds has been finally decided against the claimants in the Supreme Court. The claim has been pending in Congress and the courts for more than ten years, and the work itself was done nearly twenty years ago.

The agents of the Prince Line of steamships flung their banners to the wind yesterday, and announced that they were ready to meet all comers as competitors for the freight and passenger traffic between this country and Brazil and the Argentine Republic.

The manner in which the election news service of the United Press was appreciated on the Pacific coast is partially told in the following extracts taken from editorial notices in various California papers:

Sergt. O'Toole of the Essex Market squad and Detective Sergeant William Frinck of Police Headquarters were placed under arrest and brought before Judge Fitzgerald, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, on indictments charging them with bribery and extortion.

The annual Horse Show sale of horses of all classes, including many prize winners at the recent exhibition, held by Tattersalls at Madison Square Garden, was concluded yesterday. The lot sold yesterday did not bring as large a price as that sold on Monday, but individual prices were good, and the horses were a good-looking consignment.

Although the grain traffic, so far as the railroads are concerned, has almost come to a standstill, the west-bound freight tonnage on all lines is increasing, the country merchants showing an inclination to buy merchandise freely. The shipments of miscellaneous merchandise are so large now that they completely compensate most of the roads for the loss of the grain traffic.

The Abeel Trophy match, in which nineteen teams of ten men each are competing on the Seventh's range, was continued last evening, when six teams took part. Company B took the lead by scoring 633 points, which is six points ahead of G's Monday night record. The scores follow:

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday Mr. T. A. Kerrigan sold, at $3,450, to F.W. Keller the two-story frame dwelling 24 Dodworth Street, 25 by 91. To the Broadway Dry Goods Co-operative Building-Loan Association, he sold, at $2,600, the two-and-one-half-story frame dwelling 849 Gates Avenue, 25 by 100.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 20. -- A decision was rendered late this afternoon by Justice Adler, in the Police Court, in the bribery suit against Messrs,. Kurth and Deterling, delegates to the Constitutional Convention. The motion to dismiss the complaint is denied. Neither of the accused was in court. The case will remain open until Friday morning, and if they do not appear then their bondsmen will be prosecuted.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Nov. 20. -- By an explosion of coal dust this afternoon in the Blanche Coal Mines, near Colliers, West Va., seven miles east of Steubenville, on the Pan Handle Railroad, seven men were killed and four badly injured. Those killed were:

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Fully sixty feet of the heavy steel smokestack of the University Building, in Dearborn Street, near Madison Street, was torn from its fastenings about 11 o'clock to-day by a terrific gust of wind, and hurled westward to the roof of the building at 94 Washington Street, occupied by Handy Co., abstract and title searchers.

Ten policemen who are charged with having secured their appointment on the force without having passed the civil-service examination required by law, having been impersonated by other persons, were brought before the Police Commissioners yesterday in proceedings to test the legality of their appointment.

T.J. Murphy, a real estate agent of 189 Montague Street, Brooklyn, announced yesterday that he lost $1,800 Thursday, and that he will pay $500 for its return. He said he had not reported the matter to the police of Brooklyn because he did not think the police would be of much assistance to him.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- The market opened with a more buoyant feeling, prices were higher, and a disposition to buy was evinced, but after the first hour the speculation halted. The market became dull, and quotations receded throughout the remainder of the session, closing at the bottom. In the traction stocks, People's was the feature.

The superior advantages enjoyed by the newspapers served by the United Press over those of the papers served by the Chicago organization, styling itself the "Associated Press" were shown Monday and Tuesday in the reports of the Czar's funeral handled by the two associations. A comparison of the New-York City papers can easily be made.

The first games rolled in this city in the bowling tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs were decided last evening on the Manhattan Bicycle Club's temporary alleys at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-second Street. Opposed to the Manhattan's five were the Columbia Wheelmen's bowlers of Brooklyn. When these teams met at Bantle's alleys in Brooklyn last week they divided the honors, the Manhattans taking the first game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- A meeting of the Executive Committee of the Committee of Awards of the World's Columbian Ex- position was held to-day. There were present John Boyd Thacher of New-York, Chairman; Bradley B. Smalley of Vermont, Alfred T. Britton of the District of Columbia, and Mr. Williams of Tennessee, Secretary.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 20. -- Anton Gregor Rubinstein, the famous Russian pianist and composer, died at Peterhof, near this city, this morning. The cause of his death was heart disease.

The interesting feature at the regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday was the step taken in the fight between the Third Avenue Railway Company and the Metropolitan Traction Company to build a line on St. Nicholas Avenue and the King's Bridge Road. Until yesterday the Metropolitan was ahead.

The Excise Board will investigate, to-day, charges made against the character of Patrick Coleman's saloon at 34 Catharine Street. It may revoke his license if the statements made in the following report from Superintendent Byrnes are substantiated:

There has recently been organized in this city an association, which, it is expected, will have a large influence on the wholesale lumber trade throughout the country. It is called the National Wholesale Lumber Dealers' Association. The organization is the outgrowth of a voluntary association which has been in existence for some months, but never been legally incorporated.

Mount Morris Baptist Church, Fifth Avenue, near One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, was the scene of a pretty wedding at 8:30 o'clock last evening, when Miss Anna Roach, daughter of Walter Roach, was married to Trusten Polk Edwards, formerly of Virginia, but now of this city.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 20. -- President S.H. H. Clark of the Union Pacific has returned from an extended tour of inspection of all of the lines and branches of the Union Pacific Railway system, having been absent for something more than five weeks. He comes back to the city much improved in health and well pleased with the railway outlook, considering the condition of the last season's crops.

Yesterday's special meeting of the Directors of the Real Estate Exchange was looked to by the members and stockholders as particularly important, in view of the subjects announced for consideration and action. The results seemed to warrant the expectations and indicated a determination to make the Exchange more serviceable than it has at times been to brokers and others interested in realty.

The assumed analogy between a police force and a military force may be pushed altogether too far. There is the same need, in the two forces, for effective discipline and for undivided authority in their control, but there is no analogy in their functions, and a military system is not applicable to the police service in its ordinary sense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- There is reason for believing that the United States has received a reply to the note of inquiry sent to Japan and China, at the request of China, to ascertain the disposition of the combatants to accept an offer of mediation, and that the Japanese reply is not favorable to accepting the offer at this time.

BUDA-PESTH, Nov. 20. -- The continuance of the Wekerle Ministry is greatly jeopardized, owing to its tolerance of the agitation, of the Extreme Left in behalf of Kossuth's son. It is feared that Emperor Francis Joseph will not sanction the ecclesiastical laws, seeing that the Ministry is doing nothing to repress Kossuth.

A man's outfit of clothing, except a shirt and underclothing, awaits an owner, supposed to be John E. Castle, at the West Thirty-seventh Street Station House. It was found in front of Henry S. Dirkes's house, at 319 West Thirty-first Street, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, when the thermometer was below freezing point.

We predicted a short time before the election that if the vote should be favorable to municipal construction of rapidtransit roads the Manhattan Company would be stimulated to efforts to improve its service, which nothing but the prospect of effective competition would induce it to do.

-- The New-York Universalist Sunday School Institute will hold an afternoon and evening session at the Church of the Divine Paternity next Friday. Miss Cornelia T. Bradford will give an address in the afternoon on "The Whittier House" and the Rev. Robert Collyer in the evening on "The Church and the Children."

At the meeting of the Board of RapidTransit Commissioners yesterday Commissioners Orr, Low, Claflin, Steinway, and Inman were present, and Messrs. Beekman and Boardman of counsel, Mr. Parsons, chief engineer, and Mr. Delafield, Secretary, were in attendance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Bureau of Navigation's tables show that on June 30, 1894, the documented merchant marine of the United States comprised 23,386 vessels, of 4,684,029 gross tons, distributed geographically as follows:

Seven shipwrecked mariners reached this port yesterday on board a rescuing craft and told an exciting yarn about their vessel having been hove on her beam ends by an easterly blast and righted again by an outfly from the west.
BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- The will of Anna Cabot Lowell, filed, to-day, gives over $27,000 to public institutions, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Nearly one-half of the amount necessary to pay the first installment on the proposed issue of bonds has been withdrawn from the gold reserve since Secretary Carlisle's circular was issued. According to this circular bidders whose proposals are accepted will be required to pay 20 per cent, in gold coin or gold certificates upon the amounts of their bids as soon as they receive notice of the acceptance of such bids.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 20. -- The Naval Small-Arms Board continued its work with the Luger gun this morning. The disassembly and assembly test was the first in order. The expert performed the two acts in 1.28 minutes and 2.48 1/2 minutes. The non-expert required 2 minutes 59 seconds and 3 minutes 51 seconds for like work.

A big six-story brick store house at Benson and Leonard Streets, belonging to E.S. Jaffray Co., the dry goods firm, was destroyed by fire last night, and for nearly an hour the main building of the firm at Broadway and Leonard Street, and several valuable buildings surrounding it were in immil nent danger of destruction.

-- Archibald Maclean died Monday evening after a lingering illness, at his home in Princeton. Mr. Maclean was graduated at the College of New-Jersey with high honors, and was a prominent lawyer in New-York and New-Orleans for several years. His father was a professor in the college from 1795 to 1812.

Capt. McNamara of the Prospect Park police squad, at the suggestion of Brooklyn's Park Commissioner, Frank Squier, caused the wheelmen passing down the Coney Island Boulevard to be counted on the first two Sundays of the present month. This was done to enable a better idea to be formed of the use to which the cycle path now in course of construction will be put when completed.

Fourteen of the Trustees of the College of the City of New-York met in regular meeting in the Board of Education Hall yesterday. Chairman Charles H. Knox presided. The following tutors were, on recommendation of the Executive Committee, promoted to be instructors:

The Franklin National Bank caused the arrest of Stephen A. Dutton in an action brought against him in the Supreme Court to recover $1,001.25. The order of arrest was granted by Justice Truax, and bail was fixed in $1,250.

George Roeschman, who says he is employed in Hardy, Voorhies Co.'s lumber yard, in Grand Street, Williamsburg, near Newtown Creek, as a watchman, called at the Stagg Street Police Station yesterdaymorning and told a story which, if true, shows that that section of the city is a dangerous place at night and throws light on a number of mysterious things that have recently occurred in that vicinity.

Isidor Schaup, a weazened little man about fifty years old, appeared before Police Justice Divver, in the Morrisania Police Court, yesterday, against his wife, Margaret, whom he charged with having beaten him. When the Clerk called Schaup's name the little man stepped before the Justice, glancing nervously about him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The audience that assembled this afternoon in Metzerott Hall to listen to Mr. Joseph Jefferson's lecture upon "Dramatic Art" was one of the most distinguished that could be gathered at the national capital. Long before the hour for beginning every seat was occupied with representatives of political and fashionable circles, artists, and artisans, clergymen of different denominations, literateurs, and men of science invited by the Art Students' League.
The memory of John Jay was honored by a memorial service under the auspices of the Evangelical Alliance for the United States, given, last night in the concert hall of the Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO,Nov. 20. -- Holders of wheat had even less courage to-day than yesterday. The shorts, with recollections of last week's strength, were timid and not disposed to press offerings very hard. This uncertainty on both sides resulted in inactivity and comparative quiet. The odds, however, were in favor of lower prices, and a net loss of 3/8c for the day was made.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent. throughout the day.

The character of the stock market continued to be almost wholly professional. There were few customers in the offices of brokers and out-of-town commission orders were few and far between. The board-room traders were responsible for the fluctuations yesterday.

We are now beginning to find in the medical journals elaborate reports concerning the use of antitoxine for diphtheria in American hospital practice, and I although the number of cases so treated in this country has been comparatively small thus far, the results appear to be in accord with those exhibited by the impressive statistics concerning the new treatment in Paris and Berlin.

BARCELONA, Nov. 20. -- The Governor of the prison went this afternoon to the cell of Salvador Franch, the chief conspirator in the Lyceum Theatre outrage, and read to him his death warrant. Some time ago Franch declared his penitence and was admitted to a monastic order. Later he became as blasphemous as ever.

-- There should be some lively cycle racing on Thanksgiving Day at Jamaica, L.I. Three events have been arranged by Frank Tatum to take place on the road, and in each fast work is looked for. The eight-mile event for boys under fifteen years of age will probably have a large number of entries, and so will the twenty-five-mile handicap.

SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- Coroner Apgar held, an inquest this afternoon into the tragedy at Croton Dam, in which William Sheehan was shot and killed by his sister Margaret, as was told in The New-York Times of this morning. John Sheehan, the father, said his son and daughter quarreled on many occasions.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The funeral of the Rev. Dr. James McCosh, ex-President of Princeton University, was held at Princeton this afternoon. All departments of the university participated in the ceremonies and services, and many other educational institutions had representatives present.

The entries for the international bicycle races at Madison Square Garden next week came in in such large numbers yesterday at Manager Sheehan's office, 5 Vanderbilt Avenue, that it will probably be a day or two yet before the list is announced. No indoor tournament ever held in this country has had so many prominent riders on the list of attractions as this one.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- When anything out of the ordinary routine occurs at the White House, all sorts of rumors are usually set afloat in Washington, and there was no exception to-day when the President failed to drive in town from his country place, and disappointed the Secretaries of the departments, who went to the Executive Mansion at 11 o'clock to attend the regular Tuesday Cabinet meeting.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20. -- The official closing quotations for mining stocks to-day were as follows:

The American Wool and Cotton Reporter says in a recent issue, with reference to the changes in the tariff to be made on Jan. 1: "Our observations lead us to believe that, so far as prices are concerned in all the ordinary grades of woolen goods, the domestic manufacturer has absolutely nothing to fear from foreign competition."
LONDON, Nov. 20. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Shanghai says that severe fighting is reported to have taken place at Port Arthur on Nov. 15, the Japa- nese having massed their troops there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Assistant Secretary Hamlin, as a result of his visit to the seal islands, has recommended that no seals be killed next season, and so informed Gen. Jeffries, the attorney resident of the North American Commercial Company, lessee of the seal islands from the United States, at a conference held to-day at the Treasury Department.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 20. -- For a total of $7,670 William Easton sold forty head of thoroughbred brood mares and yearlings here to-day. The sale was closed with good attendance, spirited bidding, and fair prices for well-bred dams. Best prices follow:

Mayor Schieren and the leaders of the Brooklyn Law Enforcement Society are at odds over the Mayor's policy of permitting the "side-door" liquor traffic on Sundays. The Rev. A.C. Dixon, Chairman of the society's Executive Committee, declared yesterday that the society would take steps to compel Mayor Schieren and Police Commissioner Welles to perform their duty and close saloons on Sundays.

Mrs. Philomana Barona, an Italian, aged twenty years, who lives at 180 Prince Street with her husband, was arraigned yesterday before Justice Hogan in the Jefferson Market Police Court, on the charge of being a party to the theft of a pocketbook. containing $60, from Mrs. Francisco Amelio. The prisoner carried a twenty-months-old baby in her arms, who, in a curious way, was involved in the theft.

The people of New-York do not seem to realize how much power and responsibility the law puts in the hands of the Police Justices or to what an extent these officials control the personal liberty of citizens.

No gold-holding bank has yet taken gold for its own use from the Sub-Treasury for the purchase of new bonds. There was withdrawn, yesterday, $1,250,000, but in every instance the applicants said the money was needed for customers who could not get gold in any other way. This was self-evident in the case of Mayor-elect Strong's bank, the Central National, which called for $500,000 yesterday, having previously taken $500,000.

It is possible, of course, to make too much of the notions and intentions even of a new Czar. Theoretically the new Czar is omnipotent, and can do anything he chooses, even to bestowing upon the Russian people by ukase a complete system of constitutional government, by which his own omnipotence is limited, and which shall subsist until he chooses to overthrow it.

The Kings County Wheelmen and the Liberty Bicycle Club played their first tournament bowling games last night on the Town Hall alleys. Bedford Avenue and Halsey Street, Brooklyn. The first game was close all the way through, with the Libertys leading from the second frame to the end of the eighth by a slight margin, the game finally gaing to Kings County by five points.
-- Mark Fagin was convicted of manslaughter in the first degree yesterday, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, for killing John Woods, He will be sentenced on Friday.

District Attorney Fellows has consented to join with the Seventy in asking Gov. Flower to require the Attorney General, in person or by deputy, to take charge of proposed proceedings against violators of the election laws in this county and proceedings involving the misconduct of public officers.
Hundreds of New-York's substantial business men joined in the annual festival of the Chamber of Commerce last night.
The New-York State Federation of Woman's Clubs is an established fact.

Prince Ruspoli visited Eliis Island yesterday, escorted by Baron Fava, the Italian Minister to the United State. The visitors, who were received by Commissioner Senner, expressed themselves as being very much interested in the operation of the immigration Bureau.

With Plymouth Church as the starting point, an important movement in furtherance of continued and permanent good government in Brooklyn was inaugurated there last night, which is to spread throughout all parts of that city. It is non-sectarian, and is closely akin to that which has been so successfully projected and carried forward in New-York under the auspices of the Good Government Clubs.

The police of the Fifth Street Station reported another suicide yesterday in the "House of Suicides," which is the title given to a ramshackle barracks at 14 First Street, because there have been a number of suicides in the building. Respondent beings have ended their lives there by almost every conceivable means.

James Hood Wright of Drexel, Morgan Co., who died suddenly of heart disease last week at the Rector Street elevated station, left an estate valued roughly at $20,000,000. His will was filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's office. By the terms of this document no direct bequests are made to charitable or public institutions.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- The committee of the Chamber of Deputies to which the matter was referred has made a report acceding to the demands of the Government for a credit and legislative sanction to the French expedition against Madagascar.

Mayor Schieren announced yesterday that he would veto the resolution or ordinance adopted by the Brooklyn Aldermen Monday prohibiting wandering minstrels from singing or playing in the streets of Brooklyn.

-- The seventh annual report of the West End Street Railway Company, in Boston, issued yesterday, shows the gross earnings to Sept. 30 to have been $6,823,879, an increase of $131,301, while the net earnings decreased $125,047, to $2,016,795. The balance after charges is $1,291,731, a decrease of $160,323, and the surplus, after dividends, including 1 1/2 per cent., paid Oct. 1, is $98,356, a decrease of $24,058.

BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- The first meeting and banquet of the season of the New-England Tariff Reform League was held this evening at the Copley Square Hotel. The object of the dinner was to consider the adoption of amendments to the constitution, changing the name of the organization to the New-England Free Trade League, and so revising the articles as to make the following statement of the league's object:
BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- One thousand dollars was paid to-day for a pocket Bible of sixteen pages, and $800 for the first English Bible printed.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Nov. 20. -- Burglars forced an entrance into the Post Office here about 3 o'clock this morning. They blew open the safe with dynamite, and escaped with money and stamps to the amount of $150, and a package of letters containing money and checks that will, it is expected, bring the loss up to $1,000.

Gen. Nelson A. Miles, the successor of Gen. O.O. Howard as Commander of the Department of the East, arrived in town yesterday and is stopping at the Holland House. In his party are Mrs. Miles, Miss Miles, Sherman Miles, and Capt. Marion P. Maus of his personal staff.

Company F's team surpassed their own unbeaten record of 648 points last evening by scoring 649 points in the Abeel Trophy match on the Seventh Regiment's range, and will now hold that trophy for another three months, subject to challenge. Company H's team also shot well, scoring 644 points.

Judge Cowing recently received a letter bearing on the case of Mrs. Caroline Uhlig of 2,164 Seventh Avenue, who several years ago charged Frank E. Smith, a builder, with having defrauded her out of $2,500 by selling her a house incumbered with mortgages to the amount of $90,000 which he represented to be free and clear.

St. Louis, Nov. 21 -- John Scherpe, President of the Enterprise Brick Company and ex-member of the Iron firm of Scherpe Koken, committed suicide in his office this morning by shooting himself in the head. Scherpe was arrested some time ago on complaint of his wife, who claimed he was demented.

The following is a list of the best bicycle records made in the United States during the season just closed, and a few made in 1892 and 1893 that were not bettered. The number of these is very small, as nearly every record for distance or time had to go with the improved bicycles and more careful training of contestants.

HOG PRODUCTS keep on the downward move, and they close unsettled and much disturbed by another large receipt of hogs, with full estimates of near future supplies, and from the declining grain markets. It is almost impossible to do business with importers with the current weakness as to prices, as they are all inclined to hold off for bottom or until there is more regularity to the situation.

A guessing match has been in progress for several weeks by real estate brokers and speculators and by certain classes of business men with regard to purchases of property made by Frederick Southack Co. on Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

The nineteenth annual fair of the Brooklyn Orphan Asylum was begun yesterday in the Academy of Music. The large building was crowded. The little orphans, in their neat suits and smiling faces, were on hand, and, as usual, gave an exhibition military drill in an excellent manner. The fair will continue until Saturday night.

Gen. Nelson A. Miles, formerly Commander of the Department of the Missouri and recently appointed by President Cleveland to succeed Gen. Oliver Otis Howard, retired, as Commander of the Department of the East, yesterday morning paid his first visit to Governors Island since Gen. Hancock's death some years ago.

The members of the Bushwick Democratic Club of Brooklyn, are indignant over the disgraceful actions of several of the younger members of that organization on election night. The club is composed of respectable and influential Democrats of the Eastern District of the City of Churches. S.S. Whitehouse, Chairman of the old Democratic General Committee, was formerly President of the club, and County Auditor Keller is one of the members.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 21 -- The Canadian cruiser Petrel arrived at Windsor this morning, having on board 102 American fishing nets, claimed to have been seized in Canadian waters, near Middle Island, last Saturday. Capt. Dunn has not received instructions from Ottawa how to dispose of them.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The Consolidated Traction Company intrusted $1,546 to Thomas White of Jersey City to-day, with which to pay off men on the electric car track construction gangs, and a few hours afterward White reported that the money was gone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- While Secretary Gresham declines at present to give out the text of the reply received from Minister Dun, the United States representative at Tokio, the nature of that reply has been distinctly known to Washington for several days, and has been plainly foreshadowed in United Press dispatches.
LEONIA, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Leonia held a borough election to-day, and decided against incorporation by a vote of 64 to 9.
ALBANY, Nov. 21--Gov. Flower issued the following to-day:

WHITE PLAINS, N.T., Nov. 21 -- Periodically the people of this vicinity are treated to stories in the newspapers of the appearance of wild animals of different kinds, causing destruction in the outskirts of some of the hamlets in this town, or near by. A few years ago a panther was described as frightening the farmers and killing live stock but when investigated, the story proved a hoax.

Readers of Mr. Stevenson's "Rajah's Diamond" will not have forgotten the "Story of the Young Man in Holy Orders," who was so overcome by the sight of the jewel in question that he tried to steal it out of the adjoining compartment on a railway train. The delightful extravagance of the story teller's imagination has been exceeded by a young clergyman whose abode is in or near Buffalo.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 21 -- James J. Van Alen, the well-known Newport cottager, is about to purchase a building site in Bristol, R.I., next to the residence of the late Senator Joshua Wilbor, on Hope Street. It is a charming location, and Mr. Van Alen expects to have a Summer residence erected there.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- Attorney General Hancock to-day wrote the following reply to Gov. Flower's communication requesting an opinion as to whether or not any State official has authority to allow an attempt at resuscitation of a convict after being electrocuted:

The first steps toward reorganizing the "reorganized" Democracy of Kings County, of which James D. Bell is Chairman, were taken Tuesday night by about fifty members of the organization. They met in the Clarendon Hotel, Brooklyn, and formed a club, the purpose of which is to effect a change in the methods which have heretofore prevailed in that body.
The City of Brooklyn has acquired during the last ten years a considerable amount of real estate for which it has no use. The property hag been acquired through the Arrearage act.

Owing to the absence of the court stenographer at Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday the case of Mrs. William Astor versus Garvin, the tired tramp was deferred until this morning. The crowd of sightseers was disappointed in not catching a glimpse of Mr. Astor, who was represented by his butler, Thomas Hade, on whose testimony the second warrant was issued.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Orders were issued last week by the Navy Department directing a court-martial to meet at the Washington Navy Yard to try Commander F.R. Smith, retired, for "scandalous conduct," and "disobedience of the orders of the Secretary of the Navy."

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The Pall Mall Gazette severely arraigns Sir Charles Tupper, Canadian High Commissioner, in connection with the recent election in Forfarshire, Scotland. The paper particularly blames him in that, while he was in Dundee during the election contest, he took occasion to attack violently the Ministry of Agriculture on account of the Government's restrictions upon Canadian cattle.

As the time approaches when bids for the new Government bonds must be forwarded to Washington, the topic is uppermost in the financial district. Every bank and banking house is getting letters by every mail from correspondents and customers who wish to make original subscriptions. Wherever banking men meet they talk over what they can do to secure some of the bonds.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Nov. 21 -- Benton T. Lyman came here from Chicago last February and placed on record a deed from a person named Bond to Lyman for 100 feet front on Rush and Second Streets. Bond got title by deed from Minnie R. Williams, executed before a notary whose name was said to be Holmes. On this property Lyman began the erection of a threestory stone building.

"Old men for counsel, young men for action" is a safe enough rule if, before acting, the young men will take counsel of the old men. The Good Government Club young men who have brought charges against District Attorney Fellows appear to have disregarded this essential condition.

-- The drum corps of Grammar School No. 66 of King's Bridge will give an exhibition drill at the Flower Show, at the Grand Central Palace, Saturday evening. The Flower Show is attracting as many visitors as ever, and every visit gives the promenader an additional surprise. The Pan-American exhibit in the Mexican section shows a collection of manufactured articles.

Among the passengers on the Rhaetia, which got up to Quarantine last night after a tussle with head seas and strong winds all the way from Hamburg, which she left Nov. 7, were Dr. Emil Halub and his wife, Dr. Rosa Halub.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- The fact has leaked out to-night that the Manning interest in The Albany Argus has passed from the hands of its former holders. It consisted of two-thirds of the capital, and was held by James H. Manning, his brother-in-law, John A. Delehanty; Frederick C. Manning, and Daniel S. Lamont.

The completion of the Tehuantepec Railroad is announced. It will connect the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans, by way of the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, a distance of 130 miles, the Isthmus of Tehuantepec being in the southern part of Mexico, adjoining Guatemala. The new railroad passes through several important cities, such as Tehuantepec and Manititlau, as well as pueblos or towns.
Three candidates for the Speakership were in this city yesterday. They were Mr. Malby, Mr. Fish, and Mr. Ainsworth. Each claimed to have from thirty to fifty votes "pledged."

The Princetons made their final appearance in public before their game with Yale by playing against the eleven of the Orange Athletic Club on Orange Oval yesterday afternoon. They won by a score of 16 to 4. Orange made a touch-down, which must be credited to the wet ball and ground rather than to good playing.
"Religious Toleration" was the subject of a lecture delivered by George Parsons Lathrop in the Madison Square Concert Hall last night, under the auspices of the Catholic Club.

The New-York Times published an article yesterday showing what immense power the Police Justices posses over the personal liberty of the citizens of New-York, and how little the extent of this great and arbitrary authority and its capacity for evil and oppression is appreciated by the people.

Contracts were unusually active and higher, with the early trading giving but poor promise of an advance, as Liverpool made but a slight gain, and the drift of the room was to lower prices. The late trading was exciting, owing to a heavy rush of outside buying orders, and prices advanced rapidly and closed very steady at 9@11 points' gain. Spot were quiet at 1-16c advance, with sales of 61 bales to spinners.

The Brooklyn Bicycle Club gave its first "stag" of the season last night, and the clubhouse, at 80 Hanson Place, was crowded by the members and their friends. W.J. Kenmore, William J. McCahill and C.G. Balmanno, the Entertainment Committee, provided a capital programme, which was begun about 9 o'clock. Wally Edgley started the programme and played several popular tunes on the piano.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 21 -- Notwithstanding the silence of the State Department on the Japanese note question, the opinion has prevailed here for several days that the United States had received a reply to the inquiry made at the request of China as to the willingness of that nation to accept the friendly offices of the United States to bring about a peace between China and Japan.

The meeting of the Kings County Democratic General Committee, at the Brooklyn Atheneum, Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, last night, proved to be quite lively from the beginning. James D. Bell presided. Bernard J. York, Chairman of the Executive Committee, recommended that the primaries for the election of delegates to the General Committee and district offices be held on Tuesday evening, Dec. 11.
With navigation blocked by the densest fog that the oldest boatmen have konwn in many years, it was very difficult to obtain transportation across the river last night.
-- Commander T.A. Lyon has been detached from the New-York Navy Yard, a sick leave for six months having been granted him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- In speculations concerning the organization of the next House of Representatives by the Republicans, outside of the almost universal acceptance of Mr. Reed as the inevitable speaker, the only place that has suggested candidates is that of Clerk of the House. Two names have been heard for several days, the first being that of Thomas H. McKee, the acting Secretary of the Republican Congressional Committee.

The Board of Aldermen, sitting as a Board of Election Canvassers, yesterday finished the official count of the votes cast in the late election. No further changes in the announced result were made by the canvass of the districts made yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 21 -- The South and West Grain Congress convened at 10 o'clock to-day, at Washington Artillery Hall, with several hundred delegates in attendance, representing all the Southern States, and Missouri, Kansas, and Iowa. The objects of the convention are to increase the grain trade between the West and the Gulf ports, and obtain better freight rates between the two sections.
Mrs. Louise Galligan's twenty-flve-thousand-dollar suit against four of the School Trustees of the Nineteenth Ward was dismissed yesterday by Justice Barrett, in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The effort for a monster gun, the largest yet built in this country, is to be renewed by the army ordnance officers this year. Gen. Flagler, the army Chief or Ordnance, will probably once more ask Congress to appropriate a sum sufficient to begin construction. This gun will be sixteen-inch calibre and will be mounted on one of the coast-defense emplacements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Recorder-elect Goff of New-York has been in Washington for a few days, and to-day submitted to be interviewed at length by a local news-paper. He gave a long and interesting history of the revolt in New-York against the corrupt practices of the police-a history told with a terseness and attractiveness that make it readable even by those who have been familiar with the investigations of the Lexow committee.

A reorganization plan has been issued by the Chicago and Northern Pacific bondholders' committee, of which J. Edward Simmons is Chairman. The plan provides for the formation of a new company under the name of the Chicago Terminal and Railway Company. This new corporation will issue stock to an amount not exceeding the amount of its bonded indebtedness, and it may be divided into common and preferred.
Admission is free and all New-York is invited.

-- "The Crust of Society." -- Here is the cast of "The Crust of Society," which Carrie Turner will present at the Fifth Avenue Theatre to-night: Oliver St. Aubyn, Edgar L. Davenport; Capt. Randall Northcote, John Flood; Cavendish Comyns, M.P., Joseph E. Whiting; the Earl of Colchester, Herbert Ayling; Mrs. Echo, Elita Proctor Otis; Violet Esmond, Carrie Radcliffe; Lady Downe, Kate Lester, and Carrie Turner as Mrs. Eastlake Chapel.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The first floor of Mangel Schmidt's bakery, at 348 to 352 Fifteenth Avenue, suddenly crashed into the cellar below at 8:35 o'clock this morning, carrying with it hundreds of barrels and bags of flour.

Winfield S. Smith of Guthrie, Oklahoma, formerly of Owego, N.Y., a man who settled on the present site of Guthrie the day that the Territory was thrown open to settlement, was asked by a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday about the state of society there.

Some Interesting facts regarding the estate of Jay Gould, its extent, and its present condition, will be brought to light if an ex parte order to show cause, granted yesterday, is sustained on a hearing set down for to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Alley "L" was again the centre of interest on the Stock Exchange to-day. The market in the early dealings scored a sharp advance over the closing prices last night, but the improvement was based almost entirely on the covering of one or two big short lines which had been put out on the down turn yesterday.

The Castle Point Cyclers bowled on their home alleys in Quartet Hall, Washington Street, Hoboken, last evening for the first time since the beginning of the bowling tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs. The Pointers' team of five had as opponents the bowling team of the Brooklyn Bicycle Club, one of the strongest in the league.
Police Justice -- Joseph M. Deuel, Republican, to succeed Solon B. Smith, Republican; term extends to Jan. 7, 1903, under present law; salary, $8,000 per year.

The official publication of the facts respecting the tender through the State Department of the good offices of the United States to reconcile the contending powers in the East has been in substance anticipated by the Washington dispatches of this journal. It appears that, as in Mr. Gilbert's libretto, we are right and they are right and everything is quite correct.

Mrs. Ida Simons, who lives with her husband, a chorus singer, at 323 West Twenty-ninth Street, appeared before Justice Hogan in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday as complainant against Mrs. Johanna Wild of 388 Eighth Avenue, who she claimed had entered her room while she was living at 323 West Twenty-fourth Street, and taken all her clothing.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.)

Police Captain Ennis of the Stagg Street Precinct, Brooklyn, does not give any credence to the story told by John Roeschman, to the effect that he was robbed near the Grand Street bridge, over Newtown Creek, on the night of Nov. 9, and afterward thrown into the creek by four men, who first put a bag over his head.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The Peekskill Military Academy defeated Holbrook's School of Sing Sing at football to-day at Sing Sing by the score of 32 to 0.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21 -- A quintet of bowlers from the Atlanta Wheelmen to-night rolled two games in the tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs with the Columbia Wheelmen's five of Brooklyn at Montgomery's Alleys on Clinton Street. The alleys were thronged with the friends of both sides, and big scores were liberally applauded.

PARIS, Nov. 21 Several of this morning's papers publish an interview with a Soudan explorer, in which he declares that the Tuareg tribe holds four European prisoners, one of them being Col. Flutters, who was reported to have been murdered in February, 1881, while surveying the route for the projected Central Soudan Railway from Algeria.

It was Thursday, and the second mail day of the week at Hop Meadow Village. All the leading citizens and most of the dogs were gathered at the Post Office, waiting for Aaron Damon to arrive from Bountiful with the mail. Presently they saw his buckboard through the trees, descending the slope; then, watched it straight across the wide meadow to which the place was indebted for his name, and then he drove up.
The New-York and Texas steamship Alamo, which arrived from Galveston yesterday afternoon, was sunk at Pier 20, East River, this morning, to extinguish a fire in the cotton in her hold.

Whatever may be thought of Commissioner Starin's other suggestions on the subject of underground rapid-transit roads, most people will agree with him that they ought to provide for the local transportation of freight. With a fourtrack road of proper construction, two of the tracks could be used after a certain hour at night for carrying a great variety of freight.
The Board of Education met yesterday afternoon, with President Charles H. Knox in the chair, and considered in executive session the nominations for School Trustees.
The money market continued easy. Call loans were made at 1 per cent, throughout the day.
Adolph Rothmuller and his wife Clementine were arrested at their home, 5 West One Hundred and Sixth Street, yesterday on a bench warrant issued by Judge Hudspeth of Weehawken.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Smoking is a necessity. At least that is the logic of the Town Council's last action.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 21 -- The State Board of Canvassers, consisting of State Secretary Phelan, Treasurer Sanger, and Controller Staub, met at the Capitol this afternoon and canvassed the records of the votes cast at the State election. They made the official count of the vote as follows:

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Borough Clerk Alexis McNulty of Rutherford disappeared Sept. 12. Apparent shortages amounting to $541 were found in his borough accounts, and it was charged that certain insurance companies had lost money through McNulty's acting as their agent. A successor to the missing man was appointed, and a suit was begun against his estate on behalf of the borough.
