WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- Mayor-elect James B. Wise has been made the defendant in a suit brought by George B. Holbrook for $10,000 for alleged alienation of the affections of Holbrook's wife, who was employed by Wise as stenographer and typewriter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The leading officials of the State and Navy Departments declined at first to confirm or deny the accuracy of the cable dispatch from Minister Denby, dated Thanksgiving Day, stating that "chaos reigns in Pekin; the American Legation in danger; need protection." But this failure to give explicit information created no surprise in view of the reticence invariably maintained in matters of such a grave and delicate nature.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 1. -- The big British steamship Maroa, Capt. Adams, sailed this morning for Havre, from New-Orleans, with the largest single cargo of cotton that has ever left the City of New-Orleans, or any other city for that matter.

Rockford, Ill., Dec. 1 -- Commander in Chief Lawler of the Grand Army of the Republic has called a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Council of Administration at Louisville, Dec. 18, to arrange for the next National Encampment.

Annie J. Squire, twenty-eight years old, of 237 Flatbush Avenue, and Mary McGovern, thirty-two years old, of 1,320 Herkimer street, Brooklyn, were arrested yesterday afternoon, on the charge of shoplifting. They were caught in Journeay Burnham's dry goods store in Flatbush Avenue, and when arrested had in their possession goods sufficient for two dresses valued at $18.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The State Department finds Mr. Ralph's last statement about the surrendered and executed Japanese in Shanghai to be stronger justification than it could have hoped for of the correctness of the course of our Government in deciding that the men must be yielded to the Chinese and that they submit to trial under Chinese law.

The pheasants which formed the subjects of the following observations were hatched out in an incubator from eggs kindly given me by Sir Cecil Miles. The eggs were taken from the hen and transferred to the mcubator a few days before the young birds were due to emerge.

Shortly after 2 o'clock the sturdy youths from Yale were seen emerging from their dressing room, and their appearance on the field was the signal for an outburst of enthusiasm. First came Capt. Hinkey, the silent man from Tonawanda, and he was followed in short order by Stillman, Murphy, Beard, Thorne, Butterworth, and the other regular players and substitutes.
Ward McAllister is jubilant over the coming season in society, which he declares will begin with the first meeting of the Patriarchs on Dec. 10.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Fifty-third Congress will be back here in Washington before this reaches the eyes of the readers of The New-York Times, and on Monday it will meet to begin the short three months' session that will end on March 3.

Senator Daniel Bradley has been for some time anxious to have a Senatorial committee visit Brooklyn and investigate the affairs of the city and of its officials. Now appears Senator Henry Wolfert with a proposition somewhat similar to that of Senator Bradley.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- There has been, there will be, no end of governmental solicitation about the national grief of France. It is as sincere as it is general. During long dreary days the nation watches, hoping against hope. Russia is far off, but the Czar was near to the heart of France. Nobody knows or cares anything about the laws or the customs of the friendly country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Brazilian Minister and Mme. Mendonsa gave a delightful musicale to-night, which was the first of a series of six which will take place during the Winter.
HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 1 -- The British steamer City of Lincoln, from Antwerp for Boston, has reached here.

LONDON, Dec. 1, [Copyright 1894.] -- Notwithstanding the fact that the outward movement of gold has been kept up with tolerable regularity during the week, the stock is not reduced to a point which would affect the financial situation unfavorably. There is a well-marked scarcity of bills, and difficulty is experienced in maintaining stiff rates of discount.

An application was made before Justice Gaynor in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, for a temporary injunction, restraining City Works Commissioner Sharkey of Long Island City from interfering with the Long Island City and Newtown Railroad Company in its attempt to relay the tracks on Borden Avenue, near Vernon Avenue.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 1. -- The first day of December has come and gone in Alabama's capital, and all has been as quiet, peaceful, and orderly as upon any previous inauguration day in its history. Col. W.C. Oates has been duly installed as Governor, and not a blow has been struck, not a gun fired, nor a drop of blood spilled, notwithstanding all the wild vaporings that have been attributed to the Populists.

Woonsocket, R.I., Dec. 1. -- The old Timothy Hopkins shoddy mill, operated by the Laurel Hill Woolen Company and owned by Frank and Olney T. Inman, at Laurel Hill, Burrillville, was burned to-day. Loss, including contents, $10,000; no insurance.

From The Sioux City (Iowa) Tribune. One of the questions likely to create some contention at Pierre the coming Winter is the removal of the capital. The Huron people appear to think the present an opportune time to spring the question, as the capital city has made little or no progress since it became the seat of government, and the train service to and from it is very limited.

The burlesque, "Our Boys up to Date," will be presented by the sophomore class at Berkeley Lyceum, Dec. 17 and 18. The Glee, Mandolin, and Banjo Clubs will be worked in, and several new songs have been especially prepared for the occasion. P.A. Bates is the manager.

The Catholic temperance societies of this city met last night in St. Brigid's Church, in Avenue B, to prepare for the convention of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America, which is to be held here next August.

American writers of books were among the most earnest advocates of international copyright. We never saw any indication that their advocacy was prompted by self-interest. Most of them followed Mr. Lowell's example in resting the argument on common honesty. Some of them may have hoped, under copyright protection, to tempt the English reader.

If the Government loan, with all the success which marked its issue, had come at any other time, it might have had a much more beneficial effect on stock values. But a flood of bear news developed in the beginning of the week, and more than offset the good effect of the re-establishment of the Treasury gold reserve.

"Rodman, if you are chilly, close the sitting-room window," were the last words spoken in life to W. Rodman Winslow by his wife in their apartment on the seventh floor of the Sevillia apartment house, 117 West Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- The speech from the throne has finally been revised, and is now in the form in which the Emperor will read it to the Deputies next Wednesday. It contains the usual declarations that Germany enjoys friendly relations with the powers, and that the aspirations of all Europe seem to point to the maintenance of peace.

To the Editor of The New-YorK Times: There has been so much said on the subject of football, and so adverse am I to newspaper discussion on this and other college sports by rival partisans, that I have hesitated about expressing my views, but I so love this game, which, when properly played, I believe to be by all odds the best game there is to-day, that I wish to offer a few suggestions.

John Burns, the noted English labor agitator, who was first sent to jail and then to Parliament, was a passenger by the Cunard steamship Etruria, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday. He was accompanied by David Holmes, a trades union leader, and John Williams Benn, whose status on this visit is described by himself as that of an escort of honor to the distinguished Socialist.
Four thousand persons crowded the Grand Central Palace Saturday night to witness an exhibition drill by pupils of Grammar School No. 87, who have formed the First Battalion of the American Guard.

Katie Conroy, thirteen years old, who lives with her widowed mother at 316 East Thirty-sixth Street, was arraigned before Justice Burke in the Harlem Police Court yesterday by Agent King of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. She was remanded in the custody of the society until Tuesday.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 2 -- United States Senator A.J. McLaurin has decided to enter the race for Governor of Mississippi. He was seen yesterday, and, in reply to the direct question, said it was his intention to run.

After a let-up of a week, in consequence of the bicycle tournament at Madison Square Garden, the Wheelmen's Bowling League will resume its scheduled games this evening. The Bushwicks are booked to meet the Manhattans on the former's alleys, and the Kings Countys to test the mettle of the Montauks at Acme Hall, Ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn.
ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The State Commissioners of Fisheries have completed their annual report for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.

Dissatisfaction over the regular nominees for offices in that flourishing cycling association the Riverside Wheelmen, has resulted in an independent ticket, with strong support. The independents have canvassed the club's membership and claim a controlling majority. The nominees on their ticket are as follows:

According to the confession of E. Austin Leitch, who, while a bookkeeper of the Manufacturers' National Bank of Williamsburg, became a defaulter for $7,800, Isaac S. Moog of 200 Graham Avenue, Brooklyn, stood in the same relation to him as did Frederick Baker to Samuel C. Seely, who helped rob the Shoe and Leather Bank of this city.

VALPARAISO, Chile, Dec. 2 -- The Esmeralda will leave Chilean waters this week, bound direct for Ecuador. The formalities have been fully completed regarding her insurance by the English Lloyds, and the inspection report by an agent of that company who accompanied the Esmeralda on her trial trip has been duly filed with his company.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- The published charges said to emanate from Yale sources that some of Pennsylvania's football team are paid professionals and are not bona-fide students regularly attending recitations and college work, were brought to the notice to-day of some of the older alumni interested in Pennsylvania's athletics.
LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 2 -- Side doors with the word "Push" on them were a delusion in this city to-day. The more the thirsty wayfarer pushed the less chance was there of his getting in.

Mayor-elect Strong has announced that he will probably make public no more selections for city offices under his administration until Jan. 1. Meantime, he is getting his private business affairs into such condition that he may practically be relieved of all responsibility when it becomes time for him to take his seat in the City Hall.

Some of our respected Republican contemporaries are expressing great glee over the prospect of the baiting of the Democrats in the House by ex-Speaker Reed. Undoubtedly there will be a tempting field for the exercise of that distinguished humorist's well-known talents.

The body of a drowned man was found floating in the North River off the pier at the foot of West Forty-eighth Street yesterday. It was identified as that of Alfred Clausen, aged fifty years, the Captain of the schooner John Beers of Searsport, Me. The identification was made by John Hayes of 853 Tenth Avenue, a deckhand on the schooner, who stated that the Captain had been missing since 7 o'clock Saturday evening.
Burns and Holmes visited the Central Labor Union in the afternoon. When the visitors came upon the platform they were greeted with a round of cheers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Cleveland has extended an act of executive clemency to Judge Advocate General Swaim that many Republicans think ought to have been offered years ago by President Harrison. He has remitted the unexpired term of the General's suspension from the army of twelve years, and assigned him to duty in Washington.

NEWNAN, Ga., Dec. 2. -- The most horrible murder in the history of this section, and one which was intended only as a prelude to other crimes, was committed just over the Campbell County line, about twelve miles from here, late last night. An old and prominent citizen was killed, and an effort was made to kill his wife, in order that the murderer might have their two daughters at his mercy.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I desire to express my approval of your attitude in this unfortunate Turkish affair. As an American who has just returned from Constantinople, after a somewhat long visit, I feel in a position to think and speak intelligently on the subject.

The money market was somewhat firmer. On Wednesday call loans were made as high as 2 per cent.; on Friday small amounts were placed at 3 per cent. After that the rate fell back to 1 per cent., and the average for the week was about 1 1/2 per cent.

TAHLEQUAH, Indian Territory, Dec. 2. -- A notable wedding in many respects occurred in this Territory just south of the Kansas line, a few days ago. The principals were prisoners and the witnesses were outlaws. Elder Farnham, who lives four miles south of Chetopa and within a quarter of a mile of the Territory line, was visited last Thursday afternoon by three men on horseback, who asked him to accompany them to their camp.

From The Lewiston (Me.) Journal. A Maine Central conductor tells a story which shows how queer it is that it should cost a railroad less to kill a passenger in an accident than to maim one. A very inquisitive passenger one day began asking the brakeman all sorts of questions about things that he saw. The employe answered courteously and explained everything until the conversation began to weary him.
The Rev. Madison C. Peters of the Bloomingdale Church, Boulevard and West Sixty-eighth Street, in a prelude to his sermon last evening said:

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Manager Harold McCormick of the University Glee Club has completed his schedule of concerts to be given previous to the Christmas trip, which will begin Dec. 17. The club will visit Elizabeth Dec. 6, giving a concert there in the evening. On the following evening a concert will be given at Orange, after which the clubs will return to Princeton and take a rest till Dec. 12.

The Committee of Seventy is preparing a statement for publication, setting forth its position as regards the more extended and detailed reforms which it has recently decided to undertake. This statement, with the sub-committees charged with investigation of various departments in the City Government, will probably be completed by to-night or to-morrow.

BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- The explosion of a parlor oil stove and the resulting fire caused the loss of two lives in an Italian tenement house in North Square this afternoon. The fire was in the four-and-a-half-story brick tenement house at 18 North Square, and started in the office of Dr. E. Ferrara on the second floor.
The golden jubilee of the Simpson Methodist Church, Willoughby and Clermont Avenues, Brooklyn, was celebrated yesterday by a congregation which filled the church to the doors.

AURORA, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- Prof. C.T. Winchester, L.H.D., of Wesleyan University, has completed his course of lectures on the "Victorian Writers." In addition to this course, Prof. Winchester spoke Saturday evening on "Old London," and at the Sunday vesper service read a paper on "Literature as a Means of Christian Culture."

Thirty Gaiety girls and ten Gaiety men, all members of the "Gaiety Girl" Company, were vaccinated yesterday by city physicians. Then, with other members of the company, who didn't have to submit to the needle, either because they had been vaccinated recently or had had the smallpox, they went to their homes, packed their trunks, and left at 4 o'clock for Boston, with a clean bill of health.

GREENSBOROUGH, N.C., Dec. 1. -- This town of thriving business and steady habits for the first time has been the scene if a political ferment for the last three months, and the end is not yet. A.E. Holton, who was made Chairman of the Republican State Committee by Congressman Thomas Settle, at the instance of his sponsor, made this place the headquarters of the Republican machine.
The Rev. Dr. J.A.B. Wilson of the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church seems to have stirred up a hornet's nest in prosecuting the movement to drive disorderly houses out of his neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Controller of the Currency Eckels, in his annual report, which will be submitted to Congress tomorrow, says that suggestions have been received from many eminent financial sources that the whole question of a banking and currency system ought to be referred by Congress to a commission, to be created by law, appointed by the President, and clothed with proper authority.

I have the pleasure to inclose you to-day issue of the Greek newspaper, Atlantis, the leading article of which, under the title of "The Massacres in Armenia," expresses the greatest sympathy for your people, and bitterly condemns Mavroyeni Bey for the gratuitous defence of the Turkish Government, quoting at the same time the reply published in The Herald.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed a decrease in reserve of $13,806,800. The banks now hold $52,820,800 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $4,456,700, a decrease in specie of $19,531,900, an increase in legal tenders of $2,591,200, a decrease in deposits of $12,535,600, and an increase in circulation of $9,600.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The Times's correspondent in Che-Foo telegraphs:

Everybody this side of Texas that has been active in the line of harness racing this season seems to have gone into Winter quarters but Monroe Salisbury. Even that indefatigable collector of record breakers has been obliged to suspend activities on this side of the continent, and to set out with his string of celebrities for California.

The Earl of Aberdeen, Governor General of Canada, accompanied by his aid, Archi-bald Majoribanks, and Secretary Hewitt, went to Brooklyn yesterday morning and attended services in Plymouth Church. Dr. Lyman Abbott is an old friend of the Earl.

The rumor that a new twelve-story hotel would soon be built at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street was confirmed yesterday by Hawk Wetherbee, the proprietors of the Windsor Hotel.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 2 -- Fire this morning did $30,000 damage in J.M. Burns's business block on North Street. The heaviest losers are: Lasch Sons, men's furnishings; F.W. Pickup Co., novelty store; Prince Walker, carpets. The latter firm loses $20,000 worth of goods; fully insured.
As a prelude to his sermon, the Rev. Howard Duffield in the First Presbyterian Church yesterday morning spoke upon the Sunday saloon question. He said:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- Advent Sunday was made memorable in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in this city this morning by the adoption of a service including all the seven points of the ritual. The day is also the ninth anniversary of the rectorate of the Rev. Father Lewis T. Wattson.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Dec. 2. -- The Fall River schooner Julia A. Warr, Capt. George D. Warr, master, was run into on Long Island Sound last night, and her bow was stove below the water's edge. She sustained a terrific shock, and that she did not go down was due to the fact that she was but three years old, and was light loaded.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- The best-known of the prizes offered by Cornell is the Woodford Prize in Oratory -- a gold medal of the value of $100, given to that member of the senior class presenting the best oration at an annual contest. The prize is almost as old as Cornell, and was founded by Gen. Stewart L. Woodford.
Postmaster Dayton favors the Classification bill. He said so yesterday afternoon at a largely-attended meeting of the Post Office Clerks' Association, held in Webster Hall.

We published yesterday the important information that the production of the serum remedy for diphtheria has been undertaken by the Board of Health, the first inoculations having been made seven weeks ago under the direction of Dr. Hermann M. Biggs, pathologist and director of the bacteriological laboratory, and Dr. William H. Park, the bacteriological diagnostician and inspector of diphtheria.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: From your editorial of this morning on the city ownership of tenements I derive the impression that the recommendations made by me have not been fully stated or entirely understood. Will you permit me, therefore, to epitomize the main points, as follows:
Vicar General John M. Farley blessed a statue of the Virgin Mary in St. Joseph's Church, Sixth Avenue and Washington Place, last night.
MANSFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 2. -- Michael D. Harter to-day talked freely about the future course of the Democratic Party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The annual report of Commissioner of Navigation Chamberlain is mainly an argument for free ships, based on maritime facts of the United States, and other nations. Only six American steamships, including the New-York and Paris, crossed the Atlantic and only seven the Pacific last year, while from New-York and Philadelphia alone thirty-three steamships, mainly new steel vessels owned by Americans, crossed regularly to Europe under foreign flags.

-- B. Johnson Barbour died at his home in Barboursyille, Orange County, Va., yesterday morning, in the seventy-sixth year of his age. He was a son of Gov. Barbour of Virginia, who was also Minister to the Court of St. James. He served in the General Assembly of Virginia, and took a deep interest in public affairs, but was more widely known as a brilliant orator and on account of his high literary attainments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A sensational paragraph was manufactured here a day or two ago about an alleged alarming dispatch from Pekin representing that Minister Denby had telegraphed to Secretary Gresham that he was in great danger, and it has been repeated with great and painful elaboration of circumstances, until there is some likelihood that it may find believers.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2. -- There is dissatisfaction among the Republicans with the slate recently adopted by the Board of Chosen Freeholders, and the selected men may be changed from the positions in which they were published in The New-York Times. The ticket as made up recognizes only Americans, whereas one of the greatest party factors is the Germans.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 2 -- Trust deeds aggregating $1,500,000 were filed here yesterday from the Consolidated Elevator Company to the Franklin Trust Company of Brooklyn. The deeds are to secure bond issues made by the Lake Superior Union Improvement and Northern Pacific Elevator Companies, all of which have been succeeded by the Consolidated Elevator Company.

Ex-State Senator J.J. Linson, whom Gov. Flower appointed to investigate charges of neglect of duty preferred against District Attorney Fellows, will begin his duties today at 11 o'clock, in the brownstone building formerly occupied by the Court of General Sessions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2. -- Apart from the athletic life of the university, there is no such stirring elements in affairs at Cambridge as the meetings and doings of the members of the various clubs. These organizations are of four classes -- political, literary, religious, and social. To the first class belong, of course, the debating clubs, the International Law Club, the Civil Service Reform Club, and the Republican Club.
"Slippers" was the suggestion that accompanied the weather indications yesterday morning, and those who had good sense and were not compelled to leave home adopted it.

It was probably without reference to the date of elections on Manhattan Island that the far-famed and widely-advertised Indian known as Tammany divided up his calendar seasons. But in the days of that noble red man, the patron saint of the worshippers at the present Fourteenth Street Wigwam, the month of December was known as "the month of frosts, the first in the Season of Snows."

Al Hayman of Manager Charles Frohman's staff has just returned from Akron, Ohio, where he went early last week to put a damper on the Thanksgiving festivities of the society people of that city. He accomplished his mission, and, incidentally, administered a sharp blow to the play pirates who have become so numerous and bold in the West.
It is the intention of the managers of the Broadway cable company to have cable cars running in Ninth Avenue by noon today.

The family of William Stair Miller of 39 Fifth Avenue was just sitting down to dinner yesterday when a blaze was discovered in one of the chimneys. The sparks flew over the fashionable Grosvenor apartment house, close by, which led to the supposition that that building had caught fire. None of the occupants of the Grosvenor knew of the fire, however, until the fire engines rumbled past.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2. -- The exterior of the new Law School building is completed, and the work on the interior is progressing rapidly. Large iron bookcases will be put in the library, as will also the fire-proof doors which open into the hallways. The interior woodwork is all ready to be put in place, but the builders have received instructions to defer this until the building is thoroughly dry.
The combination of manufacturers of steel rails has been renewed for another year. Says The Iron Age:

From The Columbus (Ohio) State Journal. Mr. E.D. Grafton, the Cincinnati artist and poet, has made a new design for the American flag that is receiving considerable attention. His plan proposes a rearrangement in the placing of the stars that under present conditions are badly crowded in the blue field. He ranges the thirteen original stars in a circle in the centre, and sets the remainder in artistic groupings around them.

No better indoor bicycle racing was ever seen than at the international tournament at Madison Square Garden last week. Experts all agree to this. Many indoor records fell, and there was very little loafing in the contests. The climax was reached on Saturday evening in a ten-mile event for professionals, when Zimmerman, unaided and alone, gained a full lap on such high-class fliers as Wheeler.
It was Yale day in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. Even the Princeton student, who was arrested for being intoxicated on Broadway, was blue.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Interviews obtained by the United Press correspondent with several of Lord Dunraven's yachting friends indicate that no challenge for the America's Cup will be sent this year. The yachtsmen object to the Cup Committee's desire to abandon the conditions of the Vigilant-Valkyrie contest.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- The Rev. John L. Seudder, pastor of the Congregational Tabernacle, this evening delivered a prelude entitled: "Is Football Degenerating?" Among other things he said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The gavels in both houses of Congress will sound at noon to-morrow, and the members will enter upon the duties of the short session, which necessarily must come to an end on March 3. There is general comment about the apathy displayed on the eve of the reassembling of Congress, and one hears predictions that no legislation of importance outside of the appropriation bills will be accomplished.

There was an exciting time, which, at one moment looked as if it would become a free fight, at a meeting of what is popularly known as the "Fifth Avenue Journeymen Tailors," in the Murray Hill Lyceum, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The news of the sale of the Chilean cruiser Esmeralda to the Ecuadorian Government has excited a great deal of comment here among foreign representatives, particularly those from Soutn America, and the transaction has also interested the officers of the navy who have known the reputation of the Esmeralda for speed and general efficiency.

The twenty-first anniversary of the organization of the Reformed Episcopal Church was commemorated with special services in the First Reformed Church, Fifty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, last night. Reports were made showing the progress of the Church since its organization, and addresses were made by Stewart L. Woodford, Theodore R. Shear, and the Rev. Mason Gallagher.

Samuel C. Seely, the fugitive defaulting bookkeeper of the National Shoe and Leather Bank, continues to elude the detectives. There is no clue to his whereabouts, but all sorts of stories have been set in motion by the small army of amateur detectives on his trail.

An author who puts into something less than 400 pases even a "brief review" of the literature of England during a period of fourteen and a half centuries has no slight task of condensation on his hands. And in this particular quality of condensation the particular history under our notice is surpassingly good.

The New-York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society held its annual meeting for the year 1894-5 last night, in the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, Bishop Potter, who presided, said, in opening the meeting:

The President has pretty successfully kept from the public knowledge the recommendations he will make to Congress as to finance and the currency. Controller Eckels, in his annual report, speaks favorably of the plan of appointing a commission "to devise a currency system sound in every part, and one which would commend itself to every interest of the country."

The Rev. Joseph Silverman yesterday declared that Judaism was a philosophy and not a system of creeds. The sermon was delivered at the morning service in Temple Emanu-El, the subject being: "Why Do "We Still Remain Jews ?" He said:

-- Philip Vallance of Cob Court, Sussex, England, is probably the most extraordinary cyclist living, says The Bicycle News. Mr. Vallance is now ninety-two years of age, and still cycles energetically on a three-wheeler. He actually learned to ride an ordinary high bicycle when over eighty years of age. The story of his conversion to cycling is interesting.

From The New-York Sun of Yesterday. The Sandusky Register is an Associated Press paper, and its editor, Mr. I.F. Mack, was for years the President of the Western Associated Press. There is no one whose name in journalism stands higher than Mr. Mack's does when it is a question of integrity backed by a fair spirit and manly independence. We find the following article in his paper of the 29th ult.:

NEWPORT R.I., Dec. 2 -- It is learned here that the Herreshoffs have been approached by the representative of a syndicate in regard to the building of a cup defender. Who are the names of the syndicate cannot be learned, but C. Oliver Iselin, who managed the Vigilant, George J. Gould, present owner of the yacht, and Commodore E.D. Morgan are the prime movers.

The four volumes of which this is the first will contain the translation of what Prof. Holm calls a "short" history of Greece. The professor undertook to put into this work practically all that was in his previous writings on the same subject, and to tell in a brief, clean-cut story as much as anybody except specialists need know of Grecian history.

In the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, the Rev. William Wilkinson, who has been one of the most active workers for the relief of the victims of the Minnesota fires, yesterday recounted to his congregation the story or that great disaster.

With the approaching season when mince pie figures, its antiquity is worthy of mention. In a culinary sense it shows the older method of mixing together meats and sweets. When saffron was the main or only flavorer, spices being unobtainable, primitive man must have sweetened his meat with honey.

The sugar refineries in Brooklyn that are controlled by the Sugar Trust, and which were closed last Wednesday with the statement that it was impossible to carry on business any longer owing to the fact that there was a tremendous stock on hand and no market, resumed work yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Under the management of Miss Lulu Potter, a pupil of James Sauvage, the operetta "A Dress Rehearsal" will be given to-morrow and Tuesday evenings in North End Hall, Belleville Avenue. Miss Adalina Dinelli, violinist from the Royal Academy of Music, London, and other talent will appear.

We have already alluded to the lucid exposition of the principles of sound administration made in his annual report by Postmaster General Bissell. As some of the matters he discusses will come before the Congress that meets to-day, it is well to point out one striking feature of the statement of Mr. Bissell.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 2. -- The British steamer Starlight of West Hartlepool, Capt. Voss, bound from Galveston to Liverpool, cotton laden, arrived here this afternoon with her cargo on fire.

LEBANON, Penn., Dec. 2 -- The Report of this city has completed arrangements by which it will hereafter daily publish a full news service furnished exclusively by the United Press. The Report has been a client of the Western Associated Press.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2. -- "It was just such a day as this, with the sun shining brightly, the temperature frosty but kindly, and everything smiling and bright -- only it was fifty years ago." Col. Richard Malcolm Johnston recalled the half century with all the joy and buoyancy of a young man entering his twenty-first year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Civil Service Commission, in its annual report, says that in the larger Post Offices the civil service law is observed better now than it has ever been before, and the Post Office at Baltimore is mentioned as one in which a marked improvement is shown, and is affording an instance of the good done by the commission's investigations.

Chester, Vt., Dec. 2. -- Omer Stuart, a prominent farmer and freight teamster between Londonderry and Chester, was arrested last night, charged with forging the name of Fred Valies of Londonderry to two notes that were discounted at the National Bank of Chester some months ago. Stuart has always borne a first-class reputation for honesty, and has held important offices.

-- Macmillan Co. will soon issue the promised biography of Dean Church. The work is divided into three parts, the first dealing with his life at Oxford, the second with his life as rector of Whatley, and the third with his career as Dean of St. Paul's.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I cannot help but commend the articles which have appeared from time to time in the editorial columns of your paper on the subject of tuberculosis in dairy herds, for the reason that such articles tend eventually to crystallize public interest into a law requiring a more rigid and compulsory inspection of dairy herds in this and adjoining States which supply this market with milk.
Sorosis held a meeting yesterday which was a memorable one in its history. It debated an important question long and earnestly and then reached a positive decision.
Benjamin Rosenthal, a dealer in glassware at 103 Chambers Street, was assaulted and knocked down at Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue shortly afternoon yesterday by a gang of boys.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 3. -- In a week Yale will elect a Captain of the 'Varsity football team to succeed F. A. Hinkey. The player most talked of to-day for the position is Thorne, the only '96 man on the eleven. He certainly can have the place if he wants it. There is some talk of Murphy for Captain, but the general sentiment seems to be in favor of Thorne.

Several large sales of realty, in this city were reported yesterday as having been completed, but the parties interested were averse to making them public. Several others, also, are about to be completed.

A handsome woman, dressed in the latest French fashion, was plaintiff yesterday before justice Andrews of the Supreme Court in an action involving the dower right in an estate estimated at $600,000. She was Mrs. Libbie Spannechia, formerly an office clerk in this city, but now residing permanently in Paris, having come to New-York simply to testify in the suit on trial.

In order to carry out the great work of municipal reform so well begun at the last election, the Committee of Seventy appointed a special committee to select subcommittees to study and present for the special consideration of the incoming municipal administration the subjects of street cleaning, garbage disposal, improvement of the water front, public schools, civil service, public baths and lavatories, small parks, tenement-house reform, and pay rolls.
North side of Rockfield Street, 325 feet east of Anthony Avenue, by Eliza Hall, two-story frame dwelling; cost, $100.

Mr. Cleveland treats two phases of the currency question -- the Government paper and its redemption, and bank currency, its present defects and possible improvement. As to the first, he speaks with his usual sincerity, care, and firmness. He describes the condition of the gold reserve, the actual and contingent demands upon it, the obligation of the Government to maintain it, the means that should be provided, and those avail- able and used.
WHITEHALL, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- Two persons were killed and five injured by a peculiar railroad accident on the Delaware and Hudson Railroad at 1 o'clock this afternoon.

The Committee on Organization of the anti-Tammany (O'Brien) Democracy, at a meeting last night at 144 West Forty-second Street, resolved to ask the State Senate to authorize the Lexow committee to investigate several departments of the City Government, when it is done with the police.

Did you ever stop to think about the necessity for a stimulant? Nature supplies her own. It is astonishing what she will do if given a chance. In how short a time will she revive the over-tired brain by means of rest and sleep! A healthy man or woman responds readily to her treatment. But we are not all healthy.

LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The British steamer Albertina, which was last reported from Lynn Nov. 20, for Antwerp, was towed into Yarmouth thin morning with her bows badly shattered. She reports that during a dense fog last evening she collided, off Hasborough, with a large steamer, striking her amidships.

To The Editor of The New-York Times: In to-day's issue of your paper there appeared a letter from ex-Mayor Hewitt on the subject of free musical education which contains a statement requiring correction, as Mr. Hewitt has evidently been misinformed in regard to it. After referring to the successful establishment and maintenance of the People's Singing Classes he writes: " Why he [Mr. DamroschJ abandoned Cooper Union I do not know."

The gloomy statement of last week respecting the sugar industry's condition having failed to make much impression on the price of Sugar Trust certificates in the stock market or on the prospects of freesugar legislation in Congress, and the refineries having resumed work despite his assertion that they would be shut down, President H. O. Havemeyer explained himself yesterday in a new statement:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The book of estimates submitted to-day by Secretary Carlisle to the Congress contains some recommendations made by Assistant Treasurer Jordan as to the necessary appropriations for the maintenance of the New-York SubTreasury.
The annual dinner of the Alumni Association of St. Francis Xavier's College was held last night at the Hotel Savoy.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 3. -- Mrs. Edith Armstrong, once Edith Forney, of an aristocratic Virginia family, and niece of John W. Forney, founder of The Philadelphia Press, was found dead in her cell in the county jail this morning. She was a slave to morphine and opium, and had committed a number of thefts to obtain the drugs.

The Manufacturers' National Bank of Wiliamsburg, it is said, will not prosecute E. Austin Leitch, its former bookkeeper, ana Isaac S. Moog, a depositor, who together are charged with defrauding the bank out of $7,800.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Business on the local Stock Exchange to-day was active, but the course of prices was irregular. The elevated stocks opened with a show of considerable strength, but heavy realizing sales quickly brought about a reduction. Alley "L" showed a loss of 2 points before 1 o'clock from the top quotation.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 3. -- The State Food and Dairy Commission to-day resumed operations against Paskola. G.G. Luebbing, the Assistant Commissioner, appeared in Justice Winkler's court this morning and swore out a warrant for the arrest of John Oesper, a clerk for Druggist Dow of 552 West Fifth Street Oesper, it is alleged, sold a package of Paskola to Mr. Luebbing on Oct. 4.

The monthly meeting of the Board of Trustees of Columbia College was held yesterday afternoon in Hamilton Hall. The following members of the board were present: Cornelius Vanderbilt, Seth Low, Dr. Wheelock, the Rev. De Vincent, R.C. Cameron, W.S. Schermerhorn, Stephen P. Nash, John Crosby Brown, Dr. W.H. Draper, and J.W. Harper.

Judge Oliver Wendell Holmes, son and sole executor of the late Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes, applied to Surrogate Abbott, of Kings County yesterday for ancillary letters of administration, and his application was granted.

The dismissal until January of the Extraordinary Grand Jury summoned in the Court of Oyer and Terminer to investigate charges of fraud at the election and of misconduct in public office will postpone all prosecutions of those cases until the new administrations come into power in both city and State.

The President's message puts the relations of our Government to the war in the East in a clear and favorable light. The apprehension that we might have appeared to be officious in offering a mediation which the combatants did not desire, as was pretty distinctly done by the British Foreign Office, need no longer be entertained.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Not all of the members of the Senate or of the House are prepared to give elaborate opinions of the message.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- There was great disinclination to-day on the part of Senators on both sides of the chamber to talk about the probable work of the session. Senator Harris, who had charge of the parliamentary tactics on the Democratic side in connection with the Tariff bill last Summer, was asked by a correspondent of The New-York Times if he had an idea as to what action might be taken regarding the "popgun" bills.

Surrogate Arnold yesterday heard a complicated contest over the estate of Mrs. Julia Stevens, who died Aug. 11 last. Mrs. Stevens was a professional nurse. She had been in the employ of prominent families in this city, and was supposed to have saved and invested considerable money.

Opinion regarding the President's message was not clearly defined in the financial district yesterday, for the reason that bankers have acquired the habit of considering well what they may say. They were reluctant yesterday to express themselves upon a paper so carefully drawn.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3. -- The local market opened strong, then sold off fractionally, and subsequently became stronger, and closed generally at the best prices of the day. At the opening the feature was the strength of People's and Electric on the prospects of the consummation of the traffic agreement between these two companies and the possibilities of a final consolidation. People's opened 1 1/4 higher, at 56 3/4, and Electric 3/4 higher, at 93 1/4.

From The St. Paul News-Record, Dec. 1. The achievements of the United Press in the modern science of gathering and disseminating news has established a standard of excellence which will furnish an ambitious goal for other institutions of like nature for years to come. By amalgamation with it of the Southern Press Association, the final needed mainstay has been furnished to make it pre-eminently the greatest news service of the world.
Benjamin W. Downing. Ex-District Attorney Benjamin W. Downing of Queens County, N. Y., died Sunday at Tampa, Fla., where he had gone several months ago for his health.
WANTAGH, L. I., Dec. 3. -- Andrew J. Russell, a farmer of this village and a veteran of the late war, has a bullet hole in his left hip which he received last night on his way home from church.

Payments by New-York subscribers for the purchase of new Government bonds were completed yesterday by the deposit at the Sub-Treasury of $1,298,544.73 in coin. This covered a face value purchase of $1,105,000, to which were added in premiums $188,700.85 and for interest $4,843,88.
The following are comments of newspapers in this country and abroad upon the President's message:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The Secretary of the Navy will to-morrow advertise for proposals for three torpedo boats, for which Congress appropriated $450,000. These boats are of the general type of the Ericsson, with slightly greater displacement, and must attain an average speed of not less than 24.3 knots on the acceptance trial.

The annual dinner of the St. George's Athletic Cricket Club was given at Riccadonna's of Union Square on Saturday night. Quite a large number of members and guests assembled to discuss the good things provided for them, and a very enjoyable evening was spent.

At a meeting under the management of the American Federation of Labor, John Burns, M. P., the English labor agitator, and his associates, David Holmes, a North of England trades unionist, and John Williams Benn, member of Parliament for St. Georgre's in the East, addressed an audience of workingmen last night that filled the big Cooper Union Hall.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 1@1 1/2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.

The artists occupying the upper part of the building on the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, formerly occupied by the Manhattan Club, were routed from their studios about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon by a fire in the basement.

Mme. Nordica, the opera singer, has stirred up unpleasantness in Brooklyn by her refusal to fulfill her contract to sing next Monday night at the second concert of the Seidl Society in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.Her refusal was not generally known until yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- In the Senate there was unusual warmth in the greeting's between members. Some of the gentlemen, particularly those from the granger States, showed their pleasure at being back again in the meeting place of "the most exclusive club in the world." Senator Peffer was the first one to appear on the floor.

BOSTON, Dec. 3. -- The feature for local stocks was the attack on Bay State Gas securities, which resulted in depressing the stock a full point, to 10 7/8. The first fives opened at 82 and declined to 77, recovering later to 78. The seconds declined 1 1/2, to 56y 1/2, while the incomes fell to 35. There is no particular reason assigned for the decline, and it looks as though insiders were caught napping.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 3. -- Asaph Gholbreen, a Syrian, aged about twenty-five years; his sister-in-law, Mrs. Salma Gholbreen, Mrs. Kate Moore, and her sister, Miss Annie Kirk; George Mashany, a Syrian, and John Nichols and Joseph Lazerus, two men employed on the Windsor Ferry Line, are under arrest charged with smuggling.

There was filed in the Clerk's office of the United States Circuit Court yesterday a finding, taken from the preliminary report of a Master in Chancery, on a claim of the Manhattan Trust Company, as trustee for the benefit of holders of $5,000,000 collateral trust bonds, upon the Nicaragua Construction Company.

The annual report of Commissioner Chamberlain of the Bureau of Navigation of the Treasury Department is devoted to a demonstration that the policy of our shipping laws is fatal to American shipping. The fact has been demon strated for years by practical experience, and no argument is needed to prove it.

A very fast and powerful cruiser is being constructed in England at the works of Sir W. Armstrong, Mitchell Co. The craft is of a similar type to the Blanco Encalada, which was purchased by the Chilean Government. According to The Naval and Military Record, (British,) the new vessel has not been sold, but the paper says that several Governments are negotiating with the builders with a view to purchase her.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Officials of the State Department who at first placed no reliance whatever in the reports of massacred Armenians in Asiatic Turkey are now disposed to attach some significance to the lack of information obtainable by American diplomatic and Consular agents in Turkey.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 3. -- Political circles in Queens County are excited over the charge delivered to the December Grand Jury this morning by County Judge Garretson. The charge was based on rumors that have been, flying arougd since election and statements contained in a county newspaper that money and corrupt methods had been used at conventions held, prior to the late general election to secure nominations.

The Manhattan Bicycle Club and the Bushwick Wheelmen rolled two games last night in the wheelmen's bowling tournament series, on Gaetzner's alleys, Hamburg and Greene Avenues, Brooklyn. The Bushwicks won the first game by 21 pins and showed such good form that the Manhattans seemed to have no chance in the one to follow.

JAMAICA, Dec. 3. -- The Game Committee of the State Senate, appointed last April to investigate the fish and game laws of the State, held a hearing here to-day. There were present Senators H.J. Donaldson of Ballston, Chairman; John L. Childs of Floral Park, and Charles L. Guy of New-York, constituting the committee; Assemblyman Higbie of Suffolk County, and Edward Dowling of Long Island City, Sergeant at Arms of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Representative E.J. Dunphy of New-York is very much gratified by the interest taken in New-York City and elsewhere in the bill introduced by him, during the last session of Congress, providing for the classification and salaries of clerks in first and second class Post Offices.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 3. -- The entire time of the Union County Court was taken up to-day with the trial of David McAdams, a sporting man and manager of the Red Jacket Hotel, Elizabethport, who is accused of complicity in a robbery committed here April 2 last, by "Sheeney Mike" Kurtz, "Dutch Fred " Ryder, and Michael Malone.

Manager Al Hayman is indignant at the story, widely published, that the Bostonians have canceled their dates in his Western theatres. He says that he himself canceled dates of the Bostonians, and he exhibits documentary evidence to prove his statement. To a reporter for The NewYork Times yesterday Mr. Hay man said:

Justice Ingraham, sitting in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, had some forcible things to say yesterday regarding the failure of Gov. Flower to appoint a Deputy Attorney General to prosecute election law violators and corrupt officials, as requested by the Committee of Seventy. In addressing an Extraordinary Grand Jury panel which had been summoned to investigate this class of cases, Justice Ingraham said:

For the first time in months the Tammany Society, or Columbian Order, met last night in the wigwam. It was the first meeting of any kind held there since the election, and appropriately enough the society's ritual declares this to be the "season of snows." One of those present last night said he thought it was the season of cyclones as well.

The Law Enforcement League of Brooklyn will open its headquarters in the Arbuckle Building, opposite the City Hall, this week, and will begin active work to see that the law is enforced in that city. One of the leaders in the new league is the Rev. A.C. Dixon, pastor of the Hanson Place Baptist Church, who is now busy preparing an address to the people.
The Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage is no longer the pastor of the Brooklyn Tabernacle.

The Mayor's Advisory Commission on Parks held a public meeting in the Brooklyn City Hall last night and received suggestions for sites for a number of new parks. Park Commissioner Frank Squier presided, and the Commissioners present were Col. Andrew D. Baird, Gen. John B. Woodward, Theodore Drier, H. B. Scharman, Walter E. Parfitt, John W. Erregger, and W. H. Kenyon.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 3. -- The Connecticut Legislature is overloaded with timber for the Speakership this year, half a dozen aspirants being in the field for the place. For years after the two Harrisons -- H. Lynde, the most brilliant parliamentarian in the State, and ex-Gov. Henry B. of New-Haven -- there was a notable deterioration in the House Speakership, the lowest level being reached during the dead-lock session of 1891.

This was the opening day of the midwinter sales of thoroughbreds here by Woodard Shanklin. There were many turfmen present from distant States, and some good prices were realized. The ninety-five head disposed of brought a total of $22,230, an average of $230 per head. Many youngsters went for less than $100, those sold to-day being yearlings. Best prices follow:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- James T. Kilbreth, Collector of the Port of New-York, arrived in Washington to-night and went to the Arlington.

Forty "rooters," all members of the Montauk Wheelmen, accompanied that club's bowling team to the Acme Hall-alleys, in Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, last evening, and yelled for a double-headed victory over the " five" representing the Kings County Wheelmen. These teams met in a regularly-scheduled match in the tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs.

Ed-ward P. Schell, Sylvester Pope, and William L. Condit were yesterday appointed temporary administrators of the estate of Mrs. Josephine L. Peyton by Surrogate Fitzgerald. They are the executors named by Mrs. Peyton and will act as administrators pending the issue of the contest instituted by Mrs. Peyton's husband, William K. Peyton, to set the will aside.

Sutton Vane's melodrama, "The Cotton King," had its first presentation in this city at the Academy of Music last night. It will hold that stage for the holiday season. No pains have been spared to give it an effective setting. The scenery is elaborate and pleasing. Much of it has been prepared with excellent taste.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 3. -- The Hoboken Post Office was entered this afternoon during the absence of Postmaster Curran and robbed of postage stamps to the value of $7,300.

At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Lehigh and Hudson River Road in this city yesterday, Directors were elected as follows: Grinnell Burt, J. S. Harris, Edward D. Adams, George F. Baker, Henry Graves, G. A. Hobart, John S. Martin, J. Rogers Maxwell, George W. Sanford, W. R. Potts, Charles Caldwell, and R. T. Davies.

The action of the President in remitting the unexpired portion of the sentence of Brig. Gen. David G. Swaim, the titular Judge Advocate General of the army, apparently with a view to his retirement a few weeks hence, will relieve the service of an extraordinary condition of affairs.

The Hotel Brunswick was the scene of one of the largest dinners of the season last evening, when the Presbyterian Union of New-York held its annual banquet. Over 260 covers were laid, the many long tables being handsomely decorated with roses and chrysanthemums of various colors, and with smilax and evergreens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- No matter how great the interest may be next December in the assembling of the Fifty-fourth Congress, it certainly will be impossible to get a larger audience into the House of Representatives galleries on that occasion than was there this morning to see the third session of the Fifty-third Congress begin.

"The Masqueraders," the four-act play by Henry Arthur Jones, about the prodigious success of which in London we have all heard so much since last Spring, was produced at the Empire Theatre last evening. The audience was the same as usual. In the view of the habitue of "first nights," everybody was there.

Ex-Senator J.J. Linson of Kingston sat in this city yesterday as Special Commissioner, appointed by Gov. Flower, to hear testimony on the charges of neglect of duty preferred against District Attorney John R. Fellows by R.W.G. Welling, Preble Tucker, Fulton McMahon, Clarence Goadby, and Charles Taber of the Good Government Clubs, and also charges of the same general nature made by the German-American Reform Union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The President's message was presented to Congress to-day soon after the opening of the session and was read in both houses. It is as follows: To the Congress of the United States:

It is a great pleasure to be able to put upon paper some warm praise of the efforts of the Metropolitan Opera House managers to give the public good operatic entertainment. Last night the stage of the house was occupied by a great modern masterpiece, performed -- at least in its principal roles -- by artists of world-wide reputation, two of them Verdi's own chosen interpreters.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 3. -- In the Supreme Court to-day Mrs. E.A. Webster Ross filed an affidavit declaring that she was the next of kin of William H. King, whose release from an insane asylum she asks. Her counsel declared that to state the exact relationship at this time would prejudice her case.

ROME, Dec. 3. -- King Humbert in person to-day delivered the speech from the throne opening Parliament. The entrances to the Parliament buildings were thronged with crowds, which gave the King an ovation when he appeared on his way to the Chamber. His Majesty, in his speech, referred to the improved economic situation of the country, and the necessity for equalizing the budget, and also spoke of several undefined financial measures.
Has not twice as much protection on refined sugar as was given by the McKinley tariff been enough for the Sugar Trust during the last three months?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The Postmaster General has received information that the International Patentees' Agency, composed of William K. Munns, Percy Willis, and Henry Martin, is conducting a fraudulent scheme, through the American and international mails, from 55 and 56 Chancery Lane and 14 and 15 Southampton Building, London.

ALBANY, Dec. 3. -- Three members of the Albany Board of Water Commissioners tendered their resignations to Mayor Wilson to-day. They are: Elnathan Sweet and George H. Thacher, Democrats, and Eugene R. Hartt, Republican.

ALBANY, Dec. 3. -- Albany society is indulging this week in a historical pageant in Harmanus Bleeker Hall, consisting of a series of tableaus of historical events in Albany from 1553, when Hiawatha was received by the Mohawks in the Vale of Tawasentha on the Normanskill, to 1865, when scenes from the civil war are presented.
GRAND FORKS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Russian farmers from Emmons County have been Indicted for stealing Government buildings at Fort Lincoln, near Mandam.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Governor-elect Coffin has practically decided on the personnel of his staff, and the official announcement will be made at the end of this week.

In several substantial and even essential features the plan submitted by the Secretary of the Treasury for the remodeling of the bank currency system of the United States is extremely encouraging. Its general purpose proves, on examination, to be, as we inferred from the President's summary of it, excellent.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 4 -- A new chapter was added to-day to the story of trouble that has existed during the past two years between the Hempstead Harbor Yacht Club and Miss Mary Ellen McKenzie, a wealthy resident of Glen Cove.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Mme. Nordica signed a contract with the Gounod Society of this city to sing in "The Messiah" in this city on Tuesday, Dec. 18. This afternoon word was received from New-York from Mme. Nordica that she would not come to New-Haven, and there is great disappointment over the news.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 4 -- Ex-Gov. Oden Bowie died this morning at his home, in Bowie, Md.

Additional indictments, based on the statements of Mrs. Augusta Thurow before the Lenxow committee that she had paid bribes for police protection while the proprietress of a disorderly house, were found yesterday against ex-Police Captains John T. Stephenson and Michael Doherty, ex-Sergts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The House was in session four hours to-day. Representative Storer of Ohio secured the passage of a resolution extending until the next term of Congress the time in which the engineer officers surveying proposed routes for a canal to unite Lake Erie with the Ohio River may make their report to Congress.

Police Captain Donald Grant of the Madison Street Police Station was placed on trial before the Police Commissioners yesterday on charges of having clubbed striking cloakmakers in Rutgers Square on Oct. 11. Patrolmen Andrew McCarthy, Joseph Manion, and Frank P. Glennon were also accused. The accusation against Glennon was dismissed when it was shown that his accusers were mistaken about him.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Dec. 4 -- A deputation of three leading citizens of Grand Junction, Col., has made an appeal to the Governor for protection against the Colorado Indians, who have come in strong numbers over the State line. The committee says the Indians are in a defiant mood, that they vastly outnumber the whites, and that they declare they have come to stay in Utah.

Street-Cleaning Commissioner Andrews was the star witness before the Lexow committee yesterday. He was a voluntary witness, having asked permission to refute charges of bribery which were made against him by former Chief Inspector Tomlinson of the Excise Department in connection with August L. Lewis's license for Madame Chaude's Hotel Tortoni.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- Copper stocks were quiet, and prices changed but little.. Montana sold at 30. Quincy was firm at 94. The product of the Quincy mine for November is reported at 926 1/2 tons, against 1,000 1/2 tons in 1893. Officials of the company state that the mine is looking very well, and that they have no copper on hand at the mine.

The bowling team of the Manhattan Bicycle Club and the Tourist Cycle Club of Paterson invaded the Bowery last evening and played two games in the Uncle Sam alleys in the tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs. The Paterson artists of the alleys are trailing in the race for first prize.

It is to be hoped that the hackmen who are petitioning the Board of Aldermen to be allowed to stand wherever they like may not succeed. They have failed hitherto because Mayor Gilroy has judiciously threatened to veto an ordinance allowing them to do so, if such an ordinance were passed by the Aldermen.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Matters are daily growing more complex in the passenger situation among all the Western and transcontinental lines, and to-day a, solution of the problem of how rates shall best be maintained seems remote. Two meetings were held this morning and afternoon, both having in view some agreement as to the basis of a general association, but neither accomplished anything.

Seton Hospital, the Roman Catholic home for consumptives, on Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, which has been in course of construction for more than a year, was formally opened by Archbishop Corrigan. with impressive ceremonies yesterday afternoon.

Lizzie Lundborg, the twenty-two-year-old daughter of Charles G. Lundborg of 233 West One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, is an inmate of the insane pavilion of Bellevue Hospital. It is believed that her strange love for another woman has unbalanced her mind.

The question of the construction of the will of Mrs. Angelina Crane, a widow who died at the Hotel Brunswick last September, leaving a will bequeathing $5 to her daughter, Edith Hawthorne Simmons, the wife of Dr. Robert S. Simmons, came before Surrogate Arnold yesterday.
Under a decision handed down yesterday by Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, the Manhattan Elevated Railway will get out of paying 5300,000 in taxes for the year 1804.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 4 -- Five men were killed and a score of people injured by an explosion of dynamite in Hull, Quebec, a few minutes before 8 o'clock this morning. The Dead.

At auction in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. T.A. Kerrigan sold, at $3,100, to the plaintiff, John Plate, the property on the south-west side of Vandyke Street, 70 feet south-east of Richards Street, 25 by 100. To the same plaintiff, at $2,100, he sold the property on the northeast side of Dikeman Street, 130 feet northwest of Dwight Street, 20 by 100.

Benefactors' Day was celebrated yesterday at the Cathedral Mission, formerly the old Epiphany House, 130 Stanton Street, and a reception was tendered to Bishop Henry C. Potter and those who contribute to support the extensive and valuable work of the mission.

"The fight which the old Republican leaders are making against William Brookfield for Chairman of the county organization is simply a fight against the election district system of organization," said a member of the County Committee yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- The local stock market to-day was without especial feature, Trading, especially in the elevateds, was fairly heavy, and while the tone of the general market during the greater portion of the day was strong, the changes in quotations were, as a rule, unimportant. Alley "L" was freely traded in at prices ranging from 24 1/2 to 25, while Lake Street Elevated ruled about a point below that.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The effort of Senator Butler to make permanent his injunction restraining the State Treasurer of South Carolina from paying Election Commissioners and managers at the recent election on the ground that the election law is unconstitutional is regarded, by several members of the Congressional delegation from South Carolina as a futile attempt to retain his seat in the Senate.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 4 -- This was the second day of the Woodard and Shanklin's auction sale of thoroughbreds and many well-known performers changed hands. Byron McClelland sold Halloween and Queen May because he does not think they can win in the East next season.

The Rapid Transit Commission held its regular meeting yesterday in its rooms in the Home Life Insurance Building. President Alexander E. Orr presided, and Messrs. Lowe, Claflin, Inman, and Steinway of the commission, Beekman and Bourdman, the counsel, and William E. Parsons, the engineer, were present.
Edward M. Shepard lectured last night before the Holy Name Society of St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, Sackett and Hoyt Streets, on the subject, "The Liberty of Law."

Though the first session held by the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association at the Murray Hill Hotel last evening was a quiet one, some interesting cases are likely to come up before this turf tribunal gets through with the docket. One or these is the case in which Monroe Salisbury was expelled by the Driving Club of New-York last September.

TOKIO, Dec. 4 -- Japan has notified China that no further peace proposals will be considered unless made by a regularly accredited Ambassador from the Chinese Court. At the same time Japan reminds China that it is not Japan, but China that is suing for peace. Japan is dissatisfied with China's temporizing policy, and claims that China is seeking concessions in advance of a formal conference looking to a settlement.
The money market was quiet. Call loans Were made at 1@1 1/2 percent. The last loan was made at 1 per cent.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 4 -- R.F. Kolb. who calls himself "Governor de jure" of Alabama, has Issued a message "to the General Assembly and the people of Alabama."

The first fair in aid of the Chapin Home, a non-sectarian home for aged couples in Sixty-sixth Street, near Lexington Avenue, was opened yesterday afternoon in one of the parlors of the Hotel Waldorf. It will be continued to-day and to-morrow. Admission is free.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Frank C. Ives played the game of his life to-night in the second installment of the big billiard tourney, putting Schaefer,so far behind that ii is doubtful if the Wizard with come anywhere near him in the present contest. Ives was in the pink of form, making the,most difficult shots with the greatest of ease and wheedling the balls into position persistently and as persistently keeping them there.
M. Fournil of Paris and Mr. Gallagher of Chicago continued their play in their match game of 1,000 points at cushion carroms in Maurice Daly's Billiard Academy last evening.

Preparations are now nearly completed for the round table and authors' reception which is to take place at Sherry's on Dec. 7, 8, and 10, in aid of the St. Mary's Hospital for Children, in this city, and the Round Table Industrial School Building at Good-Will Farm, Maine.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- Municipal elections were held in 21 of the 31 cities in the Comnonwealth to-day, and in most instances full vote was polled. The Republicans lave made large gains, due, in several initances, to the indorsement of its candiates by the A.P.A. In a number of cities the A.P.A. has succeeded in electing its candidates to the School Committee and individual members of the City Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Democratic Senators to-day made an effort to decide upon a plan which should govern the actions of the majority in the short session, but after a discussion which continued more than three hours they found themselves far from an agreement and arranged to hold a caucus on Thursday, when they will try again to reach an understanding.

Every sparkle in those imported "Brilliants" having been used up in just a month. Miss Lillian Russell has had recourse to Offenbach, the ever gay and always reliable, and, thanks to him and his "Grand Duchess," Abbey's Theatre resounded last evening, at intervals by no means widely spaced with applause, which, while never by any means " wild," was always sincerely cordial and for not a few reasons exceedingly well deserved.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- The opening of the grain markets to-day was a promising one. Wheat was up from 1/4 to 1/2c from the closing quotations of yesterday, the other cereals exhibiting equal strength. In wheat the advance was not substantial, short sellers and holders alike taking advantage of the situation and selling freely.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Leon Abbett, Supreme Court Justice and twice Governor of New-Jersey, died in his home, Montgomery Street and Jersey Avenue, at 2:58 o'clock this afternoon. His only daughter, Mrs. Mary Post; his only surviving son, Leon Abbett, Jr.; his brother, B. Frank Abbett, and Mrs. Dodd, his sister-in-law, were at his bedside.
There was a house-warming and Installation of ofiicers at the new Lincoln Club, 211 West Thirtieth Street, lust night. Nearly all the 230 members were present.
BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- Prince Bismarck is expected to reach Friedrichsruh on the 10th inst., accompanied by Drs. Sehweninger and Chrysander and his family. He sleeps well and appears to be in good health.

President Cleveland's message to Congress and Secretary Carlisle's report have excited much closer attention in the financial district than is usually given to State papers. Bankers feel specially interested, because the leading subject in both documents is one with which their business makes them familiar, and one which, in their opinion, will dominate public discussion until existing conditions give place to better ones.
Another remarkable phase in the Bernard divorce suit-a suit that has been remarkable from beginning to end-was developed yesterday before Justice Patterson, in the Supreme Court.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 4 -- The opinion of Frederick J. Kingsbury, in regard to the evident improvement in business, bears great weight, not only because he is a prominent citisen of this manufacturing town, and a close student of social and industrial problems, but on account of his large connection with manufacturing establishments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Secretary of the Treasury directs attention to the extraordinary increase of the catches of the pelagic sealers last season, under the license given them by the articles of the Bering, Sea Tribunal. He says that if the work of these hunters should go on as it progressed last season, the seals practically will be exterminated on the Pribilef Islands in five years.

Manager Palmer, who owns the American rights to "Little Christopher," received a letter yesterday from Herbert J. Pearson, manager of the "Morocco Bound" syndicate, claiming that the second act ct "Little Christopher," as now being played at the Garden Theatre, is identical with the second act of "Morocco Bound."
The race for the Speakership of the Assembly still goes merrily on, with each of the three leading candidates -- Messrs. Malby, Fish, and Ainsworth -- satisfied that his chance is excellent.
Sons of Ohio, now living in New-York, gave a dinner last night to Mayor-elect William L. Strong at Delmonico's.

The Liberty Wheelmen's bowlers rode rough shod over the Union County Roadsters at Avon Hall, Bedford Avenue and Halsey Street, Brooklyn, last night. This was the first meeting of the teams in the wheelmen's bowling tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The friends of the Nicaragua Canal bill are making an effort to get it before the House. Mr. Mallory of Florida, who was the Chairman of the special committee which framed the bill now on the calendar, had a conference this morning with Speaker Crisp regarding the measure."

Rufino B. Blanco, Consul for Venezuela at Philadelphia, the story of whose arrest with that of his companion, Cesar Zumeta, was told in The New-York Times of yesterday, was before Justice Voorhis, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, charged with assault and also with carrying a "blackjack."

The Democrats of the House and Senate appear to have no plan of action for the session, no policy either as a party or as lawmakers. We can suggest to them a policy that, if they adopt it, will prove sagacious from the point of view of party, beneficial to the country, and universally popular.

Flames swept upward from the warerooms of the D.J. Solomon Company, at 547 Broadway, about 6 o'clock last evening, and, because of the hundreds of persons hurrying to and fro on their way home at that hour, the great thoroughfare was quickly in an uproar of excitement.
Prof. John T. Fisk, the celebrated scholar and historical writer, was a witness yesterday in the proceedings relating to the estate of Mrs. Catherine E. Youmans.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- State Committeeman William Barnes of this city, who is living in the hope that the next Legislature will put him in a position to control all the State printing, has sent out notices requesting all the members of Assembly in the Third and Fourth Judicial Districts to meet at the Kenmore Hotel, in this city, on Thursday afternoon.
HUNTINGTON, Ind., Dec. 4 -- The second terrible dynamite explosion in less than a month happened in the Flint Creek sewer this morning.

With tears in his eyes, William Wahl yesterday told Judge Giegerich and a jury in the Court of Common Pleas how Herman Wahl, his cousin, had torn out the most beautiful growth of whiskers any man had ever owned.

Gov. Flower is never so entertaining as when he is engaged in pandering to the prejudices of the better element. His retort upon Judge Ingraham will be hotly resented by that jurist, but he cannot deny that it is an animated and diverting utterance.
The Board of Aldermen yesterday passed an ordinance prohibiting peddlers from selling candy and toys within 250 feet of public schools between 8 A.M. and 4 P.M.

"A green rag, symbolizing only religious bigotry on the one hand and national disloyalty on the other," the designation of the Irish emblem by the Rev. R.S. MacArthur in his Thanksgiving sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, was temperately discussed at the headquarters of the Irish National Federation of America in the Cooper Union last night.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 4 -- It is not at all without the range of probabilities that the sugar interests of Louisiana may soon be found among the foremost antagonists of the Sugar Trust and among the stanchest sutporters of President Cleveland's recommendation that the differential duties on sugar be abolished.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Judge McComas of the District Criminal Court to-day rendered his decision as to the demurrers filed by Capt. Henry W. Howgate, the ex-United States signal officer, to the indictments charging him with forgery and embezzlement. The demurrers as to forgery are sustained, while those as to embezzlement are overruled.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 4 -- At noon today John Gary Evans was inaugurated Governor before the two houses of the General Assembly, in the hall of the lower house, Chief Justice Mclver administering the cath.

PORT HURON, Mich., Dec. 4 -- A man and woman named Ingalls arrived here from Buffalo about ten days ago, and began living in a house near the river. The neighbors noticed that the curtains were always drawn and began to talk. It was suggested that a gang of counterfeiters were operating in the house, and Detective Buckridge paid a visit there Saturday.
The second annual fair of the Ladies' Auxiliary Society of the New-York Throat and Nose Hospital was held from 2 until 10 o'clock P.M. yesterday in the small pink parlor at Sherry's.

Alderman "Silver Dollar" Smith will have to prove next Friday to the satisfaction of a Police Justice that he did not commit a felonious assault upon a neighboring saloon keeper, August J. Gloistein, 354 Grand Street, or submit to the ignominy of paying the penalty of such a crime.

In the suit brought by Vincent Sternroyd, the actor, aginst Richard Mansfield, to recover $6,000 salary alleged to be due, Hamilton Odell, the referee, has just made his report, holding that no money is due Mr. Sternroyd from Mr. Mansfield.
Michael J. Dady of Brooklyn, who thought that Charles A. Schieren was a poor candidate for office and John Y. McKane a good one, has gone back into the Republican fold.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I am very much relieved and gracitied to learn from the card of Mr. Frank Damrosch that I was mistaken in saying, in a private letter not intended for publication, that be had discontinued his musical instruction in the great hall of Cooper Union. The error, however, is easily explained.

LEONIA, N.J., Dec. 4 -- Palisades Park does not know whether or not it is a borough. The election was held to-day, and a majority of the voters decided in favor of incorporation, but their action is useless until the matter has been settled in the courts.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 4 -- The funeral of the Rev. Dr. Henry M. Storrs, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, was held in the church this afternoon, and fully 1,500 people crowded into the edifice. The business places in the city were closed at noon out of respect to the clergyman, and the flags on the public buildings and school houses were displayed at half mast.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4 -- Dr. J. Edward Lee was again arrested to-day, charged with the murder of Maggie Schloss of Ansonia. In July, 1893, Drs. Lee and Whitten were arrested on the same charge, that of causing the death of the girl by performing a criminal operation. After a long trial before Judge Callahan, in the City Court, both were found not guilty.
