For a week there was an effort on the part of mistaken newspapers to save the foreign residents at the Chinese capital by sending fifty marines to their assistance, and the difficulty of getting the marines, and afterward of transporting them across a hostile country, was magnified from all points of view.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Notwithstanding the secrecy with which the Interior Department guards its action with reference to the Ute Indian troubles in Southern Utah, the fact developed this morning that Secretary Smith has ordered Agent Day by telegraph to follow the Utes into South-western Utah and bring them back to the reservation.

Henry Elias, thirty-seven years old, of 414 East Fifty-seventh Street, Vice President of the Elias Brewing Company, attempted suicide at his home early yesterday morning by cutting his throat with a pocketknife.

The America's Cup Committee met at exCommodore James D. Smith's, office yesterday afternoon to consider the Royal Yacht Squadron's challenge and the explanatory better received from Lord Dunraven last Saturday. The members present were Chairman James D. Smith. Latham A. Fish, A. Cass Canfield, Gouverneur Kortright, Archibald Rogers, C. Oliver Iselin, and J. Frederic Tams.
The heirs of Jay Gould won a decided victory yesterday in the fight they are making against the payment of $180,000 in taxes in their father's estate.

Harry Hayward of Minneapolis, who is supposed to have been instrumental in causing the death of Catherine Ging, is known pretty well in the East. William Ellery Hills, a lawyer in the Equitable Building, said to a reporter for The New-York Times yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The nominations of Postmasters for ten New-York State offices were sent to-day to the Senate by the President. The list contains the names of James Halligan, Canajoharie; George H. McKinley, Clayton; John S. Edwards, Sayville; John C. Vandyke, Stamford; Thomas A. Riley, Ticonderoga; Robert B. Barrett, Washingtonville; William H. S. Smith, Hempstead; De Witt C. McKeel, Farmer; Winfield S. Watson, Fairport, and Henry J. Buell, Holley.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Samuel C. Seely, wanted in New-York for the embezzlement of $354,000 while an assistant bookkeeper in the National Shoe and Leather Bank of that city, is under arrest in Chicago.
The American Sabbath Union met yesterday morning at Calvary Baptist Church, Fifty-seventh Street, nea-r Sixth Avenue, to consider the Sunday question.

David L. Kellam, the broker, and Henry M. Haigh, the lawyer, who were arrested Friday, charged with conspiracy to forge and sell promissory notes signed by Henry E. Simmons, had a hearing yesterday at the Tombs Police Court, before Justice Grady.

WESTVILLE, Fla., Dec. 10 -- A cyclone passed five miles north of this place early this morning. It struck the farm of J.N. Skinner, the Representative-elect from Holmes County, and demolished every building on the place.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 10 -- An attempt was made to rob the Post Office here last night. William F. Jones of The Montclair Journal, whose office is directly over the mailing department, found the door fastened, which is unusual, about 10 o'clock. He shook the door and a stick, which had evidently been used to fasten it, fell to the floor, while he heard retreating footsteps inside.

Three attachments were obtained here yesterday against the Commercial Bank of Newfoundland, aggregating $11,130. They were served at the National Bank of the Republic, where the St. John's bank had a balance of $13. Two of the attachments were in favor of Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. for $8,731, and the third was in favor of the Produce Exchange Bank for $2,399.
The Alpha Delta Phi Club gave a reception and tea to ladies yesterday afternoon between 2 and 6 o'clock.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Dec. 10 -- Many politicians and office holders spent most of to-day in attendance at the County Court House here, the Queens County Grand. Jury having resumed its inquiry into the reported purchase of nominations at the conventions held prior to the recent general election.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 10 -- The fight between the Consolidated Road and the Bridgeport Traction Company was renewed at 4 o'clock this morning when a work train containing about fifty Italians stopped at the Fairfield Avenue crossing, West End, and in a few minutes the trolley wires and cable running under the railroad tracks were severed.

The detailed facts concerning the marriage of Julian Potter, a well-known club man, to Alice Bernise Pixley, sister of the late Annie Pixley, on Sept. 14, were not made public until yesterday. The Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton performed the ceremony at the bride's home, 27 West Sixty-first Street.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10 -- At a meeting tonight of all the men who played in either the football game with Pennsylvania or Yale this season, Langdon Lea of the junior class in the John C. Green School of Science, was elected Captain of the Princeton University team for the season of 1895. He had no opposition, and his election was made by acclamation.

Commissioners Abraham L. Jacobs, Howard Ives, and Dr. A.N. Brockway began taking testimony yesterday in the Supreme Court to ascertain whether or not Mrs. Johanna Barbara Widmayer is competent to take care of her property and manage it satisfactorily. Mrs. Widmayer is about eighty-two years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Closure may engage the attention of the Senate to-morrow. Senator Vest has given assurances in the last ten hours of his determination to press his resolution calling for a change in the rules, and it assumed by those who are acquainted with his intentions that he will not waste any time.
ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Ex-Judge Learned, in his report, said that he agreed with his associates as to many of their findings.

At the residence of Mrs. Gilbert E. Jones, 222 Madison Avenue, a musicale was given on Sunday evening to open the new house and new music room. The entertainment began with a piano solo by Ferdinand Sinzig. M. de Gromzeski of the Opera House then sang an air from Massenet's "Herodiade."
Charles Stewart Smith of the Chamber of Commerce has received the following letter from Carl Schurz in reference to the reorganization of the police force of New-York City:

With the opening of the Fall Academy, the regular art season in New-York may be said to have begun. While the event is never one of great importance, and while the artists rarely send their best or most important works, there is always here and there something of interest, some touch of nature not yet spoiled by overelaboration or with the life taken out of it by too much studio work.
Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan surrendered himself yesterday on the indictment found against him for contempt of the Lexow committee.
ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Gov. Flower, after careful examination of the reports of the Commissioners, to-day dismissed the charges against the Board of Managers of the Elmira Reformatory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- No better indication of the interest felt in the question of currency reform could have been asked than the attendance and attention manifested today at the hearing opened by the House Committee on Banking and Currency, which sat in the room of the Committee on Ways and Means to accommodate the large audience, principally of members of the House.

The report of Dr. Flint and Mr. Deyo upon the case of the Elmira Reformatory announces the conclusions to which the whole course of the investigation has convinced all sensible men that the investigators must come. Gov. Flower is to be congratulated upon having chosen two men of such intelligence, impartiality, character, and special knowledge to investigate the charges made against the reformatory, because the findings of these men will be accepted.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Business on the local Stock Exchange continues to be confined largely to trailing in Alley "L." That stock opened weak this morning, under a heavy selling pressure, and within a few minutes declined to 21 1/4, against a close on Saturday of 23. Here the market rallied as a result of covering, and subsequently more than recovered the early loss.

Rates on second-class passenger business, east bound out of Chicago, have been in a demoralized condition for the past three or four weeks, and they are not likely to be ny better until after Jan. 1, when the new ronclad agreement goes into effect.
The left arm of John Ford, twenty-four years old, of 590 West Fifty-fourth Street, was amputated yesterday in a conduit of the cable road at Fifty-third Street and Seventh Avenue.

-- Mrs. Alfred Edwards's Dinner. -- Mrs. Alfred Edwards' of 12 West Thirty-third Street opened the evening of the Patriarchs' Ball with a dinner at Sherry's to the season's debutantes in honor of her daughter, Miss Helen Edwards. Covers were laid for 150 people. There were six different tables, decorated in pink, blue, lavender, and various other shades.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 10 -- The feature of the first day's session of the fourteenth annual convention of the American Federation of Labor, aside from the annual address of the President, Samuel Gompers, and the reports of the Treasurer and the Secretary, was the address made by John Burns., M.P., of England, in response to the seating of himself and David Holmes as delegates upon the floor by the convention.
Eighteen members of the police force who have asked to be retired were before the Boardof Surgeons yesterday for physical examination to determine their fitness to perform police duty.
At a meeting of the Board of Managers of the National Temperance Society yesterday at 58 Reade Street the following resolutions were unanimously adopted:

The principal interest last evening at the fair in the Grand Central Palace, was the reception given to Mgr. Satolli, the Apostolic Delegate, and to Archbishop Corrigan by the Cathedral Centre of the League of the Sacred Heart, and the presentation to the prelates of a set of resolutions adopted some time ago.

ST. JOHN'S N.F., Dec. 10 -- This city is in the midst of a financial crisis, the outcome of which cannot, at present, be fore-shadowed. To-day the Commercial Bank and five leading fish and sealing houses suspended, while the Union Bank, after paying out gold for a short time, closed its doors temporarily, in order to allow it to replenish its coffers.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 1 per cent.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 10 -- The new Grand Jury of Hudson County, which will assemble in the Court of Oyer and Terminer here to-morrow, will receive from the Grand Jury which was discharged to-day a legacy in the shape of evidence of a twenty-thousand-dollar bribe.
Signor Rimoldi has come out victorious in his contest with John Chatfield, proprietor of the Hotel Jefferson, Fifteenth Street, near Union Square East.

The Pouch Mansion, in Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, was filled with an array of legal talent last night, when the annual dinner of the Brooklyn Bar Association was given. It was one of the most pleasant affairs in the history of that organization. Joseph A. Burr, the President of the association, presided.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- The majority report, signed by Dr. Austin Flint and Israel T. Deyo, discusses at considerable length the appointment of the commission and the methods of procedure in the investigation. It said:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Miss Carrie Banks, formerly of Pleasantville, N.Y., and Walter E. Sniffin of White Plains, were quietly married this evening at the Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church parsonage. The Rev. Dr. McChesney officiated.

Probably Ward McAllister, even in his happiest dreams, or the loftiest flights of his imagination, never pictured to himself so brilliant a Patrairchs' as the big ball held at Delmonico's last evening.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Referring to the recent agitation for a change in the rules of the Senate, Senator Voorhees to-night said he was very earnestly in favor of a change.

To describe in detail all the women's costumes worn at the Patriarchs' ball would be to collect in words the innumerable ideas of the Parisian, London, and American dressmakers. There were gowns of every cut, provided, of course, that the cut conformed most accurately with the latest fashions -- and gowns of every hue and material -- provided that the hue and the material were both in accordance with the formality of the occasion.

A circular relating to the reorganization of the Erie Railway was issued yesterday, simultaneously in New-York and London, by Drexel, Morgan Co. and J.S. Morgan Co. respectively. It is addressed to the holders of receipts issued by the two firms named for the Erie seconds, the coupon and the income bonds, under the terms of the reorganization plan.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Insane through brooding over his discharge from the Otis Elevator Works, Ludwig Hageman this evening shot and fatally wounded Frederick Cassen, whom he blamed for his dismissal. Thinking he had killed Cassen, Hageman fired two bullets into his owns head.

The Anti-Lynching Society had a public meeting in Association Hall, Fulton Street, near Bond, Brooklyn, last night. There was a large attendance, as it was believed that Frederick Douglass would assist Miss Ida B. Wells in her crusade against the negro atrocities in the South.

The suspension of the Commercial Bank of Newfoundland, at St. John's, and the resulting embarrassment of other financial and mercantile interests in that city, may be due in some measure to the recent victory of the descredited Whiteway Party. About a year ago the supporters of Sir William Whiteway, then Premier, elected twenty-four of the thirty-six members of the legislative assembly.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 10 -- Mrs. Annie Hahn, a widow thirty-six years old, was found dead in her rooms at 78 Hoboken Avenue yesterday. Her husband, W.C.H. Hahn, was connected with the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New-York. He left an estate valued at $40,000 to be divided between his wife and his two sisters, who live in Germany.

The Robert Anderson and A.S. Williams Post, No. 394, Grand Army of the Republic, has elected the following officers for 1895: Commander -- Joseph B. Lord; Senior Vice Commander -- Luther F. Shaw, Junior Vice Commander -- William E. Lockwood; Chaplain -- F.M. Hopper; Surgeon -- John W. Jack; Quartermaster -- Robert Stackpole; Trustees -- J.F. Nesbitt, F.W. Hopper, and W.E. Lockwood.

The Lexow committee will begin its sessions again this morning, and will, in all probability, continue to sit each day until Saturday. It is expected that at these hearings much sensational evidence will be produced that will affect the higher police officials of the city.

Mr. Harrigan and his inseparables, Mrs. Yeamans and Mr. Wild, left us last February, for a long professional tour of other cities. Last night they began a new season at Harrigan's Theatre. Their long absence seemed to have made the hearts of their fellow-citizens fonder. The house was crowded, the applause was vehement, and the principal members of the company had receptions that would not be despised by great military heroes.

AUCKLAND, New-Zealand, Dec. 10 -- The inquiry into the circumstances of the loss of the steamship Wairarapa, from Sydney, New-South Wales, for this port, on the night of Oct. 28, when she went ashore on Great Barrier Island, has been closed. The court finds that the wrecking of the ship and the consequent drowning of upward of eighty of her passengers and crew was the fault of Capt. McIntosh, who was himself drowned.
John Garvey, the "Astor Tramp," was found guilty yesterday of "unlawfully entering the house of Mrs. Caroline Astor."

To the Editor of The New-York Times: On the first resolution by the United States House of Representatives to pass a bill allowing the railroads to pool their earnings under the supervision of the Inter-State Commissioners, merely on the suggestion and the strong appeal made in its favor by Mr. Reed there was reflected in the marts of the world that deal in American railroad securities a more cheerful feeling.

RAHWAY, N.J., Dec. 10 -- The annual election of the Union County Roadsters officers was held to-night in the clubhouse on Main Street. Excitement was at fever heat all through the meeting. The clubhouse was packed when the meeting was called to order at 8:30.

A reception was held last night at the United Service Club, 10 West Thirty-first Street, in honor of Gen. Nelson A. Miles. It was of an informal nature, and there was very little speechmaking. the object being to introduce the army and navy officers of this vicinity to the new commander of the Department of the East.

The decision of the Supreme Court of Connecticut, allowing the State an appeal in a case in which a man charged with the crime of murder has been acquitted by a jury, and granting a new trial for the same offense, is so contrary to established practice and to what has been accepted as a fundamental principle that it is likely to attract wide attention.

Sugar certificates were not as active in the stock market yesterday as on the days of heavy dealings last week, although they furnished 55 per cent. of the day's business. Sales reached 133.887 shares in a total of 240,371 shares. The stock was about as good a gamble as usual. It opened at 90 1/2, advanced to 93, and closed at 90 7/8, a loss of 3/8 for the day.
Samuel C. Seely was for fourteen years a bookkeeper in the National Shoe and Leather Bank, Broadway and Chambers Street.

BUDA-PESTH, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Wekerle, Prime Minister of Hungary, announced in the Chamber of Deputies to-day that the laws dealing with disputes between the Church and State had received the royal sanction. The announcement was received with great applause. Premier Wekerle, continuing his remarks, said that Count Kalnoky, the Imperial Prime Minister, had never meddled in the internal affairs of Hungary.
The battle for supremacy in the Republic an County organization will begin at the primaries to be held in the 1,141 election districts of this city to-night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The power and authority of the Postmaster General to enter into a contract for a long lease of property for Post Office purposes, without express appropriation to meet the liability thus incurred, was the subject of a decision rendered in the United States Supreme Court to-day by Justice Harlan.
"The motto of modern medicine," says a writer in The British Medical Review," is prophylaxis."
The Long Island Association of the Sons of the Revolution met last night at the Brooklyn Club to commemorate the battle of Long Island in 1777. John Jay Pierrepont presided.

A great many persons who entertain a more or less sentimental regard for Old Trinity, in New-York, will be surprised and not at all pleased by the facts which have appeared in the publication of the controversy going on between the church corporation in question and the Board of Health and Tenement House Commission.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 10 -- The Wells memorial table of bronze, erected to the memory of Dr. Horace Wells of this city, the reputed discoverer of anaesthesia, which has been placed on the front of the marble Corning Building, just south of the corner of Asylum and Main Streets, was unveiled this afternoon without ceremony, owing to the inclemency of the weather.

The shipments of dead freight out of Chicago to the Atlantic seaboard last week aggregated 45,833 tons, as against 34,182 tons in the previous week and 62,266 tons the same week last year. As usual of late, the Pittsburg and Fort Wayne Line got the cream of the traffic, carrying 7,459 tons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- If this was a Congress that could accustom itself to consider great public questions broadly, and to dispose of them with some reference to the idea that the United States is to have a hereafter, the Nicaragua Canal bill, which was taken up in the Senate to-day, would be assured of passage before the Congress should be half through Us last session.

Carl F. Schuldt, a saloon keeper at 459 Ninth Avenue, was charged, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, with selling a glass of whisky to Policeman Morris Cohen of Inspector McAvoy's staff, on Sunday.

Thomas C. Platt served notice on the public last night that the recent election in this city and State was a Republican victory, pure and simple. After last year's election he gave some credit to Divine Providence, but now that all the State offices have fallen into Republican hands Mr. Platt wants to have it understood that the change is due to the G.O.P.
In the United States Circuit Court yesterday the Harney Peak Tin Mining, Milling, and Manufacturing Company filed an answer to the suit of Charles Fletcher and others against the company.

LONDON, Dee. 10 -- A dispatch from Yokohama to The Westminster Gazette says that the Japanese second army will make an early advance upon Pekin. The Japanese Government has contracted for a force of 8,000 coolies to accompany this army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The returns to the Statistical Division of the Department of Agriculture for the month of December relate principally to the average farm price of the various agricultural products on the first day of the month. By farm price is meant the price of product on the farm or in the nearest locality or railway market.

-- Daly's Theatre. -- "Love on Crutches," the second revival of the season at Daly's Theatre, which is to be presented Saturday night, is likely to prove an agreeable surprise, even to those playgoers who remember its former production here. Mr. Daly has had entirely new scenery prepared for the revival, and the dresses are to be all new.

Never was there a more surprised team of bowlers than were the Columbia Wheelmen last night. When they groped their way through the clouds of tobacco smoke in Gaetzner's alleys, Hamburg and Greene Avenues, Brooklyn, and saw the Bushwick Wheelmen's five, they commented on the size of the latter and announced that "we'll wipe the floor with the little fellows."

The performance of "Mignon" at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening was heard by an audience of considerable size, but of inconsiderable enthusiasm. The opera has not been given here since Messrs. Abbey, Schoeffel Grau's first season, when the title role was sung by Marie Van Zandt, and Mme. Lilli Lehmann was the Filina.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 11. -- A boy walking across a vacant lot bounded by Third and Fourth Streets and West Avenue and Front Street this morning found a counterfeit silver dollar. Going a few steps further he came across another counterfeit coin. The boy took the counterfeits to the Second Precinct Police Station and gave them to Sergeant Dunn.

Senator Clarence Lexow and several of his associates on the committee which has been conducting the police investigation were the guests of honor at a dinner given by Herbert Booth King at the Waldorf last night.
SING SING, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- Mysterious letters have been received by prominent citizens in this village asking for the address of G.W. Gray, if such a person lives here.

Ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt has on hand just now a wholesale job at "molding public opinion." Only yesterday he gave out for publication in New-York a statement in which he claimed the recent victory as Republican pure and simple, leaving no ground for any one who swallowed his statement to make any substantial claim that it was non-partisan.

The bowling team of the Union County Roadsters came to town from Rahway last evening to keep an appointment made for them with the Manhattan Bicycle Club "five." The meeting place was the Uncle Sam. Amusement Palace in the Bowery, and on the alleys in the basement of this resort the teams met in the two contests scheduled in the bowling tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 11. -- Capt. E.C. Reed of the whaling bark Petrel, of this port, in a letter just received by his wife, in this city, relates a thrilling story of adventure upon the high seas and discloses the incidents connected with the destruction of a noble and substantial vessel by her crew.

The action of the lower house of Congress yesterday in passing the pooling amendments to the Inter-State Commerce act will be cordially approved by the railroad companies throughout the country, and there is good reason for the belief that it will have a stimulating effect upon railway business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Keeping in mind th necessity for economy in expenditure during the coining year, the Appropriations Committee is discouraging any legislation that looks to the undertaking of business involving new expenses and drafts upon the receipts of the Treasury. For that reason the committee regarded with disfavor the effort made yesterday in the House to pass a bill for a free public library for the District of Columbia.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- The Court of Appeals to-day, in the case of the people, appellants, against Charles W. Gardner, sustained a reversal of the judgment of conviction and ordered a new trial.

There should be no misunderstanding about the attitude of the Republican Senators, or a majority of them, toward the proposed removal of the discriminating duty on German sugar and of the Sugar Trust's differential of 1-8 of a cent a pound. They have decided that they will not permit either of these duties to be repealed.
An interesting will contest that will be most stubbornly fought was begun yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 11. -- The details of the biggest street railway consolidation ever effected in Pittsburg were completed to-day. The new system, under the name of the Second Avenue Traction Company, will be in operation by Jan. 1, and has a paid-in capital of $5,000,000. There are four branches, with a total of sixty miles of track.
Six painters have taken possession of the American Art Galleries, and the result is a most interesting exhibition of oils, water colors, and black and white.

William W. MacFarland, the well-known lawyer, formerly partner of ex-Secretary of the Navy Benjamin F. Tracy, appeared in court yesterday as the advocate of his daughter in a divorce suit, in a motion to compel the payment of alimony.

Ex-United States District Attorney Asa W. Tenney, one of the most prominent Republicans of Brooklyn, whose name has been mentioned for one of the new places on the Supreme Court bench provided for by the new Constitution, speaking of the question as to whether Governor-elect Morton would have power to make the appointments, said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The pooling bill was passed by the House late this afternoon by a vote of 166 to 110, after the opposition had exhausted every filibustering motion possible under the order of the Committee on Rules.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The legend "Pierce, Wright Co." still indicates the occupancy by that exposed firm of the handsome offices which they fitted up at 52 New-Broad Street, E.C., where they conducted business as "foreign bankers" and from which were issued the fraudulent Dakota school bonds which hastened the firm's exposure.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Inasmuch as recent developments have revealed to yachtsmen the truth of my letter published in Saturday's Times, if you will allow me more space in your yachting columns I will say a few words, this time addressing myself to Lord Dunraven's representative, Mr. Kersey.

Joseph T. Nightingale, a real estate dealer at 424 De Kalb Avenue, who lives at 356 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, is missing, and his accounts as Secretary of the Long Island Building and Lean Association are short about $6,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The following is the full text of Secretary Carlisle's plan for currency reform, formulated into a bill:

There is said to be trouble in the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, one of the leading Irish societies, of Brooklyn. At the annual meeting last Monday evening ten members resigned, it is alleged, because John C. Kelley, who ran on the Democratic Reform ticket for County Treasurer at the last election, was elected President of the society.
The Quill Club held its thirty-ninth regular meeting at the Arena, in West Thirty-first Street, last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The venerable Senator from Vermont, Mr. Morrill, entertained the Senate to-day with one of his witty speeches. It was on the subject of Populistic panaceas for financial troubles, and, on his motion, all the bills introduced as such measures of universal prosperity and happiness were postponed indefinitely.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The latest news from British Honduras bring the news of a serious revolt in the police force early in November. The revolt of the police, which is virtually a military body, was due to a wages dispute. The mutineers held Belize for days, retaining their rifles, bayonets, revolvers, and ammunition, each man having sixty rounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- There are sev eral shades of opinion in the Banking and Currency Committee upon the subject of currency reform, and it has been a matter of conjecture during the last week whether these differences could be so harmonized as to enable the committee to produce a bill to secure the results sought by the Secretary and the Controller or the Currency.
The movement to give the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst a substantial testimonial in recognition of his work for municipal reform has taken definite shape.
LONDON, Dec. 11. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Tien-Tsin says the Japanese have landed in force and captured Kin-Chow, fifty miles north of Shan-Hia-Kwan.

The manifesto, forwarded to Washington by our Consul General at Berlin, of the Agrarians in the Prussian Legislature contains statements that ought to excite interest throughout the grain belt of the United States, which is conterminous with a part of the area over which Populism and the silver craze prevail.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- Local stocks were quiet, and there were few changes in prices. Bay State Gas was stronger than yesterday, selling up 1/2, to 11 1/8. The seconds were quiet at 58 1/2. Mexican Central 4s sold at 54. Bell Telephone was steady at 198, with Erie up 3/8, to 51 7/8. The pending sale of 5,000 shares of Bell Telephone at auction does not seem to affect the price of stock.

Archibald D. Gordon, well known in theatrical and journalistic circles as a writer for the stage and newspapers, is suffering at his home, in Port Richmond, S.I., from, a stroke of paralysis. He is in a precarious condition, yet his physician thinks there is a chance that he will recover. Even in the case of a favorable turn, Mr. Gordon will not be able to resume work before Winter has passed.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 11. -- James A. Bailey disposed of a large amount of surplus circus material and trappings, belonging to spectacular features of the Greatest Show on Earth, at auction at the Winter quarters today. William A. Brady, manager for Champion James J. Corbett, purchased a lot of ballet costumes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Messrs. Richard and Daly, two attorneys of New-York City, friends of Mr. Lee, the Superintendent of the registry division of the New-York Post Office, who was removed a few days ago, called on Acting Postmaster General Jones to-day in Mr. Lee's behalf.

Primaries for the election of delegates to the Republican Assembly District conventions to be held in every Assembly district next Tuesday night, were held last night in the 1,141 election districts of this city.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 11. -- Edward A. Dugan, the ex-Commissioner who told the Grand Jury yesterday that an attempt had been made to bribe him, and that he had been offered $20,000 to vote for a certain water contract, refuses to give the name of the man who made the offer.

Senator Lexow, Chairman of the Senate investigating committee, declared yesterday morning in open session that he did not believe it practicable to legislate the present Police Department out of office.
There is talk of organizing another whist league in New-Jersey. The present league has been very successful, and it now has a full quota of teams, so there is no chance for many new clubs to join it.
YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- Capt. Edgar C. Merriman, retired, United States Navy, died this afternoon at his home, 90 Locust Hill Avenue, after a short illness from pneumonia.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 11. -- Delegates to the fourteenth annual convention of the American Federation of Labor cast aside the duties of the convention to-day and went off for a holiday. At the invitation of the Denver Trades Assembly, the visitors enjoyed a trip over the Loop. The two English labor advocates, Messrs.

A delightful entertainment was given last evening by the Henry Ward Beecher Mission Band of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, to raise money for a pulpit to be presented to the Rev. James E. Tracy, a missionary in India. It was held in the lecture room of the church and consisted of amateur performances by young women and children of the church.
The number of burglaries in Brooklyn is on the increase, and the police, from all appearances, are not able to deal with them.

Alderman Rinn of the Seventeenth District made his maiden speech in the Board of Aldermen yesterday, when the Committee on Parks reported in favor of granting permission to the Park Department to make a contract for building a house for skaters in Central Park, at a cost of $4,500.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Turkish Legation has received the following communication:

Trading on the Stock Exchange fell off materially yesterday, the transactions footing up only 150,000 shares, or considerably less than was done on several days recently in Sugar alone. Operations also were almost wholly of a professional character. There was some buying back of stock sold on Monday, particularly of Erie and St. Paul.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- West side cable trains came in collision in the Washington Street tunnel shortly after 6 o'clock tonight, causing the worst wreck and disaster that has happened on the street car lines of the city.
The regular monthly meeting of the NewYork City Training School for Nurses was held yesterday afternoon at the alumnae parlors, 137 West Twenty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- A resolution, which was agreed to, was offered to-day in the House by Mr. Dingley, (Rep., Me.,) calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury for information as to the workings of the regulations prepared by the Paris Tribunal of Arbitration for the preservation of the Bering Sea seal herd and the cost of carrying them into effect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- James Quigley, who was a second-class fireman on the Baltimore, and a beneficiary to the extent of $1,000 of the Chilean indemnity on account of the treatment of that ship at Valparaiso during the Balmaceda revolution, was yesterday released from imprisonment at the Mare Island Navy Yard, and presented with his money.

Capt. Thomas Reilly of the East Fiftyfirst Street Police Station and seventeen Sergeants and patrolmen who had applied for retirement from the police force under the twenty-year provision or the law were examined by the Police Board Surgeons yesterday as to their fitness for duty.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Dec. 11. -- Four ramshackle buildings in Canal Street were destroyed by fire at 2:30 this morning. The less is about $6,000. Several tenants had a narrow escape from death by suffocation or fire.

After all, Superintendent Brockway has substantial compensations for the annoyance he has been put to. It was a terrible fight, and the chances were against him. He had to meet calumny, unscrupulousness, malignity, platoons of soulless perjurers organized and drilled, and all the resources of a powerful enemy clamoring for his head.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 11. -- There was a sensational fight in the courtroom at Hazard, Ky., yesterday, which is thought by the citizens of Perry County, to be the reopening of the French-Eversole feud. Judge Floyd Hall began the regular term of Circuit Court there, and the first case was the Commonwealth against Jesse Fields and Joe Atkins, for the murder of Josiah Combs.

ST. JOHN'S, N. F., Dec. 11. -- Several small firms suspended to-day, but there were no important developments in Newfoundland's financial crisis. Nearly every manufacturing concern in the city has ceased running.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- As the result of a cruel practical joke played on him on Thanksgiving Day, William O'Hearn, thirty years old, of Wappinger's Falls, is lying at the point of death from blood poisoning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Surprise was manifested this afternoon when the Senate confirmed a large batch of Postmasters, some of whom had been appointed a year ago, had failed of confirmation, and had been reappointed during the recess of Congress, for this list contained the names of many New-York appointees whom the NewYork Senators had formerly opposed.

At last the dilatory Board of Supervisors of Kings County has got its election returns on file with the Secretary of State at Albany and we know exactly what the State vote was at the election of five weeks ago.

The committee appointed by the Board of Education to investigate the charges made by the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur, to the effect that the teachers of the public schools paid tribute to political leaders, was much disappointed Monday afternoon when it held a meeting not to find Dr. MacArthur before it ready to substantiate these charges.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The Hamburg-American Packet Company of Hamburg and the Thingvalla Steamship Company of Copenhagen have agreed upon uniform traffic rates between New-York and Gothenburg, Copenhagen, and Hamburg.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- The local market was very dull but strong. A number of stocks showed a tendency to advance. There was a scarcity of stock for sale, notably Lehigh Valley, which advanced from 33 3/4 to 35 without sales, excepting at 34 1/2, at which figure a few odd lots changed hands.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- All preparations for the big nine-day cycling tournament are completed, and excellent sport is anticipated. The amateur part of the tourney, beginning on Thursday evening and lasting through three nights, bids fair to be a great success. The number of entries from New-York and New-Jersey is an indication of the widespread interest shown in the affair.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- The hall and galleries of the Reichstag were crowded to-day by members and visitors -in expectation of exciting scenes over a motion of Chancellor Hohenlohe to prosecute Herren Liebknecht, Singer, and Ulricht, and the other Socialist Deputies who refused to respond to the President's call for cheers for the Kaiser last Thursday.

Messrs. Bennett Graff have sold for John C. Umberfield to Emil Caliman, at about $60,000, the four-story brownstone dwelling 7 West Seventy-fifth Street, 22 by 60, with extension, by 102.2. This is the third house of the row sold within ten days.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 11. -- Official notice has been received that Dr. Seeballoa, Minister of the Argentine Republic to the United States, has advised his Government to make an exhibit at the exposition in Atlanta next year. He has recommended an independent building for the Argentine Republic, and is especially pleased at the efforts of the exposition to establish closer trade relations between this country and the South American Republics.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 11. -- Deputy United States Marshals to-night arrested at Terrall, Indian Territory, the three bandits who robbed the Rock Island train at Red iRver, this morning. They have been identified positively by passengers who were victims.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Comprehensive plans for the immediate reorganization of the Police Department on a civil-service basis were submitted to Mayor Hopkins this afternoon by John W. Ela, John H. Hamline, and Harry Rubens, the members of the commission appointed by the Mayor. Within a week it is expected that the department will be under the administration of the board.

We hope the Church Wardens and Vestrymen of Trinity Church will not fall into the deplorable mistake of treating as public enemies the persons who have exposed their ramshackle and rotten tenements to the public view.

HENNESSEY, Oklahoma, Dec. 11. -- At 11:50 last night the north-bound passenger and express train on the Rock Island Road was stopped by three masked men, about one mile south of Red River, in Texas, and near the Indian Territory line. The men compelled the engineer and fireman to assist them in breaking open the express car, which they entered and rifled.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 11. -- The demurrer filed by the defense in the case of the State Food and Dairy Commision against John Oesper was argued before Justice Winkler this morning. Oesper, who sold a botle of Paskola to Assistant Commissioner G.G. Luebbin, is charged with violating the drug law in disposing of an article which fell below its professed standard of quality.

All the testimony for and against exPolice Captain John T. Stephenson for accepting a bribe of four baskets of peaches from Martin W. Edwards, was taken yesterday. Three sessions of Judge Ingraham's court were held. This morning the lawyers will make their arguments, and the case will then go to the jury.

Fanny Davenport produced the new Sardou drama of superstition, lust, and murder at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last evening, in presence of an extraordinary audience, in a superb manner. The scene of "Gismonda" is Athens under the Florentine rule, which affords a splendid opportunity to the scene painter and costumer.

TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 11. -- The Evening News says editorially: " The political and commercial crisis in Newfoundland is a matters of grave import for Canada in more ways than one. The aggregate of our trade with the island is about $3,000,000 a year, and this must be affected by the troubles now existing.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Dec. 11. -- Chief of Police Pratt is for the second time behind the walls of the penitentiary, on the charge of contempt of court. He was again summoned to reveal the name of the woman who had been detained under sensational circumstances in a hack, and to whom he had passed his word of honor not to disclose her name.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- All of the election returns have been received at the office of the Secretary of State, those from Kings County arriving to-day.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- Municipal elections were held to-day in eleven cities of the commonwealth, including Boston, and surprises were the result in several cases, both as regards candidates elected and the vote on the question of licensing the sale of liquors.

"The Vestry of Trinity Church," said Col. S. Van Rensselaer Cruger, the Controller of the Trinity Church Corporation, yesterday, to a reporter for The New-York Times, "has decided not to make any public statement in regard to the condition of its tenement property. That is all there is to say on the matter."

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The Manchester Guardian says that, as the result of a conference between Lord Rosebery and Lord Kimberley yesterday, the British Government demanded absolute freedom in the matter of reporting upon the situation in Armenia, and that the demand was at once conceded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The Secretary of the Interior has referred to the Attorney General for action by his department a detailed report by Francisco Estudillo, Indian Agent at the Tule River Mission, San Jacinto, Gal., as to the mysterious murder on the night of Sept. 20 last of Mrs. Mary J. Platt, the Government school teacher and Indian missionary at Pechanga, Cal.
The official inquiry into the alleged insanity of Mrs. Margaret A. Harrison was begun yesterday before a Sheriff's jury.

The account given by Lieut. Naoki Miyaoka, in last Sunday's Times, of the great naval engagement off the mouth of the Yalu, was, as all readers must agree, an exceedingly clear and instructive narrative. Nor did this officer's just pride in his country's success affect his professional view of its lessons, although the personal factors were surely potent and the Chinese officers and men were outfought all the way through.
A poorly-dressed, middle-aged man, speaking German only, entered a large establishment in West Fourteenth Street yesterday morning and made a tour of the different departments.

The presentation of Secretary Carlisle's plan for bank currency has already led to several distinct and valuable advantages, quite independent of the merits and defects of the plan itself. The chief of these undoubtedly is the effect on the public opinion of the South and West.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Postmaster Charles W. Dayton of New-York came to Washington to-night, and will remain until Saturday. He was accompanied by C.O. Shepard, Chief of The Salaries and Allowance Division of the Post Office Department, who, with Superintendent Augustus W. Machen of the free-delivery service, has been making a thorough investigation of the needs of the New-York Post Office in the matter of improved facilities and an increased force of employes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The National Civil Service Reform League convened in this city at the rooms of the Commerce Club at 11 o'clock to-day. A distinguished gathering of representatives from all over the country was present. The first meeting was one of the General and Executive Committees, which elected officers and a new Executive Committee for the ensuing year.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Sir John S.D. Thompson, Premier of the Dominion of Canada, died suddenly at Windsor at 1:45 P.M. today, shortly after the adjournment of the Council, which he had gone to Windsor to attend.

Dealers in pork, lard, flour, beans, and other lines of eatables, in which a large trade was developed with Spanish possessions in the West Indies while reciprocity was in force, believe now that this trade will be revived. The Spanish Government shut it off, when the new tariff abrogated the reciprocity treaties, by imposing prohibitive duties on American goods.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 12. -- Latest information from St. John's is to the effect that the worst fears of the panic will be realized. The Commercial Bank is a hopeless wreck, and nearly all its Directors, who are among the principal merchants, are also bankrupt. Those familiar with the inside facts have but little hope of the Union Bank resuming payments.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- The marriage of Prince Adolphus of Teck, brother of the Duchess of York, to Lady Margaret Grosvenor, daughter of the Duke of Westminster, the richest peer in the United Kingdom, took place in the chapel at Eaton Hall, Chester, one of the seats of the Duke of Westminster, at noon to-day.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Lord Dunraven has been asked for a final decision in regard to the answer to his challenge for the America's cup, but is unable to reply at present, as the matter has been referred to the Royal Yacht Squadron.

It is understood that a change will soon be made in the executive management of the Tradesmen's National Bank, at Broadway and Reade Street. The bank has paid no dividend for eighteen months. Some of its Directors think it ought to prosper in such a neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- When the Senate to-day finally got to the discussion of the Nicaragua Canal bill, Mr. Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) took the floor. He discussed the international question involved in the right of this Government to participate in the construction of the canal, in view of treaties with other powers.
Christine Mulfinger, a pretty German girl, was arrested yesterday on a charge of forgery in the second degree.
BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 12. -- The eightyfourth annual report of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions was published to-day. Following are some of its most interesting features:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 12. -- William H. Price, member of the firm of printing press manufacturers, Chandler Price, was almost instantly killed by a burglar at his home, 124 Hawthorne Avenue, at 2:30 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- James B. Babcock, chief of the draughting division of the Patent Office, was accidentally shot in the back by John B. Peyton at Wright's wharf, twenty miles down the river from this city, where they and Mr. Edelin had been spending a few days duck shooting. Mr. Babcock died at the Emergency Hospital at 5:30 P.M. to-day from the effects of the wound.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Many of the cracks entered in the amateur races, which introduce the big professional six-day cycling contest at Industrial Hall, practiced on the inclined track to-day and pronounced it well suited to rapid wheeling. The amateur races begin tomorrow evening and continue three nights, after which the endurance contest will occupy the boards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The President to-day nominated Henry H. Babcock to be Collector of Customs for the district of New-Haven, Conn. He also nominated Passed Assistant Engineer R.R. Leitch to be Chief Engineer and Assistant Engineer F.H. Conant to be Passed Assistant Engineer.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- John T. Ulrich of Plainfield, who is organizer of the State Republican League of New-Jersey and editor of The Royal Craftsman, a Masonic publication, was taken to the New-Jersey asylum to-day, suffering from dementia.

The agreement existing between the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company and its employes will expire Jan. 1 next, and since it was made there have been many changes against which employes of the company are protesting.

When the friends of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley Martin and W.K. Vanderbilt heard yesterday that the steamship Teutonic, from Liverpool, had been sighted off Sandy Hook at 4 o'clock A.M., and had reached Quarantine, despite the heavy fog, at 5 o'clock, they hurried down to the White Star pier, at the foot of West Tenth Street, to greet the home-comers with open arms and a warm welcome.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 12. -- The report of Gen. Butterworth's statement in regard to his son's injury in the recent Harvard-Yale game caused considerable comment in Cambridge. Harvard students, in general with players and coaches, all agree that such a statement of Butterworth's being intentionally injured, that he might be put out of the game, is absurd.

There was a stormy session of the Park Board yesterday. President Clausen excitedly accused Commissioner Bell of seeking newspaper notoriety, and Commissioner Bell accused the President of having a notoriety that he (Bell) would not have for a fortune. Commissioner Tappen then accused Commissioner Bell of misrepresenting him, and at one time refused to take part in the meeting.

PATERSON, Dec. 12. -- The speedy bowlers of the Brooklyn Cycle Club met the Tourist Cycle Club team here to-night and placed two games to their credit in the tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs. The first game was close and exciting, but the Brooklyn men came with a tremendous rush at the finish and won handily.

Mr. Goff's exposure of the abuses of the system of police pensions is much to be commended. The law relating to the pension fund has been an object of particular solicitude to the police, and they have never found any difficulty in having it tinkered to meet their views, no matter what the political complexion of the Legislature to which they applied.
FORSYTHE, Ga., Dec. 12. -- A terrific tornado struck Forsythe about 3 o'clock this morning. Many persons were injured, and a property loss of from $30,000 to $50,000 resulted.

ALBANY, Dec. 12. -- The Mortons, father, mother, and daughter, took a casual look over the Executive Mansion to-day, and left for New-York at 5 o'clock this afternoon. The Flowers will vacate the mansion next week, in order that the incoming Governor and his family may move into it such articles as they desire.

The civil service examination of Brooklyn policemen seems to be too much for them to master. Out of sixteen patrolmen last week, who were examined for promotion of Roundsmen, not one of them was able to secure the necessary 70 per cent. The highest percentage received was 66.

With the approach of the season when exports of gold are expected, close watch is kept in the financial district on the development of conditions that will draw gold to Europe. The indications in this respect are rates of foreign exchange and drafts on the Treasury reserve.

Across the front of the brick tenement 323 Hudson Street, between Vandam and Charlton Streets, is a long sign, extending nearly the full width of the building, on which appears, in letters distinguishable several blooks away:

JASPER, Tenn., Dec. 12. -- Martha Taylor, a middle-aged woman from the mountains, was wedded this afternoon to Gene Kennedy, who on Monday will be hanged with his younger brother, John. The ceremony was performed in a cell by the Rev. J. Beatty and was witnessed by the jail officials and a half dozen friends of the couple.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- It looked for a little while recently as if the elaborate ceremony which had been arranged for the dedication of the New-Hampshire statues in Statuary Hall of the House of Representatives, would have to be postponed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- It is still the same old Sugar Senate, after all. The lesson of the elections, is unheeded by it as completely as if it were a Senate of wooden images. The decision of the Democratic Party that the Sugar bill and the closure amendment should be suffered to die has been ratified by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Secretary Herbert to-day gave the Naval Committee of the Senate to understand that he does not favor the proposition of the House, made last session, to strip certain vessels of the navy of designated armor plates, in order that they may be subjected to ballistic tests.

The Wednesday Cotillion Association held its first dance at Sherry's fist evening, and the ball was, as it gave promise to be, one of the most brilliant ever given in New-York under the auspices of Southerners.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Weather Bureau has issued the following instructions:

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 12. -- Evidence is now well in hand to the effect that Harry Hayward was the local member of an insurance swindling gang whose operations extended over the country. Enough has been learned, however, to warrant the statement that the police are looking for at least three other men who are wanted in connection with the murder of Catherine Ging.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The income-tax provisions of the Tariff bill of 1894 will be carried out. The only chance discovered to nullify the law was that of refusing to appropriate the money to carry it out. When that was suggested as a way to kill the civil-service law it was denounced as an unworthy method by many who are opposed to the civil-service system.

The Quartet Hall alleys, in Washington Street, Hoboken, formed the battle ground for one of the two tournament contests in the Wheelmen's Bowling League. The opposing teams represented the Castle Point Cyclers and the Bushwick Wheelmen of Brooklyn. The tussle ended with honors even, each side getting a victory.

The Century Company has an important race on. The competitors hardly seem to belong to the same class, but as they are apparently fairly well matched, no one can put in any objections. Palmer Cox's Brownies are making a sturdy and persistent effort, in their inimitable way, to distance, in the popular estimation, "The Century Book for Young Americans."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Mr. Platt (Rep. Conn.,) addressed the Senate to-day on the bill to create the Territory of Indianola, out of a portion of the Indian Territory. For himself he preferred a Government by a commission, like that in the District of Columbia, but he supposed that it would be open to the objection that such a method was contrary to the American doctrine of self-government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Mrs. Bissell has as her guest Miss Love of Buffalo, in whose honor she gave a luncheon to-day. The room was fragrant with American Beauty roses, with which the table was decorated. The guests invited to meet Miss Love were: Mrs. Carlisle, Mrs. Olney, Mrs. Lamont, Mrs. Herenden, Mrs. Archibald Hopkins, Miss Stoughton, Miss Hamlin, Mrs. Endicott, and Mrs. Bowler.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Secretary of War is making rapid progress in his policy of weeding out the Indian soldiers of the army who were enlisted under the last Administration as an experiment in civilization.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 12. -- The sudden death of Sir John Thompson has cast a deep gloom over the city, and flags are flying at half mast on all public and many private buildings.

There was a large array of prominent Brooklyn people in Justice Neu's courtroom in the City Hall yesterday, when the Board of Excise held its weekly meeting to consider the applications for excise licenses.

Messrs. E. H. Ludlow Co. were the brokers in the sale of the college of Pharmacy property, 209 to 213 East Twentythird Street, hitherto reported in The NewYork Times. The purchasers are the Cass Realty Corporation, who will build a fireproff steel-skeleton six-story business structure on the site.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 12. -- A startling story is told by an officer about the unavoidable condition of things at the Ohio penitentiary. There are now 2,100 convicts confined there, only about 1,000 of them being employed at work, the balance remaining in the idle house. This condition waged brought about by the warfare waged against convict-made goods by labor organizations.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. - In the Reichstag today Herr von Kardorff, Free Conservative, declared that it was imperative that the present system of universal suffrage should be modified if there were any truth in the Radical assertion that the level of the members of the Reichstag had been lowered.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A somewhat acrimonious debate sprang up to-day while the House in Committee of the Whole, was considering the urgent deficiency bill.

The best estimates yesterday as to the result of the Republican primaries Tuesday night gave a victory to William Brookfield, the present County Chairman, over the opposition which has been making the fight against the present system of organization, for which Mr. Brookfield stands.

The most important point brought out before the Lexow committee yesterday was that the present city administration has stolen a march on Mayor-elect Strong by letting out valuable contracts for next year, thus keeping the patronage with Tammany Hall.

JAMAICA, L.I., Dec. 12. -- Frederick S. Allen, thirty-one years old, was arrested here last evening, charged with attempting to steal a horse and carriage. Allen says he is an agent of the Boston Land Company, and lives at 151 East Twentieth Street, New-York City.
Republican State Committeeman W.L. Proctor of St. Lawrence County told this story yesterday to a group of politicians at the Fifth Avenue Hotel:

News came yesterday by the steamer Allianca, from Colon, that the Pacific Steam Navigation Company's steamer Puno was boarded at Ilo and Pisco, in Peru, by order of the Peruvian Government, and search made for arms, , supposed to be on board, consigned to the Montaniros, or rebel party.

A pitiable case of destitution was brought to light yesterday morning by the discovery of an elderly man and his wife in a starving condition in a tiny shanty at One Hundred and Twenty-second Street and the Boulevard.

TORONTO Ontario, Dec. 12. -- The one topic of conversation on the streets, at the City Hall, in the clubs, and everywhere is the startling news of the death of Sir John Thompson at Windsor Castle. When the United Press bulletin was first posted it was generally believed to be incorrect, but when a confirmation speedily followed, it occasioned much excitement.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 12. -- The complaint upon which the warrant against Olney is issued is drawn toy State's Attorney John L. Hunter, and charges Mr. Olney with having received $2,632.25 in various sums from E.L. Gunn and T.K. Wilkins of Lima, Ohio, as Commissioners for loaning money of the school fund on real estate in Ohio.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 12. -- The lease of the Crescent Iron Works Shipyard, at Elizabeth-port, for five years, to Lewis Nixon, late Superintendent of the Cramps shipyard, Suprintendent was signed to-day in that city. Miller F. Moore, senior member of the Elizabethport firm, went to Philadelphia for that purpose.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 12. -- In the convention of the American Federation of Labor President Gompers to-day announced his committees on Resolutions, Organization, Grievances, and Local Federated Bodies. The Committee on Rules reported indorsing the rules of the last convention, with slight amendments as to the length of sessions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12. -- Gen. Antonio Ezeta, the exiled Vice President of Salvador, is about to return to his country and seek to replace President Guettierez. Two Salvadorean officers, Col. Jorge Duehl and Col. Meriano Pinto, have arrived here to induce Ezeta to accompany them back. They say that the people of Salvador are anxiously awaiting Ezeta's return, eager to enlist under his banner.

Guthrie, Oklahoma, Dec. 12. -- Prof. Austin, Principal of the Lincoln School, is accused of brutally beating Buela Smith, aged sixteen, his pupil. It is said he beat her with a bell rope and pulled out tufts of her hair. Then he threw her down and jumped on the girl's breast, breaking four ribs and producing internal injuries from which it is feared she will die.

The percentage of increased railway earnings for the first week of December will probably be much larger than at any other time since the panic. Reports thus far published show a decided improvement even over the favorable conditions that prevailed last month. A large proportion of the roads report increased earnings, and in most instances where decreased earnings are reported the figures are small as compared with the losses of the past few weeks.

John T. Stephenson, who had been degraded from the rank of Captain of Police in the Fifth Precinct and dismissed from the service, was convicted yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer of accepting a bribe of four baskets of peaches from Martin W. Edwards.
Controller Fitch discharged two clerks yesterday, and suspended judgment in the case of another.

SHELBYVILLE, Ind., Dec. 12. -- R.H. Capehart, Justice of the Peace at Velpin, Pike County, while trying a railroad man, whose name is unknown, for some minor offense, was struck on the head by the prisoner and almost instantly killed, the murderer escaping in the confusion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The local stock market to-day was featureless. Trading was on a limited scale, and fluctuations were narrow. West Chicago was less active but firmer, sales being made at 129 1/2. There was a fair amount of business in Alley L, but the market showed no decided tendency either way; most of the trading was at 23, or fractionally better.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- There was plain talk to-day before the Banking and Currency Committee of the House on the Carlisle plan for the reform of the currency. Several features of the plan were objected to by George A. Butler of New-Haven, and in a letter from Lyman J. Gage of Chicago other objections were made to it, principally on the ground that it would lead to expansion of the currency.

The passage of the bill amending the antipooling clause of the Inter-State Commerce act by the House of Representatives by a much larger majority than had been anticipated was received with satisfaction by holders of railway securities, and to the fact was attributed the much better feeling which prevailed on yesterday's stock market.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 12. -- Charles L. Buck of New-York, Vice President of the Yellow Pine Company of that city, appeared in the United States District Court here to-day as plaintiff in a suit against the Florida Central and Peninsular Railway Company, to recover $50,000 paid by the old firm of L. Bucki Son in excess of freight charges.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 12. -- Nothing for years so shocked this city as did the news of the death of Sir John Thompson. He was born and brought up in Halifax and was personally known by nearly every one in the city. Men of both political parties are outdoing each Other in their expressions of heartfelt regret at the taking off of their honored fellow-townsman.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- John M. Crane, President of the National Shoe and Leather Bank, arrived here this afternoon, and was taken immediately to the Central Station, where, in the Inspector's office, Samuel C. Seely, the defaulter, was brought before him.

The eleventh subscription night of the current season at the Metropolitan Opera House was devoted to the performance of Gounod's "Faust," which had been offered once at a matinee. The attractiveness of this ever fresh and melodious work, when presented with a strong cast seems to be perennial.

Railroad men were unanimous yesterday In their expressions of approval of the action of the House of Representatives in passing the bill to permit the pooling of railway business. There is a general expectation that the bill will become a law.

It is high but merited praise to say that the address of Mr. Carl Schurz, as President of the National Civil Service Reform League, at the annual meeting at Chicago, ranks with those which the late Mr. Curtis made for so many years. It consists, as did each of those, of a statement of the purpose of the reform, a review of its progress during the year, and indications of the work to be done.
Comedian William H. Crane had a very amusing experience in Philadelphia last Sunday, which he related at the Lambs Club yesterday afternoon.

The fact that a Police Captain has been brought to trial and convicted of levying blackmail is in itself so gratifying that it is an occasion for public rejoicing. Without any desire to comment upon Capt. Stephenson's case in particular, however, we may call attention to the plea of his counsel, which was that the accuser, who testified to paying blackmail, was a "self-confessed criminal."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The marriage of Miss Mary Sherman, daughter of Senator Sherman of Ohio, and Mr. James Iver McCallum of this city took place at noon today at the handsome home of the Shermans on K Street.
Auguste Laureut Burdean. Auguste Laurent Burdeau, President of the French Chamber of Deputies, died in Paris yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- The opposition to the present management of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company has assumed formal shape by the announcement of a committee having been formed to solicit proxies for the annual election, for the creation of a new management. The committee names no candidate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A New-York paper this morning published a long story concerning what it described as "Secretary Gresham's woes" about the situation in Nicaragua. The story is attributed, at the State Department, to "the man with the sore toe," that afflicted author being a Republican person who was found by the Secretary in a very lucrative office and removed to make room for a Democrat.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Father Longinoto, vicar of St. Edward's Church, in Windsor, performed last evening a service for the dead over the body of Sir John Thompson. Sir Charles Tupper, the master of the Queen's household, and most of the members of the household were present.

The sessions of the Senate investigating committee yesterday were prolific of sensations. During the morning, after hearing more about brutality on the part of policemen. Mrs Kate Monahan told how she had been sent from pillar to post when she endeavored to get rid of alleged disorderly houses in her neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Senator Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) to-day asked unanimous consent to have the vote on the Nicaragua Canal bill taken next Thursday at 3 o'clock, but objection was made by Mr. Caffery, (Dem., La.) Mr. Morgan then resumed his argument in support of the bill.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The congested condition of the Buffalo docket of the Eighth Judicial District is beyond all precedent, and a determined effort is to be made to clear it. The docket now contains over 600 cases, and arrangements have been made for a continuous session of the court until July 30, 1895, during most of which time two branches will be running.

"I don't think that a straight Republican ticket could have been successful at the recent election," said Joseph Larocque, Chairman of the Committee of Seventy, to a reporter for The New-York Times, who asked him yesterday if he thought it proper that the recent victory in this city should be called a Republican victory.
BURLINGTON, N.J., Dec. 13. -- Bridget Doyle lies at her home probably dying from a stab wound in the abdomen, and exCouncilman I. Snowden Haines is suffering from gunshot wounds in the back and legs.

What will our Republican friends say now about the attitude of their party in the Senate toward the discriminating duty of 1-10 of a cent a pound on sugar from Germany and the Trust's protective differential of 1/8 of a cent on sugar that has been refined.
A correspondent who labors under certain erroneous impressions writes to us the following letter:

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 13. -- The first murder growing out of the investigation into City Hall corruption occurred shortly afternoon to-day, when ex-Crier Jeff Davis of the Criminal Court shot and instantly killed ex-Deputy Sheriff George Boya.

The annual reception of the University Settlement Society was held last night at the Guild House, 26 Delancey Street. More than 200 society women and men interested in the work of this famous and succesful charity organization were present.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Dec. 13. -- A big safe, owned by the city, was removed, several months ago, from the railroad office of ex-Mayor Gleason, in Front Street, and taken to the City Hall. What the safe contained has never been made public. It was thought it held public documents.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The International Metal Company, with principal office in New-York City, was incorporated to-day, with the Secretary of State, to carry on the business of mining ores and of dealing in the products of ores, not including the buying of gold or silver bullion or foreign coins.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The report of the Board of Visitors to the United States Military Academy submitted to Congress yesterday contains a number of recommendations for the improvement of the system of education at that institution, of which the following are the most important:

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- There was a largely increased attendance at to-day's session of the National Civil Service Reform League Convention. The meeting opened with the reading of the following report of the Committee on Resolutions:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- As stated in a dispatch to The New-York Times yesterday, the Committee on Banking and Currency has concluded to report a currency bill to the House on Monday. Mr. Cox, a member of the committee, asserts this purpose today, and he says that the bill will be that submitted by Mr. Carlisle.
NASHUA, N.H., Dec. 13. -- Frank A. McKean, cashier of the Indian Head National Bank, has not been in the city since last Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- The cruiser Minneapolis, which has been at the League Island Navy Yard for the last few days, whither she was taken from Cramps' Shipyard, was placed in commission at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The ceremonies were brief. Since the sister ship of the Columbia has been at the League Island yard, she has been under the charge of Capt. McCurley of the navy yard.

Mr. George R. Read has sold for Mrs. Rebecca E. Brown, to Thomas G. Shortland, at $32,500, the four-story brick building, with store, 15 South William Street, extending through to Stone Street, about 90 feet deep, with fronts of 15 and 18 feet.

There was a rear-end collision on the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad, at Nostrand and Lexington Avenues, at 6 o'clock last evening. Several women were slightly injured. The rear car of the forward train was damaged considerably, the engine of the rear train was smashed, and travel was delayed for three hours.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- A nine days' bicycle tournament began here to-night at Industrial Hall, with four races between Class A men. None of to-night's races was finished, only the preliminary heats being ridden off. The attendance was not large, only about 20O people being present.

So much time has been taken up by the Lexow committee in showing up the corruption of the police force that its brutality has received something less than justice. Indeed, the brutality of the police is that one of its vices that is more obvious than its corruption and equally fatal to its efficiency.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 13. -- This evening at 6 o'clock, at the First Presbyterian Church, Miss Amy Hurd, daughter of John Kurd, the lumberman of the Adirondacks, formerly of this city, was married to Cuyler Shaw of Albany, N.Y., by the Rev. H.A. Davenport. The church was, filled with fashionable people.

There was a good deal of excitement at the Herald Square Theatre yesterday morning, ending in the unsuccessful chase of a thief, which made of West Thirty-fifth Street one of the liveliest thoroughfares of the city for a few minutes.
Mr. J.M. Coonan has sold to F.R. McDermott ten lots at the northwest corner of Fortieth Street and Fort Hamilton Avenue, at about $6,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The Treasury gold reserve at the close of business to-day had been reduced to $101,050,000. The withdrawals to-day amounted to $1,450,000 at New-York, with reported withdrawals at Boston in redemption of United States notes.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- Mrs. T.J. Simmons, wife of Chief Justice Simmons of Georgia, called upon Mayor Stuart this afternoon and preferred a request to him that Philadelphia allow the old Liberty Bell to be taken to the coming Cotton States and International Exposition, to be held at Atlanta next year.

Gotham's only representative in the wheelmen's bowling tournament, the Manhattan Bicycle Club team, paid the Brooklyn Bicycle Club "five" a visit at the Elephant alleys, in Brooklyn, last evening, and, according to one of the defeated men, "got it in the neck." By this it is supposed that he meant the Manhattans were badly whipped.

RAHWAY, N.J., Dec. 13. -- The Union County Roadsters thoroughly redeemed themselves tonight on the alleys after the stinging defeat administered to them Tuesday night by the Manhattans. They beat the strong Kings County Wheelmen, 873 to 805 in the first game, and 875 to 742 in the second.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 13. -- A big deal was consummated here to-day involving from $6,000,000 to $8,000,000, which will make Toledo the most important oil centre in the Ohio field, and at the same time will give the Standard Oil Company a new and formidable competitor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- When the House to-day in Committee of the Whole resumed consideration of the Urgent Deficiency bill -- the pending question being the amendment offered by Mr. Henderson (Rep., Iowa,) to reduce the amount of the appropriation for special pension agents from $250,000 to $125,000 -- Mr. Hicks (Rep., Penn.,) took the floor to advocate the amendment.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall will be called before the end of this month, probably just after Christmas. This will in all probability be followed by meetings of the Tammany Committee on Organization and the General Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A protest signed by a number of Europeans and one American residing in Japan has been, it is said, filed with the State Department against the confirmation by the Senate of the recent treaty concluded between the United States and Japan. The protest, it is alleged, comes from those whose interests and privileges will be curtailed by the treaty.

The conviction of a man who had but recently held the autocratic position of a New-York Police Captain, his incarceration, with other offenders, in the Tombs prison, and the possibility that he may serve a ten years' sentence as a convict in stripes-those were the unprecedented announcements over which the metropolitan civilians wondered and metropolitan policemen worried yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Capt. Thomas H. McKee, Assistant Secretary of the Republican Congressional Committee, announces that he no longer is a candidate for Clerk of the House ou Representatives in the Fifty-fourth Congress. He says circumstances have arisen which warrant his withdrawal from the field of candidates, but declines to say what the circumstances are.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 13. -- The farmers of South Carolina are much pleased with the corn crop, which is the largest grown in the State since the war, and is all paid for. The hog-and-hominy policy will control on the farm in 1895, as it largely has controlled in the present year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day approved the income tax regulations. Every citizen of the United States, whether residing at home or abroad, and every person residing or doing business in the United States who has an annual income of more than $3,500, is required to make return, under oath, before the first Monday in March of each year.
Adjt. Gen. Josiah Porter was stricken with apoplexy Wednesday night.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 13. -- This morning, at 10:30 o'clock, a man believed to be William Good of 35 Hawkins Street, was knocked down by one of the Bowery cars, either No. 16 or No. 19, on Market Street, between Chambers and Frederick Streets.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- One of the officials of the Colonial Office said, in an interview this morning, that the late Government of Newfoundland had asked the Home Government for assistance to weather the financial storm. Nothing had been done in the matter, he said, and it remained to be seen whether the successors of the late Government would renew the request.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 13. -- Joseph W. Reinhart, ex-President and late receiver of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe system of railway lines, accompanied by his attorney, Charles W. Moyer, left Pittsburg for New-York last evening. Mr. Reinhart was requested to make some statement as to the possible future of the property and the causes of his relinquishing the receivership.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13. -- J.H. Turner, a real estate dealer, has been arrested for obtaining money under false pretenses on two charges, aggregating $20,000. It is said, however, that Turner's swindling operations will aggregate nearly $500,000, with many victims. He is charged with mortgaging property of which he is not the owner, and of selling the same land to several purchasers.

Mr. Olmsted has read the Park Board a lecture which is all the more edifying and all the more severe because of its tone of mild and temperate exposition. He declined, in the first place, to advise the board upon the landscape treatment of the speedway except in conjunction with the board's regular professional adviser.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 13. -- The Populist contests referred to in these dispatches some days ago have begun. Notice has beer served by Populist competitors upon Allen in the First; Money, in the Fourth; Will iams, in the Fifth, and Spencer, in the Seventh Congressional District. In addition to numerous charges of fraud on the day of and leading up to the election, it is alleged that Article XII.
Even New-York and New-Jersey lawyers are sometimes deceived by oily-tongued individuals, who tell them heartrending tales and promise them princely fees.
