The officers of the American National Red Cross have issued from their headquarters in Washington an interesting statement concerning the origin, history, and methods of the association, together with an outline of what the Japanese branch is doing for humanity's sake in the war now waging in the East.

"Suppose Martin gives the lie to Reppenhagen; what then? Doesn't it block Creeden's confession? Won't it stop the stampede of those in a hurry to secure immunity?" were comments -- born, perhaps, of hope -- in police circles yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 16. -- The committee for the third annual joint play of the two junior societies of Yale, Psi U. and D.K.E., is already hard at work on a new play that will be given during the month of May, as in previous years. The regular burlesque will be presented, containing musical selections, topical songs, specialties, and choruses that were so successful last year.

"If John Martin does not meet the accusation of John W. Reppenhagen that he received $10,000 of the $15,000 collected in the interest of Capt. Creeden," said Justice John R. Voorhis yesterday, "I shall insist on being heard by the Lexow committee."

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- According to the agreement between the University of Pennsylvania and Cornell, the question for the intercollegiate debate is selected alternately. This year it was Pennsylvania's turn to select a subject, and the following was recently decided upon and forwarded to Ithaca:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Charles M. Roberts, accompanied by his wife and five children, walked into Plice Headquarters and asked Lieut. Astley for lodgings for himself and family last night. The man was tall, a typical Southerner in appearance, and his wife and family were like himself, neat and clean.

The market during last week was not characterized with the snap that has prevailed during the past six weeks; not that prices showed any decline, but as many investors and institutions are now closing up their books preparatory to the first of the year they are not in the market. After the first of the year bond dealers are looking for an active demand for bonds, and if it comes, higher prices will probably prevail.

The confession of Policeman and Ward Man Augustus J. Thorne to Assistant District Attorney Lindsay does away with the necessity and expense of negotiating with pensioner and ex-Ward Man James Kelly, who fled to Ireland last Summer after giving his wife a power of attorney to draw his money at Police Headquarters.

BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- The majority of Deputies are not eager to begin the debate on the Anti-Socialist bill next Tuesday. When, two weeks ago, the date for the first reading was fixed, there were protests from all sides except the Conservatives. The party leaders appealed to the President to postpone the debate until after the Christmas recess, and Herr von Levetsow seemed inclined to assent.
The Lexow committee and its counsel will not, on the eve of adjournment, deviate from their policy of absolute secrecy in regard to their plans of investigation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 15 -- The local stock market for the week shows the usual conditions at this time of the year, and until after the holidays no material activity is to be expected. The bank stock list continues quiet, with but few transactions, and prices as a rule are fairly well sustained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Members of the Senate have received word that within a day or two an attack is to be made all along the line against the treaty with Japan that was sent to the Senate on Dec. 6, and which, it was supposed, would be promptly ratified without objection worth mentioning.
Brooklyn had a novelty yesterday in the nature of a comparatively dry Sunday. Many of the 4,500 saloons were tightly closed, but there were several places where a lively side-door business was done.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed an increase in reserve of $443,175. The banks now hold $33,345,825 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $862,200, an increase in specie of $6,375,900, a decrease in legal tenders of $6,244,200, a decrease in deposits of $1,246,300, and a decrease in circulation of $29,900.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- A lecture on "Scientific Football" was given last Saturday evening by two Yale graduates of '94, Mr. Cochran, assisted by Mr. Lounsbury.

At least 100 men who were candidates and several hundred of their friends will read with feelings of regret that Governor-elect Morton has about made up his mind not to appoint the twelve new Justices of the Supreme Court, whom some politicians thought he had authority to appoint under the new Constitution.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Lord Rosebery has asked F.S. Stevenson, M.P., as Chairman of the Anglo-Armenian Association, that a deputation be appointed at the mass meeting to be held here to-morrow to submit to Lord Kimberley of the Foreign Office the resolutions there adopted.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 16 -- The conservative element in the Yale Faculty have taken an action which, similar to that begun at Cornell and recommended by President Eliot of Harvard, shows a strong current of sentiment on athletic matters. At the last Faculty meeting a professor introduced a motion that hereafter all Yale athletic contests be limited to this city.

The drought, which was accompanied by siroccos at short intervals, that prevailed from Western Texas to Central Minnesota during portions of last July and August, and which blasted the corn crop of six States, has proved to be a most potent educational factor to Western farmers, and is undoubtedly the greatest blessing that has been bestowed on Western American agriculture for many years.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Carl S. Williams, the newly-elected Captain of the University of Pennsylvania eleven, is one of the active football men who do not favor any radical changes in the rules of the game. Speaking of the proposed alterations to a New-York Times correspondent, he said:
Referring editorially to the decision of the railroads to charge for the transportation of cycles and baby carriages, the Michigan Cyclist says:

HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Archbishop Hughes of New-York sent the Rev. John Rogers to this city fifty years ago to open a mission and begin the work of establishing a Roman Catholic parish. Father Rogers was succeeded in 1848 by the Rev. Father Kelly, but the idea was abandoned five months later, to be resumed in 1851 by the Rev. Father Cauvin.
Reformer Thomas C. Platt was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening, and entertained in his rooms two or three local politicians, among them being Jacob M. Patterson and Edward Lauterbach.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Washington Star has made an editorial suggestion that is likely to meet with a good deal of Congressional approval. At a meting of the Senate Committee on the District of Columbia, held on Friday, Gen. Casey, Chief of Engineers, United States Army, was agreed upon as a member of the commission to have charge of the construction of a municipal building for Washington, whenever it shall be built.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The Central News correspondent in Antong telegraphed late in the evening of Dec. 14:
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 16 -- The Stevens Colliery, in West Pittston, operated by Jenkins Co., was the scene of considerable excitement at a late hour last night.

JACKSON, Mich., Dec. 16 -- Forty young children were thrown into a panic last night at the home of Mrs. George C. Truesdell by the accidental tipping over of a large stand lamp in the parlor. The children, none of whom was over twelve years of age, were participating in a birthday party.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16 -- The committee of Republicans appointed to inquire into the propriety and policy of contesting the Congressional elections in the First, Third, and Fourth Districts has decided that no efforts should be made to unseat Mr. Miles in the First District nor John K. Cowen in the Fourth.
The funeral of Gen. Josiah Porter will be held at 2.30 o'clock this afternoon at St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue.

The body of Abraham Keyser, a retired grocer, was found in the Hutchinson River, near Pelham Bay Park, Westchester County, last Tuesday. Mr. Keyser's mind was weak. He left his home, 425 East Eighty-third Street, Oct. 19 to go to see his son Lester, who keeps a grocery at 1,410 Second Avenue.

The movement for municipal reform in New-York has been gloriously carried through its first stage under the admirable direction of three men, Dr. Parkhust, Mr. Charles S. Smith, and Mr. Goff -- each having been the leader in a different sphere. Mr. Smith's efforts, least open to popular observation, have received the smallest share of the reward they deserve.

The reports of the progress of the Massachusetts Cattle Commission's campaign for the eradication of bovine tuberculosis in that State are quite interesting to those who know how desirable it is that dairy herds, as well as herds of cattle to be slaughtered for beef, should be free from this disease.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 17. -- Newell G. Benjamin, a well-to-do jeweler here, reached home from Albany at 5:45 A.M. to-day. Finding the doors of his house, at 126 Applegate Avenue, locked, he smashed in a window and climbed in. He entered the parlor, and, placing a revolver at his right temple, pulled the trigger.

From The Buffalo Times of Dec. 12. The Chicago organization styling itself the "Associated Press," but which has no relation to the original Associated Press, is doing considerable explaining these days, a sure sign of pending defeat. Manager Stone's latest fairy tale is that his concern has been annexing United Press papers at the rate of three per week for a year.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 17 -- John McBride is well known throughout the country, and especially through the mining regions, because of his activity in all matters affecting the miners. He is recognized as one of the ablest and most conservative of the labor leaders of the country.

Messrs, Smyth Ryan have sold, for Jefferson M. Levy, to Mother Superior Francis Xavier Cabrini of the Silesian Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart the four-story brick buildings 226 East Twentieth Street, 95 by 92, formerly occupied by the Post-Graduate Hospital, at about $65,000.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 17. -- Dr. Charles W. Dabney, Chairman of the Government commission, is here perfecting details for the United States Government exhibit at the exposition here next year. The Government will take charge of the building to be erected by the exposition company for minerals and forestry, and will furnish those exhibits.

--George W. Cram was put on trial in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning. He is charged with the murder of his wife, Rachel. The prisoner is sixty years old. His wife was fifty-four. Before the talesmen were called in for examination, counsel for the defense asked for an adjournment, in order to give time for further preparation.

Tennyson's "Idyls of the King" are again before us as operatic material. Goldmark's "Merlin" will be remembered as a former production based upon these tender and sensitive poems. The new work is called "Elaine." The book is by Paul Ferrier and the music by Herman Bemberg, a young gentleman born in Buenos Ayres, but nurtured in the atmosphere of Paris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Army officers in Washington approve the suggestion of placing retired officers in charge of the street-cleaning divisions in New-York City. Adjt. Gen. Ruggles sees no objection to the retired officers performing this class of work. In fact, similar duties have been performed by officers on the retired list and on leave.
Inability at this time to do a profitable business has decided the Directors of the Federal Bank, situated at 504 Third Avenue, corner, of Thirty-fourth Street, to liquidate its affairs.

GEORGETOWN, S.C., Dec. 17. -- President Cleveland and party arrived here at 6:10 o'clock this morning in the private car Wildwood. Owing to the early hour at which they came, very few people were at the station. It was rumored on Saturday night that the President was coming, but up to that time, and even yesterday, it was denied by those who had charge of the plans.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- An evening paper, referring to its Nashua (N.H.) special, which says that Embezzling Cashier Frank A. McKean of the Indian Head National Bank, is liable to return there, and that his friends would come to his rescue and save him from punishment, says that, in view of what has been learned to-day, this action is extremely doubtful.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Fuller information concerning the reported massacre of Chinese by the Japanese troops after the fall of Port Arthur was received by the Japanese Minister. Mr. Kurino, this morning from Mr. Mutsu, the Minister of Foreign Affairs at Tokio. Mr. Mutsu says in his dispatch that the Government is not yet in possession of all the facts about the alleged atrocities, but that many details have been ascertained.

A large assemblage at the cathedral fair, at the Grand Central Palace, last evening listened to an address by Chauncey M. Depew, who, at the special invitation of Archbishop Corrigan, was the guest of the managers of the fair. On his arrival, Mr. Depew was received by Father Lavelle of the cathedral, and John D. Crimmins.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- The six-day professional bicycle race that was to have started in Industrial Hall at 12:05 o'clock this morning did not begin on schedule time owing to a squabble between the riders and the management over the possible insufficiency of gate receipts. The crowd was not large and the half dozen prospective contestants were not satisfied that the percentage of receipts would be sufficient to guarantee their beginning such a contest.
RHINECLIFF-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- Governor-elect Morton made the following announcement this evening:

The America's Cup Committee met yesterday afternoon at ex-Commodore Smith's office on Broad Street to discuss the latest message received from the Royal Yacht Squadron. Those present were James D. Smith, Chairman; A. Cass Canfield, Secretary; Archibald Rogers, C. Oliver Iselin, Latham A. Fish, J.F. Tams, and Gouverneur Kortright.

The New-York State Society of Colonial Wars will hold its third general court and business meeting to-morrow night at the Hotel Waldorf. This will be the two hundred and nineteenth anniversary of the great swamp fight in King Philip's war of 1675, when the Indian warriors were defeated with great slaughter by the colonists.
The predictions, roorbachs, and "statements" published yesterday in regard to the Police Department and the Lexow committee lacked neither variety nor sensationalism.

(All communications for this column must be addressed to the "City Editor, The New-York Times." Matter which correspondents desire to have used in the Sunday edition of The Times must reach this office not later than Thursday evening.) M. Bagby's Musical Morning. -- The main drawing room of the Waldorf was crowded yesterday morning with fashionable folk, who attended Albert Morris Bagby's musical morning.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 18 -- The South Windsor murderer, John Cronin, who shot Albert J. Skinner in that town a year and a half ago, was executed in the State prison, at Wethersfield, this morning soon after midnight. The execution was the first to take place under the new law requiring the death penalty to be carried out at the State prison.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill was reported to the House to-day. It carries an appropriation of $1,562,118, which is a decrease of $1,800 from the appropriation for the current fiscal year. Three thousand dollars is appropriated as compensation for the services rendered by John Bassett Moore in compiling the diplomatic correspondence of the Revolution.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The Board of Aldermen at its last regular meeting was notified that the courts had declared unconstitutional the law for electing Freeholders by Assembly districts, and also that appointments must be made to hold until May 1. To-night the election was held, resulting as follows:

A few years ago the pretty gowns worn in the first act of "The Masqueraders" at the Empire Theatre would have aroused unrestrained enthusiasm and pens would have been busy describing and descanting. These are not the days, however, when tinsel, cotton velvet, and curtain lace make up stage finery, and the expectant audience discreetly reserved their enthusiasm for the next act.

There was an imposing ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary Star of the Sea in Court Street, near Luquer, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, when the Rev. Father Joseph C. O'Connell was formally invested with the robes of a Monsignor by Bishop McDonnell.

Over 2,000 officers and members of the National Guard attended the funeral of Adit. Gen. Josiah Porter at St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. Most of them were in citizen's dress, the family having expressed a wish that there be no military display beyond the regular escort.

The murder of Gilbert Cooper, an inmate of the Blackwell's Island Almshouse, was reported to the Coroner yesterday. Dr. Weston will to-day make an autopsy on the body, which was sent to the City Morgue. Cooper was sixty-seven years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Post Office Department has received information that certain "fake" jewelry concerns are operating an extensive swindling scheme, and that Postmasters in different parts of the country are being made the innocent means of furthering the designs of the swindlers.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Caroline Lexow, wife of Allan Lexow, a brother of Senator Lexow, was a defendant in the Hudson County Circuit Court this afternoon on contract for debt. The creditor who sued is Leo Thorsh, a farmer at Nanuet, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. Lexow reside at 901 Hudson Street, Hoboken. Mr. Lexow is Treasurer of the New-York Hack Company.

NEWARK, Dec. 17 -- Funeral services for the late James Smith, Sr., father of Senator Smith, were held at the cathedral at 10 o'clock this morning, in the presence of a large number of the friends of the deceased and his family.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Two requests have been received from the leading cities in the Southern States, whose chief newspapers comprise the Southern Associated Press:

Wilkesbarre, Penn., Dec. 17. -- On Saturday next all the mines now in operation in the Wyoming and Lackawanna regions will shut down work for the remainder of this year. A prominent official said: "It Cannot fail to have a good effect upon the market. By the first of next year the stock on hand will be nearly exhausted, and there will be a brisk demand for all sizes of coal by that time."

FLUSHING, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The North Baptist Church, over which the Rev. D. Chockley, commonly known as the "Fighting Parson," presides, held services as usual yesterday. Eighteen members, who have not yet determined whether they will support the pastor and Mrs. Moulton or Deacon Thornton and Mrs. Parks in the controversy as to who shall conduct the affairs of the church, and, incidentally, play the organ, were present.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 17 -- President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor was to-day defeated for re-election, and the headquarters of the federation were ordered removed to Indianapolis. New-York was selected as the place for holding the next convention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The judgment of the United States Court for the District of Massachusetts in the case of Asa P. Potter, President of the Maverick National Bank of Boston, was reversed by the Supreme Court to-day in an opinion read by Justice Brewer.

"The Amazons,'' which drew large audiences at the Lyceum for many weeks last season, was revived there last night for a fortnight only, though its reception was warm enough to justify a longer run. The cast has not been changed, except in the substitution of "sabel Irving for Georgia Cayvan in the part of Lady Noelline.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The report of the Republican members of the Banking and Currency Committee on the Carlisle Banking bill begins with the statement that the signers "most heartily and enthusiastically join with the Democratic majority of the committee in repudiating the measure."

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- Local stocks were not very active, and the tone of the market was somewhat mixed. There was no special feature. Gas was quiet, selling down to 10 1/8, with the first bonds steady at 80, and the seconds 1 lower, at 57. It is reported that bids of 100 were made for Brookline Gas stock on the street to-day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 17 -- Harry Hayward was arraigned in the District Court this afternoon for the murder of Catherine Ging. The indictment charged murder in the first degree, and the court allowed him until Saturday to plead.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Miner's Theatre was the scene of a notable gathering of society people to-night, the occasion being the "Spielkartenfest" arranged for the benefit of the Home for the Friendless. One side of the house was decorated in violet and the other in yellow, and the occupants on seats on the respective sides wore chrysanthemums to match in color.
Archbishop Corrigan and Father Ducey met yesterday morning, and everything looks as if a reconciliation had taken place.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- At a meeting, of delegates from clubs and other organizations Interested, this afternoon, a resolution was adopted that the delegates pledge themselves to do all in their power to induce the State of Illinois to take the Lincoln Monument out of the hands of the Monument Association, which now has control of it, and turn it over to the control of State authorities.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 17. -- The Novosti says that the best pledge England and Russia can give of the mutual sincerity of their understanding is joint, forcible intervention in Armenia. The writer advocates a policy which will culminate in Armenia's independence.

Stock speculation was exceedingly tame yesterday, and prices were only slightly changed. The opening was quiet, with the industrials and Grangers under some pressure. Chicago Gas developed weakness, and sold below 70, although it recovered to that figure at the close, scoring a net loss of 1/2.
Hamilton Fish was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night, accompanied by Louis F. Payn and others who sympathize with him in his contest for the Speakership.

Thirty Republican conventions, one in each Assembly District of the city, will be held to-night. They will elect members of the Republican County Committee and officers of the Assembly District associations.

Undoubtedly the most exciting games played thus far in the bowling tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs were the two rolled last evening by the "fives" representing the Montauk Wheelmen and the Brooklyn Bicycle Club. The sport took place at the Acme Hall alleys, in Ninth Street, Brooklyn, and was attended by more enthusiasm than is usual on such inspiring occasions.

In the Supreme Court, before Justice Patterson, yesterday, Lydia Katz began the contest over the will of her mother, Jeannette Gerstle, who died in January, 1891. She made her will in June, 1890, her estate being valued at $50,000. The defendants in the suit are Robert J. Gerstle and Celia Schnaier, executors, and a brother and sister of the contestant.

As Virginius, Wilson Barrett looks well and acts with sufficient strength and the tact of an experienced and tasteful actor. He does not force the scene even in the famous "patience" speech. His posing is apt to be a trifle too elaborate, but his poses are all graceful. He sets "Virginius" with fine pictures.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- A mass meeting was held this evening under the auspices of the Armenian Society. Several delegations from foreign cities were present. Francis Seymour Stevenson, M.P., Chairman of the Anglo-Armenian Association, presided. He read a leter from Mr. Gladstone, who was unable to accept his invitation to be present, but sent these words of encouragement:

Sister Franchise of the French Order of Registe is at the point of death in the Harlem Hospital as a result of injuries by being struck by a cable car near One Hundred and Third Street and Third Avenue yesterday afternoon.

The members of Sorosis had a pleasant gathering in the parlors of Sherry's yesterday afternoon, when J. Wells Champney told them many interesting things about pastels after the monthly business meeting.

From The Washington Star. The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage, accompanied by his daughter, was recently a guest at the Arlington for several days. Every time the distinguished divine scratches his name down on a hotel register, somebody who owns an autograph album spies it, and the hotel people are straightway requested to take charge of the volume, and get Mr. Talmage "to write something in it."

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- About 150 members of the Young Men's Democratic Club of Massachusetts attended its seventh annual dinner at the Quincy House this eveing. At the annual meeting in the afternoon the reports of the Secretary and Treasurer were presented, the platform already published was adopted, and officers were elected, with Charles E. Stratton of Boston President, Eben S. Stevens of Dudley Secretary, and Robert Treat Paine, Jr., of Boston, Treasurer.

Ex-Assemblyman John Martin, who is wanted as a witness by the Lexow committee, was reported yesterday as being very low at his home, Bleecker and Jones Streets. His mother said his left side was completely paralyzed.

On the day that Napoleon first put on uniform as a sous-lieutenant of artillery he presented himself in Mme. Parmon's salon and her cruel young daughters burst into a fit of laughter at the absurd appearance of his boots, which were "so high and wide that his little thin legs seemed buried in them."

H.S. Henry of Philadelphia has made up his mind that it is cheaper to catch tarpon than to breed trotters. Mr. Henry recently figured in this city in a suit brought against Monroe Salisbury, the California manager of race horses, in which he sought to recover the value of a brood mare, which he claimed was several years older than represented when he bought her.

We published on the 21st ult. a summary of the interesting report of Dr. A. Campbell White concerning the effect of the blood-serum treatment for diphtheria in twenty cases at the Willard Hospital, which had been selected for a test of the new remedy on account of their severity. This was the first addition from an American hospital to the long statistical record from German and French hospitals as to the value of the antitoxine.

-- The Maryland Trust Company gives notice that the time for depositing the bonds of the Chariotte, Columbia and Augusta Railroad for extension will expire next Thursday. Holders failing to have their bonds in by that time will be debarred from participating in the extension. Already more than two-thirds of the $2,000,000 which mature Jan. 1, 1895, have been presented for extension.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Arrangements for the removal of the body of Sir John Thompson to Portsmouth are not yet complete. There will be very few formalities in connection with the transportation of the body to Portsmouth. Applications for permission to accompany the remains to Portsmouth have been so numerous that it has been found necessary to provide a special train from Waterloo Station for the accommodation of the applicants.

Clergymen and others who engage in the discussion of the question of allowing the opening of saloons or the selling of liquor on Sunday should remember that it is a practical and not a sentimental question, and that it involves considerations of greater or less good and evil to the community and not of absolute good and evil.
From the Chicago Inter Ocean. There is no truth whatever in the alleged seventh-year rise and fall of the lakes. It is merely an old popular delusion.
We have been impressed by the enthusiastic confidence exhibited in the following remarks, which may be found in The Chicago Inter Ocean's weekly literary letter from Boston, of a recent date:

Col. Michael C. Murphy, the Treasurer of the Board of Excise, was indignant yesterday at the statements in a Sunday newspaper charging that the expenses of the board were excessive; that $90,000 a year was expended by the Commissioners for political purposes, and that there were no safeguards about the funds handled by the board.

-- Joseph L. Shipley died at Springfield, Mass., yesterday. Mr. Shipley was born at Londonderry, N.H., in 1836, and was graduated from Yale in 1861. From 1863 to 1866 he was connected with The Springfield Republican. Then he joined the staff of The Boston Journal and remained until 1872, when he returned to Springfield as a subeditor of The Springfield Union.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The dispatch to the Central News from Tien-Tsin says that the foreign sailors and marines who were summoned to Pekin to protect the legations of their respective countries were refused the right to travel through Chinese territory by the Government authorities. The foreign Ministers combined to protect their legations, whereupon the Emperor issued a new order and appointed officers and soldiers to afford the necessary protection to the legations.

Michael J. Dady, one of John T. McKane's intimate friends, and one of the favored few contractors who were given jobs in the old town of Gravesend, applied by counsel, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, before Justice Cullen, yesterday, for a mandamus to compel Supervisor Bennett, who succeeded McKane, to issue bonds for the purpose of meeting the expenses of opening and grading Neptune Avenue.

-- A remarkable collection of beautiful Chinese antique art, consisting of old cloisonne enamels, handsome porcelains, and rare hard-stone ornaments and curios, will be offered for sale at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries, 366 Fifth Avenue, Dec. 20, 21, and 22. The collection has recently arrived from Pekin, Shanghai, and Tien-Tsin, and is now on free exhibition at the art galleries.

ROME, Dec. 17. -- The Marquis di Rudini, formerly Premier, has written a letter to his electors, in which he accuses Premier Crispi of having purposely avoided a debate in the Chamber of Deputies by forcing a prorogation. The Chamber, in view of the new elections and the dissensions among the Deputies, he says, was not concerned in the political, but the moral, situation.

Richard Wagner, the boy who was arrested on Saturday for stealing from a Broadway retail house, and who told a pathetic story about being eager to make a Christmas present to his mother, appears to be a prevaricator of considerable skill. Developments in his case yesterday show that he is entitled to no sympathy whatever.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- A dispatch to The Star, dated Apia, Samoa, Dec. 8, confirms the report that Robert Louis Stevenson, the novelist, died suddenly a few days ago from apoplexy. His body was buried on the summit of Paa Mountain, 1,300 feet high.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 1 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Ambassador Bayard, in a letter to the Secretary of State, repeats a warning frequently given before by the American Ministers in London, but which will probably continue to be disregarded by credulous dupes, as to the existence of vast unclaimed fortunes in England awaiting American heirs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Now that the Carlisle Currency bill has been reported, it is not at all certain that it will pass the House. If the Committee on Rules could be assured that the bill would go through without delay or serious opposition, that committee probably would report an order of business limiting debate on the bill, so that it could be sent to the Senate before the holiday recess.
Police Justice Divver was called to answer yesterday before the full bench of the Court of Common Pleas the charges prepared by Lawyer William H. Hale of Brooklyn.

Another series -- the third -- of living pictures was put on view at Koster Bial's last evening. As a whole, it is quite equal to its predecessors, there or elsewhere, and half a dozen of the new groups are perhaps the best things in this particular line New-York has ever seen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- In the House to-day Mr. Springer (Dem., Ill.,) reported from the Committee on Banking and Currency the Carlisle bill, and gave notice that he would ask the House to begin general debate upon it to-morrow. The bill was accompanied by the views of the majority, prepared by Mr. Springer, and of the minority, prepared by Mr. Walker, (Rep., Mass.)
Mayor-elect Strong's certificate of election declares that he has been "duly elected for the term of two years."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- There has been another change in the command of the Atlanta. Capt. Kane, who had been in command of the Miantonomoh, was ordered two or three days ago to relieve Capt. Bartlett on board the Atlanta, and to the latter officer was granted a sick leave.

-Robert J., 2:01 1/2, was the largest money winner among harness horses on the turf this year, yet his total winnings were but $29,875, a small sum compared with what the best of thoroughbreds win. Benzetta, 2:12 3/4, was the largest winner among the trotters, with $22,880 to her credit. The only other harness horse that won upward of $20,000 was Mary Best, who has $21,050 to her credit.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- When the boxes containing the ballots cast in the special Mayoralty election a year ago were examined to-day by the Election Commissioners during the transfer of the office of Chief Clerk of the board, it wag found that the seals of a large number of boxes had been severed with a knife.

Of the contests in the fifteen districts in Brooklyn growing out of the recent primaries, to consider which the committee appointed by Chairman Bell of the Democratic General Committee met in the Thomas Jefferson Building last night, six were in the Tenth Ward. Alderman John J. McGarry is the leader of that ward, and he desires to retain his leadership.

-- Fourteenth Street Theatre. -- Linda da Costa, the original Queen Titania of "The Brownies," resumed her part in the fairy spectacle at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last night, singing a new song composed by Malcolm Douglas, and a new duet with Alice Johnson, the Prince Florimel of the cast.

Edward Fournil and Thomas J. Gallagher began a match game of balk-line billiards at Maurice Daly's billiard academy last evening for a purse of $500. Fournil is to play 3,000 points to Gallagher's 1,500, the former playing 500 points a night to Gallagher's 250.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Dec. 17. -- Edward Margolies was a candidate for member of Assembly in the Fourth Assembly District of New-York City on the independent county ticket at the last election. Being defeated, he retired from politics and came to this village. He opened a hotel near the station, and has since surprised the community by his philanthropy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A board has been ordered to inspect the Castine at New-York, preparatory to sending her on a three years' cruise in the South Atlantic.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- The local market to-day was dull, with a declining tendency. The traction stocks led in point of weakness. Philadelphia sold down to 100, Electric to 89 1/2, and People's to 54. These are the lowest prices seen for the stocks for over sixty days. Metropolitan held fairly strong around 106@106 1/4, until the close, when it declined to 105 5/8.

The new-elected Executive Committee of the Driving Club of New-York held its first meeting last night at the Hotel Metropole, and after electing officers for the ensuing year decided to hold a high-class trotting meeting at Fleetwood Park in 1895, notwithstanding the anti-betting amendment to the State Constitution.

Certain Republican Aldermen of Brooklyn are opposed to Mayor Schieren's excise policy. When it became known that he favored an increase in the price of licenses these Aldermen arose and said the Mayor was foolish, and that if he expected to be renominated he had better change his position.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Austen H. Mc-Gregor closed his clothing store, at 850 Broad Street, about 11 o'clock Saturday night, and, with his partner, started away from the store. A buggy drew up in front of the store, and a stout little man, the only occupant of the vehicle, called Mr. McGregor to him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Senator Hawley to-day introduced a bill for the reorganization of the army. It is a bill prepared to meet the recommendations of Secretary Lamont in his annual report, and was published in full by The New-York Times last Friday.

Judge Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, handed down his decision in the celebrated Daniel B. Fayerweather will case, awarding the millions in contest to the twenty colleges originally named in Mr. Fayerweather's will.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Although considerable cold water was thrown upon the Nicaragua Canal bill to-day in the Senate, the friends of the measure believe that it will receive the indorsement of that body. Some of them think it will reach a vote before the holiday recess.
Samuel C. Seely yesterday pleaded guilty, in the United States Circuit Court, to abstracting the funds of the National Shoe and Leather Bank, and making false entries in the books.

The third round in the New-Jersey Whist League was finished last week, resulting in victories for the Montclair, Plainfield, and Fanwood Clubs. Some of the games were very closely contests. The Fanwood and Elizabeth Clubs had a particularly exciting match, the Fanwoods finally winning by the narrow margin of four points, or two tricks.
The cornerstone of the new armory of the Ninth Regiment of the State National Guard was laid by Mayor Gilroy yesterday morning in West Fourteenth Street, just west of the Fourteenth Street Theatre.

William Collier brought to the city last night "A Back Number," written for him by Edward E. Kidder, and produced it at the Harlem Opera House. He has a snug company, and since his own powers of entertainment have never been better, a brisk, moving play would have been well treated at his hands.

"What right has the 'average young woman' to 'go to a home of her own with a few practical ideas' on this subject, [food,] and 'dyspepsia waiting in the shadow of her table? And, still worse, to inveigle into it an innocent young man, who supposes that domestic accomplishments come to all women by nature?"

-- Rose Coghlan as Lady Gay Spanker. -- Rose Coghlan will give the first performance of "London Assurance" at the Star Theatre since 1880 on Thursday evening of this week. The last performance was given on May 31 of that year for the benefit of the late W.R. Floyd. In the cast at that time were John Gilbert, John T. Raymond, Frederic Robinson, Henry Edwards, Maurice Barrymore, Stella Boniface, and Rose Coghlan.

George A. Reid, indicted for sending an annoying letter to George Cox, Jr., of Cox Callender, brokers, pleaded guilty before Judge Cowing, in Part III. of General Sessions, yesterday. Immediate sentence was asked for.

The action for slander brought by "Dave" Gideon against Philip H. Dwyer came up on demurrer before Judge Barrett in the Supreme Court yesterday. The demurrer states that the words used do not constitute a slander and are not actionable in law.

Henry Thomas, Jr., who was arrested by Secret Service agents last week at Suffern, N.Y., was arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday afternoon on the charge of making and passing counterfeit money.
A meeting of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association was held yesterday afternoon at St. Luke's Hospital. The President, George Macculloch Miller, occupied the chair.
Aldace F. Walker, one of the receivers of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, who is now in Topeka, Kan., issued the following statement yesterday:
The Nominating Committee of the Republican Club last night posted its ticket of candidates for offices for the next year.
Thirty Republican conventions, one in each Assembly District, were held last night in this city to elect members of the new County Committee.

LONDON, Dec. I8. -- It is understood that the agreement between England and Russia in regard to the war in the East does not permit any warlike operations in the vicinity of or approaches to Shanghai. This includes prohibhition of a hostile fleet passing up either the northern or southern entrance to the Yang-tse-Kiang River.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- Argument was heard to-day in the United States Circuit Court, Judges Dallas and Butler presiding, upon the exceptions of Isaac L. Rice to the report of Special Master Crawford on the petition against the receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- The market for the elevated securities broke badly to-day. Lake Street stock, which has been rather weak for the last few days, was the first to give way, and Alley "L," which at the opening showed an upward tendency, quickly followed. The losses in both cases amounted to about 2 points.

The police are searching for F.N. Nicholas, a confidential clerk In the employ of Oscar Frommel Brothers, produce dealers in West Washington Market. Nicholas is said to have absconded with over $1,300. He is forty-two years old, and was always considered a man of integrity and exemplary habits.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 18 -- The suggestion which has been made from several sources that the Republicans should pass a national election law just as soon as they have the President and both houses of Congress, meets with no favor In this State from the Republicans or Populists.

The decision of the House Committee on Rules not to ask the House to dispose of the Currency bill before the holiday recess is plainly a sensible one. It is true, as has been urged, that the subject has been discussed for years, and that about everything is known of it that can be known.

There is great distress among the cloakmakers on the east side, owing to the continuance of the strike. At the headquarters of the Relief Committee, 98 Clinton Street, where supplies purchased by subscriptions from labor unions are distributed to the families of the strikers, it was said yesterday that the stock is nearly exhausted, and unless money is soon raised or the strike settled the committee will have to close its doors.

Work on the interior of the Casino, which was begun last week, is progressing rapidly, but it will be impossible to complete the changes contemplated by Rudolph Aronson in time to open the house as a vaudeville theatre next Monday, as was originally designed.
The tug Eddie H. Harrison, with a canalboat in tow, was passing the Battery yesterday afternoon, when Arthur Fairbanks, a deckhand on the canalboat, tumbled overboard.

STAPLETON, S.I., Dec. 18 -- The Greek tragedy "Ion," was produced in the theatre of the German Club, at this place, to-night by the leaders of the youngor set in Staten Island society for the benefit of the building fund of Christ Church, at New-Brighton. The play has been rehearsed for two months under the direction of Edmund Russell, who played the leading role, and the production was a complete success.

Sherry's large ballroom was well filled with fashionable young folk last evening when Mrs. John T. Hall's dancing class, better known as the Tuesday Evening Class, held a meeting. A cotillion was danced.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 18 -- Much interest is taken by leading railroad attorneys in the arguments now being heard by Judge Jenkins in the suit of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company against the Chicago and Northern Pacific Railroad Company. It is part of the Northern Pacific case pertaining to the Chicago and Northern Pacific Company.

ISLIP, L.I., Dec. 18 -- Miss Lillian Patton came to Islip in September and began to teach in the district school. She had been graduated the previous June from the Oswego Normal School. She was graceful and pretty, and perhaps it was the scarcity of young men in the village that caused her to express the opinion that Islip was "too stupid for anything."

Navy officers have much to interest them in these piping days of peace. There is the proposed squadron of evolution for the testing of new signals and the practice of new manoeuvres. A board has been ordered to convene and examine a new set of steam fleet tactics compiled by Commander McCalla.

The action of the Police Commissioners in reinstating Capt. Creeden in deference to the wishes of the committee was the subject of remark by Senator Lexow and Mr. Goff. Senator Lexow said that the Commissioners' action was commendable. Capt. Creeden's confession, he said, was privileged testimony, and there was no foundation for his suspension.
Several failures in the shoe trade were announced yesterday.

-- At the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Driving Club on Monday night, George Maling stated that he and his brother, Philip, had lost $7,000 in running the clubhouse at Fleetwood Park during the last year. Philip Maling bought the clubhouse privilege for $2,250, and kept the place going until after the Grand Circuit meeting in September.

Patrick Baker, a coachman, sixty years old, of One Hundred and Seventy-third Street and Jerome Avenue, was arraigned in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday charged with having assaulted his neighbor, William H. Hoey. Baker has been in court before on complaints by other neighbors, all of whom turned out yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 18 -- William D. Washburn will probably not set in the Senate of the United States after March 4, 1895. This statement made three weeks ago would have elicited merriment among Minnesota politicians, but a change has come over the leaders, and they all now admit that Washburn has on his hands the fight of his life, with the chances decidedly against him.

All newspaper readers who are interested in yachting must have made up their minds by this time how it has come about that the likelihood of a series of races for the cup next season has been turned into an unlikelihood. Certainly the fault has not been on this side of the water.
The statement made on Saturday by Policeman Thorne, while under arrest on an indictment for perjury committed at the trial of Capt. Stephenson, has not been submitted to the Grand Jury.

Justice Truax has ideas on domestic economy. He leaves the bench in January, having been defeated for re-election by Henry R. Beekman last November. A decision which he handed down yesterday would probably have brought Judge Truax many voters from the fathers of large and growing families if it had only been filed before election day.

"The Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn has made a complete recantation. He is no longer an apostle of the doctrines for preaching which he brought on himself the ban of excommunication from the Roman Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Besides listening to Mr. Hill's speech on closure, the Senate heard to-day a long address by Mr. Turpie, the second installment of his speech against the Nicaragua Canal bill. Mr. Turpie hopes to complete his attack tomorrow.

Much interest was occasioned some time ago respecting the trials of an aluminium torpedo boat which was built by the English Yarrows for the French Government. The boat was of a phenomenal lightness and showed remarkable speed on her trial trip. It was then confidently predicted that aluminium would come into general use for the building of such vessels.

In my last letter I presented some evidence of the supreme importance of securing the control, at the earliest moment possible, of the vast powers of the Police Board, now being wielded by two Tammanyite and two Plattite Police Commissioners, and of the grave need of seeking this control by methods which will in the least degree be open to effective opposition.
There was a large attendance at the meeting of Good Government Club C last night, at its headquarters, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. George M. Cumming, the President, presided.
A fire was discovered at 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon on the third floor of the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, Sixtyeighth Street and Columbus Avenue.

The stock market has assumed a holiday character, there being little done except by professional traders, and their operations are confined to "scalping eighths." During the morning yesterday prices were inclined to heaviness. In the afternoon the bears took advantage of the absence of support and became more aggressive.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- While Lawyer Wilson Brown, Jr., was on his way home on Hamilton Avenue last evening, carrying his gripsack, he was assaulted from behind by two men. He received a heavy blow on the back of the head, and fell insensible. He was found later, and taken home.

Mr. Amund Johnsen has sold to Adolph Hoffstadt, for a friend, at $85,000, the sevenstory brick and stone business building, just being finished, at 79 Fourth Avenue, east side, between Tenth and Eleventh Streets, 24 by 101. The store and first loft of the building have already been rented.

Two candidates for the appointment of Health Officer of the Port have distanced all others, so that the race is believed to be a certainty for one of them. It is the general belief that Governor-elect Morton will select Dr. Alvah H. Doty, although the friends of Dr. Daniel Lewis think that his chances are good.

The fifth annual dinner of the Association of the Eleventh Army Corps, Army of the Potomac, which was held at Morello's last night, was attended by a number of veterans, who wore the crescent corps badge on their lapels.

Bernnard Stavenhagen, pianist, and Jean Gerardy, violoncellist, gave the first of two recitals at Carnegie Music Hall last night. The second is to be given tomorrow night, and lovers of music who don't go will miss a genuine treat. The entertainment offered by the two players last night was enjoyable throughout, except in the matter of encore numbers.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 18 -- A resolution against compulsory arbitration was adopted at the beginning of the morning session of the American Federation of Labor without discussion. A resolution to appropriate $1,000 to aid the families of strikers confined in prisons for alleged offenses was referred to the Executive Council for favorable consideration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. I8 -- Having determined that the preposterous, rules of the Senate shall not be amended in the least, the majority of that body is disposed to regard with indifference such efforts is may be made from time to time to introduce the previous question. This disposition was well illustrated to-day when Mr. Hill made his promised speech in advocacy of closure.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The United States was appellant in a case argued before the Supreme Court to-day coming from the Circuit Court for the United States for the Southern District of New-York.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13 -- The Louisville Driving and Fair Association was organized yesterday with a capital stock of $100,000. The following officers were elected: Rael Jones, President; J.J. Douglass and John Doerhoeffer, Vice Presidents, and William Porter, Secretary. The association has purchased land south of Louisville on the Grand Boulevard, and has built a fine track and stables. It is proposed to hold a six-days meeting next September.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 18 -- In the House to-day a joint resolution was offered by Mr. Magill of Abbeville extending to President Cleveland and party, who are now on a hunting expedition in this State, an invitation to visit the General Assembly and to accept the privileges of the floor of the two houses.

The Sound-Currency Committee of the Reform Club has published (52 William Street, price 5 cents,) a paraph let, entitled "Canadian Bank-Note Currency," by L. Carroll Root, in which a succinct account is given of the principal features of this latest development of a bank-note currency system.

Not since 1887, when M. Durand-Ruel gave an exhibition of the French school of impressionists at the Academy of Design, has there been seen so complete or so comprehensive a collection of the work of the greac French decorative painter, Puvis de Chavannes, as is now shown at the new Durand-Ruel Galleries, in Fifth Avenue.

Most of the time of the Sinking Fund Commission was taken up yesterday in considering requests for furniture and improvements in the new Criminal Courts Building. Recorder Smyth was present; and pointed out the necessity for some of the things asked for.

Charles H. Ferraro, thirty-eight years old, of 497 Lexington Avenue, who says he is a professor of music, employed by the Board of Education, was held in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon for stabbing the ticket chopper at the Fortyseventh Street station of the Third Avenue Elevated Railroad, Charles Wimpfheimer of 1,499 Third Avenue.

The Excelsior Cycle Club, which is composed principally of women devotees of wheeling, held its final entertainment of the year on Monday evening at its clubrooms, 1,786 Broadway. There were many members present, and a most enjoyable evening ensued. Following the musical and literary programme, which was of an unusually entertaining character, there came dancing and refreshments.

The Board of Street Openings held a special meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday to hear the complaints of property owners against the assessment of $260,000 for the purchase of property for St. John's Park.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Alexander Laird of Glenwood Avenue was stricken with diphtheria about a week ago, after three of his children had died of the disease. As the case was a serious one and as he did not improve under ordinary treatment, Dr. J.L. Porteous, his physician, sent to a private concern in New-York for some antitoxine.

The cricketers of the metropolitan district had a great time last night at the annual distribution of prizes of the Metropolitan District Cricket League, at Columbia Hall, on Lexington Avenue. The league comprises twelve clubs, and all of these were well represented at the entertainment. An appropriation was made from the treasury to provide refreshments and "a smoke," and before the regular business a smoking concert was given.

Mrs. Mamie Anderson, housekeeper of the Sea View House, Canarsie, was a complainant in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday against August Douve of 165 East Thirty-first Street, whom she charged with detaining and beating her seven-year-old boy Alfred.

Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, for mothers and children, was filled with officers of the institution and interested visitors yesterday afternoon and evening, when for the first time its doors were thrown open to the public.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18. -- The local market opened with some pressure to sell the traction stocks. Electric was the most vulnerable and broke from 89 1/2 to 85, on sales of less than thirty shares. The decline was brought about by a stop order at 88, and insiders did not support the stock until 85 was touched, at which they took all the stock offered and bid it up to 86.

It is a singular coincidence that the number of deaths in the houses and tenements of the Trinity Church Corporation increases, as a rule, in proportion to the number of sanitary complaints made against the premises to the Board of Health.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Gov. Flower has appointed J. Seaver Page of NewYork City a member of the Greater NewYork Commission to succeed the late George R. Cathcart.

NORTH BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 18 -- Nurseryman P. H. Foster, one of the bestknown residents of this section, is missing. He left town for New-York over a month ago, and has not been heard from but once or twice since.

-- A report sent out yesterday by Howard L. Perkins, Chairman of the Membership Commutes of the League of American Wheelmen, contains the following items of general interest: Byrd Moore (No. 67,195) of Des Moines, Iowa, was protested on the grounds of professionalism. The case was referred to the Racing Board, which overruled the protest.

President Clausen of the Park Board said yesterday that letters had been received by the Commissioners from landscape architects taking exception to the views of Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux regarding the Harlem River Driveway. They did not agree that the engineer should be entirely under the control of the landscape architect.
ROME, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Cashier John E. Bielby of the Central National BanK at Rome is a defaulter to the amount of at least $27,000.

The Times began in 1887 to direct attention to the scandalous manipulation of the Bell Telephone Company's Berliner application in the Patent Office, to the apparent motive of the Bell Company, and to the value to that company of a long postponement of the issue of a patent upon that application.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- The long-contested suit of the Central Transportation Company against the Pullman Palace Car Company was practically settled to-day, and a large amount of money, said to aggregate nearly $3,000,000, will in the near future be collected toy the transportation company, nearly all of the stockholders in which are Philadelphians.

Riker's Island, with its mass of ill-smelling garbage, of which the inhabitants in the annexed district complain so bitterly, should have a reputation as a health resort, according to Assistant Corporation Counsel Blandy. The island, with its choice odors, was a subject for judicial consideration yesterday.

President Luscomb of the League of American Wheelmen is confident that, with able support on all sides, the league will secure the legislation which will allow the transmission through the mails of The L.A.W. Bulletin as secondclass matter. Unless this result is obtained. The Bulletin will probably not be delivered at all, as the postage, under the existing circumstances, is excessive beyond reason, and cannot be paid except at a great loss to the organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Treasury gold reserve to-day stands $8,500,000 below the reserve limit of $100,000.000. The rapidity with which the gold has been withdrawn from the Treasury since the second bond issue of $50,000,000 on Nov. 24 has given the officials at the New-York Sub-Treasury so much work in handling and counting the money that an extra force has had to be employed and worked overtime.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made 1 1/2@2 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- In accordance with his notice, given yesterday, Mr. Springer (Dem., Ill.,) moved this morning that the House resolve itself into Committee of the Whole to consider the Currency bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The statues of Daniel Webster and Gen. Stark, presented by the State of New-Hampshire to Congress, will be unveiled at 2 o'clock on Thursday afternoon. There will be no formal presentation, as was the case a year ago when the bronze statue of Gen. Shields, the gift of Illinois, was unveiled.

-- The Dullest Week of the Year. -- This week is recognised by theatrical managers as the dullest in the year, and many of the traveling companies suspend operations and take a holiday. The stores are all open evenings, and these are more potent attractions to the women who enjoy Christmas shopping than the theatres.

The question whether or not men who are sufficiently provided with this world's goods to enable them to belong to clubs in which they may obtain spirituous and other drinks on Sundays should have an advantage over their poorer brethren whose places for refreshment and conviviality are closed on that day has long been a mooted one.

A mass meeting was held at Chickering Hall last night to protest against the recent massacre of Armenian Christians by the Kurds and Turkish troops at Sassoun, and to call upon the United States Government to take measures to suppress the civil and religious persecution of Christians by the Turkish Government.
The fishing banks steamboat Al Foster and the ferryboat Fulton of the Fulton Ferry Company were in collision yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- In the strength of Northwestern markets, where an advance of 5/8@3/4c from yesterday ruled most of the day, and In the gradually diminishing primary receipts, wheat in Chicago found important relief to-day. Within a half hour of the close Ream became a notable seller, presumably of long wheat, prices showing the maximum of the session's weakness.

--The Newark Daily Advertiser described yesterday the alleged discovery of a painting by Raphael. It had been at Perth Amboy for many years in the lumber room of the Catholic rectory. It was sold by a local auctioneeer to a painter of local fame for $12. It was bought from the latter by a New-Yorker, a picture lover, for $250.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- A step was taken by the transcontinental lines to-day which insures the formation of one or several big associations for the interests of transcontinental, trans-Missouri, and Western passenger lines. This was the settlement of the much-mooted question of Canadian Pacific differentials.
Sheriff-elect Tamsen has practically decided to reappoint five of the present Deputy Sheriffs, and they are all members of Tammany Hall.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- The murder of the two lone women, Mrs, Winslow Shearman and Mrs. Cynthia Davis, near this city, last Saturday afternoon, continues to grow in mystery. A hundred rumors or clues have been investigated and exploded by the local officers, who are more in the dark to-day than ever before.

We invite attention to the following statement, published yesterday in a letter signed by Dr. T. Mitchell Prudden, Dr. Hermann M. Biggs, Dr. William H. Park, Dr. John S. Thacher, and Dr. John W. Brannan:

From The Daily News of Yesterday. That the United Press telegraphic service is by far the best to be had is acknowledged by the papers of the Southern Associated Press after a trial which dates back only to the first of this month, but which has left almost nothing to be desired in the way of promptness and skill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Associate Justice and Mrs. Brown gave a reception tonight at their home, on Sixteenth Street. The rooms were decorated beautifully with palms and roses. The guests entered by the side entrance and went directly to the dressing rooms, on the second floor, and in this way the disagreeable feature of the incoming guests meeting those already present was avoided.

Stephen Peori, five years old, son of Michael and Theresa Peori of 330 East Thirtyfourth Street, was run over yesterday afternoon by a street car on the Thirty-fourth Street line. He received a compound fracture of the thigh bone and was removed to Bellevue Hospsital, where he is in a critical condition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The text of the order putting the Internal Revenue Bureau into the civil service was promulgated today. It reads:

Seasonable business is reported in all grades of rice, both domestic and foreign, and it is evident from the peremptory demands for immediate shipment in out-oftown orders that stocks throughout the country are light. Advices from the South note that all of the mills will close this week and remain so until the turn of the year.

The 14-inch balls line billiard match between E. Fournil and Thomas Gallagher was continued at Daly's last night. Fournil is to try and make 500 points while Gallagher scores 250 each night of the tournament. On Monday night the Frenchman won by a point, and last night he won again, but by 15 points this time.

The Brooklyn Republican Ward Committees, consisting of delegates elected at the primaries held on Dec. 13, mot last night at their ward association rooms and selected from their members representatives on the Republican General and Executive Committees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Messrs. Wright and Kernan, two of the Commissioners appointed by President Cleveland to investigate the recent labor troubles in Chicago, have, after several conferences with Congressmen Erdman, Springer, and McGann, prepared an arbitration bill which is entitled "A bill Concerning Carriers Engaged in Inter-State Commerce and their Employes," which will be introduced in the House to-morrow.

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- Judge Carpenter, in the United States Circuit Court this noon, decreed that the telephone patent, 463,569, issued Nov. 17, 1891, to Emile Berliner, be declared void and delivered up to be canceled.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 18 -- The British steamship Oakfield, Capt. Flaws, which sailed from Galveston Nov. 26 for Liverpool with a cargo of cotton, has arrived at this port with her cargo on fire.

The tailenders In the wheelmen's bowling league, the Castle Point Cyclers' team, faced the Manhattan Bicycle Club "five" in two tournament games last evening, and got one victory in championship style. It was no secret that the local team, expected to place two credit marks in its column on the record slate as a result of the meeting, but the Hobokenites were out to win, and therein the Manhattans miscalculated.

The three trotting mares, Sadie Hasson, 2:26 1/2; Alletta, 2:34 1/2, and Bianca, 2:41, which were shipped to England from this port last Saturday are bound for the breeding farm of Harry Livesey Rothersham, by whom they are owned. Mr. Livesey is one of the leading hackney breeders in England whose horses have won upward of 250 prizes within the last three years.

For their fifth annual minstrel show the members of the New-York Athletic Club broke clear away from all stage traditions last night relating to the old-fashioned minstrel circle, with, trimmings of musicians and tassels in the shape of end men. They introduced Instead a schoolroom scene.

-- Gen. E.S. Dennis died Monday at Carlyle, Ill., aged eighty-two years. Gen. Dennis was born at Newburg, N.Y., in 1812. He spent his youth on Long Island. He went to Illinois in 1836. He served two terms in the lower house and two terms in the Senate of Illinois. He was United States Marshal of the State of Kansas under President Pierce.

Ada King, the young woman who Monday afternoon, when in a rather reckless mood, jumped into a buggy standing in front of 22 East Fourteenth Street and drove the big roan horse attached to it up Fifth Avenue, making short and uncertain tacks from one side to the other, and who was arrested, was discharged in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday, the owner of the rig.

BERLIN, Dec. I8 -- The Cologne Gazette urges the powers not to place any reliance upon the promises of Turkey in regard to the situation in Armenia, as it is plain that the Sultan's Government is putting every obstacle possible in the way of the commission, until the setting in of the rigorous Armenian Winter, which may be depended upon to furnish any amount of impediment.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 18. -- The Assembly ceiling bids fair to again occupy the attention of the public mind.

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- Local stocks were generally dull, but there were one or two noteworthy exceptions. Telephone stocks were active and suffered a decline all around on account of the decision on the Berliner patent being against the company. Bell opened at 200 1/2, but on the report of the decision dropped to 191, later recovering to 194 1/2, and closing at 193 1/2, suffering a net loss of 7 points.
At a meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners yesterday afternoon, President Martin made the following announcement:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 18 -- All the Ministers of the old Cabinet are now in the city. They were met by the Hon. Mackenzie Bowell in his office to-day. The interview lasted until late in the afternoon. It is believed that a new Cabinet is well shaped by this time.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 18 -- The Monongahela Presbytery of the United Presbyterian Church met in the Fifth Church, Pittsburg, to-day, and, after an animated debate, rejected, by a vote of 38 to 10, an overture from the General Assembly that the latter body should have power over all the seminaries, instead of their being separately controlled by the different Synods, as at present.

From The New-London (Conn.) Day. The very latest is the skip-your-break-fast-and-be-healthy idea. It has been tried by more than 100 persons in this vicinity, and as a result of their experience you could not get them to eat breakfast if you were to set before them, a feast such as Lucullus was wont to enjoy or imagined he enjoyed.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19 Richard Stevens of Newark and Rutherford Coleman of Trenton, who were appointed by Justice Beastry to investigate the accounts of the Middlesex County Board of Freeholders, met to-day, and after exam

When lawyers go to law among themselves they generally make very bitter fighters. A motion made yesterday, in the Supreme Court, before Judge Andrews, to put on the short-cause calendar a suit brought by Simon Sterne, the well-known railroad lawyer, against the sureties on an undertaking to the Court of Appeals of Charles F. Beach illustrates this fact.
When Mayor Gilroy took his seat at his carved rosewood desk yesterday, the unusual groups of men clustered about the room indicated that something out of the ordinary course was going to happen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- It will be possible to pass the Nicaragua Canal bill as soon as its friends in the Senate shall have made their speeches for it. Mr. Morgan will succeed in bringing it to a vote without much more delay. Opposition thus far has been made by but one Senator -- Mr. Turpie -- whose speech began several days ago and came to an end late this afternoon.

The real estate belonging to the shoe firm of Samuel Conn Brother of Sixth Avenue and Fifteenth Street and 271 Grand Street, which failed on Tuesday, was transferred yesterday by Samuel Cohn, in whose name it was held, to Rudolph G. Salomon of Newark, N.J., for a nominal consideration.

More domestic cotton goods were sold at auction yesterday than at any preceding single sale. The goods belonged to ten mills of which Bliss, Fabyan Co. are the agents. The auctioneers were Wilmerding, Morris Mitchell, and the sale was held at their warerooms, 64 and 66 White Street. Over $2,225,000 worth of cottons were disposed of.

There were no noisemakers at the Quartette Alleys, Washington Street and Tenth Street, Hoboken, last night, during the tournament games played by the Castle Point Cyclers and Kings County Wheelmen teams. But the Brooklyn boys are convinced that there was a "hoodoo" somewhere in the building during the first game.
Fifteen members and ex-members of the Police Department who are under indictment appeared in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning to have time fixed for the trial of their cases.

We have been glad to record the fact that certain repairs are going on in the tenement houses of Trinity Church. The investigations of the Health Department, made in the course of its regular duty and much less thorough than they would be were the department better equipped, supplemented by the inquiries of the press, have guided the managers of Trinity in the right direction.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Interest on the local Stock Exchange centred in the "L" securities. The market for these was demoralized. Rumors that the Lake Street Road would default on its bonds in January started a selling movement yesterday, which was continued to-day with increased force. The stock dropped to 18 1/2 by noon, and the bonds went below 61.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- W.S. Reese of Alabama, a Populist who alleges that there were frauds in the Alabama election and that on account of them he failed to be elected a Senator from Alabama, in place of Mr. Morgan, has brought with him to Washington a certificate of election, signed by Kolb, who calls himself Governor of Alabama.

The stock market was slightly more active than on recent days, but was still very dull. Traders were inclined to take the bear side of the market, and, as a result, stocks were feverish and unsettled. Much of the uneasiness was due to the uncertainty over the currency situation in Congress and to the steady withdrawals of gold from the Sub-Treasury.

Bishop Potter's daughter, Miss Mary Brown Potter, was married at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon to William Henry Hyde, Jr., in Grace Protestant Episcopal Church. The wedding was one of the most fashionable and interesting of the season, and was attended by a large number of prominent society people.
Pierce, Wright Co.'s operations in floating fraudulent school bonds on the credit of Yankton, S.D., as reported in a dispatch to The New-York Times yesterday, do not seem to have touched this city.

"Romeo et Juliette" was performed for the third time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The audience was one of good size and of plentiful enthusiasm. The performance was in every way worthy of applause. Mme. Eames reappeared as Juliet, a part in which she made herself popular last season.

John Charlton, fifty years old, of 140 West Fifty-second Street, was assaulted, Dec. 11, at a Republican primary at 114 West Fifty-third Street. He was taken to his home, where, according to his physician, he is lying in a very critical condition, with one side paralyzed and his face badly bruised and battered.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19 -- The team of college men who live to play several games of hockey with a Canadian team during the Christmas recess have made all the arrangements for the tour, and will start for Canada Wednesday, Dec. 26.

George Hageman, fifty years old, a carpenter living at the corner of East Broadway and Lloyd Street, in the Twentyninth Ward, is a patient in the Kings County Hospital, because of an encounter with his pet watch dog.

Yachtsmen's hopes of a race for the America's Cup next year were revived yesterday by the receipt in this city of two cablegrams. One was for the Cup Committee, and was from Richard Grant, Secretary of the Royal Yacht Squadron. The other was for H. Maitland Kersey, and was from Lord Dunraven.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The body of Sir John Thompson will be accompanied on the passage of the Blenheim from Portsmouth to Halifax by Sir Charles Tupper and Senator Sanford.

Announcement was made yesterday of a plan arranged by Messrs. Scott Bowne of 415 Pearl Street, manufacturers of Scott's Emulsion of Codliver Oil, by which Mr. S.W. Bowne will take sole charge of the business in North and South America, while Mr. Alfred B. Scott will have sole charge of foreign countries controlled by the London house.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Richard S. Hopkins of 32 Franklin Street, this city, entertained about 100 of the most prominent residents of Newark at a banquet of horseflesh, at his home tonight. Dr. Hopkins is a veterinary surgeon, and the purpose of the dinner was to show the utility of horseflesh as an article of every-day diet.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- Charles H. Clark, who recently had a little difficulty in connection with the Murphy temperance crusade in Mount Vernon, which led to his arrest, was delivering a lecture in the Town Hall here last evening, when some one who apparently had a grudge against Clark placed some cayenne pepper in the heater.

The Council of the Confederated Good Government Clubs of this city has decided to petition the Legislature for an amendment of the election laws providing for the blanket ballot, and is to have a bill drafted making the desired provision. It recommends "the Massachusetts ballot," with the addition of party emblems opposite the names of candidates.

Mrs. Margaret A. Harrison, who has boarded for several years at 22 East Twentieth Street, and whose daughter, Mrs. Georglana H. Salter, wife of William T. Salter of 36 West Nineteenth Street, alleged that she was insane, was declared yesterday afternoon by a Sheriff's jury in the Supreme Court to be an incompetent person, who was, by reason of infirmity, brought on by advancing years, incapable of managing herself or her property.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 19 -- No cotton was moved on the wharves to-day, owing to a strike of white screwmen and stevedores. The trouble grows out of an attempt on the part of the ship agents to abolish the color line in the employment of labor along the river.

ROME, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- The further investigation of the defalcation of John E. Bielby, cashier of the Central National Bank of Rome, and of Samuel Gillett, the teller, discloses a total shortage of nearly $40,000, of which amount $3,000 is traced to the teller, who received the money on deposits, credited it on the depositors' pass books, but did not enter it on the books of the bank.

Thomas J. Gallagher of Chicago, who is trying to score 1,500 points at the balk-line game of billiards before Edward Fournil of Paris scores 3,000, made up his handicap last evening, and now leads the Frenchman by 38 points, the score standing Fournil, 1,462, and Gallagher, 750.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19.-The engagement is announced of Miss Annie Alien of Springfield Avenue. Irvington to Gilbert Lawrence of Cottage Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The local market was more active to-day than for some time past, but values suffered in consequence. The liquidation noted yesterday in the traction stocks continued to-day, causing a decline in People's to 52 1/8, in Metropolitan to 103 1/4, and in Philadelphia to 98.

The third general court and business meeting of the New-York State Society of Colonial Wars was held at the Waldorf last evening. The meeting commemorated the two hundred and nineteenth anniversary of the famous swamp fight in King Philip's war of 1675, when the colonists defeated their Indian foes.

The club members' pool tournament of the Kings County Wheelmen has brought to light more talent than was suspected by the projectors of the scheme. J.T. Beckwith was practically an unknown quantity, and the handicapper, when allowing him five balls in fifty, was thought to have dealt rather severely with him. Judging from the form Beckwith has shown up to his last game, he will have no trouble in winning first honors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- John G. Ames, Superintendent of Documents, Department of the Interior, has just issued to the Congress and to those libraries entitled to receive Government publications a "Comprehensive Index of Government Publications" for the years 1889-93. It is a folio of 480 pages and its value as a guide to those who seek information that has been published by the Government is very great.

The athletic work in the Twenty-third Street Young Men's Christian Association for the present season is now well under way. Basket ball, which is undoubtedly the most popular indoor game, is being played by a large number of young men. In all, there are about sixty men playing the game, and when their rival teams come together in friendly matches the contest is one worth seeing.
Perrin H. Sumner, the "great identifier," made his appearance in public again yesterday. A few years ago he won much notoriety by identifying the celebrated Getty House suicide in Yonkers.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 19. -- The Executive Committee of the G.A.R., at a meeting presided over by Commander in Chief Lawler, this morning, decided that the Twenty-ninth National Encampment would be held here during the week beginning Sept. 8. Wednesday will be the opening day.
The following is the full list of houses and tenements owned by Trinity Church. It is the same list as was published in this paper last week:
